   <TITLE>Chapter 16</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER SIXTEEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the cold gray dawn the sisters lit their lamp and read



<P>their chapter with an earnestness never felt before.&nbsp; For now



<P>the shadow of a real trouble had come, the little books were full



<P>of help and comfort, and as they dressed, they agreed to say goodbye



<P>cheerfully and hopefully, and send their mother on her anxious



<P>journey unsaddened by tears or complaints from them.&nbsp; Everything



<P>seemed very strange when they went down, so dim and still outside,



<P>so full of light and bustle within.&nbsp; Breakfast at that early hour



<P>seemed odd, and even Hannah's familiar face looked unnatural as she



<P>flew about her kitchen with her nightcap on.&nbsp; The big trunk stood



<P>ready in the hall, Mother's cloak and bonnet lay on the sofa, and



<P>Mother herself sat trying to eat, but looking so pale and worn



<P>with sleeplessness and anxiety that the girls found it very hard



<P>to keep their resolution.&nbsp; Meg's eyes kept filling in spite of



<P>herself, Jo was obliged to hide her face in the kitchen roller



<P>more than once, ant the little girls wore a grave, troubled



<P>expression, as if sorrow was a new experience to them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nobody talked much, but as the time drew very near and they



<P>sat waiting for the carriage, Mrs. March said to the girls, who



<P>were all busied about her, one folding her shawl, another smoothing



<P>out the strings of her bonnet, a third putting on her overshoes,



<P>and a forth fastening up her travelling bag...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Children, I leave you to Hannah's care and Mr. Laurence's



<P>protection.&nbsp; Hannah is faithfulness itself, and our good neighbor



<P>will guard you as if you were his own.&nbsp; I have no fears for you,



<P>yet I am anxious that you should take this trouble rightly.&nbsp; Don't



<P>grieve and fret when I am gone, or think that you can be idle and



<P>comfort yourselves by being idle and trying to forget.&nbsp; Go on with



<P>your work as usual, for work is a blessed solace.&nbsp; Hope and keep

busy,



<P>and whatever happens, remember that you never can be fatherless."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Mother."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Meg, dear, be prudent, watch over your sisters, consult



<P>Hannah, and in any perplexity, go to Mr. Laurence.&nbsp; Be patient,

Jo,



<P>don't get despondent or do rash things, write to me often, and be



<P>my brave girl, ready to help and cheer all.&nbsp; Beth, comfort yourself



<P>with your music, and be faithful to the little home duties, and You



<P>Amy, help all you can, be obedient, and keep happy safe at home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We will, Mother!&nbsp; We will!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The rattle of an approaching carriage made them all start and



<P>listen.&nbsp; That was the hard minute, but the girls stood it well.&nbsp;

No



<P>one cried, no one ran away or uttered a lamentation, though their



<P>hearts were very heavy as they sent loving messages to Father,



<P>remembering, as they spoke that it might be too late to deliver them.



<P>They kissed their mother quietly, clung about her tenderly, and



<P>tried to wave their hands cheerfully when she drove away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie and his grandfather came over to see her off, and Mr.



<P>Brooke looked so strong and sensible and kind that the girls



<P>christened him `Mr. Greatheart' on the spot.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Goodby, my darlings!&nbsp; God bless and keep us all!" whispered



<P>Mrs. March, as she kissed one dear little face after the other,



<P>and hurried into the carriage.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she rolled away, the sun came out, and looking back, she



<P>saw it shining on the group at the gate like a good omen.&nbsp; They



<P>saw it also, and smiled and waved their hands, and the last thing



<P>she beheld as she turned the corner was the four bright faces, and



<P>behind them like a bodyguard, old Mr. Laurence, faithful Hannah,



<P>and devoted Laurie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How kind everyone is to us!" she said, turning to find fresh



<P>proof of it in the respectful sympathy of the young man's face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't see how they can help it," returned Mr. Brooke,



<P>laughing so infectiously that Mrs. March could not help smiling.



<P>And so the journey began with the good omens of sunshine, smiles,



<P>and cheerful words.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I feel as if there had been an earthquake," said Jo, as their



<P>neighbors went home to breakfast, leaving them to rest and refresh



<P>themselves.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It seems as if half the house was gone," added Meg forlornly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth opened her lips to say something, but could only point to



<P>the pile of nicely mended hose which lay on Mother's table, showing



<P>that even in her last hurried moments she had thought and worked



<P>for them.&nbsp; It was a little thing, but it went straight to their



<P>hearts, and in spite of their brave resolutions, they all broke



<P>down and cried bitterly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Hannah wisely allowed them to relieve their feelings, and



<P>when the shower showed signs of clearing up, she came to the



<P>rescue, armed with a coffeepot.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, ny dear young ladies, remember what your ma said, and



<P>don't fret.&nbsp; Come and have a cup of coffee all round, and then



<P>let's fall to work and be a credit to the family."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Coffee was a treat, and Hannah showed great tact in making it



<P>that morning.&nbsp; No one could resist her persuasive nods, or the



<P>fragrant invitation issuing from the nose of the coffee pot.&nbsp; They



<P>drew up to the table, exchanged their handkerchiefs for napkins,



<P>and in ten minutes were all right again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"`Hope and keep busy', that's the motto for us, so let's see



<P>who will remember it best.&nbsp; I shall go to Aunt March, as usual.



<P>Oh, won't she lecture though!" said Jo, as she sipped with



<P>returning spirit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall go to my Kings, though I'd much rather stay at home



<P>and attend to things here," said Meg, wishing she hadn't made her



<P>eyes so red.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No need of that.&nbsp; Beth and I can keep house perfectly well,"



<P>put in Amy, with an important air.



<P>"Hannah will tell us what to do, and we'll have everything



<P>nice when you come home," added Beth, getting out her mop and dish



<P>tub without delay.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think anxiety is very interesting," observed Amy, eating



<P>sugar pensively.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The girls couldn't help laughing, and felt better for it,



<P>though Meg shook her head at the young lady who could find



<P>consolation in a sugar bowl.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The sight of the turnovers made Jo sober again, and when the



<P>two went out to their daily tasks, they looked sorrowfully back



<P>at the window where they were accustomed to see their mother's



<P>face.&nbsp; It was gone, but Beth had remembered the little household



<P>ceremony, and there she was, nodding away at them like a



<P>rosyfaced mandarin.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's so like my Beth!" said Jo, waving her hat, with a



<P>grateful face.&nbsp; "Goodbye, Meggy, I hope the Kings won't strain



<P>today.&nbsp; Don't fret about Father, dear," she added, as they parted.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I hope Aunt March won't croak.&nbsp; Your hair is becoming,



<P>and it looks very boyish and nice," returned Meg, trying not to



<P>smile at the curly head, which looked comically small on her tall



<P>sister's shoulders.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's my only comfort." And, touching her hat a` la Laurie,



<P>away went Jo, feeling like a shorn sheep on a wintry day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>News from their father comforted the girls very much, for



<P>though dangerously ill, the presence of the best and tenderest of



<P>nurses had already done him good.&nbsp; Mr. Brooke sent a bulletin every



<P>day, and as the head of the family, Meg insisted on reading the



<P>dispatches, which grew more cheerful as the week passed.&nbsp; At first,



<P>everyone was eager to write, and plump envelopes were carefully



<P>poked into the letter box by one or other of the sisters, who felt



<P>rather important with their Washington correspondence.&nbsp; As one

of



<P>these packets contained characteristic notes from the party, we will



<P>rob an imaginary mail, and read them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>My dearest Mother:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It is impossible to tell you how happy your last letter made



<P>us, for the news was so good we couldn't help laughing and crying



<P>over it.&nbsp; How very kind Mr. Brooke is, and how fortunate that Mr.



<P>Laurence's business detains him near you so long, since he is so



<P>useful to you and Father.&nbsp; The girls are all as good as gold.&nbsp;

Jo



<P>helps me with the sewing, and insists on doing all sorts of hard



<P>jobs.&nbsp; I should be afraid she might overdo, if I didn't know her



<P>`moral fit' wouldn't last long.&nbsp; Beth is as regular about her tasks



<P>as a clock, and never forgets what you told her.&nbsp; She grieves about



<P>Father, and looks sober except when she is at her little piano.&nbsp;

Amy



<P>minds me nicely, and I take great care of her.&nbsp; She does her own



<P>hair, and I am teaching her to make buttonholes and mend her stockings.



<P>She tries very hard, and I know you will be pleased with her



<P>improvement when you come.&nbsp; Mr. Laurence watches over us like a



<P>motherly old hen, as Jo says, and Laurie is very kind and neighborly.



<P>He and Jo keep us merry, for we get pretty blue sometimes, and feel



<P>like orphans, with you so far away.&nbsp; Hannah is a perfect saint.&nbsp;

She



<P>does not scold at all, and always calls me Miss Margaret, which is



<P>quite proper, you know, and treats me with respect.&nbsp; We are all



<P>well and busy, but we long, day and night, to have you back.&nbsp; Give



<P>my dearest love to Father, and believe me, ever your own...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>MEG

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This note, prettily written on scented paper, was a great



<P>contrast to the next, which was scribbled on a big sheet of thin



<P>foreign paper, ornamented with blots and all manner of flourishes



<P>and curly-tailed letters.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>My precious Marmee:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Three cheers for dear Father!&nbsp; Brooke was a trump to telegraph



<P>right off, and let us know the minute he was better.&nbsp; I rushed

up



<P>garret when the letter came, and tried to thank god for being so



<P>good to us, but I could only cry, and say, "I'm glad!&nbsp; I'm glad!"



<P>Didn't that do as well as a regular prayer?&nbsp; For I felt a great



<P>many in my heart.&nbsp; We have such funny times, and now I can enjoy



<P>them, for everyone is so desperately good, it's like living in a



<P>nest of turtledoves.&nbsp; You'd laugh to see Meg head the table and



<P>try to be motherish.&nbsp; She gets prettier every day, and I'm in love



<P>with her sometimes.&nbsp; The children are regular archangels, and I--



<P>well, I'm Jo, and never shall be anything else.&nbsp; Oh, I must tell



<P>you that I came near having a quarrel with Laurie.&nbsp; I freed my

mind



<P>about a silly little thing, and he was offended.&nbsp; I was right,

but



<P>didn't speak as I ought, and he marched home, saying he wouldn't



<P>come again till I begged pardon.&nbsp; I declared I wouldn't and got

mad.



<P>It lasted all day.&nbsp; I felt bad and wanted you very much.&nbsp;

Laurie and



<P>I are both so proud, it's hard to beg pardon.&nbsp; But I thought he'd



<P>come to it, for I was in the right.&nbsp; He didn't come, and just at



<P>night I remembered what you said when Amy fell into the river.&nbsp;

I



<P>read my little book, felt better, resolved not to let the sun set



<P>on my anger, and ran over to tell Laurie I was sorry.&nbsp; I met him



<P>at the gate, coming for the same thing.&nbsp; We both laughed, begged



<P>each other's pardon, and felt all good and comfortable again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I made a `pome' yesterday, when I was helping Hannah wash,



<P>and as Father likes my silly little things, I put it in to amuse



<P>him.&nbsp; Give him my lovingest hug that ever was, and kiss yourself



<P>a dozen times for your...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>TOPSY-TURVY JO

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A SONG FROM THE SUDS

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Queen of my tub, I merrily sing,



<P>While the white foam rises high,



<P>And sturdily wash and rinse and wring,



<P>And fasten the clothes to dry.



<P>Then out in the free fresh air they swing,



<P>Under the sunny sky.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I wish we could wash from out hearts and souls



<P>The stains of the week away,



<P>And let water and air by their magic make



<P>Ourselves as pure as they.



<P>Then on the earth there would be indeed,



<P>A glorious washing day!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Along the path of a useful life,



<P>Will heartsease ever bloom.



<P>The busy mind has no time to think



<P>Of sorrow or care or gloom.



<P>And anxious thoughts may be swept away,



<P>As we bravely wield a broom.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I am glad a task to me is given,



<P>To labor at day by day,



<P>For it brings me health and strength and hope,



<P>And I cheerfully learn to say,



<P>"Head, you may think, Heart, you may feel,



<P>But, Hand, you shall work alway!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dear Mother,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There is only room for me to send my love, and some pressed



<P>pansies from the root I have been keeping safe in the house for



<P>Father to see.&nbsp; I read every morning, try to be good all day, and



<P>sing myself to sleep with Father's tune.&nbsp; I can't sing `LAND OF



<P>THE LEAL' now, it makes me cry.&nbsp; Everyone is very kind, and we

are



<P>as happy as we can be without you.&nbsp; Amy wants the rest of the page,



<P>so I must stop.&nbsp; I didn't forget to cover the holders, and I wind



<P>the clock and air the rooms every day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Kiss dear Father on the cheek he calls mine.&nbsp; Oh, do come soon



<P>to your loving .&nbsp; ..

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>LITTLE BETH

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Ma Chere Mamma,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>We are all well I do my lessons always and never corroberate



<P>the girls--Meg says I mean contradick so I put in both words and



<P>you can take the properest.&nbsp; Meg is a great comfort to me and lets



<P>me have jelly every night at tea its so good for me Jo says because



<P>it keeps me sweet tempered.&nbsp; Laurie is not as respeckful as he

ought



<P>to be now I am almost in my teens, he calls me Chick and hurts my



<P>feelings by talking French to me very fast when I say Merci or Bon



<P>jour as Hattie King does.&nbsp; The sleeves of my blue dress were all



<P>worn out, and Meg put in new ones, but the full front came wrong



<P>and they are more blue than the dress.&nbsp; I felt bad but did not

fret



<P>I bear my troubles well but I do wish Hannah would put more starch



<P>in my aprons and have buckwheats every day.&nbsp; Can't she?&nbsp; Didn't

I



<P>make that interrigation point nice?&nbsp; Meg says my punchtuation and



<P>spelling are disgraceful and I am mortyfied but dear me I have so



<P>many things to do, I can't stop.&nbsp; Adieu, I send heaps of love to



<P>Papa.&nbsp; Your affectionate daughter .&nbsp; ..

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>AMY CURTIS MARCH

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dear Mis March,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I jes drop a line to say we git on fust rate.&nbsp; The girls is



<P>clever and fly round right smart.&nbsp; Miss Meg is going to make a



<P>proper good housekeeper.&nbsp; She hes the liking for it, and gits the



<P>hang of things surprisin quick.&nbsp; Jo doos beat all for goin ahead,



<P>but she don't stop to cal'k'late fust, and you never know where



<P>she's like to bring up.&nbsp; She done out a tub of clothes on Monday,



<P>but she starched 'em afore they was wrenched, and blued a pink



<P>calico dress till I thought I should a died a laughin.&nbsp; Beth is

the



<P>best of little creeters, and a sight of help to me, bein so



<P>forehanded and dependable.&nbsp; She tries to learn everything, and

really



<P>goes to market beyond her years, likewise keeps accounts, with my



<P>help, quite wonderful.&nbsp; We have got on very economical so fur.&nbsp;

I



<P>don't let the girls hev coffee only once a week, accordin to your



<P>wish, and keep em on plain wholesome vittles.&nbsp; Amy does well



<P>without frettin, wearin her best clothes and eatin sweet stuff.



<P>Mr. Laurie is as full of didoes as usual, and turns the house upside



<P>down frequent, but he heartens the girls, so I let em hev full



<P>swing.&nbsp; The old gentleman send heaps of things, and is rather



<P>wearin, but means wal, and it aint my place to say nothin.&nbsp; My



<P>bread is riz, so no more at this time.&nbsp; I send my duty to Mr.



<P>March, and hope he's seen the last of his Pewmonia.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Yours respectful,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Hannah Mullet

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Head Nurse of Ward No. 2,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All serene on the Rappahannock, troops in fine condition,



<P>commisary department well conducted, the Home Guard under Colonel



<P>Teddy always on duty, Commander in Chief General Laurence reviews



<P>the army daily, Quartermaster Mullet keeps order in camp, and Major



<P>Lion does picket duty at night.&nbsp; A salute of twenty-four guns was



<P>fired on reciept of good news from Washington, and a dress parade



<P>took place at headquarters.&nbsp; Commander in chief sends best wishes,



<P>in which he is heartily joined by...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>COLONEL TEDDY

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dear Madam:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The little girls are all well.&nbsp; Beth and my boy report daily.



<P>Hannah is a model servant, and guards pretty Meg like a dragon.



<P>Glad the fine weather holds.&nbsp; Pray make Brooke useful, and draw



<P>on me for funds if expenses exceed your estimate.&nbsp; Don't let your



<P>husband want anything.&nbsp; Thank God he is mending.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Your sincere friend and servant,



<P>JAMES LAURENCE



<P>

   <TITLE>Chapter 02</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER TWO</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo was the first to wake in the gray dawn of Christmas morning.



<P>No stockings hung at the fireplace, and for a moment she



<P>felt as much disappointed as she did long ago, when her little



<P>sock fell down because it was crammed so full of goodies.&nbsp; Then



<P>she remembered her mother's promise and, slipping her hand under



<P>her pillow, drew out a little crimson-covered book.&nbsp; She knew



<P>it very well, for it was that beautiful old story of the best



<P>life ever lived, and Jo felt that it was a true guidebook for



<P>any pilgrim going on a long journey.&nbsp; She woke Meg with a "Merry



<P>Christmas," and bade her see what was under her pillow.&nbsp; A green-



<P>covered book appeared, with the same picture inside, and a few



<P>words written by their mother, which made their one present very



<P>precious in their eyes.&nbsp; Presently Beth and Amy woke to rummage



<P>and find their little books also, one dove-colored, the other



<P>blue, and all sat looking at and talking about them, while the



<P>east grew rosy with the coming day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In spite of her small vanities, Margaret had a sweet and



<P>pious nature, which unconsciously influenced her sisters,



<P>especially Jo, who loved her very tenderly, and obeyed her



<P>because her advice was so gently given.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Girls," said Meg seriously, looking from the tumbled head



<P>beside her to the two little night-capped ones in the room beyond,



<P>"Mother wants us to read and love and mind these books, and we



<P>must begin at once.&nbsp; We used to be faithful about it, but since



<P>Father went away and all this war trouble unsettled us, we have



<P>neglected many things.&nbsp; You can do as you please, but I shall keep



<P>my book on the table here and read a little every morning as soon



<P>as I wake, for I know it will do me good and help me through the day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Then she opened her new book and began to read.&nbsp; Jo put her



<P>arm round her and, leaning cheek to cheek, read also, with the



<P>quiet expression so seldom seen on her restless face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How good Meg is!&nbsp; Come, Amy, let's do as they do.&nbsp; I'll



<P>help you with the hard words, and they'' explain things if we



<P>don't understand," whispered Beth, very much impressed by the



<P>pretty books and her sisters, example.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad mine is blue," said Amy.&nbsp; and then the rooms were



<P>very still while the pages were softly turned, and the winter



<P>sunshine crept in to touch the bright heads and serious faces



<P>with a Christmas greeting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where is Mother?" asked Meg, as she and Jo ran down to



<P>thank her for their gifts, half an hour later.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Goodness only knows.&nbsp; some poor creeter came a-beggin', and



<P>your ma went straight off to see what was needed.&nbsp; There never

was



<P>such a woman for givin' away vittles and drink, clothes and firin',"



<P>replied Hannah, who had lived with the family since Meg was born,



<P>and was considered by them all more as a friend than a servant.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She will be back soon, I think, so fry your cakes, and have



<P>everything ready," said Meg, looking over the presents which were



<P>collected in a basket and kept under the sofa, ready to be produced



<P>at the proper time.&nbsp; "why, where is Amy's bottle of cologne?"



<P>she added, as the little flask did not appear.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She took it out a minute ago, and went off with it to put a



<P>ribbon on it, or some such notion," replied Jo, dancing about the



<P>room to take the first stiffness off the new army slippers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How nice my handkerchiefs look, don't they?&nbsp; Hannah washed



<P>and ironed them for me, and I marked them all myself," said Beth,



<P>looking proudly at the somewhat uneven letters which had cost her



<P>such labor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bless the child!&nbsp; She's gone and put `Mother' on them instead



<P>of `M.&nbsp; March'.&nbsp; How funny!" cried Jo, taking one up.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Isn't that right?&nbsp; I thought it was better to do it so,



<P>because Meg's initials are M.M., and I don't want anyone to use



<P>these but Marmee," said Beth;, looking troubled.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's all right, dear, and a very pretty idea, quite sensible



<P>too, for no one can ever mistake now.&nbsp; It will please her very

much,



<P>I know," said Meg, with a frown for Jo and a smile for Beth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There's Mother.&nbsp; Hide the basket, quick!" cried Jo, as a door



<P>slammed and steps sounded in the hall.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy came in hastily, and looked rather abashed when she saw



<P>her sisters all waiting for her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where have you been, and what are you hiding behind you?"



<P>asked Meg, surprised to see, by her hood and cloak, that lazy Amy



<P>had been out so early.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't laugh at me, Jo!&nbsp; I didn't mean anyone should know till



<P>the time came.&nbsp; I only meant to change the little bottle for a

big



<P>one, and I gave all my money to get it, and I'm truly trying not



<P>to be selfish any more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she spoke, Amy showed the handsome flask which replaced



<P>the cheap one, and looked so earnest and humble in her little



<P>effort to forget herself that Meg hugged her on the spot, and Jo



<P>pronounced her `a trump', while Beth ran to the window, and picked



<P>her finest rose to ornament the stately bottle.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You see I felt ashamed of my present, after reading and talking



<P>about being good this morning, so I ran round the corner and changed



<P>it the minute I was up, and I'm so glad, for mine is the handsomest



<P>now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Another bang of the street door sent the basket under the sofa,



<P>and the girls to the table, eager for breakfast.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Merry Christmas, Marmee!&nbsp; Many of them!&nbsp; Thank you for our



<P>books.&nbsp; We read some, and mean to every day," they all cried in



<P>chorus.



<P>"Merry Christmas, little daughters!&nbsp; I'm glad you began at



<P>once, and hope you will keep on.&nbsp; But I want to say one word



<P>before we sit down.&nbsp; Not far away from here lies a poor woman



<P>with a little newborn baby.&nbsp; Six children are huddled into one

bed



<P>to keep from freezing, for they have no fire.&nbsp; There is nothing

to



<P>eat over there, and the oldest boy came to tell me they were



<P>suffering hunger and cold.&nbsp; My girls, will you give them your



<P>breakfast as a Christmas present?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were all unusually hungry, having waited nearly an hour,



<P>and for a minute no one spoke, only a minute, for Jo exclaimed



<P>impetuously, "I'm so glad you came before we began!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"May I go and help carry the things to the poor little children?"



<P>asked Beth eagerly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall take the cream and the muffings," added Amy, heroically



<P>giving up the article she most liked.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg was already covering the buckwheats, and piling the bread



<P>into one big plate.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought you'd do it," said Mrs. March, smiling as if satisfied.



<P>"You shall all go and help me, and when we come back we will have bread



<P>and milk for breakfast, and make it up at dinnertime."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were soon ready, and the procession set out.&nbsp; Fortunately



<P>it was early, and they went through back streets, so few people saw



<P>them, and no one laughed at the queer party.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A poor, bare, miserable room it was, with broken windows, no



<P>fire, ragged bedclothes, a sick mother, wailing baby, and a group



<P>of pale, hungry children cuddled under one old quilt, trying to



<P>keep warm.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How the big eyes stared and the blue lips smiled as the girls



<P>went in.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ach, mein Gott!&nbsp; It is good angels come to us!" said the poor



<P>woman, crying for joy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Funny angels in hoods and mittens," said Jo, and set them to



<P>laughing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In a few minutes it really did seem as if kind spirits had been



<P>at work there.&nbsp; Hannah, who had carried wood, made a fire, and



<P>stopped up the broken panes with old hats and her own cloak.&nbsp; Mrs.



<P>March gave the mother tea and gruel, and comforted her with promises



<P>of help, while she dressed the little baby as tenderly as if it had



<P>been her own.&nbsp; The girls meantime spread the table, set the children



<P>round the fire, and fed them like so many hungry birds, laughing,



<P>talking, and trying to understand the funny broken English.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Das ist gut!"&nbsp; "Die Engel-kinder!" cried the poor things as



<P>they ate and warmed their purple hands at the comfortable blaze.



<P>The girls had never been called angel children before, and



<P>thought it very agreeable, especially Jo, who had been considered



<P>a `Sancho' ever since she was born.&nbsp; That was a very happy breakfast,



<P>though they didn't get any of it.&nbsp; And when they went away,



<P>leaving comfort behind, I think there were not in all the city



<P>four merrier people than the hungry little girls who gave away



<P>their breakfasts and contented themselves with bread and milk



<P>on Christmas morning.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's loving our neighbor better than ourselves, and I



<P>like it," said Meg, as they set out their presents while their



<P>mother was upstairs collecting clothes for the poor Hummels.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Not a very splendid show, but there was a great deal of



<P>love done up in the few little bundles, and the tall vase of



<P>red roses, white chrysanthemums, and trailing vines, which



<P>stood in the middle, gave quite an elegant air to the table.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She's coming!&nbsp; Strike up, Beth!&nbsp; Open the door, Amy!&nbsp;

Three



<P>cheers for Marmee!" cried Jo, prancing about while Meg went to



<P>conduct Mother to the seat of honor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth played her gayest march, amy threw open the door, and



<P>Meg enacted escort with great dignity.&nbsp; Mrs. March was both



<P>surprised and touched, and smiled with her eyes full as she



<P>examined her presents and read the little notes which accompanied



<P>them.&nbsp; The slippers went on at once, a new handkerchief was slipped



<P>into her pocket, well scented with Amy's cologne, the rose was



<P>fastened in her bosom, and the nice gloves were pronounced a perfect



<P>fit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a good deal of laughing and kissing and explaining,



<P>in the simple, loving fashion which makes these home festivals so



<P>pleasant at the time, so sweet to remember long afterward, and



<P>then all fell to work.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The morning charities and ceremonies took so much time that



<P>the rest of the day was devoted to preparations for the evening



<P>festivities.&nbsp; Being still too young to go often to the theater,



<P>and not rich enough to afford any great outlay for private



<P>performances, the girls put their wits to work, and necessity being



<P>the mother of invention, made whatever they needed.&nbsp; Very clever



<P>were some of their productions, pasteboard guitars, antique lamps



<P>made of old-fashioned butter boats covered with silver paper,



<P>gorgeous robes of old cotton, glittering with tin spangles from



<P>a pickle factory, and armor covered with the same useful diamond



<P>shaped bits left inn sheets when the lids of preserve pots were



<P>cut out.&nbsp; The big chamber was the scene of many innocent revels.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No gentleman were admitted, so Jo played male parts to her



<P>heart's content and took immense satisfaction in a pair of russet



<P>leather boots given her by a friend, who knew a lady who knew an



<P>actor.&nbsp; These boots, an old foil, and a slashed doublet once used



<P>by an artist for some picture, were Jo's chief treasures and



<P>appeared on all occasions.&nbsp; The smallness of the company made it



<P>necessary for the two principal actors to take several parts



<P>apiece, and they certainly deserved some credit for the hard work



<P>they did in learning three or four different parts, whisking in



<P>and out of various costumes, and managing the stage besides.&nbsp; It



<P>was excellent drill for their memories, a harmless amusement, and



<P>employed many hours which otherwise would have been idle, lonely,



<P>or spent in less profitable society.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On christmas night, a dozen girls piled onto the bed which



<P>was the dress circle, and sat before the blue and yellow chintz



<P>curtains in a most flattering state of expectancy.&nbsp; There was a



<P>good deal of rustling and whispering behind the curtain, a trifle



<P>of lamp smoke, and an occasional giggle from Amy, who was apt to



<P>get hysterical in the excitement of the moment.&nbsp; Presently a bell



<P>sounded, the curtains flew apart, and the OPERATIC TRAGEDY began.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A gloomy wood," according to the one playbill, was represented



<P>by a few shrubs in pots, green baize on the floor, and a



<P>cave in the distance.&nbsp; This cave was made with a clothes horse



<P>for a roof, bureaus for walls, and in it was a small furnace in



<P>full blast, with a black pot on it and an old witch bending over



<P>it.&nbsp; The stage was dark and the glow of the furnace had a fine



<P>effect, especially as real steam issued from the kettle when the



<P>witch took off the cover.&nbsp; A moment was allowed for the first



<P>thrill to subside, then Hugo, the villain, stalked in with a



<P>clanking sword at his side, a slouching hat, black beard,



<P>mysterious cloak, and the boots.&nbsp; After pacing to and fro in much



<P>agitation, he struck his forehead, and burst out in a wild



<P>strain, singing of his hatred to Roderigo, his love for Zara,



<P>and his pleasing resolution to kill the one and win the other.



<P>The gruff tones of Hugo's voice, with an occasional shout when



<P>his feelings overcame him, were very impressive, and the audience



<P>applauded the moment he paused for breath.&nbsp; bowing with the air



<P>of one accustomed to public praise, he stole to the cavern and



<P>ordered Hagar to come forth with a commanding, "What ho, minion!



<P>I need thee!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Out came Meg, with gray horsehair hanging about her face,



<P>a red and black robe, a staff, and cabalistic signs upon her



<P>cloak.&nbsp; Hugo demanded a potion to make Zara adore him, and one



<P>destroy Roderigo.&nbsp; Hagar, in a fine dramatic melody, promised



<P>both, and proceeded to call up the spirit who would bring the



<P>love philter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Hither, hither, from thy home,



<P>Airy sprite, I bid thee come!



<P>Born of roses, fed on dew,



<P>Charms and potions canst thou brew?



<P>Bring me here, with elfin speed,



<P>The fragrant philter which I need.



<P>Make it sweet and swift and strong,



<P>Spirit, answer now my song!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A soft strain of music sounded, and then at the back of the



<P>cave appeared a little figure in cloudy white, with glittering



<P>wings, golden hair, and a garland of roses on its head.&nbsp; Waving



<P>a wand, it sang...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Hither I come,



<P>From my airy home,



<P>Afar in the silver moon.



<P>Take the magic spell,



<P>And use it well,



<P>Or its power will vanish soon!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And dropping a small, gilded bottle at the witch's feet, the



<P>spirit vanished.&nbsp; Another chant from Hagar produced another apparition,



<P>not a lovely one, for with a bang an ugly black imp appeared and,



<P>having croaked a reply, tossed a dark bottle at Hugo and disappeared



<P>with a mocking laugh.&nbsp; Having warbled his thanks and put the potions



<P>in his boots, Hugo departed, and Hagar informed the audience that



<P>as he had killed a few of her friends in times past, she had cursed



<P>him, and intends to thwart his plans, and be revenged on him.&nbsp;

Then



<P>the curtain fell, and the audience reposed and ate candy while



<P>discussing the merits of the play.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A good deal of hammering went on before the curtain rose again,



<P>but when it became evident what a masterpiece of stage carpentery



<P>had been got up, no one murmured at the delay.&nbsp; It was truly superb.



<P>A tower rose to the ceiling, halfway up appeared a window with a



<P>lamp burning in it, and behind the white curtain appeared Zara in



<P>a lovely blue and silver dress, waiting for Roderigo.&nbsp; He came

in



<P>gorgeous array, with plumed cap, red cloak, chestnut lovelocks, a



<P>guitar, and the boots, of course.&nbsp; Kneeling at the foot of the

tower,



<P>he sang a serenade in melting tones.&nbsp; Zara replied and, after a



<P>musical dialogue, consented to fly.&nbsp; Then came the grand effect

of



<P>the play.&nbsp; Roderigo produced a rope ladder, with five steps to

it,



<P>threw up one end, and invited Zara to descend.&nbsp; Timidly she crept



<P>from her lattice, put her hand on Roderigo's shoulder, and was



<P>about to leap gracfully down when "Alas!&nbsp; Alas for Zara!" she



<P>forgot her train.&nbsp; It caught in the window, the tower tottered,



<P>leaned forward, fell with a crash, and buried the unhappy lovers



<P>in the ruins.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A universal shriek arose as the russet boots waved wildly



<P>from the wreck and a golden head emerged, exclaiming, "I told you



<P>so!&nbsp; I told you so!"&nbsp; With wonderful presence of mind, Don

Pedro,



<P>the cruel sire, rushed in, dragged out his daughter, with a hasty



<P>aside...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't laugh!&nbsp; Act as if it was all right!" and, ordering



<P>Roderigo up, banished him form the kingdom with wrath and scorn.



<P>Though decidedly shaken by the fall from the tower upon him,



<P>Roderigo defied the old gentleman and refused to stir.&nbsp; This



<P>dauntless example fired Zara.&nbsp; She also defied her sire, and he



<P>ordered them both to the deepest dungeons of the castle.&nbsp; A stout



<P>little retainer came in with chains and led them away, looking very



<P>much frightened and evidently forgetting the speech he ought to



<P>have made.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Act third was the castle hall, and here Hagar appeared, having



<P>come to free the lovers and finish Hugo.&nbsp; She hears him coming

and



<P>hides, sees him put the potions into two cups of wine and bid the



<P>the timid little servant, "Bear them to the captives in their cells,



<P>and tell them I shall come anon."&nbsp; The servant takes Hugo aside

to



<P>tell him something, and Hagar changes the cups for two others which



<P>are harmless.&nbsp; Ferdinando, the `minion', carries them away, and



<P>Hagar puts back the cup which holds the poison meant for Roderigo.



<P>Hugo, getting thirsty after a long warble, drinks it, loses his wits,



<P>and after a good deal of clutching and stamping, falls flat and dies,



<P>while Hagar informs him what she has done in a song of exquisite



<P>power and melody.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was a truly thrilling scene, though some persons might



<P>have thought that the sudden tumbling down of a quantity of long red



<P>hair rather marred the effect of the villain's death.&nbsp; He was called



<P>before the curtain, and with great propriety appeared, leading Hagar,



<P>whose singing was considered more wonderful than all the rest of the



<P>performance put together.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Act fourth displayed the despairing Roderigo on the point of



<P>stabbing himself because he has been told that Zara has deserted him.



<P>Just as the dagger is at his heart, a lovely song is sung under his



<P>window, informing him that Zara is true but in danger, and he can



<P>save her if he will.&nbsp; A key is thrown in, which unlocks the door,



<P>and in a spasm of rapture he tears off his chains and rushes away



<P>to find and rescue his lady love.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Act fifth opened with a stormy scene between Zara and Don Pedro.



<P>He wishes her to go into a convent, but she won't hear of it, and



<P>after a touching appeal, is about to faint when Roderigo dashes in



<P>and demands her hand.&nbsp; Don Pedro refuses, because he is not rich.



<P>They shout and gesticulate tremendously but cannot agree, and



<P>Rodrigo is about to bear away the exhausted Zara, when the timid



<P>servant enters with a letter and a bag from Hagar, who has mysteriously



<P>disappeared.&nbsp; The latter informs the party that she bequeths



<P>untold wealth to the young pair and an awful doom to Don Pedro, if



<P>he doesn't make them happy.&nbsp; The bag is opened, and several quarts

of



<P>tin money shower down upon the stage till it is quite glorified with



<P>the glitter.&nbsp; This entirely softens the stern sire.&nbsp; He consents



<P>without a murmur, all join in a joyful chorus, and the curtain falls



<P>upon the lovers kneeling to receive Don Pedro's blessing in attitudes



<P>of the most romantic grace.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tumultuous applause followed but received an unexpected check,



<P>for the cot bed, on which the dress circle was built, suddenly shut



<P>up and extinguished the enthusiastic audience.&nbsp; Roderigo and Don



<P>Pedro flew to the rescue, and all were taken out unhurt, though many



<P>were speechless with laughter.&nbsp; the excitement had hardly subsided



<P>when Hannah appeared, with "Mrs. March's compliments, and would the



<P>ladies walk down to supper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was a surprise even to the actors, and when they saw the



<P>table, they looked at one another in rapturous amazement.&nbsp; It was



<P>like Marmee to get up a little treat for them, but anything so fine



<P>as this was unheard of since the departed days of plenty.&nbsp; There

was



<P>ice cream, actually two dishes of it, pink and white, and cake and



<P>fruit and distracting french bonbons and, in the middle of the



<P>table, four great bouquets of hot house flowers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It quite took their breath away, and they stared first at the



<P>table and then at their mother, who looked as if she enjoyed it



<P>immensely.



<P>"Is it fairies?" asked Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Santa Claus," said Beth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mother did it." And Meg smiled her sweetest, in spite of her



<P>gray beard and white eyebrows.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aunt March had a good fit and sent the supper," cried Jo, with



<P>a sudden inspiration.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"All wrong.&nbsp; Old Mr. Laurence sent it," replied Mrs. March.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The Laurence boy's grandfather! What in the world put such a



<P>thing into his head?&nbsp; We don't know him!' exclaimed Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hannah told one of his servants about your breakfast party.



<P>He is an odd old gentleman, but that pleased him.&nbsp; He knew my father



<P>years ago, and he sent me a polite note this afternoon, saying he



<P>hoped I would allow him to express his friendly feeling toward my



<P>children by sending them a few trifles in honor of the day.&nbsp; I



<P>could not refuse, and so you have a little feast at night to make



<P>up for the bread-and-milk breakfast."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That boy; put it into his head, I know he did!&nbsp; He's a capital



<P>fellow, and I wish we could get acquainted.&nbsp; He looks as if he'd



<P>like to know us but he's bashful, and Meg is so prim she won't let



<P>me speak to him when we pass," said Jo, as the plates went round,



<P>and the ice began to melt out of sight, with ohs and ahs of satisfaction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You mean the people who live in the big house next door, don't



<P>you?" asked one of the girls.&nbsp; "My mother knows old Mr. Laurence,



<P>but says he's very proud and doesn't like to mix with his neighbors.



<P>He keeps his grandson shut up, when he isn't riding or walking with



<P>his tutor, and makes him study very hard.&nbsp; We invited him to our



<P>party, but he didn't come.&nbsp; Mother says he's very nice, though

he



<P>never speaks to us girls."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Our cat ran away once, and he brought her back, and we



<P>talked over the fence, and were getting on capitally, all about



<P>cricket, and so on, when he saw Meg coming, and walked off.&nbsp; I



<P>mean to know him some day, for he needs fun, I'm sure he does,"



<P>said Jo decidedly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I like his manners, and he looks like a little gentleman, so



<P>I've no objection to your knowing him, if a proper opportunity comes.



<P>He brought the flowers himself, and I should have asked him in, if



<P>I had been sure what was going on upstairs.&nbsp; He looked so wistful



<P>as he went away, hearing the frolic and evidently having none of



<P>his own."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's a mercy you didn't , Mother!" laughed Jo, looking at



<P>her boots.&nbsp; "But we'll have another play sometime that he can



<P>see.&nbsp; Perhaps he'll help act.&nbsp; Wouldn't that be jolly?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never had such a fine bouquet before!&nbsp; How pretty it is!"



<P>And Meg examined her flowers with great interest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They are lovely.&nbsp; But Beth's roses are sweeter to me," said



<P>Mrs. March, smelling the half-dead posy in her belt.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth nestled up to her, and whispered softly, "I wish I



<P>could send my bunch to Father.&nbsp; I'm afraid he isn't having such



<P>a merry Christmas as we are."



<P>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 03</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER THREE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>"Jo!&nbsp; Jo!&nbsp; Where are you?" cried Meg at the foot of the garret

stairs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here!" answered a husky voice from above, and, running up,



<P>Meg found her sister eating apples and crying over the Heir of



<P>Redclyffe, wrapped up in a comforter on an old three-legged sofa



<P>by the sunny window.&nbsp; This was Jo's favorite refuge, and here she



<P>loved to retire with half a dozen russets and a nice book, to enjoy



<P>the quiet and the society of a pet rat who lived near by and didn't



<P>mind her a particle.&nbsp; As Meg appeared, Scrabble whisked into his



<P>hole.&nbsp; Jo shook the tears off her cheeks and waited to hear the

news.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such fun!&nbsp; Only see!&nbsp; A regular note of invitation from Mrs.



<P>Gardiner for tomorrow night!" cried Meg, waving the precious paper



<P>and then proceeding to read it with girlish delight.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"`Mrs. Gardiner would be happy to see Miss March and Miss Josephine



<P>at a little dance on New Year's Eve.' Marmee is willing we should go,



<P>now what shall we wear?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What's the use of asking that, when you know we shall wear



<P>our poplins, because we haven't got anything else?" answered Jo



<P>with her mouth full.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I only had a silk!" sighed Meg.&nbsp; "Mother says I may when



<P>I'm eighteen perhaps, but two years is an everlasting time to wait."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm sure our pops look like silk, and they are nice enough for



<P>us.&nbsp; Yours is as good as new, but I forgot the burn and the tear

in



<P>mine.&nbsp; Whatever shall I do?&nbsp; The burn shows badly, and I can't

take



<P>any out."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must sit still all you can and keep your back out of sight.



<P>The front is all right.&nbsp; I shall have a new ribbon for my hair,

and



<P>Marmee will lend me her little pearl pin, and my new slippers are



<P>lovely, and my gloves will do, though they aren't as nice as I'd like."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mine are spoiled with lemonade, and I can't get any new ones,



<P>so I shall have to go without," said Jo, who never troubled herself



<P>much about dress.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must have gloves, or I won't go," cried Meg decidedly.



<P>"Gloves are more important than anything else.&nbsp; You can't dance



<P>without them, and if you don't I should be so mortified."



<P>"Then I'll stay still.&nbsp; I don't care much for company dancing.



<P>It's no fun to go sailing round.&nbsp; I like to fly about and cut capers."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You can't ask Mother for new ones, they are so expensive, and



<P>you are so careless.&nbsp; She said when you spoiled the others that

she



<P>shouldn't get you any more this winter.&nbsp; Can't you make them do?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can hold them crumpled up in my hand, so no one will know



<P>how stained they are.&nbsp; That's all I can do.&nbsp; No!&nbsp; I'll

tell you how



<P>we can manage, each wear one good one and carry a bad one.&nbsp; Don't



<P>you see?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your hands are bigger than mine, and you will stretch my glove



<P>dreadfully," began Meg, whose gloves were a tender point with her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then I'll go without.&nbsp; I don't care what people say!" cried Jo,



<P>taking up her book.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You may have it, you may!&nbsp; Only don't stain it, and do behave



<P>nicely.&nbsp; Don't put your hands behind you, or stare, or say `Christopher



<P>Columbus!' will you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't worry about me.&nbsp; I'll be as prim ad I can and not get



<P>into any scrapes, if I can help it.&nbsp; Now go and answer your note,



<P>and let me finish this splendid story."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So Meg went away to `accept with thanks', look over her dress,



<P>and sing blithely as she did up her one real lace frill, while Jo



<P>finished her story, her four apples, and had a game of romps with



<P>Scrabble.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On New Year's Eve the parlor was deserted, for the two younger



<P>girls played dressing maids and the two elder were absorbed in the



<P>all-important business of `getting ready for the party'.&nbsp; Simple



<P>as the toilets were, there was a great deal of running up and down,



<P>laughing and talking, and at one time a strong smell of burned hair



<P>pervaded the house.&nbsp; Meg wanted a few curls about her face, and

Jo



<P>undertook to pinch the papered locks with a pair of hot tongs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ought they to smoke like that?" asked Beth from her perch



<P>on the bed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's the dampness drying," replied Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a queer smell!&nbsp; It's like burned feathers," observed Amy,



<P>smoothing her own pretty curls with a superior air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There, now I'll take off the papers and you'll see a cloud



<P>of little ringlets," said Jo, putting down the tongs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She did take off the papers, but no cloud of ringlets appeared,



<P>for the hair came with the papers, and the horrified hairdresser



<P>laid a row of little scorched bundles on the bureau before her victim.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, oh, oh! What have you done?&nbsp; I'm spoiled!&nbsp; I can't go!&nbsp;

My



<P>hair, oh, my hair!" wailed Meg, looking with despair at the uneven



<P>frizzle on her forehead.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Just my luck!&nbsp; You shouldn't have asked me to do it.&nbsp; I always



<P>spoil everything.&nbsp; I'm so sorry, but the tongs were too hot, and

so



<P>I've made a mess," groaned poor Jo, regarding the little black



<P>pancakes with tears of regret.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It isn't spoiled.&nbsp; Just frizzle it, and tie your ribbon so



<P>the ends come on your forehead a bit, and it will look like the



<P>last fashion.&nbsp; I've seen many girls do it so," said Amy consolingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Serves me right for trying to be fine.&nbsp; I wish I'd let my hair



<P>alone," cried Meg petulantly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So do I, it was so smooth and pretty.&nbsp; But it will soon grow



<P>out again," said Beth, coming to kiss and comfort the shorn sheep.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After various lesser mishaps, Meg was finished at last, and



<P>by the united exertions of the entire family Jo's hair was got up



<P>and her dress on.&nbsp; They looked very well in their simple suits,



<P>Meg's in silvery drab, with a blue velvet snood, lace frills, and



<P>the pearl pin.&nbsp; Jo in maroon, with a stiff, gentlemanly linen



<P>collar, and a white chrysanthemum or two for her only ornament.



<P>Each put on one nice light glove, and carried one soiled one, and



<P>all pronounced the effect "quite easy and fine".&nbsp; Meg's high-heeled



<P>slippers were very tight and hurt her, though she would not own it,



<P>and Jo's nineteen hairpins all seemed stuck straight into her head,



<P>which was not exactly comfortable, but, dear me, let us be elegant



<P>or die.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have a good time, dearies!" said Mrs. March, as the sisters



<P>went daintily down the walk.&nbsp; "Don't eat much supper, and come



<P>away at eleven when I send Hannah for you."&nbsp; As the gate clashed



<P>behind them, a voice cried from a window...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Girls, girls!&nbsp; Have you you both got nice pocket handkerchiefs?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, yes, spandy nice, and Meg has cologne on hers," cried Jo,



<P>adding with a laugh as they went on, "I do believe Marmee would ask



<P>that if we were all running away from an earthquake.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is one of her aristocratic tastes, and quite proper, for a



<P>real lady is always known by neat boots, gloves, and handkerchief,"



<P>replied Meg, who had a good many little `aristocratic tastes' of



<P>her own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now don't forget to keep the bad breadth out of sight, Jo.



<P>Is my sash right?&nbsp; And does my hair look very bad?" said Meg, as



<P>she turned from the glass in Mrs. Gardiner's dressing room after



<P>a prolonged prink.



<P>"I know I shall forget.&nbsp; If you see me doing anything wrong,



<P>just remind me by a wink, will you?" returned Jo, giving her



<P>collar a twitch and her head a hasty brush.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, winking isn't ladylike.&nbsp; I'll lift my eyebrows if any



<P>thing is wrong, and nod if you are all right.&nbsp; Now hold your



<P>shoulder straight, and take short steps, and don't shake hands if



<P>you are introduced to anyone.&nbsp; It isn't the thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How do you learn all the proper ways?&nbsp; I never can.&nbsp; Isn't



<P>that music gay?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Down they went, feeling a trifle timid, for they seldom went



<P>to parties, and informal as this little gathering was, it was an



<P>event to them.&nbsp; Mrs. Gardiner, a stately old lady, greeted them



<P>kindly and handed them over to the eldest of her six daughters.



<P>Meg knew Sallie and was at her ease very soon, but Jo, who didn't



<P>care much for girls or girlish gossip, stood about, with her back



<P>carefully against the wall, and felt as much out of place as a



<P>colt in a flower garden.&nbsp; Half a dozen jovial lads were talking



<P>about skates in another part of the room, and she longed to go



<P>and join them, for skating was one of the joys of her life.&nbsp; She



<P>telegraphed her wish to Meg, but the eyebrows went up so alarmingly



<P>that she dared not stir.&nbsp; No one came to talk to her, and one by



<P>one the group dwindled away till she was left alone.&nbsp; She could



<P>not roam about and amuse herself, for the burned breadth would



<P>show, so she stared at people rather forlornly till the dancing



<P>began.&nbsp; Meg was asked at once, and the tight slippers tripped



<P>about so briskly that none would have guessed the pain their



<P>wearer suffered smilingly.&nbsp; Jo saw a big red headed youth



<P>approaching her corner, and fearing he meant to engage her, she



<P>slipped into a curtained recess, intending to peep and enjoy



<P>herself in peace.&nbsp; Unfortunately, another bashful person had



<P>chosen the same refuge, for, as the curtain fell behind her,



<P>she found herself face to face with the `Laurence boy'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear me, I didn't know anyone was here!" stammered Jo,



<P>preparing to back out as speedily as she had bounced in.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But the boy laughed and said pleasantly, though he looked



<P>a little startled, "Don't mind me, stay if you like."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shan't I disturb you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a bit.&nbsp; I only came here because I don't know many



<P>people and felt rather strange at first, you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So did I.&nbsp; Don't go away, please, unless you'd rather."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The boy sat down again and looked at his pumps, till Jo



<P>said, trying to be polite and easy, "I think I've had the pleasure



<P>of seeing you before.&nbsp; You live near us, don't you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Next door."&nbsp; And he looked up and laughed outright, for Jo's



<P>prim manner was rather funny when he remembered how they had chatted



<P>about cricket when he brought the cat home.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That put Jo at her ease and she laughed too, as she said, in



<P>her heartiest way, "We did have such a good time over your nice



<P>Christmas present."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Grandpa sent it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you put it into his head, didn't you, now?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How is your cat, Miss March?" asked the boy, trying to look



<P>sober while his black eyes shone with fun.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nicely, thank you, Mr. Laurence.&nbsp; But I am not Miss March, I'm



<P>only Jo," returned the young lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm not Mr. Laurence, I'm only Laurie."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Laurie Laurence, what an odd name."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My first name is theodore, but I don't like it, for the



<P>fellows called me Dora, so I made the say Laurie instead."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hate my name, too, so sentimental!&nbsp; I wish every one would



<P>say Jo instead of Josephine.&nbsp; How did you make the boys stop calling



<P>you Dora?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thrashed `em."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't thrash Aunt March, so I suppose I shall have to bear



<P>it."&nbsp; And Jo resigned herself with a sigh.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't you like to dance, Miss Jo?" asked Laurie, looking



<P>as if he thought the name suited her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I like it well enough if there is plenty of room, and everyone



<P>is lively.&nbsp; In a place like this I'm sure to upset something,



<P>tread on people's toes, or do something dreadful, so I keep out



<P>of mischief and let Meg sail about.&nbsp; Don't you dance?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sometimes.&nbsp; You see I've been abroad a good many years, and



<P>haven't been into company enough yet to know how you do things here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Abroad!." cried Jo.&nbsp; "Oh, tell me about it!&nbsp; I love dearly

to



<P>hear people describe their travels."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie didn't seem to know where to begin, but Jo's eager



<P>questions soon set him going, and he told her how he had been at



<P>school in Vevay, where the boys never wore hats and had a fleet of



<P>boats on the lake, and for holiday fun went on walking trips about



<P>Switzerland with their teachers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't I wish I'd been there!" cried Jo.&nbsp; "Did you go to Paris?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We spent last winter there."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Can you talk French?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We were not allowed to speak anything else at Vevay."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do say some!&nbsp; I can read it, but can't pronounce."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Quel nom a cetter jeune demoiselle en les pantoulles jolis?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How nicely you do it!&nbsp; Let me see...you said, `Who is the



<P>young lady in the pretty slippers', didn't you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oui, mademoiselle."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's my sister Margaret, and you knew it was!&nbsp; Do you think



<P>she is pretty?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, she makes me think of the German girls, she looks so



<P>fresh and quiet, and dances like a lady."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo quite glowed with pleasure at this boyish praise of her



<P>sister, and stored it up to repeat to Meg.&nbsp; Both peeped and



<P>critisized and chatted till they felt like old acquaintances.&nbsp;

Laurie's



<P>bashfulness soon wore off, for Jo's gentlemanly demeanor amused and



<P>set him at his ease, and Jo was her merry self again, because her



<P>dress was forgotten and nobody lifted their eyebrows at her.&nbsp; She



<P>liked the `Laurence boy' better than ever and took several good



<P>looks at him, so that she might describe him to the girls, for they



<P>had no brothers, very few male cousins, and boys were almost unknown



<P>creatures to them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Curly black hair, brown skin, big black eyes, handsome nose,



<P>fine teeth, small hands and feet, taller than I am, very polite,



<P>for a boy, and altogether jolly.&nbsp; Wonder how old he is?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was on the tip of Jo's tongue to ask, but she checked



<P>herself in time and, with unusual tact, tried to find out in a



<P>round-about way.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I suppose you are going to college soon?&nbsp; I see you pegging



<P>away at your books, no, I mean studying hard."&nbsp; And Jo blushed



<P>at the dreadful `pegging' which had escaped her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie smiled but didn't seem shocked, and answered with a



<P>shrug.&nbsp; "Not for a year or two.&nbsp; I won't go before seventeen,



<P>anyway."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aren't you but fifteen?" asked Jo, looking at the tall lad,



<P>whom she had imagined seventeen already.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sixteen, next month."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How I wish I was going to college!&nbsp; You don't look as if



<P>you liked it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hate it!&nbsp; Nothing but grinding or skylarking.&nbsp; And I don't



<P>like the way fellows do either, in this country."



<P>"What do you like?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To live in Italy, and to enjoy myself in my own way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo wanted very much to ask what his own way was, but his



<P>black brows looked rather threatening as he knit them, so she



<P>changed the subject by saying, as her foot kept time, "That's a



<P>splendid polka!&nbsp; Why don't you go and try it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you will come too," he answered, with a gallant little bow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't, for I told meg I wouldn't, because..." There Jo



<P>stopped, and looked undecided whether to tell or to laugh.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Because, what?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You won't tell?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I have a bad trick of standing before the fire, and so



<P>I burn my frocks, and I scorched this one, and though it's nicely



<P>mended, it shows, and Meg told me to keep still so no one would



<P>see it.&nbsp; You may laugh, if you want to.&nbsp; It is funny, I know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Laurie didn't laugh.&nbsp; He only looked dawn a minute, and



<P>the expression of his face puzzled Jo when he said very gently,



<P>"Never mind that.&nbsp; I'll tell you how we can manage.&nbsp; There's

a long



<P>hall out there, and we can dance grandly, and no one will see us.



<P>Please come."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo thanked him and gladly went, wishing she had two neat gloves



<P>when she saw the nice, pearl-colored ones her partner wore.&nbsp; The



<P>hall was empty, and they had a grand polka, for Laurie danced well,



<P>and taught her the German step, which delighted Jo, being full of



<P>swing and spring.&nbsp; When the music stopped, they sat down on the



<P>stairs to get their breath, and Laurie was in the midst of an account



<P>of a students' festival at Heidelberg when Meg appeared in search of



<P>her sister.&nbsp; She beckoned, and Jo reluctantly followed her into

a



<P>side room, where she found her on a sofa, holding her foot, and



<P>looking pale.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've sprained my ankle.&nbsp; That stupid high heel turned and



<P>gave me a sad wrench.&nbsp; It aches so, I can hardly stand, and I don't



<P>know how I'm ever going to get home," she said, rocking to and fro



<P>in pain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I knew you'd hurt your feet with those silly shoes.&nbsp; I'm



<P>sorry.&nbsp; But I don't see what you can do, except get a carriage,

or



<P>stay here all night," answered Jo, softly rubbing the poor ankle as



<P>she spoke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't have a carriage without its costing ever so much.&nbsp; I



<P>dare say I can't get one at all, for most people come in their own,



<P>and it's a long way to the stable, and no one to send."



<P>"I'll go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed!&nbsp; It's past nine, and dark as Egypt.&nbsp; I can't

stop



<P>here, for the house is full.&nbsp; Sallie has some girls staying with

her.



<P>I'll rest till Hannah comes, and then do the best I can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll ask Laurie.&nbsp; He will go," said Jo," looking relieved as



<P>the idea occurred to her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mercy, no!&nbsp; Don't ask or tell anyone.&nbsp; Get me my rubbers,

and



<P>put these slippers with our things.&nbsp; I can't dance anymore, but

as



<P>soon as supper is over, watch for Hannah and tell me the minute she



<P>comes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They are going out to supper now.&nbsp; I'll stay with you.&nbsp; I'd



<P>rather."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, dear, run along, and bring me some coffee.&nbsp; I'm so tired



<P>I can't stir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So Meg reclined, with rubbers well hidden, and Jo went blundering



<P>away to the dining room, which she found after going into a



<P>china closet, and opening the door of a room where old Mr. Gardiner



<P>was taking a little private refreshment.&nbsp; Making a dart at the



<P>table, she secured the coffee, which she immediately spilled,



<P>thereby making the front of her dress as bad as the back.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, dear, what a blunderbuss I am!" exclaimed Jo, finishing



<P>Meg's glove by scrubbing her gown with it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Can I help you?" said a friendly voice.&nbsp; And there was Laurie,



<P>with a full cup in one hand and a plate of ice in the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was trying to get something for Meg, who is very tired, and



<P>someone shook me, and here I am in a nice state," answered Jo,



<P>glancing dismally from the stained skirt to the coffee-colored glove.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Too bad!&nbsp;&nbsp; I was looking for someone to give this to.&nbsp;

May I



<P>take it to your sister?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, thank you!&nbsp; I'll show you where she is.&nbsp; I don't offer

to



<P>take it myself, for I should only get into another scrape if I did."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo led the way, and as if used to waiting on ladies, Laurie



<P>drew up a little table, brought a second installment of coffee and



<P>ice for Jo, and was so obliging that even particular Meg pronounced



<P>him a `nice boy'.&nbsp; They had a merry time over the bonbons and mottoes,



<P>and were in the midst of a quiet game of BUZZ, with two or three



<P>other young people who had strayed in, when Hannah appeared.&nbsp; Meg



<P>forgot her foot and rose so quickly that she was forced to catch



<P>hold of Jo, with an exclamation of pain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hush!&nbsp; Don't say anything," she whispered, adding aloud, "It's



<P>nothing.&nbsp; I turned my foot a little, that's all," and limped upstairs



<P>to put her things on.



<P>Hannah scolded, Meg cried, and Jo was at her wits' end, till



<P>se decided to take things into her own hands.&nbsp; Slipping out, she

ran



<P>down and, finding a servant, asked if he could get her a carriage.



<P>It happened to be a hired waiter who knew nothing about the



<P>neighborhood and Jo was looking round for help when Laurie, who had



<P>heard what she said, came up and offered his grandfather's carriage,



<P>which had just come for him, he said.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's so early!&nbsp; You can't mean to go yet?" began Jo.&nbsp; looking



<P>relieved but hesitating to accept the offer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I always go early, I do, truly!&nbsp; Please let me take you home.



<P>It's all on my way, you know, and it rains, they say."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That settled it, and telling him of Meg's mishap, Jo gratefully



<P>accepted and rushed up to bring down the rest of the party.&nbsp; Hannah



<P>hated rain as much as a cat does so she made no trouble, and they



<P>rolled away in the luxurious close carriage, feeling very festive



<P>and elegant.&nbsp; Laurie went on the box so Meg could keep her foot

up,



<P>and the girls talked over their party in freedom.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had a capital time.&nbsp; Did you?' asked Jo, rumpling up her



<P>hair, and making herself comfortable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, till I hurt myself.&nbsp; Sallie's friend, Annie Moffat, took



<P>a fancy to me, and asked me to come and spend a week with her when



<P>Sallie does.&nbsp; She is going in the spring when the opera comes,

and



<P>it will be perfectly splendid, if Mother only lets me go," answered



<P>Meg, cheering up at the thought.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I saw you dancing with the red headed man I ran away from.&nbsp; Was



<P>he nice?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh.&nbsp; very!&nbsp; His hair is auburn, not red, and he was very

polite,



<P>and I had a delicious redowa with him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He looked like a grasshopper in a fit when he did the new step.



<P>Laurie and I couldn't help laughing.&nbsp; Did you hear us?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, but it was very rude.&nbsp; What were you about all that time,



<P>hidden away there?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo told her adventures, and by the time she had finished they



<P>were at home.&nbsp; With many thanks, they said good night and crept

in,



<P>hoping to disturb no one, but the instant their door creaked, two



<P>little nightcaps bobbed up, and two sleepy but eager voices cried out...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tell about the party!&nbsp; Tell about the party!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With what Meg called `a great want of manners' Jo had saved some



<P>bonbons for the little girls, and they soon subsided, after hearing



<P>the most thrilling events of the evening.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I declare, it really seems like being a fine young lady, to



<P>come home from the party in a carriage and sit in my dressing gown



<P>wit a maid to wait on me," said Meg, as Jo bound up her foot with



<P>arnica and brushed her hair.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't believe fine young ladies enjoy themselves a bit more



<P>than we do, in spite of our burned hair, old gowns, one glove apiece



<P>and tight slippers that sprain our ankles when we are silly enough



<P>to wear them," And I think Jo was quite right.



<P>
