<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER SEVENTEEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For a week the amount of virtue in the old house would have



<P>supplied the neighborhood.&nbsp; It was really amazing, for everyone



<P>seemed in a heavenly frame of mind, and self-denial was all the



<P>fashion.&nbsp; Relieved of their first anxiety about their father,



<P>girls insensibly relaxed their praiseworthy efforts a little,



<P>and began to fall back into old ways.&nbsp; They did not forget



<P>their motto, but hoping and keeping busy seemed to grow easier,



<P>and after such tremendous exertions, they felt that Endeavor



<P>deserved a holiday, and gave it a good many.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo caught a bad cold through neglect to cover the shorn



<P>head enough, and was ordered to stay at home till she was better,



<P>for Aunt March didn't like to hear people read with colds in



<P>their heads.&nbsp; Jo liked this, and after an energetic rummage from



<P>garret to cellar, subsided on the sofa to nurse her cold with



<P>arsenicum and books.&nbsp; Amy found that housework and art did not



<P>go well together, and returned to her mud pies.&nbsp; Meg went daily



<P>to her pupils, and sewed, or thought she did, at home, but much



<P>time was spent in writing long letters to her mother, or reading



<P>the Washington dispatches over and over.&nbsp; Beth kept on, with only



<P>slight relapses into idleness or grieving.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All the little duties were faithfully done each day, and



<P>many of her sisters' also, for they were forgetful, and the house



<P>seemed like a clock whose pendulum was gone a-visiting.&nbsp; When her



<P>heart got heavy with longings for Mother or fears for Father, she



<P>went away into a certain closet, hid her face in the folds of a



<P>dear old gown, and made her little moan and prayed her little



<P>prayer quietly by herself.&nbsp; Nobody knew what cheered her up after



<P>a sober fit, but everyone felt how sweet and helpful Beth was, and



<P>fell into a way of going to her for comfort or advice in their



<P>small affairs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All were unconscious that this experience was a test of



<P>character, and when the first excitement was over, felt that they



<P>had done well and deserved praise.&nbsp; So they did, but their



<P>mistake was in ceasing to do well, and they learned this lesson



<P>through much anxiety and regret.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Meg, I wish you'd go and see the Hummels.&nbsp; You know Mother



<P>told us not to forget them." said Beth, ten days after Mrs. March's



<P>departure.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm too tired to go this afternoon," re;lied Meg, rocking



<P>comfortably as she sewed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Can't you, Jo?' asked Beth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Too stormy for me with my cold."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought it was almost well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's well enough for me to go out with Laurie, but not well



<P>enough to go to the Hummels'," said Jo, laughing, but looking a



<P>little ashamed of her inconsistency.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why don't you go yourself?" asked Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have been every day, but the baby is sick, and I don't



<P>know what to do for it.&nbsp; Mrs. Hummel goes away to work, and



<P>Lottchen takes care of it.&nbsp; But it gets sicker and sicker,



<P>and I think you or Hannah ought to go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth spoke earnestly, and Meg promised she would go tomorrow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ask Hannah for some nice little mess, and take it round, Beth,



<P>the air will do you good," said Jo, adding apologetically, "I'd go



<P>but I want to finish my writing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My head aches and I'm tired, so I thought maybe some of you



<P>would go," said Beth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Amy will be in presently, and she will run down for us,



<P>suggested Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So Beth lay down on the sofa, the others returned to their work,



<P>and the Hummels were forgotten.&nbsp; An hour passed.&nbsp; Amy did

not come,



<P>Meg went to her room to try on a new dress, Jo was absorbed in her



<P>story, and Hannah was sound asleep before the kitchen fire, when



<P>Beth quietly put on her hood, filled her basket with odds and ends



<P>for the poor children, and went out into the chilly air with a heavy



<P>head and a grieved look in her patient eyes.&nbsp; It was late when

she



<P>came back, and no one saw her creep upstairs and shut herself into



<P>her mother's room.&nbsp; Half an hour after, Jo went to `Mother's closet'



<P>for something, and there found little Beth sitting on the medicine



<P>chest, looking very grave, with red eyes and a camphor bottle in



<P>her hand.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Christopher Columbus!&nbsp; What's the matter?" cried Jo, as Beth



<P>put out her hand as if to warn her off, and asked quickly, "You've



<P>had the scarlet fever, havent't you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Years ago, when Meg did.&nbsp; Why?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then I'll tell you.&nbsp; Oh, Jo, the baby's dead!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What baby?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mrs. Hummel's.&nbsp; It died in my lap before she got home," cried



<P>Beth with a sob.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My poor dear, how dreadful for you!&nbsp; I ought to have gone,"



<P>said Jo, taking her sister in her arms as she sat down in her



<P>mother's bit chair, with a remorseful face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It wasn't dreadful, Jo, only so sad!&nbsp; I saw in a minute it



<P>was sicker, but Lottchen said her mother had gone for a doctor, so



<P>I took Baby and let Lotty rest.&nbsp; It seemed asleep, but all of a



<P>sudden if gave a little cry and trembled, and then lay very still.



<P>I tried to warm its feet, and Lotty gave it some milk, but it didn't



<P>stir, and I knew it was dead."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't cry, dear!&nbsp; What did you do?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I just sat and held it softly till Mrs. Hummel came with the



<P>doctor.&nbsp; He said it was dead, and looked at Heinrich and Minna,

who



<P>have sore throats.&nbsp; `Scarlet fever, ma'am.&nbsp; Ought to have

called me



<P>before, ' he said crossly.&nbsp; Mrs. Hummel told him she was poor,

and



<P>had tried to cure baby herself, but now it was too late, and she



<P>could only ask him to help the others and trust to charity for his



<P>pay.&nbsp; He smiled then, and was kinder, but it was very sad, and

I



<P>cried with them till he turned round all of a sudden, and told me



<P>to go home and take belladonna right away, or I'd have the fever."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, you won't!" cried Jo, hugging her close, with a frightened



<P>look.&nbsp; "Oh, Beth, if you should be sick I never could forgive myself!



<P>What shall we do?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't be frightened, I guess I shan't have it badly.&nbsp; I looked



<P>in Mother's book, and saw that it begins with headache, sore throat,



<P>and queer feelings like mine, so I did take some belladonna, and I



<P>feel better," said Beth, laying her cold hands on her hot forehead



<P>and trying to look well.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If Mother was only at home!" exclaimed Jo, seizing the book,



<P>and feeling that Washington was an immense way off.&nbsp; She read a

page,



<P>looked at Beth, felt her head, peeped into her throat, and then



<P>said gravely, "You've been over the baby every day for more than a



<P>week, and among the others who are going to have it, so I'm afraid



<P>you are going to have it, Beth.&nbsp; I'll call Hannah, she knows all



<P>about sickness."



<P>"Don't let Amy come.&nbsp; She never had it, and I should hate to



<P>give it to her.&nbsp; Can't you and Meg have it over again?" asked Beth,



<P>anxiously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I guess not.&nbsp; Don't care if I do.&nbsp; Serve me right, selfish

pig,



<P>to let you go, and stay writing rubbish myself!" muttered Jo, as she



<P>went to consult Hannah.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The good soul was wide awake in a minute, and took the lead at



<P>once, assuring that there was no need to worry; every one had scarlet



<P>fever, and if rightly treated, nobody died, all of which Jo believed,



<P>and felt much relieved as they went up to call Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now I'll tell you what we'll do," said Hannah, when she had



<P>examined and questioned Beth, "we will have Dr. Bangs, just to take



<P>a look at you, dear, and see that we start right.&nbsp; Then we'll send



<P>Amy off to Aunt March's for a spell, to keep her out of harm's way,



<P>and one of you girls can stay at home and amuse Beth for a day or two."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall stay, of course, I'm oldest," began Meg, looking anxious



<P>and self-reproachful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall, because it's my fault she is sick.&nbsp; I told Mother I'd



<P>do the errands, and I haven't," said Jo decidedly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Which will you have, Beth?&nbsp; There ain't no need of but one,"



<P>aid Hannah.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo, please." And Beth leaned her head against her sister with



<P>a contented look, which effectually settled that point.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll go and tell Amy," said Meg, feeling a little hurt, yet



<P>rather relieved on the whole, for she did not like nursing, and Jo



<P>did.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy rebelled outright, and passionately declared that she had



<P>rather have the fever than go to Aunt March.&nbsp; Meg reasoned, pleaded,



<P>and commanded, all in vain.&nbsp; Amy protested that she would not go,



<P>and Meg left her in despair to ask Hannah what should be done.&nbsp;

Before



<P>she came back, Laurie walked into the parlor to find Amy sobbing, with



<P>her head in the sofa cushions.&nbsp; She told her story, expecting to

be



<P>consoled, but Laurie only put his hands in his pockets and walked



<P>about the room, whistling softly, as he knit his brows in deep



<P>thought.&nbsp; Presently he sat down beside her, and said, in his most



<P>wheedlesome tone, "Now be a sensible little woman, and do as they say.



<P>No, don't cry, but hear what a jolly plan I've got.&nbsp; You go to

Aunt



<P>March's, and I'll come and take you out every day, driving or walking,



<P>and we'll have capital times.&nbsp; Won't that be better than moping

here?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't wish to be sent off as if I was in the way," began Amy,



<P>in an injured voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bless your heart, child, it's to keep you well.&nbsp; You don't



<P>want to be sick, do you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I'm sure I don't, but I dare say I shall be, for I've been



<P>with Beth all the time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's the very reason you ought to go away at once, so that



<P>you may escape it.&nbsp; Change of air and care will keep you well,

I



<P>dare say, or if it does not entirely, you will have the fever more



<P>lightly.&nbsp; I advise you to be off as soon as you can, for scarlet

fever



<P>is no joke, miss."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But it's dull at Aunt March's, and she is so cross," said Amy,



<P>looking rather frightened.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It won't be dull with me popping; in every day to tell you how



<P>Beth is, and take you out gallivanting.&nbsp; The old lady likes me,

and



<P>I'll be as sweet as possible to her, so she won't peck at us,



<P>whatever we do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Will you take me out in the trotting wagon with Puck?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"On my honor as a gentleman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And come every single day?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"See if I don't/"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And bring me back the minute Beth is well?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The identical minute."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And go to the theater, truly?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A dozen theaters, if we may."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well--I guess I will," said Amy slowly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good girl!&nbsp; Call Meg, and tell her you'll give in," said



<P>Laurie, with an approving pat, which annoyed Amy more than the



<P>`giving in'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg and Jo came running down to behold the miracle which had



<P>been wrought, and Amy, feeling very precious and self-sacrificing,



<P>promised to go, if the doctor said Beth was going to be ill.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How is the little dear?" asked Laurie, for Beth was his



<P>especial pet, and he felt more anxious about her than he liked to



<P>show.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She is lying down on Mother's bed, and feels better.&nbsp; The



<P>baby's death troubled her, but I dare say she has only got cold.



<P>Hannah says she thinks so, but she looks worried, and that makes me



<P>fidgety," answered Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a trying world it is!" said Jo, rumpling up her hair in



<P>a fretful way.&nbsp; "No sooner do we get out of one trouble than down



<P>comes another.&nbsp; There doesn't seem to be anything to hold on to



<P>when Mother's gone, so I'm all at sea."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, don't make a porcupine of yourself, it isn't becoming.



<P>Settle your wig, Jo, and tell me if I shall telegraph to your mother,



<P>or do anything?" asked Laurie, who never had been reconciled to the



<P>loss of his friend's one beauty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is what troubles me," said Meg.&nbsp; "I think we ought to tell



<P>her if Beth is really ill, but Hannah says we mustn't, for Mother



<P>can't leave Father, and it will only make them anxious.&nbsp; Beth won't



<P>be sick long, and Hannah knows just what to do, and Mother said we



<P>were to mind her, so I suppose we must, but it doesn't seem quite



<P>right to me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hum, well, I can't say.&nbsp; Suppose you ask Grandfather after



<P>the doctor has been."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We will.&nbsp; Jo, go and get Dr. Bangs at once," commanded Meg.



<P>"We can't decide anything till he has been."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Stay where you are, Jo.&nbsp; I'm errand boy to this establishment,"



<P>said Laurie, taking up his cap.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm afraid you are busy," began Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I've done my lessons for the day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you study in vacation time?" asked Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I follow the good example my neighbors set me," was Laurie's



<P>answer, as he swung himself out of the room.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have great hopes for my boy," observed Jo, watching him



<P>fly over the fence with an approving smile.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He does very well, for a boy," was Meg's somewhat ungracious



<P>answer, for the subject did not interest her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dr. Bangs came, said Beth had symptoms of the fever, but he thought



<P>she would have it lightly, though he looked sober over the Hummel story.



<P>Amy was ordered off at once, and provided with something to ward



<P>off danger, she departed in great state, with Jo and Laurie as escort.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Aunt March received them with her usual hospitality.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What do you want now?" she asked, looking sharply over her



<P>spectacles, while the parrot, sitting on the back of her chair,



<P>called out...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Go away.&nbsp; No boys allowed here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie retired to the window, and Jo told her story.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No more than I expected, if you are allowed to go poking



<P>about among poor folks.&nbsp; Amy can stay and make herself useful



<P>if she isn't sick, which I've no doubt she will be, looks like



<P>it now.&nbsp; Don't cry, child, it worries me to hear people sniff."



<P>Amy was on the point of crying, but Laurie slyly pulled the



<P>parrot's tail, which caused Polly to utter an astonished croak and



<P>call out, "Bless my boots!" in such a funny way, that she laughed



<P>instead.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What do you hear from your mother?" asked the old lady



<P>gruffly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Father is much better," replied Jo, trying to keep sober.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, is her?&nbsp; Well, that won't last long, I fancy.&nbsp; March



<P>never had any stamina," was the cheerful reply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ha, ha!&nbsp; Never say die, take a pinch of snuff, goodbye, goodbye!"



<P>squalled Polly, dancing on her perch, and clawing at the old



<P>lady's cap as Laurie tweaked him in the rear.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hold your tongue, you disrespectful old bird!&nbsp; And, Jo, you'd



<P>better go at once.&nbsp; It isn't proper to be gadding about so late

with



<P>a rattlepated boy like..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hold your tongue, you disrespectful old bird!" cried Polly,



<P>tumbling off the chair with a bounce, and running to peck the



<P>`rattlepated' boy, who was shaking with laughter at the last speech.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't think I can bear it, but I'll try," thought Amy, as



<P>she was left alone with Aunt March.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Get along, you fright!" screamed Polly, and at that rude speech



<P>Amy could not restrain a sniff.



<P>

<HTML>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <TITLE>Chapter 01</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<FONT SIZE=+3>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Little Women</FONT>



<P><FONT SIZE=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

by Louisa May Alcott</FONT>

<BR><FONT SIZE=+1></FONT>&nbsp;

<BR><FONT SIZE=+1></FONT>&nbsp;



<P><B><U>CHAPTER ONE</U></B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>"Christmas won't be Christmas without any presents," grumbled



<P>Jo, lying on the rug.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's so dreadful to be poor!" sighed Meg, looking down at



<P>her old dress.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't think it's fair for some girls to have plenty of



<P>pretty things, and other girls nothing at all," added little Amy,



<P>with an injured sniff.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We've got Father and Mother, and each other," said Beth



<P>contentedly from her corner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The four young faces on which the firelight shone brightened



<P>at the cheerful words, but darkened again as Jo said sadly,



<P>"We haven't got Father, and shall not have him for a long time."



<P>She didn't say "perhaps never," but each silently added it, thinking



<P>of Father far away, where the fighting was.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nobody spoke for a minute; then Meg said in an altered tone,



<P>"You know the reason Mother proposed not having any presents this



<P>Christmas was because it is going to be a hard winter for everyone;



<P>and she thinks we ought not to spend money for pleasure, when



<P>our men are suffering so in the army.&nbsp; We can't do much, but we

can



<P>make our little sacrifices, and ought to do it gladly.&nbsp; But I am



<P>afraid I don't."&nbsp; And Meg shook her head, as she thought regretfully



<P>of all the pretty things she wanted.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I don't think the little we should spend would do any



<P>good.&nbsp; We've each got a dollar, and the army wouldn't be much helped



<P>by our giving that.&nbsp; I agree not to expect anything from Mother

or



<P>you, but I do want to buy UNDINE AND SINTRAM for myself.&nbsp; I've



<P>wanted it so long," said Jo, who was a bookworm.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I planned to spend mine in new music," said Beth, with a



<P>little sigh, which no one heard but the hearth brush and kettle



<P>holder.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall get a nice box of Faber's drawing pencils.&nbsp; I



<P>really need them," said Amy decidedly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mother didn't say anything about our money, and she won't



<P>wish us to give up everything.&nbsp; Let's each buy what we want, and



<P>have a little fun.&nbsp; I'm sure we work hard enough to earn it," cried



<P>Jo, examining the heels of her shoes in a gentlemanly manner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know I do--teaching those tiresome children nearly all



<P>day, when I'm longing to enjoy myself at home," began Meg, in the



<P>complaining tone again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You don't have half such a hard time as I do," said Jo.



<P>"How would you like to be shut up for hours with a nervous, fussy



<P>old lady, who keeps you trotting, is never satisfied, and worries



<P>you till you you're ready to fly out the window or cry?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's naughty to fret, but I do think washing dishes and



<P>keeping things tidy is the worst work in the world.&nbsp; It makes me



<P>cross, and my hands get so stiff, I can't practice well at all."



<P>And Beth looked at her rough hands with a sigh that any one could



<P>hear that time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't believe any of you suffer as I do," cried Amy, "for



<P>you don't have to go to school with impertinent girls, who plague



<P>you if you don't know your lessons, and laugh at your dresses, and



<P>label your father if he isn't rich, and insult you when your nose



<P>isn't nice."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you mean libel, I'd say so, and not talk about labels, as



<P>if Papa was a pickle bottle," advised Jo, laughing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know what I mean, and you needn't be statirical about it.



<P>It's proper to use good words, and improve your vocabilary,"



<P>returned Amy, with dignity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't peck at one another, children.&nbsp; Don't you wish we



<P>had the money Papa lost when we were little, Jo?&nbsp; Dear me! How



<P>happy and good we'd be, if we had no worries!" said Meg, who



<P>could remember better times.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You said the other day you thought we were a deal happier



<P>than the King children, for they were fighting and fretting all



<P>the time, in spite of their money."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So I did, Beth.&nbsp; Well, I think we are.&nbsp; For though we do



<P>have to work, we make fun of ourselves, and are a pretty jolly



<P>set, as Jo would say."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo does use such slang words!" observed Amy, with a



<P>reproving look at the long figure stretched on the rug.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo immediately sat up, put her hands in her pockets, and



<P>began to whistle.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't, Jo.&nbsp; It's so boyish!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's why I do it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I detest rude, unladylike girls!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hate affected, niminy-piminy chits!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Birds in their little nests agree," sang Beth, the



<P>peacemaker, with such a funny face that both sharp voices



<P>softened to a laugh, and the "pecking" ended for that time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Really, girls, you are both to be blamed," said Meg,



<P>beginning to lecture in her elder-sisterly fashion."You are old



<P>enough to leave off boyish tricks, and to behave better,



<P>Josephine.&nbsp; It didn't matter so much when you were a little



<P>girl, but now you are so tall, and turn up your hair, you should



<P>remember that you are a young lady."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm not!&nbsp;&nbsp; And if turning up my hair makes me one, I'll



<P>wear it in two tails till I'm twenty," cried Jo, pulling off



<P>her net, and shaking down a chestnut mane.&nbsp; "I hate to think



<P>I've got to grow up, and be Miss March, and wear long gowns,



<P>and look as prim as a China Aster!&nbsp; It's bad enough to be a



<P>girl, anyway, when I like boy's games and work and manners!&nbsp; I



<P>can't get over my disappointment in not being a boy.&nbsp; And it's



<P>worse than ever now, for I'm dying to go and fight with Papa.



<P>And I can only stay home and knit, like a poky old woman!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And Jo shook the blue army sock till the needles rattled



<P>like castanets, and her ball bounded across the room.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor Jo!&nbsp; It's too bad, but it can't be helped.&nbsp; So you



<P>must try to be contented with making your name boyish, and



<P>playing brother to us girls," said Beth, stroking the rough



<P>head with a hand that all the dish washing and dusting in the



<P>world could not make ungentle in its touch.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As for you, Amy," continued Meg, "you are altogether



<P>to particular and prim.&nbsp; Your airs are funny now, but you'll



<P>grow up an affected little goose, if you don't take care.&nbsp; I



<P>I like your nice manners and refined ways of speaking, when



<P>you don't try to be elegant.&nbsp; But your absurd words are as bad



<P>as Jo's slang."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If Jo is a tomboy and Amy a goose, what am I, please?"



<P>asked Beth, ready to share the lecture.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You're a dear, and nothing else," answered Meg warmly,



<P>and no one contradicted her, for the `Mouse' was the pet of the



<P>family.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As young readers like to know `how people look', we will



<P>take this moment to give them a little sketch of the four



<P>sisters, who sat knitting away in the twilight, while the



<P>December snow fell quietly without, and the fire crackled



<P>cheerfully within.&nbsp; It was a comfortable room, though the carpet



<P>was faded and the furniture very plain, for a good picture or



<P>two hung on the walls, books filled the recesses, chrysanthemums



<P>and Christmas roses bloomed in the windows, and a pleasant



<P>atmosphere of home peace pervaded it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Margaret, the eldest of the four, was sixteen, and very pretty,



<P>being plump and fair, with large eyes, plenty of soft brown hair, a



<P>sweet mouth, and white hands, of which she was rather vain.&nbsp; Fifteen-



<P>year-old Jo was very tall, thin, and brown, and reminded one of a



<P>colt, for she never seemed to know what to do with her long limbs,



<P>which were very much in her way.&nbsp; She had a decided mouth, a comical



<P>nose, and sharp, gray eyes, which appeared to see everything, and



<P>were by turns fierce, funny, or thoughtful.&nbsp; Her long, thick hair



<P>was her one beauty, but it was usually bundled into a net, to be



<P>out of her way.&nbsp; Round shoulders had Jo, big hands and feet,



<P>a flyaway look to her clothes, and the uncomfortable appearance of



<P>a girl who was rapidly shooting up into a woman and didn't like it.



<P>Elizabeth, or Beth, as everyone called her, was a rosy, smooth-



<P>haired, bright-eyed girl of thirteen, with a shy manner, a timid



<P>voice, and a ;peaceful expression which was seldom disturbed.&nbsp;

Her



<P>father called her `Little Miss Tranquility', and the name suited



<P>her excellently, for she seemed to live in a happy world of her



<P>own, only venturing out to meet the few whom she trusted and loved.



<P>Amy, though the youngest, was a most important person, in her own



<P>opinion at least.&nbsp; A regular snow maiden, with blue eyes, and



<P>yellow hair curling on her shoulders, pale and slender, and always



<P>carrying herself like a young lady mindful of her manners.&nbsp; What



<P>the characters of the four sisters were we will leave to be found out.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The clock struck six and, having swept up the hearth, Beth



<P>put a pair of slippers down to warm.&nbsp; Somehow the sight of the

old



<P>shoes had a good effect upon the girls, for Mother was coming, and



<P>everyone brightened to welcome her.&nbsp; Meg stopped lecturing, and



<P>lighted the lamp, Amy got out of the easy chair without being asked,



<P>and Jo forgot how tired she was as she sat up to hold the slippers



<P>nearer to the blaze.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They are quite worn out.&nbsp; Marmee must have a new pair."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought I'd get her some with my dollar," said Beth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I shall!" cried Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm the oldest," began Meg, but Jo cut in with a decided,



<P>"I'm the man of the family now Papa is away, and I shall provide



<P>the slippers, for he told me to take special care of Mother while



<P>he was gone."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll tell you what we'll do," said Beth, "let's each get her



<P>something for Christmas, land not get anything for ourselves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's like you, dear!&nbsp; What will we get?" exclaimed Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Everyone thought soberly for a minute, then Meg announced, as



<P>if the idea was suggested by the sight of her own pretty hands,



<P>"I shall give her a nice pair of gloves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Army shoes, best to be had," cried Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Some handkerchiefs, all hemmed," said Beth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll get a little bottle of cologne.&nbsp; She likes it, and it won't



<P>cost much, so I'll have some left to buy my pencils," added Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How will we give the things?" asked Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Put them on the table, and bring her in and see her open



<P>the bundles.&nbsp; Don't you remember how we used to do on our



<P>birthdays?" answered Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I used to be so frightened when it was my turn to sit in the



<P>chair with the crown on, and see you all come marching round to



<P>give the presents, with a kiss.&nbsp; I liked the things and the kisses,



<P>but it was dreadful to have you sit looking at me while I opened



<P>the bundles," said Beth, who was toasting her face and the bread



<P>for tea at the same time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let Marmee think we are getting things for ourselves, and



<P>then surprise her.&nbsp; We must go shopping tomorrow afternoon, Meg.



<P>There is so much to do about the play for Christmas night," said



<P>Jo, marching up and down, with her hands behind her back, and her



<P>nose in the air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't mean to act any more after this time.&nbsp; I'm getting



<P>too old for such things," observed Meg, who was as much a child



<P>as ever about `dressing-up' frolics.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You won't stop, I know, as long as you can trail round in a



<P>white gown with your hair down, and wear gold-paper jewelry.



<P>You are the best actress we've got, and there'll be an end



<P>of everything if you quit the boards," said Jo.&nbsp; "We ought



<P>to rehearse tonight.&nbsp; Come here, Amy, and do the fainting scene,



<P>for you are as stiff as a poker in that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't help it.&nbsp; I never saw anyone faint, and I don't choose



<P>to make myself all black and blue, tumbling flat as you do.&nbsp; If

I



<P>can go down easily, I'll drop.&nbsp; If I can't, I shall fall into a



<P>chair and be graceful.&nbsp; I don't care if Hugo does come at me with



<P>a pistol," returned Amy, who was not gifted with dramatic power,



<P>but was chosen because she was small enough to be borne out shrieking



<P>by the villain of the piece.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do it this way.&nbsp; Clasp your hands so, and stagger across the



<P>room, crying frantically, `Roderigo Save me! Save me!' and away



<P>went Jo, with a melodramatic scream which was truly thrilling.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy followed, but she poked her hands out stiffly before her,



<P>and jerked herself along as if she went by machinery, and her "Ow!"



<P>was more suggestive of pins being run into her than of fear and



<P>anguish.&nbsp; Jo gave a despairing groan, and Meg laughed outright,



<P>while Beth let her bread burn as she watched the fun with interest.



<P>"It's no use!&nbsp; Do the best you can when the time comes, and if



<P>the audience laughs, don't blame me.&nbsp; Come on, Meg."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then things went smoothly, for Don Pedro defied the world in



<P>a speech of two pages without a single break.&nbsp; Hagar, the witch,



<P>chanted an awful incantation over her kettleful of simmering toads,



<P>with weird effect.&nbsp; Roderigo rent his chains asunder manfully,

and



<P>Hugo died in agonies of remorse and arsenic, with a wild, "Ha! Ha!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's the best we've had yet," said Meg, as the dead villain



<P>sat up and rubbed his elbows.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't see how you can write and act such splendid things,



<P>Jo.&nbsp; You're a regular Shakespeare!" exclaimed Beth, who firmly



<P>believed that her sisters were gifted with wonderful genius in all



<P>things.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not quite," replied Jo modestly.&nbsp; "I do think THE WITCHES CURSE,



<P>an Operatic Tragedy is rather a nice thing, but I'd like to try



<P>McBETH, if we only had a trapdoor for Banquo.&nbsp; I always wanted

to



<P>do the killing part.&nbsp; `Is that a dagger that I see before me?"



<P>muttered Jo, rolling her eyes and clutching at the air, as she had



<P>seen a famous tragedian do.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, it's the toasting fork, with Mother's shoe on it instead



<P>of the bread.&nbsp; Beth's stage-struck!" cried Meg, and the rehearsal



<P>ended in a general burst of laughter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Glad to find you so merry, my girls," said a cheery voice at



<P>the door, and actors and audience turned to welcome a tall, motherly



<P>lady with a `can I help you' look about her which was truly delightful.



<P>She was not elegantly dressed, but a noble-looking woman, and the



<P>girls thought the gray cloak and unfashionable bonnet covered the most



<P>splendid mother in the world.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, dearies, how have you got on today?&nbsp; There was so much to



<P>do, getting the boxes ready to go tomorrow, that I didn't come home



<P>to dinner.&nbsp; Has anyone called, Beth?&nbsp; How is your cold, Meg?&nbsp;

Jo,



<P>you look tired to death.&nbsp; Come and kiss me, baby."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While making these maternal inquiries Mrs. March got her wet



<P>things off, her warm slippers on, and sitting down in the easy



<P>chair, drew Amy to her lap, preparing to enjoy the happiest hour



<P>of her busy day.&nbsp; The girls flew about, trying to make things



<P>comfortable, each in her own way.&nbsp; Meg arranged the tea table,

Jo



<P>brought wood and set chairs, dropping, over-turning, and clattering



<P>everything she touched.&nbsp; Beth trotted to and fro between parlor



<P>kitchen, quiet and busy, while Amy gave directions to everyone, as



<P>she sat with her hands folded.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As they gathered about the table, Mrs. March said, with a



<P>particularly happy face, "I've got a treat for you after supper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A quick, bright smile went round like a streak of sunshine.



<P>Beth clapped her hands, regardless of the biscuit she held,



<P>and Jo tossed up her napkin, crying, "A letter!&nbsp; A letter!&nbsp;

Three



<P>cheers for Father!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, a nice long letter.&nbsp; He is well, and thinks he shall



<P>get through the cold season better than we feared.&nbsp; He sends all



<P>sorts of loving wishes for Christmas, and an especial message



<P>to you girls," said Mrs. March, patting her pocket as if she



<P>had got a treasure there.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hurry and get done!&nbsp; Don't stop to quirk your little finger



<P>and simper over your plate, Amy," cried Jo, choking on her tea



<P>and dropping her bread, butter side down, on the carpet in her



<P>haste to get at the treat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth ate no more, but crept away to sit in her shadowy corner



<P>and brood over the delight to come, till the others were ready.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think it was so splendid in Father to go as chaplain



<P>when he was too old to be drafted, and not strong enough for



<P>a soldier," said Meg warmly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't I wish I could go as a drummer, a vivan--what's its



<P>name?&nbsp; Or a nurse, so I could be near him and help him," exclaimed



<P>Jo, with a groan.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It must be very disagreeable to sleep in a tent, and eat



<P>all sorts of bad-tasting things, and drink out of a tin mug,"



<P>sighed Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When will he come home, Marmee?&nbsp; asked Beth, with a little



<P>quiver in her voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not for many months, dear, unless he is sick.&nbsp; He will stay



<P>and do his work faithfully as long as he can, and we won't ask



<P>for him back a minute sooner than he can be spared.&nbsp; Now come and



<P>hear the letter."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They all drew to the fire, Mother in the big chair with Beth



<P>at her feet, Meg and Amy perched on either arm of the chair, and



<P>Jo leaning on the back, where no one would see any sign of emotion



<P>if the letter should happen to be touching.&nbsp; Very few letters were



<P>written in those hard times that were not touching, especially



<P>those which fathers sent home.&nbsp; In this one little was said of

the



<P>hardships endured, the dangers faced, or the homesickness conquered.



<P>It was a cheerful, hopeful letter, full of lively descriptions



<P>of camp life, marches, and military news, and only at the end



<P>did the writer's heart over-flow with fatherly love and longing



<P>for the little girls at home.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Give them all of my dear love and a kiss.&nbsp; Tell them I think



<P>of them by day, pray for them by night, and find my best comfort



<P>in their affection at all times.&nbsp; A year seems very long to wait



<P>before I see them, but remind them that while we wait we may all



<P>work, so that these hard days need not be wasted.&nbsp; I know they

will



<P>remember all I said to them, that they will be loving children to



<P>you, will do their duty faithfully, fight their bosom enemies bravely,



<P>and conquer themselves so beautifully that when I come back to them



<P>I may be fonder and prouder than ever of my little women."



<P>Everybody sniffed when they came to that part.&nbsp; Jo wasn't



<P>ashamed of the great tear that dropped off the end of her nose, and



<P>Amy never minded the rumpling of her curls as she hid her face on



<P>her mother's shoulder and sobbed out, "I am a selfish girl!&nbsp; But



<P>I'll truly try to be better, so he mayn't be disappointed in me



<P>by-and-by."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>We all will," cried Meg.&nbsp; "I think too much of my looks and



<P>hate to work, but won't any more, if I can help it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll try and be what he loves to call me, `a little woman'



<P>and not be rough and wild, but do my duty here instead of wanting



<P>to be somewhere else," said Jo, thinking that keeping her temper



<P>at home was a much harder task than facing a rebel or two down South.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth said nothing, but wiped away her tears with the blue army



<P>sock and began to knit with all her might, losing no time in doing



<P>the duty that lay nearest her, while she resolved in her quiet



<P>little soul to be all that Father hoped to find her when the year



<P>brought round the happy coming home.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March broke the silence that followed Jo's words, by



<P>saying in her cheery voice, "Do you remember how you used to play



<P>Pilgrims Progress when you were little things?&nbsp; Nothing delighted



<P>you more than to have me tie my piece bags on your backs for burdens,



<P>give you hats and sticks and rolls of paper, and let you travel



<P>through the house from the cellar, which was the City of Destruction,



<P>up, up, to the housetop, where you had all the lovely things you



<P>could collect to make a Celestial City."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What fun it was, especially going by the lions, fighting



<P>Apollyon, and passing through the valley where the hob-goblins



<P>were," said Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I liked the place where the bundles fell off and tumbled



<P>downstairs," said Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't remember much about it, except that I was afraid of



<P>the cellar and the dark entry, and always liked the cake and milk



<P>we had up at the top.&nbsp; If I wasn't too old for such things, I'd



<P>rather like to play it over again," said Amy, who began to talk



<P>of renouncing childish things at the mature age of twelve.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We never are too old for this, my dear, because it is a play



<P>we are playing all the time in one way or another.&nbsp; Out burdens

are



<P>here, our road is before us, and the longing for goodness and



<P>happiness is the guide that leads us through many troubles and



<P>mistakes to the peace which is a true Celestial City.&nbsp; Now, my

little



<P>pilgrims, suppose you begin again, not in play, but in earnest,



<P>and see how far on you can get before Father comes home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Really, Mother?&nbsp; Where are our bundles?" asked Amy, who was



<P>a very literal young lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Each of you told what your burden was just now, except Beth.



<P>I rather think she hasn't got any," said her mother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I have.&nbsp; Mine is dishes and dusters, and envying girls



<P>with nice pianos, and being afraid of people."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth's bundle was such a funny one that everybody wanted to



<P>laugh, but nobody did, for it would have hurt her feelings very



<P>much.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let us do it," said Meg thoughtfully.&nbsp; "It is only another



<P>name for trying to be good, and the story may help us, for though



<P>we do want to be good, it's hard work and we forget, and don't do



<P>our best."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We were in the Slough of Despond tonight, and Mother came



<P>and pulled us out as Help did in the book.&nbsp; We ought to have our



<P>roll of directions, like Christian.&nbsp; What shall we do about that?"



<P>asked Jo, delighted with the fancy which lent a little romance to



<P>the very dull task of doing her duty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Look under your pillows christmas morning, and you will



<P>find your guidebook," replied Mrs. March.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They talked over the new plan while old Hannah cleared the



<P>table, then out came the four little work baskets, and the needles



<P>flew as the girls made sheets for Aunt March.&nbsp; It was uninteresting



<P>sewing, but tonight no one grumbled.&nbsp; They adopted Jo's plan of



<P>dividing the long seams into four parts, and calling the quarters



<P>Europe, Asia, Africa, and America, and in that way got on capitally,



<P>especially when they talked about the different countries as they



<P>stitched their way through them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At nine they stopped work, and sang, as usual, before they



<P>went to bed.&nbsp; No one but Beth could get much music out of the old



<P>piano, but she had a way of softly touching the yellow keys and



<P>making a pleasant accompaniment to the simple songs they sang.&nbsp;

Meg



<P>had a voice like a flute, and she and herr mother led the little



<P>choir.&nbsp; Amy chirped like a cricket, and Jo wandered through the

airs



<P>at her own sweet will, always coming out at the wrong place with a



<P>croak or a quaver that spoiled the most pensive tune.&nbsp; They had



<P>always done this from the time they could lisp...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Crinkle, crinkle, 'ittle 'tar,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>and it had become a household custom, for the mother was a born



<P>singer.&nbsp; The first sound in the morning was her voice as she went



<P>about the house singing like a lark, and the last sound at night



<P>was the same cheery sound, for the girls never grew too old for



<P>that familiar lullaby.



<P>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <TITLE>Chapter 15</TITLE>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FIFTEEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"November is the most disagreeable month in the whole year,"



<P>said Margaret, standing at the window one dull afternoon,



<P>looking out at the frostbitten garden.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's the reason I was born in it," observed Jo pensively,



<P>quite unconscious of the blot on her nose.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If something very pleasant should happen now, we should



<P>think it a delightful month," said Beth, who took a hopeful view



<P>of everything, even November.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say, but nothing pleasant ever does happen in this



<P>family," said Meg, who was out of sorts.&nbsp; "We go grubbing along



<P>day after day, without a bit of change, and very little fun.&nbsp; We



<P>might as well be in a treadmill."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My patience, how blue we are!" cried Jo.&nbsp; "I don't much



<P>wonder, poor dear, for you see other girls having splendid times,



<P>while you grind, grind, year in and year out.&nbsp; Oh, don't I wish



<P>I could manage things for you as I do for my heroines!&nbsp; You're



<P>pretty enough and good enough already, so I'd have some rich relation



<P>leave you a fortune unexpectedly.&nbsp; Then you'd dash out as an heiress,



<P>scorn everyone who has slighted you, go abroad, and come home my Lady



<P>Something in a blaze of splendor and elegance."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"People don't have fortunes left them in that style nowadays,



<P>men have to work and women marry for money.&nbsp; It's a dreadfully

unjust



<P>world," said Meg bitterly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo and I are going to make fortunes for you all.&nbsp; Just wait ten



<P>years, and see if we don't," said Amy, who sat in a corner making mud



<P>pies, as Hannah called her little clay models of birds, fruit, and



<P>faces.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Can't wait, and I'm afraid I haven't much faith in ink and dirt,



<P>though I'm grateful for your good intentions.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg sighed, and turned to the frostbitten garden again.&nbsp; Jo



<P>groaned and leaned both elbows on the table in a despondent attitude,



<P>but Amy spatted away energetically, and Beth, who sat at the other



<P>window, said, smiling, "Two pleasant things are going to happen



<P>right away.&nbsp; Marmee is coming down the street, and Laurie is tramping



<P>through the garden as if he had something nice to tell."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In they both came, Mrs. March with her usual question, "Any letter



<P>from Father, girls?" and Laurie to say in his persuasive way, "Won't



<P>some of you come for a drive?&nbsp; I've been working away at mathematics



<P>till my head is in a muddle, and I'm going to freshen my wits by a



<P>brisk turn.&nbsp; It's a dull day, but the air isn't bad, and I'm going

to



<P>take Brooke home, so it will be gay inside, if it isn't out.&nbsp; Come,



<P>Jo, you and Beth will go, won't you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course we will."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Much obliged, but I'm busy."&nbsp; And Meg whisked out her workbasket,



<P>for she had agreed with her mother that it was best, for her at least,



<P>not to drive too often with the young gentleman.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We three will be ready in a minute," cried Amy, running away to



<P>wash her hands.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Can I do anything for you, Madam Mother?" asked Laurie, leaning



<P>over Mrs. March's chair with the affectionate look and tone he always



<P>gave her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, thank you, except call at the office, if you'll be so kind,



<P>dear.&nbsp; It's our day for a letter, and the postman hasn't been.&nbsp;

Father



<P>is as regular as the sun, but there's some delay on the way, perhaps."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A sharp ring interrupted her, and a minute after Hannah came in



<P>with a letter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's one of them horrid telegraph things, mum," she said,



<P>handling it as if she was afraid it would explode and do some damage.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At the word `telegraph', Mrs. March snatched it, read the two



<P>lines it contained, and dropped back into her chair as white as if



<P>the little paper had sent a bullet to her heart.&nbsp; Laurie dashed



<P>downstairs for water, while Meg and Hannah supported her, and Jo read



<P>aloud, in a frightened voice...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March:



<P>Your husband is very ill.&nbsp; Come at once.



<P>S.&nbsp; HALE



<P>Blank Hospital, Washington.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How still the room was as they listened breathlessly, how



<P>strangely the day darkened outside, and how suddenly the whole world



<P>seemed to change, as the girls gathered about their mother, feeling



<P>as if all the happiness and support of their lives was about to be



<P>taken from them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March was herself again directly, read the message over,



<P>and stretched out her arms to her daughters, saying, in a tone they



<P>never forgot, "I shall go at once, but it may be too late.&nbsp; Oh,



<P>children, children, help me to bear it!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For several minutes there was nothing but the sound of sobbing



<P>in the room, mingled with broken words of comfort, tender assurances



<P>of help, and hopeful whispers that died away in tears.&nbsp; Poor Hannah



<P>was the first to recover, and with unconscious wisdom she set all the



<P>rest a good example, for with her, work was panacea for most



<P>afflictions.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The Lord keep the dear man!&nbsp; I won't waste no time a-cryin',



<P>but git your things ready right away, mum," she said heartily, as she



<P>wiped her face on her apron, gave her mistress a warm shake of the



<P>hand with her own hard one, and went away to work like three women



<P>in one.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She's right, there's no time for tears now.&nbsp; Be calm, girls,



<P>and let me think."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They tried to be calm, poor things, as their mother sat up,



<P>looking pale but steady, and put away her grief to think and plan



<P>for them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where's Laurie?' she asked presently, when she had collected



<P>her thoughts and decided on the first duties to be done.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here, ma'am.&nbsp; Oh, let me do something!" cried the boy,



<P>hurrying from the next room whither he had withdrawn, feeling that



<P>their first sorrow was too sacred for even his friendly eyes to see.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Send a telegram saying I will come at once.&nbsp; The next train



<P>goes early in the morning.&nbsp; I'll take that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What else?&nbsp; The horses are ready.&nbsp; I can go anywhere, do



<P>anything," he said, looking ready to fly to the ends of the earth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Leave a note at Aunt March's.&nbsp; Jo, give me that pen and paper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tearing off the blank side of one of her newly copied pages,



<P>Jo drew the table before her mother, well knowing that money for the



<P>long, sad journey must be borrowed, and feeling as if she could do



<P>anything to add to a little to the sum for her father.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now go, dear, but don't kill yourself driving at a desperate



<P>pace.&nbsp; There is no need of that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March's warning was evidently thrown away, for five minutes



<P>later Laurie tore by the window on his own fleet horse, riding as if



<P>for his life.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo, run to the rooms, and tell Mrs. King that I can't come.



<P>On the way get these things.&nbsp; I'll put them down, they'll be needed



<P>and I must go prepared for nursing.&nbsp; Hospital stores are not always



<P>good.&nbsp; Beth, go and ask Mr. Laurence for a couple of bottles of

old



<P>wine.&nbsp; I'm not too proud to beg for Father.&nbsp; He shall have

the best



<P>of everything.&nbsp; Amy, tell Hannah to get down the black trunk, and



<P>Meg, come and help me find my things, for I'm half bewildered."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Writing, thinking, and directing all at once might well bewilder



<P>the poor lady, and Meg begged her to sit quietly in her room



<P>for a little while, and let them work.&nbsp; Everyone scattered



<P>like leaves before a gust of wind, and the quiet, happy household



<P>was broken up as suddenly as if the paper had been an evil spell.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Laurence came hurrying back with Beth, bringing every



<P>comfort the kind old gentleman could think of for the invalid, and



<P>friendliest promises of protection for the girls during the mother's



<P>absence, which comforted her very much.&nbsp; There was nothing he didn't



<P>offer, from his own dressing gown to himself as escort.&nbsp; But the



<P>last was impossible.&nbsp; Mrs. March would not hear of the old



<P>gentleman's undertaking the long journey, yet an expression of relief

was



<P>visible when he spoke of it, for anxiety ill fits one for traveling.



<P>He saw the look, knit his heavy eyebrows, rubbed his hands, and



<P>marched abruptly away, saying he'd be back directly.&nbsp; No one had



<P>time to think of him again till, as Meg ran through the entry, with



<P>a pair of rubbers in one hand and a cup of tea in the other, she



<P>came suddenly upon Mr. Brooke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm very sorry to hear of this, Miss March," he said, in the



<P>kind, quiet tone which sounded very pleasantly to her perturbed



<P>spirit.&nbsp; "I came to offer myself as escort to your mother.&nbsp;

Mr.



<P>Laurence has commissions for me in Washington, and it will give me



<P>real satisfaction to be of service to her there."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Down dropped the rubbers, and the tea was very near following,



<P>as Meg put out her hand, with a face so full of gratitude that Mr.



<P>Brooke would have felt repaid for a much greater sacrifice than



<P>the trifling one of time and comfort which he was about to take.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How kind you all are!&nbsp; Mother will accept, I'm sure, and it



<P>will be such a relief to know that she has someone to take care of



<P>her.&nbsp; Thank you very, very much!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg spoke earnestly, and forgot herself entirely till something



<P>in the brown eyes looking down at her made her remember the



<P>cooling tea, and lead the way into the parlor, saying she would



<P>call her mother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Everything was arranged by the time Laurie returned with a



<P>note from Aunt March, enclosing the desired sum, and a few lines



<P>repeating what she had often said before, that she had always told



<P>them it was absurd for March to go into the army, always predicted



<P>that no good would come of it, and she hoped they would take her



<P>advice the next time.&nbsp; Mrs. March put the note in the fire, the



<P>money in her purse, and went on with her preparations, with her



<P>lips folded tightly in a way which Jo would have understood if she



<P>had been there.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The short afternoon wore away.&nbsp; All other errands were done,



<P>and Meg and her mother busy at some necessary needlework, while



<P>Beth and Amy goth tea, and Hannah finished her ironing with what



<P>she called a `slap and a bang', but still Jo did not come.&nbsp; They



<P>began to get anxious, and Laurie went off to find her, for no one



<P>knew what freak Jo might take into her head.&nbsp; He missed her,



<P>however, and she came walking in with a very queer expression of



<P>countenance, for there was a mixture of fun and fear, satisfaction



<P>and regret in it, which puzzled the family as much as did the roll



<P>of bills she laid before her mother, saying with a little choke in



<P>her voice, "That's my contribution toward making Father comfortable



<P>and bringing him home!"



<P>"My dear, where did you get it?&nbsp; Twenty-five dollars!&nbsp; Jo,

I



<P>hope you haven't done anything rash?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, it's mine honestly.&nbsp; I didn't beg, borrow, or steal it.&nbsp;

I



<P>earned it, and I don't think you'll blame me, for I only sold what



<P>was my own."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she spoke, Jo took off her bonnet, and a general outcry arose,



<P>for all her abundant hair was cut short.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your hair!&nbsp; Your beautiful hair!"&nbsp; "Oh, Jo, how could you?

Your



<P>one beauty."&nbsp; "My dear girl, there was no need of this."&nbsp;

"She doesn't



<P>look like my Jo any more, but I love her dearly for it!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As everyone exclaimed, and Beth hugged the cropped head tenderly,



<P>Jo assumed an indifferent air, which did not deceive anyone a particle,



<P>and said, rumpling up the brown bush and trying to look as if she liked



<P>it, "It doesn't affect the fate of the nation, so don't wail, Beth.&nbsp;

It



<P>will be good for my vanity, I getting too proud of my wig.&nbsp; It

will do



<P>my brains good to have that mop taken off.&nbsp; My head feels deliciously



<P>light and cool, and the barber said I could soon have a curly crop,



<P>which will be boyish, becoming, and easy to keep in order.&nbsp; I'm

satisfied,



<P>so please take the money and let's have supper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tell me all about it, Jo.&nbsp; I am not quite satisfied, but I can't



<P>blame you, for I know how willingly you sacrificed your vanity, as



<P>you call it, to your love.&nbsp; But, my dear, it was not necessary,

and



<P>I'm afraid you will regret it one of these days," said Mrs. March.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I won't!" returned Jo stoutly, feeling much relieved that



<P>her prank was not entirely condemned.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What made you do it?" asked Amy, who would as soon have thought



<P>of cutting off her head as her pretty hair.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I was wild to to something for Father," replied Jo, as



<P>they gathered about the table, for healthy young people can eat even



<P>in the midst of trouble.&nbsp; "I hate to borrow as much as Mother does,



<P>and I knew Aunt March would croak, she always does, if you ask for



<P>a ninepence.&nbsp; Meg gave all her quarterly salary toward the rent,

and



<P>I only got some clothes with mine, so I felt wicked, and was bound



<P>to have some money, if I sold the nose off my face to get it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You needn't feel wicked, my child! You had no winter things and



<P>got the simplest with your own hard earnings," said Mrs. March with

a



<P>look that warmed Jo's heart.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hadn't the least idea of selling my hair at first, but as I



<P>went along I kept thinking what I could do, and feeling as if I'd



<P>like to dive into some of the rich stores and help myself.&nbsp; In

a



<P>barber's window I saw tails of hair with the prices marked, and one



<P>black tail, not so thick as mine, was forty dollars.&nbsp; It came to

me



<P>all of a sudden that I had one thing to make money out of, and



<P>without stopping to think, I walked in, asked if they bought hair,



<P>and what they would give for mine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't see how you dared to do it," said Beth in a tone of awe.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, he was a little man who looked as if he merely lived to oil



<P>his hair.&nbsp; He rather stared at first, as if he wasn't used to having



<P>girls bounce into his shop and ask him to buy their hair.&nbsp; He said

he



<P>didn't care about mine, it wasn't the fashionable color, and he never



<P>paid much for it in the first place.&nbsp; The work he put it into it

made



<P>it dear, and so on.&nbsp; It was getting late, and I was afraid if it



<P>wasn't done right away that I shouldn't have it done at all, and you



<P>know when I start to do a thing, I hate to give it up.&nbsp; So I begged



<P>him to take it, and told him why I was in such a hurry.&nbsp; It was



<P>silly, I dare say, but it changed his mind, for I got rather excited,



<P>and told the story in my topsy-turvy way, and his wife heard, and



<P>said so kindly, `Take it, Thomas, and oblige the young lady.&nbsp; I'd

do



<P>as much for our Jimmy any day if I had a spire of hair worth selling."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Who was Jimmy?" asked Amy, who liked to have things explained



<P>as they went along.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Her son, she said, who was in the army.&nbsp; How friendly such



<P>things make strangers feel, don't they?&nbsp; She talked away all the



<P>time the man clipped, and diverted my mind nicely."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Didn't you feel dreadfully when the first cut came?" asked



<P>Meg, with a shiver.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I took a last look at my hair while the man got his things,



<P>and that was the end of it.&nbsp; I never snivel over trifles like that.



<P>I will confess, though, I felt queer when I saw the dear old hair



<P>laid out on the table, and felt only the short rough ends of my head.



<P>It almost seemed as if I'd an arm or leg off.&nbsp; The woman saw me

look



<P>at it, and picked out a long lock for me to keep.&nbsp; I'll give it

to



<P>you, Marmee, just to remember past glories by, for a crop is so



<P>comfortable I don't think I shall ever have a mane again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March folded the wavy chestnut lock, and laid it away with



<P>a short gray one in her desk.&nbsp; She only said, "Thank you, deary,"



<P>but something in her face made the girls change the subject, and



<P>talk as cheerfully as they could about Mr. Brooke's kindness, the



<P>prospect of a fine day tomorrow, and the happy times they would have



<P>when Father came home to be nursed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No one wanted to go to bed when at ten o'clock Mrs. March put



<P>by the last finished job, and said, "Come girls."&nbsp; Beth went to

the



<P>piano and played the father's favorite hymn.&nbsp; All began bravely,

but



<P>broke down one by one till Beth was left alone, singing with all her



<P>heart, for to her music was always a sweet consoler.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Go to bed and don't talk, for we must be up early and shall



<P>need all the sleep we can get.&nbsp; Good night, my darlings," said

Mrs.



<P>March, as the hymn ended, for no one cared to try another.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They kissed her quietly, and went to bed as silently as if the



<P>dear invalid lay in the next room.&nbsp; Beth and Amy soon fell asleep

in



<P>spite of the great trouble, but Meg lay awake, thinking the most



<P>serious thoughts she had ever known in her short life.&nbsp; Jo lay



<P>motionless, and her sister fancied that she was asleep, till a stifled



<P>sob made her exclaim, as she touched a wet cheek...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo, dear, what is it?&nbsp; Are you crying about father?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, not now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What then?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My...My hair!" burst out poor Jo, trying vainly to smother



<P>her emotion in the pillow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It did not seem at all comical to Meg, who kissed and caressed



<P>the afflicted heroine in the tenderest manner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm not sorry," protested Jo, with a choke.&nbsp; "I'd do it again



<P>tomorrow, if I could.&nbsp; It's only the vain part of me that goes

and



<P>cries in this silly way.&nbsp; Don't tell anyone, it's all over now.&nbsp;

I



<P>thought you were asleep, so I just made a little private moan for my



<P>one beauty.&nbsp; How came you to be awake?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't sleep, I'm so anxious," said Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Think about something pleasant, and you'll soon drop off."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I tried it, but felt wider awake than ever."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What did you think of?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Handsome faces--eyes particularly," answered Meg, smiling to



<P>herself in the dark.



<P>"What color do you like best?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Brown, that is, sometimes.&nbsp; Blue are lovely."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo, laughed, and Meg sharply ordered her not to talk, then



<P>amiably promised to make her hair curl, and fell asleep to dream of



<P>living in her castle in the air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The clocks were striking midnight and the rooms were very still



<P>as a figure glided quietly from bed to bed, smoothing a coverlet here,



<P>settling a pillow there, and pausing to look long and tenderly at each



<P>unconscious face, to kiss each with lips that mutely blessed, and to



<P>pray the fervent prayers which only mothers utter.&nbsp; As she lifted

the



<P>curtain to look out into the dreary night, the moon broke suddenly



<P>from behind the clouds and shone upon her like a bright, benignant



<P>face, which seemed to whisper in the silence," Be comforted, dear



<P>soul!&nbsp; There is always light behind the clouds."



<P>
