<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 29</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER TWENTY-NINE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come, Jo, it's time."



<P>"For what?"



<P>"You don't mean to say you have forgotten that you promised



<P>to make half a dozen calls with me today?"

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've done a good many rash and foolish things in my life,



<P>but I don't think I ever was mad enough to say I'd make six calls



<P>in one day, when a single one upsets me for a week."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, you did, it was a bargain between us.&nbsp; I was to finish



<P>the crayon of Beth for you, and you were to go properly with me,



<P>and return our neighbors' visits."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If it was fair, that was in the bond, and I stand to the



<P>letter of my bond, Shylock.&nbsp; There is a pile of clouds in the east,



<P>it's not fair, and I don't go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, that's shirking.&nbsp; It's a lovely day, no prospect of rain,



<P>and you pride yourself on keeping; promises, so be honorable, come



<P>and do your duty, and then be at peace for another six months."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At that minute Jo was particularly absorbed in dressmaking,



<P>for she was mantua-maker general to the family, and took especial



<P>credit to herself because she could use a needle as well as a pen.



<P>It was very provoking to be arrested in the act of a first tryingon,



<P>and ordered out to make calls in her best array on a warm July day.



<P>She hated calls of the formal sort, and never made any till Amy



<P>compelled her with a bargain, bribe, or promise.&nbsp; In the present



<P>instance there was no escape, and having clashed her scissors



<P>rebelliously, while protesting that she smelled thunder, she gave in,



<P>put away her work, and taking up her hat and gloves with an air of



<P>resignation, told Amy the victim was ready.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo March, you are perverse enough to provoke a saint!&nbsp; You don't



<P>intend to make calls in that state, I hope," cried Amy, surveying



<P>her with amazement.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why not?&nbsp; I'm neat and cool and comfortable, quite proper



<P>for a dusty walk on a warm day.&nbsp; If people care more for my



<P>clothes than they do for me, I don't wish to see them.&nbsp; You can



<P>dress for both, and be as elegant as you please.&nbsp; It pays for



<P>you to be fine.&nbsp; It doesn't for me, and furbelows only worry me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, dear!" sighed Amy, "now she's in a contrary fit, and



<P>will drive me distracted before I can get her properly ready.



<P>I'm sure it's no pleasure to me to go today, but it's a debt we



<P>owe society, and there's no one to pay it but you and me.&nbsp; I'll



<P>do anything for you, Jo, if you'll only dress yourself nicely,



<P>and come and help me do the civil.&nbsp; You can talk so well, look



<P>so aristocratic in your best things, and behave so beautifully,



<P>if you try, that I'm proud of you.&nbsp; I'm afraid to go alone, do



<P>come and take care of me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You're an artful little puss to flatter and wheedle your



<P>cross old sister in that way.&nbsp; The idea of my being aristocratic



<P>and well-bred, and your being afraid to go anywhere alone!&nbsp; I



<P>don't know which is the most absurd.&nbsp; Well, I'll go if I must,



<P>and do my best.&nbsp; You shall be commander of the expedition, and



<P>I'll obey blindly, will that satisfy you?" said Jo, with a sudden



<P>change from perversity to lamblike submission.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You're a perfect cherub!&nbsp; Now put on all your best things,



<P>and I'll tell you how to behave at each place, so that you will



<P>make a good impression.&nbsp; I want people to like you, and they



<P>would if you'd only try to be a little more agreeable.&nbsp; Do your



<P>hair the pretty way, and put the pink rose in your bonnet.&nbsp; It's



<P>becoming, and you look too sober in your plain suit.&nbsp; Take your



<P>light gloves and the embroidered handkerchief.&nbsp; We'll stop at



<P>Meg's, and borrow her white sunshade, and then you can have my



<P>dove-colored one."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While Amy dressed, she issued her orders, and Jo obeyed



<P>them, not without entering her protest, however, for she sighed



<P>as she rustled into her new organdie, frowned darkly at herself



<P>as she tied her bonnet strings in an irreproachable bow,



<P>wrestled viciously with pins as she put on her collar,



<P>wrinkled up her features generally as she shook out the handkerchief,



<P>whose embroidery was as irritating to her nose as the present mission



<P>was to her feelings, and when she had squeezed her hands into



<P>tight gloves with three buttons and a tassel, as the last touch



<P>of elegance, she turned to Amy with an imbecile expression of



<P>countenance, saying meekly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm perfectly miserable, but if you consider me presentable,



<P>I die happy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You're highly satisfactory.&nbsp; turn slowly round, and let me



<P>get a careful view."&nbsp; Jo revolved, and Amy gave a touch here and



<P>there, then fell back, with her head on one side, observing graciously,



<P>"Yes, you'll do.&nbsp; Your head is all I could ask, for that



<P>white bonnet with the rose is quite ravishing.&nbsp; Hold back your



<P>shoulders, and carry your hands easily, no matter if your gloves



<P>do pinch.&nbsp; There's one thing you can do well, Jo, that is, wear

a



<P>shawl.&nbsp; I can't, but it's very nice to see you, and I'm so glad



<P>Aunt March gave you that lovely one.&nbsp; It's simple, but handsome,



<P>and those folds over the arm are really artistic.&nbsp; Is the point

of



<P>my mantle in the middle, and have I looped my dress evenly?&nbsp; I

like



<P>to show my boots, for my feet are pretty, though my nose isn't."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are a thing of beauty and a joy forever," said Jo, looking



<P>through her hand with the air of a connoisseur at the blue feather



<P>against the golden hair.&nbsp; "Am I to drag my best dress through the



<P>dust, or loop it up, please, ma'am?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hold it yup when you walk, but drop it in the house.&nbsp; The



<P>sweeping style suits you best, and you must learn to trail your



<P>skirts gracefully.&nbsp; You haven't half buttoned one cuff, do it at



<P>once.&nbsp; You'll never look finished if you are not careful about

the



<P>little details, for they make yup the pleasing whole."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo sighed, and proceeded to burst the buttons off her glove,



<P>in doing up her cuff, but at last both were ready, and sailed away,



<P>looking as `pretty as picters', Hannah said, as she hung out of the



<P>upper window to watch them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Jo dear, the Chesters consider themselves very elegant



<P>people, so I want you to put on your best deportment.&nbsp; Don't make



<P>any of your abrupt remarks, or do anything odd, will you?&nbsp; Just

be



<P>calm, cool, and quiet, that's safe and ladylike, and you can easily



<P>do it for fifteen minutes," said Amy, as they approached the first



<P>place, having borrowed the white parasol and been inspected by Meg,



<P>with a baby on each arm.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let me see.&nbsp; `Calm, cool, and quiet', yes, I think I can



<P>promise that.&nbsp; I've played the part of a prim young lady on the



<P>stage, and I'll try it off.&nbsp; My powers are great, as you shall

see,



<P>so be easy in your mind, my child."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy looked relieved, but naughty Jo took her at her word, for



<P>during the first call she sat with every limb gracefully composed,



<P>every fold correctly draped, calm as a summer sea, cool as a snowbank,



<P>and as silent as the sphinx.&nbsp; In vain Mrs. Chester alluded to



<P>her `charming novel', and the Misses Chester introduced parties,



<P>picnics, the opera, and the fashions.&nbsp; Each and all were answered



<P>by a smile, a bow, and a demure "Yes" or "No" with the chill on.



<P>In vain Amy telegraphed the word `talk', tried to draw her out, and



<P>administered covert pokes with her foot.&nbsp; Jo sat as if blandly

unconcious



<P>of it all, with deportment like Maud's face, `icily regular, splendidly

null'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a haughty, uninteresting creature that oldest Miss March is!"



<P>was the unfortunately audible remark of one of the ladies, as



<P>the door closed upon their guests.&nbsp; Jo laughed noiselessly all



<P>through the hall, but Amy looked disgusted at the failure of her



<P>instructions, and very naturally laid the blame upon Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How could you mistake me so?&nbsp; I merely meant you to be properly



<P>dignified and composed, and you made yourself a perfect stock and



<P>stone.&nbsp; Try to be sociable at the Lamb's'.&nbsp; Gossip as other

girls do,



<P>and be interested in dress and flirtations and whatever nonsense



<P>comes up.&nbsp; They move in the best society, are valuable persons

for



<P>us to know, and I wouldn't fail to make a good impression there for



<P>anything."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll be agreeable.&nbsp; I'll gossip and giggle, and have horrors



<P>and raptures over any trifle you like.&nbsp; I rather enjoy this, and



<P>now I'll imitate what is called `a charming girl'.&nbsp; I can do it,



<P>for I have May Chester as a model, and I'll improve upon her.&nbsp;

See if



<P>the Lambs don't say, `What a lively, nice creature that Jo March is!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy felt anxious, as well she might, for when Jo turned freakish



<P>there was no knowing where she would stop.&nbsp; Amy's face was a



<P>study when she saw her sister skim into the next drawing room, kiss



<P>all the young ladies with effusion, beam graciously upon the young



<P>gentlemen, and join in the chat with a spirit which amazed the beholder.



<P>Amy was taken possession of by Mrs. Lamb, with whom she



<P>was a favorite, and forced to hear a long account of Lucretia's



<P>last attack, while three delightful young gentlemen hovered near,



<P>waiting for a pause when they might rush in and rescue her.&nbsp; So



<P>situated, she was powerless to check Jo, who seemed possessed by



<P>a spirit of mischief, and talked away as volubly as the lady.&nbsp;

A



<P>knot of heads gathered about her, and Amy strained her ears to hear



<P>what was going on, for broken sentences filled her with curiosity,



<P>and frequent peals of laughter made her wild to share the fun.&nbsp;

One



<P>may imagine her suffering on overhearing fragments of this sort of



<P>conversation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She rides splendidly.&nbsp; who taught her?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No one.&nbsp; She used to practice mounting, holding the reins, and



<P>sitting straight on an old saddle in a tree.&nbsp; Now she rides anything,



<P>for she doesn't know what fear is, and the stableman lets her have



<P>horses cheap because she trains them to carry ladies so well.&nbsp;

She



<P>has such a passion for it, I often tell her if everything else fails,



<P>she can be a horsebreaker, and get her living so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At this awful speech Amy contained herself with difficulty, for



<P>the impression was being given that she was rather a fast young lady,



<P>which was her especial aversion.&nbsp; But what could she do?&nbsp;

For the



<P>old lady was in the middle of her story, and long before it was done,



<P>Jo was off again, make more droll revelations and committing still



<P>more fearful blunders.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Amy was in despair that day, for all the good beasts were



<P>gone, and of three left, one was lame, one blind, and the other so



<P>balky that you had to put dirt in his mouth before he would start.



<P>Nice animal for a pleasure party, wasn't it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Which did she choose?" asked one of the laughing gentlemen,



<P>who enjoyed the subject.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"None of them.&nbsp; She heard of a young horse at the farm house



<P>over the river, and though a lady had never ridden him, she resolved



<P>to try, because he was handsome and spirited.&nbsp; Her struggles



<P>were really pathetic.&nbsp; There was no one to bring the horse to the



<P>saddle, so she took the saddle to the horse.&nbsp; My dear creature,

she



<P>actually rowed it over the river, put it on her head, and marched



<P>up to the barn to the utter amazement of the old man!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did she ride the horse?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course she did, and had a capital time.&nbsp; I expected to see



<P>her brought home in fragments, but she managed him perfectly, and



<P>was the life of the party."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I call that plucky!"&nbsp; And young Mr. Lamb turned an approving



<P>glance upon Amy, wondering what his mother could be saying to make



<P>the girl look so red and uncomfortable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was still redder and more uncomfortable a moment after,



<P>when a sudden turn in the conversation introduced the subject of



<P>dress.&nbsp; One of the young ladies asked Jo where she got the pretty



<P>drab hat she wore to the picnic and stupid Jo, instead of mentioning



<P>the place where it was bought two years ago, must needs answer



<P>with unnecessary frankness, "Oh, Amy painted it.&nbsp; You can't buy



<P>those soft shades, so we paint ours any color we like.&nbsp; It's a

great



<P>comfort to have an artistic sister."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Isn't that an original idea?" cried Miss Lamb, who found Jo great fun.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's nothing compared to some of her brilliant performances.



<P>There's nothing the child can't do.&nbsp; Why, she wanted a pair of

blue



<P>boots for Sallie's party, so she just painted her soiled white ones



<P>the loveliest shade of sky blue you ever saw, and they looked exactly



<P>like satin," added Jo, with an air of pride in her sister's accomplishments



<P>that exasperated Amy till she felt that it would be a relief to throw

her



<P>cardcase at her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We read a story of yours the other day, and enjoyed it very much,"



<P>observed the elder Miss Lamb, wishing to compliment the literary



<P>lady, who did not look the character just then, it must be confessed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Any mention of her `works' always had a bad effect upon Jo,



<P>who either grew rigid and looked offended, or changed the subject



<P>with a brusque remark, as now.&nbsp; "Sorry you could find nothing better



<P>to read.&nbsp; I write that rubbish because it sells, and ordinary people



<P>like it.&nbsp; Are you going to New York this winter?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As Miss Lamb had `enjoyed' the story, this speech was not



<P>exactly grateful or complimentary.&nbsp; The minute it was made Jo saw



<P>her mistake, but fearing to make the matter worse, suddenly remembered



<P>that it was for her to make the first move toward departure,



<P>and did so with an abruptness that left three people with half-



<P>finished sentences in their mouths.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Amy, we must go.&nbsp; Good-by, dear, do come and see us.&nbsp; We

are



<P>pining for a visit.&nbsp; I don't dare to ask you, Mr. Lamb, but if

you



<P>should come, I don't think I shall have the heart to send you away."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo said this with such a droll imitation of May Chester's



<P>gushing style that Amy got out of the room as rapidly as possible,



<P>feeling a strong desire to laugh and cry at the same time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Didn't I do well?" asked Jo, with a satisfied air as they walked away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing could have been worse," was Amy's crushing reply.



<P>"What possessed you to tell those stories about my saddle, and



<P>the hats and boots, and all the rest of it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, it's funny, and amuses people.&nbsp; They know we are poor,



<P>so it's no use pretending that we have grooms, buy three or



<P>four hats a season, and have things as easy and fine as they do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You needn't go and tell them all our little shifts, and



<P>expose our; poverty in that perfectly unnecessary way.&nbsp; You haven't



<P>a bit of proper pride, and never will learn when to hold your



<P>tongue and when to speak," said Amy despairingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Jo looked abashed, and silently chafed the end of her



<P>nose with the stiff handkerchief, as if performing a penance for



<P>her misdemeanors.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How shall I behave here?" she asked, as they approached the



<P>third mansion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Just as you please.&nbsp; I wash my hands of you," was Amy's short



<P>answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then I'll enjoy myself.&nbsp; The boys are at home, and we'll have



<P>a comfortable time.&nbsp; Goodness knows I need a little change, for



<P>elegance has a bad effect upon my constitution," returned Jo gruffly,



<P>being disturbed by her failure to suit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>An enthusiastic welcome from three big boys and several pretty



<P>children speedily soothed her ruffled feelings, and leaving Amy to



<P>entertain the hostess and Mr. Tudor, who happened to be calling



<P>likewise, Jo devoted herself to the young folks and found the



<P>change refreshing.&nbsp; She listened to college stories with deep interest,



<P>caressed pointers and poodles without a murmur, agreed heartily



<P>that "Tom Brown was a brick," regardless of the improper form



<P>of praise, and when one lad proposed a visit to his turtle tank,



<P>she went with an alacrity which caused Mamma to smile upon her,



<P>as that motherly lady settled the cap which was left in a ruinous



<P>condition by filial hugs, bearlike but affectionate, and dearer to



<P>her than the most faultless coiffure from the hands of an inspired



<P>Frenchwoman.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Leaving her sister to her own devices, Amy proceeded to enjoy



<P>herself to her heart's content.&nbsp; Mr. Tudor's uncle had married

an



<P>English lady who was third cousin to a living lord, and Amy regarded



<P>the whole family with great respect, for in spite of her American



<P>birth and breeding, she possessed that reverence for titles which



<P>haunts the best of us--that unacknowledged loyalty to the early



<P>faith in kings which set the most democratic nation under the sun



<P>in ferment at the coming of a royal yellow-haired laddie, some years



<P>ago, and which still has something to do with the love the young



<P>country bears the old, like that of a big son for an imperious little



<P>mother, who held him while she could, and let him go with a farewell



<P>scolding when he rebelled.&nbsp; But even the satisfaction of talking

with



<P>a distant connection of the British nobility did not render Amy forgetful



<P>of time, and when the proper number of minutes had passed, she



<P>reluctantly tore herself from this aristocratic society, and looked



<P>about for Jo, fervently hoping that her incorrigible sister would not



<P>be found in any position which should bring disgrace upon the name of

March.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It might have been worse, but Amy considered it bad.&nbsp; For Jo



<P>sat on the grass, with an encampment of boys about her, and a



<P>dirty-footed dog reposing on the skirt of her state and festival dress,



<P>as she related one of Laurie's pranks to her admiring audience.&nbsp;

One



<P>small child was poking turtles with Amy's cherished parasol, a second



<P>was eating gingerbread over Jo's best bonnet, and a third playing



<P>ball with her gloves.&nbsp; but all were enjoying themselves, and when

Jo



<P>collected her damaged property to go, her escort accompanied her,



<P>begging her to come again, "It was such fun to hear about Laurie's larks."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Capital boys, aren't they?&nbsp; I feel quite young and brisk again



<P>after that." said Jo, strolling along with her hands behind her,



<P>partly from habit, partly to conceal the bespattered parasol.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why do you always avoid Mr. Tudor?" asked Amy, wisely refraining



<P>from any comment upon Jo's dilapidated appearance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't like him, he puts on airs, snubs his sisters, worries



<P>his father, a nd doesn't speak respectfully of his mother.&nbsp; Laurie



<P>says he is fast, and I don't consider him a desirable acquaintance,



<P>so I let him alone."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You might treat him civilly, at least.&nbsp; You gave him a cool



<P>nod, and just now you bowed and smiled in the politest way to



<P>Tommy Chamberlain, whose father keeps a grocery store.&nbsp; If you



<P>had just reversed the nod and the bow, it would have been right,"



<P>said Amy reprovingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, it wouldn't," returned Jo, "I neither like, respect, nor



<P>admire Tudor, though his grandfather's uncle's nephew's niece was



<P>a third cousin to a lord.&nbsp; Tommy is poor and bashful and good and



<P>very clever.&nbsp; I think well of him, and like to show that I do,

for



<P>he is a gentleman in spite of the brown paper parcels."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's no use trying to argue with you," began Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not the least, my dear," interrupted Jo, "so let us look



<P>amiable, and drop a card here, as the Kings are evidently out,



<P>for which I'm deeply grateful."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The family cardcase having done its duty the girls walked



<P>on, and Jo uttered another thanksgiving on reaching the fifth



<P>house, and being told that the young ladies were engaged.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"now let us go home, and never mind Aunt March today.&nbsp; We



<P>can run down there any time, and it's really a pity to trail



<P>through the dust in our best bibs and tuckers, when we are



<P>tired and cross."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Speak for yourself, if you please.&nbsp; Aunt March likes to have us



<P>pay her the compliment of coming in style, and making a formal call.



<P>It's a little thing to do, but it gives her pleasure, and I don't



<P>believe it will hurt your things half so much as letting dirty dogs



<P>and clumping boys spoil them.&nbsp; Stoop down, and let me take the



<P>crumbs off of your bonnet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a good girl you are, Amy!" said Jo, with a repentant



<P>glance from her own damaged costume to that of her sister, which



<P>was fresh and spotless still.&nbsp; "I wish it was as easy for me to

do



<P>little things to please people as it is for you.&nbsp; I think of them,



<P>but it takes too much time to do them, so I wait for a chance to



<P>confer a great favor, and let the small ones slip, but they tell



<P>best in the end, I fancy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy smiled and was mollified at once, saying with a maternal



<P>air, "Women should learn to be agreeable, particularly poor ones,



<P>for they have no other way of repaying the kindnesses they receive.



<P>If you'd remember that, and practice it, you'd be better liked



<P>than I am, because there is more of you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm a crotchety old thing, and always shall be, but I'm



<P>willing to own that you are right, only it's easier for me to



<P>risk my life for a person than to be pleasant to him when I don't



<P>feel like it.&nbsp; It's a great misfortune to have such strong likes



<P>and dislikes, isn't it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's a greater not to be able to hide them.&nbsp; I don't mind



<P>saying that I don't approve of Tudor any more than you do, but I'm



<P>not called upon to tell him so.&nbsp; Neither are you, and there is

no



<P>use in making yourself disagreeable because he is."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I think girls ought to show when they disapprove of



<P>young men, and how can they do it except by their manners?



<P>Preaching does not do any good, as I know to my sorrow, since I've



<P>had Teddie to manage.&nbsp; But there are many little ways in which

I can



<P>influence him without a word, and I say we ought to do it to others



<P>if we can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Teddy is a remarkable boy, and can't be taken as a sample



<P>of other boys," said Amy, in a tone of solemn conviction, which



<P>would have convulsed the `remarkable boy' if he had heard it.&nbsp;

"If



<P>we were belles, or women of wealth and position, we might do something,



<P>perhaps, but for us to frown at one set of young gentlemen because



<P>we don't approve of them, and smile upon another set because



<P>we do, wouldn't have a particle of effect, and we should



<P>only be considered odd and puritanical."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So we are to countenance things and people which we detest,



<P>merely because we are not belles and millionaires, are we?



<P>That's a nice sort of morality."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't argue about it, I only know that it's the way of



<P>the world, and people who set themselves against it only get



<P>laughed at for their pains.&nbsp; I don't like reformers, and I hope



<P>you never try to be one."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do like them, and I shall be one if I can, for in spite of



<P>the laughing the world would never get on without them.&nbsp; We can't



<P>agree about that.&nbsp; for you belong to the old set, and I to the

new.



<P>You will get on the best, but I shall have the liveliest time of it.



<P>I should rather enjoy the brickbats and hooting, I think."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, compose yourself now, and don't worry Aunt with your



<P>new ideas."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll try not to, but I'm always possessed to burst out with



<P>some particularly blunt speech or revolutionary sentiment before



<P>her.&nbsp; It's my doom, and I can't help it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They found Aunt Carrol with the old lady, both absorbed in



<P>some very interesting subject, but they dropped it as the girls



<P>came in, with a conscious look which betrayed that they had been



<P>talking about their nieces.&nbsp; Jo was not in a good humor, and the



<P>perverse fit returned, but Amy, who had virtuously done her duty,



<P>kept her temper and pleased everybody, was in a most angelic frame



<P>of mind.&nbsp; This amiable spirit was felt at once, and both aunts

`my



<P>deared' her affectionately, looking what they afterward said emphatically,



<P>"That child improves every day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Are you going to help about the fair, dear?" asked Mrs. Carrol,



<P>as Amy sat down beside her with the confiding air elderly people like



<P>so well in the young.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Aunt.&nbsp; Mrs. Chester asked me if I would, and I offered to



<P>tend a table, as I have nothing but my time to give."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm not," put in Jo decidedly.&nbsp; "I hate to be patronized, and



<P>the Chesters think it's a great favor to allow us to help with their



<P>highly connected fair.&nbsp; I wonder you consented, Amy, they only

want



<P>you to work."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am willing to work.&nbsp; It's for the freedmen as well as the



<P>Chesters, and I think it very kind of them to let me share the



<P>labor and the fun.&nbsp; Patronage does not trouble me when it is well



<P>meant."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Quite right and proper.&nbsp; I like your grateful spirit, my dear.



<P>It's a pleasure to help people who appreciate our efforts.&nbsp; Some

do



<P>not, and that is trying," observed Aunt March, looking over her



<P>spectacles at Jo, who sat apart, rocking herself, with a somewhat



<P>morose expression.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If Jo had only known what a great happiness was wavering in



<P>the balance for one of them, she would have turned dove-like in a



<P>minute, but unfortunately, we don't have windows in our breasts,



<P>and cannot see what goes on in the minds of our friends.&nbsp; Better



<P>for us that we cannot as a general thing, but now and then it



<P>would be such a comfort, such a saving of time and temper.&nbsp; By

her



<P>next speech, Jo deprived herself of several years of pleasure, and



<P>received a timely lesson in the art of holding her tongue.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't like favors, they oppress and make me feel like a



<P>slave.&nbsp; I'd rather do everything for myself, and be perfectly



<P>independent."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ahem!" coughed Aunt Carrol softly, with a look at Aunt March.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I told you so," said Aunt March, with a decided nod to Aunt Carrol.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mercifully unconscious of what she had done, Jo sat with her nose in



<P>the air, and a revolutionary aspect which was anything but inviting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you speak French, dear?" asked Mrs. Carrol, laying a hand on Amy's.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pretty well, thanks to Aunt March, who lets Esther talk to



<P>me as often as I like," replied amy, with a grateful look, which



<P>caused the old lady to smile affably.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How are you about languages?" asked Mrs. Carrol of JO.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't know a word.&nbsp; I'm very stupid about studying anything,



<P>can't bear French, it's such a slippery, silly sort of language,"



<P>was the brusque reply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Another look passed between the ladies, and Aunt March said



<P>to Amy, 'You are quite strong and well no, dear, I believe?&nbsp; Eyes



<P>don't trouble you any more, do they?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not at all, thank you, ma'am.&nbsp; I'm very well, and mean to do



<P>great things next winter, so that I may be ready for Rome, whenever



<P>that joyful time arrives."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good girl!&nbsp; You deserve to go, and I'm sure you will some



<P>day," said Aunt March, with an approving; pat on the head, as Amy



<P>picked up her ball for her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Crosspatch, draw the latch,



<P>Sit by the fire and spin,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>squalled Polly, bending down from his perch on the back of her



<P>chair to peep into Jo's face, with such a comical air of impertinent



<P>inquiry that it was impossible to help laughing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Most observing bird," said the old lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come and take a walk, my dear?" cried Polly, hopping toward



<P>the china closet, with a look suggestive of a lump of sugar.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, I will.&nbsp; Come Amy."&nbsp; And Jo brought the visit

to



<P>an end, feeling more strongly than ever that calls did have a bad



<P>effect upon her constitution.&nbsp; She shook hands in a gentlemanly



<P>manner, but Amy kissed both the aunts, and the girls departed,



<P>leaving behind them the impression of shadow and sunshine, which



<P>impression caused Aunt March to say, as they vanished...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'd better do it, Mary.&nbsp; I'll supply the money.&nbsp; And Aunt



<P>Carrol to reply decidedly, "I certainly will, if her father and



<P>mother consent."



<P>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER TWENTY-EIGHT</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Like most other young matrons, Meg began her married life



<P>with the determination to be a model housekeeper.&nbsp; John should



<P>find home a paradise, he should always see a smiling face,



<P>should fare sumptuously every day, and never know the loss of



<P>a button.&nbsp; She brought so much love, energy, and cheerfulness



<P>to the work that she could not but succeed, in spite of some



<P>obstacles.&nbsp; Her paradise was not a tranquil one, for the little



<P>woman fussed, was over-anxious to please, and bustled about like



<P>a true Martha, cumbered with many cares.&nbsp; She was too tired, sometimes,



<P>even to smile, John grew dyspeptic after a course of dainty



<P>dishes and ungratefully demanded plain fare.&nbsp; As for buttons,



<P>she soon learned to wonder where they went, to shake her head over



<P>the carelessness of men, and to threaten to make him sew them



<P>on himself, and see if his work would stand impatient and clumsy



<P>fingers any better than hers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were very happy, even after they discovered that they



<P>couldn't live on love alone.&nbsp; John did not find Meg's beauty diminished,



<P>though she beamed at him from behind the familiar coffee pot.



<P>Nor did Meg miss any of the romance from the daily parting, when her



<P>husband followed up his kiss with the tender inquiry, "Shall I send



<P>some veal or mutton for dinner, darling?" The little house ceased



<P>to be a glorified bower, but it became a home, and the young couple



<P>soon felt that it was a change for the better.&nbsp; At first they played



<P>keep-house, and frolicked over it like children.&nbsp; Then John took



<P>steadily to business, feeling the cares of the head of a family upon



<P>his shoulders, and Meg laid by her cambric wrappers, put on a big apron,



<P>and fell to work, as before said, with more energy than discretion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While the cooking mania lasted she went through Mrs. Cornelius's



<P>Receipt Book as if it were a mathematical exercise, working out the



<P>problems with patience and care.&nbsp; Sometimes her family were invited



<P>in to help eat up a too bounteous feast of successes, or Lotty would



<P>be privately dispatched with a batch of failures, which were to be



<P>concealed from all eyes in the convenient stomachs of the little



<P>Hummels.&nbsp; An evening with John over the account books usually produced



<P>a temporary lull in the culinary enthusiasm, and a frugal fit



<P>would ensue, during which the poor man was put through a course of



<P>bread pudding, hash, and warmed-over coffee, which tried his soul,



<P>although he bore it with praiseworthy fortitude.&nbsp; Before the golden



<P>mean was found, however, Meg added to her domestic possessions what



<P>young couples seldom get on long without, a family jar.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fired a with housewifely wish to see her storeroom stocked with



<P>homemade preserves, she undertook to put up her own currant jelly.



<P>John was requested to order home a dozen or so of little pots and an



<P>extra quantity of sugar, for their own currants were ripe and were



<P>to be attended to at once.&nbsp; As John firmly believed that `my wife'



<P>was equal to anything, and took a natural pride in her skill, he



<P>resolved that she should be gratified, and their only crop of fruit



<P>laid by in a most pleasing form for winter use.&nbsp; Home came four



<P>dozen delightful little pots, half a barrel of sugar, and a small



<P>boy to pick the currants for her.&nbsp; With her pretty hair tucked

into



<P>a little cap, arms bared to the elbow, and a checked apron which



<P>had a coquettish look in spite of the bib, the young housewife fell



<P>to work, feeling no doubts about her success, for hadn't she seen



<P>Hannah do it hundreds of times?&nbsp; The array of pots rather amazed

her



<P>at first, but John was so fond of jelly, and the nice little jars



<P>would look so well on the top shelf, that Meg resolved to fill them



<P>all, and spend a long day picking, boiling, straining, and fussing



<P>over her jelly.&nbsp; She did her best, she asked advice of Mrs. Cornelius,



<P>she racked her brain to remember what Hannah did that she left



<P>undone, she reboiled, resugared, and restrained, but that dreadful



<P>stuff wouldn't `jell'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She longed to run home, bib and all, and ask Mother to lend her



<P>a hand, but John and she had agreed that they would never annoy anyone



<P>with their private worries, experiments, or quarrels.&nbsp; They had



<P>laughed over that last word as if the idea it suggested was a most



<P>preposterous one, but they had held to their resolve, and whenever



<P>they could get on without help they did so, and no one interfered,



<P>for Mrs. March had advised the plan.&nbsp; So Meg wrestled alone with

the



<P>refractory sweetmeats all that hot summer day, and at five o'clock



<P>sat down in her topsy-turvey kitchen, wrung her bedaubed hands,



<P>lifted up her voice and wept.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now, in the first flush of the new life, she had often said,



<P>"My husband shall always feel free to bring a friend home whenever



<P>he likes.&nbsp; I shall always be prepared.&nbsp; There shall be no

flurry, no



<P>scolding, no discomfort, but a neat house, a cheerful wife, and a



<P>good dinner.&nbsp; John, dear, never stop to ask my leave, invite whom



<P>you please, and be sure of a welcome from me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How charming that was, to be sure!&nbsp; John quite glowed with



<P>pride to hear her say it, and felt what a blessed thing it was to



<P>have a superior wife.&nbsp; But, although they had had company from

time



<P>to time, it never happened to be unexpected, and Meg had never had



<P>an opportunity to distinguish herself till now.&nbsp; It always happens



<P>so in this vale of tears, there is an inevitability about such things



<P>which we can only wonder at, deplore, and bear as we best can.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If John had not forgotten all about the jelly, it really would



<P>have been unpardonable in him to choose that day, of all the days in



<P>the year, to bring a friend home to dinner unexpectedly.&nbsp; Congratulating



<P>himself that a handsome repast had been ordered that morning,



<P>feeling sure that it would be ready to the minute, and indulging in



<P>pleasant anticipations of the charming effect it would produce, when



<P>his pretty wife came running out to meet him, he escorted his friend



<P>to his mansion, with the irrepressible satisfaction of a young host

and husband.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It is a world of disappointments, as John discovered when he



<P>reached the Dovecote.&nbsp; the front door usually stood hospitably

open.



<P>Now it was not only shut, but locked, and yesterday's mud still



<P>adorned the steps.&nbsp; The parlor windows were closed and curtained,



<P>no picture of the pretty wife sewing on the piazza, in white, with



<P>a distracting little bow in her hair, or a bright-eyed hostess,



<P>smiling a shy welcome as she greeted her guest.&nbsp; Nothing of the

sort,



<P>for not a soul appeared but a sanginary-looking boy asleep under the



<P>current bushes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm afraid something has happened.&nbsp; Step into the garden, Scott,



<P>while I look up Mrs. Brooke," said John, alarmed at the silence and



<P>solitude.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Round the house he hurried, led by a pungent smell of burned



<P>sugar, and Mr. Scott strolled after him, with a queer look on his



<P>face.&nbsp; He paused discreetly at a distance when Brooke disappeared,



<P>but he could both see and hear, and being a bachelor, enjoyed the



<P>prospect mightily.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the kitchen reigned confusion and despair.&nbsp; One edition of



<P>jelly was trickled from pot to pot, another lay upon the floor,



<P>and a third was burning gaily on the stove.&nbsp; Lotty, with Teutonic



<P>phlegm, was calmly eating bread and currant wine, for the jelly was



<P>still in a hopelessly liquid state, while Mrs. Brooke, with her apron



<P>over her head, sat sobbing dismally.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dearest girl, what is the matter?" cried John, rushing in,



<P>with awful visions of scalded hands, sudden news of affliction, and



<P>secret consternation at the thought of the guest in the garden.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, John, I am so tired and hot and cross and worried!&nbsp; I've



<P>been at it till I'm all worn out.&nbsp; Do come and help me or I shall



<P>die!" And the exhausted housewife cast herself upon his breast,



<P>giving him a sweet welcome in every sense of the word, for her



<P>pinafore had been baptized at the same time as the floor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What worries you dear?&nbsp; Has anything dreadful happened?"



<P>asked the anxious John, tenderly kissing the crown of the little



<P>cap, which was all askew.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," sobbed Meg despairingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tell me quick, then.&nbsp; Don't cry.&nbsp; I can bear anything better



<P>than that.&nbsp; Out with it, love."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The...The jelly won't jell and I don't know what to do!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>John Brooke laughed then as he never dared to laugh afterward,



<P>and the derisive Scott smiled involuntarily as he heard the hearty



<P>peal, which put the finishing stroke to poor Meg's woe.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is that all?&nbsp; Fling it out of the window, and don't bother any



<P>more about it.&nbsp; I'll buy you quarts if you want it, but for heaven's



<P>sake don't have hysterics, for I've brought Jack Scott home to dinner,



<P>and..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>John got no further, for Meg cast him off, and clasped her hands



<P>with a tragic gesture as she fell into a chair, exclaiming in a tone



<P>of mingled indignation, reproach, and dismay...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A man to dinner, and everything in a mess!&nbsp; John Brooke, how



<P>could you do such a thing?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hush, he's in the garden!&nbsp; I forgot the confounded jelly, but



<P>it can't be helped now," said John, surveying the prospect with an



<P>anxious eye.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You ought to have sent word, or told me this morning, and you



<P>ought to have remembered how busy I was," continued Meg petulantly,



<P>for even turtledoves will peck when ruffled.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I didn't know it this morning, and there was no time to send



<P>word, for I met him on the way out.&nbsp; I never thought of asking

leave,



<P>when you have always told me to do as I liked.&nbsp; I never tried it

before,



<P>and hang me if I ever do again!" added John, with an aggrieved air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should hope not!&nbsp; Take him away at once.&nbsp; I can't see him,



<P>and there isn't any dinner."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I like that!&nbsp; Where's the beef and vegetables I sent



<P>home, and the pudding you promised?" cried John, rushing to the



<P>larder.



<P>"I hadn't time to cook anything.&nbsp; I meant to dine at Mother's.



<P>I'm sorry, but I was so busy," and Meg's tears began again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>John was a mild man, but he was human, and after a long day's



<P>work to come home tired, hungry, and hopeful, to find a chaotic



<P>house, an empty table, and a cross wife was not exactly conductive



<P>to repose of mind or manner.&nbsp; He restrained himself however, and

the



<P>little squall would have blown over, but for one unlucky word.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's a scrape, I acknowledge, but if you will lend a hand,



<P>we'll pull through and have a good time yet.&nbsp; Don't cry, dear,

but



<P>just exert yourself a bit, and fix us up something to eat.&nbsp; We're



<P>both as hungry as hunters, so we shan't mind what it is.&nbsp; Give

us



<P>the cold meat, and bread and cheese.&nbsp; We won't ask for jelly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He meant it to be a good-natured joke, but that one word sealed



<P>his fate.&nbsp; Meg thought it was too cruel to hint about her sad failure,



<P>and the last atom of patience vanished as he spoke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must get yourself out of the scrape as you can.&nbsp; I'm too



<P>used up to `exert' myself for anyone.&nbsp; It's like a man to propose



<P>a bone and vulgar bread and cheese for company.&nbsp; I won't have anything



<P>of the sort in my house.&nbsp; Take that Scott up to Mother's, and



<P>tell him I'm away, sick, dead, anything.&nbsp; I won't see him, and

you



<P>two can laugh at me and my jelly as much as you like.&nbsp; You won't



<P>have anything else here."&nbsp; And having delivered her defiance all



<P>on one breath, Meg cast away her pinafore and precipitately left the



<P>field to bemoan herself in her own room.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>What those two creatures did in her absence, she never knew,



<P>but Mr. scott was not taken `up to Mother's', and when Meg descended,



<P>after they had strolled away together, she found traces of a promiscuous



<P>lunch which filled her with horror.&nbsp; Lotty reported that they had

eaten



<P>"a much, and greatly laughed, and the master bid her throw away all



<P>the sweet stuff, and hide the pots."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg longed to go and tell Mother, but a sense of shame at her own



<P>short comings, of loyalty to John, "who might be cruel, but nobody



<P>should know it," restrained her, and after a summary cleaning up,



<P>she dressed herself prettily, and sat down to wait for John to



<P>come and be forgiven.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Unfortunately, John didn't come, not seeing the matter in that



<P>light.&nbsp; He had carried it off as a good joke with Scott, excused

his



<P>little wife as well as he could, and played the host so hospitably



<P>that his friend enjoyed the impromptu dinner, and promised to come



<P>again, but John was angry, though he did not show it, he felt that



<P>Meg had deserted him in his hour of need.&nbsp; "It wasn't fair to tell



<P>a man to bring folks home any time, with perfect freedom, and when



<P>he took you at your word, to flame up and blame him, and leave him



<P>in the lurch, to be laughed at or pitied.&nbsp; No, by George, it wasn't!



<P>And Meg must know it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had fumed inwardly during the feast, but when the flurry was



<P>over and he strolled home after seeing Scott off, a milder mood came



<P>over him.&nbsp; "Poor little thing!&nbsp; It was hard upon her when

she tried so



<P>heartily to please me.&nbsp; She was wrong, of course, but then she

was



<P>young.&nbsp; I must be patient and teach her."&nbsp; He hoped she had

not gone



<P>home--he hated gossip and interference.&nbsp; For a minute he was ruffled



<P>again at the mere thought of it, and then the fear that Meg would cry



<P>herself sick softened his heart, and sent him on at a quicker pace,



<P>resolving to be calm and kind, but firm, quite firm, and show her



<P>where she had failed in her duty to her spouse.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg likewise resolved to be `calm and kind, but firm', and show



<P>him his duty.&nbsp; She longed to run to meet him, and beg pardon, and

be



<P>kissed and comforted, as she was sure of being, but, of course, she



<P>did nothing of the sort, and when she saw John coming, began to hum



<P>quite naturally, as she rocked and sewed, like a lady of leisure in



<P>her best parlor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>John was a little disappointed not to find a tender Niobe, but



<P>feeling that his dignity demanded the first apology, he made none,



<P>only came leisurely in and laid himself upon the sofa with the singularly



<P>relevant remark, "We are going to have a new moon, my dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've no objection," was Meg's equally soothing remark.&nbsp; A few



<P>other topics of general interest were introduced by Mr. Brooke and



<P>wet-blanketed by Mrs. Brooke, and conversation languished.&nbsp; John



<P>went to one window, unfolded his paper, and wrapped himself in it,



<P>figuratively speaking.&nbsp; Meg went to the other window, and sewed

as



<P>if new rosettes for slippers were among the necessaries of life.



<P>Neither spoke.&nbsp; Both looked quite `calm and firm', and both felt



<P>desperately uncomfortable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, dear," thought Meg, "married life is very trying, and



<P>does need infinite patience as well as love, as Mother says."&nbsp;

The



<P>word `Mother' suggested other maternal counsels given long ago, and



<P>received with unbelieving protests.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"John is a good man, but he has his faults, and you must learn



<P>to see and bear with them, remembering your own.&nbsp; He is very decided,



<P>but never will be obstinate, if you reason kindly, not oppose impatiently.



<P>He is very accurate, and particular about the truth--a good



<P>trait, though you call him `fussy'.&nbsp; Never deceive him by look

or



<P>word, Meg, and he will give you the confidence you deserve, the



<P>support you need.&nbsp; He has a temper, not like ours--one flash and

then



<P>all over--but the white, still anger that is seldom stirred, but



<P>once kindled is hard to quench.&nbsp; Be careful, be very careful, not

to



<P>wake his anger against yourself, for peace and happiness depend on



<P>keeping his respect.&nbsp; Watch yourself, be the first to ask pardon

if



<P>you both err, and guard against the little piques, misunderstandings,



<P>and hasty words that often pave the way for bitter sorrow and regret."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These words came back to Meg, as she sat sewing in the sunset,



<P>especially the last.&nbsp; This was the first serious disagreement,

her



<P>own hasty speeches sounded both silly and unkind, as she recalled



<P>them, her own anger looked childish now, and thoughts of poor John



<P>coming home to such a scene quite melted her heart.&nbsp; She glanced

at



<P>him with tears in her eyes, but he did not see them.&nbsp; She put down



<P>her work and got up, thinking, "I will be the first to say,



<P>`Forgive me', but he did not seem to hear her.&nbsp; She went very slowly



<P>across the room, for pride was hard to swallow, and stood by him,



<P>but he did not turn his head.&nbsp; For a minute she felt as if she



<P>really couldn't do it, then came the thought, This is the beginning.



<P>I'll do my part, and have nothing to reproach myself with,"



<P>and stooping sown, she softly kissed her husband on the forehead.



<P>Of course that settled it.&nbsp; The penitent kiss was better than a



<P>world of words, and John had her on his knee in a minute, saying



<P>tenderly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was too bad to laugh at the poor little jelly pots.



<P>Forgive me, dear.&nbsp; I never will again!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But he did, oh bless you, yes, hundreds of times, and so did



<P>Meg, both declaring that it was the sweetest jelly they ever made,



<P>for family peace was preserved in that little family jar.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After this, Meg had Mr. Scott to dinner by special invitation,



<P>and served him up a pleasant feast without a cooked wife for the



<P>first course, on which occasion she was so gay and gracious, and



<P>made everything go off so charmingly, that Mr. Scott told John he



<P>was a lucky fellow, and shook his head over the hardships of bachelorhood



<P>all the way home.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the autumn, new trials and experiences came to Meg.&nbsp; Sallie



<P>Moffat renewed her friendship, was always running out for a dish of



<P>gossip at the little house, or inviting `that poor dear' to come in



<P>and spend the day at the big house.&nbsp; It was pleasant, for in dull



<P>weather Meg often felt lonely.&nbsp; All were busy at home, John absent



<P>till night, and nothing to do but sew, or read, or potter about.&nbsp;

So



<P>it naturally fell out that Meg got into the way of gadding and gossiping



<P>with her friend.&nbsp; Seeing Sallie's pretty things made her long for



<P>such, and pity herself because she had not got them.&nbsp; Sallie was

very



<P>kind, and often offered her the coveted trifles, but Meg declined



<P>them, knowing that John wouldn't like it, and then this foolish little



<P>woman went and did what John disliked even worse.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She knew her husband's income, and she loved to feel that he



<P>trusted her, not only with his happiness, but what some men seem to



<P>value more--his money.&nbsp; She knew where it was, was free to take

what



<P>she liked, and all he asked was that she should keep account of every



<P>penny, pay bills once a month, and remember that she was a poor man's



<P>wife.&nbsp; Till now she had done well, been prudent and exact, kept

her



<P>little account books neatly, and showed them to him monthly without



<P>fear.&nbsp; But that autumn the serpent got into Meg's paradise, and

tempted



<P>her like many a modern Eve, not with apples, but with dress.&nbsp; Meg



<P>didn't like to be pitied and made to feel poor.&nbsp; It irritated her,



<P>but she was ashamed to confess it, and now and then she tried to console



<P>herself by buying something pretty, so that Sallie needn't think



<P>she had to economize.&nbsp; She always felt wicked after it, for the

pretty



<P>things were seldom necessaries, but then they cost so little, it wasn't



<P>worth worrying about, so the trifles increased unconsciously, and in



<P>the shopping excursions she was no longer a passive looker-on.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But the trifles cost more than one would imagine, and when she



<P>cast up her accounts at the end of the month the sum total rather



<P>scared her.&nbsp; John was busy that month and left the bills to her,

the



<P>next month he was absent, but the third he had a grand quarterly



<P>settling up, and Meg never forgot it.&nbsp; A few days before she had

done



<P>a dreadful thing, and it weighed upon her conscience.&nbsp; Sallie had



<P>been buying silks, and Meg longed for a new one, just a handsome light



<P>one for parties, her black silk was so common, and thin things for



<P>evening wear were only proper for girls.&nbsp; Aunt March usually gave

the



<P>sisters a present of twenty-five dollars apiece at New Year's.&nbsp;

That



<P>was only a month to wait, and here was a lovely violet silk going at



<P>a bargain, and she had the money, if she only dared to take it.&nbsp;

John



<P>always said what was his was hers, but would he think it right to



<P>spend not only the prospective five-and-twenty, but another



<P>five-and-twenty out of the household fund?&nbsp; That was the question.



<P>Sallie had urged her to do it, had offered to lend the money, and with



<P>the best intentions in life had tempted Meg beyond her strength.



<P>In an evil moment the shopman held up the lovely, shimmering folds,



<P>and said, "A bargain, I assure, you, ma'am." She answered, "I'll take



<P>it," and it was cut off and paid for, and Sallie had exulted, and she



<P>had laughed as if it were a thing of no consequence, and driven away,



<P>feeling as if she had stolen something, and the police were after her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When she got home, she tried to assuage the pangs of remorse



<P>by spreading forth the lovely silk, but it looked less silvery now,



<P>didn't become her, after all, and the words `fifty dollars' seemed



<P>stamped like a pattern down each breadth.&nbsp; She put it away, but

it



<P>haunted her, not delightfully as a new dress should, but dreadfully



<P>like the ghost of a folly that was not easily laid.&nbsp; When John

got



<P>out his books that night, Meg's heart sank, and for the first time



<P>in her married life, she was afraid of her husband.&nbsp; The kind,

brown



<P>eyes looked as if they could be stern, and though he was unusually



<P>merry, she fancied he had found her out, but didn't mean to let her



<P>know it.&nbsp; The house bills were all paid, the books all in order.



<P>John had praised her, and was undoing the old pocketbook which they



<P>called the `bank', when Meg, knowing that it was quite empty, stopped



<P>his hand, saying nervously...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You haven't seen my private expense book yet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>John never asked to see it, but she always insisted on his doing



<P>so, and used to enjoy his masculine amazement at the queer things women



<P>wanted, and made him guess what piping was, demand fiercely the meaning



<P>of a hug-me-tight, or wonder how a little thing composed of three



<P>rosebuds, a bit of velvet, and a pair of strings, could possibly be



<P>a bonnet, and cost six dollars.&nbsp; That night he looked as if he

would



<P>like the fun of quizzing her figures and pretending to be horrified



<P>at her extravagance, as he often did, being particularly proud of



<P>his prudent wife.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The little book was brought slowly out and laid down before him.



<P>Meg got behind his chair under pretense of smoothing the wrinkles



<P>out of his tired forehead, and standing there, she said, with her



<P>panic increasing with every word .&nbsp; ..

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"John, dear, I'm ashamed to show you my book, for I've really



<P>been dreadfully extravagant lately.&nbsp; I go about so much I must

have



<P>things, you know, and Sallie advised my getting it, so I did, and



<P>my New Year's money will partly pay for it, but I was sorry after



<P>I had done it, for I knew you'd think it wrong in me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>John laughed, and drew her round beside him, saying goodhumoredly,



<P>"Don't go and hide.&nbsp; I won't beat you if you have got



<P>a pair of killing boots.&nbsp; I'm rather proud of my wife's feet, and



<P>don't mind if she does pay eight or nine dollars for her boots, if



<P>they are good ones."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That had been one of her last `trifles', and John's eye had



<P>fallen on it as he spoke.&nbsp; "Oh, what will he say when he comes

to



<P>that awful fifty dollars!" thought Meg, with a shiver.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's worse than boots, it's a silk dress," she said, with the



<P>calmness of desperation, for she wanted the worst over.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, dear, what is the `dem'd total', as Mr. Mantalini says?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That didn't sound like John, and she knew he was looking up at



<P>her with the straightforward look that she had always been ready to



<P>meet and answer with one as frank till now.&nbsp; She turned the page

and



<P>her head at the same time, pointing to the sum which would have been



<P>bad enough without the fifty, but which was appalling to her with



<P>that added.&nbsp; For a minute the room was very still, then John said



<P>slowly--but she could feel it cost him an effort to express no



<P>displeasure--. . .

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I don't know that fifty is much for a dress, with all the



<P>furbelows and notions you have to have to finish it off these days."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It isn't made or trimmed," sighed Meg, faintly, for a sudden



<P>recollection of the cost still to be incurred quite overwhelmed her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Twenty-five yards of silk seems a good deal to cover one small



<P>woman, but I've no doubt my wife will look as fine as Ned Moffat's



<P>when she gets it on," said John dryly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know you are angry, John, but I can't help it.&nbsp; I don't mean



<P>to waste your money, and I didn't think those little things would



<P>count up so.&nbsp; I can't resist them when I see Sallie buying all

she



<P>wants, and pitying me because I don't.&nbsp; I try to be contented,

but



<P>it is hard, and I'm tired of being poor."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The last words were spoken so low she thought he did not hear



<P>them, but he did, and they wounded him deeply, for he had denied



<P>himself many pleasures for Meg's sake.&nbsp; She could have bitten her



<P>tongue out the minute she had said it, for John pushed the books



<P>away and got up, saying with a little quiver in his voice, "I was



<P>afraid of this.&nbsp; I do my best, Meg."&nbsp; If he had scolded her,

or



<P>even shaken her, it would not have broken her heart like those few



<P>words.&nbsp; She ran to him and held him close, crying, with repentant



<P>tears, "Oh, John, my dear, kind, hard-working boy.&nbsp; I didn't mean



<P>it!&nbsp; It was so wicked, so untrue and ungrateful, how could I say

it!



<P>Oh, how could I say it!"



<P>He was very kind, forgave her readily, and did not utter one



<P>reproach, but Meg knew that she had done and said a thing which



<P>would not be forgotten soon, although he might never allude to it



<P>again.&nbsp; She had promised to love him for better or worse, and then



<P>she, his wife, had reproached him with his poverty, after spending



<P>his earnings recklessly.&nbsp; It was dreadful, and the worst of it

was



<P>John went on so quietly afterward, just as if nothing had happened,



<P>except that he stayed in town later, and worked at night when she



<P>had gone to cry herself to sleep.&nbsp; A week or remorse nearly made



<P>Meg sick, and the discovery that John had countermanded the order



<P>for his new greatcoat reduced her to a state of despair which was



<P>pathetic to behold.&nbsp; He had simply said, in answer to her surprised



<P>inquiries as to the change, "I can't afford it, my dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg said no more, but a few minutes after he found her in the



<P>hall with her face buried in the old greatcoat, crying as if her



<P>heart would break.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They had a long talk that night, and Meg learned to love her



<P>husband better for his poverty, because it seemed to have made a



<P>man of him, given him the strength and courage to fight his own way,



<P>and taught him a tender patience with which to bear and comfort



<P>the natural longings and failures of those he loved.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Next day she put her pride in her pocket, went to Sallie, told



<P>the truth, and asked her to buy the silk as a favor.&nbsp; The good-



<P>natured Mrs. Moffat willingly did so, and had the delicacy not to



<P>make her a present of it immediately afterward.&nbsp; Then Meg ordered



<P>home the greatcoat, and when John arrived, she put it on, and asked



<P>him how he liked her new silk gown.&nbsp; One can imagine what answer

he



<P>made, how he received his present, and what a blissful state of



<P>things ensued.&nbsp; John came home early, Meg gadded no more, and that



<P>greatcoat was put on in the morning by a very happy husband, and



<P>taken off at night by a most devoted little wife.&nbsp; So the year



<P>rolled round, and at midsummer there came to Meg a new experience,



<P>the deepest and tenderest of a woman's life.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie came sneaking into the kitchen of the Dovecote one



<P>Saturday, with an excited face, and was received with the clash



<P>of cymbals, for Hannah clapped her hands with a saucepan in one



<P>and the cover in the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How's the little mamma?&nbsp; Where is everybody?&nbsp; Why didn't



<P>you tell me before I came home?" began Laurie in a loud whisper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Happy as a queen, the dear!&nbsp; Every soul of `em is upstairs



<P>a worshipin'.&nbsp; We didn't want no hurrycanes round.&nbsp; Now you

go



<P>into the parlor, and I'll send `em down to you," with which



<P>somewhat involved reply Hannah vanished, chuckling ecstatically.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Presently Jo appeared, proudly bearing a flannel bundle laid



<P>forth upon a large pillow.&nbsp; Jo's face was very sober, but her eyes



<P>twinkled, and there was an odd sound in her voice of repressed



<P>emotion of some sort.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shut your eyes and hold out your arms," she said invitingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie backed precipitately into a corner, and put his hands



<P>behind him with an imploring gesture.&nbsp; "No, thank you.&nbsp; I'd

rather



<P>not.&nbsp; I shall drop it or smash it, as sure as fate."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then you shan't see your nevvy," said Jo decidedly, turning



<P>as if to go.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will, I will!&nbsp; Only you must be responsible for damages."



<P>And obeying orders, Laurie heroically shut his eyes while something



<P>was put into his arms.&nbsp; A peal of laughter from Jo, Amy,



<P>Mrs. March, Hannah, and John caused him to open them the next



<P>minute, to find himself invested with two babies instead of one.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No wonder they laughed, for the expression of his face was



<P>droll enough to convulse a Quaker, as he stood and stared wildly



<P>from the unconscious innocents to the hilarious spectators with



<P>such dismay that Jo sat down on the floor and screamed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Twins, by Jupiter!" was all he said for a minute, then



<P>turning to the women with an appealing look that was comically



<P>piteous, he added, "Take `em quick, somebody!&nbsp; I'm going to



<P>laugh, and I shall drop `em."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo rescued his babies, and marched up and down, with one



<P>on each are, as if already initiated into the mysteries of babytending,



<P>while Laurie laughed till the tears ran down his cheeks.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's the best joke of the season, isn't it?&nbsp; I wouldn't have



<P>told you, for I set my heart on surprising you, and I flatter



<P>myself I've done it," said Jo, when she got her breath.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never was more staggered in my life.&nbsp; Isn't it fun?&nbsp; Are

they boys?



<P>What are you going to name them?&nbsp; Let's have another look.&nbsp;

Hold me up,



<P>Jo, for upon my life it's one too many for me," returned Laurie,



<P>regarding the infants with the air of a big,&nbsp; benevolent Newfoundland



<P>looking at a pair of infantile kittens.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Boy and girl.&nbsp; Aren't they beauties?" said the proud papa,



<P>beaming upon the little red squirmers as if they were unfledged angels.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Most remarkable children I ever saw.&nbsp; Which is which?" and



<P>Laurie bent like a well-sweep to examine the prodigies.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Amy put a blue ribbon on the boy and a pink on the girl,



<P>French fashion, so you can always tell.&nbsp; Besides, one has blue



<P>eyes and one brown.&nbsp; Kiss them, Uncle Teddy," said wicked Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm afraid they mightn't like it," began Laurie, with unusual



<P>timidity in such matters.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course they will, they are used to it now.&nbsp; Do it this



<P>minute, sir!" commanded Jo, fearing he might propose a proxy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie screwed up his face and obeyed with a gingerly peck



<P>at each little cheek that produced another laugh, and made the



<P>babies squeal.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There, I knew they didn't like it!&nbsp; That's the boy, see



<P>him kick, he hits out with his fists like a good one.&nbsp; Now then,



<P>young Brooke, pitch into a man of your own size, will you?" cried



<P>Laurie, delighted with a poke in the face from a tiny fist, flapping



<P>aimlessly about.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He's to be named John Laurence, and the girl Margaret, after



<P>mother and grandmother.&nbsp; We shall call her Daisey, so as not to



<P>have two Megs, and I suppose the mannie will be Jack, unless we



<P>find a better name," said Amy, with aunt-like interest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Name him Demijohn, and call him Demi for short," said Laurie

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Daisy and Demi, just the thing!&nbsp; I knew Teddy would do it,"



<P>cried Jo clapping her hands.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Teddy certainly had done it that time, for the babies were



<P>`Daisy' and `Demi' to the end of the chapter.



<P>
