</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 38</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER THIRTY-EIGHT</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In France the young girls have a dull time of it till they are



<P>married, when `Vive la liberte!' becomes their motto.&nbsp; In America,



<P>as everyone knows, girls early sign the declaration of independence,



<P>and enjoy their freedom with republican zest, but the young matrons



<P>usually abdicate with the first heir to the throne and go into a



<P>seclusion almost as close as a French nunnery, though by no means



<P>as quiet.&nbsp; Whether they like it or not, they are virtually put



<P>upon the shelf as soon as the wedding excitement is over, and most



<P>of them might exclaim, as did a very pretty woman the other day,



<P>"I'm as handsome as ever, but no one takes any notice of me because



<P>I'm married."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Not being a belle or even a fashionable lady, Meg did not



<P>experience this affliction till her babies were a year old,



<P>for in her little world primitive customs prevailed, and she



<P>found herself more admired and beloved than ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she was a womanly little woman, the maternal instinct



<P>was very strong, and she was entirely absorbed in her children,



<P>to the utter exclusion of everything and everybody else.&nbsp; Day



<P>and night she brooded over them with tireless devotion and



<P>anxiety, leaving John to the tender mercies of the help, for



<P>an Irish lady now presided over the kitchen department.&nbsp; Being



<P>a domestic man, John decidedly missed the wifely attentions he



<P>had been accustomed to receive, but as he adored his babies, he



<P>cheerfully relinquished his comfort for a time, supposing with



<P>masculine ignorance that peace would soon be restored.&nbsp; But



<P>three months passed, and there was no return of repose.&nbsp; Meg



<P>looked worn and nervous, the babies absorbed every minute of



<P>her time, the house was neglected, and Kitty, the cook, who took



<P>life `aisy', kept him on short commons.&nbsp; When he went out in



<P>the morning he was bewildered by small commissions for the captive



<P>mamma, if he came gaily in at night, eager to embrace his



<P>family, he was quenched by a "Hush!&nbsp; They are just asleep after



<P>worrying all day."&nbsp; If he proposed a little amusement at home,



<P>"No, it would disturb the babies."&nbsp; If he hinted at a lecture



<P>or a concert, he was answered with a reproachful look, and a



<P>decided "Leave my children for pleasure, never!"&nbsp; His sleep was



<P>broken by infant wails and visions of a phantom figure pacing



<P>noiselessly to and fro in the watches of the night.&nbsp; His meals



<P>were interrupted by the frequent flight of the presiding genius,



<P>who deserted him, half-helped, if a muffled chirp sounded from



<P>the nest above.&nbsp; And when he read his paper of an evening,



<P>Demi's colic got into the shipping list and Daisy's fall affected



<P>the price of stocks, for Mrs. Brooke was only interested in domestic

news.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The poor man was very uncomfortable, for the children had



<P>bereft him of his wife, home was merely a nursery and the perpetual



<P>`hushing' made him feel like a brutal intruder whenever



<P>he entered the sacred precincts of Babyland.&nbsp; He bore it very



<P>patiently for six months, and when no signs of amendment appeared,



<P>he did what other paternal exiles do--tried to get a little comfort



<P>elsewhere.&nbsp; Scott had married and gone to housekeeping not



<P>far off, and John fell into the way of running over for an hour



<P>or two of an evening, when his own parlor was empty, and his



<P>own wife singing lullabies that seemed to have no end.&nbsp; Mrs.



<P>Scott was a lively, pretty girl, with nothing to do but be



<P>agreeable, and she performed her mission most successfully.&nbsp; The



<P>parlor was always bright and attractive, the chessboard ready,



<P>the piano in tune, plenty of gay gossip, and a nice little supper



<P>set forth in tempting style.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>John would have preferred his own fireside if it had not



<P>been so lonely, but as it was he gratefully took the next best



<P>thing and enjoyed his neighbor's society.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg rather approved of the new arrangement at first, and



<P>found it a relief to know that John was having a good time



<P>instead of dozing in the parlor, or tramping about the house



<P>and waking the children.&nbsp; But by-and-by, when the teething



<P>worry was over and the idols went to sleep at proper hours,



<P>leaving Mamma time to rest, she began to miss John, and find



<P>her workbasket dull company, when he was not sitting opposite



<P>in his old dressing gown, comfortably scorching his slippers



<P>on the fender.&nbsp; She would not ask him to stay at home, but felt



<P>injured because he did not know that she wanted him without



<P>being told, entirely forgetting the many evenings he had waited



<P>for her in vain.&nbsp; She was nervous and worn out with watching



<P>and worry, and in that unreasonable frame of mind which the best



<P>of mothers occasionally experience when domestic cares oppress



<P>them.&nbsp; Want of exercise robs them of cheerfulness, and too much



<P>devotion to that idol of American women, the teapot, makes them



<P>feel as if they were all nerve and no muscle.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," she would say, looking in the glass, "I'm getting



<P>old and ugly.&nbsp; John doesn't find me interesting any longer, so



<P>he leaves his faded wife and goes to see his pretty neighbor,



<P>who has no incumbrances.&nbsp; Well, the babies love me, they don't



<P>care if I am thin and pale and haven't time to crimp my hair,



<P>they are my comfort, and some day John will see what I've



<P>gladly sacrificed for them, won't he, my precious?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To which pathetic appeal daisy would answer with a coo,



<P>or Demi with a crow, and Meg would put by her lamentations for



<P>a maternal revel, which soothed her solitude for the time being.



<P>But the pain increased as politics absorbed John, who was always



<P>running over to discuss interesting points with Scott, quite



<P>unconscious that Meg missed him.&nbsp; Not a word did she say, however,



<P>till her mother found her in tears one day, and insisted



<P>on knowing what the matter was, for Meg's drooping spirits had



<P>not escaped her observation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wouldn't tell anyone except you, Mother, but I really



<P>do need advice, for if John goes on much longer I might as well



<P>be widowed," replied Mrs. Brooke, drying her tears on Daisy's



<P>bib with an injured air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Goes on how, my dear?" asked her mother anxiously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He's away all day, and at night when I want to see him,



<P>he is continually going over to the Scotts'.&nbsp; It isn't fair



<P>that I should have the hardest work, and never any amusement.



<P>Men are very selfish, even the best of them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So are women.&nbsp; Don't blame John till you see where you



<P>are wrong yourself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But it can't be right for him to neglect me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't you neglect him?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, Mother, I thought you'd take my part!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So I do, as far as sympathizing goes, but I think the fault



<P>is yours, Meg."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't see how."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let me show you.&nbsp; Did John ever neglect you, as you call it,



<P>while you made it a point to give him your society of an evening,



<P>his only leisure time?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, but I can't do it now, with two babies to tend."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think you could, dear, and I think you ought.&nbsp; May I



<P>speak quite freely, and will you remember that it's Mother who



<P>blames as well as Mother who sympathizes?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed I will!&nbsp; Speak to me as if I were little Meg again.



<P>I often feel as if I needed teaching more than ever since these



<P>babies look to me for everything."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg drew her low chair beside her mother's, and with a little



<P>interruption in either lap, the two women rocked and talked lovingly



<P>together, feeling that the tie of motherhood made them more one



<P>than ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have only made the mistake that most young wives make-forgotten



<P>your duty to your husband in your love for your children.



<P>A very natural and forgivable mistake, Meg, but one that



<P>had better be remedied before you take to different ways, for



<P>children should draw you nearer than ever, not separate you, as



<P>if they were all yours, and John had nothing to do but support



<P>them.&nbsp; I've seen it for some weeks, but have not spoken, feeling



<P>sure it would come right in time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm afraid it won't.&nbsp; If I ask him to stay, he'll think I'm



<P>jealous, and I wouldn't insult him by such an idea.&nbsp; He doesn't



<P>see that I want him, and I don't know how to tell him without



<P>words."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Make it so pleasant he won't want to go away.&nbsp; My dear,



<P>he's longing for his little home, but it isn't home without you,



<P>and you are always in the nursery."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oughtn't I to be there?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not all the time, too much confinement makes you nervous,



<P>and then you are unfitted for everything.&nbsp; Besides, you owe



<P>something to John as well as to the babies.&nbsp; Don't neglect husband



<P>for children, don't shut him out of the nursery, but teach



<P>him how to help in it.&nbsp; His place is there as well as yours, and



<P>the children need him.&nbsp; Let him feel that he has a part to do,

and



<P>he will do it gladly and faithfully, and it will be better for you



<P>all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You really think so, Mother?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know it, Meg, for I've tried it, and I seldom give advice



<P>unless I've proved its practicability.&nbsp; When you and Jo were little,



<P>I went on just as you are, feeling as if I didn't do my duty unless



<P>I devoted myself wholly to you.&nbsp; Poor Father took to his books,



<P>after I had refused all offers of help, and left me to try my experiment



<P>alone.&nbsp; I struggled along as well as I could, but Jo was



<P>too much for me.&nbsp; I nearly spoiled her by indulgence.&nbsp; You

were



<P>poorly, and I worried about you till I fell sick myself.&nbsp; Then



<P>Father came to the rescue, quietly managed everything, and made



<P>himself so helpful that I saw my mistake, and never have been able



<P>to got on without him since.&nbsp; That is the secret of our home happiness.



<P>He does not let business wean him from the little cares



<P>and duties that affect us all, and I try not to let domestic worries



<P>destroy my interest in his pursuits.&nbsp; Each do our part alone in



<P>many things, but at home we work together, always."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is so, Mother, and my great wish is to be to my husband



<P>and children what you have been to yours.&nbsp; Show me how, I'll do



<P>anything you say."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You were always my docile daughter.&nbsp; Well, dear, if I were



<P>you, I'd let John have more to do with the management of Demi,



<P>for the boy needs training, and it's none too soon to begin.



<P>Then I'd do what I have often proposed, let Hannah come and



<P>help you.&nbsp; She is a capital nurse, and you may trust the precious



<P>babies to her while you do more housework.&nbsp; You need the exercise,



<P>Hannah would enjoy the rest, and John would find his wife again.



<P>Go out more, keep cheerful as well as busy, for you are the



<P>sunshine-maker of the family, and if you get dismal there is no



<P>fair weather.&nbsp; Then I'd try to take an interest in whatever John



<P>likes--talk with him, let him read to you, exchange ideas, and



<P>help each other in that way.&nbsp; Don't shut yourself up in a bandbox



<P>because you are a woman, but understand what is going on, and



<P>educate yourself to take your part in the world's work, for it



<P>all affects you and yours."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"John is so sensible, I'm afraid he will think I'm stupid if



<P>I ask questions about politics and things."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't believe he would.&nbsp; Love covers a multitude of sins,



<P>and of whom could you ask more freely than of him?&nbsp; Try it, and



<P>see if he doesn't find your society far more agreeable than Mrs.



<P>Scott's suppers."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will.&nbsp; Poor John!&nbsp; I'm afraid I have neglected him sadly,



<P>but I thought I was right, and he never said anything."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He tried not to be selfish, but he has felt rather forlorn,



<P>I fancy.&nbsp; This is just the time, Meg, when young married people



<P>are apt to grow apart, and the very time when they ought to be



<P>most together, for the first tenderness soon wears off, unless



<P>care is taken to preserve it.&nbsp; And no time is so beautiful and



<P>precious to parents as the first years of the little lives



<P>given to them to train.&nbsp; Don't let John be a stranger to the



<P>babies, for they will do more to keep him safe and happy in



<P>this world of trial and temptation than anything else, and



<P>through them you will learn to know and love one another as



<P>you should.&nbsp; Now, dear, good-by.&nbsp; Think over Mother's preachment,



<P>act upon it if it seems good, and God bless you all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg did think it over, found it good, and acted upon it,



<P>though the first attempt was not made exactly as she planned



<P>to have it.&nbsp; Of course the children tyrannized over her, and



<P>ruled the house as soon as they found out that kicking and



<P>squalling brought them whatever they wanted.&nbsp; Mamma was an



<P>abject slave to their caprices, but Papa was not so easily



<P>subjugated, and occasionally afflicted his tender spouse by



<P>an attempt at paternal discipline with his obstreperous son.



<P>For Demi inherited a trifle of his sire's firmness of character,



<P>we won't call it obstinacy, and when he made up his



<P>little to have or to do anything, all the king's horses and



<P>all the king's men could not change that pertinacious little



<P>mind.&nbsp; Mamma thought the dear too young to be taught to conquer



<P>his prejudices, but Papa believed that it never was too



<P>soon to learn obedience.&nbsp; So Master Demi early discovered that



<P>when he undertook to `wrastle' with `Parpar', he always got



<P>the worst of it, yet like the Englishman, baby respected the



<P>man who conquered him, and loved the father whose grave "No,



<P>no," was more impressive than all Mamma's love pats.



<P>A few days after the talk with her mother, Meg resolved



<P>to try a social evening with John, so she ordered a nice



<P>supper, set the parlor in order, dressed herself prettily, and



<P>put the children to bed early, that nothing should interfere



<P>with her experiment.&nbsp; But unfortunately Demi's most unconquerable



<P>prejudice was against going to bed, and that night he decided



<P>to go on a rampage.&nbsp; So poor Meg sang and rocked,



<P>told stories and tried every sleep-prevoking wile she could



<P>devise, but all in vain, the big eyes wouldn't shut, and long



<P>after Daisy had gone to byelow, like the chubby little bunch



<P>of good nature she was, naughty Demi lay staring at the light,



<P>with the most discouragingly wide-awake expression of countenance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Will Demi lie still like a good boy, while Mamma runs



<P>down and gives poor Papa his tea?" asked Meg, as the hall



<P>door softly closed, and the well-known step went tip-toeing



<P>into the dining room.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me has tea!" said Demi, preparing to join in the revel.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, but I'll save you some little cakies for breakfast,



<P>if you'll go bye-by like Daisy.&nbsp; Will you, lovey?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Iss!" and Demi shut his eyes tight, as if to catch sleep



<P>and hurry the desired day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Taking advantage of the propitious moment, Meg slipped



<P>away and ran down to greet her husband with a smiling face



<P>and the little blue bow in her hair which was his especial



<P>admiration.&nbsp; He saw it at once and said with pleased surprise,



<P>"Why, little mother, how gay we are tonight.&nbsp; Do you expect



<P>company?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Only you, dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I'm tired of being dowdy, so I dressed up as a



<P>change.&nbsp; You always make yourself nice for table, no matter



<P>how tired you are, so why shouldn't I when I have the time?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do it out of respect for you, my dear," said old-fashioned John.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ditto, ditto, Mr. Brooke," laughed Meg, looking young



<P>and pretty again, as she nodded to him over the teapot.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, it's altogether delightful, and like old times.&nbsp; This



<P>tastes right.&nbsp; I drink your health, dear."&nbsp; And John sipped

his



<P>tea with an air of reposeful rapture, which was of very short



<P>duration however, for as he put down his cup, the door handle



<P>rattled mysteriously, and a little voice was heard, saying impatiently



<P>...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Opy doy.&nbsp; Me's tummin!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's that naughty boy.&nbsp; I told him to go to sleep alone,



<P>and here he is, downstairs, getting his death a-cold pattering



<P>over that canvas," said Meg, answering the call.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mornin' now," announced Demi in joyful tone as he entered,



<P>with his long nightgown gracefully festooned over his arm and



<P>every curl bobbing gayly as he pranced about the table, eyeing



<P>the `cakies' with loving glances.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, it isn't morning yet.&nbsp; You must go to bed, and not



<P>trouble poor Mamma.&nbsp; Then you can have the little cake with



<P>sugar on it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me loves Parpar," said the artful one, preparing to climb



<P>the paternal knee and revel in forbidden joys.&nbsp; But John shook



<P>his head, and said to Meg...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you told him to stay up there, and go to sleep alone,



<P>make him do it, or he will never learn to mind you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, of course.&nbsp; Come, Demi."&nbsp; And Meg led her son away,



<P>feeling a strong desire to spank the little marplot who hopped



<P>beside her, laboring under the delusion that the bribe was to



<P>be administered as soon as they reached the nursery.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nor was he disappointed, for that shortsighted woman



<P>actually gave him a lump of sugar, tucked him into his bed,



<P>and forbade any more promenades till morning.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Iss!" said Demi the perjured, blissfully sucking his sugar,



<P>and regarding his first attempt as eminently successful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg returned to her place, and supper was progressing



<P>pleasantly, when the little ghost walked again and exposed



<P>the maternal delinquencies by boldly demanding, "More sudar,



<P>Marmar."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now this won't do," said John, hardening his heart against



<P>the engaging little sinner.&nbsp; "We shall never know any peace till



<P>that child learns togo to bed properly.&nbsp; You have made a slave

of



<P>yourself long enough.&nbsp; Give him one lesson, and then there will



<P>be an end of it.&nbsp; Put him in his bed and leave him, Meg."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He won't stay there, he never does unless I sit by him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll manage him.&nbsp; Demi, go upstairs, and get into your bed,



<P>as Mamma bids you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"S'ant!" replied the young rebel, helping himself to the



<P>coveted `cakie', and beginning to eat the same with calm audacity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must never say that to Papa.&nbsp; I shall carry you if you



<P>don't go yourself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Go 'way, me don't love Parpar."&nbsp; And Demi retired to his



<P>mother's skirts for protection.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But even that refuge proved unavailing, for he was delivered



<P>over to the enemy, with a "Be gentle with him, John,"



<P>which struck the culprit with dismay, for when Mamma deserted



<P>him, then the judgment day was at hand.&nbsp; Bereft of his cake,



<P>defrauded of his frolic, and borne away by a strong hand to



<P>that detested bed, poor Demi could not restrain his wrath, but



<P>openly defied Papa, and kicked and screamed lustily all the



<P>way upstairs.&nbsp; The minute he was put into bed on one side, he



<P>rolled out on the other, and made for the door, only to be



<P>ignominiously caught up by the tail of his little toga and



<P>put back again, which lively performance was kept up till the



<P>young man's strength gave out, when he devoted himself to



<P>roaring at the top of his voice.&nbsp; This vocal exercise usually



<P>conquered Meg, but John sat as unmoved as the post which is



<P>popularly believed to be deaf.&nbsp; No coaxing, no sugar, no



<P>lullaby, no story, even the light was put out and only the



<P>red glow of the fire enlivened the `big dark' which Demi



<P>regarded with curiosity rather than fear.&nbsp; This new order



<P>of things disgusted him, and he howled dismally for `Marmar',



<P>as his angry passions subsided, and recollections of his



<P>tender bondwoman returned to the captive autocrat.&nbsp; The



<P>plaintive wail which succeeded the passionate roar went to



<P>Meg's heart, and she ran up to say beseechingly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let me stay with him, he'll be good now, John."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, my dear.&nbsp; I've told him he must go to sleep, as you



<P>bid him, and he must, if I stay here all night."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But he'll cry himself sick," pleaded Meg, reproaching herself



<P>for deserting her boy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, he won't, he's so tired he will soon drop off and then



<P>the matter is settled, for he will understand that he has got to



<P>mind.&nbsp; Don't interfere, I'll manage him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He's my child, and I can't have his spirit broken by harshness."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He's my child, and I won't have his temper spoiled by



<P>indulgence.&nbsp; Go down, my dear, and leave the boy to me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When John spoke in that masterful tone, Meg always obeyed,



<P>and never regretted her docility.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Please let me kiss him once, John?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly.&nbsp; Demi, say good night to Mamma, and let her go and

rest,



<P>for she is very tired with taking care of you all day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg always insisted upon it that the kiss won the victory,



<P>for after it was given, Demi sobbed more quietly, and lay quite



<P>still at the bottom of the bed, whither he had wriggled in his



<P>anguish of mind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor little man, he's worn out with sleep and crying.&nbsp; I'll



<P>cover him up, and then go and set Meg's heart at rest." thought



<P>John, creeping to the bedside, hoping to find his rebellious



<P>heir asleep.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But he wasn't, for the moment his father peeped at him,



<P>Demi's eyes opened, his little chin began to quiver, and he put



<P>up his arms, saying with a penitent hiccough, "Me's dood, now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sitting on the stairs outside Meg wondered at the long



<P>silence which followed the uproar, and after imagining all



<P>sorts of impossible accidents, she slipped into the room to



<P>set her fears at rest.&nbsp; Demi lay fast asleep, not in his usual



<P>spreadeagle attitude, but in a subdued bunch, cuddled close in



<P>the circle of his father's arm and holding his father's finger,



<P>as if he felt that justice was tempered with mercy, and had



<P>gone to sleep a sadder and wiser baby.&nbsp; So held, John had waited



<P>with a womanly patience till the little hand relaxed its hold,



<P>and while waiting had fallen asleep, more tired by that tussle



<P>with his son than with his whole day's work.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As Meg stood watching the two faces on the pillow, she



<P>smiled to herself, and then slipped away again, saying in a



<P>satisfied tone, "I never need fear that John will be too harsh



<P>with my babies.&nbsp; He does know how to manage them, and will be



<P>a great help, for Demi is getting too much for me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When John came down at last, expecting to find a pensive



<P>or reproachful wife, he was agreeably surprised to find Meg



<P>placidly trimming a bonnet, and to be greeted with the request



<P>to read something about the election, if he was not



<P>too tired.&nbsp; John saw in a minute that a revolution of some



<P>kind was going on, but wisely asked no questions, knowing



<P>that Meg was such a transparent little person, she couldn't



<P>keep a secret to save her life, and therefore the clue would



<P>soon appear.&nbsp; He read a long debate with the most amiable



<P>readiness and then explained it in his most lucid manner,



<P>while Meg tried to look deeply interested, to ask intelligent



<P>questions, and keep her thoughts from wandering from the



<P>state of the nation to the state of her bonnet.&nbsp; In her secret



<P>soul, however, she decided that politics were as bad as mathematics,



<P>and the the mission of politicians seemed to be calling



<P>each other names, but she kept these feminine ideas to herself,



<P>and when John paused, shook her head and said with what she



<P>thought diplomatic ambiguity, "Well, I really don't see what



<P>we are coming to."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>John laughed, and watched her for a minute, as she poised



<P>a pretty little preparation of lace and flowers on her hand,



<P>and regarded it with the genuine interest which his harangue



<P>had failed to waken.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She is trying to like politics for my sake, so I'll try and



<P>like millinery for hers, that's only fair," thought John the Just,



<P>adding aloud, "That's very pretty.&nbsp; Is it what you call a breakfast

cap?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear man, it's a bonnet!&nbsp;&nbsp; My very best go-to-concert-and-theater

bonnet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I beg your pardon, it was so small, I naturally mistook



<P>it for one of the flyaway things you sometimes wear.



<P>How do you keep it on?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"These bits of lace are fastened under the chin with a rosebud, so."



<P>And Meg illustrated by putting on the bonnet and regarding



<P>him with an air of calm satisfaction that was irresistible.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's a love of a bonnet, but I prefer the face inside, for



<P>it looks young and happy again."&nbsp; And John kissed the smiling



<P>face, to the great detriment of the rosebud under the chin.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad you like it, for I want you to take me to one



<P>of the new concerts some night.&nbsp; I really need some music to



<P>put me in tune.&nbsp; Will you, please?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course I will, with all my heart, or anywhere else you



<P>like.&nbsp; You have been shut up so long, it will do you no end of



<P>good, and I shall enjoy it, of all things.&nbsp; What put it into



<P>your head, little mother?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I had a talk with Marmee the other day, and told



<P>her how nervous and cross and out of sorts I felt, and she



<P>said I needed change and less care, so Hannah is to help me



<P>with the children, and I'm to see to things about the house more,



<P>and now and then have a little fun, just to keep me from getting



<P>to be a fidgety, broken-down old woman before my time.&nbsp; It's



<P>only an experiment, John, and I want to try it for your sake



<P>as much as for mine, because I've neglected you shamefully



<P>lately, and I'm going to make home what it used to be, if I



<P>can.&nbsp; You don't object, I hope?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Never mind what John said, or what a very narrow escape



<P>the little bonnet had from utter ruin.&nbsp; All that we have any



<P>business to know is that John did not appear to object, judging



<P>from the changes which gradually took place in the house



<P>and its inmates.&nbsp; It was not all Paradise by any means, but



<P>everyone was better for the division of labor system.&nbsp; The



<P>children throve under the paternal rule, for accurate, stedfast



<P>John brought order and obedience into Babydom, while Meg



<P>recovered her spirits and composed her nerves by plenty of



<P>wholesome exercise, a little pleasure, and much confidential



<P>conversation with her sensible husband.&nbsp; Home grew homelike



<P>again, and John had no wish to leave it, unless he took Meg



<P>with him.&nbsp; The Scotts came to the Brookes' now, and everyone



<P>found the little house a cheerful place, full of happiness,



<P>content, and family love.&nbsp; Even Sallie Moffatt liked to go



<P>there.&nbsp; "It is always so quiet and pleasant here, it does me



<P>good, Meg," she used to say, looking about her with wistful



<P>eyes, as if trying to discover the charm, that she might use



<P>it in her great house, full of splendid lonliness, for there



<P>were no riotous, sunny-faced babies there, and Ned lived in



<P>a world of lis own, where there was no place for her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This household happiness did not come all at once, but



<P>John and Meg had found the key to it, and each year of Married



<P>life taught them how to use it, unlocking the treasuries



<P>of real home love and mutual helpfulness, which the poorest



<P>may possess, and the richest cannot buy.&nbsp; This is the sort



<P>of shelf on which young wives and mothers may consent to be



<P>laid, safe from the restless fret and fever of the world,



<P>finding loyal lovers in the little sons and daughters who



<P>cling to them, undaunted by sorrow, poverty, or age, walking



<P>side by side, through fair and stormy weather, with a faithful



<P>friend, who is, in the true sense of the good old Saxon word,



<P>the `house-band', and learning, as Meg learned, that a woman's



<P>happiest kingdom is home, her highest honor the art of ruling



<P>it not as a queen, but as a wise wife and mother.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.03 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 04</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FOUR</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, dear, how hard it does seem to take up our packs



<P>and go on," sighed Meg the morning after the party, for now



<P>the holidays were over, the week of merrymaking did not fit



<P>her for going on easily with the task she never liked.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish it was Christmas or New Year's all the time.



<P>Wouldn't it be fun?" answered Jo, yawning dismally.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We shouldn't enjoy ourselves half so much as we do now.



<P>But it does seem so nice to have little suppers and bouquets,



<P>and go to parties, and drive home, and read and rest, and not



<P>work.&nbsp; It's like other people, you know, and I always envy



<P>girls who do such things, I'm so fond of luxury," said Meg,



<P>trying to decide which of two shabby gowns was the least



<P>shabby.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, we can't have it, so don't let us grumble but



<P>shoulder our bundles and trudge along as cheerfully as



<P>Marmee does.&nbsp; I'm sure Aunt March is a regular Old Man of



<P>the Sea to me, but I suppose when I've learned to carry her



<P>without complaining, she will tumble off, or get so light



<P>that I shan't mind her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This idea tickled Jo's fancy and put her in good spirits,



<P>but Meg didn't brighten, for her burden, consisting



<P>of four spoiled children, seemed heavier than ever.



<P>She had not heart enough even to make herself pretty



<P>as usual by putting on a blue neck ribbon and dressing



<P>her hair in the most becoming way.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where's the use of looking nice, when no one sees me



<P>but those cross midgets, and no one cares whether I'm pretty



<P>or not?" she muttered, shutting her drawer with a jerk.&nbsp; "I



<P>shall have to toil and moil all my days, with only little



<P>bits of fun now and then, and get old and ugly and sour,



<P>because I'm poor and can't enjoy my life as other girls do.



<P>It's a shame!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So Meg went down, wearing an injured look, and wasn't at



<P>all agreeable at breakfast time.&nbsp; Everyone seemed rather out



<P>of sorts and inclined to croak.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth had a headache and lay on the sofa, trying to comfort



<P>herself with the cat and three kittens.&nbsp; Amy was fretting



<P>because her lessons were not learned, and she couldn't



<P>find her rubbers.&nbsp; Jo would whistle and make a great racket



<P>getting ready.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March was very busy trying to finish a letter,



<P>which must go at once, and Hannah had the grumps, for being



<P>up late didn't suit her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There never was such a cross family!" cried Jo, losing



<P>her temper when she had upset an inkstand, broken both boot



<P>lacings, and sat down upon her hat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You're the crossest person in it!" returned Amy, washing



<P>out the sum that was all wrong with the tears that had



<P>fallen on her slate.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Beth, if you don't keep these horrid cats down cellar



<P>I'll have them drowned," exclaimed Meg angrily as she tried



<P>to get rid of the kitten which had scrambled up her back and



<P>stuck like a burr just out of reach.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo laughed, Meg scolded, Beth implored, and Amy wailed



<P>because she couldn't remember how much nine times twelve was.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Girls, girls, do be quiet one minute!&nbsp; I must get this



<P>off by the early mail, and you drive me distracted with your



<P>worry," cried Mrs. March, crossing out the third spoiled sentence



<P>in her letter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a momentary lull, broken by Hannah, who stalked in,



<P>laid two hot turnovers on the table, and stalked out again.



<P>These turnovers were an institution, and the girls called



<P>them `muffs', for they had no others and found the hot



<P>pies very comforting to their hands on cold mornings.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Hannah never forgot to make them, no matter how busy or



<P>grumpy she might be, for the walk was long and bleak.



<P>The poor things got no other lunch and were seldom home



<P>before two.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Cuddle your cats and get over your headache, Bethy.



<P>Goodbye, Marmee.&nbsp; We are a set of rascals this morning, but



<P>we'll come home regular angels.&nbsp; Now then, Meg!"&nbsp; And Jo



<P>tramped away, feeling that the pilgrims were not setting out



<P>as they ought to do.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They always looked back before turning the corner, for



<P>their mother was always at the window to nod and smile, and



<P>wave her hand to them.&nbsp; Somehow it seemed as if they couldn't



<P>have got through the day without that, for whatever their



<P>mood might be, the last glimpse of that motherly face was



<P>sure to affect them like sunshine.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If Marmee shook her fist instead of kissing her hand



<P>to us, it would serve us right, for more ungrateful wretches



<P>than we are were never seen," cried Jo, taking a remorseful



<P>satisfaction in the snowy walk and bitter wind.



<P>"Don't use such dreadful expressions," replied Meg from



<P>the depths of the veil in which she had shrouded herself



<P>like a nun sick of the world.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I like good strong words that mean something," replied



<P>Jo, catching her hat as it took a leap off her head



<P>preparatory to flying away altogether.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Call yourself any names you like, but I am neither a



<P>rascal nor a wretch and I don't choose to be called so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You're a blighted being, and decidedly cross today because



<P>you can't sit in the lap of luxury all the time.&nbsp; Poor dear,



<P>just wait till I make my fortune, and you shall revel



<P>in carriages and ice cream and high-heeled slippers,



<P>and posies, and red-headed boys to dance with."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How ridiculous you are, Jo!"&nbsp; But Meg laughed at the



<P>nonsense and felt better in spite of herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Lucky for you I am, for if I put on crushed airs and



<P>tried to be dismal, as you do, we should be in a nice state.



<P>Thank goodness, I can always find something funny to keep me



<P>up.&nbsp; Don't croak any more, but come home jolly, there's a dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo gave her sister an encouraging pat on the shoulder



<P>as they parted for the day, each going a different way, each



<P>hugging her little warm turnover, and each trying to be



<P>cheerful in spite of wintry weather, hard work, and the



<P>unsatisfied desires of pleasure-loving youth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When Mr. March lost his property in trying to help an



<P>unfortunate friend, the two oldest girls begged to be allowed



<P>to do something toward their own support, at least.&nbsp; Believing



<P>that they could not begin too early to cultivate energy,



<P>industry, and independence, their parents consented, and



<P>both fell to work with the hearty good will which in spite



<P>of all obstacles is sure to succeed at last.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Margaret found a place as nursery governess and felt



<P>rich with her small salary.&nbsp; As she said, she was `fond of



<P>luxury', and her chief trouble was poverty.&nbsp; She found it



<P>harder to bear than the others because she could remember a



<P>time when home was beautiful, life full of ease and pleasure,



<P>and want of any kind unknown.&nbsp; She tried not to be envious



<P>or discontented, but it was very natural that the young girl



<P>should long for pretty things, gay friends, accomplishments,



<P>and a happy life.&nbsp; At the Kings' she daily saw all she wanted,



<P>for the children's older sisters were just out, and Meg



<P>caught frequent glimpses of dainty ball dresses and bouquets,



<P>heard lively gossip about theaters, concerts, sleighing parties,



<P>and merrymakings of all kinds, and saw money lavished



<P>on trifles which would have been so precious to her.&nbsp; Poor



<P>Meg seldom complained, but a sense of injustice made her feel



<P>bitter toward everyone sometimes, for she had not yet learned



<P>to know how rich she was in the blessings which alone can



<P>make life happy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo happened to suit Aunt March, who was lame and needed



<P>an active person to wait upon her.&nbsp; The childless old lady



<P>had offered to adopt one of the girls when the troubles came,



<P>and was much offended because her offer was declined.&nbsp; Other



<P>friends told the Marches that they had lost all chance of



<P>being remembered in the rich old lady's will, but the



<P>unworldly Marches only said...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We can't give up our girls for a dozen fortunes.&nbsp; Rich



<P>or poor, we will keep together and be happy in one another."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The old lady wouldn't speak to them for a time, but happening



<P>to meet Jo at at a friend's, something in her comical face



<P>and blunt manners struck the old lady's fancy, and she



<P>proposed to take her for a companion.&nbsp; This did not suit Jo



<P>at all, but she accepted the place since nothing better



<P>appeared and, to every one's surprise, got on remarkably well



<P>with her irascible relative.&nbsp; There was an occasional tempest,



<P>and once Jo marched home, declaring she couldn't bear



<P>it longer, but Aunt March always cleared up quickly, and



<P>sent for her to come back again with such urgency that she



<P>could not refuse, for in her heart she rather liked the



<P>peppery old lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I suspect that the real attraction was a large library



<P>of fine books, which was left to dust and spiders since



<P>Uncle March died.&nbsp; Jo remembered the kind old gentleman, who



<P>used to let her build railroads and bridges with his big



<P>dictionaries, tell her stories about queer pictures in his



<P>Latin books, and buy her cards of gingerbread whenever he



<P>met her in the street.&nbsp; The dim, dusty room, with the busts



<P>staring down from the tall bookcases, the cozy chairs, the



<P>globes, and best of all, the wilderness of books in which



<P>she could wander where she liked, made the library a region



<P>of bliss to her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The moment Aunt March took her nap, or was busy with



<P>company, Jo hurried to this quiet place, and curling herself



<P>up in the easy chair, devoured poetry, romance, history,



<P>travels, and pictures like a regular bookworm.&nbsp; But, like



<P>all happiness, it did not last long, for as sure as she had



<P>just reached the heart of the story, the sweetest verse of



<P>a song, or the most perilous adventure of her traveler, a



<P>shrill voice called, "Josy-phine! Josy-phine! and she had



<P>to leave her paradise to wind yarn, wash the poodle, or



<P>read Belsham's Essays by the hour together.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo's ambition was to do something very splendid.&nbsp; What



<P>it was, she had no idea as yet, but left it for time to tell



<P>her, and meanwhile, found her greatest affliction in the



<P>fact that she couldn't read, run, and ride as much as she



<P>liked.&nbsp; A quick temper, sharp tongue, and restless spirit



<P>were always getting her into scrapes, and her life was a



<P>series of ups and downs, which were both comic and pathetic.



<P>But the training she received at Aunt March's was just what



<P>she needed, and the thought that she was doing something to



<P>support herself made her happy in spite of the perpetual



<P>"Josy-phine!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth was too bashful to go to school.It had been tried,



<P>but she suffered so much that it was given up, and she did



<P>her lessons at home with her father.&nbsp; Even when he went away,



<P>and her mother was called to devote her skill and energy to



<P>Soldiers' Aid Societies, Beth went faithfully on by herself



<P>and did the best she could.&nbsp; She was a housewifely little



<P>creature, and helped Hannah keep home neat and comfortable



<P>for the workers, never thinking of any reward but to be



<P>loved.&nbsp; Long, quiet days she spent, not lonely nor idle, for



<P>her little world was peopled with imaginary friends, and she



<P>was by nature a busy bee.&nbsp; There were six dolls to be taken



<P>up and dressed every morning, for Beth was a child still



<P>and and loved her pets as well as ever.&nbsp; Not one whole or



<P>handsome one among them, all were outcasts till Beth took



<P>them in, for when her sisters outgrew these idols, they



<P>passed to her because Amy would have nothing old or ugly.



<P>Beth cherished them all the more tenderly for that very



<P>reason, and set up a hospital for infirm dolls.&nbsp; No pins



<P>were ever stuck into their cotton vitals, no harsh words or



<P>blows were ever given them, no neglect ever saddened the



<P>heart or the most repulsive, but all were fed and clothed,



<P>nursed and caressed with an affection which never failed.



<P>One forlorn fragment of dollanity had belonged to Jo and,



<P>having led a tempestuous life, was left a wreck in the rag



<P>bag, from which dreary poorhouse it was rescued by Beth



<P>and taken to her refuge.&nbsp; Having no top to its head, she



<P>tied on a neat little cap, and as both arms and legs were



<P>gone, she hid these deficiencies by folding it in a blanket



<P>and devoting her best bed to this chronic invalid.&nbsp; If anyone



<P>had known the care lavished on that dolly, I think it



<P>would have touched their hearts, even while they laughed.



<P>She brought it bits of bouquets, she read to it, took it



<P>out to breathe fresh air, hidden under her coat, she sang



<P>it lullabies and never went to be without kissing its dirty



<P>face and whispering tenderly, "I hope you'll have a good



<P>night, my poor dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth had her troubles as well as the others, and not



<P>being an angel but a very human little girl, she often `wept



<P>a little weep' as Jo said, because she couldn't take music



<P>lessons and have a fine piano.&nbsp; She loved music so dearly,



<P>tried so hard to learn, and practiced away so patiently at



<P>the jingling old instrument, that it did seem as if someone



<P>(not to hint Aunt March) ought to help her.&nbsp; Nobody did,



<P>however, and nobody saw Beth wipe the tears off the yellow



<P>keys, that wouldn't keep in tune, when she was all alone.



<P>She sang like a little lark about her work, never was too



<P>tired for Marmee and the girls, and day after day said



<P>hopefully to herself," I know I'll get my music some time,



<P>if I'm good."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There are many Beths in the world, shy and quiet, sitting



<P>in corners till needed, and living for others so cheerfully



<P>that no one sees the sacrifices till the little cricket on



<P>the hearth stops chirping, and the sweet, sunshiny presence



<P>vanishes, leaving silence and shadow behind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If anybody had asked Amy what the greatest trial of her



<P>life was, she would have answered at once, "My nose."&nbsp; When



<P>she was a baby, Jo had accidently dropped her into the coal hod,



<P>and Amy insisted that the fall had ruined her nose forever.&nbsp; It



<P>was not big nor red, like poor `Petrea's', it was only rather



<P>flat, and all the pinching in the world could not give it an



<P>aristocratic point.&nbsp; No one minded it but herself, and it was



<P>doing its best to grow, but Amy felt deeply the want of a



<P>Grecian nose, and drew whole sheets of handsome ones to console



<P>herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Little Raphael," as her sisters called her, had a decided



<P>talent for drawing, and was never so happy as when copying



<P>flowers, designing fairies, or illustrating stories with queer



<P>specimens of art.&nbsp; Her teachers complained that instead of



<P>doing her sums she covered her slate with animals, the blank



<P>pages of her atlas were used to copy maps on, and caricatures



<P>of the most ludicrous description came fluttering out of all



<P>her books at unlucky moments.&nbsp; She got through her lessons as



<P>well as she could, and managed to escape reprimands by being



<P>a model of deportment.&nbsp; She was a great favorite with her mates,



<P>being good-tempered and possessing the happy art of pleasing



<P>without effort.&nbsp; Her little airs and graces were much admired,



<P>so were her accomplishments, for besides her drawing, she could



<P>play twelve tunes, crochet, and read French without mispronouncing



<P>more than two-thirds of the words.&nbsp; She had a plaintive



<P>way of saying, "When Papa was rich we did so-and-so," which



<P>was very touching, and her long words were considered `perfectly



<P>elegant' by the girls.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy was in a fair way to be spoiled, for everyone petted



<P>her, and her small vanities and selfishnesses were growing nicely.



<P>One thing, however, rather quenched the vanities.&nbsp; She had to wear



<P>her cousin's clothes.&nbsp; Now Florence's mama hadn't a particle of



<P>taste, and Amy suffered deeply at having to wear a red instead of



<P>a blue bonnet, unbecoming gowns, and fussy aprons that did not



<P>fit.&nbsp; Everything was good, well made, and little worn, but Amy's



<P>artistic eyes were much afflicted, especially this winter, when



<P>her school dress was a dull purple with yellow dots and no



<P>trimming.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My only comfort," she said to Meg, with tears in her eyes,



<P>"is that Mother doesn't take tucks in my dresses whenever I'm



<P>naughty, as Maria Parks's mother does.&nbsp; My dear, it's really



<P>dreadful, for sometimes she is so bad her frock is up to her



<P>knees, and she can't come to school.&nbsp; When I think of this



<P>deggerredation, I fell that I can bear even my flat nose and



<P>purple gown with yellow skyrockets on it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg was Amy's confidante and monitor, and by some strange



<P>attraction of opposites Jo was gentle Beth's.&nbsp; To Jo alone did



<P>the shy child tell her thoughts, and over her big harum-scarum



<P>sister Beth unconsciously exercised more influence than anyone



<P>in the family.&nbsp; The two older girls were a great deal to one



<P>another, but each took one of the younger sisters into her



<P>keeping and watched over her in her own way, `playing mother'



<P>they called it, and put their sisters in the places of



<P>discarded dolls with the maternal instinct of litte women.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Has anybody got anything to tell?&nbsp; It's been such a dismal



<P>day I'm really dying for some amusement," said Meg, as they sat



<P>sewing together that evening.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had a queer time with Aunt today, and, as I got the best



<P>of it, I'll tell you about it," began Jo, who dearly loved to tell



<P>stories.&nbsp; "I was reading that everlasting Belsham, and droning



<P>away as I always do, for Aunt soon drops off, and then I take out



<P>some nice book, and read like fury till she wakes up.&nbsp; I actually



<P>made myself sleepy, and before she began to nod, I gave such a



<P>gape that she asked me what I meant by opening my mouth wide



<P>enough to take the whole book in at once.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish I could, and be done with it," said I, trying not to



<P>be saucy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then she gave me a long lecture on my sins, and told me to



<P>sit and think them over while she just `lost' herself for a moment.



<P>She never finds herself very soon, so the minute her cap began to



<P>bob like a top-heavy dahlia, I whipped the VICAR OF WAKEFIELD out



<P>of my pocket, and read away, with one eye on him and one on Aunt.



<P>I'd just got to where they all tumbled into the water when I



<P>forgot and laughed out loud.&nbsp; Aunt woke up and, being more



<P>good-natured after her nap, told me to read a bit and show what



<P>frivolous work I preferred to the worthy and instructive Belsham.



<P>I did my very best, and she liked it, though she only said...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't understand what it's all about.&nbsp; Go back and begin



<P>it, child."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Back I went, and made the Primroses as interesting as ever I



<P>could.&nbsp; Once I was wicked enough to stop in a thrilling place,

and



<P>say meekly, "I'm afraid it tires you, ma'am.&nbsp; Shan't I stop now?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She caught up her knitting, which had dropped out of her



<P>hands, gave me a sharp look through her specs, and said, in her



<P>short way, `Finish the chapter, and don't be impertinent, miss'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did she own she liked it?" asked Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, bless you, no!&nbsp; But she let old Belsham rest, and when I



<P>ran back after my gloves this afternoon, there she was, so hard at



<P>the Vicar that she didn't hear me laugh as I danced a jig in the hall



<P>because of the good time coming.&nbsp; What a pleasant life she might

have



<P>if only she chose!&nbsp; I don't envy her much, in spite of her money,

for



<P>after all rich people have about as many worries as poor ones, I



<P>think," added Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That reminds me," said Meg, "that I've got something to tell.



<P>It isn't funny, like Jo's story, but I thought about it a good deal



<P>as I came home.&nbsp; At the Kings' today I found everybody in a flurry,



<P>and one of the children said that her oldest brother had done



<P>something dreadful, and Papa had sent him away.&nbsp; I heard Mrs. King



<P>crying and Mr. King talking very loud, and Grace and Ellen turned



<P>away their faces when they passed me, so I shouldn't see how red and



<P>swollen their eyes were.&nbsp; I didn't ask any questions, of course,

but



<P>I felt so sorry for them and was rather glad I hadn't any wild



<P>brothers to do wicked things and disgrace the family."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think being disgraced in school is a great deal tryinger



<P>than anything bad boys can do," said Amy, shaking her head, as if



<P>her experience of life had been a deep one.&nbsp; "Susie Perkins came



<P>to school today with a lovely red carnelian ring.&nbsp; I wanted it



<P>dreadfully, and wished I was her with all my might.&nbsp; Well, she



<P>drew a picture of Mr. Davis, with a monstrous nose and a hump,



<P>and the words, `Young ladies, my eye is upon you!' coming out of



<P>his mouth in a balloon thing.&nbsp; We were laughing over it when all



<P>of a sudden his eye was on us, and he ordered Susie to bring up



<P>her slate.&nbsp; She was parrylized with fright, but she went, and oh,



<P>what do you think he did?&nbsp; He took her by the ear--the ear!&nbsp;

Just



<P>fancy how horrid!--and led her to the recitation platform, and



<P>made her stand there half and hour, holding the slate so everyone



<P>could see."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Didn't the girls laugh at the picture?" asked Jo, who



<P>relished the scrape.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Laugh? Not one! They sat still as mice, and Susie cried



<P>quarts, I know she did.&nbsp; I didn't envy her then, for I felt that



<P>millions of carnelian rings wouldn't have made me happy after that.



<P>I never, never should have got over such a agonizing mortification."



<P>And Amy went on with her work, in the proud consciousness of virtue



<P>and the successful utterance of two long words in a breath.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I saw something I liked this morning, and I meant to tell it



<P>at dinner, but I forgot," said Beth, putting Jo's topsy-turvy basket



<P>in order as she talked.&nbsp; "When I went to get some oysters for Hannah,



<P>Mr. Laurence was in the fish shop, but he didn't see me, for I kept



<P>behind the fish barrel, and he was busy with Mr. Cutter the fishman.



<P>A poor woman came in with a pail a mop, and asked Mr. Cutter if he



<P>would let her do some scrubbing for a bit of fish, because she



<P>hadn't any dinner for her children, and had been disappointed of a



<P>day's work.&nbsp; Mr. Cutter was in a hurry and said `No', rather



<P>crossly, so she was going away, looking hungry and sorry, when Mr.



<P>Laurence hooked up a big fish with the crooked end of his cane and



<P>held it out to her.&nbsp; She was so glad and surprised she took it



<P>right into her arms, and thanked him over and over.&nbsp; He told her

to



<P>`go along and cook it', and she hurried off, so happy!&nbsp; Wasn't

it



<P>good of him?&nbsp; Oh, she did look so funny, hugging the big, slippery



<P>fish, and hoping Mr. Laurence's bed in heaven would be `aisy'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When they had laughed at Beth's story, they asked their mother



<P>for one, and after a moments thought, she said soberly, "As I sat



<P>cutting out blue flannel jackets today at the rooms, I felt very



<P>anxious about Father, and thought how lonely and helpless we should



<P>be , if anything happened to him.&nbsp; It was not a wise thing to do,



<P>but I kept on worrying till an old man came in with an order for some



<P>clothes.&nbsp; He sat down near me, and I began to talk to him, for

he



<P>looked poor and tired and anxious.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"`Have you sons in the army?' I asked, for the note he brought



<P>was not to me.



<P>"Yes, ma'am.&nbsp; I had four, but two were killed, one is a prisoner,



<P>and I'm going to the other, who is very sick in a Washington hospital.'



<P>he answered quietly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"`You have done a great deal for your country, sir, ' I said,



<P>feeling respect now, instead of pity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"`Not a mite more than I ought, ma'am.&nbsp; I'd go myself, if I was



<P>any use.&nbsp; As I ain't, I give my boys, and give 'em free.'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He spoke so cheerfully, looked so sincere, and seemed so glad



<P>to give his all, that I was ashamed of myself.&nbsp; I'd given one man

and



<P>thought it too much, while he gave four without grudging them.&nbsp;

I had



<P>all my girls to comfort me at home, and his last son was waiting,



<P>miles away, to say good-by to him, perhaps!&nbsp; I felt so rich, so

happy



<P>thinking of my blessings, that I made him a nice bundle, gave him



<P>some money, and thanked him heartily for the lesson he had taught me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tell another story, Mother, one with a moral to it, like this.



<P>I like to think about them afterward, if they are real and not too



<P>preachy," said Jo, after a minute's silence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March smiled and began at once, for she had told stories to



<P>this little audience for many years, and knew how to please them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Once upon a time, there were four girls, who had enough to eat



<P>and drink and wear, a good many comforts and pleasures, kind friends



<P>and parents who loved them dearly, and yet they were not contented."



<P>(Here the listeners stole sly looks at one another, and began to sew

diligently.) "These girls were



<P>anxious to be good and made many



<P>excellent resolutions, but they did not keep them very well, and were



<P>constantly saying, `If only we had this, ' or `If we could only do



<P>that, ' quite forgetting how much they already had, and how many



<P>things they actually could do.&nbsp; So they asked an old woman what

spell



<P>they could use to make them happy, and she said, `When you feel



<P>discontented, think over your blessings, and be grateful.'" (Here Jo



<P>looked up quickly, as if about to speak, but changed her mind, seeing



<P>that the story was not done yet.)

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Being sensible girls, they decided to try her advice, and soon



<P>were surprised to see how well off they were.&nbsp; One discovered that



<P>money couldn't keep shame and sorrow out of rich people's houses,



<P>another that, though she was poor, she was a great deal happier, with



<P>her youth, health, and good spirits, than a certain fretful, feeble



<P>old lady who couldn't enjoy her comforts, a third that, disagreeable



<P>as it was to help get dinner, it was harder still to go begging for



<P>it and the fourth, that even carnelian rings were not so valuable as



<P>good behavior.&nbsp; So they agreed to stop complaining, to enjoy the



<P>blessings already possessed, and try to deserve them, lest they



<P>should be taken away entirely, instead of increased, and I believe



<P>they were never disappointed or sorry that they took the old woman's



<P>advice."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Marmee, that is very cunning of you to turn our own



<P>stories against us, and give us a sermon instead of a romance!"



<P>cried Meg.



<P>"I like that kind of sermon.&nbsp; It's the sort Father used to tell



<P>us," said Beth thoughtfully, putting the needles straight on Jo's



<P>cushion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't complain near as much as the others do, and I shall be



<P>more careful than ever now, for I've had warning from Susies's downfall,"



<P>said Amy morally.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We needed that lesson, and we won't forget it.&nbsp; If we do so,



<P>you just say to us, as old Chloe did in UNCLE TOM, `Tink ob yer



<P>marcies, chillen! `Tink ob yer marcies!'" added Jo, who could not,



<P>for the life of her, help getting a morsel of fun out of the little



<P>sermon, though she took it to heart as much as any of them.



<P>

   <TITLE>Chapter 10</TITLE>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER TEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As spring came on, a new set of amusements became the



<P>fashion, and the lengthening days gave long afternoons for



<P>work and play of all sorts.&nbsp; The garden had to be put in order,



<P>and each sister had a quarter of the little plot to do what she



<P>liked with.&nbsp; Hannah used to say, "I'd know which each of them



<P>gardings belonged to, ef I see 'em in Chiny," and so she might,



<P>for the girls' tastes differed as much as their characters.&nbsp; Meg's



<P>had roses and heliotrope, myrtle, and a little orange tree in it.



<P>Jo's bed was never alike two seasons, for she was always trying



<P>experiments.&nbsp; This year it was to be a plantation of sun flowers,



<P>the seeds of which cheerful land aspiring plant were to feed



<P>Aunt Cockle-top and her family of chicks.&nbsp; Beth had old-fashioned



<P>fragrant flowers in her garden, sweet peas and mignonette,



<P>larkspur, pinks, pansies, and southernwood, with chickweed for



<P>the birds and catnip for the pussies.&nbsp; Amy had a bower in hers,



<P>rather small and earwiggy, but very pretty to look at, with



<P>honeysuckle and morning-glories hanging their colored horns and



<P>bells in graceful wreaths all over it, tall white lilies, delicate



<P>ferns, and as many brilliant, picturesque plants as would consent



<P>to blossom there.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Gardening, walks, rows on the river, and flower hunts employed



<P>the fine days, and for rainy ones, they had house diversions,



<P>some old, some new, all more or less original.&nbsp; One of these



<P>was the `P.C', for as secret societies were the fashion,



<P>it was thought proper to have one, and as all of the girls



<P>admired Dickens, they called themselves the Pickwick Club.&nbsp; With



<P>a few interruptions, they had kept this up for a year, and met



<P>every Saturday evening in the big garret, on which occasions the



<P>ceremonies were as follows:&nbsp; Three chairs were arranged in a row



<P>before a table on which was a lamp, also four white badges, with



<P>a big `P.C.' in different colors on each, and the weekly



<P>newspaper called, The Pickwick Portfolio, to which all contributed



<P>something, while Jo, who reveled in pens and ink, was the editor.



<P>At seven o'clock, the four members ascended to the clubroom,



<P>tied their badges round their heads, and took their seats with



<P>great solemnity.&nbsp; Meg, as the eldest, was Samuel Pickwick, Jo,



<P>being of a literary turn, Augustus Snodgrass, Beth, because she



<P>was round and rosy, Tracy Tupman, and Amy, who was always trying



<P>to do what she couldn't, was Nathaniel Winkle.&nbsp; Pickwick, the



<P>president, read the paper, which was filled with original tales,



<P>poetry, local news, funny advertisements, and hints, in which



<P>they good-naturedly reminded each other of their faults and



<P>short comings.&nbsp; On one occasion, Mr. Pickwick put on a pair



<P>of spectacles without any glass, rapped upon the table, hemmed,



<P>and having stared hard at Mr. Snodgrass, who was tilting back



<P>in his chair, till he arranged himself properly, began to read:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"THE PICKWICK PORTFOLIO"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>MAY 20, 18---

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>POET'S CORNER

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>ANNIVERSARY ODE

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Again we meet to celebrate



<P>With badge and solemn rite,



<P>Our fifty-second anniversary,



<P>In Pickwick Hall, tonight.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>We all are here in perfect health,



<P>None gone from our small band:



<P>Again we see each well-known face,



<P>And press each friendly hand.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Our Pickwick, always at his post,



<P>With reverence we greet,



<P>As, spectacles on nose, he reads



<P>Our well-filled weekly sheet.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Although he suffers from a cold,



<P>We joy to hear him speak,



<P>For words of wisdom from him fall,



<P>In spite of croak or squeak.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Old six-foot Snodgrass looms on high,



<P>With elephantine grace,



<P>And beams upon the company,



<P>With brown and jovial face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poetic fire lights up his eye,



<P>He struggles 'gainst his lot.



<P>Behold ambition on his brow,



<P>And on his nose, a blot.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Next our peaceful Tupman comes,



<P>So rosy, plump, and sweet,



<P>Who chokes with laughter at the puns,



<P>And tumbles off his seat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Prim little Winkle too is here,



<P>With every hair in place,



<P>A model of propriety,



<P>Though he hates to wash his face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The year is gone, we still unite



<P>To joke and laugh and read,



<P>And tread the path of literature



<P>That doth to glory lead.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Long may our paper prosper well,



<P>Our club unbroken be,



<P>And coming years their blessings pour



<P>On the useful, gay `P.&nbsp; C.'.



<P>A.&nbsp; SNODGRASS

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>________

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>THE MASKED MARRIAGE



<P>(A Tale Of Venice)

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Gondola after gondola swept up to the marble



<P>steps, and left its lovely load to swell the



<P>brilliant throng that filled the stately halls of Count



<P>Adelon.&nbsp; Knights and ladies, elves and pages, monks



<P>and flower girls, all mingled gaily in the dance.



<P>Sweet voices and rich melody filled the air, and so



<P>with mirth and music the masquerade went on.



<P>"Has your Highness seen the Lady viola tonight?"



<P>asked a gallant troubadour of the fairy queen who



<P>floated down the hall upon his arm.



<P>"Yes, is she not lovely, though so sad!&nbsp; Her



<P>dress is well chosen, too, for in a week she weds



<P>Count Antonio, whom she passionately hates."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"By my faith, I envy him.&nbsp; Yonder he comes,



<P>arrayed like a bridegroom, except the black mask.



<P>When that is off we shall see how he regards the



<P>fair maid whose heart he cannot win, though her



<P>stern father bestows her hand," returned the troubadour.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tis whispered that she loves the young English



<P>artist who haunts her steps, and is spurned by the



<P>old Count," said the lady, as they joined the dance.



<P>The revel was at its height when a priest



<P>appeared, and withdrawing the young pair to an alcove,



<P>hung with purple velvet, he motioned them to kneel.



<P>Instant silence fell on the gay throng, and not a



<P>sound, but he dash of fountains or the rustle of



<P>orange groves sleeping in the moonlight, broke the



<P>hush, as Count de Adelon spoke thus:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My lords and ladies, pardon the ruse by which



<P>I have gathered you here to witness the marriage of



<P>my daughter.&nbsp; Father, we wait your services."



<P>All eyes turned toward the bridal party, and a



<P>murmur of amazement went through the throng, for



<P>neither bride nor groom removed their masks.&nbsp; Curiosity



<P>and wonder possessed all hearts, but respect restrained



<P>all tongues till the holy rite was over.&nbsp; Then the



<P>eager spectators gathered round the count, demanding



<P>an explanation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Gladly would I give it if I could, but I only



<P>know that it was the whim of my timid Viola, and I



<P>yielded to it.&nbsp; Now, my children, let the play end.



<P>Unmask and receive my blessing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But neither bent the knee, for the young bridegroom



<P>replied in a tone that startled all listeners



<P>as the mask fell, disclosing the noble face of Ferdinand



<P>Devereux, the artist lover, and leaning on the



<P>breast where now flashed the star of an English earl



<P>was the lovely Viola, radiant with joy and beauty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My lord, you scornfully bade me claim your



<P>daughter when I could boast as high a name and vast a



<P>fortune as the Count antonio.&nbsp; I can do more, for even



<P>your ambitious soul cannot refuse the Earl of Devereux



<P>and De Vere, when he gives his ancient name and boundless



<P>wealth in return for the beloved hand of this fair lady,



<P>now my wife.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The count stood like one changed to stone, and



<P>turning to the bewildered crowd, Ferdinand added, with



<P>a gay smile of triumph, "To you, my gallant friends, I



<P>can only wish that your wooing may prosper as mine has



<P>done, and that you may all win as fair a bride as I have



<P>by this masked marriage."



<P>S.&nbsp; PICKWICK

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Why is the P.&nbsp; C.&nbsp; like the Tower of Babel?



<P>It is full of unruly members.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>___________

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>THE HISTORY OF A SQUASH

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>_____

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Once upon a time a farmer planted a little seed.



<P>in his garden, and after a while it sprouted and became



<P>a vine and bore many squashes.&nbsp; One day in October,



<P>when they were ripe, he picked one and took it



<P>to market.&nbsp; A gorcerman bought and put it in his shop.



<P>That same morning, a little girl in a brown hat



<P>and blue dress, with a round face and snub nose, went



<P>and bought it for her mother.&nbsp; She lugged it home, cut



<P>it up, and boiled it in the big pot, mashed some of it



<P>salt and butter, for dinner.&nbsp; And to the rest she added



<P>a pint of milk, two eggs, four spoons of sugar, nutmeg,



<P>and some crackers, put it in a deep dish, and baked it



<P>till it was brown and nice, and next day it was eaten



<P>by a family named March.



<P>T.&nbsp; TUPMAN

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>_____________

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Pickwick, Sir:-



<P>I address you upon the subject of sin the sinner



<P>I mean is a man named Winkle who makes trouble in his



<P>club by laughing and sometimes won't write his piece in



<P>this fine paper I hope you will pardon his badness and



<P>let him send a French fable because he can't write out



<P>of his head as he has so many lessons to do and no brains



<P>in future I will try to take time by the fetlock and



<P>prepare some work which will be all commy la fo that



<P>means all right I am in haste as it is nearly school



<P>time



<P>Yours respectably,



<P>N.&nbsp; WINKLE

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>[The above is a manly and handsome aknowledgment of past



<P>misdemeanors.&nbsp; If our young friend studied punctuation, it



<P>would be well.]

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>_________

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A SAD ACCIDENT

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On Friday last, we were startled by a violent shock



<P>in our basement, followed by cries of distress.



<P>On rushing in a body to the cellar, we discovered our beloved



<P>President prostrate upon the floor, having tripped and



<P>fallen while getting wood for domestic purposes.&nbsp; A perfect



<P>scene of ruin met our eyes, for in his fall Mr. Pickwick



<P>had plunged his head and shoulders into a tub of water,



<P>upset a keg of soft soap upon his manly form,&nbsp; and torn



<P>his garments badly.&nbsp; On being removed from this perilous



<P>situation, it was discovered that he had suffered



<P>no injury but several bruises, and we are happy to add,



<P>is now doing well.



<P>ED.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>THE PUBLIC BEREAVEMENT

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It is our painful duty to record the sudden and



<P>mysterious disappearance of our cherished friend, Mrs.



<P>Snowball Pat Paw.&nbsp; This lovely and beloved cat was the



<P>pet of a large circle of warm and admiring friends; for



<P>her beauty attracted all eyes, her graces and virtues



<P>endeared her to all hearts, and her loss is deeply felt



<P>by the whole community.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When last seen, she was sitting at the gate, watching



<P>the butcher's cart, and it is feared that some villain,



<P>tempted by her charms, basely stole her.&nbsp; Weeks have passed,



<P>but no trace of her has been discovered, and we relinquish



<P>all hope, tie a black ribbon to her basket, set aside her



<P>dish, and weep for her as one lost to us forever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A sympathizing friend sends the following gem:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A LAMENT



<P>(FOR S.&nbsp; B.&nbsp; PAT PAW)

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>We mourn the loss of our little pet,



<P>And sigh o'er her hapless fate,



<P>For never more by the fire she'll sit,



<P>Nor play by the old green gate.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The little grave where her infant sleeps



<P>Is 'neath the chestnut tree.



<P>But o'er her grave we may not weep,



<P>We know not where it may be.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her empty bed, her idle ball,



<P>Will never see her more;



<P>No gentle tap, no loving purr



<P>Is heard at the parlor door.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Another cat comes after her mice,



<P>A cat with a dirty face,



<P>But she does not hunt as our darling did,



<P>Nor play with her airy grace.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her stealthy paws tread the very hall



<P>Where Snowball used to play,



<P>But she only spits at the dogs our pet



<P>So gallantly drove away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She is useful and mild, and does her best,



<P>But she is not fair to see,



<P>And we cannot give her your place dear,



<P>Nor worship her as we worship thee.



<P>A.S.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;
