<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>HINTS

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If S.P.&nbsp; didn't use so much soap on his hands,



<P>he wouldn't always be late at breakfast.&nbsp; A.S.



<P>is requested not to whistle in the street.&nbsp; T.T



<P>please don't forget Amy's napkin.&nbsp; N.W.&nbsp; must



<P>not fret because his dress has not nine tucks.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>_______________________________________________

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>WEEKLY REPORT

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg--Good.



<P>Jo--Bad.



<P>Beth--Very Good.



<P>Amy--Middling.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>___________________________________________________________________

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As the President finished reading the paper (which I beg



<P>leave to assure my readers is a bona fide copy of one written



<P>by bona fide girls once upon a time), a round of applause



<P>followed, and then Mr. Snodgrass rose to make a proposition.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. President and gentlemen," he began, assuming a



<P>parliamentary attitude and tone, "I wish to propose the admission



<P>of a new member--one who highly deserves the honor, would be



<P>deeply grateful for it, and would add immensely to the spirit



<P>of the club, the literary value of the paper, and be no end



<P>jolly and nice.&nbsp; I propose Mr. Theodore Laurence as an honorary



<P>member of the P.&nbsp; C.&nbsp; Come now, do have him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo's sudden change of tone made the girls laugh, but all



<P>looked rather anxious, and no one said a word as Snodgrass



<P>took his seat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We'll put it to a vote," said the President.&nbsp; "All in



<P>favor of this motion please to manifest it by saying, `Aye'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Contrary-minded say, `No'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg and Amy were contrary-minded, and Mr. Winkle rose to



<P>say with great elegance, "We don't wish any boys, they only



<P>joke and bounce about.&nbsp; This is a ladies' club, and we wish to



<P>be private and proper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm afraid he'll laugh at our paper, and make fun of us



<P>afterward," observed Pickwick, pulling the little curl on her



<P>forehead, as she always did when doubtful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Up rose Snodgrass, very much in earnest.&nbsp; "Sir, I give you



<P>my word as a gentleman, Laurie won't do anything of the sort.&nbsp;

He



<P>likes to write, and he'll give a tone to our contributions and



<P>keep us from being sentimental, don't you see?&nbsp; We can do so little



<P>for him, and he does so much for us, I think the least we can do



<P>is to offer him a place here, and make him welcome if he comes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This artful allusion to benefits conferred brought Tupman to



<P>his feet, looking as if he had quite made up his mind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, we ought to do it, even if we are afraid.&nbsp; I say he may



<P>come, and his grandpa, too, if he likes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This spirited burst from Beth electrified the club, and Jo



<P>left her seat to shake hands approvingly.&nbsp; "Now then, vote again.



<P>Everybody remember it's our Laurie, and say, `Aye!'"



<P>cried Snodgrass excitedly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye!&nbsp; Aye!&nbsp; Aye!" replied three voices at once.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good!&nbsp; Bless you!&nbsp; Now, as there's nothing like `taking time



<P>by the fetlock', as Winkle characteristically observes, allow me



<P>to present the new member."&nbsp; And, to the dismay of the rest of

the



<P>club, Jo threw open the door of the closet, and displayed Laurie



<P>sitting on a rag bag, flushed and twinkling with suppressed laughter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You rogue!&nbsp; You traitor!&nbsp; Jo, how could you?" cried the three



<P>girls, as Snodgrass led her friend triumphantly forth, and producing



<P>both a chair and a badge, installed him in a jiffy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The coolness of you two rascals is amazing," began Mr. Pickwick,



<P>trying to get up an awful frown and only succeeding in producing



<P>an amiable smile.&nbsp; But the new member was equal to the occasion,



<P>and rising, with a grateful salutation to the Chair, said



<P>in the most engaging manner, "Mr. President and ladies--I beg pardon,



<P>gentlemen--allow me to introduce myself as Sam Weller, the very



<P>humble servant of the club."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good!&nbsp; Good!" cried Jo, pounding with the handle of the old



<P>warming pan on which she leaned.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My faithful friend and noble patron," continued Laurie with



<P>a wave of the hand, "who has so flatteringly presented me, is not



<P>to be blamed for the base stratagem of tonight.&nbsp; I planned it,

and



<P>she only gave in after lots of teasing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come now, don't lay it all on yourself.&nbsp; You know I proposed



<P>the cupboard," broke in Snodgrass, who was enjoying the joke



<P>amazingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never mind what she says.&nbsp; I'm the wretch that did it, sir,"



<P>said the new member, with a Welleresque nod to Mr. Pickwick.&nbsp; "But



<P>on my honor, I never will do so again, and henceforth devote myself



<P>to the interest of this immortal club."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hear!&nbsp; Hear!" cried Jo, clashing the lid of the warming pan



<P>like a cymbal.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Go on, go on!" added Winkle and Tupman, while the President



<P>bowed benignly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I merely wish to say, that as a slight token of my gratitude



<P>for the honor done me, and as a means of promoting friendly relations



<P>between adjoining nations, I have set up a post office in the hedge



<P>in the lower corner of the garden, a fine, spacious building with



<P>padlocks on the doors and every convenience for the mails, also the



<P>females, if I may be allowed the expression.&nbsp; It's the old martin



<P>house, but I've stopped up the door and made the roof open, so it



<P>will hold all sorts of things, and save our valuable time.&nbsp; Letters,



<P>manuscripts, books, and bundles can be passed in there, and as each



<P>nation has a key, it will be uncommonly nice, I fancy.&nbsp; Allow me

to



<P>present the club key, and with many thanks for your favor, take my



<P>seat."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Great applause as Mr. Weller deposited a little key on the



<P>table and subsided, the warming pan clashed and waved wildly, and



<P>it was some time before order could be restored.&nbsp; A long discussion



<P>followed, and everyone came out surprising, for everyone did her



<P>best.&nbsp; So it was an unusually lively meeting, and did not adjourn



<P>till a late hour, when it broke up with three shrill cheers for the



<P>new member.&nbsp; No one ever regretted the admittance of Sam Weller,

for



<P>a more devoted, well-behaved, and jovial member no club could have.



<P>He certainly did add `spirit' to the meetings, and `a tone' to the



<P>paper, for his orations convulsed his hearers and his contributions



<P>were excellent, being patriotic, classical, comical, or dramatic,



<P>but never sentimental.&nbsp; Jo regarded them as worthy of Bacon, Milton,



<P>or Shakespeare, and remodeled her own works with good effect, she



<P>thought.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The P. O. was a capital little institution, and flourished



<P>wonderfully, for nearly as many queer things passed through it as



<P>through the real post office.&nbsp; Tragedies and cravats, poetry and



<P>pickles, garden seeds and long letters, music and gingerbread,



<P>rubbers, invitations, scoldings, and puppies.&nbsp; The old gentleman



<P>liked the fun, and amused himself by sending odd bundles,



<P>mysterious messages, and funny telegrams, and his gardener, who was



<P>smitten with Hannah's charms, actually sent a love letter to Jo's



<P>care.&nbsp; How they laughed when the secret came out, never dreaming



<P>how many love letters that little post office would hold in the



<P>years to come.



<P>

<B>CHAPTER ELEVEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The first of June!&nbsp; The Kings are off to the seashore tomorrow,



<P>and I'm free.&nbsp; Three months' vacation--how I shall enjoy it!"



<P>exclaimed Meg, coming home one warm day to find Jo laid



<P>upon the sofa in an unusual state of exhaustion, while Beth took



<P>off her dusty boots, and Amy made lemonade for the refreshment



<P>of the whole party.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aunt March went today, for which, oh, be joyful!" said Jo.



<P>"I was mortally afraid she'd ask me to go with her.&nbsp; If she



<P>had, I should have felt as if I ought to do it, but Plumfield is



<P>about as gay as a churchyard, you know, and I'd rather be excused.



<P>We had a flurry getting the old lady off, and I had a fright every



<P>time she spoke to me, for I was in such a hurry to be through that



<P>I was uncommonly helpful and sweet, and feared she'd find it



<P>impossible to part from me.&nbsp; I quaked till she was fairly in the



<P>carriage, and had a final fright, for as it drove of, she popped



<P>out her head, saying, `Josyphine, won't you--?' I didn't hear any



<P>more, for I basely turned and fled.&nbsp; I did actually run, and



<P>whisked round the corner whee I felt safe."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor old Jo!&nbsp; She came in looking as if bears were after her,"



<P>said Beth, as she cuddled her sister's feet with a motherly air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aunt March is a regular samphire, is she not?" observed Amy,



<P>tasting her mixture critically.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She means vampire, not seaweed, but it doesn't matter.&nbsp; It's



<P>too warm to be particular about one's parts of speech," murmured



<P>Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What shall you do all your vacation?" asked Amy, changing



<P>the subject with tact.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall lie abed late, and do nothing," replied Meg, from



<P>the depths of the rocking chair.&nbsp; "I've been routed up early all



<P>winter and had to spend my days working for other people, so now



<P>I'm going to rest and revel to my heart's content."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No," said Jo, "that dozy way wouldn't suit me.&nbsp; I've laid



<P>in a heap of books, and I'm going to improve my shining hours



<P>reading on my perch in the old apple tree, when I'm not having



<P>l..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't say `larks!'" implored Amy, as a return snub for the



<P>samphire' correction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll say `nightingales' then, with Laurie.&nbsp; That's proper



<P>and appropriate, since he's a warbler."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't let us do any lessons, Beth, for a while, but play



<P>all the time and rest, as the girls mean to," proposed Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I will, if Mother doesn't mind.&nbsp; I want to learn some



<P>new songs, and my children need fitting up for the summer.&nbsp; They



<P>are dreadfully out of order and really suffering for clothes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"May we, Mother?" asked Meg, turning to Mrs. March, who



<P>sat sewing in what they called `Marmee's corner'.



<P>"You may try your experiment for a week and see how you like



<P>it.&nbsp; I think by Saturday night you will find that all play and

no



<P>work is as bad as all work and no play."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, dear, no!&nbsp; It will be delicious, I'm sure," said Meg



<P>complacently.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I now propose a toast, as my `friend and pardner,



<P>Sairy Gamp', says.&nbsp; Fun forever, and no grubbing!"



<P>cried Jo, rising, glass in hand, as the lemonade went round.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They all drank it merrily, and began the experiment by



<P>lounging for the rest of the day.&nbsp; Next morning, Meg did not



<P>appear till ten o'clock.&nbsp; Her solitary breakfast did not taste



<P>nice, and the room seemed lonely and untidy, for Jo had not



<P>filled the vases, Beth had not dusted, and Amy's books lay



<P>scattered about.&nbsp; Nothing was neat and pleasant but `Marmee's



<P>corner', which looked as usual.&nbsp; And there Meg sat, to `rest and



<P>read', which meant to yawn and imagine what pretty summer dresses



<P>she would get with her salary.&nbsp; Jo spent the morning on the river



<P>with Laurie and the afternoon reading and crying over The Wide,



<P>Wide World, up in the apple tree.&nbsp; Beth began by rummaging everything



<P>out of the big closet where her family resided, but getting



<P>tired before half done, she left her establishment topsy-turvy



<P>and went to her music, rejoicing that she had no dishes to wash.



<P>Amy arranged her bower, put on her best white frock, smoothed her



<P>curls, and sat down to draw under the honeysuckle, hoping someone



<P>would see and inquire who the young artist was.&nbsp; As no one appeared



<P>but an inquisitive daddy-longlegs, who examined her work with interest,



<P>she went to walk, got caught in a shower, and came home dripping.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At teatime they compared notes, and all agreed that it had



<P>been a delightful, though unusually long day.&nbsp; Meg, who went shopping



<P>in the afternoon and got a `sweet blue muslin, had discovered,



<P>after she had cut the breadths off, that it wouldn't wash, which



<P>mishap made her slightly cross.&nbsp; Jo had burned the skin off her



<P>nose boating, and got a raging headache by reading too long.&nbsp; Beth



<P>was worried by the confusion of her closet and the difficulty of



<P>learning three or four songs at once, and Amy deeply regretted the



<P>damage done her frock, for Katy Brown's party was to be the next



<P>day and now like Flora McFlimsey, she had `nothing to wear'.&nbsp; But



<P>these were mere trifles, and they assured their mother that the



<P>experiment was working finely.&nbsp; She smiled, said nothing, and with



<P>Hannah's help did their neglected work, keeping home pleasant and



<P>the domestic machinery running smoothly.&nbsp; It was astonishing what



<P>a peculiar and uncomfortable state of things was produced by the



<P>`resting and reveling' process.&nbsp; The days kept getting longer and



<P>longer, the weather was unusually variable and so were tempers, and



<P>unsettled feeling possessed everyone, and Satan found plenty of



<P>mischief for the idle hands to do.&nbsp; As the height of luxury, Meg



<P>put out some of her sewing, and then found time hang so heavily that



<P>she fell to snipping and spoiling her clothes in her attempts to



<P>furbish them up a`la Moffat.&nbsp; Jo read till her eyes gave out and



<P>she was sick of books, got so fidgety that even good-natured Laurie



<P>had a quarrel with her, and so reduced in spirits that she desperately



<P>wished she had gone with Aunt March.&nbsp; Beth got on pretty well,



<P>for she was constantly forgetting that it was to be all play and



<P>no work, and fell back into her old ways now and then.&nbsp; But something



<P>in the air affected her, and more than once her tranquility was much



<P>disturbed, so much so that on one occasion she actually shook poor



<P>dear Joanna and told her she was a fright'.&nbsp; Amy fared worst of

all,



<P>for her resources were small, and when her sisters left her to amuse



<P>herself, she soon found that accomplished and important little self



<P>a great burden.&nbsp; She didn't like dolls, fairy tales were childish,



<P>and one couldn't draw all the time.&nbsp; Tea parties didn't amount

to



<P>much neither did picnics unless very well conducted.&nbsp; "If one could



<P>have a fine house, full of nice girls, or go traveling, the summer



<P>would be delightful, but to stay at home with three selfish sisters



<P>and a grown-up boy was enough to try the patience of a Boaz,"



<P>complained Miss Malaprop, after several days devoted to pleasure,



<P>fretting, and ennui.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No one would own that they were tired of the experiment, but



<P>by Friday night each acknowledged to herself that she was glad the



<P>week was nearly done.&nbsp; Hoping to impress the lesson more deeply,



<P>Mrs. March, who had a good deal of humor, resolved to finish off



<P>the trial in an appropriate manner, so she gave Hannah a holiday and



<P>let the girls enjoy the full effect of the play system.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When they got up on Saturday morning, there was no fire in



<P>the kitchen, no breakfast in the dining room, and no mother



<P>anywhere to be seen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mercy on us!&nbsp; What has happened?" cried Jo, staring about



<P>her in dismay.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg ran upstairs and soon came back again, looking relieved



<P>but rather bewildered, and a little ashamed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mother isn't sick, only very tired, and she says she is



<P>going to stay quietly in her room all day and let us do the best



<P>we can.&nbsp; It's a very queer thing for her to do, she doesn't act



<P>a bit like herself.&nbsp; But she says it has been a hard week for



<P>her, so we mustn't grumble but take care of ourselves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's easy enough, and I like the idea, I'm aching for



<P>something to do, that is, some new amusement, you know," added



<P>Jo quickly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In fact it was an immense relief to them all to have a little



<P>work, and they took hold with a will, but soon realized the truth



<P>of Hannah's saying, "Housekeeping ain't no joke."&nbsp; There was plenty



<P>of food in the larder, and while Beth and Amy set the table, Meg and



<P>Jo got breakfast, wondering as they did why servants ever talked



<P>about hard work.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall take some up to Mother, though she said we were not



<P>to think of her, for she'd take care of herself," said Meg, who



<P>presided and felt quite matronly behind the teapot.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So a tray was fitted out before anyone began, and taken up



<P>with the cook's compliments.&nbsp; The boiled tea was very bitter, the



<P>omelet scorched, and the biscuits speckled with saleratus, but



<P>Mrs. March received her repast with thanks and laughed heartily



<P>over it after Jo was gone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor little souls, they will have a hard time, I'm afraid,



<P>but they won't suffer, and it will do them good," she said,



<P>producing the more palatable viands with which she had provided



<P>herself, and disposing of the bad breakfast, so that their



<P>feelings might not be hurt, a motherly little deception for which



<P>they were grateful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Many were the complaints below, and great the chagrin of



<P>the head cook at her failures.&nbsp; "Never mind, I'll get the dinner



<P>and be servant, you be mistress, keep your hands nice, see



<P>company, and give orders," said Jo, who knew still less than Meg,



<P>about culinary affairs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This obliging offer was gladly accepted, and Margaret retired



<P>to the parlor, which she hastily put in order by whisking the



<P>litter under the sofa and shutting the blinds to save the trouble



<P>of dusting.&nbsp; Jo, with perfect faith in her own powers and a



<P>friendly desire to make up the quarrel, immediately put a note in



<P>the office, inviting Laurie to dinner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'd better see what you have got before you think of having



<P>company," said Meg, when informed of the hospitable but rash act.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, there's corned beef and plenty of poatoes, and I shall



<P>get some asparagus and a lobster, `for a relish', as Hannah says.



<P>We'll have lettuce and make a salad.&nbsp; I don't know how, but the



<P>book tells.&nbsp; I'll have blancmange and strawberries for dessert,



<P>and coffee too, if you want to be elegant."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't try too many messes, Jo, for you can't make anything



<P>but gingerbread and molasses candy fit to eat.&nbsp; I wash my hands



<P>of the dinner party, and since you have asked Laurie on your own



<P>responsibility, you may just take care of him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't want you to do anything but be civil to him and help



<P>to the pudding.&nbsp; You'll give me your advice if I get in a muddle,



<P>won't you?" asked Jo, rather hurt.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, but I don't know much, except about bread and a few



<P>trifles.&nbsp; You had better ask Mother's leave before you order



<P>anything," returned Meg prudently.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course I shall.&nbsp; I'm not a fool."&nbsp; And Jo went off in

a



<P>huff at the doubts expressed of her powers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Get what you like, and don't disturb me.&nbsp; I'm going out to



<P>dinner and can't worry about things at home," said Mrs. March, when



<P>Jo spoke to her.&nbsp; "I never enjoyed housekeeping, and I'm going

to



<P>take a vacation today, and read, write, go visiting, and amuse myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The unusual spectacle of her busy mother rocking comfortably



<P>and reading early in the morning made Jo feel as if some unnatural



<P>phenomenon had occurred, for an eclipse, an earthquake, or a



<P>volcanic eruption would hardly have seemed stranger.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Everything is out of sorts, somehow," she said to herself,



<P>going downstairs.&nbsp; "There's Beth crying, that's a sure sign that



<P>something is wrong in this family.&nbsp; If Amy is bothering, I'll



<P>shake her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Feeling very much out of sorts herself, Jo hurried into the



<P>parlor to find Beth sobbing over Pip, the canary, who lay dead in



<P>the cage with his little claws pathetically extended, as if



<P>imploring the food for want of which he had died.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's all my fault, I forgot him, there isn't a seed or a



<P>drop left.&nbsp; Oh, Pip!&nbsp; Oh, Pip!&nbsp; How could I be so cruel

to you?"



<P>cried Beth, taking the poor thing in her hands and trying to



<P>restore him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo peeped into his half-open eye, felt his little heart, and



<P>finding him stiff and cold, shook her head, and offered her domino



<P>box for a coffin.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Put him in the oven, and maybe his will get warm and revive,"



<P>said Amy hopefully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He's been starved, and he shan't be baked now he's dead.&nbsp; I'll



<P>make him a shroud, and he shall be buried in the garden, and I'll



<P>never have another bird, never, my Pip!&nbsp; For I am too bad to own



<P>one," murmured Beth, sitting on the floor with her pet folded in



<P>her hands.



<P>"The funeral shall be this afternoon, and we will all go.&nbsp; Now,



<P>don't cry, Bethy.&nbsp; It's a pity, but nothing goes right this week,



<P>and Pip has had the worst of the experiment.&nbsp; Make the shroud,

and



<P>lay him in my box, and after the dinner party, we'll have a nice



<P>little funeral," said Jo, beginning to feel as if she had undertaken



<P>a good deal.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Leaving the others to console Beth, she departed to the kitchen,



<P>which was in a most discouraging state of confusion.&nbsp; Putting on

a



<P>big apron, she fell to work and got the dishes piled up ready for



<P>washing, when she discovered that the fire was out.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here's a sweet prospect!" muttered Jo, slamming the stove



<P>door open, and poking vigorously among the cinders.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Having rekindled the fire, she thought she would go to market



<P>while the water heated.&nbsp; The walk revived her spirits, and flattering



<P>herself that she had made good bargins, she trudged home again, after



<P>buying a very young lobster, some very old asparagus, and two boxes



<P>of acid strawberries.&nbsp; By the time she got cleared up, the dinner



<P>arrived and the stove was red-hot.&nbsp; Hannah had left a pan of bread



<P>to rise, Meg had worked it up early, set it on the hearth for a



<P>second rising, and forgotten it.&nbsp; Meg was entertaining Sallie



<P>Gardiner in the parlor, when the door flew open and a floury, crocky,



<P>flushed, and disheveled figure appeared, demanding tartly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I say, isn't bread `riz' enough when it runs over the pans?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sallie began to laugh, but Meg nodded and lifted her eyebrows



<P>as high as they would go, which caused the apparition to vanish and



<P>put the sour bread into the oven without further delay.&nbsp; Mrs. March



<P>went out, after peeping here and there to see how matters went, also



<P>saying a word of comfort to Beth, who sat making a winding sheet,



<P>while the dear departed lay in state in the domino box.&nbsp; A strange



<P>sense of helplessness fell upon the girls as the gray bonnet



<P>vanished round the corner, and despair seized them when a few minutes



<P>later Miss Crocker appeared, and said she'd come to dinner.&nbsp; Now



<P>this lady was a thin, yellow spinster, with a sharp nose and



<P>inquisitive eyes, who saw everything and gossiped about all she saw.



<P>They disliked her, but had been taught to be kind to her, simply



<P>because she was old and poor and had few friends.&nbsp; So Meg gave

her



<P>the easy chair and tried to entertain her, while she asked questions,



<P>critsized everything, and told stories of the people whom she knew.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Language cannot describe the anxieties, experiences, and exertions



<P>which Jo underwent that morning, and the dinner she served up became

a



<P>standing joke.&nbsp; Fearing to ask any more advice, she did her best

alone,



<P>and discovered that something more than energy and good will is



<P>necessary to make a cook.&nbsp; She boiled the asparagus for an hour

and was



<P>grieved to find the heads cooked off and the stalks harder than ever.



<P>The bread burned black, for the salad dressing so aggravated her that



<P>she could not make it fit to ear.&nbsp; The lobster was a scarlet mystery

to



<P>her, but she hammered and poked till it was unshelled and its meager



<P>proportions concealed in a grove of lettuce leaves.&nbsp; The potatoes

had



<P>to be hurried, not to keep the asparagus waiting, and were not done



<P>at the last.&nbsp; The blancmange was lumpy, and the strawberries not

as



<P>ripe as they looked, having been skilfully `deaconed'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, they can eat beef and bread and butter, if they are



<P>hungry, only it's mortifying to have to spend your whole morning for



<P>nothing," thought Jo, as she rang the bell half an hour later than



<P>usual, and stood, hot, tired, and dispirited, surveying the feast



<P>spread before Laurie, accustomed to all sorts of elegance, and Miss



<P>Crocker, whose tattling tongue would report them far and wide.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Jo would gladly have gone under the table, as one thing



<P>after another was tasted and left, while Amy giggled, Meg looked



<P>distressed, Miss Crocker pursed her lips, and Laurie talked and



<P>laughed with all his might to give a cheerful tone to the festive



<P>scene.&nbsp; Jo's one strong point was the fruit, for she had sugared

it



<P>well, and had a pitcher of rich cream to eat with it.&nbsp; Her hot

cheeks



<P>cooled a trifle, and she drew a long breath as the pretty glass



<P>plates went round, and everyone looked graciously at the little rosy



<P>islands floating in a sea of cream.&nbsp; Miss Crocker tasted first,

made



<P>a wry face, and drank some water hastily.&nbsp; Jo, who refused, thinking



<P>there might not be enough, for they dwindled sadly after the picking



<P>over, glanced at Laurie, but he was eating away manfully, though there



<P>was a slight pucker about his mouth and he kept his eye fixed on his



<P>plate.&nbsp; Amy, who was fond of delicate fare, took a heaping spoonful,



<P>choked, hid her face in her napkin, and left the table precipitately.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, what is it?" exclaimed Jo, trembling.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Salt instead of sugar, and the cream is sour," replied Meg



<P>with a tragic gesture.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo uttered a groan and fell back in her chair, remembering that



<P>she had given a last hasty powdering to the berries out of one of



<P>the two boxes on the kitchen table, and had neglected to put the



<P>milk in the refrigerator.&nbsp; She turned scarlet and was on the verge



<P>of crying, when she met Laurie's eyes, which would look merry in



<P>spite of his heroic efforts.&nbsp; The comical side of the affair suddenly



<P>struck her, and she laughed till the tears ran down her cheeks.&nbsp;

So



<P>did everyone else, even `Croaker' as the girls called the old lady,



<P>and the unfortunate dinner ended gaily, with bread and butter, olives



<P>and fun.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I haven't strength of mind enough to clear up now, so we will



<P>sober ourselves with a funeral," said Jo, as they rose, and Miss



<P>Crocker made ready to go, being eager to tell the new story at



<P>another friend's dinner table.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They did sober themselves for Beth's sake.&nbsp; Laurie dug a grave



<P>under the ferns in the grove, little Pip was laid in, with many tears



<P>by his tender-hearted mistress, and covered with moss, while a wreath



<P>of violets and chickweed was hung on the stone which bore his epitaph,



<P>composed by Jo while she struggled with the dinner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here lies Pip March,



<P>Who died the 7th of June;



<P>Loved and lamented sore,



<P>And not forgotten soon.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At the conclusion of the ceremonies, Beth retired to her room,



<P>overcome with emotion and lobster, but there was no place of repose,



<P>for the beds were not made, and she found her grief much assuaged



<P>by beating up the pillows and putting things in order.&nbsp; Meg helped



<P>Jo clear away the remains of the feast, which took half the afternoon



<P>and left them so tired that they agreed to be contented with tea and



<P>toast for supper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie took Amy to drive, which was a deed of charity, for the



<P>sour cream seemed to have had a bad effect upon her temper.&nbsp; Mrs.



<P>March came home to find the three older girls hard at work in the



<P>middle of the afternoon, and a glance at the closet gave her an idea



<P>of the success of one part of the experiment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Before the housewives could rest, several people called, and



<P>there was a scramble to get ready to see them.&nbsp; Then tea must be

got,



<P>errands done, and one or two necessary bits of sewing neglected until



<P>the last minute.&nbsp; As twilight fell, dewy and still, one by one

they



<P>gathered on the porch where the June roses were budding beautifully,



<P>and each groaned or sighed as she sat down, as if tired or troubled.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a dreadful day this has been!" began Jo, usually the first



<P>to speak.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It has seemed shorter than usual, but so uncomfortable," said Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a bit like home," added Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It can't seem so without Marmee and little Pip," sighed Beth,



<P>glancing with full eyes at the empty cage above her head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here's Mother, dear, and you shall have another bird tomorrow,



<P>if you want it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she spoke, Mrs. March came and took her place among them,



<P>looking as if her holiday had not been much pleasanter than theirs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Are you satisfied with your experiment, girls, or do you want



<P>another week of it?" she asked, as Beth nestled up to her and the



<P>rest turned toward her with brightening faces, as flowers turn



<P>toward the sun.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't!" cried Jo decidedly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nor I," echoed the others.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You think then, that it is better to have a few duties and



<P>live a little for others, do you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Lounging and larking doesn't pay," observed Jo, shaking her head.



<P>"I'm tired of it and mean to go to work at something right off."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Suppose you learn plain cooking.&nbsp; That's a useful accomplishment,



<P>which no woman should be without," said Mrs. March, laughing



<P>inaudibly at the recollection of Jo's dinner party, for she had



<P>met Miss Crocker and heard her account of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mother, did you go away and let everything be, just to see how



<P>we'd get on?" cried Meg, who had had suspicions all day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I wanted you to see how the comfort of all depends on



<P>each doing her share faithfully.&nbsp; While Hannah and I did your work,



<P>you got on pretty well, though I don't think you were very happy



<P>or amiable.&nbsp; So I thought, as a little lesson, I would show you



<P>what happens when everyone thinks only of herself.&nbsp; Don't you feel



<P>that it is pleasanter to help one another, to have daily duties



<P>which make leisure sweet when it comes, and to bear and forbear,



<P>that home may be comfortable and lovely to us all?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We do, Mother we do!" cried the girls.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then let me advise you to take up your little burdens again,



<P>for though they seem heavy sometimes, they are good for us, and



<P>lighten as we learn to carry them.&nbsp; Work is wholesome, and there



<P>is plenty for everyone.&nbsp; It keeps us from ennui and mischief, is



<P>good for health and spirits, and gives us a sense of power and



<P>independence better than money or fashion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We'll work like bees, and love it too, see if we don't,"



<P>said Jo.&nbsp; "I'll learn plain cooking for my holiday task, and the



<P>dinner party I have shall be a success."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll make the set of shirts for father, instead of letting



<P>you do it, Marmee.&nbsp; I can and I will, though I'm not fond of sewing.



<P>That will be better than fussing over my own things, which are plenty



<P>nice enough as they are." said Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll do my lessons every day, and not spend so much time with



<P>my music and dolls.&nbsp; I am a stupid thing, and ought to be studying,



<P>not playing," was Beth's resolution, while Amy followed their example



<P>by heroically declaring, "I shall learn to make buttonholes, and



<P>attend to my parts of speech."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very good!&nbsp; Then I am quite satisfied with the experiment, and



<P>fancy that we shall not have to repeat it, only don't go to the other



<P>extreme and delve like slaves.&nbsp; Have regular hours for work and

play,



<P>make each day both useful and pleasant, and prove that you understand



<P>the worth of time by employing it well.&nbsp; Then youth will be delightful,



<P>old age will bring few regrets, and life become a beautiful success,

in



<P>spite of poverty."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We'll remember, Mother!"&nbsp; And they did.



<P>

   <TITLE>Chapter 05</TITLE>
