<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FIVE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What in the world are you going to do now, Jo." asked



<P>Meg one snowy afternoon, as her sister came tramping through



<P>the hall, in rubber boots, old sack, and hood, with a broom



<P>in one hand and a shovel in the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Going out for exercise," answered Jo with a mischievous



<P>twinkle in her eyes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should think two long walks this morning would have



<P>been enough!&nbsp; It's cold and dull out, and I advise you to



<P>stay warm and dry by the fire, as I do," said Meg with a



<P>shiver.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never take advice!&nbsp; Can't keep still all day, and not



<P>being a pussycat, I don't like to doze by the fire.&nbsp; I like



<P>adventures, and I'm going to find some."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg went back to toast her feet and read IVANHOE, and Jo



<P>began to dig paths with great energy.&nbsp; The snow was light, and



<P>with her broom she soon swept a path all round the garden, for



<P>Beth to walk in when the sun came out and the invalid dolls



<P>needed air.&nbsp; Now, the garden separated the Marches' house from



<P>that of Mr. Laurence.&nbsp; Both stood in a suburb of the city, which



<P>was still countrylike, with groves and lawns, large gardens, and



<P>quiet streets.&nbsp; A low hedge parted the two estates.&nbsp; On one

side



<P>was an old, brown house, looking rather bare and shabby, robbed



<P>of the vines that in summer covered its walls and the flowers,



<P>which then surrounded it.&nbsp; On the other side was a stately stone



<P>mansion, plainly betokening every sort of comfort and luxury, from



<P>the big coach house and well-kept grounds to the conservatory and



<P>the glimpses of lovely things one caught between the rich curtains.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Yet it seemed a lonely, lifeless sort of house, for no children



<P>frolicked on the lawn, no motherly face ever smiled at the windows,



<P>and few people went in and out, except the old gentleman and his



<P>grandson.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To Jo's lively fancy, this fine house seemed a kind of enchanted



<P>palace, full of splendors and delights which no one enjoyed.&nbsp; She



<P>had long wanted to behold these hidden glories, and to know the



<P>Laurence boy, who looked as if he would like to be known, if he only



<P>knew how to begin.&nbsp; Since the party, she had been more eager than

ever,



<P>and had planned many ways of making friends with him, but he had not



<P>been seen lately, and Jo began to think he had gone away, when she



<P>one day spied a brown face at an upper window, looking wistfully down



<P>into their garden, where Beth and Amy were snow-balling one another.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That boy is suffering for society and fun," she said to herself.



<P>"His grandpa does not know what's good for him, and keeps him shut up



<P>all alone.&nbsp; He needs a party of jolly boys to play with, or somebody



<P>young and lively.&nbsp; I've a great mind to go over and tell the old



<P>gentleman so!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The idea amused Jo.&nbsp; who liked to do daring things and was



<P>always scandalizing Meg by her queer performances.&nbsp; The plan of



<P>`going over' was not forgotten.&nbsp; And when the snowy afternoon came,



<P>Jo resolved to try what could be done.&nbsp; She saw Mr. Lawrence drive

off,



<P>and then sallied out to dig her way down to the hedge, where she



<P>paused and took a survey.&nbsp; All quiet, curtains down at the lower

windows,



<P>servants out of sight, and nothing human visible but a curly



<P>black head leaning on a thin hand at the upper window.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There he is," thought Jo, "Poor boy!&nbsp; All alone and sick this



<P>dismal day.&nbsp; It's a shame!&nbsp; I'll toss up a snowball and make

him look



<P>out, and then say a kind word to him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Up went a handful of soft snow, and the head turned at once,



<P>showing a face which lost its listless look in a minute, as the big



<P>eyes brightened and the mouth began to smile.&nbsp; Jo nodded and laughed,



<P>and flourished her broom as she called out...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How do you do?&nbsp; Are you sick?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie opened the window, and croaked out as hoarsely as a raven...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Better, thank you.&nbsp; I've had a bad cold, and been shut up a



<P>week."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm sorry.&nbsp; What do you amuse yourself with?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing.&nbsp; It's dull as tombs up here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't you read?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not much.&nbsp; They won't let me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Can't somebody read to you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Grandpa does sometimes, but my books don't interest him, and



<P>I hate to ask Brooke all the time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have someone come and see you then."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There isn't anyone I'd like to see.&nbsp; Boys make such a row, and



<P>my head is weak."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Isn't there some nice girl who'd read and amuse you?&nbsp; Girls



<P>are quiet and like to play nurse."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't know any."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You know us," began Jo, then laughed and stopped.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So I do!&nbsp; Will you come, please?" cried Laurie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm not quiet and nice, but I'll come, if Mother will let me.



<P>I'll go ask her.&nbsp; Shut the window, like a good boy, and wait till

I



<P>come."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With that, Jo shouldered her broom and marched into the house,



<P>wondering what they would all say to her.&nbsp; Laurie was in a flutter



<P>of excitement at the idea of having company, and flew about to get



<P>ready, for as Mrs. March said, he was `a little gentleman'.&nbsp; and

did



<P>honor to the coming guest by brushing his curly pate, putting on a



<P>fresh color, and trying tidy up the room, which in spite of half a



<P>dozen servants, was anything but neat.&nbsp; Presently there came a

loud



<P>ring, than a decided voice, asking for `Mr. laurie', and a surprised-



<P>looking servant came running up to announce a young lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"All right, show her up, it's Miss Jo, "said Laurie, going to the



<P>door of his little parlor to meet Jo, who appeared, looking rosy and



<P>quite at her ease, with a covered dish in one hand and Beth's three



<P>kittens in the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here I am, bag and baggage," she said briskly.&nbsp; "Mother sent her



<P>love, and was glad if I could do anything for you.&nbsp; Meg wanted

me to



<P>bring some of her blancmange, she makes it very nicely, and Beth thought



<P>her cats would be comforting.&nbsp; I knew you'd laugh at them, but

I couldn't



<P>refuse, she was so anxious to do something."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It so happened that Beth's funny loan was just the thing, for



<P>in laughing over the kits, Laurie forgot his bashfulness, and grew



<P>sociable at once.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That looks too pretty to eat," he said, smiling with pleasure,



<P>as Jo uncovered the dish, and showed the blancmange, surrounded by a



<P>garland of green leaves, and the scarlet flowers of Amy's pet geranium.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It isn't anything, only they all felt kindly and wanted to show



<P>it.&nbsp; Tell the girl to put it away for your tea.&nbsp; It's so simple

you can



<P>eat it, and being soft, it will slip down without hurting your sore



<P>throat.&nbsp; What a cozy room this is!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It might be it it was kept nice, but the maids are lazy, and



<P>I don't know how to make them mind.&nbsp; It worries me though."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll right it up in two minutes, for it only needs to have the



<P>hearth brushed, so--and the things made straight on the mantelpiece,



<P>so--and the books put here, and the bottles there, and your sofa



<P>turned from the light, and the pillows plumped up a bit.&nbsp; Now then,



<P>you're fixed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And so he was, for, as she laughed and talked, Jo had whisked



<P>things into place and given quite a different air to the room.&nbsp;

Laurie



<P>watched her in respectful silence, and when she beckoned him to his



<P>sofa, he sat down with a sigh of satisfaction, saying gratefully...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How kind you are!&nbsp; Yes, that's what it wanted.&nbsp; Now please

take



<P>the big chair and let me do something to amuse my company."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I came to amuse you.&nbsp; Shall I read aloud?" and Jo looked



<P>affectionately toward some inviting books near by.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you!&nbsp; I've read all those, and if you don't mind, I'd



<P>rather talk," answered Laurie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a bit.&nbsp; I'll talk all day if you'll only set me going.



<P>Beth says I never know when to stop."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is Beth the rosy one, who stays at home good deal and sometimes



<P>goes out with a little basket?" asked Laurie with interest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, that's Beth.&nbsp; She's my girl, and a regular good one she is,

too."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The pretty one is Meg, and the curly-haired one is Amy, I believe?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie colored up, but answered frankly, "Why, you see I often



<P>hear you calling to one another, and when I'm alone up here, I can't



<P>help looking over at your house, you always seem to be having such



<P>good times.&nbsp; I beg your pardon for being so rude, but sometimes

you



<P>forget to put down the curtain at the window where the flowers are.



<P>And when the lamps are lighted, it's like looking at a picture to



<P>see the fire, and you all around the table with your mother.&nbsp; Her



<P>face is right opposite, and it looks so sweet behind the flowers,



<P>I can't help watching it.&nbsp; I haven't got any mother, you know."



<P>And Laurie poked the fire to hide a little twitching of the lips



<P>that he could not control.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The solitary, hungry look in his eyes went straight to Jo's



<P>warm heart.&nbsp; she had been so simply taught that there was no



<P>nonsense in her head, and at fifteen she was as innocent and frank



<P>as any child.&nbsp; Laurie was sick and lonely, and feeling how rich

she



<P>was in home and happiness, she gladly tried to share it with him.



<P>Her face was very friendly and her sharp voice unusually gentle as



<P>she said...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We'll never draw that curtain any more, and I give you leave



<P>to look as much as you like.&nbsp; I just wish, though, instead of peeping,



<P>you'd come over and see us.&nbsp; Mother is so splendid, she'd do you

heaps



<P>of good, and Beth would sing to you if I begged her to, and Amy would



<P>dance.&nbsp; Meg and I would make you laugh over our funny stage



<P>properties, and we'd have jolly times.&nbsp; Wouldn't your grandpa let

you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think he would, if your mother asked him.&nbsp; He's very kind,



<P>though he does not look so, and he lets me do what I like, pretty much,



<P>only he's afraid I might be a bother to strangers," began Laurie,



<P>brightening more and more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We are not strangers, we are neighbors, and you needn't think



<P>you'd be a bother.&nbsp; We want to know you, and I've been trying to

do



<P>it this ever so long.&nbsp; We haven't been here a great while, you

know,



<P>but we have got acquainted with all our neighbors but you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You see, Grandpa lives among his books, and doesn't mind much



<P>what happens outside.&nbsp; Mr. Brooke, my tutor, doesn't stay here,

you



<P>know, and I have no one to go about with me, so I just stop at home



<P>and get on as I can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's bad.&nbsp; You ought to make an effort and go visiting



<P>everywhere you are asked, then you'll have plenty of friends, and



<P>pleasant places to go to.&nbsp; Never mind being bashful.&nbsp; It won't

last



<P>long if you keep going."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie turned red again, but wasn't offended at being accused



<P>of bashfulness, for there was so much good will in Jo it was



<P>impossible not to take her blunt speeches as kindly as they were



<P>meant.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you like your school?" asked the boy, changing the subject,



<P>after a little pause, during which he stared at the fire and Jo



<P>looked about her, well pleased.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't go to school, I'm a businessman--girl, I mean.&nbsp; I go to



<P>wait on my great-aunt, and a dear, cross old soul she is, too,"



<P>answered Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie opened his mouth to ask another question, but remembering



<P>just in time that it wasn't manners to make too many inquiries into



<P>people's affairs, he shut it again, and looked uncomfortable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo liked his good breeding, and didn't mind having a laugh at



<P>Aunt March, so she gave him a lively description of the fidgety



<P>old lady, her fat poodle, the parrot that talked Spanish, and the



<P>library where she reveled.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie enjoyed that immensely, and when she told about the



<P>prim old gentleman who came once to woo Aunt March, and in the



<P>middle of a fine speech, how Poll had tweaked his wig off to his



<P>great dismay, the boy lay back and laughed till the tears ran



<P>down his cheeks, and a maid popped her head in to see what was



<P>the matter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; That does me no end of good.&nbsp; Tell on, please," he



<P>said, taking his face out of the sofa cushion, red and shining



<P>with merriment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Much elated with her success, Jo did `tell on', all about



<P>their plays and plans, their hopes and fears for Father, and



<P>the most interesting events of the little world in which the



<P>sisters lived.&nbsp; Then they got to talking about books, and to



<P>Jo's delight, she found that Laurie loved them as well as she



<P>did, and had read even more than herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you like them so much, come down and see ours.&nbsp; Grandfather



<P>is out, so you needn't be afraid," said Laurie, getting up.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm not afraid of anything," returned Jo, with a toss of



<P>the head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't believe you are!" exclaimed the boy, looking at her



<P>with much admiration, though he privately thought she would have



<P>good reason to be a trifle afraid of the old gentleman, if she



<P>met hem in some of his moods.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The atmosphere of the whole house being summerlike, Laurie



<P>led the way from room to room, letting Jo stop to examine whatever



<P>struck her fancy.&nbsp; And so, at last they came to the library,



<P>where she clapped her hands and pranced, as she always did when



<P>especially delighted.&nbsp; It was lined with books, and there were



<P>pictures and statues, and distracting little cabinets full of



<P>coins and curiosities, and Sleepy Hollow chairs, and queer tables,



<P>and bronzes, and best of all, a great open fireplace with quaint



<P>tiles all round it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What richness!" sighed Jo, sinking into the depth of a velour



<P>chair and gazing about her with an air of intense satisfaction.



<P>"Theodore Laurence, you ought to be the happiest boy in the world,"



<P>she added impressively.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A fellow can't live on books," said Laurie, shaking his head



<P>as he perched on a table opposite.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Before he could more, a bell rang, and Jo flew up, exclaiming



<P>with alarm, "Mercy me!&nbsp; It's your grandpa!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, what if it is?&nbsp; You are not afraid of anything, you



<P>know," returned the boy, looking wicked.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think I am a little bit afraid of him, but I don't know



<P>why I should be.&nbsp; Marmee said I might come, and I don't think



<P>you're any the worse for it," said Jo, composing herself, though



<P>she kept her eyes on the door.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm a great deal better for it, and ever so much obliged.



<P>I'm only afraid you are very tired of talking to me.&nbsp; It was so



<P>pleasant, I couldn't bear to stop," said Laurie gratefully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The doctor to see you, sir," and the maid beckoned as she



<P>spoke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Would you mind if I left you for a minute?&nbsp; I suppose I



<P>must see him," said Laurie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't mind me.&nbsp; I'm happy as a cricket here," answered Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie went away, and his guest amused herself in her own way.



<P>She was standing before a fine portrait of the old gentleman when



<P>the door opened again, and without turning, she said decidedly, "I'm



<P>sure now that I shouldn't be afraid of him, for he's got kind eyes,



<P>though his mouth is grim, and he looks as if he had a tremendous will



<P>of his own.&nbsp; He isn't as handsome as my grandfather, but I like

him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, ma'am," said a gruff voice behind her, and there,



<P>to her great dismay, stood old Mr. Laurence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Jo blushed till she couldn't blush any redder, and her



<P>heart began to beat uncomfortably fast as she thought what she had



<P>said.&nbsp; For a minute a wild desire to run away possessed her, but



<P>that was cowardly, and the girls would laugh at her, so she resolved



<P>to stay and get out of the scrape as she could.&nbsp; A second look

showed



<P>her that the living eyes, under the bushy eyebrows, were kinder even



<P>than the painted ones, and there was a sly twinkle in them, which



<P>lessened her fear a good deal.&nbsp; The gruff voice was gruffer than

ever,



<P>as the old gentleman said abruptly, after the dreadful pause, "So



<P>you're not afraid of me, hey?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not much, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And you don't think me as handsome as your grandfather?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not quite, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I've got a tremendous will, have I?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I only said I thought so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you like me in spite of it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I do, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That answer pleased the old gentleman.&nbsp; He gave a short laugh,



<P>shook hands with her, and, putting his finger under her chin, turned



<P>up her face, examined it gravely, and let it go, saying with a nod,



<P>"You've got your grandfather's spirit, if you haven't his face.&nbsp;

He



<P>was a fine man, my dear, but what is better, he was a brave and an



<P>honest one, and I was proud to be his friend."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, sir," And Jo was quite comfortable after that, for



<P>it suited her exactly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What have you been doing to this boy of mine, hey?" was the



<P>next question, sharply put.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Only trying to be neighborly, sir."&nbsp; And Jo to how her visit



<P>came about.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You think he needs cheering up a bit, do you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sir, he seems a little lonely, and young folks would do



<P>him good perhaps.&nbsp; We are only girls, but we should be glad to



<P>help if we could, for we don't forget the splendid Christmas present



<P>you sent us," said Jo eagerly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tut, tut, tut!&nbsp; That was the boy's affair.&nbsp; How is the poor



<P>woman?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Doing nicely, sir."&nbsp; And off went Jo, talking very fast, as



<P>she told all about the Hummels, in whom her mother had interested



<P>richer friends than they were.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Just her father's way of doing good.&nbsp; I shall come and see



<P>your mother some fine day.&nbsp; Tell her so.&nbsp; There's the tea

bell,



<P>we have it early on the boy's account.&nbsp; Come down and go on being



<P>neighborly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you'd like to have me, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shouldn't ask you, if I didn't."&nbsp; And Mr. Laurence offered



<P>her his arm with old-fashioned courtesy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What would Meg say to this?" thought Jo, as she was marched



<P>away, while her eyes danced with fun as she imagined herself telling



<P>the story at home.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hey!&nbsp; Why, what the dickens has come to the fellow?" said the



<P>old gentleman, as Laurie came running downstairs and brought up with



<P>a start of surprise at the astounding sight of Jo arm in arm with



<P>his redoubtable grandfather.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I didn't know you'd come, sir," he began, as Jo gave him a



<P>triumphant little glance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's evident, by the way you racket downstairs.&nbsp; Come to



<P>your tea, sir, and behave like a gentleman."&nbsp; And having pulled



<P>the boy's hair by way of a caress, Mr. Laurence walked on, while



<P>Laurie went through a series of comic evolutions behind their



<P>backs, which nearly produced an explosion of laughter from Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The old gentleman did not say much as he drank his four



<P>cups of tea, but he watched the young people, who soon chatted



<P>away like old friends, and the change in his grandson did not



<P>escape him.&nbsp; There was color, light, and life in the boy's face



<P>now, vivacity in his manner, and genuine merriment in his laugh.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She's right, the lad is lonely.&nbsp; I'll see what these little



<P>girls can do for him," thought Mr. Laurence, as he looked and



<P>listened.&nbsp; He liked Jo, for her odd, blunt ways suited him, and



<P>she seemed to understand the boy almost as well as if she had



<P>been one herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If the Laurences had been what Jo called `prim and poky',



<P>she would not have got on at all, for such people always made



<P>her shy and awkward.&nbsp; But finding them free and easy, she was



<P>so herself, and made a good impression.&nbsp; When they rose she



<P>proposed to go, but Laurie said he had something more to show



<P>her, and took her away to the conservatory, which had been



<P>lighted for her benefit.&nbsp; It seemed quite fairylike to Jo, as



<P>she went up and down the walks, enjoying the blooming walls on



<P>either side, the soft light, the damp sweet air, and the wonderful



<P>vines and trees that hung about her, while her new friend cut the



<P>finest flowers till his hands were full.&nbsp; Then he tied them up,



<P>saying, with the happy look Jo liked to see, "Please give these



<P>to your mother, and tell her I like the medicine she sent me very



<P>much."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They found Mr. Laurence standing before the fire in the great



<P>drawing room, by Jo's attention was entirely absorbed by a grand



<P>piano, which stood open.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you play?" she asked, turning to Laurie with a respectful



<P>expression.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sometimes," he answered modestly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Please do now.&nbsp; I want to hear it, so I can tell Beth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Won't you first?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't know how.&nbsp; Too stupid to learn, but I love music dearly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So Laurie played and Jo listened, with her nose luxuriously



<P>buried in heliotrope and tea roses.&nbsp; Her respect and regard for



<P>the `Laurence' boy increased very much, for he played remarkably well



<P>and didn't put on any airs.&nbsp; She wished Beth could hear him, but



<P>she did not say so, only praised him till he was quite abashed, and



<P>his grandfather came to his rescue.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That will do, that will do, young lady.&nbsp; too many sugarplums



<P>are not good for him.&nbsp; His music isn't bad, but I hope he will

do



<P>as well in more important things.&nbsp; Going?&nbsp; well, I'm much

obliged



<P>to you, and I hope you'll come again.&nbsp; My respects to your mother.



<P>Good night, Doctor Jo."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He shook hands kindly, but looked as if something did not



<P>please him.&nbsp; When they got into the hall, Jo asked Laurie if she



<P>had said something amiss.&nbsp; He shook his head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, it was me.&nbsp; He doesn't like to hear me play."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why not?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll tell you some day.&nbsp; John is going home with you, as I



<P>can't."



<P>"No need of that.&nbsp; I am not a young lady, and it's only a



<P>step.&nbsp; Take care of yourself, won't you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, but you will come again, I hope?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you promise to come and see us after you are well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good night, Laurie!"



<P>"Good night, Jo, good night!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When all the afternoon's adventures had been told, the family



<P>felt inclined to go visiting in a body, for each found something



<P>very attractive in the big house on the other side of the hedge.



<P>Mrs. March wanted to talk of her father with the old man who had



<P>not forgotten him, Meg longed to walk in the conservatory, Beth



<P>sighed for the grand piano.&nbsp; and Amy was eager to see the fine



<P>pictures and statues.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mother, why didn't Mr. Laurence like to have Laurie play?"



<P>asked Jo, who was of an inquiring disposition.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not sure, but I think it was because his son, Laurie's



<P>father, married an Italian lady, a musician, which displeased the



<P>old man, who is very proud.&nbsp; The lady was good and lovely and



<P>accomplished, but he did not like her, and never saw his son after



<P>he married.&nbsp; They both died when Laurie was a little child, and



<P>then his grandfather took him home.&nbsp; I fancy the boy, who was born



<P>in Italy, is not very strong, and the old man is afraid of losing



<P>him, which makes him so careful.&nbsp; Laurie comes naturally by his



<P>love of music, for he is like his mother, and I dare say his



<P>grandfather fears that he may want to be a musician.&nbsp; At any rate,



<P>his skill reminds him of the woman he did not like, and so he



<P>`glowered' as Jo said."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear me, how romantic!" exclaimed Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How silly!" said Jo.&nbsp; "Let him be a musician if he wants to,



<P>and not plague his life out sending him to college, when he hates



<P>to go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's why he has such handsome black eyes and pretty manners,



<P>I suppose.&nbsp; Italians are always nice," said Meg, who was a little



<P>sentimental.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What do you know about his eyes and his manners?&nbsp; You never



<P>spoke to him, hardly," cried Jo, who was not sentimental.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I saw him at the party, and what you tell shows that he knows



<P>how to behave.&nbsp; That was a nice little speech about the medicine



<P>Mother sent him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He meant the blanc mange, I suppose."



<P>"How stupid you are, child!&nbsp; He meant you, of course."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did he?" And Jo opened her eyes as if it had never occurred



<P>to her before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never saw such a girl!&nbsp; You don't know a compliment when



<P>you get it," said Meg, with the air of a young lady who knew all



<P>about the matter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think they are great nonsense, and I'll thank you not to



<P>be silly and spoil my fun.&nbsp; Laurie's a nice boy and I like him,



<P>and I won't have any sentimental stuff about compliments and such



<P>rubbish.&nbsp; We'll all be good to him because he hasn't got any mother,



<P>and he may come over and see us, mayn't he, Marmee?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Jo, your little friend is very welcome, and I hope Meg



<P>will remember that children should be children as long as they can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't call myself a child, and I'm not in my teens yet,"



<P>observed Amy.&nbsp; "What do you say, Beth?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was thinking about our `PILGRIM'S PROGRESS'," answered Beth,



<P>who had not heard a word.&nbsp; "How we got out of the Slough and through



<P>the Wicket Gate by resolving to be good, and up the steep hill by



<P>trying, and that maybe the house over there, full of splendid things,



<P>is going to be our Palace Beautiful."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We have got to get by the lions first," said Jo, as if she



<P>rather liked the prospect.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 39</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER THIRTY-NINE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie went to Nice intending to stay a week, and remained



<P>a month.&nbsp; He was tired of wandering about alone, and Amy's



<P>familiar presence seemed to give a homelike charm to the



<P>foreign scenes in which she bore a part.&nbsp; He rather missed the



<P>`petting' he used to receive, and enjoyed a taste of it again,



<P>for no attentions, however flattering, from strangers, were half



<P>so pleasant as the sisterly adoration of the girls at home.&nbsp; Amy



<P>never would pet him like the others, but she was very glad to



<P>see him now, and quite clung to him, feeling that he was the



<P>representative of the dear family for whom she longed more



<P>than she would confess.&nbsp; They naturally took comfort in each



<P>other's society and were much together, riding, walking, dancing,



<P>or dawdling, for at Nice no one can be very industrious during



<P>the gay season.&nbsp; But, while apparently amusing themselves in



<P>the most careless fashion, they were half-consciously making



<P>discoveries and forming opinions about each other.&nbsp; Amy rose



<P>daily in the estimation of her friend, but he sank in hers,



<P>and each felt the truth before a word was spoken.&nbsp; Amy tried



<P>to please, and succeeded, for she was grateful for the many



<P>pleasures he gave her, and repaid him with the little services



<P>to which womanly women know how to lend an indescribable



<P>charm.&nbsp; Laurie made no effort of any kind, but just let



<P>himself drift along as comfortably as possible, trying to



<P>forget, and feeling that all women owed him a kind word because



<P>one had been cold to him.&nbsp; It cost him no effort to be



<P>generous, and he would have given Amy all the trinkets in



<P>Nice if she would have taken them, but at the same time he



<P>felt that he could not change the opinion she was forming of



<P>him, and he rather dreaded the keen blue eyes that seemed to



<P>watch him with such half-sorrowful, half-scornful surprise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"All the rest have gone to Monaco for the day.&nbsp; I preferred



<P>to stay at home and write letters.&nbsp; They are done now,



<P>and I am going to Valrosa to sketch, will you come?' said Amy,



<P>as she joined Laurie one lovely day when he lounged in as usual



<P>about noon.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, yes, but isn't it rather warm for such a long walk?"



<P>he answered slowly, for the shaded salon looked inviting after



<P>the glare without.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm going to have the little carriage, and Baptiste can



<P>drive, so you'll have nothing to do but hold your umbrella,



<P>and keep your gloves nice," returned Amy, with a sarcastic



<P>glance at the immaculate kids, which were a weak point with



<P>Laurie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then I'll go with pleasure."&nbsp; And he put out his hand for



<P>her sketchbook.&nbsp; But she tucked it under her arm with a sharp...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't trouble yourself.&nbsp; It's no exertion to me, but you



<P>don't look equal to it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie lifted his eyebrows and followed at a leisurely pace



<P>as she ran downstairs, but when they got into the carriage he took



<P>the reins himself, and left little Baptiste nothing to do but fold



<P>his arms and fall asleep on his perch.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The two never quarreled.&nbsp; Amy was too well-bred, and just now



<P>Laurie was too lazy, so in a minute he peeped under her hatbrim



<P>with an inquiring air.&nbsp; She answered him with a smile, and they



<P>went on together in the most amicable manner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a lovely drive, along winding roads rich in the picturesque



<P>scenes that delight beauty-loving eyes.&nbsp; Here an ancient



<P>monastery, whence the solemn chanting of the monks came down to



<P>them.&nbsp; There a bare-legged shepherd, in wooden shoes, pointed hat,



<P>and rough jacket over one shoulder, sat piping on a stone while



<P>his goats skipped among the rocks or lay at his feet.&nbsp; Meek,



<P>mouse-colored donkeys, laden with panniers of freshly cut grass



<P>passed by, with a pretty girl in a capaline sitting between the



<P>green piles, or an old woman spinning with a distaff as she went.



<P>Brown, soft-eyed children ran out from the quaint stone hovels



<P>to offer nosegays, or bunches of oranges still on the bough.



<P>Gnarled olive trees covered the hills with their dusky foliage,



<P>fruit hung golden in the orchard, and great scarlet anemones



<P>fringed the roadside, while beyond green slopes and craggy heights,



<P>the Maritime Alps rose sharp and white against the blue Italian sky.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Valrosa well deserved its name, for in that climate of perpetual



<P>summer roses blossomed everywhere.&nbsp; They overhung the



<P>archway, thrust themselves between the bars of the great gate



<P>with a sweet welcome to passers-by, and lined the avenue, winding



<P>through lemon trees and feathery palms up to the villa on the hill.



<P>Every shadowy nook, where seats invited one to stop and rest, was



<P>a mass of bloom, every cool grotto had its marble nymph smiling



<P>from a veil of flowers and every fountain reflected crimson, white,



<P>or pale pink roses, leaning down to smile at their own beauty.



<P>Roses covered the walls of the house, draped the cornices, climbed



<P>the pillars, and ran riot over the balustrade of the wide terrace,



<P>whence one looked down on the sunny Mediterranean, and the white-walled



<P>city on its shore.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is a regular honeymoon paradise, isn't it?&nbsp; Did you



<P>ever see such roses?" asked Amy, pausing on the terrace to enjoy



<P>the view, and a luxurious whiff of perfume that came wandering by.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, nor felt such thorns," returned Laurie, with his thumb



<P>in his mouth, after a vain attempt to capture a solitary scarlet



<P>flower that grew just beyond his reach.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Try lower down, and pick those that have no thorns," said



<P>Amy, gathering three of the tiny cream-colored ones that starred



<P>the wall behind her.&nbsp; She put them in his buttonhole as a peace



<P>offering, and he stood a minute looking down at them with a



<P>curious expression, for in the Italian part of his nature there



<P>was a touch of superstition, and he was just then in that state



<P>of half-sweet, half-bitter melancholy, when imaginative young



<P>men find significance in trifles and food for romance everywhere.



<P>He had thought of Jo in reaching after the thorny red rose, for



<P>vivid flowers became her, and she had often worn ones like that



<P>from the greenhouse at home.&nbsp; The pale roses Amy gave him were



<P>the sort that the Italians lay in dead hands, never in bridal



<P>wreaths, and for a moment he wondered if the omen was for Jo or



<P>for himself, but the next instant his American common sense got



<P>the better of sentimentality, and he laughed a heartier laugh



<P>than Amy had heard since he came.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's good advice, you'd better take it and save your fingers,"



<P>she said, thinking her speech amused him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, I will," he answered in jest, and a few months



<P>later he did it in earnest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Laurie, when are you going to your grandfather?" she asked



<P>presently, as she settled herself on a rustic seat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very soon."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have said that a dozen times within the last three



<P>weeks."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say, short answers save trouble."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He expects you, and you really ought to go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hospitable creature!&nbsp; I know it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then why don't you do it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Natural depravity, I suppose."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Natural indolence, you mean.&nbsp; It's really dreadful!"



<P>And Amy looked severe.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not so bad as it seems, for I should only plague him if I



<P>went, so I might as well stay and plague you a little longer,



<P>you can bear it better, in fact I think it agrees with you excellently."



<P>And Laurie composed himself for a lounge on the broad ledge of the balustrade.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy shook her head and opened her sketchbook with an



<P>air of resignation, but she had made up her mind to lecture



<P>`that boy' and in a minute she began again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What are you doing just now?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Watching lizards."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no.&nbsp; I mean what do you intend and wish to do?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Smoke a cigarette, if you'll allow me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How provoking you are!&nbsp; I don't approve of cigars and I will only

allow



<P>it on condition that you let me put you into my sketch.&nbsp; I need

a figure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"With all the pleasure in life.&nbsp; How will you have me, full



<P>length or three-quarters, on my head or my heels?&nbsp; I should



<P>respectfully suggest a recumbent posture, then put yourself



<P>in also and call it `Dolce far niente'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Stay as you are, and go to sleep if you like.&nbsp; I intend to



<P>work hard," said Amy in her most energetic tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What delightful enthusiasm!"&nbsp; And he leaned against a tall



<P>urn with an ir of entire satisfaction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What would Jo say if she saw you now?" asked Amy impatiently,



<P>hoping to stir him up by the mention of her still more



<P>energetic sister's name.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As usual, `Go away, Teddy.&nbsp; I'm busy!'" He laughed as he



<P>spoke, but the laugh was not natural, and a shade passed over



<P>his face, for the utterance of the familiar name touched the



<P>wound that was not healed yet.&nbsp; Both tone and shadow struck Amy,



<P>for she had seen and heard them before, and now she looked up



<P>in time to catch a new expression on Laurie's face--a hard bitter



<P>look, full of pain, dissatisfaction, and regret.&nbsp; It was gone before



<P>she could study it and the listless expression back again.



<P>She watched him for a moment with artistic pleasure, thinking



<P>how like an Italian he looked, as he lay basking in the sun



<P>with uncovered head and eyes full of southern dreaminess, for



<P>he seemed to have forgotten her and fallen into a reverie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You look like the effigy of a young knight asleep on his



<P>tomb," she said, carefully tracing the well-cut profile defined



<P>against the dark stone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Wish I was!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's a foolish wish, unless you have spoiled your life.



<P>You are so changed, I sometimes think--" There Amy stopped,



<P>with a half-timid, half-wistful look, more significant than her



<P>unfinished speech.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie saw and understood the affectionate anxiety which



<P>she hesitated to express, and looking straight into her eyes,



<P>said, just as he used to say it to her mother, "It's all right, ma'am."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That satisfied her and set at rest the doubts that had begun



<P>to worry her lately.&nbsp; It also touched her, and she showed



<P>that it did, by the cordial tone in which she said...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad of that!&nbsp; I didn't think you'd been a very bad



<P>boy, but I fancied you might have wasted money at that wicked



<P>Baden-Baden, lost your heart to some charming Frenchwoman



<P>with a husband, or got into some of the scrapes that young men



<P>seem to consider a necessary part of a foreign tour.&nbsp; Don't



<P>stay out there in the sun, come and lie on the grass here and



<P>`let us be friendly', as Jo used to say when we got in the sofa



<P>corner and told secrets."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie obediently threw himself down on the turf, and



<P>began to amuse himself by sticking daisies into the ribbons of



<P>Amy's hat, that lay there.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm all ready for the secrets."&nbsp; And he glanced up with



<P>a decided expression of interest in his eyes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've none to tell.&nbsp; You may begin."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Haven't one to bless myself with.&nbsp; I thought perhaps you'd



<P>had some news from home.."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have heard all that has come lately.&nbsp; Don't you hear



<P>often?&nbsp; I fancied Jo would send you volumes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She's very busy.&nbsp; I'm roving about so, it's impossible to



<P>be regular, you know.&nbsp; When do you begin your great work of art,



<P>Raphaella?' he asked.&nbsp; changing the subject abruptly after



<P>another pause, in which he had been wondering if Amy knew his



<P>secret and wanted to talk about it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never," she answered, with a despondent but decided air.



<P>"Rome took all the vanity out of me, for after seeing the



<P>wonders there, I felt too insignificant to live and gave up



<P>all my foolish hopes in despair."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why should you, with so much energy and talent?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's just why, because talent isn't genius, and no



<P>amount of energy can make it so.&nbsp; I want to be great, or nothing.



<P>I won't be a common-place dauber, so I don't intend to try any more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And what are you going to do with yourself now, if I may ask?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Polish up my other talents, and be an ornament to society,



<P>if I get the chance."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a characteristic speech, and sounded daring, but



<P>audacity becomes young people, and Amy's ambition had a good



<P>foundation.&nbsp; Laurie smiled, but he liked the spirit with



<P>which she took up a new purpose when a long-cherished one



<P>died, and spent no time lamenting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good!&nbsp; And here is where Fred Vaughn comes in, I fancy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy preserved a discreet silence, but there was a conscious



<P>look in her downcast face that made Laurie sit up and say gravely,



<P>"Now I'm going to play brother, and ask questions.&nbsp; May I?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't promise to answer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your face will, if your tongue won't.&nbsp; You aren't woman of



<P>the world enough yet to hide your feelings, my dear.&nbsp; I heard



<P>rumors about Fred and you last year, and it's my private opinion



<P>that if he had not been called home so suddenly and detained



<P>so long, something would have come of it, hey?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's not for me to say," was Amy's grim reply, but her lips



<P>would smile, and there was a traitorous sparkle of the eye



<P>which betrayed that she knew her power and enjoyed the knowledge.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are not engaged, I hope?" And Laurie looked very



<P>elder-brotherly and grave all of a sudden.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you will be, if he comes back and goes properly down



<P>on his knees, won't you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very likely."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then you are fond of old Fred?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I could be, if I tried."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you don't intend to try till the proper moment? Bless



<P>my soul, what unearthly prudence!&nbsp; He's a good fellow, Amy, but



<P>not the man I fancied you'd like."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He is rich, a gentleman, and has delightful manners,"



<P>began Amy, trying to be quite cool and dignified, but feeling



<P>a little ashamed of herself, in spite of the sincerity of her



<P>intentions.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I understand.&nbsp; Queens of society can't get on without money,



<P>so you mean to make a good match, and start in that way?&nbsp; Quite



<P>right and proper, as the world goes, but it sounds odd from the



<P>lips of one of your mother's girls."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"True, nevertheless."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A short speech, but the quiet decision with which it was



<P>uttered contrasted curiously with the young speaker.&nbsp; Laurie



<P>felt this instinctively and laid himself down again, with a



<P>sense of disappointment which he could not explain.&nbsp; His look



<P>and silence, as well as a certain inward self-disapproval,



<P>ruffled Amy, and made her resolve to deliver her lecture



<P>without delay.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish you'd do me the favor to rouse yourself a little,"



<P>she said sharply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do it for me, there's a dear girl."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I could, if I tried."&nbsp; And she looked as if she would like



<P>doing it in the most summary style.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Try, then.&nbsp; I give you leave," returned Laurie, who enjoyed



<P>having someone to tease, after his long abstinence from



<P>his favorite pastime.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'd be angry in five minutes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm never angry with you.&nbsp; It takes two flints to make a fire.



<P>You are as cool and soft as snow."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You don't know what I can do.&nbsp; Snow produces a glow and a tingle,



<P>if applied rightly.&nbsp; Your indifference is half affectation,



<P>and a good stirring up would prove it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Stir away, it won't hurt me and it may amuse you, as the



<P>big man said when his little wife beat him.&nbsp; Regard me in the



<P>light of a husband or a carpet, and beat till you are tired,



<P>if that sort of exercise agrees with you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Being decidedly nettled herself, and longing to see him



<P>shake off the apathy that so altered him, Amy sharpened both



<P>tongue and pencil, and began.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Flo and I have got a new name for you.&nbsp; It's Lazy Laurence.



<P>How do you like it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She thought it would annoy him, but he only folded his



<P>arms under his head, with an imperturbable, "That's not bad.



<P>Thank you, ladies."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you want to know what I honestly think of you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pining to be told."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I despise you."



<P>If she had even said `I hate you' in a petulant or coquettish



<P>tone, he would have laughed and rather liked it, but



<P>the grave, almost sad, accent in her voice made him open his



<P>eyes, and ask quickly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, if you please?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Because, with every chance for being good, useful, and



<P>happy, you are faulty, lazy, and miserable."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Strong language, mademoiselle."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you like it, I'll go on."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pray do, it's quite interesting."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought you'd find it so.&nbsp; Selfish people always like to



<P>talk about themselves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Am I selfish?" The question slipped out involuntarily and



<P>in a tone of surprise, for the one virtue on which he prided



<P>himself was generosity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, very selfish," continued Amy, in a calm, cool voice,



<P>twice as effective just then as an angry one.&nbsp; "I'll show you



<P>how, for I've studied you while we were frolicking, and I'm



<P>not at all satisfied with you.&nbsp; Here you have been abroad



<P>nearly six months, and done nothing but waste time and money



<P>and disappoint your friends."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Isn't a fellow to have any pleasure after a four-year



<P>grind?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You don't look as if you'd had much.&nbsp; At any rate, you are



<P>none the better for it, as far as I can see.&nbsp; I said when we



<P>first met that you had improved.&nbsp; Now I take it all back, for I



<P>don't think you half so nice as when I left you at home.&nbsp; You



<P>have grown abominably lazy, you like gossip, and waste time on



<P>frivolous things, you are contented to be petted and admired



<P>by silly people, instead of being loved and respected by wise



<P>ones.&nbsp; With money, talent, position, health, and beauty, ah



<P>you like that old Vanity!&nbsp; But it's the truth, so I can't help



<P>saying it, with all these splendid things to use and enjoy, you



<P>can find nothing to do but dawdle, and instead of being the man



<P>you ought to be, you are only..."&nbsp; There she stopped, with



<P>a look that had both pain and pity in it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Saint Laurence on a gridiron," added Laurie, blandly



<P>finishing the sentence.&nbsp; But the lecture began to take effect,



<P>for there was a wide-awake sparkle in his eyes now and a



<P>half-angry, half-injured expression replaced the former indifference.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I supposed you'd take it so.&nbsp; You men tell us we are



<P>angels, and say we can make you what we will, but the instant



<P>we honestly try to do you good, you laugh at us and won't



<P>listen, which proves how much your flattery is worth." Amy



<P>spoke bitterly, and turned her back on the exasperating



<P>martyr at her feet.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In a minute a hand came down over the page, so that she



<P>could not draw, and Laurie's voice said, with a droll imitation



<P>of a penitent child, "I will be good, oh, I will be good!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Amy did not laugh, for she was in earnest, and tapping



<P>on the outspread hand with her pencil, said soberly, "Aren't



<P>you ashamed of a hand like that?&nbsp; It's as soft and white as a



<P>woman's, and looks as if it never did anything but wear Jouvin's



<P>best gloves and pick flowers for ladies.&nbsp; You are not a dandy,



<P>thank Heaven, so I'm glad to see there are no diamonds or big



<P>seal rings on it, only the little old one Jo gave you so long



<P>ago.&nbsp; Dear soul, I wish she was here to help me!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So do I!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The hand vanished as suddenly as it came, and there was



<P>energy enough in the echo of her wish to suit even Amy.&nbsp; She



<P>glanced down at him with a new thought in her mind, but he



<P>was lying with his hat half over his face, as if for shade, and



<P>his mustache hid his mouth.&nbsp; She only saw his chest rise and



<P>fall, with a long breath that might have been a sigh, and the



<P>hand that wore the ring nestled down into the grass, as if to



<P>hide something too precious or too tender to be spoken of.



<P>All in a minute various hints and trifles assumed shape and



<P>significance in Amy's mind, and told her what her sister never



<P>had confided to her.&nbsp; She remembered that Laurie never spoke



<P>voluntarily of Jo, she recalled the shadow on his face just



<P>now, the change in his character, and the wearing of the little



<P>old ring which was no ornament to a handsome hand.&nbsp; Girls are



<P>quick to read such signs and feel their eloquence.&nbsp; Amy had



<P>fancied that perhaps a love trouble was at the bottom of the



<P>alteration, and now she was sure of it.&nbsp; Her keen eyes filled,



<P>and when she spoke again, it was in a voice that could be



<P>beautifully soft and kind when she chose to make it so.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know I have no right to talk so to you, Laurie, and if



<P>you weren't the sweetest-tempered fellow in the world, you'd be



<P>very angry with me.&nbsp; But we are all so fond and proud of you,



<P>I couldn't bear to think they should be disappointed in you at



<P>home as I have been, though, perhaps they would understand



<P>the change better than I do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think they would," came from under the hat, in a grim



<P>tone, quite as touching as a broken one.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They ought to have told me, and not let me go blundering



<P>and scolding, when I should have been more kind and patient



<P>than ever.&nbsp; I never did like that Miss Randal and now I hate



<P>her!" said artful Amy, wishing to be sure of her facts this time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hang Miss Randal!"&nbsp; And Laurie knocked the hat off his



<P>face with a look that left no doubt of his sentiments toward



<P>that young lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I beg pardon, I thought..."&nbsp; And there she paused



<P>diplomatically.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, you didn't, you knew perfectly well I never cared for



<P>anyone but Jo," Laurie said that in his old, impetuous tone,



<P>and turned his face away as he spoke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I did think so, but as they never said anything about it,



<P>and you came away, I supposed I was mistaken.&nbsp; And Jo wouldn't



<P>be kind to you?&nbsp; Why, I was sure she loved you dearly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She was kind, but not in the right way, and it's lucky for



<P>her she didn't love me, if I'm the good-for-nothing fellow you



<P>think me.&nbsp; It's her fault though, and you may tell her so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The hard, bitter look came back again as he said that, and



<P>it troubled Amy, for she did not know what balm to apply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was wrong, I didn't know.&nbsp; I'm very sorry I was so cross,



<P>but I can't help wishing you'd bear it better, Teddy, dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't, that's her name for me!"&nbsp; And Laurie put up his



<P>hand with a quick gesture to stop the words spoken in Jo's



<P>half-kind, half-reproachful tone.&nbsp; "Wait till you've tried it



<P>yourself," he added in a low voice, as he pulled up the grass



<P>by the handful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'd take it manfully, and be respected if i couldn't be



<P>loved," said Amy, with the decision of one who knew nothing



<P>about it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now, Laurie flattered himself that he had borne it remarkably



<P>well, making no moan, asking no sympathy, and taking his



<P>trouble away to live it down alone.&nbsp; Amy's lecture put the



<P>Matter in a new light, and for the first time it did look



<P>weak and selfish to lose heart at the first failure, and shut



<P>himself up in moody indifference.&nbsp; He felt as if suddenly



<P>shaken out of a pensive dream and found it impossible to go



<P>to sleep again.&nbsp; Presently he sat up and asked slowly, "Do



<P>you think Jo would despise me as you do?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, if she saw you now.&nbsp; She hates lazy people.&nbsp; Why don't



<P>you do something splendid, and make her love you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I did my best, but it was no use."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Graduating well, you mean?&nbsp; That was no more than you



<P>ought to have done, for your grandfather's sake.&nbsp; It would



<P>have been shameful to fail after spending so much time and



<P>money, when everyone knew that you could do well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I did fail, say what you will, for Jo wouldn't love me,"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>began Laurie, leaning his head on his hand in a despondent



<P>attitude.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, you didn't, and you'll say so in the end, for it did



<P>you good, and proved that you could do something if you tried.



<P>If you'd only set about another task of some sort, you'd soon



<P>be your hearty, happy self again, and forget your trouble."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's impossible."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Try it and see.&nbsp; You needn't shrug your shoulders, and



<P>think, `Much she knows about such things'.&nbsp; I don't pretend



<P>to be wise, but I am observing, and I see a great deal more



<P>than you'd imagine.&nbsp; I'm interested in other people's experiences



<P>and inconsistencies, and though I can't explain, I remember



<P>and use them for my own benefit.&nbsp; Love Jo all your days,



<P>if you choose, but don't let it spoil you, for it's wicked



<P>to throw away so many good gifts because you can't have the



<P>one you want.&nbsp; There, I won't lecture any more, for I know



<P>you'll wake up and be a man in spite of that hardhearted girl."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Neither spoke for several minutes.&nbsp; Laurie sat turning



<P>the little ring on his finger, and Amy put the last touches to



<P>the hasty sketch she had been working at while she talked.



<P>Presently she put it on his knee, merely saying, "How do you



<P>like that?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He looked and then he smiled, as he could not well help



<P>doing, for it was capitally done, the long, lazy figure on the



<P>grass, with listless face, half-shut eyes, and one hand holding



<P>a cigar, from which came the little wreath of smoke that encircled



<P>the dreamer's head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How well you draw!" he said, with a genuine surprise



<P>and pleasure at her skill, adding, with a half-laugh,



<P>"Yes, that's me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As you are.&nbsp; This is as you were."&nbsp; And Amy laid another



<P>sketch beside the one he held.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was not nearly so well done, but there was a life and



<P>spirit in it which atoned for many faults, and it recalled the



<P>past so vividly that a sudden change swept over the young



<P>man's face as he looked.&nbsp; Only a rough sketch of Laurie taming



<P>a horse.&nbsp; Hat and coat were off, and every line of the active



<P>figure, resolute face, and commanding attitude was full of



<P>energy and meaning.&nbsp; The handsome brute, just subdued, stood



<P>arching his neck under the tightly drawn rein, with one foot



<P>impatiently pawing the ground, and ears pricked up as if



<P>listening for the voice that had mastered him.&nbsp; In the ruffled



<P>mane.&nbsp; The rider's breezy hair and erect attitude, there was a



<P>suggestion of suddenly arrested motion, of strength, courage,



<P>and youthful buoyancy that contrasted sharply with the supine



<P>grace of the `DOLCE FAR NIENTE' sketch.&nbsp; Laurie said nothing



<P>but as his eye went from one to the other, Amy say him flush



<P>up and fold his lips together as if he read and accepted the



<P>little lesson she had given him.&nbsp; That satisfied her, and



<P>without waiting for him to speak, she said, in her sprightly



<P>way...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't you remember the day you played Rarey with Puck,



<P>and we all looked on?&nbsp; Meg and Beth were frightened, but Jo



<P>clapped and pranced, and I sat on the fence and drew you.&nbsp; I



<P>found that sketch in my portfolio the other day, touched it



<P>up, and kept it to show you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Much obliged.&nbsp; You've improved immensely since then,



<P>and I congratulate you.&nbsp; May I venture to suggest in ` a



<P>honeymoon paradise' that five o'clock is the dinner hour at



<P>your hotel?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie rose as he spoke, returned the pictures with a smile



<P>and a bow and looked at his watch, as if to remind her that



<P>even moral lectures should have an end.&nbsp; He tried to resume his



<P>former easy, indifferent air, but it was an affectation now, for



<P>the rousing had been more effacious than he would confess.&nbsp; Amy



<P>felt the shade of coldness in his manner, and said to herself .&nbsp;

..

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, I've offended him.&nbsp; Well, if it does him good, I'm



<P>glad, if it makes him hate me, I'm sorry, but it's true, and



<P>I can't take back a word of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They laughed and chatted all the way home, and little



<P>Baptist, up behind, thought that monsieur and madamoiselle



<P>were in charming spirits.&nbsp; But both felt ill at ease.&nbsp; The



<P>friendly frankness was disturbed, the sunshine had a shadow



<P>over it, and despite their apparent gaiety, there was a secret



<P>discontent in the heart of each.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shall we see you this evening, mon frere?" asked Amy, as



<P>they parted at her aunt's door.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Unfortunately I have an engagement.&nbsp; Au revoir, madamoiselle."



<P>And Laurie bent as if to kiss her hand, in the foreign fashion,



<P>which became him better than many men.&nbsp; Something in his face



<P>made Amy say quickly and warmly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, be yourself with me, Laurie, and part in the good old way.



<P>I'd rather have a hearty English handshake than all the



<P>sentimental salutations in France."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Goodbye, dear." And with these words, uttered in the tone she liked,



<P>Laurie left her, after a handshake almost painful in its heartiness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Next morning, instead of the usual call, Amy received a



<P>note which made her smile at the beginning and sigh at the end.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>My Dear Mentor,



<P>Please make my adieux to your aunt, and exult within



<P>yourself, for `Lazy Laurence' has gone to his grandpa, like



<P>the best of boys.&nbsp; A pleasant winter to you, and may the gods



<P>grant you a blissful honeymoon at Valrosa!&nbsp; I think Fred



<P>would be benefited by a rouser.&nbsp; Tell him so, with my congratulations.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Yours gratefully, Telemachus

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good boy!&nbsp; I'm glad he's gone," said Amy, with an approving smile.



<P>The next minute her face fell as she glanced about the empty room,



<P>adding, with an involuntary sigh, "Yes, I am glad, but how I shall miss

him."



<P>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
