   <TITLE>Chapter 13</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER THIRTEEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie lay luxuriously swinging to and fro in his hammock



<P>one warm September afternoon, wondering what his neighbors were



<P>about, but too lazy to go and find out.&nbsp; He was in one of his



<P>moods, for the day had been both unprofitable and unsatisfactory,



<P>and he was wishing he could live it over again.&nbsp; The hot weather



<P>made him indolent, and he had shirked his studies, tried Mr.



<P>Brooke's patience to the utmost, displeased his grandfather by



<P>practicing half the afternoon, frightened the maidservants half



<P>out of their wits by mischievously hinting that one of his dogs



<P>was going mad, and, after high words with the stableman about



<P>some fancied neglect of his horse, he had flung himself into



<P>his hammock to fume over the stupidity of the world in general,



<P>till the peace of the lovely day quieted him in spite of himself.



<P>Staring up into the green gloom of the horse-chestnut trees above



<P>him, he dreamed dreams of all sorts, and was just imagining



<P>himself tossing on the ocean in a voyage round the world,



<P>when the sound of voices brought him ashore in a flash.



<P>Peeping through the meshes of the hammock, he saw the Marches



<P>coming out, as if bound on some expedition.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What in the world are those girls about now?" thought



<P>Laurie, opening his sleepy eyes to take a good look, for there



<P>was something rather peculiar in the appearance of his



<P>neighbors.&nbsp; Each wore a large, flapping hat, a brown linen pouch



<P>slung over one shoulder, and carried a long staff.&nbsp; Meg had a



<P>cushion, Jo a book, Beth a basket, and Amy a portfolio.&nbsp; All



<P>walked quietly through the garden, out at the little back gate,



<P>and began to climb the hill that lay between the house and river.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, that's cool," said Laurie to himself, "to have a picnic



<P>and never ask me!&nbsp; They can't be going in the boat, for they



<P>haven't got the key.&nbsp; Perhaps they forgot it.&nbsp; I'll take it

to them,



<P>and see what's going on."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Though possessed of half a dozen hats, it took him some time



<P>to find one, then there was a hunt for the key, which was at last



<P>discovered in his pocket, so that the girls were quite out of sight



<P>when leaped the fence and ran after them.&nbsp; Taking the shortest

way



<P>to the boathouse, he waited for them to appear, but no one came,



<P>and he went up the hill to take an observation.&nbsp; A grove of pines



<P>covered one part of it, and from the heart of this green spot came



<P>a clearer sound than the soft sigh of the pines or the drowsy chirp



<P>of the crickets.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here's a landscape!" thought Laurie, peeping through the



<P>bushes, and looking wide-awake and good-natured already.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a rather pretty little picture, for the sisters sat



<P>together in the shady nook, with sun and shadow flickering over



<P>them, the aromatic wind lifting their hair and cooling their hot



<P>cheeks, and all the little wood people going on with their affairs



<P>as if these were no strangers but old friends.&nbsp; Meg sat upon her



<P>cushion, sewing daintily with her white hands, and looking as fresh



<P>and sweet as a rose in her pink dress among the green.&nbsp; Beth was



<P>sorting the cones that lay thick under the hemlock near by, for



<P>she made pretty things with them.&nbsp; Amy was sketching a group of



<P>ferns, and Jo was knitting as she read aloud.&nbsp; A shadow passed



<P>over the boy's face as he watched them, feeling that he ought to



<P>go away because uninvited, yet lingering because home seemed very



<P>lonely and this quiet party in the woods most attractive to his



<P>restless spirit.&nbsp; He stood so still that a squirrel, busy with

it's



<P>harvesting, ran dawn a pine close beside him, saw him suddenly



<P>and skipped back, scolding so shrilly that Beth looked up, espied



<P>the wistful face behind the birches, and beckoned with a reassuring



<P>smile.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"May I come in, please?&nbsp; Or shall I be a bother?" he asked,



<P>advancing slowly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg lifted her eyebrows, but Jo scowled at her defiantly and



<P>said at once, "Of course you may.&nbsp; We should have asked you before,



<P>only we thought you wouldn't care for such a girl's game as this."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I always like your games, but if Meg doesn't want me, I'll



<P>go away."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've no objection, if you do something.&nbsp; It's against the



<P>rules to be idle here," replied Meg gravely but graciously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Much obliged.&nbsp; I'll do anything if you'll let me stop a bit,



<P>for it's as dull as the Desert of Sahara down there.&nbsp; Shall I sew,



<P>read, cone, draw, or do all at once? Bring on your bears.



<P>I'm ready."&nbsp; And Laurie sat down with a submissive expression



<P>delightful to behold.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Finish this story while I set my heel," said Jo, handing him



<P>the book.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes'm." was the meek answer, as he began, doing his best to



<P>prove his gratitude for the favor of admission into the `Busy Bee



<P>Society'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The story was not a long one, and when it was finished, he



<P>ventured to ask a few questions as a reward of merit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Please, ma'am, could I inquire if this highly instructive



<P>and charming institution is a new one?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Would you tell him?" asked Meg of her sisters.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He'll laugh," said Amy warningly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Who cares?" said Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I guess he'll like it," added Beth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course I shall!&nbsp; I give you my word I won't laugh.&nbsp; Tell



<P>away, Jo, and don't be afraid."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The idea of being afraid of you!&nbsp; Well, you see we used to



<P>play Pilgrim's Progress, and we have been going on with it in



<P>earnest, all winter and summer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I know," said Laurie, nodding wisely.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Who told you?" demanded Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Spirits."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I did.&nbsp; I wanted to amuse him one night when you were



<P>all away, and he was rather dismal.&nbsp; He did like it, so don't



<P>scold, Jo," said Beth meekly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You can't keep a secret.&nbsp; Never mind, it saves trouble now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Go on, please," said Laurie, as Jo became absorbed in her



<P>work, looking a trifle displeased.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, didn't she tell you about this new plan of ours?&nbsp; Well,



<P>we have tried not to waste our holiday, but each has had a task



<P>and worked at it with a will.&nbsp; The vacation is nearly over, the



<P>stints are all done, and we are ever so glad that we didn't dawdle."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I should think so," and Laurie thought regretfully of



<P>his own idle days.



<P>"Mother likes to have us out-of-doors as much as possible, so



<P>we bring our work here and have nice times.&nbsp; For the fun of it

we



<P>bring our things in these bags, wear the old hats, use poles to



<P>climb the hill, and play pilgrims, as we used to do years ago.&nbsp;

We



<P>call this hill the Delectable Mountain, for we can look far away



<P>and see the country where we hope to live some time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo pointed, and Laurie sat up to examine, for through an



<P>opening in the wood one could look cross the wide, blue river,



<P>the meadows on the other side, far over the outskirts of the



<P>great city, to the green hills that rose to meet the sky.&nbsp; The



<P>sun was low, and the heavens glowed with the splendor of an



<P>autumn sunset.&nbsp; Gold and purple clouds lay on the hilltops,



<P>and rising high into the ruddy light were silvery white peaks



<P>that shone like the airy spires of some Celestial City.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How beautiful that is!" said Laurie softly, for he was quick



<P>to see and feel beauty of any kind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's often so, and we like to watch it, for it is never the



<P>same, but always splendid," replied Amy, wishing she could paint it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo talks about the country where we hope to live sometime--the



<P>real country, she means, with pigs and chickens and haymaking.



<P>It would be nice, but I wish the beautiful country up there was real,



<P>and we could ever go to it," said Beth musingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is a lovelier country even than that, where we shall go,



<P>by-and-by, when we are good enough," answered Meg with her sweetest

voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It seems so long to wait, so hard to do.&nbsp; I want to fly away



<P>at once, as those swallows fly, and go in at that splendid gate."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'll get there, Beth, sooner or later, no fear of that,"



<P>said Jo.&nbsp; "I'm the one that will have to fight and work, and climb



<P>and wait, and maybe never get in after all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"you'll have me for company, if that's any comfort.&nbsp; I shall



<P>have to do a deal of traveling before I come in sight of your



<P>Celestial City.&nbsp; If I arrive late, you'll say a good word for me,



<P>won't you, Beth?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Something in the boy's face troubled his little friend, but



<P>she said cheerfully, with her quiet eyes on the changing clouds,



<P>"If people really want to go, and really try all their lives, I



<P>think they will get in, for I don't believe there are any locks



<P>on that door or any guards at the gate.&nbsp; I always imagine it is



<P>as it is in the picture, where the shining ones stretch out their



<P>hands to welcome poor Christian as he comes up from the river.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Wouldn't it be fun if all the castles in the air which we



<P>make could come true, and we could live in them?" said Jo, after



<P>a little pause.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've made such quantities it would be hard to choose which



<P>I'd have," said Laurie, lying flat and throwing cones at the



<P>squirrel who had betrayed him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'd have to take your favorite one.&nbsp; What is it?" asked



<P>Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I tell mine, will you tell yours?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, if the girls will too."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We will.&nbsp; Now, Laurie."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"After I'd seen as much of the world as I want to, I'd like



<P>to settle in Germany and have just as much music as I choose.&nbsp;

I'm



<P>to be a famous musician myself, and all creation is to rush to hear



<P>me.&nbsp; And I'm never to be bothered about money or business, but

just



<P>enjoy myself and live for what I like.&nbsp; That's my favorite castle.



<P>What's yours, Meg?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Margaret seemed to find it a little hard to tell hers, and



<P>waved a brake before her face, as if to disperse imaginary gnats,



<P>while she said slowly, "I should like a lovely house, full of all



<P>sorts of luxurious things--nice food, pretty clothes, handsome



<P>furniture, pleasant people, and heaps of money.&nbsp; I am to be



<P>mistress of it, and manage it as I like, with plenty of servants,



<P>so I never need work a bit.&nbsp; How I should enjoy it!&nbsp; For I

wouldn't



<P>be idle, but do good, and make everyone love me dearly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Wouldn't you have a master for your castle in the air?" asked



<P>Laurie slyly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I said `pleasant people', you know," And Meg carefully tied



<P>up her shoe as she spoke, so that no one saw her face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why don't you say you'd have a splendid, wise, good husband



<P>and some angelic little children?&nbsp; You know your castle wouldn't



<P>be perfect without," said blunt Jo, who had no tender fancies yet,



<P>and rather scorned romance, except in books.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'd have nothing but horses, inkstands, and novels in



<P>yours," answered Meg petulantly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Wouldn't I though?&nbsp; I'd have a stable full of Arabian steeds,



<P>rooms piled high with books, and I'd write out of a magic inkstand,



<P>so that my works should be as famous as Laurie's music.&nbsp; I want

to



<P>do something splendid before I go into my castle, something heroic



<P>or wonderful that won't be forgotten after I'm dead.&nbsp; I don't know



<P>what, but I'm on the watch for it, and mean to astonish you all



<P>some day.&nbsp; I think I shall write books, and get rich and famous,



<P>that would suit me, so that is my favorite dream."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mine is to stay at home safe with Father and Mother, and



<P>help take care of the family," said Beth contentedly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't you wish for anything else?" asked Laurie.



<P>"Since I had my little piano, I am perfectly satisfied.&nbsp; I



<P>only wish we may all keep well and be together, nothing else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have ever so many wishes, but the pet one is to be an



<P>artist, and go to Rome, and do fine pictures, and be the best



<P>artist in the whole world," was Amy's modest desire.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We're an ambitious set, aren't we?&nbsp; Every one of us, but



<P>Beth, wants to be rich and famous, and gorgeous in every respect.



<P>I do wonder if any of us will ever get our wishes," said Laurie,



<P>chewing grass like a meditative calf.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've got the key to my castle in the air, but whether I can



<P>unlock the door remains to be seen," observed Jo mysteriously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've got the key to mine, but I'm not allowed to try it.



<P>Hang college!" muttered Laurie with an impatient sigh.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here's mine!" and Amy waved her pencil.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I haven't got any," said Meg forlornly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, you have," said Laurie at once.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"In your face."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nonsense, that's of no use."



<P>"Wait and see if it doesn't bring you something worth having,"



<P>replied the boy, laughing at the thought of a charming little



<P>secret which he fancied he knew.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg colored behind the brake, but asked no questions and



<P>looked across the river with the same expectant expression which



<P>Mr. Brooke had worn when he told the story of the knight.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If we are all alive ten years hence, let's meet, and see how



<P>many of us have got our wishes, or how much nearer we are then than



<P>now," said Jo, always ready with a plan.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bless me!&nbsp; How old I shall be, twenty-seven!" exclaimed Meg,



<P>who felt grown up already, having just reached seventeen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You and I will be twenty-six, Teddy, Beth twenty-four, and



<P>Amy twenty-two.&nbsp; What a venerable party!" said Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope I shall have done something to be proud of by that



<P>time, but I'm such a lazy dog, I'm afraid I shall dawdle, Jo."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You need a motive, Mother says, and when you get it, she is



<P>sure you'll work splendidly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is she?&nbsp; By Jupiter, I will, if I only get the chance!" cried



<P>Laurie, sitting up with sudden energy.&nbsp; "I ought to be satisfied

to



<P>please Grandfather, and I do try, but it's working against the grain,



<P>you see, and comes hard.&nbsp; He wants me to be an India merchant,

as he



<P>was, and I'd rather be shot.&nbsp; I hate tea and sild and spices, and



<P>every sort of rubbish his old ships bring, and I don't care how soon



<P>they go to the bottom when I own them.&nbsp; Going to college ought

to



<P>satisfy him, for if I give him four years he ought to let me off



<P>from the business.&nbsp; But he's set, and I've got to do just as he

did,



<P>unless I break away and please myself, as my father did.&nbsp; If there



<P>was anyone left to stay with the old gentleman, I'd do it tomorrow."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie spoke excitedly, and looked ready to carry his threat



<P>into execution on the slightest provocation, for he was growing up



<P>very fast and, in spite of his indolent ways, had a young man's



<P>hatred of subjection, a young man's restless longing to try the



<P>world for himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I advise you to sail away in one of your ships, and never



<P>come home again till you have tried your own way," said Jo, whose



<P>imagination was fired by the thought of such a daring exploit, and



<P>whose sympathy was excited by what she called `Teddy's Wrongs'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's not right, Jo.&nbsp; You mustn't talk in that way, and Laurie



<P>mustn't take your bad advice.&nbsp; You should do just what your



<P>grandfather wishes, my dear boy," said Meg in her most maternal tone.



<P>"Do your best at college, and when he sees that you try to please him,



<P>I'm sure he won't be hard on you or unjust to you.&nbsp; As you say,

there



<P>is no one else to stay with and love him, and you'd never forgive



<P>yourself if you left him without his permission.&nbsp; Don't be dismal

or



<P>fret, but do your duty and you'll get your reward, as good Mr. Brooke



<P>has, by being respected and loved."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What do you know about him?" asked Laurie, grateful for the



<P>good advice, but objecting to the lecture, and glad to turn the



<P>conversation from himself after his unusual outbreak.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Only what your grandpa told us about him, how he took good



<P>care of his own mother till she died, and wouldn't go abroad as



<P>tutor to some nice person because he wouldn't leave her.&nbsp; And how



<P>he provides now for an old woman who nursed his mother, and never



<P>tells anyone, but is just as generous and patient and good as he



<P>can be."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So he is, dear old fellow!" said Laurie heartily, as Meg



<P>paused, looking flushed and earnest with her story.&nbsp; "It's like



<P>Grandpa to find out all about him without letting him know, and



<P>to tell all his goodness to others, so that they might like him.



<P>Brooke couldn't understand why your mother was so kind to him,



<P>asking him over with me and treating him in her beautiful friendly



<P>way.&nbsp; He thought she was just perfect, and talked about it for



<P>days and days, and went on about you all in flaming style.&nbsp; If

ever



<P>I do get my wish, you see what I'll do for Booke."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Begin to do something now by not plaguing his life out,"



<P>said Meg sharply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How do you know I do, Miss?"



<P>"I can always tell by his face when he goes away.&nbsp; If you



<P>have been good, he looks satisfied and walks briskly.&nbsp; If you



<P>have plagued him, he's sober and walks slowly, as if he wanted



<P>to go back and do his work better."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I like that?&nbsp; So you keep an account of my good and



<P>bad marks in Brooke's face, do you?&nbsp; I see him bow and smile as



<P>he passes your window, but I didn't know you'd got up a telegraph."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We haven't.&nbsp; Don't be angry, and oh, don't tell him I said



<P>anything!&nbsp; It was only to show that I cared how you get on, and



<P>what is said here is said in confidence, you know," cried Meg,



<P>much alarmed at the thought of what might follow from her



<P>careless speech.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't tell tales," replied Laurie, with his `high and mighty'



<P>air, as Jo called a certain expression which he occasionally wore.



<P>"Only if Brooke is going to be a thermometer, I must mind and have



<P>fair weather for him to report."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Please don't be offended.&nbsp; I didn't meant to preach or tell



<P>tales or be silly.&nbsp; I only thought Jo was encouraging you in a



<P>feeling which you'd be sorry for by-and-by.&nbsp; You are so kind to



<P>us, we feel as if you were our brother and say just what we think.



<P>Forgive me, I meant it kindly."&nbsp; And Meg offered her hand with

a



<P>gesture both affectionate and timid.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Ashamed of his momentary pique, Laurie squeezed the kind



<P>little hand, and said frankly, "I'm the one to be forgiven.&nbsp; I'm



<P>cross and have been out of sorts all day.&nbsp; I like to have you



<P>tell me my faults and be sisterly, so don't mind if I am grumpy



<P>sometimes.&nbsp; I thank you all the same."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Bent on showing that he was not offended, he made himself as



<P>agreeable as possible, wound cotton for Meg, recited poetry to



<P>please Jo, shook down cones for Beth, and helped Amy with her



<P>ferns, proving himself a fit person to belong to the `Busy Bee



<P>Society'.&nbsp; In the midst of an animated discussion on the domestic



<P>habits of turtles (one of those amiable creatures having strolled



<P>up from the river), the faint sound of a bell warned them that



<P>Hannah had put the tea `to draw', and they would just have time



<P>to get home to supper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"May I come again?" asked Laurie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, if your are good, and love your book, as the boys in



<P>the primer are told to do," said Meg, smiling.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"i'll try."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then you may come, and I'll teach you to knit as the Scotchmen do.



<P>There's a demand for socks just now," added Jo, waving hers



<P>like a big blue worsted banner as they parted at the gate.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That night, when Beth played to Mr. Laurence in the twilight,



<P>Laurie, standing in the shadow of the curtain, listened to the



<P>little David, whose simple music always quieted his moody spirit,



<P>and watched the old man, who sat with his gray head on his hand,



<P>thinking tender thoughts of the dead child he had loved so much.



<P>Remembering the conversation of the afternoon, the boy said to



<P>himself, with the resolve to make the sacrifice cheerfully, "I'll



<P>let my castle go, and stay with the dear old gentleman while he



<P>needs me, for I am all he has."



<P>

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 07</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER SEVEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That boy is a perfect cyclops, isn't he?" said Amy one day,



<P>as Laurie clattered by on horseback, with a flourish of his whip



<P>as he passed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How dare you say so, when he's got both his eyes?&nbsp; And



<P>very handsome ones they are, too," cried Jo, who resented any



<P>slighting remarks about her friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I didn't day anything about his eyes, and I don't see why



<P>you need fire up when I admire his riding."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, my goodness!&nbsp; That little goose means a centaur, and she



<P>called him a Cyclops," exclaimed Jo, with a burst of laughter.



<P>"You needn't be so rude, it's only a `lapse of lingy', as Mr.



<P>Davis says," retorted Amy, finishing Jo with her Latin.&nbsp; "I just



<P>wish I had a little of the money Laurie spends on that horse," she



<P>added, as if to herself, yet hoping her sisters would hear.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why?" asked Meg kindly, for Jo had gone off in another laugh



<P>at Amy's second blunder.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I need it so much.&nbsp; I'm dreadfully in debt, and it won't be



<P>my turn to have the rag money for a month."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"In debt, Amy?&nbsp; What do you mean?" And Meg looked sober.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, I owe at least a dozen pickled limes, and I can't pay



<P>them, you know, till I have money, for Marmee forbade my having



<P>anything charged at the shop."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tell me all about it.&nbsp; Are limes the fashion now?&nbsp; It used



<P>to be pricking bits of rubber to make balls."&nbsp; And Meg tried to



<P>keep her countenance, Amy looked so grave and important.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, you see, the girls are always buying them, and unless



<P>you want to be thought mean, you must do it too.&nbsp; It's nothing



<P>but limes now, for everyone is sucking them in their desks in



<P>schooltime, and trading them off for pencils, bead rings, paper



<P>dolls, or something else, at recess.&nbsp; If one girl likes another,



<P>she gives her a lime.&nbsp; If she's mad with her, she eats one before



<P>her face, and doesn't offer even a suck.&nbsp; They treat by turns,



<P>and I've had ever so many but haven't returned them, and I ought



<P>for they are debts of honor, you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How much will pay them off and restore your credit?" asked



<P>Meg, taking out her purse."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A quarter would more than do it, and leave a few cents over



<P>for a treat for you.&nbsp; Don't you like limes?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not much.&nbsp; You may have my share.&nbsp; Here's the money.&nbsp;

Make it



<P>last as long as you can, for it isn't very plenty, you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, thank you!&nbsp; It must be so nice to have pocket money!&nbsp;

I'll



<P>have a grand feast, for I haven't tasted a lime this week.&nbsp; I felt



<P>delicate about taking any, as I couldn't return them, and I'm



<P>actually suffering for one."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Next day Amy was rather late at school, but could not resist the



<P>temptation of displaying, with pardonable pride, a moist brown-paper



<P>parcel, before she consigned it to the inmost recesses of her desk.



<P>During the next few minutes the rumor that Amy March had got twenty-



<P>four delicious limes (she ate one on the way) and was going to



<P>treat circulated through her `set', and the attentions of her friends



<P>became quite overwhelming.&nbsp; Katy Brown invited her to her next

party



<P>on the spot.&nbsp; Mary Kinglsey insisted on lending her her watch till



<P>recess, and Jenny Snow, a satirical young lady, who had basely twitted



<P>Amy upon her limeless state, promptly buried the hatchet and offered



<P>to furnish answers to certain appalling sums.&nbsp; But Amy had not



<P>forgotten Miss Snow's cutting remarks about `some persons whose noses



<P>were not too flat to smell other people's limes, and stuck-up people



<P>who were not too proud to ask for them', and she instantly crushed



<P>`that Snow girl's' hopes by the withering telegram, "You needn't be



<P>so polite all of a sudden, for you won't get any."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A distinguished personage happened to visit the school that



<P>morning, and Amy's beautifully drawn maps received praise, which



<P>honor to her foe rankled in the soul of Miss Snow, and caused Miss



<P>March to assume the airs of a studious young peacock.&nbsp; But, alas,



<P>alas!&nbsp; Pride goes before a fall, and the revengeful Snow turned

the



<P>tables with disastrous success.&nbsp; No sooner had the guest paid the



<P>usual stale compliments and bowed himself out, than Jenny, under



<P>pretense of asking an important question, informed Mr. Davis, the



<P>teacher, that Amy March had pickled limes in her desk.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now Mr. Davis had declared limes a contraband article, and



<P>solemnly vowed to publicly ferrule the first person who was found



<P>breaking the law.&nbsp; This much-enduring man had succeeded in banishing



<P>chewing gum after a long and stormy war, had made a bonfire of the



<P>confiscated novels and newspapers, had suppressed a private post



<P>office, had forbidden distortions of the face, nicknames, and



<P>caricatures, and done all that one man could do to keep half a hundred



<P>rebellious girls in order.&nbsp; Boys are trying enough to human patience,



<P>goodness knows, but girls are infinitely more so, especially to



<P>nervous gentlemen with tyrannical tempers and no more talent for



<P>teaching than Dr. Blimber.&nbsp; Mr. Davis knew any quantity of Greek,



<P>Latin, algebra, and ologies of all sorts so he was called a fine



<P>teacher, and manners, morals, feelings, and examples were not



<P>considered of any particular importance.&nbsp; It was a most unfortunate



<P>moment for denouncing Amy, and Jenny knew it.&nbsp; Mr. Davis had



<P>evidently taken his coffee too strong that morning, there was an



<P>east wind, which always affected his neuralgia, and his pupils had



<P>not done him the credit which he felt he deserved.&nbsp; Therefore,

to



<P>use the expressive, if not elegant, language of a schoolgirl, "He



<P>was as nervous as a witch and as cross as a bear".&nbsp; The word `limes'



<P>was like fire to powder, his yellow face flushed, and he rapped on



<P>his desk with an energy which made Jenny skip to her seat with



<P>unusual rapidity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Young ladies, attention, if you please!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At the stern order the buzz ceased, and fifty pairs of blue,



<P>black, gray, and brown eyes were obediently fixed upon his awful



<P>countenance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss March, come to the desk."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy rose to comply with outward composure, but a secret fear



<P>oppressed her, for the limes weighed upon her conscience.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bring with you the limes you have in your desk," was the



<P>unexpected command which arrested her before she got out of her seat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't take all." whispered her neighbor, a young lady of great



<P>presence of mind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy hastily shook out half a dozen and laid the rest down before



<P>Mr. Davis, feeling that any man possessing a human heart would relent



<P>when that delicious perfume met his nose.&nbsp; Unfortunately, Mr. Davis



<P>particularly detested the odor of the fashionable pickle, and disgust



<P>added to his wrath.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is that all?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not quite," stammered Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bring the rest immediately."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With a despairing glance at her set, she obeyed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are sure there are no more?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never lie, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So I see.&nbsp; Now take these disgusting things two by two, and



<P>throw them out of the window."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a simultaneous sigh, which created quite a little gust,



<P>as the last hope fled, and the treat was ravished from their longing



<P>lips.&nbsp; Scarlet with shame and anger, Amy went to and fro six dreadful



<P>times, and as each doomed couple, looking oh, so plump and juicy, fell



<P>from her reluctant hands, a shout from the street completed the anguish



<P>of the girls, for it told them that their feast was being exulted over



<P>by the little Irish children, who were their sworn foes.&nbsp; This--this



<P>was too much.&nbsp; All flashed indignant or appealing glances at the



<P>inexorable Davis, and one passionate lime lover burst into tears.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As Amy returned from her last trip, Mr. Davis gave a portentous



<P>"Hem!" and said, in his most impressive manner...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Young ladies, you remember what I said to you a week ago.&nbsp; I



<P>am sorry this has happened, but I never allow my rules to be infringed,



<P>and I never break my word.&nbsp; Miss March, hold out your hand."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy started, and put both hands behind her, turning on him an



<P>imploring look which pleaded for her better than the words she could



<P>not utter.&nbsp; She was rather a favorite with `old Davis', as, of

course,



<P>he was called, and it's my private belief that he would have broken



<P>his word if the indignation of one irrepressible young lady had not



<P>found vent in a hiss.&nbsp; That hiss, faint as it was, irritated the



<P>irascible gentleman, and sealed the culprit's fate.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your hand, Miss March!" was the only answer her mute appeal



<P>received, and too proud to cry or beseech, Amy set her teeth, threw



<P>bach her head defiantly, and bore without flinching several tingling



<P>blows on her little palm.&nbsp; They were neither many nor heavy, but

that



<P>made no difference to her.&nbsp; For the first time in her life she

had



<P>been struck, and the disgrace, in her eyes, was as deep as if he had



<P>knocked her down.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You will now stand on the platform till recess," said Mr. Davis,



<P>resolved to do the thing thoroughly, since he had begun.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That was dreadful.&nbsp; It would have been bad enough to go to her



<P>seat, and see the pitying faces of her friends, or the satisfied



<P>ones of her few enemies, but to face the whole school, with that



<P>shame fresh upon her, seemed impossible, and for a second she felt



<P>as if she could only drop down where she stood, and break her heart



<P>with crying.&nbsp; A bitter sense of wrong and the thought of Jenny

Snow



<P>helped her to bear it, and, taking the ignominious place, she fixed



<P>her eyes on the stove funnel above what now seemed a sea of faces,



<P>and stood there, so motionless and white that the girls found it



<P>hard to study with that pathetic figure before them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>During the fifteen minutes that followed, the proud and sensitive



<P>little girl suffered a shame and pain which she never forgot.&nbsp;

To



<P>others it might seem a ludicrous or trivial affair, but to her it was



<P>a hard experience, for during the twelve years of her life she had been



<P>governed by love alone, and a blow of that sort had never touched her



<P>before.&nbsp; The smart of her hand and the ache of her heart were forgotten



<P>in the sting of the thought, "I shall have to tell at home, and they



<P>will be so disappointed in me!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The fifteen minutes seemed an hour, but they came to an end at



<P>last, and the word `Recess!' had never seemed so welcome to her before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You can go, Miss March," said Mr. Davis, looking, as he felt,



<P>uncomfortable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He did not soon forget the reproachful glance Amy gave him, as



<P>she went, without a word to anyone, straight into the anteroom,



<P>snatched her things, and left the place "forever," as she passionately



<P>declared to herself.&nbsp; She was in a sad state when she got home,

and



<P>when the older girls arrived, some time later, an indignation meeting



<P>was held at once.&nbsp; Mrs. March did not say much but looked disturbed,



<P>and comforted her afflicted little daughter in her tenderest manner.



<P>Meg bathed the insulted hand with glycerine and tears, Beth felt



<P>that even her beloved kittens would fail as a balm for griefs like



<P>this, Jo wrathfully proposed that Mr. Davis be arrested without delay,



<P>and Hannah shook her fist at the `villain' and pounded potatoes for



<P>dinner as if she had him under her pestle.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No notice was taken of Amy's flight, except by her mates, but



<P>the sharp-eyed demoiselles discovered that Mr. Davis was quite



<P>benignant in the afternoon, also unusually nervous.&nbsp; Just before



<P>school closed, Jo appeared, wearing a grim expression as she



<P>stalked up to the desk, and delivered a letter from her mother,



<P>then collected Amy's property, and departed, carefully scraping



<P>the mud from her boots on the door mat, as if she shook that dust



<P>of the place off her feet.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, you can have a vacation from school, but I want you to



<P>study a little every day with Beth," said Mrs. March that evening.



<P>"I don't approve of corporal punishment, especially for girls.&nbsp;

I



<P>dislike Mr. Davis's manner of teaching and don't think the girls



<P>you associate with are doing you any good, so I shall ask your



<P>father's advice before I send you anywhere else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's good!&nbsp; I wish all the girls would leave, and spoil



<P>his old school.&nbsp; It's perfectly maddening to think of those lovely



<P>limes," sighed Amy, with the air of a martyr.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not sorry you lost them, for you broke the rules, and



<P>deserved some punishment for disobedience," was the severe reply,



<P>which rather disappointed the young lady, who expected nothing but



<P>sympathy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you mean you are glad I was disgraced before the whole



<P>school?" cried Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should not have chosen that way of mending a fault,"



<P>replied her mother, "but I'm not sure that it won't do you more



<P>good than a molder method.&nbsp; You are getting to be rather conceited,



<P>my dear, and it is quite time you set about correcting it.&nbsp; You



<P>have a good many little gifts and virtues, but there is no need of



<P>parading them, for conceit spoils the finest genius.&nbsp; There is

not



<P>much danger that real talent or goodness will be overlooked long,



<P>even if it is, the consciousness of possessing and using it well



<P>should satisfy one, and the great charm of all power is modesty."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So it is!" cried Laurie, who was playing chess in a corner



<P>with Jo.&nbsp; "I knew a girl once, who had a really remarkable talent



<P>for music, and she didn't know it, never guessed what sweet little



<P>things she composed when she was alone, and wouldn't have believed



<P>it if anyone had told her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish I'd known that nice girl.&nbsp; Maybe she would have helped



<P>me, I'm so stupid," said Beth, who stood beside him, listening



<P>eagerly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You do know her, and she helps you better than anyone else



<P>could," answered Laurie, looking at her with such mischievous



<P>meaning in his merry black eyes that Beth suddenly turned very



<P>red, and hid her face in the sofa cushion, quite overcome by such



<P>an unexpected discovery.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo let Laurie win the game to pay for that praise of her Beth,



<P>who could not be prevailed upon to play for them after her compliment.



<P>So Laurie did his best, and sang delightfully, being in a particularly



<P>lively humor, for to the Marches he seldom showed the moody side



<P>of his character.&nbsp; When he was gone, amy, who had been pensive



<P>all evening, said suddenly, as if busy over some new idea,



<P>"Is Laurie an accomplished boy?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, he has had an excellent education, and has much talent.



<P>He will make a fine man, if not spoiled by petting," replied her mother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And he isn't conceited, is he?" asked Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not in the least.&nbsp; That is why he is so charming and we all



<P>like him so much."



<P>"I see.&nbsp; It's nice to have accomplishments and be elegant, but



<P>not to show off or get perked up," said Amy thoughtfully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"These things are always seen and felt in a person's manner



<P>and conversations, if modestly used, but it is not necessary to



<P>display them," said Mrs. March.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Any more than it's proper to wear all your bonnets and gowns



<P>and ribbons at once, that folks may know you've got them," added Jo,



<P>and the lecture ended in a laugh.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">
