</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 06</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER SIX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The big house did prove a Palace Beautiful, though it took



<P>some time for all to get in, and Beth found it very hard to pass



<P>the lions.&nbsp; Old Mr. Laurence was the biggest one, but after he



<P>had called, said something funny or kind to each one of the girls,



<P>and talked over old times with their mother, nobody felt much



<P>afraid of him, except timid Beth.&nbsp; The other lion was the fact

that



<P>they were poor and Laurie rich, for this made them shy of accepting



<P>favors which they could not return.&nbsp; But, after a while, they found



<P>that he considered them the benefactors, and could not do enough to



<P>show how grateful he was for Mrs. March's motherly welcome, their



<P>cheerful society, and the comfort he took in that humble home of



<P>theirs.&nbsp; So they soon forgot their pride and interchanged kindnesses



<P>without stopping to think which was the greater.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All sorts of pleasant things happened about that time, for the



<P>new friendship flourished like grass in spring.&nbsp; Every one liked



<P>Laurie, and he privately informed his tutor that "the Marches were



<P>regularly splendid girls."&nbsp; With the delightful enthusiasm of youth,



<P>they took the solitary boy into their midst and made much of him,



<P>and he found something very charming in the innocent companionship



<P>of these simple-hearted girls.&nbsp; Never having known mother or sisters,



<P>he was quick to feel the influences they brought about him, and



<P>their busy, lively ways made him ashamed of the indolent life he led.



<P>He was tired of books, and found people so interesting now that Mr.



<P>Brooke was obliged to make very unsatisfactory reports, for Laurie



<P>was always playing truant and running over to the Marches'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never mind, let him take a holiday, and make it up afterward,"



<P>said the old gentleman.&nbsp; "The good lady next door says he is studying



<P>too hard and needs young society, amusement, and exercise.&nbsp; I suspect



<P>she is right, and that I've been coddling the fellow as if I'd been



<P>his grandmother.&nbsp; Let him do what he likes, as long as he is happy.



<P>He can't get into mischief in that little nunnery over there, and



<P>Mrs. March is doing more for him than we can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>What good times they had, to be sure.&nbsp; Such plays and tableaux,



<P>such sleigh rides and skating frolics, such pleasant evenings in



<P>the old parlor, and now and then such gay little parties at the



<P>great house.&nbsp; Meg could walk in the conservatory whenever she liked



<P>and revel in bouquets, Jo browsed over the new library voraciously,



<P>and convulsed the old gentleman with her criticisms, Amy copied



<P>pictures and enjoyed beauty to her heart's content, and Laurie



<P>played `lord of the manor' in the most delightful style.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Beth, though yearning for the grand piano, could not



<P>pluck up courage to go to the `Mansion of Bliss', as Meg called



<P>it.&nbsp; She went once with Jo, but the old gentleman, not being



<P>aware of her infirmity, stared at her so hard from under his



<P>heavy eyebrows, and said "Hey!" so loud, that he frightened her



<P>so much her `feet chattered on the floor', she never told her



<P>mother, and she ran away, declaring she would never go there



<P>any more, not even for the dear piano.&nbsp; No persuasions or



<P>enticements could overcome her fear, till, the fact coming to



<P>Mr. Laurence's ear in some mysterious way, he set about mending



<P>matters.&nbsp; During one of the brief calls he made, he artfully



<P>led the conversation to music, and talked away about great



<P>singers whom he had seen, fine organs he had heard, and told



<P>such charming anecdotes that Beth found it impossible to stay



<P>in her distant corner, but crept nearer and nearer, as if



<P>fascinated.&nbsp; At the back of his chair she stopped and stood



<P>listening, with her great eyes wide open and her cheeks red



<P>with excitement of this unusual performance.&nbsp; Taking no more



<P>notice of her than if she had been a fly, Mr. Laurence talked on



<P>about Laurie's lessons and teachers.&nbsp; And presently, as if the



<P>idea had just occurred to him, he said to Mrs. March...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The boy neglects his music now, and I'm glad of it, for



<P>he was getting too fond of it.&nbsp; But the piano suffers for want



<P>of use.&nbsp; Wouldn't some of your girls like to run over, and



<P>practice on it now and then, just to keep it in tune, you know,



<P>ma`am?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth took a step forward, and pressed her hands tightly



<P>together to keep from clapping them, for this was an irresistible



<P>temptation, and the thought of practicing on that splendid



<P>instrument quite took her breath away.&nbsp; Before Mrs. March could



<P>reply, Mr. Laurence went on with an odd little nod and smile...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They needn't see or speak to anyone, but run in at any time.



<P>For I'm shut up in my study at the other end of the house, Laurie



<P>is out a great deal, and the servants are never near the drawing



<P>room after nine o'clock."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here he rose, as if going, and Beth made up her mind to speak,



<P>for that last arrangement left nothing to be desired.&nbsp; "Please,

tell



<P>the young ladies what I say, and if they don't care to come, why,



<P>never mind."&nbsp; Here a little hand slipped into his, and Beth looked



<P>up at him with a face full of gratitude, as she said, in her earnest



<P>yet timid way...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh sir, they do care, very very much!"



<P>"Are you the musical girl?" he asked, without any startling



<P>"Hey!" as he looked down at her very kindly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm Beth.&nbsp; I love it dearly, and I'll come, if you are quite



<P>sure nobody will hear me, and be disturbed," she added, fearing to



<P>be rude, and trembling at her own boldness as she spoke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a soul, my dear.&nbsp; The house is empty half the day, so



<P>come and drum away as much as you like, and I shall be obliged to



<P>you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How kind you are, sir!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth blushed like a rose under the friendly look he wore, but she



<P>was not frightened now, and gave the hand a grateful squeeze because



<P>she had no words to thank him for the precious gift he had given her.



<P>The old gentleman softly stroked the hair off her forehead, and,



<P>stooping down, he kissed herr, saying, in a tone few people ever heard...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had a little girl once, with eyes like these.&nbsp; God bless you,



<P>my dear!&nbsp; Good day.&nbsp; madam."&nbsp; And away he went, in a

great hurry.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth had a rapture with her mother, and then rushed up to



<P>impart the glorious news to her family of invalids, as the girls



<P>were not home.&nbsp; How blithely she sang that evening, and how they



<P>all laughed at her because she woke Amy in the night by playing



<P>the piano on her face in her sleep.&nbsp; Next day, having seen both



<P>the old and young gentleman out of the house, Beth, after two or



<P>three retreats, fairly got in at the side door, and made her way



<P>as noiselessly as any mouse to the drawing room where her idol



<P>stood.&nbsp; Quite by accident, of course, some pretty, easy music lay



<P>on the piano, and with trembling fingers and frequent stops to



<P>listen and look about, Beth at last touched the great instrument,



<P>and straightway forgot her fear, herself, and everything else but



<P>the unspeakable delight which the music gave her, for it was like



<P>the voice of a beloved friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She stayed till Hannah came to take her home to dinner, but she



<P>had no appetite, and could only sit and smile upon everyone in a general



<P>state of beatitude.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After that, the little brown hood slipped through the hedge



<P>nearly every day, and the great drawing room was haunted by a tuneful



<P>spirit that came and went unseen.&nbsp; She never knew that Mr. Laurence



<P>opened his study door to hear the old-fashioned airs he liked.&nbsp;

She



<P>never saw Laurie mount guard in the hall to warn the servants away.



<P>She never suspected that the exercise books and new songs which she



<P>found in the rack were put there for her especial benefit, and when



<P>he talked to her about music at home, she only thought how kind he



<P>was to tell things that helped her so much.&nbsp; So she enjoyed herself



<P>heartily, and found, what isn't always the case, that her granted



<P>wish was all she had hoped.&nbsp; Perhaps it was because she was so

grateful



<P>for this blessing that a greater was given her.&nbsp; At any rate she



<P>deserved both.



<P>"Mother, I'm going to work Mr. Laurence a pair of slippers.&nbsp; He



<P>is so kind to me, I must thank him, and I don't know any other way.



<P>Can I do it?" asked Beth, a few weeks after that eventful call of his.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, dear.&nbsp; It will please him very much, and be a nice way of



<P>thanking him.&nbsp; The girls will help you about them, and I will pay

for



<P>the making up," replied Mrs. March, who took peculiar pleasure in



<P>granting Beth's requests because she so seldom asked anything for



<P>herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After many serious discussions with Meg and Jo, the pattern was



<P>chosen, the materials bought, and the slippers begun.&nbsp; A cluster

of



<P>grave yet cheerful pansies on a deeper purple ground was pronounced



<P>very appropriate and pretty, and beth worked away early and late, with



<P>occasional lifts over hard parts.&nbsp; She was a nimble little needlewoman,



<P>and they were finished before anyone got tired of them.&nbsp; Then she

wrote



<P>a short, simple note, and with Laurie's help, got them smuggled onto



<P>the study table one morning before the old gentleman was up.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When this excitement was over, Beth waited to see what would



<P>happen.&nbsp; All day passed a a part of the next before any



<P>acknowledgement arrived, and she was beginning to fear she had offended



<P>her crochety friend.&nbsp; On the afternoon of the second day, she went

out



<P>to do an errand, and give poor Joanna, the invalid doll, her daily



<P>exercise.&nbsp; As she came up the street, on her return, she saw three,



<P>yes, four heads popping in and out of the parlor windows, and the



<P>moment they saw her, several hands were waved, and several joyful



<P>voices screamed...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here's a letter from the old gentleman!&nbsp; Come quick, and read

it!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, Beth, he's sent you..." began Amy, gesticulating with



<P>unseemly energy, but she got no further, for Jo quenched her by



<P>slamming down the window.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth hurried on in a flutter of suspense.&nbsp; At the door her



<P>sisters seized and bore her to the parlor in a triumphal procession,



<P>all pointing and all saying at once, "Look there!&nbsp; Look there!"&nbsp;

Beth



<P>did look, and turned pale with delight and surprise, for there stood



<P>a little cabinet piano, with a letter lying on the glossy lid, directed



<P>like a sign board to "Miss Elizabeth March."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"For me?" gasped Beth, holding onto Jo and feeling as if she



<P>should tumble down, it was such an overwhelming thing altogether.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, all for you, my precious!&nbsp; Isn't it splendid of him?&nbsp;

Don't



<P>you think he's the dearest old man in the world?&nbsp; Here's the key

in



<P>the letter.&nbsp; We didn't open it, but we are dying to know what he

says,"



<P>cried Jo, hugging her sister and offering the note.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You read it!&nbsp; I can't, I feel so queer!&nbsp; Oh, it is too lovely!"



<P>and Beth hid her face in Jo's apron, quite upset by her present.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo opened the paper and began to laugh, for the first worked she



<P>saw were...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss March:



<P>"Dear Madam--"



<P>"How nice it sounds!&nbsp; I wish someone would write to me so!" said



<P>Amy, who thought the old-fashioned address very elegant.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"`I have had many pairs of slippers in my life, but I never had



<P>any that suited me so well as yours, '" continues Jo.&nbsp; "`Heartsease

is



<P>my favorite flower, and these will always remind me of the gentle



<P>giver.&nbsp; I like to pay my debts, so I know you will allow `the old



<P>gentleman' to send you something which once belonged to the little



<P>grand daughter he lost.&nbsp; With hearty thanks and best wishes, I

remain



<P>"`Your grateful friend and humble servant,



<P>"`JAMES LAURENCE'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There, Beth, that's an honor to be proud of, I'm sure! Laurie



<P>told me how fond Mr.Laurence used to be of the child who died, and



<P>how he kept all her little things carefully.&nbsp; Just think, he's

given



<P>you her piano.&nbsp; That comes of having big blue eyes and loving music,"



<P>said Jo, trying to soothe Beth, who trembled and looked more excited



<P>than she had ever been before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"See the cunning brackets to hold candles, and the nice green



<P>sild, puckered up, with a gold rose in the middle, and the pretty



<P>rack and stool, all complete," added Meg, opening the instrument



<P>and displaying its beauties.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"`Your humble servant, James Laurence'.&nbsp; Only think of his



<P>writing that to you.&nbsp; I'll tell the girls.&nbsp; They'll think

it's



<P>splendid," said Amy, much impressed by the note.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Try it, honey.&nbsp; Let's hear the sound of the baby pianny,"



<P>said Hannah, who always took a share in the family joys and sorrows.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So Beth tried it, and everyone pronounced it the most remarkable



<P>piano ever heard.&nbsp; It had evidently been newly tuned and put in

apple-



<P>pie order, but, perfect as it was, I think the real charm lay in the



<P>happiest of all happy faces which leaned over it, as Beth lovingly



<P>touched the beautiful black and white keys and pressed the bright pedals.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'll have to go and thank him," said Jo, by way of a joke,



<P>for the idea of the child's really going never entered her head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I mean to.&nbsp; I guess I'll go no, before I get frightened



<P>thinking about it." And, to the utter amazement of the assembled



<P>family, Beth walked deliberately down the garden, through the



<P>hedge, and in at the Laurences' door.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I wish I may die if it ain't the queerest thing I ever



<P>see!&nbsp; The pianny has turned her head!&nbsp; She'd never have gone

in



<P>her right mind," cried Hannah, staring after her, while the girls



<P>were rendered quite speechless by the miracle.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They would have been still more amazed if they had seen what



<P>Beth did afterward.&nbsp; If you will believe me, she went and knocked



<P>at the study door before she gave herself time to think, and when



<P>a gruff voice called out, "come in!" she did go in, right up to



<P>Mr. Laurence, who looked quite taken aback, and held out her hand,



<P>saying, with only a small quaver in her voice, "I came to thank you,



<P>sir, for..." But she didn't finish, for he looked so friendly that



<P>she forgot her speech and, only remembering that he had lost the



<P>little girl he loved, she put both arms round his neck and kissed



<P>him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If the roof of the house had suddenly flown off, the old



<P>gentleman wouldn't have been more astonished.&nbsp; But he liked it.



<P>Oh, dear, yes, he liked it amazingly!&nbsp; And was so touched and



<P>pleased by that confiding little kiss that all his crustiness



<P>vanished, and he just set her on his knee, and laid his



<P>wrinkled cheek against her rosy one, feeling as if he had got his



<P>own little grand daughter back again.&nbsp; Beth ceased to fear him



<P>from that moment, and sat there talking to him as cozily as if



<P>she had known him all her life, for love casts out fear, and



<P>gratitude can conquer pride.&nbsp; When she went home, he walked with



<P>her to her own gate, shook hands cordially, and touched his hat



<P>as he marched back again, looking very stately and erect, like



<P>a handsome, soldierly old gentleman, as he was.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the girls saw that performance, Jo began to dance a jig,



<P>by way of expressing her satisfaction, Amy nearly fell out of the



<P>window in her surprise, and Meg exclaimed, with up-lifted hands,



<P>"Well, I do believe the world is coming to an end.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 12</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER TWELVE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth was postmistress, for, being most at home, she could



<P>attend to it regularly, and dearly liked the daily task of



<P>unlocking the little door and distributing the mail.&nbsp; One July



<P>day she came in with her hands full, and went about the house



<P>leaving letters and parcels like the penny post.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here's your posy, Mother!&nbsp; Laurie never forgets that," she



<P>said, putting the fresh nosegay in the vase that stood in `Marmee's



<P>corner', and was kept supplied by the affectionate boy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Meg March, one letter and a glove," continued Beth,



<P>delivering the articles to her sister, who sat near her mother,



<P>stitching wristbands.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, I left a pair over there, and here is only one," said



<P>Meg, looking at the gray cotton glove.&nbsp; "Didn't you drop the



<P>other in the garden?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I'm sure I didn't, for there was only one in the office."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hate to have odd gloves!&nbsp; Never mind, the other may be



<P>found.&nbsp; My letter is only a translation of the German song I



<P>wanted.&nbsp; I think Mr. Brooke did it, for this isn't Laurie's



<P>writing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March glanced at Meg, who was looking very pretty in



<P>her gingham morning gown, with the little curls blowing about her



<P>forehead, and very womanly, as she sat sewing at her little worktable,



<P>full of tidy white rolls, so unconscious of the thought in her



<P>mother's mind as she sewed and sang, while her fingers flew



<P>and her thoughts were busied with girlish fancies as innocent



<P>and fresh as the pansies in her belt, that Mrs. March smiled and



<P>was satisfied.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Two letters for Doctor Jo, a book, and a funny old hat,



<P>which covered the whole post office and stuck outside," said



<P>Beth, laughing as she went into the study where Jo sat writing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a sly fellow Laurie is!&nbsp; I said I wished bigger hats



<P>were the fashion, because I burn my face every hot day.&nbsp; He said,



<P>`Why mind the fashion?&nbsp; Wear a big hat, and be comfortable!' I



<P>said I would if I had one, and he has sent me this to try me.&nbsp;

I'll



<P>wear it for fun, and show him I don't care for the fashion."&nbsp; And



<P>hanging the antique broadbrim on a bust of Plato, Jo read her



<P>letters.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>One from her mother made her cheeks glow and her eyes fill,



<P>for it said to her...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>My Dear:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I write a little word to tell you with how much satisfaction



<P>I watch your efforts to control your temper.&nbsp; You say nothing



<P>about your trials, failures, or successes, and think, perhaps,



<P>that no one sees them but the Friend whose help you daily ask,



<P>if I may trust the well-worn cover of your guidebook.&nbsp; I, too,



<P>have seen them all, and heartily believe in the sincerity of



<P>your resolution, since it begins to bear fruit.&nbsp; Go on, dear,



<P>patiently and bravely, and always believe that no one sympathizes



<P>more tenderly with you than your loving...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mother

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That does me good!&nbsp; That's worth millions of money and



<P>pecks of praise.&nbsp; Oh, Marmee, I do try!&nbsp; I will keep on trying,



<P>and not get tired, since I have you to help me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laying her head on her arms, Jo wet her little romance with



<P>a few happy tears.&nbsp; for she had thought that no one saw and



<P>appreciated her efforts to be good, and this assurance was doubly



<P>precious, doubly encouraging, because unexpected and from the



<P>person whose commendation she most valued.&nbsp; Feeling stronger than



<P>ever to meet and subdue her Apollyon, she pinned the note inside her



<P>frock, as a shield and a reminder, lest she be taken unaware, and



<P>proceeded to open her other letter, quite ready for either good or



<P>bad news.&nbsp; In a big, dashing hand, Laurie wrote...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dear Jo,



<P>What ho!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Some english girls and boys are coming to see me tomorrow



<P>and I want to have a jolly time.&nbsp; If it's fine, I'm going to pitch



<P>my tent in Longmeadow, and row up the whole crew to lunch and



<P>croquet--have a fire, make messes, gypsy fashion, and all sorts



<P>of larks.&nbsp; They are nice people, and like such things.&nbsp; Brooke

will



<P>go to keep us boys steady, and Kate Vaughn will play propriety for



<P>the girls.&nbsp; I want you all to come, can't let Beth off at any price,



<P>and nobody shall worry her.&nbsp; Don't bother about rations, I'll see



<P>to that and everything else, only do come, there's a good fellow!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In a tearing hurry,



<P>Yours ever, Laurie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here's richness!" cried Jo, flying in to tell the news to Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course we can go, Mother?&nbsp; It will be such a help to



<P>Laurie, for I can row, and Meg see to the lunch, and the children



<P>be useful in some way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope the Vaughns are not fine grown-up people.&nbsp; Do you



<P>know anything about them, Jo?" asked Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Only that there are four of them.&nbsp; Kate is older than you,



<P>Fred and Frank (twins) about my age, and a little girl (Grace), who



<P>is nine or ten.&nbsp; Laurie knew them abroad, and liked the boys.&nbsp;

I



<P>fancied, from the way he primmed up his mouth in speaking of her,



<P>that he didn't admire Kate much."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm so glad my French print is clean, it's just the thing



<P>and so becoming!" observed Meg complacently.&nbsp; "Have you anything



<P>decent, Jo?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Scarlet and gray boating suit, good enough for me.&nbsp; I shall



<P>row and tramp about, so I don't want any starch to think of.&nbsp; You'll



<P>come, Betty?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you won't let any boys talk to me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a boy!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I like to please Laurie, and I'm not afraid of Mr. Brooke,



<P>he is so kind.&nbsp; But I don't want to play, or sing, or say anything.



<P>I'll work hard and not trouble anyone, and you'll take care of me,



<P>Jo, so I'll go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's my good girl.&nbsp; You do try to fight off your shyness,



<P>and I love you for it.&nbsp; Fighting faults isn't easy, as I know,

and



<P>a cheery word kind of gives a lift.&nbsp; Thank you, Mother," And Jo



<P>gave the thin cheek a grateful kiss, more precious to Mrs. March



<P>than if it had given back the rosy roundness of her youth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had a box of chocolate drops, and the picture I wanted to



<P>copy," said Amy, showing her mail.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I got a note from Mr. Laurence, asking me to come over



<P>and play to him tonight, before the lamps are lighted, and I shall



<P>go," added Beth, whose friendship with the old gentleman prospered



<P>finely.



<P>"Now let's fly round, and do double duty today, so that we can



<P>play tomorrow with free minds," said Jo, preparing to replace her



<P>pen with a broom.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the sun peeped into the girls' room early next morning



<P>to promise them a fine day, he saw a comical sight.&nbsp; Each had



<P>made such preparation for the fete as seemed necessary and proper.



<P>Meg had an extra row of little curlpapers across her forehead, Jo



<P>had copiously anointed her afflicted face with cold cream, Beth



<P>had taken Joanna to bed with her to atone for the approaching



<P>separation, and Amy had capped the climax by putting a colthespin



<P>on her nose to uplift the offending feature.&nbsp; It was one of the



<P>kind artists use to hold the paper on their drawing boards,



<P>therefore quite appropriate and effective for the purpose it was now



<P>being put.&nbsp; This funny spectacle appeared to amuse the sun, for



<P>he burst out with such radiance that Jo woke up and roused her



<P>sisters by a hearty laugh at Amy's ornament.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sunshine and laughter were good omens for a pleasure party,



<P>and soon a lively bustle began in both houses.&nbsp; Beth, who was



<P>ready first, kept reporting what went on next door, and enlivened



<P>her sisters' toilets by frequent telegrams from the window.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There goes the man with the tent!&nbsp; I see Mrs. Barker doing



<P>up the lunch in a hamper and a great basket.&nbsp; Now Mr. Laurence

is



<P>looking up at the sky and the weathercock.&nbsp; I wish he would go



<P>too.&nbsp; There's Laurie, looking like a sailor, nice boy!&nbsp; Oh,

mercy



<P>me!&nbsp; Here's a carriage full of people, a tall lady, a little girl,



<P>and two dreadful boys.&nbsp; One is lame, poor thing, he's got a crutch.



<P>Laurie didn't tell us that.&nbsp; Be quick, girls!&nbsp; It's getting

late.



<P>Why, there is Ned Moffat, I do declare.&nbsp; Meg, isn't that the man



<P>who bowed to you one day when we were shopping?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So it is.&nbsp; How queer that he should come.&nbsp; I thought he was



<P>at the mountains.&nbsp; There is Sallie.&nbsp; I'm glad she got back

in time.



<P>Am I all right, Jo?" cried Meg in a flutter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A regular daisy.&nbsp; Hold up your dress and put your hat on



<P>straight, it looks sentimental tipped that way and will fly off



<P>at the first puff.&nbsp; Now then, come on!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, Jo, you are not going to wear that awful hat?&nbsp; It's too



<P>absurd!&nbsp; You shall not make a guy of yourself," remonstrated Meg,



<P>as Jo tied down with a red ribbon the broad-brimmed, old-fashioned



<P>leghorn Laurie had sent for a joke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I just will, though, for it's capital, so shady, light, and big.



<P>It will make fun, and I don't mind being a guy if I'm comfortable."



<P>With that Jo marched straight away and the rest followed,



<P>a bright little band of sisters, all looking their best in summer



<P>suits, with happy faces under the jaunty hatbrims.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie ran to meet and present them to his friends in the



<P>most cordial manner.&nbsp; The lawn was the reception room, and for



<P>several minutes a lively scene was enacted there.&nbsp; Meg was



<P>grateful to see that Miss Kate, though twenty, was dressed with



<P>a simplicity which American girls would do well to imitate, and



<P>who was much flattered by Mr. Ned's assurances that he came



<P>especially to see her.&nbsp; Jo understood why Laurie `primmed up



<P>his mouth' when speaking of Kate, for that young lady had a



<P>standoff-don't-touch-me air, which contrasted strongly with the



<P>free and easy demeanor of the other girls.&nbsp; Beth took an observation



<P>of the new boys and decided that the lame one was not `dreadful',



<P>but gentle and feeble, and she would be kind to him on that



<P>account.&nbsp; Amy found Grace a well-mannered, merry, little person,



<P>and after staring dumbly at one another for a few minutes, they



<P>suddenly became very good friends.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tents, lunch, and croquet utensils having been sent on



<P>beforehand, the party was soon embarked, and the two boats



<P>pushed off together, leaving Mr. Laurence waving his hat on the



<P>shore.&nbsp; Laurie and Jo rowed one boat, Mr. Brooke and Ned the



<P>other, while Fred Vaughn, the riotous twin, did his best to



<P>upset both by paddling about in a wherry like a disturbed water



<P>bug.&nbsp; Jo's funny hat deserved a vote of thanks, for it was of



<P>general utility.&nbsp; It broke the ice in the beginning by producing



<P>a laugh, it created quite a refreshing breeze, flapping to and



<P>fro as she rowed, and would make an excellent umbrella for the



<P>whole party, if a shower came up, she said.&nbsp; Miss Kate decided



<P>that she was `odd', but rather clever, and smiled upon her from



<P>afar.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg, in the other boat, was delightfully situated, face to



<P>face with the rowers, who both admired the prospect and feathered



<P>their oars with uncommon `skill and dexterity'.&nbsp; Mr. Brooke was



<P>a grave, silent young man, with handsome brown eyes and a pleasant



<P>voice.&nbsp; Meg liked his quiet manners and considered him a walking



<P>encyclopedia of useful knowledge.&nbsp; He never talked to her much,

but



<P>he looked at her a good deal, and she felt sure that he did not



<P>regard her with aversion.&nbsp; Ned, being in college, of course put



<P>on all the airs which freshmen think it their bounden duty to



<P>assume.&nbsp; He was not very wise, but very good-natured, and altogether



<P>an excellent person to carry on a picnic.&nbsp; Sallie Gardiner was



<P>absorbed in keeping her white pique dress clean and chattering with



<P>the ubiquitous Fred, who kept Beth in constant terror by his pranks.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was not far to Longmeadow, but the tent was pitched and



<P>the wickets down by the time they arrived.&nbsp; A pleasant green field,



<P>with three wide-spreading oaks in the middle and a smooth strip of



<P>turf for croquet.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Welcome to Camp Laurence!" said the young host, as they



<P>landed with exclamations of delight.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Brooke is commander in chief, I am commissary general, the



<P>other fellows are staff officers, and you, ladies, are company.



<P>The tent is for your especial benefit and that oak is your drawing



<P>room, this is the messroom and the third is the camp kitchen.&nbsp;

Now,



<P>let's have a game before it gets hot, and then we'll see about



<P>dinner."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Frank, Beth, Amy, and Grace sat down to watch the game



<P>played by the other eight.&nbsp; Mr. Brooke chose Meg, Kate, and Fred.



<P>Laurie took Sallie, Jo, and Ned.&nbsp; The English played well, but



<P>the Americans played better, and contested every inch of the



<P>ground as strongly as if the spirit of `76 inspired them.&nbsp; Jo and



<P>Fred had several skirmishes and once narrowly escaped high words.



<P>Jo was through the last wicket and had missed the stroke, which



<P>failure ruffled her a good deal.&nbsp; Fred was close behind her and



<P>his turn came before hers.&nbsp; He gave a stroke, his ball hit the



<P>wicket, and stopped an inch on the wrong side.&nbsp; No one was very



<P>near, and running up to examine, he gave it a sly nudge with his



<P>toe, which put it just an inch on the right side.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm through!&nbsp; Now, Miss Jo, I'll settle you, and get in



<P>first," cried the young gentleman, swinging his mallet for another



<P>blow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You pushed it.&nbsp; I saw you.&nbsp; It's my turn now," said Jo



<P>sharply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word, I didn't move it.&nbsp; It rolled a bit, perhaps,



<P>but that is allowed.&nbsp; So, stand off please, and let me have a go



<P>at the stake."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We don't cheat in America, but you can, if you choose," said



<P>Jo angrily.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yankees are a deal the most tricky, everybody knows.&nbsp; There



<P>you go!" returned Fred, croqueting her ball far away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo opened her lips to say something rude, but checked herself



<P>in time, colored up to her forehead and stood a minute, hammering



<P>down a wicket with all her might, while Fred hit the stake and



<P>declared himself out with much exultation.&nbsp; She went off to get

her



<P>ball, and was a long time finding it among the bushes, but she came



<P>back, looking cool and quiet, and waited her turn patiently.&nbsp; It



<P>took several strokes to regain the place she had lost, and when she



<P>got there, the other side had nearly won, for Kate's ball was the



<P>last but one and lay near the stake.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"By George, it's all up with us!&nbsp; Goodbye, Kate.&nbsp; Miss Jo



<P>owes me one, so you are finished," cried Fred excitedly, as they



<P>all drew near to see the finish.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yankees have a trick of being generous to their enemies,"



<P>said Jo, with a look that made the lad redden, "especially when



<P>they beat them," she added, as, leaving Kate's ball untouched, she



<P>won the game by a clever stroke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie threw up his hat, then remembered that it wouldn't do



<P>to exult over the defeat of his guests, and stopped in the middle



<P>of the cheer to whisper to his friend, "Good for you, Jo!&nbsp; He did



<P>cheat, I saw him.&nbsp; We can't tell him so, but he won't do it again,



<P>take my word for it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg drew her aside, under pretense of pinning up a loose



<P>braid, and said approvingly, "It was dreadfully provoking, but you



<P>kept your temper, and I'm so glad, Jo."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't praise me, Meg, for I could box his ears this minute.



<P>I should certainly have boiled over if I hadn't stayed among the



<P>nettles till I got my rage under control enough to hold my tongue..



<P>It's simmering now, so I hope he'll keep out of my way," returned



<P>Jo, biting her lips as she glowered at Fred from under her big hat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Time for lunch," said Mr. Brooke, looking at his watch.



<P>"Commissary general, will you make the fire and get water, while



<P>Miss March, Miss Sallie, and I spread the table?&nbsp; Who can make

good



<P>coffee?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo can," said Meg, glad to recommend her sister.&nbsp; So Jo,



<P>feeling that her late lessons in cookery were to do her honor, went



<P>to preside over the coffeepot, while the children collected dry



<P>sticks, and the boys made a fire and got water from a spring near



<P>by.&nbsp; Miss Kate sketched and Frank talked to Beth, who was making



<P>little mats of braided rushes to serve as plates.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The commander in chief and his aides soon spread the



<P>tablecloth with an inviting array of eatables and drinkables,



<P>prettily decorated with green leaves.&nbsp; Jo announced that the coffee



<P>was ready, and everyone settled themselves to a hearty meal, for youth



<P>is seldom dyspeptic, and exercise develops wholesome appetites.



<P>A very merry lunch it was, for everything seemed fresh and funny, and



<P>frequent peals of laughter startled a venerable horse who fed near



<P>by.&nbsp; There was a pleasing inequality in the table, which produced



<P>many mishaps to cups and plates, acorns dropped in the milk, little



<P>black ants partook of the refreshments without being invited, and



<P>fuzzy caterpillars swung down from the tree to see what was going



<P>on.&nbsp; Three white-headed children peeped over the fence, and an



<P>objectionable dog barked at them from the other side of the river



<P>with all his might and main.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There's salt here," said Laurie, as he handed Jo a saucer



<P>of berries.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, I prefer spiders," she replied, fishing up two



<P>unwary little ones who had gone to a creamy death.&nbsp; "How dare



<P>you remind me of that horrid dinner party, when your's is so



<P>nice in every way?' added Jo, as they both laughed and ate out



<P>of one plate, the china having run short.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had an uncommonly good time that day, and haven't got



<P>over it yet.&nbsp; This is no credit to me, you know, I don't do



<P>anything.&nbsp; It's you and Meg and Brooke who make it all go, and



<P>I'm no end obliged to you.&nbsp; what shall we do when we can't eat



<P>anymore?" asked Laurie, feeling that his trump card had been



<P>played when lunch was over.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have games till it's cooler.&nbsp; I brought Authors, and I dare



<P>say Miss Kate knows something new and nice.&nbsp; Go and ask her.&nbsp;

She's



<P>company, and you ought to stay with her more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aren't you company too?&nbsp; I thought she'd suit Brooke, but



<P>he keeps talking to Meg, and Kate just stares at them through that



<P>ridiculous glass of hers'.&nbsp; I'm going, so you needn't try to preach



<P>propriety, for you can't do it, Jo."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Kate did know several new games, and as the girls would



<P>not, and the boys could not, eat any more, they all adjourned to



<P>the drawing room to play Rig-marole.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"One person begins a story, any nonsense you like, and tells



<P>as long as he pleases, only taking care to stop short at some



<P>exciting point, when the next takes it up and does the same.&nbsp; It's



<P>very funny when well done, and makes a perfect jumble of tragical



<P>comical stuff to laugh over.&nbsp; Please start it, Mr. Brooke," said



<P>Kate, with a commanding air, which surprised Meg, who treated the



<P>tutor with as much respect as any other gentleman.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lying on the grass at the feet of the two young ladies, Mr.



<P>Brooke obediently began the story, with the handsome brown eyes



<P>steadily fixed upon the sunshiny river.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Once on a time, a knight went out into the world to seek



<P>his fortune, for he had nothing but his sword and his shield.



<P>He traveled a long while, nearly eight-and-twenty years, and



<P>had a hard time of it, till he came to the palace of a good old



<P>king, who had offered a reward to anyone who could tame and train



<P>a fine but unbroken colt, of which he was very fond.&nbsp; The knight



<P>agreed to try, and got on slowly but surely, for the colt was a



<P>gallant fellow, and soon learned to love his new master, though



<P>he was freakish and wild.&nbsp; Every day, when he gave his lessons

to



<P>this pet of the king's, the knight rode him through the city, and



<P>as he rode, he looked everywhere for a certain beautiful face,



<P>which he had seen many times in his dreams, but never found.&nbsp; One



<P>day, as he went prancing down a quiet street, he saw at the window



<P>of a ruinous castle the lovely face.&nbsp; He was delighted, inquired



<P>who lived in this old castle, and was told that several captive



<P>princesses were kept there by a spell, and spun all day to lay



<P>up money to buy their liberty.&nbsp; The knight wished intensely that



<P>he could free them, but he was poor and could only go by each



<P>day, watching for the sweet face and longing to see it out in



<P>the sunshine.&nbsp; At last he resolved to get into the castle and



<P>ask how he could help them.&nbsp; He went and knocked.&nbsp; The great



<P>door flew open, and he beheld .&nbsp; .."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A ravishingly lovely lady, who exclaimed, with a cry of



<P>rapture, `At last!&nbsp; At last!'" continued Kate, who had read



<P>French novels, and admired the style.&nbsp; "`Tis she!' cried Count



<P>Gustave, and fell at her feet in an ecstasy of joy.&nbsp; `Oh, rise!'



<P>she said, extending a hand of marble fairness.&nbsp; `Never! Till you



<P>tell me how I may rescue you, ' swore the knight, still kneeling.



<P>`Alas, my cruel fate condemns me to remain here till my tyrant



<P>is destroyed.' `Where is the villain?' `In the mauve salon.&nbsp; Go,



<P>brave heart, and save me from despair.' `I obey, and return



<P>victorious or dead!' With these thrilling words he rushed away,



<P>and flinging open the door of the mauve salon, was about to enter,



<P>when he received..."



<P>"A stunning blow from the big Greek lexicon, which an old



<P>fellow in a black gown fired at him," said Ned.&nbsp; "Instantly, Sir



<P>What's-his-name recovered himself, pitched the tyrant out of the



<P>window, and turned to join the lady, victorious, but with a bump



<P>on his brow, found the door locked, tore up the curtains, made a



<P>rope ladder, got halfway down when the ladder broke, and he went



<P>headfirst into the moat, sixty feet below.&nbsp; Could swim like a



<P>duck, paddled round the castle till he came to a little door



<P>guarded by two stout fellows, knocked their heads together till



<P>they cracked like a couple of nuts, then, by a trifling exertion



<P>of his prodigious strength, he smashed in the door, went up a



<P>pair of stone steps covered with dust a foot thick, toads as big



<P>as your fist, and spiders that would frighten you into hysterics,



<P>MIss March.&nbsp; At the top of these steps he came plump upon a sight



<P>that took his breath away and chilled his blood..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A tall figure, all in white with a veil over its face and a



<P>lamp in its wasted hand," went on Meg.&nbsp; "It beckoned, gliding



<P>noiselessly before him down a corridor as dark and cold as any



<P>tomb.&nbsp; Shadowy effigies in armor stood on either side, a dead

<P>and anon turned its face toward him, showing the glitter of awful

<P>which sounded lovely music.&nbsp; He sprang forward to enter, but the



<P>specter plucked him back, and waved threateningly before him a..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>audience.&nbsp; "`Thankee, ' said the knight politely, as he took a

pinch



<P>and sneezed seven times so violently that his head fell off.&nbsp; `Ha!

<P>princesses spinning away for dear life, the evil spirit picked up

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>"Dance a hornpipe," cut in Fred, as Jo paused for breath, "and,



<P>as they danced, the rubbishy old castle turned to a man-of-war in



<P>full sail.&nbsp; `Up with the jib, reef the tops'l halliards, helm hard



<P>alee, and man the guns!' roared the captain, as a Portuguese pirate



<P>hove in sight, with a flag black as ink flying from her foremast.



<P>`Go in and win, my hearties!' says the captain, and a tremendous



<P>fight began.&nbsp; Of course the British beat, they always do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, they don't!" cried Jo, aside.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>the schooner, whose decks were piled high with dead and whose



<P>lee scuppers ran blood, for the order had been `Cutlasses, and



<P>die hard!' `Bosun's mate, take a bight of the flying-jib sheet,

<P>"Oh, gracious!&nbsp; What shall I say?" cried Sallie, as Fred



<P>ended his rigmarole, in which he had jumbled together pell-mell

<P>"Well, they went to the bottom, and a nice mermaid welcomed them,



<P>but was much grieved on finding the box of headless knights, and

<P>about them, for being a woman, she was curious.&nbsp; By-and-by a diver



<P>came down, and the mermaid said, `I'll give you a box of pearls



<P>if you can take it up, ' for she wanted to restore the poor things

<P>hoisted it up, and was much disappointed on opening it to find

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Little goose girl, who kept a hundred fat geese in the field,"



<P>said Amy, when Sallie's invention gave out.&nbsp; "The little girl was



<P>sorry for them, and asked an old woman what she should do to help



<P>them.&nbsp; `Your geese will tell you, they know everything.' said the

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>said the girl, and ran to get twelve fine ones from her garden.



<P>She put them on, the knights revived at once, thanked her, and



<P>went on their way rejoicing, never knowing the difference, for

<P>themselves free and all gone and married, but one.&nbsp; He was in a

<P>he.&nbsp; `You must come and get it.&nbsp; I can't come to you, it isn't



<P>proper, ' said she, as sweet as honey.&nbsp; He tried to climb over



<P>the hedge, but it seemed to grow higher and higher.&nbsp; Then he



<P>tried to push through, but it grew thicker and thicker, and he



<P>was in despair.&nbsp; So he patiently broke twig after twig till he

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't.&nbsp; I'm not playing, I never do," said Frank, dismayed



<P>at the sentimental predicament out of which he was to rescue the



<P>absurd couple.&nbsp; Beth had disappeared behind Jo, and Grace was



<P>asleep.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So the poor knight is to be left sticking in the hedge, is



<P>he?" asked Mr. Brooke, still watching the river, and playing



<P>with the wild rose in his buttonhole.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I guess the princess gave him a posy, and opened the gate



<P>after a while," said Laurie, smiling to himself, as he threw



<P>acorns at his tutor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a piece of nonsense we have made!&nbsp; With practice we



<P>might do something quite clever.&nbsp; Do you know Truth?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope so," said Meg soberly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The game, I mean?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"what is it?" said Fred.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, you pile up your hands, choose a number, and draw out



<P>in turn, and the person who draws at the number has to answer



<P>truly any question put by the rest.&nbsp; It's great fun."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let's try it," said Jo, who liked new experiments.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Kate and Mr. Booke, Meg, and Ned declined, but Fred,



<P>Sallie, Jo, and Laurie piled and drew, and the lot fell to Laurie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Who are your heroes?" asked Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Grandfather and Napoleon."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Which lady here do you think prettiest?" said Sallie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Margaret."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Which do you like best?" from Fred.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo, of course."



<P>"What silly questions you ask!"&nbsp; And Jo gave a disdainful



<P>shrug as the rest laughed at Laurie's matter-of-fact tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's a very good one for you," retorted Jo in a low voice.



<P>Her turn came next.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A quick temper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a true answer.&nbsp; You must say what you really do want most."

<P>And she slyly smiled in his disappointed face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Ned, frank, and the little girls joined in this, and while it

a

who

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a queer smile about Mr. Brooke's mouth as he

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>young man would want to go, though it is hard for the mothers

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Laurie and his grandfather would care a great deal, and we

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, that sounds pleasant," began Mr. Brooke, looking



<P>cheerful again, but before he could finish his speech, Ned, mounted

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't you love to ride?" asked Grace of Amy, as they stood



<P>resting after a race round the field with the others, led by Ned.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dote upon it.&nbsp; My sister, Meg, used to ride when Papa was



<P>rich, but we don't keep any horses now, except Ellen Tree," added

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tell me about Ellen Tree.&nbsp; Is it a donkey?" asked Grace

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, you see, Jo is crazy about horses and so am I, but



<P>we've only got an old sidesaddle and no horse.&nbsp; Out in our



<P>garden is an apple tree that has a nice low branch, so Jo put



<P>the saddle on it, fixed some reins on the part that turns up,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How funny!" laughed Grace.&nbsp; "I have a pony at home, and

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Frank, sitting just behind the little girls, heard what they



<P>were saying, and pushed his crutch away from him with an impatient

<P>comical gymnastics.&nbsp; Beth, who was collecting the scattered



<P>Author cards, looked up and said, in her shy yet friendly way,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If he asked her to deliver a Latin oration, it would not



<P>have seemed a more impossible task to bashful Beth, but there



<P>was no place to run to, no Jo to hide behind now, and the poor



<P>boy looked so wistfully at her that she bravely resolved to try.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>the cards and dropping half as she tried to tie them up.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>said Frank, who had not yet learned to suit his amusements to



<P>his strength.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>My heart!&nbsp; What shall I do?&nbsp; I don't know anything about them,



<P>thought Beth, and forgetting the boy's misfortune in her flurry,



<P>she said, hoping to make him talk, "I never saw any hunting, but



<P>I suppose you know all about it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I did once, but I can never hunt again, for I got hurt leaping



<P>a confounded five-barred gate, so there are no more horses and

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>had read one of the boys' books in which Jo delighted.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Buffaloes proved soothing and satisfactory, and in her eagerness



<P>to amuse another, Beth forgot herself, and was quite unconscious

<P>had begged protection.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>aid Jo, beaming at her from the croquet ground.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>there could be no further doubt of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>said Amy, well pleased at Beth's success.&nbsp; She meant `facinating',



<P>but as Grace didn't know the exact meaning of either word,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>An impromptu circus, fox and geese, and an amicable game of

<P>Ned, getting sentimental, warbled a serenade with the pensive



<P>refrain...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Alone, alone, ah! Woe, alone,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>and at the lines...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>We each are young, we each have a heart,



<P>Oh, why should we stand thus coldly apart?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>he looked at Meg with such a lackadiasical expression that she



<P>laughed outright and spoiled his song.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>of a lively chorus.&nbsp; "You've kept close to that starched-up

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>to her rather pettishly, "There isn't a bit of flirt in that girl,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<P>her friend even while confessing her shortcomings.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She's not a stricken deer anyway," said Ned, trying to be



<P>witty, and succeeding as well as very young gentlemen usually do.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On the lawn where it had gathered, the little party separated



<P>with cordial good nights and good-bys, for the Vaughns were going



<P>to Canada.&nbsp; As the four sisters went home through the garden, Miss



<P>Kate looked after them, saying, without the patronizing tone in



<P>her voice, "In spite of their demonstrative manners, American girls



<P>are very nice when one knows them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I quite agree with you," said Mr. Brooke.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">
