<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 40</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FORTY</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the first bitterness was over, the family accepted



<P>the inevitable, and tried to bear it cheerfully, helping one



<P>another by the increased affection which comes to bind households



<P>tenderly together in times of trouble.&nbsp; They put away their grief,



<P>and each did his or her part toward making that last year a happy one.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The pleasantest room in the house was set apart for Beth,



<P>and in it was gathered everything that she most loved, flowers,



<P>pictures, her piano, the little worktable, and the beloved



<P>pussies.&nbsp; Father's best books found their way there, Mother's



<P>easy chair, Jo's desk, Amy's finest sketches, and every day



<P>Meg brought her babies on a loving pilgrimage, to make sunshine



<P>for Aunty Beth.&nbsp; John quietly set apart a little sum, that he



<P>might enjoy the pleasure of keeping the invalid supplied with



<P>the fruit she loved and longed for.&nbsp; Old Hannah never wearied



<P>of concocting dainty dishes to tempt a capricious appetite,



<P>dropping tears as she worked, and from across the sea came



<P>little gifts and cheerful letters, seeming to bring breaths



<P>of warmth and fragrance from lands that know no winter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here, cherished like a household saint in its shrine, sat



<P>Beth, tranquil and busy as ever, for nothing could change the



<P>sweet, unselfish nature, and even while preparing to leave



<P>life, she tried to make it happier for those who should remain



<P>behind.&nbsp; The feeble fingers were never idle, and one of her



<P>pleasures was to make little things for the school children



<P>daily passing to and fro, to drop a pair of mittens from her



<P>window for a pair of purple hands, a needlebook for some small



<P>mother of many dolls, penwipers for young penmen toiling through



<P>forests of pothooks, scrapbooks for picture-loving eyes, and



<P>all manner of pleasant devices, till the reluctant climbers of



<P>the ladder of learning found their way strewn with flowers, as



<P>it were, and came to regard the gentle giver as a sort of fairy



<P>godmother, who sat above there, and showered down gifts miraculously



<P>suited to their tastes and needs.&nbsp; If Beth had wanted any



<P>reward, she found it in the bright little faces always turned up



<P>to her window, with nods and smiles, and the droll little letters



<P>which came to her, full of blots and gratitude.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The first few months were very happy ones, and Beth often



<P>used to look round, and say "How beautiful this is!" as they



<P>all sat together in her sunny room, the babies kicking and crowing



<P>on the floor, mother and sisters working near, and father



<P>reading, in his pleasant voice, from the wise old books which



<P>seemed rich in good and comfortable words, as applicable now as



<P>when written centuries ago, a little chapel, where a paternal



<P>priest taught his flock the hard lessons all must learn, trying



<P>to show them that hope can comfort love, and faith make resignation



<P>possible.&nbsp; Simple sermons, that went straight to the souls of



<P>those who listened, for the father's heart was in the minister's



<P>religion, and the frequent falter in the voice gave a double



<P>eloquence to the words he spoke or read.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was well for all that this peaceful time was given them



<P>as preparation for the sad hours to come, for by-and-by, Beth



<P>said the needle was `so heavy', and put it down forever.&nbsp; Talking



<P>wearied her, faces troubled her, pain claimed her for its own,



<P>and her tranquil spirit was sorrowfully perturbed by the ills



<P>that vexed her feeble flesh.&nbsp; Ah me!&nbsp; Such heavy days, such

long,



<P>long nights, such aching hearts and imploring prayers, when those



<P>who loved her best were forced to see the thin hands stretched out



<P>to them beseechingly, to hear the bitter cry, "Help me, help me!"



<P>and to feel that there was no help.&nbsp; A sad eclipse of the serene



<P>soul, a sharp struggle of the young life with death, but both were



<P>mercifully brief, and then the natural rebellion over, the old peace



<P>returned more beautiful than ever.&nbsp; With the wreck of her frail

body,



<P>Beth's soul grew strong, and though she said little, those about her



<P>felt that she was ready, saw that the first pilgrim called was likewise



<P>the fittest, and waited with her on the shore, trying to see the



<P>Shining Ones coming to receive her when she crossed the river.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo never left her for an hour since Beth had said "I feel



<P>stronger when you are here."&nbsp; She slept on a couch in the room,



<P>waking often to renew the fire, to feed, lift, or wait upon the



<P>patient creature who seldom asked for anything, and `tried not to



<P>be a trouble'.&nbsp; All day she haunted the room, jealous of any other



<P>nurse, and prouder of being chosen then than of any honor her life



<P>ever brought her.&nbsp; Precious and helpful hours to Jo, for now her



<P>heart received the teaching that it needed.&nbsp; Lessons in patience



<P>were so sweetly taught her that she could not fail to learn them,



<P>charity for all, the lovely spirit that can forgive and truly



<P>forget unkindness, the loyalty to duty that makes the hardest



<P>easy, and the sincere faith that fears nothing, but trusts undoubtingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Often when she woke Jo found Beth reading in her well-worn



<P>little book, heard her singing softly, to beguile the sleepless



<P>night, or saw her lean her face upon her hands, while slow tears



<P>dropped through the transparent fingers, and Jo would lie watching



<P>her with thoughts too deep for tears, feeling that Beth, in



<P>her simple, unselfish way, was trying to wean herself from the



<P>dear old life, and fit herself for the life to come, by sacred



<P>words of comfort, quiet prayers, and the music she loved so well.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Seeing this did more for Jo than the wisest sermons, the



<P>saintliest hymns, the most fervent prayers that any voice could



<P>utter.&nbsp; For with eyes made clear by many tears, and a heart



<P>softened by the tenderest sorrow, she recognized the beauty of



<P>her sister's life--uneventful, unambitious, yet full of the



<P>genuine virtues which `smell sweet, and blossom in the dust',



<P>the self-forgetfulness that makes the humblest on earth remembered



<P>soonest in heaven, the true success which is possible to all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>One night when Beth looked among the books upon her table,



<P>to find something to make her forget the mortal weariness that



<P>was almost as hard to bear as pain, as she turned the leaves of



<P>her old favorite, Pilgrims's Progress, she found a little paper,



<P>scribbled over in Jo's hand.&nbsp; The name caught her eye and the



<P>blurred look of the lines made her sure that tears had fallen



<P>on it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor Jo!&nbsp; She's fast asleep, so I won't wake her to ask



<P>leave.&nbsp; She shows me all her things, and I don't think she'll



<P>mind if I look at this", thought Beth, with a glance at her



<P>sister, who lay on the rug, with the tongs beside her, ready



<P>to wake up the minute the log fell apart.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>MY BETH

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sitting patient in the shadow



<P>Till the blessed light shall come,



<P>A serene and saintly presence



<P>Sanctifies our troubled home.



<P>Earthly joys and hopes and sorrows



<P>Break like ripples on the strand



<P>Of the deep and solemn river



<P>Where her willing feet now stand.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>O my sister, passing from me,



<P>Out of human care and strife,



<P>Leave me, as a gift, those virtues



<P>Which have beautified your life.



<P>Dear, bequeath me that great patience



<P>Which has power to sustain



<P>A cheerful, uncomplaining spirit



<P>In its prison-house of pain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Give me, for I need it sorely,



<P>Of that courage, wise and sweet,



<P>Which has made the path of duty



<P>Green beneath your willing feet.



<P>Give me that unselfish nature,



<P>That with charity devine



<P>Can pardon wrong for love's dear sake--



<P>Meek heart, forgive me mine!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Thus our parting daily loseth



<P>Something of its bitter pain,



<P>And while learning this hard lesson,



<P>My great loss becomes my gain.



<P>For the touch of grief will render



<P>My wild nature more serene,



<P>Give to life new aspirations,



<P>A new trust in the unseen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Henceforth, safe across the river,



<P>I shall see forever more



<P>A beloved, household spirit



<P>Waiting for me on the shore.



<P>Hope and faith, born of my sorrow,



<P>Guardian angels shall become,



<P>And the sister gone before me



<P>By their hands shall lead me home.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Blurred and blotted, faulty and feeble as the lines were, they



<P>brought a look of inexpressible comfort to Beth's face, for her one



<P>regret had been that she had done so little, and this seemed to assure



<P>her that her life had not been useless, that her death would not bring



<P>the despair she feared.&nbsp; As she sat with the paper folded between

her



<P>hands, the charred log fell asunder.&nbsp; Jo started up, revived the

blaze,



<P>and crept to the bedside, hoping Beth slept.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not asleep, but so happy, dear.&nbsp; See, I found this and read it.



<P>I knew you wouldn't care.&nbsp; Have I been all that to you, Jo?" she



<P>asked, with wistful, humble earnestness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"OH, Beth, so much, so much!"&nbsp; And Jo's head went down upon the



<P>pillow beside her sister's.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then I don't feel as if I'd wasted my life.&nbsp; I'm not so good



<P>as you make me, but I have tried to do right.&nbsp; And now, when it's



<P>too late to begin even to do better, it's such a comfort to know



<P>that someone loves me so much, and feels as if I'd helped them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"More than any one in the world, Beth.&nbsp; I used to think I



<P>couldn't let you go, but I'm learning to feel that I don't lose



<P>you, that you'll be more to me than ever, and death can't part



<P>us, though it seems to."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know it cannot, and I don't fear it any longer, for I'm



<P>sure I shall be your Beth still, to love and help you more than



<P>ever.&nbsp; You must take my place, Jo, and be everything to Father



<P>and Mother when I'm gone.&nbsp; They will turn to you, don't fail



<P>them, and if it's hard to work alone, remember that I don't



<P>forget you, and that you'll be happier in doing that than writing



<P>splendid books or seeing all the world, for love is the only thing



<P>that we can carry with us when we go, and it makes the go easy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll try, Beth."&nbsp; And then and there Jo renounced her old



<P>ambition, pledged herself to a new and better one, acknowledging



<P>the poverty of other desires, and feeling the blessed solace of



<P>a belief in the immortality of love.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So the spring days came and went , the sky grew clearer, the



<P>earth greener, the flowers were up fairly early, and the birds



<P>came back in time to say goodbye to Beth, who, like a tired but



<P>trustful child, clung to the hands that had led her all her life,



<P>as Father and Mother guided her tenderly through the Valley of



<P>the Shadow, and gave her up to God.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Seldom except in books do the dying utter memorable words,



<P>see visions, or depart with beatified countenances, and those



<P>who have sped many parting souls know that to most the end



<P>comes as naturally and simply as sleep.&nbsp; As Beth had hoped, the



<P>`tide went out easily', and in the dark hour before dawn, on



<P>the bosom where she had drawn her first breath, she quietly



<P>drew her last, with no farewell but one loving look, one little



<P>sigh.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With tears and prayers and tender hands, Mother and sisters



<P>made her ready for the long sleep that pain would never mar again,



<P>seeing with grateful eyes the beautiful serenity that soon replaced



<P>the pathetic patience that had wrung their hearts so long, and



<P>feeling with reverent joy that to their darling death was a



<P>benignant angel, not a phantom full of dread.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When morning came, for the first time in many months the



<P>fire was out, Jo's place was empty, and the room was very still.



<P>But a bird sang blithely on a budding bough, close by, the snowdrops



<P>blossomed freshly at the window, and the spring sunshine streamed



<P>in like a benediction over the placid face upon the pillow,



<P>a face so full of painless peace that those who loved it best



<P>smiled through their tears, and thanked God that Beth was well at last.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 41</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FORTY-ONE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy's lecture did Laurie good, though, of course, he did



<P>not own it till long afterward.&nbsp; Men seldom do, for when women



<P>are the advisers, the lords of creation don't take the advice



<P>till they have persuaded themselves that it is just what they



<P>intended to do.&nbsp; Then they act upon it, and, if it succeeds,



<P>they give the weaker vessel half the credit of it.&nbsp; If it



<P>fails, they generously give her the whole.&nbsp; Laurie went back



<P>to his grandfather, and was so dutifully devoted for several



<P>weeks that the old gentleman declared the climate of Nice had



<P>improved him wonderfully, and he had better try it again.



<P>There was nothing the young gentleman would have liked better,



<P>but elephants could not have dragged him back after the scolding



<P>he had received.&nbsp; Pride forbid, and whenever the longing



<P>grew very strong, he fortified his resolution by repeating



<P>the words that had made the deepest impression, "I despise you."



<P>"Go and do something splendid that will make her love you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie turned the matter over in his mind so often that he soon



<P>brought himself to confess that he had been selfish and lazy,



<P>but then when a man has a great sorrow, he should be indulged



<P>in all sorts of vagaries till he has lived it down.&nbsp; He felt



<P>that his blighted affections were quite dead now, and though



<P>he should never cease to be a faithful mourner, there was



<P>no occasion to wear his weeds ostentatiously.&nbsp; Jo wouldn't



<P>love him, but he might make her respect and admire him by doing



<P>something which should prove that a girl's no had not spoiled



<P>his life.&nbsp; He had always meant to do something, and Amy's



<P>advice was quite unnecessary.&nbsp; He had only been waiting till



<P>the aforesaid blighted affections were decently interred.



<P>That being done, he felt that he was ready to `hide his



<P>stricken heart, and still toil on'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As Goethe, when he had a joy or a grief, put it into a song,



<P>so Laurie resolved to embalm his love sorrow in music, and to



<P>compose a Requiem which should harrow up Jo's soul and melt the



<P>heart of every hearer.&nbsp; Therefore the next time the old gentleman



<P>found him getting restless and moody and ordered him off,



<P>he went to Vienna, where he had musical friends, and fell to



<P>work with the firm determination to distinguish himself.&nbsp; But



<P>whether the sorrow was too vast to be embodied in music, or



<P>music too ethereal to uplift a mortal woe, he soon discovered



<P>that the Requiem was beyond him just at present.&nbsp; It was evident



<P>that his mind was not in working order yet, and his ideas



<P>needed clarifying, for often in the middle of a plaintive strain,



<P>he would find himself humming a dancing tune that vividly recalled



<P>the Christmas ball at Nice, especially the stout Frenchman,



<P>and put an effectual stop to tragic composition for the time being.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Then he tried an opera, for nothing seemed impossible in



<P>the beginning, but here again unforeseen difficulties beset



<P>him.&nbsp; He wanted Jo for his heroine, and called upon his memory



<P>to supply him with tender recollections and romantic visions



<P>of his love.&nbsp; But memory turned traitor, and as if possessed



<P>by the perverse spirit of the girl, would only recall Jo's



<P>oddities, faults, and freaks, would only show her in the most



<P>unsentimental aspects--beating mats with her head tied up in



<P>a bandana, barricading herself with the sofa pillow, or throwing



<P>cold water over his passion a la Gummidge--and an irresistable



<P>laugh spoiled the pensive picture he was endeavoring to



<P>paint.&nbsp; Jo wouldn't be put into the opera at any price, and he



<P>had to give her up with a "Bless that girl, what a torment she is!"



<P>and a clutch at his hair, as became a distracted composer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When he looked about him for another and a less intractable



<P>damsel to immortalize in melody, memory produced one with the



<P>most obliging readiness.&nbsp; This phantom wore many faces, but it



<P>always had golden hair, was enveloped in a diaphanous cloud, and



<P>floated airily before his mind's eye in a pleasing chaos of roses,



<P>peacocks, white ponies, and blue ribbons.&nbsp; He did not give the



<P>complacent wraith any name, but he took her for his heroine and



<P>grew quite fond of her, as well he might, for he gifted her with



<P>every gift and grace under the sun, and escorted her, unscathed,



<P>through trials which would have annihilated any mortal woman.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Thanks to this inspiration, he got on swimmingly for a time,



<P>but gradually the work lost its charm, and he forgot to compose,



<P>while he sat musing, pen in hand, or roamed about the gay city



<P>to get some new ideas and refresh his mind, which seemed to be



<P>in a somewhat unsettled state that winter.&nbsp; He did not do much,



<P>but he thought a great deal and was conscious of a change of



<P>some sort going on in spite of himself.&nbsp; "It's genius simmering,



<P>perhaps.&nbsp; I'll let it simmer, and see what comes of it," he said,



<P>with a secret suspicion all the while that it wasn't genius, but



<P>something far more common.&nbsp; Whatever it was, it simmered to



<P>some purpose, for he grew more and more discontented with his



<P>desultory life, began to long for some real and earnest work



<P>to go at, soul and body, and finally came to the wise conclusion



<P>that everyone who loved music was not a composer.&nbsp; Returning



<P>from one of Mozart's grand operas, splendidly performed at



<P>the Royal Theatre, he looked over his own, played a few of the



<P>best parts, sat staring at the busts of Mendelssohn, Beethoven,



<P>and bach, who stared benignly back again.&nbsp; Then suddenly he



<P>tore up his music sheets, one by one, and as the last fluttered



<P>out of his hand, he said soberly to himself...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She is right!&nbsp; Talent isn't genius, and you can't make it



<P>so.&nbsp; That music has taken the vanity out of my as Rome took it



<P>out of her, and I won't be a humbug any longer.&nbsp; Now what shall



<P>I do?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That seemed a hard question to answer, and Laurie began to



<P>wish he had to work for his daily bread.&nbsp; Now if ever, occurred



<P>an eligible opportunity for `going to the devil', as he once



<P>forcibly expressed it, for he had plenty of money and nothing



<P>to do, and Satan is proverbially fond of providing employment



<P>for full and idle hands.&nbsp; The poor fellow had temptations



<P>enough from without and from within, but he withstood them



<P>pretty well, for much as he valued liberty, he valued good



<P>faith and confidence more, so his promise to his grandfather,



<P>and his desire to be able to look honestly into the eyes of



<P>the women who loved him, and say "All's well," kept him safe



<P>and steady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Very likely some Mrs. Grundy will observe, "I don't believe it,



<P>boys will be boys, young men must sow their wild oats,



<P>and women must not expect miracles."&nbsp; I dare say you don't,



<P>Mrs. Grundy, but it's true nevertheless.&nbsp; Women work



<P>a good many miracles, and I have a persuasion that they may



<P>perform even that of raising the standard of manhood by



<P>refusing to echo such sayings.&nbsp; Let the boys be boys, the



<P>longer the better, and let the young men sow their wild oats



<P>if they must.&nbsp; But mothers, sisters, and friends may help to



<P>make the crop a small one, and keep many tares from spoiling



<P>the harvest, by believing, and showing that they believe, in



<P>the possibility of loyalty to the virtues which make men manliest



<P>in good women's eyes.&nbsp; If it is a feminine delusion,&nbsp; leave

us



<P>to enjoy it while we may, for without it half the beauty and



<P>the romance of life is lost, and sorrowful forebodings would



<P>embitter all our hopes of the brave, tenderhearted little lads,



<P>who still love their mothers better than themselves and are



<P>not ashamed to own it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie thought that the task of forgetting his love for Jo



<P>would absorb all his powers for years, but to his great surprise



<P>he discovered it grew easier every day.&nbsp; He refused to believe



<P>it at first, got angry with himself, and couldn't understand it,



<P>but these hearts of ours are curious and contrary things, and



<P>time and nature work their will in spite of us.&nbsp; Laurie's heart



<P>wouldn't ache.&nbsp; The wound persisted in healing with a rapidity



<P>that astonished him, and instead of trying to forget, he found



<P>himself trying to remember.&nbsp; He had not foreseen this turn of



<P>affairs, and was not prepared for it.&nbsp; He was disgusted with



<P>himself, surprised at his own fickleness, and full of a



<P>queer mixture of disappointment and relief that he could



<P>recover from such a tremendous blow so soon.&nbsp; He carefully



<P>stirred up the embers of his lost love, but they refused to



<P>burst into a blaze.&nbsp; There was only a comfortable glow that



<P>warmed and did him good without putting him into a fever,



<P>and he was reluctantly obliged to confess that the boyish



<P>passion was slowly subbsiding into a more tranquil sentiment,



<P>very tender, a little sad and resentful still, but that was



<P>sure to pass away in time, leaving a brotherly affection



<P>which would last unbroken to the end.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As the word `brotherly' passed through his mind in one



<P>of his reveries, he smiled, and glanced up at the picture of



<P>Mozart that was before him...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, he was a great man, and when he couldn't have



<P>one sister he took the other, and was happy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie did not utter the words, but he thought them, and



<P>the next instant kissed the little old ring, saying to himself,



<P>"No, I won't!&nbsp; I haven't forgotten, I never can.&nbsp; I'll try

again,



<P>and if that fails, why then...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Leaving his sentence unfinished, he seized pen and paper



<P>and wrote to Jo, telling her that he could not settle to anything



<P>while there was the least hope of her changing her mind.



<P>Couldn't she, wouldn't she, and let him come home and be happy?



<P>While waiting for an answer he did nothing, but he did it



<P>energetically, for he was in a fever of impatience.&nbsp; It came



<P>at last, and settled his mind effectually on one point, for Jo



<P>decidedly couldn't and wouldn't.&nbsp; She was wrapped up in Beth,



<P>and never wished to hear the word love again.&nbsp; Then she begged



<P>him to be happy with somebody else, but always keep a little



<P>corner of his ghart for his loving sister Jo.&nbsp; In a postscript



<P>she desired him not to tell Amy that Beth was worse, she was



<P>coming home in the spring and there was no need of saddening



<P>the remainder of her stay.&nbsp; That would be time enough, please



<P>God, but Laurie must write to her often, and not let her feel



<P>lonely, homesick or anxious.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So I will, at once.&nbsp; Poor little girl, it will be a sad



<P>going home for her, I'm afraid."&nbsp; And Laurie opened his desk,



<P>as if writing to Amy had been the proper conclusion of the



<P>sentence left unfinished some weeks before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But he did not write the letter that day, for as he rummaged



<P>out his best paper, he came across something which



<P>changed his purpose.&nbsp; Tumbling about in one part of the desk



<P>among bills, passports, and business documents of various kinds



<P>were several of Jo's letters, and in another compartment were



<P>three notes from Amy, carefully tied up with one of her blue



<P>ribbons and sweetly suggestive of the little dead roses put



<P>away inside.&nbsp; with a half-repentant, half-amused expression,



<P>Laurie gathered up all Jo's letters, smoothed, folded, and put



<P>them neatly into a small drawer of the desk, stood a minute



<P>turning the ring thoughtfully on his finger, then slowly drew



<P>it off, laid it with the letters, locked the drawer, and went



<P>out to hear High Mass at Saint Stefan's, feeling as if there



<P>had been a funeral, and though not overwhelmed with affliction,



<P>this seemed a more proper way to spend the rest of the day than



<P>in writing letters to charming young ladies.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The letter went very soon, however, and was promptly answered,



<P>for Amy was homesick, and confessed it in the most



<P>delightfully confiding manner.&nbsp; The correspondence flourished



<P>famously, and letters flew to and fro with unfailing regularity



<P>all through the early spring.&nbsp; Laurie sold his busts, made



<P>allumettes of his opera, and went back to Paris, hoping somebody



<P>would arrive before long.&nbsp; He wanted desperately to go



<P>to Nice, but would not till he was asked, and Amy would not



<P>ask him, for just then she was having little experiences of



<P>her own, which made her rather wish to avoid the quizzical



<P>eyes of `out boy'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fred Vaughn had returned, and put the question to which



<P>she had once decided to answer, "Yes, thank you," but now she



<P>said, "No, thank you," kindly but steadily, for when the time



<P>came, her courage failed her, and she found that something



<P>more than money and position was needed to satisfy the new



<P>longing that filled her heart so full of tender hopes and



<P>fears.&nbsp; The words, "Fred is a good fellow, but not at all



<P>the man I fancied you would ever like," and Laurie's face



<P>when he uttered them, kept returning to her as pertinaciously



<P>as her own did when she said in look, if not in words, "I



<P>shall marry for money."&nbsp; It troubled her to remember that



<P>now, she wished she could take it back, it sounded so unwomanly.



<P>She didn't want Laurie to think her a heartless,&nbsp; worldly



<P>creature.&nbsp; She didn't care to be a queen of society now



<P>half so much as she did to be a lovable woman.&nbsp; She was



<P>so glad he didn't hate her for the dreadful things she said,



<P>but took them so beautifully and was kinder than ever.&nbsp; His



<P>letters were such a comfort, for the home letters were very



<P>irregular and not half so satisfactory as his when they did



<P>come.&nbsp; It was not only a pleasure, but a duty to answer them,



<P>for the poor fellow was forlorn, and needed petting, since Jo



<P>persisted in being stonyhearted.&nbsp; She ought to have made an



<P>effort and tried to love him.&nbsp; It couldn't be very hard,



<P>many people would be proud and glad to have such a dear boy



<P>care for them.&nbsp; But Jo never would act like other girls, so



<P>there was nothing to do but be very kind and treat him like



<P>a brother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If all brothers were treated as well as Laurie was at



<P>this period, they would be a much happier race of beings than



<P>they are.&nbsp; Amy never lectured now.&nbsp; She asked his opinion

on



<P>all subjects, she was interested in everything he did, made



<P>charming little presents for him, and sent him two letters



<P>a week, full of lively gossip, sisterly confidences, and



<P>captivating sketches of the lovely scenes about her.&nbsp; As few



<P>brothers are complimented by having their letters carried



<P>about in their sister's pockets, read and reread diligently,



<P>cried over when short, kissed when long, and treasured carefully,



<P>we will not hint that Amy did any of these fond and



<P>foolish things.&nbsp; But she certainly did grow a little pale



<P>and pensive that spring, lost much of her relish for society,



<P>and went out sketching alone a good deal.&nbsp; She never had much



<P>to show when she came home, but was studying nature, I dare



<P>say, while she sat for hours, with her hands folded, on the



<P>terrace at Valrosa, or absently sketched any fancy that



<P>occurred to her, a stalwart knight carved on a tomb, a young



<P>man asleep in the grass, with his hat over his eyes, or a curly



<P>haired girl in gorgeous array, promenading down a ballroom on



<P>the arm of a tall gentleman, both faces being left a blur



<P>according to the last fashion in art, which was safe but not



<P>altogether satisfactory.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her aunt thought that she regretted her answer to Fred,



<P>and finding denials useless and explanations impossible, Amy



<P>left her to think what she liked, taking care that Laurie



<P>should know that Fred had gone to Egypt.&nbsp; That was all, but



<P>he understood it, and looked relieved, as he said to himself,



<P>with a venerable air .&nbsp; ..

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was sure she would think better of it.&nbsp; Poor old fellow!



<P>I've been through it all, and I can sympathize."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With that he heaved a great sigh, and then, as if he had



<P>discharged his duty to the past, put his feet up on the sofa



<P>and enjoyed Amy's letter luxuriously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While these changes were going on abroad, trouble had



<P>come at home.&nbsp; But the letter telling that Beth was failing



<P>never reached Amy, and when the next found her at Vevay, for



<P>the heat had driven them from Nice in May, and they had travelled



<P>slowly to Switzerland, by way of Genoa and the Italian



<P>lakes.&nbsp; She bore it very well, and quietly submitted to the



<P>family decree that she should not shorten her visit, for



<P>since it was too late to say goodbye to Beth, she had better



<P>stay, and let absence soften her sorrow.&nbsp; But her heart was



<P>very heavy, she longed to be at home, and every day looked



<P>wistfully across the lake, waiting for Laurie to come and



<P>comfort her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He did come very soon, for the same mail brought letters



<P>to them both, but he was in Germany, and it took some days to



<P>reach him.&nbsp; The moment he read it, he packed his knapsack,



<P>bade adieu to his fellow pedestrians, and was off to keep his



<P>promise, with a heart full of joy and sorrow, hope and suspense.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He knew Vevay well, and as soon as the boat touched the



<P>little quay, he hurried along the shore to La Tour, where the



<P>Carrols were living en pension.&nbsp; The garcon was in despair



<P>that the whole family had gone to take a promenade on the



<P>lake, but no, the blonde mademoiselle might be in the chateau



<P>garden.&nbsp; If monsier would give himself the pain of sitting



<P>down, a flash of time should present her.&nbsp; But monsieur could



<P>not wait even a `flash of time', and in the middle of the



<P>speech departed to find mademoiselle himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A pleasant old garden on the borders of the lovely lake,



<P>with chestnuts rustling overhead, ivy climbing everywhere, and



<P>the black shadow of the tower falling far across the sunny



<P>water.&nbsp; At one corner of the wide, low wall was a seat, and here



<P>Amy often came to read or work, or console herself with the



<P>beauty all about her.&nbsp; She was sitting here that day, leaning



<P>her head on her hand, with a homesick heart and heavy eyes,



<P>thinking of Beth and wondering why Laurie did not come.&nbsp; She



<P>did not hear him cross the courtyard beyond, nor see him pause



<P>in the archway that led from the subterranean path into the



<P>garden.&nbsp; He stood a minute looking at her with new eyes, seeing



<P>what no one had ever seen before, the tender side of Amy's character.



<P>Everything about her mutely suggested love and sorrow,



<P>the blotted letters in her lap, the black ribbon that tied up



<P>her hair, the womanly pain and patience in her face, even the



<P>little ebony cross at her throat seemed pathetic to Laurie,



<P>for he had given it to her, and she wore it as her only ornament.



<P>If he had any doubts about the reception she would give



<P>him, they were set at rest the minute she looked up and saw



<P>him, for dropping everything, she ran to him, exclaiming in a



<P>tone of unmistakable love and longing...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, Laurie, Laurie, I knew you'd come to me!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I think everything was said and settled then, for as they



<P>stood together quite silent for a moment, with the dark head



<P>bent down protectingly over the light one, Amy felt that no



<P>one could comfort and sustain her so well as Laurie, and



<P>Laurie decided that Amy was the only woman in the world who



<P>could fill Jo's place and make him happy.&nbsp; He did not tell her



<P>so, but she was not disappointed, for both felt the truth,



<P>were satisfied, and gladly left the rest to silence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In a minute Amy went back to her place, and while she



<P>dried her tears, Laurie gathered up the scattered papers,



<P>finding in the sight of sundry well-worn letters and suggestive



<P>sketches good omens for the future.&nbsp; As he sat down beside her,



<P>amy felt shy again, and turned rosy red at the recollection of



<P>her impulsive greeting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I couldn't help it, I felt so lonely and sad, and was so



<P>very glad to see you.&nbsp; It was such a surprise to look up and find



<P>you, just as I was beginning to fear you wouldn't come," she said,



<P>trying in vain to speak quite naturally.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I came the minute I heard.&nbsp; I wish I could say something



<P>to comfort you for the loss of dear little Beth, but I can only



<P>feel, and..."&nbsp; He could not get any further, for her too



<P>turned bashful all of a sudden, and did not quite know what to



<P>say.&nbsp; He longed to lay Amy's head down on his shoulder, and tell



<P>her to have a good cry, but he did not dare, so took her hand



<P>instead, and gave it a sympathetic squeeze that was better than



<P>words.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You needn't say anything, this comforts me," she said



<P>softly.&nbsp; "Beth is well and happy, and I mustn't wish her back,



<P>but I dread the going home, much as I long to see them all.



<P>We won't talk about it now, for it makes me cry, and I want



<P>to enjoy you while you stay.&nbsp; You needn't go right back, need



<P>you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not if you want me, dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do, so much.&nbsp; Aunt and Flo are very kind, but you



<P>seem like one of the family, and it would be so comfortable to



<P>have you for a little while."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy spoke and looked so like a homesick child whose heart



<P>was full that Laurie forgot his bashfulness all at once, and



<P>gave her just what she wanted--the petting she was used to and



<P>the cheerful conversation she needed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor little soul, you look as if you'd grieved yourself



<P>half sick!&nbsp; I'm going to take care of you, so don't cry any



<P>more, but come and walk about with me, the wind is too chilly



<P>for you to sit still," he said, in the half-caressing,



<P>half-commanding way that Amy liked, as he tied on her hat,



<P>drew her arm through his, and began to pace up and down the



<P>sunny walk under the new-leaved chestnuts.&nbsp; He felt more at



<P>ease upon his legs, and Amy found it pleasant to have a strong



<P>arm to lean upon, a familiar face to smile at her, and a kind



<P>voice to talk delightfully for her alone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The quaint old garden had sheltered many pairs of lovers,



<P>and seemed expressly made for them, so sunny and secluded was



<P>it, with nothing but the tower to overlook them, and the wide



<P>lake to carry away the echo of their words, as it rippled by



<P>below.&nbsp; For an hour this new pair walked and talked, or rested



<P>on the wall, enjoying the sweet influences which gave such a



<P>charm to time and place, and when an unromantic dinner bell



<P>warned them away, Amy felt as if she left her burden of



<P>lonliness and sorrow behind her in the chateau garden.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The moment Mrs. Carrol saw the girl's altered face, she



<P>was illuminated with a new idea, and exclaimed to herself,



<P>"Now I understand it all--the child has been pining for young



<P>Laurence.&nbsp; Bless my heart, I never thought of such a thing!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With praiseworthy discretion, the good lady said nothing,



<P>and betrayed no sign of enlightenment, but cordially urged



<P>Laurie to stay and begged Amy to enjoy his society, for it



<P>would do her more good than so much solitude.&nbsp; Amy was a



<P>model of docility, and as her aunt was a good deal occupied



<P>with Flo, she was left to entertain her friend, and did it



<P>with more than her usual success.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At Nice, Laurie had lounged and Amy had scolded.&nbsp; At



<P>Vevay, Laurie was never idle, but always walking, riding,



<P>boating, or studying in the most energetic manner, while



<P>Amy admired everything he did and followed his example as



<P>far and as fast as she could.&nbsp; He said the change was owing



<P>to the climate, and she did not contradict him, being glad



<P>of a like excuse for her own recovered health and spirits.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The invigorating air did them both good, and much exercise



<P>worked wholesome changes in minds as well as bodies.



<P>They seemed to get clearer views of life and duty up there



<P>among the everlasting hills.&nbsp; The fresh winds blew away



<P>desponding doubts, delusive fancies, and moody mists.&nbsp; The



<P>warm spring sunshine brought out all sorts of aspiring ideas,



<P>tender hopes, and happy thoughts.&nbsp; The lake seemed to wash



<P>away the troubles of the past, and the grand old mountains



<P>to look benignly down upon them saying, "Little children,



<P>love one another."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In spite of the new sorrow, it was a very happy time, so



<P>happy that Laurie could not bear to disturb it by a word.&nbsp; It



<P>took him a little while to recover from his surprise at the



<P>cure of his first, and as he had firmly believed, his last



<P>and only love.&nbsp; He consoled himself for the seeming disloyalty



<P>by the thought that Jo's sister was almost the same as Jo's



<P>self, and the conviction that it would have been impossible



<P>to love any other woman but Amy so soon and so well.&nbsp; His first



<P>wooing had been of the tempestuous order, and he looked back



<P>upon ;it as if through a long vista of years with a feeling of



<P>compassion blended with regret.&nbsp; He was not ashamed of it,



<P>but put it away as one of the bitter-sweet experiences of his



<P>life, for which he could be grateful when the pain was over.



<P>His second wooing, he resolved, should be as calm and simple



<P>as possible.&nbsp; There was no need of having a scene, hardly



<P>any need of telling Amy that he loved her, she knew it without



<P>words and had given him his answer long ago.&nbsp; It all came



<P>about so naturally that no one could complain, and he knew that



<P>everybody would be pleased, even Jo.&nbsp; But when our first little



<P>passion has been crushed, we are apt to be wary and slow in making



<P>a second trial, so Laurie let the days pass, enjoying every hour,



<P>and leaving to chance the utterance of the word that would



<P>put an end to the first and sweetest part of his new romance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had rather imagined that the denoument would take place



<P>in the chateau garden by moonlight, and in the most graceful and



<P>decorus manner, but it turned out exactly the reverse, for the



<P>matter was settled on the lake at noonday in a few blunt words.



<P>They had been floating about all the morning, from gloomy



<P>St. Gingolf to sunny Montreux, with the Alps of Savoy on one side,



<P>Mont St. Bernard and the Dent du Midi on the other, pretty Vevay in



<P>the valley, and Lausanne upon the hill beyond, a cloudless blue



<P>sky overhead, and the bluer lake below, dotted with the picturesque



<P>boats that look like white-winged gulls.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They had been talking of Bonnivard, as they glided past



<P>Chillon, and of Rousseau, as they looked up at Clarens, where he



<P>wrote his Heloise.&nbsp; Neither had read it, but they knew it was a



<P>love story, and each privately wondered if it was half as interesting



<P>as their own.&nbsp; Amy had been dabbling her hand in the water



<P>during the little pause that fell between them, and when she looked



<P>up, Laurie was leaning on his oars with an expression in his eyes



<P>that made her say hastily, merely for the sake of saying something .&nbsp;

.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must be tired.&nbsp; Rest a little, and let me row.&nbsp; It will

do me good,



<P>for since you came I have been altogether lazy and luxurious."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm not tired, but you may take an oar, if you like.&nbsp; There's



<P>room enough, though I have to sit nearly in the middle, else the



<P>boat won't trim," returned Laurie, as if he rather liked the arrangment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Feeling that she had not mended matters much, Amy took the



<P>offered third of a seat, shook her hair over her face, and accepted



<P>an oar.&nbsp; She rowed as well as she did many other things, and though



<P>she used both hands, and Laurie but one, the oars kept time, and



<P>the boat went smoothly through the water.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How well we pull together, don't we?" said Amy, who objected



<P>to silence just then.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So well that I wish we might always pull in the same boat.



<P>Will you, Amy?" very tenderly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Laurie," very low.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Then they both stopped rowing, and unconsciously added a



<P>pretty little tableau of human love and happiness to the dissolving



<P>views reflected in the lake.



<P>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FORTY-THREE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo was alone in the twilight, lying on the old sofa, looking



<P>at the fire, and thinking.&nbsp; It was her favorite way of spending



<P>the hour of dusk.&nbsp; No one disturbed her, and she used to lie



<P>there on Beth's little red pillow, planning stories, dreaming



<P>dreams, or thinking tender thoughts of the sister who never seemed



<P>far away.&nbsp; Her face looked tired, grave, and rather sad, for tomorrow



<P>was her birthday, and she was thinking how fast the years



<P>went by, how old she was getting, and how little she seemed to



<P>have accomplished.&nbsp; Almost twenty-five, and nothing to show for



<P>it.&nbsp; Jo was mistaken in that.&nbsp; There was a good deal to show,



<P>and by-and-by she saw, and was grateful for it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"An old maid, that's what I'm to be.&nbsp; A literary spinster,



<P>with a pen for a spouse, a family of stories for children, and



<P>twenty years hence a morsel of fame, perhaps, when, like poor



<P>Johnson, I'm old and can't enjoy it, solitary, and can't share



<P>it, independent, and don't need it.&nbsp; Well, I needn't be a sour



<P>saint nor a selfish sinner, and, I dare say, old maids are very



<P>comfortable when they get used to it, but..."&nbsp; And there Jo



<P>sighed, as if the prospect was not inviting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It seldom is, at first, and thirty seems the end of all things



<P>to five-and-twenty.&nbsp; But it's not as bad as it looks, and one can



<P>get on quite happily if one has something in one's self to fall



<P>back upon.&nbsp; At twenty-five, girls begin to talk about being old



<P>maids, but secretly resolve that they never will be.&nbsp; At thirty



<P>they say nothing about it, but quietly accept the fact, and if



<P>sensible, console themselves by remembering that they have twenty



<P>more useful, happy years, in which they may be learning to grow



<P>old gracefully.&nbsp; Don't laugh at the spinsters, dear girls, for



<P>often very tender, tragic romances are hidden away in the hearts



<P>that beat so quietly under the sober gowns, and many silent sacrifices



<P>of youth, health, ambition, love itself, make the faded faces



<P>beautiful in God's sight.&nbsp; Even the sad, sour sisters should



<P>be kindly dealt with, because they have missed the sweetest



<P>part of life, if for no other reason.&nbsp; And looking at them



<P>with compassion, not contempt, girls in their bloom should remember



<P>that they too may miss the blossom time.&nbsp; That rosy cheeks



<P>don't last forever, that silver threads will come in the bonnie



<P>brown hair, and that, by-and-by, kindness and respect will be as



<P>sweet as love and admiration now.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Gentlemen, which means boys, be courteous to the old maids,



<P>no matter how poor and plain and prim, for the only chivalry



<P>worth having is that which is the readiest to pay deference to



<P>the old, protect the feeble, and serve womankind, regardless of



<P>rank, age, or color.&nbsp; Just recollect the good aunts who have not



<P>only lectured and fussed, but nursed and petted, too often without



<P>thanks, the scrapes they have helped you out of, the tips



<P>they have given you from their small store, the stitches the



<P>patient old fingers have set for you, the steps the willing old



<P>feet have taken, and gratefully pay the dear old ladies the little



<P>attentions that women love to receive as long as they live.&nbsp; The



<P>bright-eyed girls are quick to see such traits, and will like you



<P>all the better for them, and if death, almost the only power that



<P>can part mother and son, should rob you of yours, you will be sure



<P>to find a tender welcome and maternal cherishing from some Aunt



<P>Priscilla, who has kept the warmest corner of her lonely old heart



<P>for `the best nevvy in the world'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo must have fallen asleep (as I dare say my reader has during



<P>this little homily), for suddenly Laurie's ghost seemed to



<P>stand before her, a substantial, lifelike ghost, leaning over her



<P>with the very look he used to wear when he felt a good deal and



<P>didn't like to show it.&nbsp; But, like Jenny in the ballad...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She could not think it he,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>and lay staring up at him in startled silence, till he stooped



<P>and kissed her.&nbsp; Then she knew him, and flew up, crying joyfully

.&nbsp; ..

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh my Teddy!&nbsp; Oh my Teddy!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear Jo, you are glad to see me, then?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Glad!&nbsp; My blessed boy, words can't express my gladness.



<P>Where's Amy?"



<P>"Your mother has got her down at Meg's.&nbsp; We stopped there by



<P>the way, and there was no getting my wife out of their clutches."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your what?" cried Jo, for Laurie uttered those two words



<P>with an unconscious pride and satisfaction which betrayed him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, the dickens!&nbsp; Now I've done it."&nbsp; And he looked so



<P>guilty that Jo was down on him like a flash.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You've gone and got married!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, please, but I never will again."&nbsp; And he went down



<P>upon his knees, with a penitent clasping of hands, and a face



<P>full of mischief, mirth, and triumph.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Actually married?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very much so, thank you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mercy on us.&nbsp; What dreadful thing will you do next?" And



<P>Jo fell into her seat with a gasp.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A characteristic, but not exactly complimentary, congratulation,"



<P>returned Laurie, still in an abject attitude, but beaming



<P>with satisfaction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What can you expect, when you take one's breath away, creeping



<P>in like a burglar, and letting cats out of bags like that? Get



<P>up, you ridiculous boy, and tell me all about it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a word, unless you let me come in my old place, and



<P>promise not to barricade."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo laughed at that as she had not done for many a long day,



<P>and patted the sofa invitingly, as she said in a cordial tone,



<P>"The old pillow is up garret, and we don't need it now.&nbsp; So, come



<P>and fess, Teddy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How good it sounds to hear you say `Teddy'! No one ever calls



<P>me that but you."&nbsp; And Laurie sat down with an air of great content.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What does Amy call you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My lord."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's like her.&nbsp; Well, you look it."&nbsp; And Jo's eye plainly



<P>betrayed that she found her boy comelier than ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The pillow was gone, but there was a barricade, nevertheless,



<P>a natural one, raised by time absence, and change of heart.&nbsp; Both



<P>felt it, and for a minute looked at one another as if that invisible



<P>barrier cast a little shadow over them.&nbsp; It was gone directly



<P>however, for Laurie said, with a vain attempt at dignity...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't I look like a married man and the head of a family?"



<P>"Not a bit, and you never will.&nbsp; You've grown bigger and



<P>bonnier, but you are the same scapegrace as ever."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now really, Jo, you ought to treat me with more respect,"



<P>began Laurie, who enjoyed it all immensely.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How can I, when the mere idea of you, married and settled,



<P>is so irresistibly funny that I can't keep sober!" answered Jo,



<P>smiling all over her face, so infectiously that they had another



<P>laugh, and then settled down for a good talk, quite in the pleasant



<P>old fashion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's no use your going out in the cold to get Amy, for



<P>they are all coming up presently.&nbsp; I couldn't wait.&nbsp; I wanted

to



<P>be the one to tell you the grand surprise, and have `first skim'



<P>as we used to say when we squabbled about the cream."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course you did, and spoiled your story by beginning at



<P>the wrong end.&nbsp; Now, start right, and tell me how it all happened.



<P>I'm pining to know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I did it to please Amy," began Laurie, with a twinkle



<P>that made Jo exclaim...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Fib number one.&nbsp; Amy did it to please you.&nbsp; Go on, and tell



<P>the truth, if you can, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now she's beginning to marm it.&nbsp; Isn't it jolly to hear her?"



<P>said Laurie to the fire, and the fire glowed and sparkled as if it



<P>quite agreed.&nbsp; "It's all the same, you know, she and I being one.



<P>We planned to come home with the Carrols, a month or more ago, but



<P>they suddenly changed their minds, and decided to pass another



<P>winter in Paris.&nbsp; But Grandpa wanted to come home.&nbsp; He went

to please



<P>me, and I couldn't let him go along, neither could I leave Amy, and



<P>Mrs. Carrol had got English notions about chaperons and such nonsense,



<P>and wouldn't let Amy come with us.&nbsp; So I just settled the difficulty



<P>by saying, `Let's be married, and then we can do as we like'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course you did.&nbsp; You always have things to suit you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not always."&nbsp; And something in Laurie's voice made Jo say



<P>hastily...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How did you ever get Aunt to agree?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was hard work, but between us, we talked her over, for we



<P>had heaps of good reasons on our side.&nbsp; There wasn't time to write



<P>and ask leave, but you all liked it, had consented to it by-and-by,



<P>and it was only `taking time by the fetlock', as my wife says."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aren't we proud of those two word, and don't we like to say



<P>them?" interrupted Jo, addressing the fire in her turn, and watching



<P>with delight the happy light it seemed to kindle in the eyes



<P>that had been so tragically gloomy when she saw them last.



<P>"A trifle, perhaps, she's such a captivating little woman I



<P>can't help being proud of her.&nbsp; Well, then Uncle and Aunt were



<P>there to play propriety.&nbsp; We were so absorbed in one another we



<P>were of no mortal use apart, and that charming arrangement would



<P>make everything easy all round, so we did it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When, where, how?" asked Jo, in a fever of feminine interest



<P>and curiosity, for she could not realize it a particle.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Six weeks ago, at the American consul's, in Paris, a very



<P>quiet wedding of course, for even in our happiness we didn't forget



<P>dear little Beth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo put her hand in his as he said that, and Laurie gently



<P>smoothed the little red pillow, which he remembered well.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why didn't you let us know afterward?" asked Jo, in a



<P>quieter tone, when they had sat quite still a minute.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We wanted to surprise you.&nbsp; We thought we were coming



<P>directly home, at first, but the dear old gentleman, as soon as



<P>we were married, found he couldn't be ready under a month, at



<P>least, and sent us off to spend our honeymoon wherever we liked.



<P>Amy had once called Valrosa a regular honeymoon home, so we went



<P>there, and were as happy as people are but once in their lives.



<P>My faith!&nbsp; Wasn't it love among the roses!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie seemed to forget Jo for a minute, and Jo was glad of



<P>it, for the fact that he told her these things so freely and so



<P>naturally assured her that he had quite forgiven and forgotten.



<P>She tried to draw away her hand, but as if he guessed the thought



<P>that prompted the half-involuntary impulse, Laurie held it fast,



<P>and said, with a manly gravity she had never seen in him before...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo, dear, I want to say one thing, and then we'll put it by



<P>forever.&nbsp; As I told you in my letter when I wrote that Amy had



<P>been so kind to me, I never shall stop loving you, but the love



<P>is altered, and I have learned to see that it is better as it is.



<P>Amy and you changed places in my heart, that's all.&nbsp; I think it



<P>was meant to be so, and would have come about naturally, if I had



<P>waited, as you tried to make me, but I never could be patient, and



<P>so I got a heartache.&nbsp; I was a boy then, headstrong and violent,



<P>and it took a hard lesson to show me my mistake.&nbsp; For it was one,



<P>Jo, as you said, and I found it out, after making a fool of myself.



<P>Upon my word, I was so tumbled up in my mind, at one time, that I



<P>didn't know which I loved best, you or Amy, and tried to love you



<P>both alike.&nbsp; But I couldn't, and when I saw her in Switzerland,



<P>everything seemed to clear up all at once.&nbsp; You both got into



<P>your right places, and I felt sure that it was well off with the



<P>old love before it was on with the new, that I could honestly



<P>share my heart between sister Jo and wife Amy, and love them dearly.



<P>Will you believe it, and go back to the happy old times when we



<P>first knew one another?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll believe it, with all my heart, but, Teddy, we never can



<P>be boy and girl again.&nbsp; The happy old times can't come back, and

we



<P>mustn't expect it.&nbsp; We are man and woman now, with sober work to

do,



<P>for playtime is over, and we must give up frolicking.&nbsp; I'm sure

you



<P>feel this.&nbsp; I see the change in you, and you'll find it in me.&nbsp;

I



<P>shall miss my boy, but I shall love the man as much, and admire



<P>him more, because he means to be what I hoped he would.&nbsp; We can't



<P>be little playmates any longer, but we will be brother and sister,



<P>to love and help one another all our lives, won't we, Laurie?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He did not say a word, but took the hand she offered him, and



<P>laid his face down on it for a minute, feeling that out of the



<P>grave of a boyish passion, there had risen a beautiful, strong



<P>friendship to bless them both.&nbsp; Presently Jo said cheerfully, for



<P>she didn't the coming home to be a sad one, "I can't make it true



<P>that you children are really married and going to set up housekeeping.



<P>Why, it seems only yesterday that I was buttoning Amy's pinafore,



<P>and pulling your hair when you teased.&nbsp; Mercy me, how time does

fly!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As one of the children is older than yourself, you needn't



<P>talk so like a grandma.&nbsp; I flatter myself I'm a `gentleman growed'



<P>as Peggotty said of David, and when you see Amy, you'll find her



<P>rather a precocious infant," said Laurie, looking amused at her



<P>maternal air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You may be a little older in years, but I'm ever so much



<P>older in feeling, Teddy.&nbsp; Women always are, and this last year

has



<P>been such a hard one that I feel forty."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor Jo!&nbsp; We left you to bear it alone, while we went pleasuring.



<P>You are older.&nbsp; Here's a line, and there's another.&nbsp; Unless

you smile,



<P>your eyes look sad, and when I touched the cushion, just now,



<P>I found a tear on it.&nbsp; You've had a great deal to bear,



<P>and had to bear it all alone.&nbsp; What a selfish beast I've been!"



<P>And Laurie pulled his own hair, with a remorseful look.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Jo only turned over the traitorous pillow, and answered,



<P>in a tone which she tried to make more cheerful, "No, I had Father



<P>and Mother to help me, and the dear babies to comfort me, and the



<P>thought that you and Amy were safe and happy, to make the troubles



<P>here easier to bear.&nbsp; I am lonely, sometimes, but I dare say it's



<P>good for me, and..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You never shall be again," broke in Laurie, putting his arm



<P>about her, as if to fence out every human ill.&nbsp; "Amy and I can't



<P>get on without you, so you must come and teach `the children' to



<P>keep house, and go halves in everything, just as we used to do,



<P>and let us pet you, and all be blissfully happy and friendly

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I shouldn't be in the way, it would be very pleasant.&nbsp; I



<P>begin to feel quite young already, for somehow all my troubles



<P>seemed to fly away when you came.&nbsp; You always were a comfort, Teddy."



<P>And Jo leaned her head on his shoulder, just as she did years ago,



<P>when Beth lay ill and Laurie told her to hold on to him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He looked down at her, wondering if she remembered the time,



<P>but Jo was smiling to herself, as if in truth her troubles had



<P>all vanished at his coming.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are the same Jo still, dropping tears about one minute,



<P>and laughing the next.&nbsp; You look a little wicked now.&nbsp; What

is it,



<P>Grandma?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was wondering how you and Amy get on together."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Like angels!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, of course, but which rules?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't mind telling you that she does now, at least I let



<P>her think so, it pleases her, you know.&nbsp; By-and-by we shall take



<P>turns, for marriage, they say, halves one's rights and doubles



<P>one's duties."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'll go on as you begin, and Amy will rule you all the



<P>days of your life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, she does it so imperceptibly that I don't think I shall



<P>mind much.&nbsp; She is the sort of woman who knows how to rule well.&nbsp;

In



<P>fact, I rather like it, for she winds one round her finger as softly



<P>and prettily as a skein of silk, and makes you feel as if she was



<P>doing you a favor all the while."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That ever I should live to see you a henpecked husband and



<P>enjoying it!" cried Jo, with uplifted hands.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was good to see Laurie square his shoulders, and smile with



<P>masculine scorn at that insinuation, as he replied, with his "high



<P>and mighty" air, "Amy is too well-bred for that, and I am not the



<P>sort of man to submit to it.&nbsp; My wife and I respect ourselves and



<P>one another too much ever to tyrannize or quarrel."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo like that, and thought the new dignity very becoming, but



<P>the boy seemed changing very fast into the man, and regret mingled



<P>with her pleasure.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am sure of that.&nbsp; Amy and you never did quarrel as we used to.



<P>She is the sun and I the wind, in the fable, and the sun managed



<P>the man best, you remember."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She can blow him up as well as shine on him," laughed Laurie.



<P>"such a lecture as I got at Nice!&nbsp; I give you my word it was a

deal



<P>worse than any or your scoldings, a regular rouser.&nbsp; I'll tell

you



<P>all about it sometime, she never will, because after telling me that



<P>she despised and was ashamed of me, she lost her heart to the despicable



<P>party and married the good-for-nothing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What baseness!&nbsp; Well, if she abuses you, come to me, and I'll



<P>defend you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I look as if I needed it, don't I?" said Laurie, getting up



<P>and striking an attitude which suddenly changed from the imposing



<P>to the rapturous, as Amy's voice was heard calling, "Where is she?



<P>Where's my dear old Jo?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In trooped the whole family, and everyone was hugged and kissed



<P>all over again, and after several vain attempts, the three wanderers



<P>were set down to be looked at and exulted over.&nbsp; Mr. Laurence,

hale



<P>and hearty as ever, was quite as much improved as the others by his



<P>foreign tour, for the crustiness seemed to be nearly gone, and the



<P>old-fashioned courtliness had received a polish which made it kindlier



<P>than ever.&nbsp; It was good to see him beam at `my children', as he



<P>called the young pair.&nbsp; It was better still to see Amy pay him



<P>the daughterly duty and affection which completely won his old heart,



<P>and best of all, to watch Laurie revolve about the two, as if never



<P>tired of enjoying the pretty picture they made.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The minute she put her eyes upon Amy, Meg became conscious that



<P>her own dress hadn't a Parisian air, that young Mrs. Mofffat would be



<P>entirely eclipsed by young Mrs. Laurence, and that `her ladyship' was



<P>altogether a most elegant and graceful woman.&nbsp; Jo thought, as she



<P>watched the pair, "How well they look together!&nbsp; I was right, and



<P>Laurie has found the beautiful, accomplished girl who will become



<P>his home better than clumsy old Jo, and be a pride, not a torment to



<P>him."&nbsp; Mrs. March and her husband smiled and nodded at each other



<P>with happy faces, for they saw that their youngest had done well,



<P>not only in worldly things, but the better wealth of love, confidence,



<P>and happiness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For Amy's face was full of the soft brightness which betokens



<P>a peaceful heart, her voice had a new tenderness in it, and the cool,



<P>prim carriage was changed to a gentle dignity, both womanly and winning.



<P>No little affectations marred it, and the cordial sweetness



<P>of her manner was more charming than the new beauty or the old grace,



<P>for it stamped her at once with the unmistakable sign of the true



<P>gentlewoman she had hoped to become.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Love has done much for our little girl," said her mother softly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She has had a good example before her all her life, my dear,"



<P>Mr. March whispered back, with a loving look at the worn face and gray



<P>head beside him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Daisy found it impossible to keep her eyes off her `pitty aunty',



<P>but attached herself like a lap dog to the wonderful chatelaine full



<P>of delightful charms.&nbsp; Demi paused to consider the new relationship



<P>before he compromised himself by the rash acceptance of a bribe, which



<P>took the tempting form of a family of wooden bears from Berne.&nbsp;

A flank



<P>movement produced an unconditional surrender, however, for Laurie knew



<P>where to have him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Young man, when I first had the honor of making your acquaintance



<P>you hit me in the face.&nbsp; Now I demand the satisfaction of a gentleman,"



<P>and with that the tall uncle proceeded to toss and tousle the small

nephew



<P>in a way that damaged his philosophical dignity as much as it delighted



<P>his boyish soul.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Blest if she ain't in silk from head to foot?&nbsp; Ain't it a relishin'



<P>sight to see her settin' there as fine as a fiddle, anch a happy



<P>procession as filed away into the little dining room!&nbsp; Mr. March



<P>proudly escorted Mrs. Laurence.&nbsp; Mrs. March as proudly leaned on



<P>the arm of `my son'.&nbsp; The old gentleman took Jo, with a whispered,



<P>"You must be my girl now," and a glance at the empty corner by the



<P>fire, that made Jo whisper back, "I'll try to fill her place, sir.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The twins pranced behind, feeling that the millennium was at



<P>hand, for everyone was so busy with the newcomers that they were



<P>left to revel at their own sweet will, and you may be sure they



<P>made the most of the opportunity.&nbsp; Didn't they steal sips of tea,



<P>stuff gingerbread ad libitum, get a hot biscuit apiece, and as a



<P>crowning trespass, didn't they each whisk a captivating little tart



<P>into their tiny pockets, there to stick and crumble treacherously,



<P>teaching them that both human nature and a pastry are frail?



<P>Burdened with the guilty consciousness of the sequestered tarts,



<P>and fearing that Dodo's sharp eyes would pierce the thin disguise of



<P>cambric and merino which hid their booty, the little sinners



<P>attached themselves to `Dranpa', who hadn't his spectacles on.&nbsp;

Amy,



<P>who was handed about like refreshments, returned to the parlor on



<P>Father Laurence's arm.&nbsp; The others paired off as before, and this



<P>arrangement left Jo companionless.&nbsp; She did not mind it at the



<P>minute, for she lingered to answer Hannah's eager inquiry.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Will Miss Amy ride in her coop (coupe), and use all them



<P>lovely silver dishes that's stored away over yander?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shouldn't wonder if she drove six white horses, ate off gold



<P>plate, and wore diamonds and point lace every day.&nbsp; Teddy thinks



<P>nothing too good for her," returned Jo with infinite satisfaction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No more there is!&nbsp; Will you have hash or fishballs for breakfast?"



<P>asked Hannah, who wisely mingled poetry and prose.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't care."&nbsp; And Jo shut the door, feeling that food was an



<P>uncongenial topic just then.&nbsp; She stood a minute looking at the



<P>party vanishing above, and as Demi's short plaid legs toiled up the



<P>last stair, a sudden sense of lonliness came over her so strongly



<P>that she looked about her with dim eyes, as if to find something to



<P>lean upon, for even Teddy had deserted her.&nbsp; If she had known what



<P>birthday gift was coming every minute nearer and nearer, she would



<P>not have said to herself, "I'll weep a little weep when I go to bed.



<P>It won't do to be dismal now."&nbsp; Then she drew her hand over her

eyes,



<P>for one of her boyish habits was never to know where her



<P>handkerchief was, and had just managed to call up a smile when



<P>there came a knock at the porch door.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She opened with hospitable haste, and started as if another



<P>ghost had come to surprise her, for there stood a tall bearded



<P>gentleman, beaming on her from the darkness like a midnight sun.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, Mr. Bhaer, I am so glad to see you!" cried Jo, with a



<P>clutch, as if she feared the night would swallow him up before



<P>she could get him in.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I to see Miss Marsch, but no, you haf a party," and the



<P>Professor paused as the sound of voices and the tap of dancing



<P>feet came down to them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, we haven't, only the family.&nbsp; My sister and friends



<P>have just come home, and we are all very happy.&nbsp; Come in, and



<P>make one of us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Though a very social man, I think Mr. Bhaer would have gone



<P>decorously away, and come again another day, but how could he,



<P>when Jo shut the door behind him, and bereft him of his hat?



<P>Perhaps her face had something to do with it, for she forgot



<P>to hide her joy at seeing him, and showed it with a frankness



<P>that proved irresistible to the solitary man, whose welcome far



<P>exceeded his boldest hopes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I shall not be Monsieur de Trop, I will so gladly see



<P>them all.&nbsp; You haf been ill, my friend?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He put the question abruptly, for, as Jo hung up his coat,



<P>the light fell on her face, and he saw a change in it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not ill, but tired and sorrowful.&nbsp; We have had trouble



<P>since I saw you last."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah, yes, I know.&nbsp; My heart was sore for you when I heard



<P>that," And he shook hands again, with such a sympathetic face



<P>that Jo felt as if no comfort could equal the look of the kind



<P>eyes, the grasp of the big, warm hand.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Father, Mother, this is my friend, Professor Bhaer," she



<P>said, with a face and tone of such irrepressible pride and



<P>pleasure that she might as well have blown a trumpet and opened



<P>the door with a flourish.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If the stranger had any doubts about his reception, they



<P>were set at rest in a minute by the cordial welcome he received.



<P>Everyone greeted him kindly, for Jo's sake at first, but very



<P>soon they liked him for his own.&nbsp; They could not help it, for



<P>he carried the talisman that opens all hearts, and these simple



<P>people warmed to him at once, feeling even the more friendly



<P>because he was poor.&nbsp; For poverty enriches those who live above



<P>it, and is a sure passport to truly hospitable spirits.&nbsp; Mr.



<P>Bhaer sat looking about him with the air of a traveler who



<P>knocks at a strange door, and when it opens, finds himself at



<P>home.&nbsp; The children went to him like bees to a honeypot, and



<P>establishing themselves on each knee, proceeded to captivate him



<P>by rifling his pockets, pulling his beard, and investigating his



<P>watch, with juvenile audacity.&nbsp; The women telegraphed their



<P>approval to one another, and Mr. March, feeling that he had got



<P>a kindred spirit, opened his choicest stores for his guest's



<P>benefit, while silent John listened and enjoyed the talk, but



<P>said not a word, and Mr. Laurence found it impossible to go to



<P>sleep.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If Jo had not been otherwise engaged, Laurie's behavior



<P>would have amused her, for a faint twinge, not of jealousy, but



<P>something like suspicion, caused that gentleman to stand aloof



<P>at first, and observe the newcomer with brotherly circumspection.



<P>But it did not last long.&nbsp; He got interested in spite of himself,



<P>and before he knew it, was drawn into the circle.&nbsp; For Mr. Bhaer



<P>talked well in this genial atmosphere, and did himself justice.



<P>He seldom spoke to Laurie, but he looked at him often, and a



<P>shadow would pass across his face, as if regretting his own lost



<P>youth, as he watched the young man in his prime.&nbsp; Then his eyes



<P>would turn to Jo so wistfully that she would have surely answered



<P>the mute inquiry if she had seen it.&nbsp; But Jo had her own eyes to



<P>take care of, and feeling that they could not be trusted, she



<P>prudently kept them on the little sock she was knitting, like a



<P>model maiden aunt.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A stealthy glance now and then refreshed her like sips of



<P>fresh water after a dusty walk, for the sidelong peeps showed



<P>her several propitious omens.&nbsp; Mr. Bhaer's face had lost the



<P>absent-minded expression, and looked all alive with interest in



<P>the present moment, actually young and handsome, she thought,



<P>forgetting to compare him with Laurie, as she usually did strange



<P>men, to their great detriment.&nbsp; Then he seemed quite inspired,



<P>though the burial customs of the ancients, to which the conversation



<P>had strayed, might not be considered an exhilarating topic.



<P>Jo quite glowed with triumph when Teddy got quenched in



<P>an argument, and thought to herself, as she watched her father's



<P>absorbed face, "How he would enjoy having such a man as my Professor



<P>to talk with every day!"&nbsp; Lastly, Mr. Bhaer was dressed



<P>in a new suit of black, which made him look more like a gentleman



<P>than ever.&nbsp; His bushy hair had been cut and smoothly brushed, but



<P>didn't stay in order long, for in exciting moments, he rumpled



<P>it up in the droll way he used to do, and Jo liked it rampantly



<P>erect better than flat, because she thought it gave his fine



<P>forehead a Jove-like aspect.&nbsp; Poor Jo, how she did glorify that



<P>plain man, as she sat knitting away so quietly, yet letting



<P>nothing escape her, not even the fact that Mr. Bhaer actually



<P>had gold sleeve-buttons in his immaculate wristbands.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear old fellow!&nbsp; He couldn't have got himself up with



<P>more care if he'd been going a-wooing," said Jo to herself, and



<P>then a sudden thought born of the words made her blush so dreadfully



<P>that she had to drop her ball, and go down after it to hide her face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The maneuver did not succeed as well as she expected, however,



<P>for though just in the act of setting fire to a funeral



<P>pyre, the Professor dropped his torch, metaphorically speaking,



<P>and made a dive after the little blue ball.&nbsp; Of course they



<P>bumped their heads smartly together, saw stars, and both came



<P>up flushed and laughing, without the ball, to resume their seats,



<P>wishing they had not left them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nobody knew where the evening went to, for Hannah skillfully



<P>abstracted the babies at an early hour, nodding like two rosy



<P>poppies, and Mr. Laurence went home to rest.&nbsp; The others sat



<P>round the fire, talking away, utterly regardless of the lapse



<P>of time, till Meg, whose maternal was impressed with a firm conviction



<P>that Daisy had tumbled out of be, and Demi set his nightgown



<P>afire studying the structure of matches, made a move to go.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We must have our sing, in the good old way, for we are all



<P>together again once more," said Jo, feeling that a good shout



<P>would be a safe and pleasant vent for the jubilant emotions of



<P>her soul.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were not all there.&nbsp; But no one found the words thougtless



<P>or untrue, for Beth still seemed among them, a peaceful presence,



<P>invisible, but dearer than ever, since death could not break



<P>the household league that love made disoluble.&nbsp; The little



<P>chair stood in its old place.&nbsp; The tidy basket, with the bit of
