<P>work she left unfinished when the needle grew `so heavy', was



<P>still on its accustomed shelf.&nbsp; The beloved instrument, seldom



<P>touched now had not been moved, and above it Beth's face, serene



<P>and smiling, as in the early days, looked down upon them, seeming



<P>to say, "Be happy.&nbsp; I am here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Play something, Amy.&nbsp; Let them hear how much you have improved,"



<P>said Laurie, with pardonable pride in his promising pupil.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Amy whispered, with full eyes, as she twirled the faded



<P>stool, "Not tonight, dear.&nbsp; I can't show off tonight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But she did show something better than brilliancy or skill,



<P>for she sang Beth's songs with a tender music in her voice which



<P>the best master could not have taught, and touched the listener's



<P>hearts with a sweeter power than any other inspiration could have



<P>given her.&nbsp; The room was very still, when the clear voice failed



<P>suddenly at the last line of Beth's favorite hymn.&nbsp; It was hard



<P>to say...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Earth hath no sorrow that heaven cannot heal;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>and Amy leaned against her husband, who stood behind her, feeling



<P>that her welcome home was not quite perfect without Beth's kiss.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, we must finish with Mignon's song, for Mr. Bhaer sings



<P>that," said Jo, before the pause grew painful.&nbsp; And Mr. Bhaer



<P>cleared his throat with a gratified "Hem!" as he stepped into the



<P>corner where Jo stood, saying...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You will sing with me?&nbsp; We go excellently well together."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A pleasing fiction, by the way, for Jo had no more idea of



<P>music than a grasshopper.&nbsp; But she would have consented if he had



<P>proposed to sing a whole opera, and warbled away, blissfully regardless



<P>of time and tune.&nbsp; It didn't much matter, for Mr. Bhaer



<P>sang like a true German, heartily and well, and Jo soon subsided



<P>into a subdued hum, that she might listen to the mellow voice that



<P>seemed to sing for her alone.



<P>Know'st thou the land where the citron blooms,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>used to be the Professor's favorite line, for `das land' meant



<P>Germany to him, but now he seemed to dwell, with peculiar warmth



<P>and melody, upon the words...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There, oh there, might I with thee,



<P>O, my beloved, go

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>and one listener was so thrilled by the tender invitation that she



<P>longed to say she did know the land, and would joyfully depart



<P>thither whenever he liked



<P>The song was considered a great success, and the singer retired



<P>covered with laurels.&nbsp; But a few minutes afterward, he forgot his



<P>manners entirely, and stared at Amy putting on her bonnet, for she



<P>had been introduced simply as `my sister', and on one had called



<P>her by her new name since her came.&nbsp; He forgot himself still further



<P>when Laurie said, in his most gracious manner, at parting...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My wife and I are very glad to meet you, sir.&nbsp; Please remember



<P>that there is always a welcome waiting for you over the way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Then the Professor thanked him so heartily, and looked so



<P>suddenly illuminated with satisfaction, that Laurie thought him



<P>the most delightfully demonstrative old fellow he ever met.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I too shall go, but I shall gladly come again, if you will



<P>gif me leave, dear madame, for a little business in the city will



<P>keep me here some days."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He spoke to Mrs. March, but he looked at Jo, and the mother's



<P>voice gave as cordial an assent as did the daughter's eyes, for



<P>Mrs. March was not so blind to her children's interest as Mrs.



<P>Moffat supposed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I suspect that is a wise man," remarked Mr. March, with



<P>placid satisfaction, from the hearthrug, after the last guest had



<P>gone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know he is a good one," added Mrs. March, with decided



<P>approval, as she wound up the clock.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought you'd like him," was all Jo said, as she slipped



<P>away to her bed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She wondered what the business was that brought Mr. Bhaer to



<P>the city, and finally decided that he had been appointed to some



<P>great honor, somewhere, but had been too modest to mention the



<P>fact.&nbsp; If she had seen his face when, safe in his own room, he



<P>looked at the picture of a severe and rigid young lady, with a



<P>good deal of hair, who appeared to be gazing darkly into futurity,



<P>it might have thrown some light upon the subject, especially when



<P>he turned off the gas, and kissed the picture in the dark.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 42</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FORTY-TWO</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was easy to promise self-abnegation when self was



<P>wrapped up in another, and heart and soul were purified by a



<P>sweet example.&nbsp; But when the helpful voice was silent, the



<P>daily lesson over, the beloved presence gone, and nothing remained



<P>but lonliness and grief, then Jo found her promise very



<P>hard to keep.&nbsp; How could she `comfort Father and Mother' when



<P>her own heart ached with a ceaseless longing for her sister,



<P>how could she `make the house cheerful' when all its light and



<P>warmth and beauty seemed to have deserted it when Beth left the



<P>old home for the new, and where in all the world could she `find



<P>some useful, happy work to do', that would take the place of the



<P>loving service which had been its own reward?&nbsp; She tried in a



<P>blind, hopeless way to do her duty, secretly rebelling against



<P>it all the while, for it seemed unjust that her few joys should



<P>be lessened, her burdens made heavier, and life get harder and



<P>harder as she toiled along.&nbsp; Some people seemed to get all sunshine,



<P>and some all shadow.&nbsp; It was not fair, for she tried more



<P>than Amy to be good, but never got any reward, only disappointment,



<P>trouble and hard work.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Jo, these were dark days to her, for something like



<P>despair came over her when she thought of spending all her life



<P>in that quiet house, devoted to humdrum cares, a few small pleasures,



<P>and the duty that never seemed to grow any easier.&nbsp; "I can't do

it.



<P>I wasn't meant for a life like this, and I know I shall break away



<P>and do something desperate if somebody doesn't come and help me,"



<P>she said to herself, when her first efforts failed and she fell



<P>into the moody, miserable state of mind which often comes when



<P>strong wills have to yield to the inevitable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But someone did come and help her, though Jo did not recognize



<P>her good angels at once because they wore familiar shapes and used



<P>the simple spells best fitted to poor humanity.&nbsp; Often she started



<P>up at night, thinking Beth called her, and when the sight of the



<P>little empty bed made her cry with the bitter cry of unsubmissive



<P>sorrow, "Oh, Beth, come back!&nbsp; Come back!" she did not stretch

out



<P>her yearning arms in vain.&nbsp; For, as quick to hear her sobbing as



<P>she had been to hear her sister's faintest whisper, her mother came



<P>to comfort her, not with words only, but the patient tenderness



<P>that soothes by a touch, tears that were mute reminders of a greater



<P>grief than Jo's, and broken whispers, more eloquent than prayers,



<P>because hopeful resignation went hand-in-hand with natural sorrow.



<P>Sacred moments, when heart talked to heart in the silence of the



<P>night, turning affliction to a blessing, which chastened grief and



<P>strengthned love.&nbsp; Feeling this, Jo's burden seemed easier to bear,



<P>duty grew sweeter, and life looked more endurable, seen from the



<P>safe shelter of her mother's arms.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When aching heart was a little comforted, troubled mind likewise



<P>found help, for one day she went to the study, and leaning



<P>over the good gray head lifted to welcome her with a tranquil smile,



<P>she said very humbly, "Father, talk to me as you did to Beth.&nbsp;

I



<P>need it more than she did, for I'm all wrong."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear, nothing can comfort me like this," he answered,



<P>with a falter in his voice, and both arms round her, as if he too,



<P>needed help, and did not fear to ask for it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Then, sitting in Beth's little chair close beside him, Jo told



<P>her troubles, the resentful sorrow for her loss, the fruitless



<P>efforts that discouraged her, the want of faith that made life look



<P>so dark, and all the sad bewilderment which we call despair.&nbsp; She



<P>gave him entire confidence, he gave her the help she needed, and



<P>both found consolation in the act.&nbsp; For the time had come when

they



<P>could talk together not only as father and daughter, but as man and



<P>woman, able and glad to serve each other with mutual sympathy as well



<P>as mutual love.&nbsp; Happy, thoughtful times there in the old study

which



<P>Jo called `the church of one member', and from which she came with



<P>fresh courage, recovered cheerfulness, and a more submissive spirit.



<P>For the parents who had taught one child to meet death without fear,



<P>were trying now to teach another to accept life without despondency



<P>or distrust, and to use its beautiful opportunities with gratitude



<P>and power.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Other helps had Jo--humble, wholesome duties and delights that



<P>would not be denied their part in serving her, and which she slowly



<P>learned to see and value.&nbsp; Brooms and dishcloths never could



<P>be as distasteful as they once had been, for Beth had presided



<P>over both, and something of her housewifely spirit seemed to



<P>linger around the little mop and the old brush, never thrown



<P>away.&nbsp; As she used them, Jo found herself humming the songs



<P>Beth used to hum, imitating Beth's orderly ways, and giving the



<P>little touches here and there that kept everything fresh and



<P>cozy, which was the first step toward making home happy, though



<P>she didn't know it till Hannah said with an approving squeeze



<P>of the hand...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You thoughtful creeter, you're determined we shan't miss



<P>that dear lamb ef you can help it.&nbsp; We don't say much, but we



<P>see it, and the Lord will bless you for't, see ef He don't."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As they sat sewing together, Jo discovered how much improved



<P>her sister Meg was, how well she could talk, how much she knew



<P>about good, womanly impulses, thoughts, and feelings, how happy



<P>she was in husband and children, and how much they were all doing



<P>for each other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Marriage is an excellent thing, after all.&nbsp; I wonder if I



<P>should blossom out half as well as you have, if I tried it?" said



<P>Jo, as she constructed a kite for Demi in the topsy-turvy nursery.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's just what you need to bring out the tender womanly half



<P>of your nature, Jo.&nbsp; You are like a chestnut burr, prickly outside,



<P>but silky-soft within, and a sweet kernal, if one can only get at



<P>it.&nbsp; Love will make you show your heart one day, and then the rough



<P>burr will fall off."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Frost opens chestnut burrs, ma`am, and it takes a good shake



<P>to bring them down.&nbsp; Boys go nutting, and I don't care to be bagged



<P>by them," returned Jo, pasting away at the kite which no wind that



<P>blows would ever carry up, for Daisy had tied herself on as a bob.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg laughed, for she was glad to see a glimmer of Jo's old



<P>spirit, but she felt it her duty to enforce her opinion by every



<P>argument in her power, and the sisterly chats were not wasted, especially



<P>as two of Meg's most effective arguments were the babies,



<P>whom Jo loved tenderly.&nbsp; Grief is the best opener of some hearts,



<P>and Jo's was nearly ready for the bag.&nbsp; A little more sunshine

to



<P>ripen the nut, then, not a boy's impatient shake, but a man's hand



<P>reached up to pick it gently from the burr, and find the kernal



<P>sound and sweet.&nbsp; If she suspected this, she would have shut up



<P>tight, and been more prickly than ever, fortunately she wasn't



<P>thinking about herself, so when the time came, down she dropped.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now, if she had been the heroine of a moral storybook, she



<P>ought at this period of her life to have become quite saintly,



<P>renounced the world, and gone about doing good in a mortified



<P>bonnet, with tracts in her pocket.&nbsp; But, you see, Jo wasn't a



<P>heroine, she was only a struggling human girl like hundreds of



<P>others, and she just acted out her nature, being sad, cross, listless,



<P>or energetic, as the mood suggested.&nbsp; It's highly virtuous



<P>to say we'll be good, but we can't do it all at once, and it takes



<P>a long pull, a strong pull, and a pull all together before some



<P>of us even get our feet set in the right way.&nbsp; Jo had got so far,



<P>she was learning to do her duty, and to feel unhappy if she did



<P>not, but to do it cheerfully, ah, that was another thing!&nbsp; She



<P>had often said she wanted to do something splendid, no matter how



<P>hard, and now she had her wish, for what could be more beautiful



<P>than to devote her life to Father and Mother, trying to make home



<P>as happy to them as they had to her?&nbsp; And if difficulties were



<P>necessary to increase the splendor of the effort, what could be



<P>harder for a restless, ambitious girl than to give up her own



<P>hopes, plans, and desires, and cheerfully live for others?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Providence had taken her at her word.&nbsp; Here was the task, not



<P>what she had expected, but better because self had no part in it.



<P>Now, could she do it?&nbsp; She decided that she would try, and in her



<P>first attempt she found the helps I have suggested.&nbsp; Still another



<P>was given her, and she took it, not as a reward, but as a comfort,



<P>as Christian took the refreshment afforded by the little arbor



<P>where he rested, as he climbed the hill called Difficulty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why don't you write?&nbsp; That always used to make you happy,"



<P>said her mother once, when the desponding fit over-shadowed Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've no heart to write, and if I had, nobody cares for my



<P>things."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We do.&nbsp; Write something for us, and never mind the rest of



<P>the world.&nbsp; Try it, dear.&nbsp; I'm sure it would do you good,

and



<P>please us very much."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't believe I can."&nbsp; But Jo got out her desk and began to



<P>overhaul her half-finished manuscripts.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>An hour afterward her mother peeped in and there she was,



<P>scratching away, with her black pinafore on, and an absorbed expression,



<P>which caused Mrs. March to smile and slip away, well pleased



<P>with the success of her suggestion.&nbsp; Jo never knew how it



<P>happened, but something got into that story that went straight to



<P>the hearts of those who read it, for when her family had laughed



<P>and cried over it, her father sent it, much against her will, to



<P>one of the popular magazines, and to her utter surprise, it was



<P>not only paid for, but others requested.&nbsp; Letters from several



<P>persons, whose praise was honor, followed the appearance of the



<P>little story, newspapers copied it, and strangers as well as friends,



<P>admired it.&nbsp; For a small thing it was a great success, and Jo was



<P>more astonished than when her novel was commended and condemned



<P>all at once.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't understand it.&nbsp; What can there be in a simple little



<P>story like that to make people praise it so?" she said, quite bewildered.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is truth in it, Jo, that's the secret.&nbsp; Humor and pathos



<P>make it alive, and you have found your style at last.&nbsp; You wrote



<P>with not thoughts of fame and money, and put your heart into it,



<P>my daughter.&nbsp; You have had the bitter, now comes the sweet.&nbsp;

Do



<P>your best, and grow as happy as we are in your success."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If there is anything good or true in what I write, it isn't



<P>mine.&nbsp; I owe it all to you and Mother and Beth," said Jo, more



<P>touched by her father's words than by any amount of praise from



<P>the world.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So taught by love and sorrow, Jo wrote her little stories,



<P>and sent them away to make friends for themselves and her, finding



<P>it a very charitable world to such humble wanderers, for they were



<P>kindly welcomed, and sent home comfortable tokens to their mother,



<P>like dutiful children whom good fortune overtakes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When Amy and Laurie wrote of their engagement, Mrs. March



<P>feared that Jo would find it difficult to rejoice over it, but



<P>her fears were soon set at rest, for thought Jo looked grave at



<P>first, she took it very quietly, and was full of hopes and plans



<P>for `the children' before she read the letter twice.&nbsp; It was a



<P>sort of written duet, wherein each glorified the other in loverlike



<P>fashion, very pleasant to read and satisfactory to think of,



<P>for no one had any objection to make.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You like it, Mother?" said Jo, as they laid down the closely



<P>written sheets and looked at one another.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I hoped it would be so, ever since Amy wrote that she



<P>had refused Fred.&nbsp; I felt sure then that something better than



<P>what you call the `mercenary spirit' had come over her, and a



<P>hint here and there in her letters made me suspect that love



<P>and Laurie would win the day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How sharp you are, Marmee, and how silent!&nbsp; You never said



<P>a worked to me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mothers have need of sharp eyes and discreet tongues when



<P>they have girls to manage.&nbsp; I was half afraid to put the idea



<P>into your head, lest you should write and congratulate them before



<P>the thing was settled."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm not the scatterbrain I was.&nbsp; You may trust me.&nbsp; I'm



<P>sober and sensible enough for anyone's confidante now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So you are, my dear, and I should have made you mine,



<P>only I fancied it might pain you to learn that your Teddy loved



<P>someone else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Mother, did you really think I could be so silly and



<P>selfish, after I'd refused his love, when it was freshest, if not



<P>best?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I knew you were sincere then, Jo, but lately I have thought



<P>that if he came back, and asked again, you might perhaps, feel like



<P>giving another answer.&nbsp; Forgive me, dear, I can't help seeing that



<P>you are very lonely, and sometimes there is a hungry look in your



<P>eyes that goes to my heart.&nbsp; So I fancied that your boy might fill



<P>the empty place if he tried now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, Mother, it is better as it ia, and I'm glad Amy has learned



<P>to love him.&nbsp; But you are right in one thing.&nbsp; I am lonely,

and perhaps



<P>if Teddy had tried again, I might have said `Yes', not because



<P>I love him any more, but because I care more to be loved than when



<P>he went away."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad of that, Jo, for it shows that you are getting on.



<P>There are plenty to love you, so try to be satisfied with Father



<P>and Mother, sisters and brothers, friends and babies, till the



<P>best lover of all comes to give you your reward."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mothers are the best lovers in the world, but I don't mind



<P>whispering to Marmee that I'd like to try all kinds.&nbsp; It's very



<P>curious, but the more I try to satisfy myself with all sorts of



<P>natural affections, the more I seem to want.&nbsp; I'd no idea hearts



<P>could take in so many.&nbsp; Mine is so elastic, it never seems full



<P>now, and I used to be quite contented with my family.&nbsp; I don't



<P>understand it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do."&nbsp; And Mrs. March smiled her wise smile, as Jo turned



<P>back the leaves to read what Amy said of Laurie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is so beautiful to be loved as Laurie loves me.&nbsp; He isn't



<P>sentimental, doesn't say much about it, but I see and feel it in



<P>all he says and does, and it makes me so happy and so humble that



<P>I don't seem to be the same girl I was.&nbsp; I never knew how good

and



<P>generous and tender he was till now, for he lets me read his heart,



<P>and I find it full of noble impulses and hopes and purposes, and



<P>am so proud to know it's mine.&nbsp; He says he feels as if he `could



<P>make a prosperous voyage now with me aboard as mate, and lots of



<P>love for ballast'.&nbsp; I pray he may, and try to be all he believes



<P>me, for I love my gallant captain with all my heart and soul and



<P>might, and never will desert him, while God lets us be together.



<P>Oh, Mother, I never knew how much like heaven this world could be,



<P>when two people love and live for one another!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And that's our cool, reserved, and worldly Amy!&nbsp; Truly, love



<P>does work miracles.&nbsp; How very, very happy they must be!"&nbsp;

And Jo



<P>laid the rustling sheets together with a careful hand, as one



<P>might shut the covers of a lovely romance, which holds the reader



<P>fast till the end comes, and he finds himself alone in the workaday



<P>world again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By-and-by Jo roamed away upstairs, for it was rainy, and she



<P>could not walk.&nbsp; A restless spirit possessed her, and the old



<P>feeling came again, not bitter as it once was, but a sorrowfully



<P>patient wonder why one sister should have all she asked, the other



<P>nothing.&nbsp; It was not true, she knew that and tried to put it away,



<P>but the natural craving for affection was strong, and Amy's happiness



<P>woke the hungry longing for someone to `love with heart



<P>and soul, and cling to while God let them be together'.



<P>Up in the garret, where Jo's unquiet wanderings ended stood



<P>four little wooden chests in a row, each marked with its owners



<P>name, and each filled with relics of the childhood and girlhood



<P>ended now for all.&nbsp; Jo glanced into them, and when she came to



<P>her own, leaned her chin on the edge, and stared absently at the



<P>chaotic collection, till a bundle of old exercise books caught



<P>her eye.&nbsp; She drew them out, turned them over, and relived that



<P>pleasant winter at kind Mrs. Kirke's.&nbsp; She had smiled at first,



<P>then she looked thoughtful, next sad, and when she came to a



<P>little message written in the Professor's hand, her lips began



<P>to tremble, the books slid out of her lap, and she sat looking



<P>at the friendly words, as they took a new meaning, and touched



<P>a tender spot in her heart.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Wait for me, my friend.&nbsp; I may be a little late, but I shall



<P>surely come."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, if he only would!&nbsp; So kine, so good, so patient with me



<P>always, my dear old Fritz.&nbsp; I didn't value him half enough when

I



<P>had him, but now how I should love to see him, for everyone seems



<P>going away from me, and I'm all alone."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And holding the little paper fast, as if it were a promise



<P>yet to be fulfilled, Jo laid her head down on a comfortable rag



<P>bag, and cried, as if in opposition to the rain pattering on the



<P>roof.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Was it all self-pity, loneliness, or low spirits?&nbsp; Or was it



<P>the waking up of a sentiment which had bided its time as patiently



<P>as its inspirer?&nbsp; Who shall say?



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 46</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FORTY-SIX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While Laurie and Amy were taking conjugal strolls over velvet



<P>carpets, as they set their house in order, and planned a blissful



<P>future, Mr. Bhaer and Jo were enjoying promenades of a different



<P>sort, along muddy roads and sodden fields.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I always do take a walk toward evening, and I don't know



<P>why I should give it up, just because I happen to meet the Professor



<P>on his way out," said Jo to herself, after two or three



<P>encounters, for though there were two paths to Meg's whichever



<P>one she took she was sure to meet him., either going or returning.



<P>He was always walking rapidly, and never seemed to see her



<P>until quite close, when he would look as if his short-sighted



<P>eyes had failed to recognize the approaching lady till that



<P>moment.&nbsp; Then, if she was going to Meg's he always had something



<P>for the babies.&nbsp; If her face was turned homeward, he had merely



<P>strolled down to see the river, and was just returning, unless



<P>they were tired of his frequent calls.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Under the circumstances, what could Jo do but greet him



<P>civilly, and invite him in?&nbsp; If she was tired of his visits, she



<P>concealed her weariness with perfect skill, and took care that



<P>there should be coffee for supper, "as Friedrich--I mean Mr.



<P>Bhaer--doesn't like tea."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By the second week, everyone knew perfectly well what was



<P>going on, yet everyone tried to look as if they were stone-blind



<P>to the changes in Jo's face.&nbsp; They never asked why she sang about



<P>her work, did up her hair three times a day, and got so blooming



<P>with her evening exercise.&nbsp; And no one seemed to have the slightest



<P>suspicion that Professor Bhaer, while talking philosophy with



<P>the father, was giving the daughter lessons in love.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo couldn't even lose her heart in a decorous manner, but



<P>sternly tried to quench her feelings, and failing to do so, led



<P>a somewhat agitated life.&nbsp; She was mortally afraid of being laughed



<P>at for surrendering, after her many and vehement declarations of



<P>independence.&nbsp; Laurie was her especial dread, but thanks to the



<P>new manager, he behaved with praiseworthy propriety, never called



<P>Mr. Bhaer `a capital old fellow' in public, never alluded, in the



<P>remotest manner, to Jo's improved appearance, or expressed the



<P>least surprise at seeing the Professor's hat on the Marches' table



<P>nearly every evening.&nbsp; But he exulted in private and longed for



<P>the time to come when he could give Jo a piece of plate, with a



<P>bear and a ragged staff on it as an appropriate coat of arms.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For a fortnight, the Professor came and went with lover-like



<P>regularity.&nbsp; Then he stayed away for three whole days, and made



<P>no sign, a proceeding which caused everybody to look sober, and



<P>Jo to become pensive, at first, and then--alas for romance--very



<P>cross.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Disgusted, I dare say, and gone home as suddenly as he came.



<P>It's nothing tome, of course, but I should think he would have



<P>come and bid us goodbye like a gentleman," she said to herself,



<P>with a despairing look at the gate, as she put on her things for



<P>the customary walk one dull afternoon.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'd better take the little umbrella, dear.&nbsp; It looks like



<P>rain," said her mother, observing that she had on her new bonnet,



<P>but not alluding to the fact.



<P>"Yes, Marmee, do you want anything in town?&nbsp; I've got to



<P>run in and get some paper," returned Jo, pulling out the bow



<P>under her chin before the glass as an excuse for not looking at



<P>her mother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I want some twilled silesia, a paper of number nine



<P>needles, and two yards of narrow lavender ribbon.&nbsp; Have you got



<P>your thick boots on, and something warm under your cloak?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I believe so," answered Jo absently.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you happen to meet Mr. Bhaer, bring him home to tea.



<P>I quite long to see the dear man," added Mrs. March.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo heard that, but made no answer, except to kiss her mother,



<P>and walk rapidly away, thinking with a glow of gratitude, in spite



<P>of her heartache, "How good she is to me! What do girls do who



<P>haven't any mothers to help them through their troubles?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The dry-goods stores were not down among the counting-houses,



<P>banks, and wholesale warerooms, where gentlemen most do congregate,



<P>but Jo found herself in that part of the city before she did a



<P>single errand, loitering along as if waiting for someone, examining



<P>engineering instruments in one window and samples of wool in



<P>another, with most unfeminine interest, tumbling over barrels,



<P>being half-smothered by descending bales, and hustled unceremoniously



<P>by busy men who looked as if they wondered `how the deuce



<P>she got there'.&nbsp; A drop of rain on her cheek recalled her thoughts



<P>from baffled hopes to ruined ribbons.&nbsp; For the drops continued

to



<P>fall, and being a woman as well as a lover, she felt that, though



<P>it was too late to save her heart, she might her bonnet.&nbsp; Now she



<P>remembered the little umbrella, which she had forgotten to take



<P>in her hurry to be off, but regret was unavailing, and nothing



<P>could be done but borrow one or submit to to a drenching.&nbsp; She



<P>looked up at the lowering sky, down at the crimson bow already



<P>flecked with black, forward along the muddy street, then one



<P>long, lingering look behind, at a certain grimy warehouse, with



<P>`Hoffmann, Swartz, &amp; Co.' over the door, and said to herself,



<P>with a sternly reproachful air...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It serves me right! what business had I to put on all my



<P>best things and come philandering down here, hoping to see the



<P>Professor?&nbsp; Jo, I'm ashamed of you!&nbsp; No, you shall not go

there



<P>to borrow an umbrella, or find out where he is, from his friends.



<P>You shall trudge away, and do your errands in the rain, and if



<P>you catch your death and ruin your bonnet, it's no more than



<P>you deserve.&nbsp; Now then!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With that she rushed across the street so impetuously that she



<P>narrowly escaped annihilation from a passing truck, and precipitated



<P>herself into the arms of a stately old gentleman, who said,



<P>"I beg pardon, ma'am," and looked mortally offended.&nbsp; Somewhat



<P>daunted, Jo righted herself, spread her handkerchief over



<P>the devoted ribbons, and putting temptation behind her, hurried on,



<P>with increasing dampness about the ankles, and much clashing of



<P>umbrellas overhead.&nbsp; The fact that a somewhat dilapidated blue



<P>one remained stationary above the unprotected bonnet attracted



<P>her attention, and looking up, she saw Mr. Bhaer looking down.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I feel to know the strong-minded lady who goes so bravely



<P>under many horse noses, and so fast through much mus.&nbsp; What do



<P>you down here, my friend?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm shopping."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Bhaer smiled, as he glanced from the pickle factory on



<P>one side to the wholesale hide and leather concern on the other,



<P>but her only said politely, "You haf no umbrella.&nbsp; May I go also,



<P>and take for you the bundles?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, thank you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo's cheeks were as red as her ribbon, and she wondered what



<P>he thought of her, but she didn't care, for in a minute she found



<P>herself walking away arm in arm with her Professor, feeling as if



<P>the sun had suddenly burst out with uncommon brilliancy, that



<P>the world was all right again, and that one thoroughly happy woman



<P>was paddling through the wet that day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We thought you had gone," said Jo hastily, for she knew he



<P>was looking at her.&nbsp; Her bonnet wasn't big enough to hide her face,



<P>and she feared he might think the joy it betrayed unmaidenly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did you believe that I should go with no farewell to those



<P>who haf been so heavenly kind tome?" he asked so reproachfully



<P>that she felt as if she had insulted him by the suggestion, and



<P>answered heartily...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I didn't.&nbsp; I knew you were busy about your own affairs,



<P>but we rather missed you, Father and Mother especially."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm always glad to see you, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In her anxiety to keep her voice quite calm, Jo made it rather



<P>cool, and the frosty little monosyllable at the end seemed to chill



<P>the Professor, for his smile vanished, as he said gravely...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thank you, and come one more time before I go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are going, then?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I haf no longer any business here, it is done."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Successfully, I hope?" said Jo, for the bitterness of disappointment



<P>was in that short reply of his.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I ought to think so, for I haf a way opened to me by which



<P>I can make my bread and gif my Junglings much help."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tell me, please!&nbsp; I like to know all about the--the boys,"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>said Jo eagerly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is so kind, I gladly tell you.&nbsp; My friends find for me



<P>a place in a college, where I teach as at home, and earn enough



<P>to make the way smooth for Franz and Emil.&nbsp; For this I should be



<P>grateful, should I not?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed you should.&nbsp; How splendid it will be to have you



<P>doing what you like, and be able to see you often, and the boys!"



<P>cried Jo, clinging to the lads as an excuse for the satisfaction



<P>she could not help betraying.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!&nbsp; But we shall not meet often, I fear, this place is at



<P>the West."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So far away!"&nbsp; And Jo left her skirts to their fate, as if



<P>it didn't matter now what became of her clothes or herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Bhaer could read several languages, but he had not



<P>learned to read women yet.&nbsp; He flattered himself that he knew



<P>Jo pretty well, and was, therefore, much amazed by the contradictions



<P>of voice, face, and manner, which she showed him in rapid



<P>succession that day, for she was in half a dozen different



<P>moods in the course of half an hour.&nbsp; When she met him she looked



<P>surprised, though it was impossible to help suspecting that she



<P>had come for that express purpose.&nbsp; When he offered her his arm,



<P>she took it with a look that filled him with delight, but when



<P>he asked if she missed him, she gave such a chilly, formal reply



<P>that despair fell upon him.&nbsp; On learning his good fortune she



<P>almost clapped her hands.&nbsp; Was the joy all for the boys?&nbsp;

Then



<P>on hearing his destination, she said, "So far away!" in a tone



<P>of despair that lifted him on to a pinnacle of hope, but the



<P>next minute she tumbled him down again by observing, like one



<P>entirely absorbed in the matter...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here's the place for my errands.&nbsp; Will you come in? It



<P>won't take long."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo rather prided herself upon her shopping capabilities,



<P>and particularly wished to impress her escort with the neatness



<P>and dispatch with which she would accomplish the business.



<P>But owing to the flutter she was in, everything went amiss.



<P>She upset the tray of needles, forgot the silesia was to be



<P>`twilled' till it was cut off, gave the wrong change, and



<P>covered herself with confusion by asking for lavender ribbon



<P>at the calico counter.&nbsp; Mr. Bhaer stood by, watching her blush



<P>and blunder, and as he watched, his own bewilderment seemed to



<P>subside, for he was beginning to see that on some occasions,



<P>women, like dreams, go by contraries.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When they came out, he put the parcel under his arm with



<P>a more cheerful aspect, and splashed through the puddles as if



<P>he rather enjoyed it on the whole.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Should we no do a little what you call shopping for the



<P>babies, and haf a farewell feast tonight if I go for my last



<P>call at your so pleasant home?" he asked, stopping before a



<P>window full of fruit and flowers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What will we buy?" asked Jo, ignoring the latter part of



<P>his speech, and sniffing the mingled odors with an affectation



<P>of delight as they went in.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"May they haf oranges and figs?" asked Mr. Bhaer, with a



<P>paternal air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They eat them when they can get them."



<P>"Do you care for nuts?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Like a squirrel."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hamburg grapes.&nbsp; Yes, we shall drink to the Fatherland in



<P>those?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo frowned upon that piece of extravagance, and asked why



<P>he didn't buy a frail of dated, a cask of raisins, and a bag of



<P>almonds, and be done with it?&nbsp; Whereat Mr. Bhaer confiscated her



<P>purse, produced his own, and finished the marketing by buying



<P>several pounds of grapes, a pot of rosy daisies, and a pretty



<P>jar of honey, to be regarded in the light of a demijohn.&nbsp; Then



<P>distorting his pockets with knobby bundles, and giving her the



<P>flowers to hold, he put up the old umbrella, and they traveled



<P>on again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Marsch, I haf a great favor to ask of you," began the



<P>Professor, after a moist promenade of half a block.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sir." And Jo's heart began to beat so hard she was



<P>afraid he would hear it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am bold to say it in spite of the rain, because so short



<P>a time remains to me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sir."&nbsp; And Jo nearly crushed the small flowerpot with



<P>the sudden squeeze she gave it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish to get a little dress for my Tina, and I am too stupid



<P>to go alone.&nbsp; Will you kindly gif me a word of taste and help?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sir." And JO felt as calm and cool all of a sudden as if



<P>she had stepped into a refrigerator.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps also a shawl for Tina's mother, she is so poor and sick,



<P>and the husband is such a care.&nbsp; Yes, yes, a thick, warm shawl



<P>would be a friendly thing to take the little mother."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll do it with pleasure, Mr. Bhaer.&nbsp; I'm going very fast,



<P>and he's getting dearer every minute," added Jo to herself, then



<P>with a mental shake she entered into the business with an energy



<P>that was pleasant to behold.



<P>Mr. Bhaer left it all to her, so she chose a pretty gown for



<P>Tina, and then ordered out the shawls.&nbsp; The clerk, being a married



<P>man, condescended to take an interest in the couple, who appeared



<P>to be shopping for their family.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your lady may prefer this.&nbsp; It's a superior article, a most



<P>desirable color, quite chaste and genteel," he said, shaking out



<P>a comfortable gray shawl, and throwing it over Jo's shoulders.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Does this suit you, Mr. Bhaer?" she asked, turning her



<P>back to him, and feeling deeply grateful for the chance of hiding



<P>her face.



<P>"Excellently well, we will haf it," answered the Professor,



<P>smiling to himself as he paid for it, while Jo continued to



<P>rummage the counters like a confirmed bargain-hunter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now shall we go home?" he asked, as if the words were



<P>very pleasant to him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, it's late, and I'm so tired." Jo's voice was more



<P>pathetic than she knew.&nbsp; For now the sun seemed to have gone



<P>in as suddenly as it came out, and the world grew muddy and



<P>miserable again, and for the first time she discovered that her



<P>feet were cold, her head ached, and that her heart was colder



<P>than the former, fuller of pain than the latter.&nbsp; Mr. Bhaer



<P>was going away, he only cared for her as a friend, it was all



<P>a mistake, and the sooner it was over the better.&nbsp; With this



<P>idea in her head, she hailed an approaching omnibus with such



<P>a hasty gesture that the daisies flew out of the pot and were



<P>badly damaged.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is not our omniboos," said the Professor, waving the



<P>loaded vehicle away, and stopping to pick up the poor little



<P>flowers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I beg your pardon.&nbsp; I didn't see the name distinctly.&nbsp; Never



<P>mind, I can walk.&nbsp; I'm used to plodding in the mud," returned Jo,



<P>winking hard, because she would have died rather than openly



<P>wipe her eyes.



<P>Mr. Bhaer saw the drops on her cheeks, though she turned her



<P>head away.&nbsp; The sight seemed to touch him very much, for suddenly



<P>stooping down, he asked in a tone that meant a great deal, "Heart's



<P>dearest, why do you cry?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now, if Jo had not been new to this sort of thing she would



<P>have said she wasn't crying, had a cold in her head, or told



<P>any other feminine fib proper to the occasion.&nbsp; Instead of which,



<P>that undignified creature answered, with an irrepressible sob,



<P>"Because you are going away."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ach, mein Gott, that is so good!" cried Mr. Bhaer, managing



<P>to clasp his hands in spite of the umbrella and the bundles,



<P>"Jo, I haf nothing but much love to gif you.&nbsp; I came to see if



<P>you could care for it, and I waited to be sure that I was something



<P>more than a friend.&nbsp; Am I?&nbsp; Can you make a little place in

your



<P>heart for old Fritz?" he added, all in one breath.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, yes!" said Jo, and he was quite satisfied, for she



<P>folded both hands over his are, and looked up at him with an



<P>expression that plainly showed how happy she would be to walk



<P>through life beside him, even though she had no better shelter



<P>than the old umbrella, if he carried it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was certainly proposing under difficulties, for even if



<P>he had desired to do so, Mr. Bhaer could not go down upon his



<P>knees, on account of the mud.&nbsp; Neither could he offer Jo his



<P>hand, except figuratively, for both were full.&nbsp; Much less could



<P>he indulge in tender remonstrations in the open street, though



<P>he was near it.&nbsp; So the only way in which he could express his



<P>rapture was to look at her, with an expression which glorified



<P>his face to such a degree that there actually seemed to be



<P>little rainbows in the drops that sparkled on his beard.&nbsp; If



<P>he had not loved Jo very much, I don't think he could have done



<P>it then, for she looked far from lovely, with her skirts in a



<P>deplorable state, her rubber boots splashed to the ankle, and



<P>her bonnet a ruin.&nbsp; Fortunately, Mr. Bhaer considered her the



<P>most beautiful woman living, and she found him more `Jove-like"



<P>than ever, though his hatbrim was quite limp with the little



<P>rills trickling thence upon his shoulders (for he held the



<P>umbrella all over Jo), and every finger of his gloves needed



<P>mending.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Passers-by probably thought them a pair of harmless lunatics,



<P>for they entirely forgot to hail a bus, and strolled



<P>leisurely along, oblivious of deepening dusk and fog.&nbsp; Little



<P>they cared what anybody thought, for they were enjoying the



<P>happy hour that seldom comes but once in any life, the magical



<P>moment which bestows youth on the old, beauty on the plain,



<P>wealth on the poor, and gives human hearts a foretaste of heaven.



<P>The Professor looked as if he had conquered a kingdom, and the



<P>world had nothing more to offer him in the way of bliss.&nbsp; While



<P>Jo trudged beside him, feeling as if her place had always been



<P>there, and wondering how she ever could have chosen any other



<P>lot.&nbsp; Of course, she was the first to speak--intelligibly, I



<P>mean, for the emotional remarks which followed her impetuous



<P>"Oh, yes!" were not of a coherent or reportable character.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Friedrich, why didn't you..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah, heaven, she gifs me the name that no one speaks since



<P>Minna died!" cried the Professor, pausing in a puddle to regard



<P>her with grateful delight.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I always call you so to myself--I forgot, but I won't unless



<P>you like it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Like it?&nbsp; It is more sweet to me than I can tell.&nbsp; Say `thou',



<P>also, and I shall say your language is almost as beautiful as mine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Isn't `thou' a little sentimental?" asked Jo, privately thinking



<P>it a lovely monosyllable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sentimental? Yes.&nbsp; Thank Gott, we Germans believe in sentiment,



<P>and keep ourselves young mit it.&nbsp; Your English `you' is so cold,

say



<P>`thou', heart's dearest, it means so much to me," pleaded Mr. Bhaer,



<P>more like a romantic student than a grave professor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, then, why didn't thou tell me all this sooner?" asked



<P>Jo bashfully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now I shall haf to show thee all my heart, and I so gladly



<P>will, because thou must take care of it hereafter.&nbsp; See, then,

my



<P>Jo--ah, the dear, funny little name--I had a wish to tell something



<P>the day I said goodbye in New York, but I thought the handsome



<P>friend was betrothed to thee, and so I spoke not.&nbsp; Wouldst thou



<P>have said `Yes', then, if I had spoken?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't know.&nbsp; I'm afraid not, for I didn't have any heart just

then."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Prut!&nbsp; That I do not believe.&nbsp; It was asleep till the fairy

prince



<P>came through the wood, and waked it up.&nbsp; Ah, well, `Die erste Liebe



<P>ist die beste', but that I should not expect."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, the first love is the best, but be so contented, for I



<P>never had another.&nbsp; Teddy was only a boy, and soon got over his



<P>little fancy," said Jo, anxious to correct the Professor's mistake.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good!&nbsp; Then I shall rest happy, and be sure that thou givest



<P>me all.&nbsp; I haf waited so long, I am grown selfish, as thou wilt



<P>find , Professorin."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I like that," cried Jo, delighted with her new name.&nbsp; "Now



<P>tell me what brought you, at last, just when I wanted you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This." And Mr. Bhaer took a little worn paper out of his



<P>waistcoat pocket.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo unfolded it, and looked much abashed, for it was one of



<P>her own contributions to a paper that paid for poetry, which



<P>accounted for her sending it an occasional attempt.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How could that bring you?" she asked, wondering what he



<P>meant.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I found it by chance.&nbsp; I knew it by the names and the



<P>initials, and in it there was one little verse that seemed to



<P>call me.&nbsp; Read and find him.&nbsp; I will see that you go not in



<P>the wet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>IN THE GARRET



<P>Four little chests all in a row,



<P>Dim with dust, and worn by time,



<P>All fashioned and filled, long ago,



<P>By children now in their prime.



<P>Four little keys hung side by side,



<P>With faded ribbons, brave and gay



<P>When fastened there, with childish pride,



<P>Long ago, on a rainy day.



<P>Four little names, one on each lid,



<P>Carved out by a boyish hand,



<P>And underneath there lieth hid



<P>Histories of the happpy band



<P>Once playing here, and pausing oft



<P>To hear the sweet refrain,



<P>That came and went on the roof aloft,



<P>In the falling summer rain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Meg" on the first lid, smooth and fair.



<P>I look in with loving eyes,



<P>For folded here, with well-known care,



<P>A goodly gathering lies,



<P>The record of a peaceful life--



<P>Gifts to gentle child and girl,



<P>A bridal gown, lines to a wife,



<P>A tiny shoe, a baby curl.



<P>No toys in this first chest remain,



<P>For all are carried away,



<P>In their old age, to join again



<P>In another small Meg's play.



<P>Ah, happy mother!&nbsp; Well I know



<P>You hear, like a sweet refrain,



<P>Lullabies ever soft and low



<P>In the falling summer rain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo" on the next lid, scratched and worn,



<P>And within a motley store



<P>Of headless, dolls, of schoolbooks torn,



<P>Birds and beasts that speak no more,



<P>Spoils brought home from the fairy ground



<P>Only trod by youthful feet,



<P>Dreams of a future never found,



<P>Memories of a past still sweet,



<P>Half-writ poems, stories wild,



<P>April letters, warm and cold,



<P>Diaries of a wilful child,



<P>Hints of a woman early old,



<P>A woman in a lonely home,



<P>Hearing, like a sad refrain--



<P>"Be worthy, love, and love will come,"



<P>In the falling summer rain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>My Beth!&nbsp; the dust is always swept



<P>From the lid that bears your name,



<P>As if by loving eyes that wept,



<P>By careful hands that often came.



<P>Death cannonized for us one saint,



<P>Ever less human than divine,



<P>And still we lay, with tender plaint,



<P>Relics in this household shrine--



<P>The silver bell, so seldom rung,



<P>The little cap which last she wore,



<P>The fair, dead Catherine that hung



<P>By angels borne above her door.



<P>The songs she sang, without lament,



<P>In her prison-house of pain,



<P>Forever are they sweetly blent



<P>With the falling summer rain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Upon the last lid's polished field--



<P>Legend now both fair and true



<P>A gallant knight bears on his shield,



<P>"Amy" in letters gold and blue.



<P>Within lie snoods that bound her hair,



<P>Slippers that have danced their last,



<P>Faded flowers laid by with care,



<P>Fans whose airy toils are past,



<P>Gay valentines, all ardent flames,



<P>Trifles that have borne their part



<P>In girlish hopes and fears and shames,



<P>The record of a maiden heart



<P>Now learning fairer, truer spells,



<P>Hearing, like a blithe refrain,



<P>The silver sound of bridal bells



<P>In the falling summer rain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Four little chests all in a row,



<P>Dim with dust, and worn by time,



<P>Four women, taught by weal and woe



<P>To love and labor in their prime.



<P>Four sisters, parted for an hour,



<P>None lost, one only gone before,



<P>Made by love's immortal power,



<P>Nearest and dearest evermore.



<P>Oh, when these hidden stores of ours



<P>Lie open to the Father's sight,



<P>May they be rich in golden hours,



<P>Deeds that show fairer for the light,



<P>Lives whose brave music long shall ring,



<P>Like a spirit-stirring strain,



<P>Souls that shall gladly soar and sing



<P>In the long sunshine after rain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's very bad poetry, but I felt it when I wrote it, one day



<P>when I was very lonely, and had a good cry on a rag bag.&nbsp; I never



<P>thought it would go where it could tell tales," said Jo, tearing



<P>up the verses the Professor had treasured so long.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let it go, it has done it's duty, and I will haf a fresh one



<P>when I read all the brown book in which she keeps her little



<P>secrets," said Mr. Bhaer with a smile as he watched the fragments



<P>fly away on the wind.&nbsp; "Yes," he added earnestly, "I read that,



<P>and I think to myself, She has a sorrow, she is lonely, she would



<P>find comfort in true love.&nbsp; I haf a heart full, full for her.&nbsp;

Shall



<P>I not go and say, "If this is not too poor a thing to gif for what



<P>I shall hope to receive, take it in Gott's name?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And so you came to find that it was not too poor, but the one



<P>precious thing I needed," whispered Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had no courage to think that at first, heavenly kind as was



<P>your welcome to me.&nbsp; But soon I began to hope, and then I said,



<P>`I will haf her if I die for it,' and so I will!" cried Mr. Bhaer,



<P>with a defiant nod, as if the walls of mist closing round them were



<P>barriers which he was to surmount or valiantly knock down.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo thought that was splendid, and resolved to be worthy of her knight,



<P>though he did not come prancing on a charger in gorgeous array.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What made you stay away so long?" she asked presently, finding



<P>it so pleasant to ask confidential questions and get delightful



<P>answers that she could not keep silent.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was not easy, but I could not find the heart to take you



<P>from that so happy home until I could haf a prospect of one to



<P>gif you, after much time, perhaps, and hard work.&nbsp; How could I

ask



<P>you to gif up so much for a poor old fellow, who has no fortune



<P>but a little learning?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad you are poor.&nbsp; I couldn't bear a rich husband,"



<P>said Jo decidedly, adding in a softer tone, "Don't fear poverty.



<P>I've known it long enough to lose my dread and be happy working



<P>for those I love, and don't call yourself old--forty is the prime



<P>of life.&nbsp; I couldn't help loving you if you were seventy!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Professor found that so touching that he would have been



<P>glad of his handkerchief, if he could have got at it.&nbsp; As her



<P>couldn't, Jo wiped his eyes for him, and said, laughing, as she



<P>took away a bundle or two...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I may be strong-minded, but no one can say I'm out of my



<P>sphere now, for woman's special mission is supposed to be drying



<P>tears and bearing burdens.&nbsp; I'm to carry my share, Friedrich,



<P>and help to earn the home.&nbsp; Make up your mind to that, or I'll



<P>never go," she added resolutely, as he tried to reclaim his load.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We shall see.&nbsp; Haf you patience to wait a long time, Jo?



<P>I must go away and do my work alone.&nbsp; I must help my boys first,



<P>because, even for you, I may not break my word to Minna.&nbsp; Can



<P>you forgif that, and be happy while we hope and wait?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I know I can, for we love one another, and that makes



<P>all the rest easy to bear.&nbsp; I have my duty, also, and my work.



<P>I couldn't enjoy myself if I neglected them even for you, so



<P>there's no need of hurry or impatience.&nbsp; You can do your part



<P>out West, I can do mine here, and both be happy hoping for the



<P>best, and leaving the future to be as God wills."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! Thou gifest me such hope and courage, and I haf nothing



<P>to gif back but a full heart and these empty hands," cried the



<P>Professor, quite overcome.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo never, never would learn to be proper, for when he said



<P>that as they stood upon the steps, she just put both hands into



<P>his, whispering tenderly, "Not empty now," and stooping down,



<P>kissed her Friedrich under the umbrella.&nbsp; It was dreadful, but



<P>she would have done it if the flock of draggle-tailed sparrows



<P>on the hedge had been human beings, for she was very far gone



<P>indeed, and quite regardless of everything but her own happiness.



<P>Though it came in such a very simple guise, that was the crowning



<P>moment of both their lives, when, turning from the night and



<P>storm and loneliness to the household light and warmth and peace



<P>waiting to receive them, with a glad "Welcome home!"&nbsp; Jo led her



<P>lover in, and shut the door.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 47</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FORTY-SEVEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For a year Jo and her Professor worked and waited, hoped



<P>and loved, met occasionally, and wrote such voluminous letters



<P>that the rise in the price of paper was accounted for, Laurie



<P>said.&nbsp; The second year began rather soberly, for their prospects



<P>did not brighten, and Aunt March died suddenly.&nbsp; But when their



<P>first sorrow was over--for they loved the old lady in spite



<P>of her sharp tongue--they found they had cause for rejoicing,



<P>for she had left Plumfield to Jo, which made all sorts of joyful



<P>things possible.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's a fine old place, and will bring a handsome sum, for



<P>of course you intend to sell it," said Laurie, as they were all



<P>talking the matter over some weeks later.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I don't," was Jo's decided answer, as she petted the



<P>fat poodle, whom she had adopted, out of respect to his former



<P>mistress.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You don't mean to live there?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, my dear girl, it's an immense house, and will take a



<P>power of money to keep it in order.&nbsp; The garden and orchard alone



<P>need two or three men, and farming isn't in Bhaer's line, I take



<P>it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He'll try his hand at it there, if I propose it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And you expect to live on the produce of the place?&nbsp; Well,



<P>that sounds paradisiacal, but you'll find it desperate hard work."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The crop we are going to raise is a profitable one," And



<P>Jo laughed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of what is this fine crop to consist, ma'am?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Boys.&nbsp; I want to open a school for little lads--a good,



<P>happy, homelike school, with me to take care of them and Fritz



<P>to teach them."



<P>"That's a truly Joian plan for you!&nbsp; Isn't that just like



<P>her?" cried Laurie, appealing to the family, who looked as much



<P>surprised as he.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I like it," said Mrs. March decidedly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So do I," added her husband, who welcomed the thought of



<P>a chance for trying the Socratic method of education on modern



<P>youth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It will be an immense care for Jo," said Meg, stroking



<P>the head or her one all-absorbing son.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo can do it, and be happy in it.&nbsp; It's a splendid idea.



<P>Tell us all about it," cried Mr. Laurence, who had been longing



<P>to lend the lovers a hand, but knew that they would refuse his



<P>help.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I knew you'd stand by me, sir.&nbsp; Amy does too--I see it in



<P>her eyes, though she prudently waits to turn it over in her mind



<P>before she speaks.&nbsp; Now, my dear people," continued Jo earnestly,



<P>"just understand that this isn't a new idea of mine, but a long



<P>cherished plan.&nbsp; Before my Fritz came, I used to think how, when



<P>I'd made my fortune, and no one needed me at home, I'd hire a



<P>big house, and pick up some poor, forlorn little lads who hadn't



<P>any mothers, and take care of them, and make life jolly for them



<P>before it was too late.&nbsp; I see so many going to ruin for want of



<P>help at the right minute, I love so to do anything for them, I



<P>seem to feel their wants, and sympathize with their troubles, and



<P>oh, I should so like to be a mother to them!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March held out her hand to Jo, who took it, smiling,



<P>with tears in her eyes, and went on in the old enthusiastic way,



<P>which they had not seen for a long while.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I told my plan to Fritz once, and he said it was just what



<P>he would like, and agreed to try it when we got rich.&nbsp; Bless his



<P>dear heart, he's been doing it all his life--helping poor boys, I



<P>mean, not getting rich, that he'll never be.&nbsp; Money doesn't stay



<P>in his pocket long enough to lay up any.&nbsp; But now, thanks to my



<P>good old aunt, who loved me better than I ever deserved, I'm rich,



<P>at least I feel so, and we can live at Plumfield perfectly well,



<P>if we have a flourishing school.&nbsp; It's just the place for boys,



<P>the house is big, and the furniture strong and plain.&nbsp; There's



<P>plenty of room for dozens inside, and splendid grounds outside.



<P>They could help in the garden and orchard.&nbsp; Such work is healthy,



<P>isn't it, sir?&nbsp; Then Fritz could train and teach in his own way,



<P>and Father will help him.&nbsp; I can feed and nurse and pet and scold



<P>them, and Mother will be my stand-by.&nbsp; I've always longed for lots



<P>of boys, and never had enough, now I can fill the house full and



<P>revel in the little dears to my heart's content.&nbsp; Think what luxury--



<P>Plumfield my own, and a wilderness of boys to enjoy it with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As Jo waved her hands and gave a sigh of rapture, the family



<P>went off into a gale of merriment, and Mr. Laurence laughed till



<P>they thought he'd have an apoplectic fit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't see anything funny," she said gravely, when she



<P>could be heard.&nbsp; "Nothing could be more natural and proper than



<P>for my Professor to open a school, and for me to prefer to reside



<P>in my own estate."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She is putting on airs already," said Laurie, who regarded



<P>the idea in the light of a capital joke.&nbsp; "But may I inquire how



<P>you intend to support the establishment? If all the pupils are



<P>little ragamuffins, I'm afraid your crop won't be profitable in



<P>a worldly sense, Mr. Bhaer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now don't be a wet-blanket, Teddy.&nbsp; Of course I shall have



<P>rich pupils, also--perhaps begin with such altogether.&nbsp; Then,



<P>when I've got a start, I can take in a ragamuffin or two, just



<P>for a relish.&nbsp; Rich people's children often need care and comfort,



<P>as well as poor.&nbsp; I've seen unfortunate little creatures left to



<P>servants, or backward ones pushed forward, when it's real cruelty.



<P>Some are naughty through mismanagment or neglect, and some lose



<P>their mothers.&nbsp; Besides, the best have to get through the hobbledehoy



<P>age, and that's the very time they need most patience and kindness.



<P>People laugh at them, and hustle them about, try to keep them



<P>out of sight, and expect them to turn all at once from pretty



<P>children into fine young men.&nbsp; They don't complain much--



<P>plucky little souls--but they feel it.&nbsp; I've been through some-



<P>thing of it, and I know all about it.&nbsp; I've a special interest



<P>in such young bears, and like to show them that I see the warm,



<P>honest, well-meaning boys' hearts, in spite of the clumsy arms



<P>and legs and the topsy-turvy heads.&nbsp; I've had experience, too,



<P>for haven't I brought up one boy to be a pride and honor to his family?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll testify that you tried to do it," said Laurie with a grateful

look.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I've succeeded beyond my hopes, for here you are, a



<P>steady, sensible businessman, doing heaps of good with your



<P>money, and laying up the blessings of the poor, instead of dollars.



<P>But you are not merely a businessman, you love good and beautiful



<P>things, enjoy them yourself, and let others go halves, as you



<P>always did in the old times.&nbsp; I am proud of you, Teddy, for you



<P>get better every year, and everyone feels it, though you won't



<P>let them say so.&nbsp; Yes, and when I have my flock, I'll just point



<P>to you, and say `There's your model, my lads'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Laurie didn't know where to look, for, man though he



<P>was, something of the old bashfulness came over him as this burst



<P>of praise made all faces turn approvingly upon him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I say, Jo, that's rather too much," he began, just in his



<P>old boyish way.&nbsp; "You have all done more for me than I can ever



<P>thank you for, except by doing my best not to disapoint you.&nbsp; You



<P>have rather cast me off lately, Jo, but I've had the best of help,



<P>nevertheless.&nbsp; So, if I've got on at all, you may thank these two



<P>for it."&nbsp; And he laid one hand gently on his grandfather's head,



<P>and the other on Amy's golden one, for the three were never far



<P>apart.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do think that families are the most beautiful things in



<P>all the world!" burst out Jo, who was in an unusually up-lifted



<P>frame of mind just then.&nbsp; "When I have one of my own, I hope it



<P>will be as happy as the three I know and love the best.&nbsp; If John



<P>and my Fritz were only here, it would be quite a little heaven



<P>on earth," she added more quietly.&nbsp; And that night when she went



<P>to her room after a blissful evening of family counsels, hopes,



<P>and plans, her heart was so full of happiness that she could only



<P>calm it by kneeling beside the empty bed always near her own, and



<P>thinking tender thoughts of Beth.



<P>It was a very astonishing year altogether, for things seemed



<P>to happen in an unusually rapid and delightful manner.&nbsp; Almost



<P>before she knew where she was, Jo found herself married and settled



<P>at Plumfield.&nbsp; Then a family of six or seven boys sprung up



<P>like mushrooms, and flourished surprisingly, poor boys as well as



<P>rich, for Mr. Laurence was continually finding some touching case



<P>of destitution, and begging the Bhaers to take pity on the child,



<P>and he would gladly pay a trifle for its support.&nbsp; In this way,



<P>the sly old gentleman got round proud Jo, and furnished her with



<P>the style of boy in which she most delighted.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Of course it was uphill work at first, and Jo made queer



<P>mistakes, but the wise Professor steered her safely into calmer



<P>waters, and the most rampant ragamuffin was conquered in the end.



<P>How Jo did enjoy her `wilderness of boys', and how poor, dear



<P>Aunt March would have lamented had she been there to see the



<P>sacred precincts of prim, well-ordered Plumfield overrun with



<P>Toms, Dicks, and Harrys!&nbsp; There was a sort of poetic justice



<P>about it, after all, for the old lady had been the terror of the boys



<P>for miles around, and now the exiles feasted freely on forbidden



<P>plums, kicked up the gravel with profane boots unreproved,



<P>and played cricket in the big field where the irritable



<P>`cow with a crumpled horn' used to invite rash youths to come and



<P>be tossed.&nbsp; It became a sort of boys' paradise, and Laurie suggested



<P>that it should be called the `Bhaer-garten', as a compliment



<P>to its master and appropriate to its inhabitants.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It never was a fashionable school, and the Professor did not



<P>lay up a fortune, but it was just what Jo intended it to be--



<P>`a happy, homelike place for boys, who needed teaching, care, and



<P>kindness'.&nbsp; Every room in the big house was soon full.&nbsp; Every



<P>little plot in the garden soon had its owner.&nbsp; A regular menagerie



<P>appeared in barn and shed, for pet animals were allowed.



<P>And three times a day, Jo smiled at her Fritz from the head of



<P>a long table lined on either side with rows of happy young faces,



<P>which all turned to her with affectionate eyes, confiding words,



<P>and grateful hearts, full of love for `Mother Bhaer'.&nbsp; She had



<P>boys enough now, and did not tire of them, though they were not



<P>angels, by any means, and some of them caused both Professor and



<P>Professorin much trouble and anxiety.&nbsp; But her faith in the good



<P>spot which exists in the heart of the naughtiest, sauciest, most



<P>tantalizing little ragamuffin gave her patience, skill, and in



<P>time success, for no mortal boy could hold out long with Father



<P>Bhaer shining on him as benevolently as the sun, and Mother Bhaer



<P>forgiving him seventy times seven.&nbsp; Very precious to Jo was the



<P>friendship of the lads, their penitent sniffs and whispers after



<P>wrongdoing, their droll or touching little confidences, their



<P>pleasant enthusiasms, hopes, and plans, even their misfortunes,



<P>for they only endeared them to her all the more.&nbsp; There were slow



<P>boys and bashful boys, feeble boys and riotous boys, boys that



<P>lisped and boys that stuttered, one or two lame ones, and a



<P>merry little quadroon, who could not be taken in elsewhere, but



<P>who was welcome to the `Bhaer-garten', though some people predicted



<P>that his admission would ruin the school.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Yes, Jo was a very happy woman there, in spite of hard work,



<P>much anxiety, and a perpetual racket.&nbsp; She enjoyed it heartily

and



<P>found the applause of her boys more satisfying than any praise of



<P>the world, for now she told no stories except to her flock of



<P>enthusiastic believers and admirers.&nbsp; As the years went on, two



<P>little lads of her own came to increase her happiness--Rob,



<P>named for Grandpa, and Teddy, a happy-go-lucky baby, who seemed



<P>to have inherited his papa's sunshiny temper as well as his



<P>mother's lively spirit.&nbsp; How they ever grew up alive in that



<P>whirlpool of boys was a mystery to their grandma and aunts, but



<P>they flourished like dandelions in spring, and their rough



<P>nurses loved and served them well.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There were a great many holidays at Plumfield, and one of



<P>the most delightful was the yearly apple-picking.&nbsp; For then the



<P>Marches, Laurences, Brookes.&nbsp; And Bhaers turned out in full force



<P>and made a day of it.&nbsp; Five years after Jo's wedding, one of these



<P>fruitful festivals occurred, a mellow October day, when the air



<P>was full of an exhilarating freshness which made the spirits rise



<P>and the blood dance healthily in the veins.&nbsp; The old orchard wore



<P>its holiday attire.&nbsp; Goldenrod and asters fringed the mossy walls.



<P>Grasshoppers skipped briskly in the sere grass, and crickets chirped



<P>like fairy pipers at a feast.&nbsp; Squirrels were busy with their



<P>small harvesting.&nbsp; Birds twittered their adieux from the alders



<P>in the lane, and every tree stood ready to send down its shower



<P>of red or yellow apples at the first shake.&nbsp; Everybody was there.



<P>Everybody laughed and sang, climbed up and tumbled down.&nbsp; Everybody



<P>declared that there never had been such a perfect day or such



<P>a jolly set to enjoy it, and everyone gave themselves up to



<P>the simple pleasures of the hour as freely as if there were no



<P>such things as care or sorrow in the world.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. March strolled placidly about, quoting Tusser, Cowley,



<P>and Columella to Mr. Laurence, while enjoying...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The gentle apple's winey juice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Professor charged up and down the green aisles like a stout



<P>Teutonic knight, with a pole for a lance, leading on the boys,



<P>who made a hook and ladder company of themselves, and performed



<P>wonders in the way of ground and lofty tumbling.&nbsp; Laurie devoted



<P>himself to the little ones, rode his small daughter in a bushel-basket,



<P>took Daisy up among the bird's nests, and kept adventurous



<P>Rob from breaking his neck.&nbsp; Mrs. March and Meg sat among



<P>the apple piles like a pair of Pomonas, sorting the contributions



<P>that kept pouring in, while Amy with a beautiful motherly expression



<P>in her face sketched the various groups, and watched over one



<P>pale lad, who sat adoring her with his little crutch beside him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo was in her element that day, and rushed about, with her



<P>gown pinned up, and her hat anywhere but on her head, and her



<P>baby tucked under her arm, ready for any lively adventure which



<P>might turn up.&nbsp; Little Teddy bore a charmed life, for nothing



<P>ever happened to him, and Jo never felt any anxiety when he was



<P>whisked up into a tree by one lad, galloped off on the back of



<P>another, or supplied with sour russets by his indulgent papa,



<P>who labored under the Germanic delusion that babies could digest



<P>anything, from pickled cabbage to buttons, nails, and their own



<P>small shoes.&nbsp; She knew that little Ted would turn up again in



<P>time, safe and rosy, dirty and serene, and she always received



<P>him back with a hearty welcome, for Jo loved her babies tenderly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At four o'clock a lull took place, and baskets remained



<P>empty, while the apple pickers rested and compared rents and



<P>bruises.&nbsp; Then Jo and Meg, with a detachment of the bigger boys,



<P>set forth the supper on the grass, for an out-of-door tea was



<P>always the crowning joy of the day.&nbsp; The land literally flowed



<P>with milk and honey on such occasions, for the lads were not



<P>required to sit at table, but allowed to partake of refreshment



<P>as they liked--freedom being the sauce best beloved by the boyish



<P>soul.&nbsp; They availed themselves of the rare privilege to the



<P>fullest extent, for some tried the pleasing experiment of drinking



<P>mild while standing on their heads, others lent a charm to



<P>leapfrog by eating pie in the pauses of the game, cookies were



<P>sown broadcast over the field, and apple turnovers roosted in



<P>the trees like a new style of bird.&nbsp; The little girls had a



<P>private tea party, and Ted roved among the edibles at his own



<P>sweet will.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When no one could eat any more, the Professor proposed the



<P>first regular toast, which was always drunk at such times--"Aunt



<P>March, God bless her!"&nbsp; A toast heartily given by the good man,



<P>who never forgot how much he owed her, and quietly drunk by the



<P>boys, who had been taught to keep her memory green.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Grandma's sixtieth birthday!&nbsp; Long life to her, with



<P>three times three!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That was given with a will, as you may well believe, and



<P>the cheering once begun, it was hard to stop it.&nbsp; Everybody's



<P>health was proposed, form Mr. Laurence, who was considered their



<P>special patron, to the astonished guinea pig, who had strayed



<P>from its proper sphere in search of its young master.&nbsp; Demi, as



<P>the oldest grandchild, then presented the queen of the day with



<P>various gifts, so numerous that they were transported to the



<P>festive scene in a wheelbarrow.&nbsp; Funny presents, some of them,



<P>but what would have been defects to other eyes were ornaments



<P>to Grandma's--for the children's gifts were all their own.&nbsp; Every



<P>stitch Daisy's patient little fingers had put into the handkerchiefs



<P>she hemmed was better than embroidery to Mrs. March.&nbsp; Demi's



<P>miracle of mechanical skill, though the cover wouldn't shut, Rob's



<P>footstool had a wiggle in its uneven legs that she declared was



<P>soothing, and no page of the costly book Amy's child gave her was



<P>so fair as that on which appeared in tipsy capitals, the words--



<P>"To dear Grandma, from her little Beth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>During the ceremony the boys had mysteriously disappeared,



<P>and when Mrs. March had tried to thank her children, and broken



<P>down, while Teddy wiped her eyes on his pinafore, the Professor



<P>suddenly began to sing.&nbsp; Then, from above him, voice after voice



<P>took up the words, and from tree to tree echoed the music of the



<P>unseen choir, as the boys sang with all their hearts the little



<P>song that Jo had written, Laurie set to music, and the Professor



<P>trained his lads to give with the best effect.&nbsp; This was something



<P>altogether new, and it proved a grand success, for Mrs. March
