<P>couldn't get over her surprise, and insisted on shaking hands



<P>with every one of the featherless birds, from tall Franz and



<P>Emil to the little quadroon, who had the sweetest voice of all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After this, the boys dispersed for a final lark, leaving Mrs.



<P>March and her daughters under the festival tree.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't think I ever ought to call myself `unlucky Jo' again,



<P>when my greatest wish has been so beautifully gratified," said Mrs.



<P>Bhaer, taking Teddy's little fist out of the milk pitcher, in which



<P>he was rapturously churning.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And yet your life is very different from the one you pictured



<P>so long ago.&nbsp; Do you remember our castles in the air?" asked Amy,



<P>smiling as she watched Laurie and John playing cricket with the boys.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear fellows!&nbsp; It does my heart good to see them forget business



<P>and frolic for a day," answered Jo, who now spoke in a maternal



<P>way of all mankind.&nbsp; "Yes, I remember, but the life I wanted then



<P>seems selfish, lonely, and cold to me now.&nbsp; I haven't given up

the



<P>hope that I may write a good book yet, but I can wait, and I'm



<P>sure it will be all the better for such experiences and illustrations



<P>as these."&nbsp; And Jo pointed from the lively lads in the



<P>distance to her father, leaning on the Professor's arm, as they



<P>walked to and fro in the sunshine, deep in one of the conversations



<P>which both enjoyed so much, and then to her mother, sitting enthroned



<P>among her daughters, with their children in her lap and at



<P>her feet, as if all found help and happiness in the face which



<P>never could grow old to them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My castle was the most nearly realized of all.&nbsp; I asked for



<P>splendid things, to be sure, but in my heart I knew I should be



<P>satisfied, if I had a little home, and John, and some dear children



<P>like these.&nbsp; I've got them all, thank God, and am the



<P>happiest woman in the world."&nbsp; And Meg laid her hand on her tall



<P>boy's head, with a face full of tender and devout content.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My castle is very different from what I planned, but I would



<P>not alter it, though, like Jo, I don't relinquish all my artistic



<P>hopes, or confine myself to helping others fulfill their dreams of



<P>beauty.&nbsp; I've begun to model a figure of baby, and Laurie says

it



<P>is the best thing I've ever done.&nbsp; I think so, myself, and mean



<P>to do it in marble, so that, whatever happens, I may at least keep



<P>the image of my little angel."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As Amy spoke, a great tear dropped on the golden hair of the



<P>sleeping child in her arms, for her one well-beloved daughter was



<P>a frail little creature and the dread of losing her was the shadow



<P>over Amy's sunshine.&nbsp; This cross was doing much for both father



<P>and mother, for one love and sorrow bound them closely together.



<P>Amy's nature was growing sweeter, deeper, and more tender.&nbsp; Laurie



<P>was growing more serious, strong, and firm, and both were learning



<P>that beauty, youth, good fortune, even love itself, cannot keep



<P>care and pain, loss and sorrow, from the most blessed for ...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Into each life some rain must fall,



<P>Some days must be dark and sad and dreary.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She is growing better, I am sure of it, my dear.&nbsp; Don't



<P>despond, but hope and keep happy," said Mrs. March, as tenderhearted



<P>Daisy stooped from her knee to lay her rosy cheek against



<P>her little cousin's pale one.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never ought to, while I have you to cheer me up, Marmee,



<P>and Laurie to take more than half of every burden," replied Amy



<P>warmly.&nbsp; "He never lets me see his anxiety, but is so sweet and



<P>patient with me, so devoted to Beth, and such a stay and comfort



<P>to me always that I can't love him enough.&nbsp; So, in spite of my



<P>one cross, I can say with Meg, `Thank God, I'm a happy woman.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There's no need for me to say it, for everyone can see



<P>that I'm far happier than I deserve," added Jo, glancing from



<P>her good husband to her chubby children, tumbling on the grass



<P>beside her.&nbsp; "Fritz is getting gray and stout.&nbsp; I'm growing

as



<P>thin as a shadow, and am thirty.&nbsp; We never shall be rich, and



<P>Plumfield may burn up any night, for that incorrigible Tommy



<P>Bangs will smoke sweet-fern cigars under the bed-clothes,



<P>though he's set himself afire three times already.&nbsp; But in



<P>spite of these unromantic facts, I have nothing to complain



<P>of, and never was so jolly in my life.&nbsp; Excuse the remark, but



<P>living among boys, I can't help using their expressions now



<P>and then."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Jo, I think your harvest will be a good one," began



<P>Mrs. March, frightening away a big black cricket that was



<P>staring Teddy out of countenance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not half so good as yours, Mother.&nbsp; Here it is, and we



<P>never can thank you enough for the patient sowing and reaping



<P>you have done," cried Jo, with the loving impetuosity which



<P>she never would outgrow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope there will be more wheat and fewer tares every



<P>year," said Amy softly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A large sheaf, but I know there's room in your heart for



<P>it, Marmee dear," added Meg's tender voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Touched to the heart, Mrs. March could only stretch out



<P>her arms, as if to gather children and grandchildren to herself,



<P>and say, with face and voice full of motherly love, gratitude,



<P>and humility...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, my girls, however long you may live, I never can



<P>wish you a greater happiness than this!"

<BR>&nbsp;



<P><B>End</B>



<P>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 45</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FORTY-FIVE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I cannot feel that I have done my duty as humble historian



<P>of the March family, without devoting at least one chapter to



<P>the two most precious and important members of it.&nbsp; Daisy and



<P>Demi had now arrived at years of discretion, for in this fast



<P>age babies of three or four assert their rights, and get them,



<P>too, which is more than many of their elders do.&nbsp; If there



<P>ever were a pair of twins in danger of being utterly spoiled



<P>by adoration, it was these prattling Brookes.&nbsp; Of course they



<P>were the most remarkable children ever born, as will be shown



<P>when I mention that they walked at eight months, talked fluently



<P>at twelve months, and at two years they took their places



<P>at table, and behaved with a propriety which charmed all beholders.



<P>At three, Daisy demanded a `needler', and actually made



<P>a bag with four stitches in it.&nbsp; She likewise set up



<P>housekeeping in the sideboard, and managed a microscopic cooking



<P>stove with a skill that brought tears of pride to Hannah's



<P>eyes, while Demi learned his letters with his grandfather, who



<P>invented a new mode of teaching the alphabet by forming letters



<P>with his arms and legs, thus uniting gymnastics for head and



<P>heels.&nbsp; The boy early developed a mechanical genius which delighted



<P>his father and distracted his mother, for he tried to



<P>imitate every machine he saw, and kept the nursery in a chaotic



<P>condition, with his `sewinsheen', a mysterious structure of



<P>string, chairs, clothespins, and spools, for wheels to go



<P>`wound and wound'.&nbsp; Also a basket hung over the back of a chair,



<P>in which he vainly tried to hoist his too confiding sister, who,



<P>with feminine devotion, allowed her little head to be bumped till



<P>rescued, when the young inventor indignantly remarked, "Why,



<P>Marmar, dat's my lellywaiter, and me's trying to pull her up."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Though utterly unlike in character, the twins got on remarkably



<P>well together, and seldom quarreled more than thrice



<P>a day.&nbsp; Of course, Demi tyrannized over Daisy, and gallantly



<P>defended her from every other aggressor, while Daisy made a



<P>galley slave of herself, and adored her brother as the one perfect



<P>being in the world.&nbsp; A rosy, chubby, sunshiny little soul



<P>was Daisy, who found her way to everybody's heart, and nestled



<P>there.&nbsp; One of the captivating children, who seem made to be



<P>kissed and cuddled, adorned and adored like little goddesses,



<P>and produced for general approval on all festive occasions.



<P>Her small virtues were so sweet that she would have been quite



<P>angelic if a few small naughtinesses had not kept her delightfully



<P>human.&nbsp; It was all fair weather in her world, and every



<P>morning she scrambled up to the window in her little nightgown



<P>to look our, and say, no matter whether it rained or shone,



<P>"Oh, pitty day, oh, pitty day!" Everyone was a friend, and she



<P>offered kisses to a stranger so confidingly that the most inveterate



<P>bachelor relented, and baby-lovers became faithful



<P>worshipers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me loves evvybody," she once said, opening her arms, with



<P>her spoon in one hand, and her mug in the other, as if eager to



<P>embrace and nourish the whole world.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she grew, her mother began to feel that the Dovecote



<P>would be blessed by the presence of an inmate as serene and loving



<P>as that which had helped to make the old house home, and to



<P>pray that she might be spared a loss like that which had lately



<P>taught them how long they had entertained an angel unawares.&nbsp; Her



<P>grandfather often called her `Beth', and her grandmother watched



<P>over her with untiring devotion, as if trying to atone for some



<P>past mistake, which no eye but her own could see.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Demi, like a true Yankee, was of an inquiring turn, wanting



<P>to know everything, and often getting much disturbed because he



<P>could not get satisfactory answers to his perpetual "What for?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He also possessed a philosophic bent, to the great delight of



<P>his grandfather, who used to hold Socratic conversations with him,



<P>in which the precocious pupil occasionally posed his teacher, to



<P>the undisguised satisfaction of the womenfolk.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What makes my legs go, Dranpa?" asked the young philosopher,



<P>surveying those active portions of his frame with a meditative air,



<P>while resting after a go-to-bed frolic one night.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's your little mind, Demi," replied the sage, stroking the



<P>yellow head respectfully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What is a little mine?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is something which makes your body move, as the spring



<P>made the wheels go in my watch when I showed it to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Open me.&nbsp; I want to see it go wound."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't do that any more than you could open the watch.&nbsp; God



<P>winds you up, and you go till He stops you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Does I?" And Demi's brown eyes grew big and bright as he



<P>took in the new thought.&nbsp; "Is I wounded up like the watch?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, but I can't show you how, for it is done when we don't see."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Demi felt his back, as if expecting to find it like that of



<P>the watch, and then gravely remarked, "I dess Dod does it when



<P>I's asleep."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A careful explanation followed, to which he listened so attentively



<P>that his anxious grandmother said, "My dear, do you think it wise



<P>to talk about such things to that baby?&nbsp; He's getting great bumps



<P>over his eyes, and learning to ask the most unanswerable questions."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If he is old enough to ask the question he is old enough to



<P>receive true answers.&nbsp; I am not putting the thoughts into his



<P>head, but helping him unfold those already there.&nbsp; These children



<P>are wiser than we are, and I have no doubt the boy understands



<P>every word I have said to him.&nbsp; Now, Demi, tell me where you keep



<P>your mind."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If the boy had replied like Alcibiades, "By the gods, Socrates,



<P>I cannot tell," his grandfather would not have been surprised, but



<P>when, after standing a moment on one leg, like a meditative young



<P>stork, he answered, in a tone of calm conviction, "In my little



<P>belly," the old gentleman could only join in Grandma's laugh, and



<P>dismiss the class in metaphysics.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There might have been cause for maternal anxiety, if Demi had



<P>not given convincing proofs that he was a true boy, as well as a



<P>budding philosopher, for often, after a discussion which caused



<P>Hannah to prophesy, with ominous nods, "That child ain't long for



<P>this world," he would turn about and set her fears at rest by



<P>some of the pranks with which dear, dirty, naughty little rascals



<P>distract and delight their parent's souls.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg made many moral rules, and tried to keep them, but what



<P>mother was ever proof against the winning wiles, the ingenious



<P>evasions, or the tranquil audacity of the miniature men and women



<P>who so early show themselves accomplished Artful Dodgers?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No more raisins, Demi.&nbsp; They'll make you sick," says Mamma



<P>to the young person who offers his services in the kitchen with



<P>unfailing regularity on plum-pudding day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me likes to be sick."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't want to have you, so run away and help Daisy make patty cakes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He reluctantly departs, but his wrongs weigh upon his spirit,



<P>and by-and-by when an opportunity comes to redress them, he outwits



<P>Mamma by a shrewd bargain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now you have been good children, and I'll play anything you



<P>like," says Meg, as she leads her assistant cooks upstairs, when



<P>the pudding is safely bouncing in the pot.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Truly, Marmar?" asks Demi, with a brilliant idea in his well-powdered

head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, truly.&nbsp; Anything you say," replies the shortsighted parent,



<P>preparing herself to sing, "The Three Little Kittens" half a



<P>dozen times over, or to take her family to "Buy a penny bun," regardless



<P>of wind or limb.&nbsp; But Demi corners her by the cool reply...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then we'll go and eat up all the raisins."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Aunt Dodo was chief playmate and confidante of both children,



<P>and the trio turned the little house topsy-turvy.&nbsp; Aunt Amy was

as



<P>yet only a name to them, Aunt Beth soon faded into a pleasantly



<P>vague memory, but Aunt Dodo was a living reality, and they made the



<P>most of her, for which compliment she was deeply grateful.&nbsp; But



<P>when Mr. Bhaer came, Jo neglected her playfellows, and dismay and



<P>desolation fell upon their little souls.&nbsp; Daisy, who was fond of



<P>going about peddling kisses, lost her best customer and became



<P>bankrupt.&nbsp; Demi, with infantile penetration, soon discovered that



<P>Dodo like to play with `the bear-man' better than she did him,



<P>but though hurt, he concealed his anguish, for he hadn't the



<P>heart to insult a rival who kept a mine of chocolate drops in



<P>his waistcoat pocket, and a watch that could be taken out of its



<P>case and freely shaken by ardent admirers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Some persons might have considered these pleasing liberties



<P>as bribes, but Demi didn't see it in that light, and continued to



<P>patronize the `the bear-man' with pensive affability, while Daisy



<P>bestowed her small affections upon him at the third call, and



<P>considered his shoulder her throne, his arm her refuge, his gifts



<P>treasures surpassing worth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Gentlemen are sometimes seized with sudden fits of admiration



<P>for the young relatives of ladies whom they honor with their regard,



<P>but this counterfeit philoprogenitiveness sits uneasily upon them,



<P>and does not deceive anybody a particle.&nbsp; Mr. Bhaer's devotion

was



<P>sincere, however likewise effective--for honesty is the best policy



<P>in love as in law.&nbsp; He was one of the men who are at home with

children,



<P>and looked particularly well when little faces made a pleasant



<P>contrast with his manly one.&nbsp; His business, whatever it was, detained



<P>him from day to day, but evening seldom failed to bring him out to



<P>see--well, he always asked for Mr. March, so I suppose he was the



<P>attraction.&nbsp; The excellent papa labored under the delusion that

he



<P>was, and reveled in long discussions with the kindred spirit, till



<P>a chance remark of his more observing grandson suddenly enlightened

him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Bhaer came in one evening to pause on the threshold of the



<P>study, astonished by the spectacle that met his eye.&nbsp; Prone upon



<P>the floor lay Mr. March, with his respectable legs in the air, and



<P>beside him, likewise prone, was Demi, trying to imitate the attitude



<P>with his own short, scarlet-stockinged legs, both grovelers



<P>so seriously absorbed that they were unconscious of spectators,



<P>till Mr. Bhaer laughed his sonorous laugh, and Jo cried out, with



<P>a scandalized face...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Father, Father, here's the Professor!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Down went the black legs and up came the gray head, as the



<P>preceptor said, with undisturbed dignity, "Good evening, Mr. Bhaer.



<P>Excuse me for a moment.&nbsp; We are just finishing our lesson.&nbsp;

Now, Demi,



<P>make the letter and tell its name."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I knows him!"&nbsp; And, after a few convulsive efforts, the red



<P>legs tok the shape of a pair of compasses, and the intelligent



<P>pupil triumphantly shouted, "It's a We, Dranpa, it's a We!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He's a born Weller," laughed Jo, as her parent gathered himself



<P>up, and her nephew tried to stand on his head, as the only



<P>mode of expressing his satisfaction that school was over.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What have you been at today, bubchen?" asked Mr. Bhaer,



<P>picking up the gymnast.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me went to see little Mary."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And what did you there?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I kissed her," began Demi, with artless frankness.



<P>"Prut!&nbsp; Thou beginnest early.&nbsp; What did the little Mary say



<P>to that?" asked Mr. Bhaer, continuing to confess the young sinner,



<P>who stood upon the knee, exploring the waistcoat pocket.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, she liked it, and she kissed me, and I liked it.&nbsp; Don't



<P>little boys like little girls?" asked Demi, with his mouth full,



<P>and an air of bland satisfaction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You precious chick!&nbsp; Who put that into your head?" said Jo,



<P>enjoying the innocent revelation as much as the Professor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"`Tisn't in mine head, it's in mine mouf," answered literal



<P>Demi, putting out his tongue, with a chocolate drop on it, thinking



<P>she alluded to confectionery, not ideas.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thou shouldst save some for the little friend.&nbsp; Sweets to



<P>the sweet, mannling." And Mr. Bhaer offered Jo some, with a look



<P>that made her wonder if chocolate was not the nectar drunk by the



<P>gods.&nbsp; Demi also saw the smile, was impressed by it, and artlessy



<P>inquired.&nbsp; ..

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do great boys like great girls, to, 'Fessor?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Like young Washington, Mr. Bhaer `couldn't tell a lie', so



<P>he gave the somewhat vague reply that he believed they did sometimes,



<P>in a tone that made Mr. March put down his clothesbrush,



<P>glance at Jo's retiring face, and then sink into his chair, looking



<P>as if the `precocious chick' had put an idea into his head



<P>that was both sweet and sour.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Why Dodo, when she caught him in the china closet half an



<P>hour afterward, nearly squeezed the breath out of his little body



<P>with a tender embrace, instead of shaking him for being there,



<P>and why she followed up this novel performance by the unexpected



<P>gift of a big slice of bread and jelly, remained one of the problems



<P>over which Demi puzzled his small wits, and was forced to



<P>leave unsolved forever.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 44</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER FORTY-FOUR</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Please, Madam Mother, could you lend me my wife for half



<P>an hour?&nbsp; The luggage has come, and I've been making hay of



<P>Amy's Paris finery, trying to find some things I want," said



<P>Laurie, coming in the next day to find Mrs. Laurence sitting



<P>in her mother's lap, as if being made `the baby' again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly.&nbsp; Go, dear, I forgot that you have any home but



<P>this." And Mrs. March pressed the white hand that wore the wedding



<P>ring, as if asking pardon for her maternal covetousness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shouldn't have come over if I could have helped it, but



<P>I can't get on without my little woman any more than a..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Weathercock can without the wind," suggested Jo, as he



<P>paused for a simile.&nbsp; Jo had grown quite her own saucy self



<P>again since Teddy came home.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Exactly, for Amy keeps me pointing due west most of the



<P>time, with only an occasional whiffle round to the south, and



<P>I haven't had an easterly spell since I was married.&nbsp; Don't know



<P>anything about the north, but am altogether salubrious and balmy,



<P>hey, my lady?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Lovely weather so far.&nbsp; I don't know how long it will last,



<P>but I'm not afraid of storms, for I'm learning how to sail my



<P>ship.&nbsp; Come home, dear, and I'll find your bootjack.&nbsp; I suppose



<P>that's what you are rummaging after among my things.&nbsp; Men are so



<P>helpless, Mother," said Amy, with a matronly air, which delighted



<P>her husband.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What are you going to do with yourselves after you get settled?"



<P>asked Jo, buttoning Amy's cloak as she used to button her pinafores.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We have our plans.&nbsp; We don't mean to say much about them



<P>yet, because we are such very new brooms, but we don't intend to



<P>be idle.&nbsp; I'm going into business with a devotion that shall delight



<P>Grandfather, and prove to him that I'm not spoiled.&nbsp; I need



<P>something of the sort to keep me steady.&nbsp; I'm tired of dawdling,



<P>and mean to work like a man."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And Amy, what is she going to do?" asked Mrs. March, well



<P>pleased at Laurie's decision and the energy with which he spoke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"After doing the civil all round, and airing our best bonnet,



<P>we shall astonish you by the elegant hospitalities of our mansion,



<P>the brilliant society we shall draw about us, and the beneficial



<P>influence we shall exert over the world at large.&nbsp; That's about



<P>it, isn't it, Madame Recamier?" asked Laurie with a quizzical



<P>look at Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Time will show.&nbsp; Come away, Impertinence, and don't shock



<P>my family by calling me names before their faces," answered Amy,



<P>resolving that there should be a home with a good wife in it



<P>before she set up a salon as a queen of society.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How happy those children seem together!" observed Mr. March,



<P>finding it difficult to become absorbed in his Aristotle after



<P>the young couple had gone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, and I think it will last," added Mrs. March, with the



<P>restful expression of a pilot who has brought a ship safely into



<P>port.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know it will.&nbsp; Happy Amy!"&nbsp; And Jo sighed, then smiled



<P>brightly as Professor Bhaer opened the gate with an impatient



<P>push.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Later in the evening, when his mind had been set at rest



<P>about the bootjack, Laurie said suddenly to his wife, "Mrs.



<P>Laurence."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My Lord!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That man intends to marry our Jo!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope so, don't you, dear?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, my love, I consider him a trump, in the fullest sense



<P>of that expressive word, but I do wish he was a little younger



<P>and a good deal richer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Laurie, don't be too fastidious and worldly-minded.



<P>If they love one another it doesn't matter a particle how old



<P>they are nor how poor.&nbsp; Women never should marry for money..."



<P>Amy caught herself up short as the words escaped her, and looked



<P>at her husband, who replied, with malicious gravity...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly not, though you do hear charming girls say that



<P>they intend to do it sometimes.&nbsp; If my memory serves me, you



<P>once thought it your duty to make a rich match.&nbsp; That accounts,



<P>perhaps, for your marrying a good-for-nothing like me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, my dearest boy, don't, don't say that!&nbsp; I forgot you



<P>were rich when I said `Yes'.&nbsp; I'd have married you if you hadn't



<P>a penny, and I sometimes wish you were poor that I might show



<P>how much I love you."&nbsp; And Amy, who was very dignified in public



<P>and very fond in private, gave convincing proofs of the truth of



<P>her words.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You don't really think I am such a mercenary creature as



<P>I tried to be once, do you?&nbsp; It would break my heart if you



<P>didn't believe that I'd gladly pull in the same boat with you,



<P>even if you had to get your living by rowing on the lake."2

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Am I an idiot and a brute?&nbsp; How could I think so, when



<P>you refused a richer man for me, and won't let me give you half



<P>I want to now, when I have the right?&nbsp; Girls do it every day,



<P>poor things, and are taught to think it is their only salvation,



<P>but you had better lessons, and though I trembled for you at



<P>one time, I was not disappointed, for the daughter was true to



<P>the mother's teaching.&nbsp; I told Mamma so yesterday, and she



<P>looked as glad and grateful as if I'd given her a check for a



<P>million, to be spent in charity.&nbsp; You are not listening to my



<P>moral remarks, Mrs. Laurence."&nbsp; And Laurie paused, for Amy's



<P>eyes had an absent look, though fixed upon his face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I am, and admiring the mple in your chin at the



<P>same time.&nbsp; I don't wish to make you vain, but I must confess



<P>that I'm prouder of my handsome husband than of all his money.



<P>Don't laugh, but your nose is such a comfort to me." And Amy



<P>softly caressed the well-cut feature with artistic satisfaction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie had received many compliments in his life, but never



<P>one that suited him better, as he plainly showed though he did



<P>laugh at his wife's peculiar taste, while she said slowly, "May



<P>I ask you a question, dear?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course, you may."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shall you care if Jo does marry Mr. Bhaer?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, that's the trouble is it?&nbsp; I thought there was something



<P>in the dimple that didn't quite suit you.&nbsp; Not being a dog in the



<P>manger, but the happiest fellow alive, I assure you I can dance



<P>at Jo's wedding with a heart as light as my heels.&nbsp; Do you doubt



<P>it, my darling?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy looked up at him, and was satisfied.&nbsp; Her little jealous



<P>fear vanished forever, and she thanked him, with a face full of



<P>love and confidence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish we could do something for that capital old Professor.



<P>Couldn't we invent a rich relation, who shall obligingly die out



<P>there in Germany, and leave him a tidy little fortune?" said Laurie,



<P>when they began to pace up and down the long drawing room, arm in



<P>arm, as they were fond of doing, in memory of the chateau garden.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo would find us out, and spoil it all.&nbsp; She is very proud



<P>of him, just as he is, and said yesterday that she thought poverty



<P>was a beautiful thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bless her dear heart!&nbsp; She won't think so when she has a



<P>literary husband, and a dozen little professors and professorins



<P>to support.&nbsp; We won't interfere now, but watch our chance, and



<P>do them a good turn in spite of themselves.&nbsp; I owe Jo for a part



<P>of my education, and she believes in people's paying their honest



<P>debts, so I'll get round her in that way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How delightful it is to be able to help others, isn't it?



<P>That was always one of my dreams, to have the power of giving



<P>freely, and thanks to you, the dream has come true."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah, we'll do quantities of good, won't we?&nbsp; There's one



<P>sort of poverty that I particularly like to help.&nbsp; Out-and-out



<P>beggars get taken care of, but poor gentle folks fare badly,



<P>because they won't ask, and people don't dare to offer charity.



<P>Yet there are a thousand ways of helping them, if one only



<P>knows how to do it so delicately that it does not offend.&nbsp; I



<P>must say, I like to serve a decayed gentleman better than a



<P>blarnerying beggar.&nbsp; I suppose it's wrong, but I do, though it



<P>is harder."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Because it takes a gentleman to do it," added the other



<P>member of the domestic admiration society.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, I'm afraid I don't deserve that pretty compliment.



<P>But I was going to say that while I was dawdling about abroad, I



<P>saw a good many talented young fellows making all sorts of sacrifices,



<P>and enduring real hardships, that they might realize their dreams.



<P>Splendid fellows, some of them, working like heros,&nbsp; poor



<P>and friendless, but so full of courage, patience, and ambition



<P>that I was ashamed of myself, and longed to give them a right



<P>good lift.&nbsp; Those are people whom it's a satisfaction to help,



<P>for if they've got genius, it's an honor to be allowed to



<P>serve them, and not let it be lost or delayed for want of fuel



<P>to keep the pot boiling.&nbsp; If they haven't, it's a pleasure to



<P>comfort the poor souls, and keep them from despair when they find



<P>it out."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, indeed, and there's another class who can't ask, and



<P>who suffer in silence.&nbsp; I know something of it, for I belonged

to



<P>it before you made a princess of me, as the king does the beggarmaid



<P>in the old story.&nbsp; Ambitious girls have a hard time, Laurie,



<P>and often have to see youth, health, and precious opportunities



<P>go by, just for want of a little help at the right minute.&nbsp; People



<P>have been very kind to me, and whenever I see girls struggling



<P>along, as we used to do, I want to put out my hand and help them,



<P>as I was helped."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And so you shall, like an angel as you are!" cried Laurie,



<P>resolving, with a glow of philanthropic zeal, to found and endow



<P>an institution for the express benefit of young women with



<P>artistic tendencies.&nbsp; "Rich people have no right to sit down



<P>and enjoy themselves, or let their money accumulate for others



<P>to waste.&nbsp; It's not half so sensible to leave legacies when one



<P>dies as it is to use the money wisely while alive, and enjoy



<P>making one's fellow creatures happy with it.&nbsp; We'll have a good



<P>time ourselves, and add an extra relish to our own pleasure by



<P>giving other people a generous taste.&nbsp; Will you be a little



<P>Dorcal, going about emptying a big basket of comforts, and



<P>filling it up with good deeds?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"With all my heart, if you will be a brave St. Martin,



<P>stopping as you ride gallantly through the world to share your



<P>cloak with the beggar."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's a bargain, and we shall get the best of it!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So the young pair shook hands upon it, and then paced



<P>happily on again, feeling that their pleasant home was more



<P>homelike because they hoped to brighten other homes, believing



<P>that their own feet would walk more uprightly along the flowery



<P>path before them, if they smoothed rough ways for other feet,



<P>and feeling that their hearts were more closely knit together



<P>by a love which could tenderly remember those less blest than they.



<P>

<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <TITLE>Chapter 37</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER THIRTY-SEVEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At three o'clock in the afternoon, all the fashionable world



<P>at Nice may be seen on the Promenade des Anglais--a charming place,



<P>for the wide walk, bordered with palms, flowers, and tropical shrubs,



<P>is bounded on one side by the sea, on the other by the grand drive,



<P>lined with hotels and villas, while beyond lie orange orchards and



<P>the hills.&nbsp; Many nations are represented, many languages spoken,

many



<P>costumes worn, and on a sunny day the spectacle is as gay and brilliant



<P>as a carnival.&nbsp; Haughty English, lively French, sober Germans,



<P>handsome Spaniards, ugly Russians, meek Jews, free-and-easy Americans,



<P>all drive, sit, or saunter here, chatting over the news, and criticzing



<P>the latest celebrity who has arrived--Ristori or Dickens, Victor



<P>Emmanuel or the Queen of the Sandwich Islands.&nbsp; The equipages are

as



<P>varied as the company and attract as much attention, especially the



<P>low basket barouches in which ladies drive themselves, with a pair



<P>of dashing ponies, gay nets to keep their voluminous flounces from



<P>overflowing the diminutive vehicles, and little grooms on the perch



<P>behind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Along this walk, on Christmas Day, a tall young man walked



<P>slowly, with his hands behind him, and a somewhat absent expression



<P>of countenance.&nbsp; He looked like an Italian, was dressed like an



<P>Englishman, and had the independent air of an American--a combination



<P>which caused sundry pairs of feminine eyes to look approvingly



<P>after him, and sundry dandies in black velvet suits, with



<P>rose-colored neckties, buff gloves, and orange flowers in their



<P>buttonholes, to shrug their shoulders, and then envy him his inches.



<P>There were plenty of pretty faces to admire, but the young man took



<P>little notice of them, except to glance now and then at some blonde



<P>girl in blue.&nbsp; Presently he strolled out of the promenade and



<P>stood a moment at the crossing, as if undecided whether to go and



<P>listen to the band in the Jardin Publique, or to wander along the



<P>beach toward Castle Hill.&nbsp; The quick trot of ponies feet made him



<P>look up, as one of the little carriages, containing a single



<P>young lady, came rapidly down the street.&nbsp; The lady was young,



<P>blonde, and dressed in blue.&nbsp; He stared a minute, then his whole



<P>face woke up, and, waving his hat like a boy, he hurried forward



<P>to meet her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, Laurie, is it really you?&nbsp; I thought you'd never come!"



<P>cried Amy, dropping the reins and holding out both hands, to the



<P>great scandalization of a French mamma, who hastened her daughter's



<P>steps, lest she should be demoralized by beholding the free manners



<P>of these `mad English'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was detained by the way, but I promised to spend Christmas



<P>with you, and here I am."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How is your grandfather?&nbsp; When did you come?&nbsp; Where are you



<P>staying?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well--last night--at the Chauvain.&nbsp; I called at your



<P>hotel, but you were out."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have so much to say, I don't know where to begin!&nbsp; Get



<P>in and we can talk at our ease.&nbsp; I was going for a drive and



<P>longing for company.&nbsp; Flo's saving up for tonight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What happens then, a ball?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A Christmas party at out hotel.&nbsp; There are many Americans



<P>there, and they give it in honor of the day.&nbsp; You'll go with us,



<P>of course?&nbsp; Aunt will be charmed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you.&nbsp; Where now?" asked Laurie, leaning back and



<P>folding his arms, a proceeding which suited Amy, who preferred



<P>to drive, for her parasol whip and blue reins over the white



<P>ponies backs afforded her infinite satisfaction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm going to the bankers first for letters, and then to



<P>Castle Hill.&nbsp; The view is so lovely, and I like to feed the peacocks.



<P>Have you ever been there?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Often, years ago, but I don't mind having a look at it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now tell me all about yourself.&nbsp; The last I heard of you,



<P>your grandfather wrote that he expected you from Berlin."



<P>"Yes, I spent a month there and then joined him in Paris,



<P>where he has settled for the winter.&nbsp; He has friends there and



<P>finds plenty to amuse him, so I go and come, and we got on capitally."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's a sociable arrangement," said Amy, missing something



<P>in Laurie's manner, though she couldn't tell what.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, you see, he hates to travel, and I hate to keep still,



<P>so we each suit ourselves, and there is no trouble.&nbsp; I am often



<P>with him, and he enjoys my adventures, while I like to feel that



<P>someone is glad to see me when I get back from my wanderings.&nbsp;

Dirty



<P>old hole, isn't it?" he added, with a look of disgust as they drove



<P>along the boulevard to the Place Napoleon in the old city.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The dirt is picturesque, so I don't mind.&nbsp; The river and the



<P>hills are delicious, and these glimpses of the narrow cross streets



<P>are my delight.&nbsp; Now we shall have to wait for that procession

to



<P>pass.&nbsp; It's going to the Church of St. John."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While Laurie listlessly watched the procession of priests



<P>under their canopies, white-veiled nuns bearing lighted tapers,



<P>and some brotherhood in blue chanting as they walked, Amy watched



<P>him, and felt a new sort of shyness steal over her, for he was



<P>changed, and she could not find the merry-faced boy she left in



<P>the moody-looking man beside her.&nbsp; He was handsomer than ever and



<P>greatly improved, she thought, but now that the flush of pleasure



<P>at meeting her was over, he looked tired and spiritless--not sick,



<P>nor exactly unhappy, but older and graver than a year or two of



<P>prosperous life should have made him.&nbsp; She couldn't understand

it



<P>and did not venture to ask questions, so she shook her head and



<P>touched up her ponies, as the procession wound away across the



<P>arches of the Paglioni bridge and vanished in the church.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Que pensez-vous?" she said, airing her French, which had



<P>improved in quantity, if not in quality, since she came abroad.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That mademoiselle has made good use of her time, and the



<P>result is charming," replied Laurie, bowing with his hand on



<P>his heart and an admiring look.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She blushed with pleasure, but somehow the compliment did



<P>not satisfy her like the blunt praises he used to give her at



<P>home, when he promenaded round her on festival occasions, and



<P>tole her she was `altogether jolly', with a hearty smile and an



<P>approving pat on the head.&nbsp; She didn't like the new tone, for



<P>though not blase, it sounded indifferent in spite of the look.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If that's the way he's going to grow up, I wish he's stay



<P>a boy," she thought, with a curious sense of disappointment and



<P>discomfort, trying meantime to seem quite easy and gay.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At Avigdor's she found the precious home letters and, giving



<P>the reins to Laurie, read them luxuriously as they wound up the



<P>shady road between green hedges, where tea roses bloomed as freshly



<P>as in June.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Beth is very poorly, Mother says.&nbsp; I often think I ought to



<P>go home, but they all say `stay'.&nbsp; So I do, for I shall never have



<P>another chance like this," said Amy, looking sober over one page.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think you are right, there.&nbsp; You could do nothing at home,



<P>and it is a great comfort to them to know that you are well and



<P>happy, and enjoying so much, my dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He drew a little nearer, and looked more like his old self as



<P>he said that, and the fear that sometimes weighed on Amy's heart



<P>was lightened, for the look, the act, the brotherly `my dear',



<P>seemed to assure her that if any trouble did come, she would not



<P>be alone in a strange land.&nbsp; Presently she laughed and showed him



<P>a small sketch of Jo in her scribbling suit, with the bow rampantly



<P>erect upon her cap, and issuing from her mouth the words, `Genius



<P>burns!'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie smiled, took it, put it in his vest pocket `to keep it



<P>from blowing away', and listened with interest to the lively letter



<P>Amy read him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This will be a regularly merry Christmas to me, with presents



<P>in the morning, you and letters in the afternoon, and a party at



<P>night," said Amy, as they alighted among the ruins of the old fort,



<P>and a flock of splendid peacocks came trooping about them, tamely



<P>waiting to be fed.&nbsp; While Amy stood laughing on the bank above

him



<P>as she scattered crumbs to the brilliant birds, Laurie looked at her



<P>as she had looked at him, with a natural curiosity to see what



<P>changes time and absence had wrought.&nbsp; He found nothing to perplex



<P>or disappoint, much to admire and approve, for overlooking a few



<P>little affectations of speech and manner, she was as sprightly and



<P>graceful as ever, with the addition of that indescribable something



<P>in dress and bearing which we call elegance.&nbsp; Always mature for

her



<P>age, she had gained a certain aplomb in both carriage and conversation,



<P>which made her seem more of a woman of the world than she was, but



<P>her old petulance now and then showed itself, her strong will still



<P>held its own, and her native frankness was unspoiled by foreign



<P>polish.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie did not read all this while he watched her feed the peacocks,



<P>but he saw enough to satisfy and interest him, and carried



<P>away a pretty little picture of a bright-faced girl standing in the



<P>sunshine, which brought out the soft hue of her dress, the fresh



<P>color of her cheeks, the golden gloss of her hair, and made her a



<P>prominent figure in the pleasant scene.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As they came up onto the stone plateau that crowns the hill,



<P>Amy waved her hand as if welcoming him to her favorite haunt, and



<P>said, pointing here and there, "Do you remember the Cathedral and



<P>the Corso, the fishermen dragging their nets in the bay, and the



<P>lovely road to Villa Franca, Schubert's Tower, just below, and best



<P>of all, that speck far out to sea which they say ils Corsica?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I remember.&nbsp; It's not much changed," he answered without



<P>enthusiasm.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What Jo would give for a sight of that famous speck!" said



<P>Amy, feeling in good spirits and anxious to see him so also.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," was all he said, but he turned and strained his eyes to



<P>see the island which a greater usurper than even Napoleon now made



<P>interesting in his sight.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Take a good look at it for her sake, and then come and tell



<P>me what you have been doing with yourself all this while," said



<P>Amy, seating herself, ready for a good talk.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But she did not get it, for though he joined her and answered



<P>all her questions freely, she could only learn that he had roved



<P>about the Continent and been to Greece.&nbsp; So after idling away an



<P>hour, they drove home again, and having paid his respects to Mrs.



<P>Carrol, Laurie left them, promising to return in the evening.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It must be recorded of Amy that she deliberately prinked that



<P>night.&nbsp; Time and absence had done its work on both the young people.



<P>She had seen her old friend in a new light, not as `our boy', but as



<P>a handsome and agreeable man, and she was conscious of a very natural



<P>desire to find favor in his sight.&nbsp; Amy knew her good points, and



<P>made the most of them with the taste and skill which is a fortune to



<P>a poor and pretty woman.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tarlatan and tulle were cheap at Nice, so she enveloped herself



<P>in them on such occasions, and following the sensible English fashion



<P>of simple dress for young girls, got up charming little toilettes



<P>with fresh flowers, a few trinkets, and all manner of dainty devices,



<P>which were both inexpensive and effective.&nbsp; It must be confessed



<P>that the artist sometimes got possession of the woman, and indulged



<P>in antique coiffures, statuesque attitudes, and classic draperies.



<P>But, dear heart, we all have out little weaknesses, and find it



<P>easy to pardon such in the young, who satisfy our eyes with their



<P>comeliness, and keep our hearts merry with their artless vanities.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do want him to think I look well, and tell them so at home,"



<P>said Amy to herself, as she put on Flo's old white silk ball dress,



<P>and covered it with a cloud of fresh illusion, out of which her



<P>white shoulders and golden head emerged with a most artistic effect.



<P>Her hair she had the sense to let alone, after gathering up the



<P>thick waves and curls into a Hebe-like knot at the back of her head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's not the fashion, but it's becoming, and I can't afford to



<P>make a fright of myself," she used to say, when advised to frizzle,



<P>puff, or braid, as the latest style commanded.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Having no ornaments fine enough for this important occasion,



<P>Amy looped her fleecy skirts with rosy clusters of azalea, and



<P>framed the white shoulders in delicate green vines.&nbsp; Remembering



<P>the painted boots, she surveyed her white satin slippers with



<P>girlish satisfaction, and chassed down the room, admiring her



<P>aristocratic feet all by herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My new fan just matches my flowers, my gloves fit to a charm,



<P>and the real lace on Aunt's mouchoir gives an air to my whole dress.



<P>If I only had a classical nose and mouth I should be perfectly happy,"



<P>she said, surveying herself with a critical eye and a candle in



<P>each hand.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In spite of this affliction, she looked unusually gay and



<P>graceful as she glided away.&nbsp; She seldom ran--it did not suit her



<P>style, she thought, for being tall, the stately and Junoesque was



<P>more appropriate than the sportive or piquante.&nbsp; She walked up

and



<P>down the long saloon while waiting for Laurie, and once arranged



<P>herself under the chandelier, which had a good effect upon her



<P>hair, then she thought better of it, and went away to the other



<P>end of the room, as if ashamed of the girlish desire to have the



<P>first view a propitious one.&nbsp; It so happened that she could not



<P>have done a better thing, for Laurie came in so quietly she



<P>did not hear him, and as she stood at the distant window, with



<P>her head half turned and one hand gathering up her dress, the



<P>slender, white figure against the red curtains was as effective



<P>as a well-placed statue.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good evening, Diana!" said Laurie, with the look of satisfaction



<P>she liked to see in his eyes when they rested on her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good evening, Apollo!" she answered, smiling back at him,



<P>for he too looked unusually debonair, and the thought of



<P>entering the ballroom on the arm of such a personable man



<P>caused Amy to pity the four plain Misses Davis from the bottom



<P>of her heart.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here are your flowers.&nbsp; I arranged them myself, remembering



<P>that you didn't like what Hannah calls a `sot-bookay', said



<P>Laurie, handing her a delicate nosegay, in a holder that she



<P>had long coveted as she daily passed it in Cardiglia's window.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How kind you are!" she exclaimed gratefully.&nbsp; "If I'd



<P>known you were coming I'd have had something ready for you today,



<P>though not as pretty as this, I'm afraid."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you.&nbsp; It isn't what it should be, but you have improved

it,"



<P>he added, as she snapped the silver bracelet on her wrist.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Please don't."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought you liked that sort of thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not from you, it doesn't sound natural, and I like your



<P>old bluntness better."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad of it," he answered, with a look of relief, then



<P>buttoned her gloves for her, and asked if his tie was straight,



<P>just as he used to do when they went to parties together at home.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The company assembled in the long salle a manger that



<P>evening was such as one sees nowhere but on the Continent.&nbsp; The



<P>hospitable Americans had invited every acquaintance they had



<P>in Nice, and having no prejudice against titles, secured a few



<P>to add luster to their Christmas ball.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A Russian prince condescended to sit in a corner for an



<P>hour and talk with a massive lady, dressed like Hamlet's mother



<P>in black velvet with a pearl bridle under her chin.&nbsp; A Polish



<P>count, aged eighteen, devoted himself to the ladies, who pronounced



<P>him, `a fascinating dear', and a German Serene Something,



<P>having come to supper alone, roamed vaguely about, seeking what



<P>he might devour.&nbsp; Baron Rothschild's private secretary, a largenosed



<P>Jew in tight boots, affably beamed upon the world, as if



<P>his master's name crowned him with a golden halo.&nbsp; A stout



<P>Frenchman, who knew the Emperor, came to indulge his mania for



<P>dancing, and Lady de Jones, a British matron, adorned the scene



<P>with her little family of eight.&nbsp; Of course, there were many



<P>light-footed, shrill-voiced American girls, handsome, lifeless-looking



<P>English ditto, and a few plain but piquante French demoiselles,



<P>likewise the usual set of traveling young gentlemen



<P>who disported themselves gaily, while mammas of all nations



<P>lined the walls and smiled upon them benignly when they danced



<P>with their daughters.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Any young girl can imagine Amy's state of mind when she



<P>`took the stage' that night, leaning on Laurie's arm.&nbsp; She



<P>knew she looked well, she loved to dance, she felt that her



<P>foot was on her native heath in a ballroom, and enjoyed the



<P>delightful sense of power which comes when young girls first



<P>discover the new and lovely kingdom they are born to rule by



<P>virtue of beauty, youth, and womanhood.&nbsp; She did pity the



<P>Davis girls, who were awkward, plain, and destitute of escort,



<P>except a grim papa and three grimmer maiden aunts, and she



<P>bowed to them in her friendliest manner as she passed, which



<P>was good of her, as it permitted them to see her dress, and



<P>burn with curiosity to know who her distinguished-looking



<P>friend might be.&nbsp; With the first burst of the band, Amy's



<P>color rose, her eyes began to sparkle, and her feet to tap the



<P>floor impatiently, for she danced well and wanted Laurie to



<P>know it.&nbsp; Therefore the shock she received can better be



<P>imagined than described, when he said in a perfectly tranquil



<P>tone, "Do you care to dance?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"One usually does at a ball."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her amazed look and quick answer caused Laurie to repair



<P>his error as fast as possible.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I meant the first dance.&nbsp; May I have the honor?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can give you one if I put off the Count.&nbsp; He dances



<P>devinely, but he will excuse me, as you are an old friend," said



<P>Amy, hoping that the name would have a good effect, and show



<P>Laurie that she was not to be trifled with.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nice little boy, but rather a short Pole to support .&nbsp; ..



<P>A daughter of the gods,



<P>Devinely tall, and most devinely fair,"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>was all the satisfaction she got, however.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The set in which they found themselves was composed of



<P>English, and Amy was compelled to walk decorously through a



<P>cotillion, feeling all the while as if she could dance the



<P>tarantella with relish.&nbsp; Laurie resigned her to the `nice little



<P>boy', and went to do his duty to Flo, without securing Amy for



<P>the joys to come, which reprehensible want of forethought was



<P>properly punished, for she immediately engaged herself till



<P>supper, meaning to relent if he then gave any signs penitence.



<P>She showed him her ball book with demure satisfaction when he



<P>strolled instead of rushed up to claim her for the next, a



<P>glorious polka redowa.&nbsp; But his polite regrets didn't impose



<P>upon her, and when she galloped away with the Count, she saw



<P>Laurie sit down by her aunt with an actual expression of relief.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That was unpardonable, and Amy took no more notice of him



<P>for a long while, except a word now and then when she came to



<P>her chaperon between the dances for a necessary pin or a



<P>moment's rest.&nbsp; Her anger had a good effect, however, for she



<P>hid it under a smiling face, and seemed unusually blithe and



<P>brilliant.&nbsp; Laurie's eyes followed her with pleasure, for she



<P>neither romped nor sauntered, but danced with spirit and



<P>grace, making the delightsome pastime what it should be.&nbsp; He



<P>very naturally fell to studying her from this new point of



<P>view, and before the evening was half over, had decided that



<P>`little Amy was going to make a very charming woman'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a lively scene, for soon the spirit of the social



<P>season took possession of everyone, and Christmas merriment made



<P>all faces shine, hearts happy, and heels light.&nbsp; The musicians



<P>fiddled, tooted, and banged as if they enjoyed it, everybody



<P>danced who could, and those who couldn't admired their



<P>neighbors with uncommon warmth.&nbsp; The air was dark with Davises,



<P>and many Jones gamboled like a flock of young giraffes.&nbsp; The



<P>golden secretary darted through the room like a meteor with



<P>a dashing frenchwoman who carped the floor with her pink satin



<P>train.&nbsp; The serene Teuton found the supper table and was happy,



<P>eating steadily through the bill of fare, and dismayed the



<P>garcons by the ravages he committed.&nbsp; But the Emperor's friend



<P>covered himself with glory, for he danced everything, whether



<P>he knew it or not, and introduced impromptu pirouettes when the



<P>figures bewildered him.&nbsp; The boyish abandon of that stout man



<P>was charming to behold, for though he `carried weight', he



<P>danced like an India-rubber ball.&nbsp; He ran, he flew, he pranced,



<P>his face glowed, his bald head shown, his coattails waved wildly,



<P>his pumps actually twinkled in the air, and when the music



<P>stopped, he wiped the drops from his brow, and beamed upon his



<P>fellow men like a French Pickwick without glasses.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy and her Pole distinguished themselves by equal enthusiasm



<P>but more graceful agility, and Laurie found himself



<P>involuntarily keeping time to the rhythmic rise and fall of the



<P>white slippers as they flew by as indefatigably as if winged.



<P>When little Vladimir finally relinquished her, with assurances



<P>that he was `desolated to leave so early', she was ready to



<P>rest, and see how her recreant knight had borne his punishment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It had been successful, for at three-and-twenty, blighted



<P>affections find a balm in friendly society, and young nerves



<P>will thrill, young blood dance, and healthy young spirits rise,



<P>when subjected to the enchantment of beauty, light, music, and



<P>motion.&nbsp; Laurie had a waked-up look as he rose to give her his



<P>seat, and when he hurried away to bring her some supper, she



<P>said to herself, with a satisfied smile, "Ah, I thought that



<P>would do him good!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You look like Balzac's `FEMME PEINTE PAR ELLE-NENE',"



<P>he said, as he fanned her with one hand and held her coffee



<P>cup in the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My rouge won't come off." And Amy rubbed her brilliant



<P>cheek, and showed him her white glove with a sober simplicity



<P>that made him laugh outright.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What do you call this stuff?" he asked, touching a fold



<P>of her dress that had blown over his knee.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Illusion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good name for it.&nbsp; It's very pretty--new thing, isn't it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's as old as the hills.&nbsp; You have seen it on dozens of



<P>girls, and you never found out that it was pretty till now?



<P>Stupide!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never saw it on you before, which accounts for the mistake,



<P>you see."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"None of that, it is forbidden.&nbsp; I'd rather take coffee



<P>than compliments just now.&nbsp; No, don't lounge, it makes me nervous."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie sat bold upright, and meekly took her empty plate



<P>feeling an odd sort of pleasure in having `little Amy' order



<P>him about, for she had lost her shyness now, and felt an



<P>irrestible desire to trample on him, as girls have a delightful



<P>way of doing when lords of creation show any signs of subjection.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where did you learn all this sort of thing?" he asked with



<P>a quizzical look.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As `this sort of thing' is rather a vague expression, would



<P>you kindly explain?" returned Amy, knowing perfectly well what he



<P>meant, but wickedly leaving him to describe what is indescribable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well--the general air, the style, the self-possession, the--



<P>the--illusion--you know", laughed Laurie, breaking down and helping



<P>himself out of his quandary with the new word.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy was gratified, but of course didn't show it, and demurely



<P>answered, "Foreign life polishes one in spite of one's self.&nbsp; I



<P>study as well as play, and as for this"--with a little gesture



<P>toward her dress--"why, tulle is cheap, posies to be had for



<P>nothing, and I am used to making the most of my poor little things."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy rather regretted that last sentence, fearing it wasn't in



<P>good taste, but Laurie liked her better for it, and found himself



<P>both admiring and respecting the brave patience that made the most



<P>of opportunity, and the cheerful spirit that covered poverty with



<P>flowers.&nbsp; Amy did not know why he looked at her so kindly, now



<P>why he filled up her book with his own name, and devoted himself



<P>to her for the rest of the evening in the most delightful manner,



<P>but the impulse that wrought this agreeable change was the result



<P>of one of the new impressions which both of them were unconsciously



<P>giving and receiving.



<P>

   <TITLE>Chapter 23</TITLE>
