   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 08</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER EIGHT</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Girls, where are you going?" asked Amy, coming into their



<P>room one Saturday afternoon, and finding them getting ready to



<P>go out with an air of secrecy which excited her curiosity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never mind.&nbsp; Little girls shouldn't ask questions," returned



<P>Jo sharply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now if there is anything mortifying to out feelings when we



<P>are young, it is to be told that, and to be bidden to "run away,



<P>dear" is still more trying to us.&nbsp; Amy bridled up at this insult,



<P>and determined to find out the secret, if she teased for an hour.



<P>Turning to Meg, who never refused her anything very long, she said



<P>coaxingly, "Do tell me! I should think you might let me go, too,



<P>for Beth is fussing over her piano, and I haven't got anything to



<P>do, and am so lonely."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't, dear, because you aren't invited," began Meg, but



<P>Jo broke in impatiently, "Now, Meg, be quiet or you will spoil it



<P>all.&nbsp; You can't go, Amy, so don't be a baby and whine about it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are going somewhere with Laurie, I know you are.&nbsp; You



<P>were whispering and laughing together on the sofa last night, and



<P>you stopped when I came in.&nbsp; Aren't you going with him?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, we are.&nbsp; Now do be still, and stop bothering."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy held her tongue, but used her eyes, and saw Meg slip a



<P>fan into her pocket.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know!&nbsp; I know!&nbsp; You're going to the theater to see the



<P>SEVEN CASTLES!" she cried, adding resolutely, "and I shall go,



<P>for Mother said I might see it, and I've got my rag money, and



<P>it was mean not to tell me in time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Just listen to me a minute, and be a good child," said Meg



<P>soothingly.&nbsp; "Mother doesn't wish you to go this week, because



<P>your eyes are not well enough yet to bear the light of this



<P>fairy piece.&nbsp; Next week you can go with Beth and Hannah, and



<P>have a nice time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't like that half as well as going with you and Laurie.



<P>Please let me.&nbsp; I've been sick with this cold so long, and shut



<P>up, I'm dying for some fun.&nbsp; Do, Meg!&nbsp; I'll be ever so good,"



<P>pleaded Amy, looking as pathetic as she could.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Suppose we take her.&nbsp; I don't believe Mother would mind,



<P>if we bundle her up well," began Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If she goes I shan't, and if I don't, Laurie won't like it,



<P>and it will be very rude, after he invited only us, to go and



<P>drag in Amy.&nbsp; I should think she'd hate to poke herself where



<P>she isn't wanted," said Jo crossly, for she disliked the trouble



<P>of overseeing a fidgety child when she wanted to enjoy herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her tone and manner angered Amy, who began to put her boots



<P>on, saying, in her most aggravating way, "I shall go.&nbsp; Meg says

I



<P>may, and if I pay for myself, Laurie hasn't anything to do with it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You can't sit with us, for our seats are reserved, and you



<P>mustn't sit alone, so Laurie will give you his place, and that



<P>will spoil our pleasure.&nbsp; Or he'll get another seat for you, and



<P>that isn't proper when you weren't asked.&nbsp; You shan't stir a



<P>step, so you may just stay where you are," scolded Jo, crosser



<P>than ever, having just pricked her finger in her hurry.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sitting on the floor with one boot on, Amy began to cry



<P>and Meg to reason with her, when Laurie called from below, and



<P>the two girls hurried down, leaving their sister wailing.&nbsp; For



<P>now and then she forgot her grown-up ways and acted like a



<P>spoiled child.&nbsp; Just as the party was setting out, Amy called



<P>over the banisters in a threatening tone, "You'll be sorry for



<P>this, Jo March, see if you ain't."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Fiddlesticks!" returned Jo, slamming the door.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They had a charming time, for THE SEVEN CASTLES OF THE



<P>DIAMOND LAKE was as brilliant and wonderful as heart could wish.



<P>But in spite of the comical red imps, sparkling elves, and the



<P>gorgeous princes and princesses, Jo's pleasure had a drop of



<P>bitterness in it.&nbsp; The fairy queen's yellow curls reminded her



<P>of Amy, and between the acts she amused herself with wondering



<P>what her sister would do to make her `sorry for it'.&nbsp; She and



<P>Amy had had many lively skirmishes in the course of their lives,



<P>for both had quick tempers and were apt to be violent when fairly



<P>roused.&nbsp; Amy teased Jo, and Jo irritated Amy, and semioccasional



<P>explosions occurred, of which both were much ashamed afterward.



<P>Although the oldest, Jo had the least self-control, and had hard



<P>times trying to curb the fiery spirit which was continually getting



<P>her into trouble.&nbsp; Her anger never lasted long, and having humbly



<P>confessed her fault, she sincerely repented and tried to do better.



<P>Her sisters used to say that they rather liked to get Jo into a



<P>fury because she was such an angel afterward.&nbsp; Poor Jo tried



<P>desperately to be good, but her bosom enemy was always ready to



<P>flame up and defeat her, and it took years of patient effort to



<P>subdue it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When they got home, they found amy reading in the parlor.



<P>She assumed an injured air as they came in, never lifted her eyes



<P>from her book, or asked a single question.&nbsp; Perhaps curiosity



<P>might have conquered resentment, if Beth had not been there to



<P>inquire and receive a glowing description of the play.&nbsp; On going



<P>up to put away her best hat, Jo's first look was toward the



<P>bureau, for in their last quarrel Amy had soothed her feelings



<P>by turning Jo's top drawer upside down on the floor.&nbsp; Everything



<P>was in its place, however, and after a hasty glance into her



<P>various closets, bags, and boxes, Jo decided that Amy had



<P>forgiven and forgotten her wrongs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There Jo was mistaken, for next day she made a discovery



<P>which produced a tempest.&nbsp; Meg, Beth, and Amy were sitting together,



<P>late in the afternoon, when Jo burst into the room, looking excited



<P>and demanding breathlessly, "Has anyone taken my book?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg and Beth said, "No." at once, and looked surprised.&nbsp; Amy



<P>poked the fire and said nothing.&nbsp; Jo saw her color rise and was



<P>down upon her in a minute.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Amy, you've got it!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I haven't."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You know where it is, then!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I don't."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's a fib!" cried Jo, taking her by the shoulders, and



<P>looking fierce enough to frighten a much braver child than Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It isn't.&nbsp; I haven't got it, don't know where it is now, and



<P>don't care."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You know something about it, and you'd better tell at once,



<P>or I'll make you."&nbsp; And Jo gave her a slight shake.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Scold as much as you like, you'll never see your silly old



<P>book again," cried Amy, getting excited in her turn.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"why not?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I burned it up."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What!&nbsp; My little book I was so fond of, and worked over, and



<P>meant to finish before Father got home?&nbsp; Have you really burned

it?"



<P>said Jo, turning very pale, while her eyes kindled and her hands



<P>clutched Amy nervously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I did!&nbsp; I told you I'd make you pay for being so cross



<P>yesterday, and I have, so..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy got no farther, for Jo's hot temper mastered her, and



<P>she shook Amy till her teeth chattered in her head, crying in a



<P>passion of grief and anger...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You wicked, wicked girl!&nbsp; I never can write it again, and



<P>I'll never forgive you as long as I live."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg flew to rescue Amy, and Beth to pacify Jo, but Jo was



<P>quite beside herself, and with a parting box on her sister's ear,



<P>she rushed out of the room up to the old sofa in the garret, and



<P>finished her fight alone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The storm cleared up below, for Mrs. March came home, and,



<P>having heard the story, soon brought Amy to a sense of the wrong



<P>she had done her sister.&nbsp; Jo's book was the pride of her heart,



<P>and was regarded by her family as a literary sprout of great



<P>promise.&nbsp; It was only half a dozen little fairy tales, but Jo



<P>had worked over them patiently, putting her whole heart into



<P>her work, hoping to make something good enough to print.&nbsp; She



<P>had just copied them with great care, and had destroyed the old



<P>manuscript, so that Amy's bonfire had consumed the loving work



<P>of several years.&nbsp; It seemed a small loss to others, but to Jo



<P>it was a dreadful calamity, and she felt that it never could be



<P>made up to her.&nbsp; Beth mourned as for a departed kitten, and Meg



<P>refused to defend her pet.&nbsp; Mrs. March looked grave and grieved,



<P>and Amy felt that no one would love her till she had asked pardon



<P>for the act which she now regretted more than any of them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the tea bell rang, Jo appeared, looking so grim and



<P>unapproachable that it took all Amy's courage to say meekly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Please forgive me, Jo.&nbsp; I'm very, very sorry."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never shall forgive you," was Jo's stern answer, and



<P>from that moment she ignored Amy entirely.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No one spoke of the great trouble, not even Mrs. March, for



<P>all had learned by experience that when Jo was in that mood words



<P>were wasted, and the wisest course was to wait till some little



<P>accident, or her own generous nature, softened Jo's resentment



<P>and healed the breach.&nbsp; It was not a happy evening, for though



<P>they sewed as usual, while their mother read aloud from Bremer,



<P>Scott, or Edgeworth, something was wanting, and the sweet home



<P>peace was disturbed.&nbsp; They felt this most when singing time came,



<P>for Beth could only play, Jo stood dumb as a stone, and Amy broke



<P>down, so Meg and Mother sang alone.&nbsp; But in spite of their efforts



<P>to be as cheery as larks, the flutelike voices did not seem to



<P>chord as well as usual, and all felt out of tune.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As Jo received her good-night kiss, Mrs. March whispered gently,



<P>"My dear, don't let the sun go down upon your anger.&nbsp; Forgive each



<P>other, help each other, and begin again tomorrow."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo wanted to lay her head down on that motherly bosom, and



<P>cry her grief and anger all away, but tears were an unmanly



<P>weakness, and she felt so deeply injured that she really couldn't



<P>quite forgive yet.&nbsp; So she winked hard, shook her head, and said



<P>gruffly because Amy was listening, "It was an abominable thing,



<P>and she doesn't deserve to be forgiven."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With that she marched off to bed, and there was no merry



<P>or confidential gossip that night.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy was much offended that her overtures of peace had been



<P>repulsed, and began to wish she had not humbled herself, to feel



<P>more injured than ever, and to plume herself on her superior



<P>virtue in a way which was particularly exasperating.&nbsp; Jo still



<P>looked like a thunder cloud, and nothing went well all day.&nbsp; It



<P>was bitter cold in the morning, she dropped her precious turnover



<P>in the gutter, Aunt March had an attack of the fidgets, Meg was



<P>sensitive, Beth would look grieved and wistful when she got home,



<P>and Amy kept making remarks about people who were always talking



<P>about being good and yet wouldn't even try when other people set



<P>them a virtuous example.



<P>"Everybody is so hateful, I'll ask Laurie to go skating.&nbsp; He



<P>is always kind and jolly, and will put me to rights, I know," said



<P>Jo to herself, and off she went.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy heard the clash of skates, and looked out with an impatient



<P>exclamation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There!&nbsp; She promised I should go next time, for this is the



<P>last ice we shall have.&nbsp; But it's no use to ask such a crosspatch



<P>to take me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't say that.&nbsp; You were very naughty, and it is hard to



<P>forgive the loss of her precious little book, but I think she



<P>might do it now, and I guess she will, if you try her at the



<P>right minute," said Meg.&nbsp; "Go after them.&nbsp; Don't say anything

till



<P>Jo has got good-natured with Laurie, than take a quiet minute and



<P>just kiss her, or do some kind thing, and I'm sure she'll be



<P>friends again with all her heart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll try," said Amy, for the advice suited her, and after a



<P>flurry to get ready, she ran after the friends, who were just



<P>disappearing over the hill.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was not far to the river, but both were ready before Amy



<P>reached them.&nbsp; Jo saw her coming, and turned her back.&nbsp; Laurie

did



<P>not see, for he was carefully skating along the shore, sounding the



<P>ice, for a warm spell had preceded the cold snap.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll go on to the first bend, and see if it's all right before



<P>we begin to race," Amy heard him say, as he shot away, looking like



<P>a young Russian in his fur-trimmed coat and cap.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo heard Amy panting after her run, stamping her feet and



<P>blowing on her fingers as she tried to put her skates on, but Jo



<P>never turned and went slowly zigzagging down the river, taking a



<P>bitter, unhappy sort of satisfaction in her sister's troubles.



<P>She had cherished her anger till it grew strong and took possession



<P>of her, as evil thoughts and feelings always do unless cast out at



<P>once.&nbsp; As Laurie turned the bend, he shouted back...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Keep near the shore.&nbsp; It isn't safe in the middle."



<P>Jo heard, but Amy was struggling to her feet and did not catch



<P>a word.&nbsp; Jo glanced over her shoulder, and the little demon she

was



<P>harboring said in her ear...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No matter whether she heard or not, let her take care of



<P>herself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie had vanished round the bend, Jo was just at the turn,



<P>and Amy, far behind, striking out toward the the smoother ice in



<P>the middle of the river.&nbsp; For a minute Jo stood still with a



<P>strange feeling in her heart, then she resolved to go on, but



<P>something held and turned her round, just in time to see Amy throw



<P>up her hands and go down, with a sudden crash of rotten ice, the



<P>splash of water, and a cry that made Jo's heart stand still with



<P>fear.&nbsp; She tried to call Laurie, but her voice was gone.&nbsp;

She tried



<P>to rush forward, but her feet seemed to have no strength in them,



<P>and for a second, she could only stand motionless, staring with a



<P>terror-stricken face at the little blue hood above the black water.



<P>Something rushed swiftly by her, and Laurie's voice cried out...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bring a rail.&nbsp; Quick, quick!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How she did it, she never knew, but for the next few minutes



<P>she worked as if possessed, blindly obeying Laurie, who was quite



<P>self-possessed, and lying flat, held Amy up by his arm and hockey



<P>stick till Jo dragged a rail from the fence, and together they



<P>got the child out, more frightened than hurt.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now then, we must walk her home as fast as we can.&nbsp; Pile our



<P>things on her, while I get off these confounded skates," cried



<P>Laurie, wrapping his coat round Amy, and tugging away at the straps



<P>which never seemed so intricate before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Shivering, dripping, and crying, they got Amy home, and after



<P>an exciting time of it, she fell asleep, rolled in blankets before



<P>a hot fire.&nbsp; During the bustle Jo had scarcely spoken but flown



<P>about, looking pale and wild, with her things half off, her dress torn,



<P>and her hands cut and bruised by ice and rails and refractory buckles.



<P>When Amy was comfortably asleep, the house quiet,&nbsp; and Mrs. March

sitting



<P>by the bed, she called Jo to her and began to bind up the hurt hands.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Are you sure she is safe?" whispered Jo, looking remorsefully



<P>at the golden head, which might have been swept away from her sight



<P>forever under the treacherous ice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Quite safe, dear.&nbsp; she is not hurt, and won't even take cold,



<P>I think, you were so sensible in covering and getting her home



<P>quickly," replied her mother cheerfully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Laurie did it all.&nbsp; I only let her go.&nbsp; Mother, if she should



<P>die, it would be my fault."&nbsp; And Jo dropped down beside the bed

in



<P>a passion of penitent tears, telling all that had happened, bitterly



<P>condemning her hardness of heart, and sobbing out her gratitude for



<P>being spared the heavy punishment which might have come upon her.



<P>"It's my dreadful temper!&nbsp; I try to cure it, I think I have,



<P>and then it breaks out worse than ever.&nbsp; OH, Mother, what shall

I



<P>do?&nbsp; What shall I do?" cried poor Jo, in despair.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Watch and pray, dear, never get tired of trying, and never



<P>think it is impossible to conquer your fault," said Mrs. March,



<P>drawing the blowzy head to her shoulder and kissing the wet cheek



<P>so tenderly that Jo cried even harder.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You don't know, you can't guess how bad it is!&nbsp; It seems as



<P>if I could do anything when I'm in a passion.&nbsp; I get so savage,

I



<P>could hurt anyone and enjoy it.&nbsp; I'm afraid I shall do something



<P>dreadful some day, and spoil my life, and make everybody hate me.



<P>Oh, Mother, help me, do help me!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will, my child, I will.&nbsp; Don't cry so bitterly, but remember



<P>this day, and resolve with all your soul that you will never know



<P>another like it.&nbsp; Jo, dear, we all have our temptations, some far



<P>greater than yours, and it often takes us all our lives to conquer



<P>them.&nbsp; You think your temper is the worst in the world, but mine



<P>used to be just like it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yours, Mother?&nbsp; Why, you are never angry!"&nbsp; And for the



<P>moment Jo forgot remorse in surprise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've been trying to cure it for forty years, and have only



<P>succeeded in controlling it.&nbsp; I am angry nearly every day of my



<P>life, Jo, but I have learned not to show it, and I still hope to



<P>learn not to feel it, though it may take me another forty years



<P>to do so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The patience and the humility of the face she loved so well



<P>was a better lesson to Jo than the wisest lecture, the sharpest



<P>reproof.&nbsp; She felt comforted at once by the sympathy and confidence



<P>given her.&nbsp; The knowledge that her mother had a fault like



<P>hers, and tried to mend it, made her own easier to bear and



<P>strengthened her resolution to cure it, though forty years seemed



<P>rather a long time to watch and pray to a girl of fifteen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mother, are you angry when you fold your lips tight together



<P>and go out of the room sometimes, when Aunt March scolds or people



<P>worry you?" asked Jo, feeling nearer and dearer to her mother



<P>than ever before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I've learned to check the hasty words that rise to my



<P>lips, and when I feel that they mean to break out against my will,



<P>I just go away for a minute, and give myself a little shake for



<P>being so weak and wicked," answered Mrs. March with a sigh and a



<P>smile, as she smoothed and fastened up Jo's disheveled hair.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How did you learn to keep still?&nbsp; That is what troubles me,



<P>for the sharp words fly out before I know what I'm about, and the



<P>more I say the worse I get, till it's a pleasure to hurt people's



<P>feelings and say dreadful things.&nbsp; Tell me how you do it, Marmee



<P>dear."



<P>"My good mother used to help me..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As you do us..." interrupted Jo, with a grateful kiss.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I lost her when I was a little older than you are, and



<P>for years had to struggle on alone, for I was too proud to confess



<P>my weakness to anyone else.&nbsp; I had a hard time, Jo, and shed a

good



<P>many bitter tears over my failures, for in spite of my efforts I



<P>never seemed to get on.&nbsp; Then your father came, and I was so happy



<P>that i found it easy to be good.&nbsp; But by-and-by, when I had four



<P>little daughters round me and we were poor, then the old trouble



<P>began again, for I am not patient by nature, and it tried me very



<P>much to see my children wanting anything."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor Mother!&nbsp; What helped you then?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your father, Jo.&nbsp; He never loses patience, never doubts or



<P>complains, but always hopes, and works and waits so cheerfully



<P>that one is ashamed to do otherwise before him.&nbsp; He helped and



<P>comforted me, and showed me that I must try to practice all the



<P>virtues I would have my little girls possess, for I was their



<P>example.&nbsp; It was easier to try for your sakes than for my own.



<P>A startled or surprised look from one of you when I spoke sharply



<P>rebuked me more than any words could have done, and the love,



<P>respect, and confidence of my children was the sweetest reward I



<P>could receive for my efforts to be the woman I would have them



<P>copy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, Mother, if I'm ever half as good as you, I shall be



<P>satisfied," cried Jo, much touched.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope you will be a great deal better, dear, but you must



<P>keep watch over your `bosom enemy', as father calls it, or it



<P>may sadden, if not spoil your life.&nbsp; You have had a warning.



<P>Remember it, and try with heart and soul to master this quick



<P>temper, before it brings you greater sorrow and regret than you



<P>have known today."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will try, Mother, I truly will.&nbsp; But you must help me,



<P>remind me, and keep me from flying out.&nbsp; I used to see Father



<P>sometimes put his finger on his lips, and look at you with a



<P>very kind but sober face, and you always folded your lips tight



<P>and went away.&nbsp; Was he reminding you then?" asked Jo softly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes.&nbsp; I asked him to help me so, and he never forgot it,



<P>but saved me from many a sharp word by that little gesture



<P>and kind look."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo saw that her mother's eyes filled and her lips trembled



<P>as she spoke, and fearing that she had said too much, she



<P>whispered anxiously, "Was it wrong to watch you and to speak of



<P>it?&nbsp; I didn't mean to be rude, but it's so comfortable to say all



<P>I think to you, and feel so safe and happy here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mu Jo, you may say anything to your mother, for it is my



<P>greatest happiness and pride to feel that my girls confide in me



<P>and know how much I love them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought I'd grieved you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, dear, but speaking of Father reminded me how much I



<P>miss him, how much I owe him, and how faithfully I should watch



<P>and work to keep his little daughters safe and good for him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yet you told him to go, Mother, and didn't cry when he



<P>went, and never complain now, or seem as if you needed any help,"



<P>said Jo, wondering.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I gave my best to the country I love, and kept my tears



<P>till he was gone.&nbsp; Why should I complain, when we both have



<P>merely done our duty and will surely be the happier for it in



<P>the end?&nbsp; If I don't seem to need help, it is because I have a



<P>better friend, even than Father, to comfort and sustain me.&nbsp; My



<P>child, the troubles and temptations of your life are beginning



<P>and may be many, but you can overcome and outlive them all if



<P>you learn to feel the strength and tenderness of your Heavenly



<P>Father as you do that of your earthly one.&nbsp; The more you love



<P>and trust Him, and the less you will depend on human power and



<P>wisdom.&nbsp; His love and care never tire or change, can never be



<P>taken from you, but my become the source of lifelong peace,



<P>happiness, and strength.&nbsp; Believe this heartily, and go to God



<P>with all your little cares, and hopes, and sins, and sorrows, as



<P>freely and confidingly as you come to your mother."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo's only answer was to hold her mother close, and in the



<P>silence which followed the sincerest prayer she had ever prayed



<P>left her heart without words.&nbsp; For in that sad yet happy hour,



<P>she had learned not only the bitterness of remorse and despair,



<P>but the sweetness of self-denial and self-control, and led by



<P>her mother's hand, she had drawn nearer to the Friend who always



<P>welcomes every child with a love stronger than that of any father,



<P>tenderer than that of any mother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy stirred and sighed in her sleep, and as if eager to begin



<P>at once to mend her fault, l Jo looked up with an expression on her



<P>face which it had never worn before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I let the sun go down on my anger.&nbsp; I wouldn't forgive her,



<P>and today, if it hadn't been for Laurie, it might have been too



<P>late!&nbsp; How could I be so wicked?" said Jo, half aloud, as she



<P>leaned over her sister softly stroking the wet hair scattered on



<P>the pillow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As if she heard, Amy opened her eyes, and held out her arms,



<P>with a smile that went straight to Jo's heart.&nbsp; Neither said a



<P>word, but they hugged one another close, in spite of the blankets,



<P>and everything was forgiven and forgotten in one hearty kiss.



<P>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
