   <TITLE>Chapter 09</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER NINE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do think it was the most fortunate thing in the world that



<P>those children should have the measles just now," said Meg, one



<P>April day, as she stood packing the `go abroady' trunk in her room,



<P>surrounded by her sisters.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And so nice of Annie Moffat not to forget her promise.&nbsp; A



<P>whole fortnight of fun will be regularly splendid," replied Jo,



<P>looking like a windmill as she folded skirts with her long arms.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And such lovely weather, I'm so glad of that," added Beth,



<P>tidily sorting neck and hair ribbons in her best box, lent for



<P>the great occasion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish I was going to have a fine time and wear all these



<P>nice things," said Amy with her mouth full of pins, as she



<P>artistically replenished her sister's cushion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish you were all going, but as you can't, I shall keep



<P>my adventures to tell you when I come back.&nbsp; I'm sure it's the



<P>least I can do when you have been so kind, lending me things



<P>and helping me get ready," said Meg, glancing round the room



<P>at the very simple outfit, which seemed nearly perfect in their



<P>eyes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What did Mother give you out of the treasure box?" asked



<P>Amy, who had not been present at the opening of a certain cedar



<P>chest in which Mrs. March kept a few relics of past splendor, as



<P>gifts for her girls when the proper time came.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A pair of silk stockings, that pretty carved fan, and a



<P>lovely blue sash.&nbsp; I wanted the violet silk, but there isn't



<P>time to make it over, so I must be contented with my old tarlatan."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It will look nice over my new muslin skirt, and the sash will



<P>set it off beautifully.&nbsp; I wish I hadn't smashed my coral bracelet,



<P>for you might have had it," said Jo, who loved to give and lend,



<P>but whose possessions were usually too dilapidated to be of much



<P>use.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is a lovely old-fashioned pearl set in the treasure



<P>chest, but Mother said real flowers were the prettiest ornament



<P>for a young girl, and Laurie promised to send me all I want,"



<P>replied Meg.&nbsp; "Now, let me see, there's my new gray walking suit,



<P>just curl up the feather in my hat, Beth, then my poplin for



<P>Sunday and the small party, it looks heavy for spring, doesn't



<P>it?&nbsp; The violet silk would be so nice.&nbsp; Oh, dear!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never mind, you've got the tarlatan for the big party, and



<P>you always look like an angel in white," said Amy, brooding



<P>over the little store of finery in which her soul delighted.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It isn't low-necked, and it doesn't sweep enough, but it



<P>will have to do.&nbsp; My blue housedress looks so well, turned and



<P>freshly trimmed, that I feel as if I'd got a new one.&nbsp; My silk



<P>sacque isn't a bit the fashion, and my bonnet doesn't look like



<P>Sallie's.&nbsp; I didn't like to say anything, but I was sadly



<P>disappointed in my umbrella.&nbsp; I told Mother black with a white



<P>handle, but she forgot and bought a green one with a yellowish



<P>handle.&nbsp; It's strong and neat, so I ought not to complain, but

I



<P>know I shall feel ashamed of it beside Annie's silk one with a



<P>gold top," sighed Meg, surveying the little umbrella with great



<P>disfavor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Change it," advised Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I won't be so silly, or hurt Marmee's feelings, when she



<P>took so much pains to get my things.&nbsp; It's a nonsensical notion



<P>of mine, and I'm not going to give up to it.&nbsp; My silk stockings



<P>and two pairs of new gloves are my comfort.&nbsp; You are a dear to



<P>lend me yours, Jo.&nbsp; I feel so rich and sort of elegant, with



<P>two new pairs, and the old ones cleaned up for common."&nbsp; And



<P>Meg took a refreshing peep at her glove box.



<P>"Annie Moffat has blue and pink bows on her nightcaps.



<P>Would you put some on mine?" she asked, as Beth brought up a



<P>pile of snowy muslins, fresh from Hannah's hands.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I wouldn't, for the smart caps won't match the plain



<P>gowns without any trimming on them.&nbsp; Poor folks shouldn't rig,"



<P>said Jo decidedly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wonder if I shall ever be happy enough to have real lace



<P>on my clothes and bows on my caps?" said Meg impatiently.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You said the other day that you'd be perfectly happy if



<P>you could only go to Annie Moffat's," observed Beth in her quiet



<P>way.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So I did!&nbsp; Well, I am happy, and I won't fret, but it does



<P>seem as if the more one gets the more one wants, doesn't it?&nbsp; There



<P>now, the trays are ready, and everything in but my ball dress,



<P>which I shall leave for Mother to pack," said Meg, cheering up, as



<P>she glanced from the half-filled trunk to the many times pressed



<P>and mended white tarlatan, which she called her `ball dress' with



<P>an important air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The next day was fine, and Meg departed in style for a fortnight



<P>of novelty and pleasure.&nbsp; Mrs. March had consented to the



<P>visit rather reluctantly, fearing that Margaret would come back



<P>more discontented than she went.&nbsp; But she begged so hard, and



<P>Sallie had promised to take good care of her, and a little pleasure



<P>seemed so delightful after a winter of irksome work that the mother



<P>yielded, and the daughter went to take her first taste of fashionable

life.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Moffats were very fashionable, and simple Meg was rather



<P>daunted, at first, by the splendor of the house and the elegance



<P>of its occupants.&nbsp; But they were kindly people, in spite of the



<P>frivolous life they led, and soon put their guest at her ease.



<P>Perhaps Meg felt, without understanding why, that they were not



<P>particularly cultivated or intelligent people, and that all their



<P>gilding could not quite conceal the ordinary material of which



<P>they were made.&nbsp; It certainly was agreeable to fare sumptuously,



<P>drive in a fine carriage, wear her best frock every day, and do



<P>nothing but enjoy herself.&nbsp; It suited her exactly, and soon she



<P>began to imitate the manners and conversation of those about her,



<P>to put on little airs and graces, use French phrases, crimp her



<P>hair, take in her dresses, and talk about the fashions as well as



<P>she could.&nbsp; The more she saw of Annie Moffat's pretty things, the



<P>more she envied her and sighed to be rich.&nbsp; Home now looked bare



<P>and dismal as she thought of it, work grew harder than ever, and



<P>she felt that she was a very destitute and much-injured girl, in



<P>spite of the new gloves and silk stockings.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had not much time for repining, however, for the three



<P>young girls were busily employed in `having a good time'.&nbsp; They



<P>shopped, walked, rode, and called all day, went to theaters and



<P>operas or frolicked at home in the evening, for Annie had many



<P>friends and knew how to entertain them.&nbsp; Her older sisters were



<P>very fine young ladies, and one was engaged, which was extremely



<P>interesting and romantic, Meg thought.&nbsp; Mr. Moffat was a fat,



<P>jolly old gentleman, who knew her father, and Mrs. Moffat, a fat,



<P>jolly old lady, who took as great a fancy to Meg as her daughter



<P>had done.&nbsp; Everyone petted her, and `Daisey', as they called her,



<P>was in a fair way to have her head turned.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the evening for the small party came, she found that



<P>the poplin wouldn't do at all, for the other girls were putting



<P>on thin dresses and making themselves very fine indeed.&nbsp; So out



<P>came the tarlatan, looking older, limper, and shabbier than ever



<P>beside Sallie's crisp new one.&nbsp; Meg saw the girls glance at it



<P>and then at one another, and her cheeks began to burn, for with



<P>all her gentleness she was very proud.&nbsp; No one said a word about



<P>it, but Sallie offered to dress her hair, and Annie to tie her



<P>sash, and Belle, the engaged sister, praised her white arms.&nbsp; But



<P>in their kindness Meg saw only pity for her poverty, and her



<P>heart felt very heavy as she stood by herself, while the others



<P>laughed, chattered, and flew about like gauzy butterflies.&nbsp; The



<P>hard, bitter feeling was getting pretty bad, when the maid



<P>brought in a box of flowers.&nbsp; Before she could speak, Annie had



<P>the cover off, and all were exclaiming at the lovely roses, heath,



<P>and fern within.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's for Belle, of course, George always sends her some,



<P>but these are altogether ravishing," cried Annie, with a great



<P>sniff.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They are for Miss March, the man said.&nbsp; And here's a note,"



<P>put in the maid, holding it to Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What fun!&nbsp; Who are they from?&nbsp; Didn't know you had a lover,"



<P>cried the girls, fluttering about Meg in a high state of curiosity



<P>and surprise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The note is from Mother, and the flowers from Laurie," said



<P>Meg simply, yet much gratified that he had not forgotten her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, indeed!" said Annie with a funny look, as Meg slipped



<P>the note into her pocket as a sort of talisman against envy,



<P>vanity, and false pride, for the few loving words had done her



<P>good, and the flowers cheered her up by their beauty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Feeling almost happy again, she laid by a few ferns and roses



<P>for herself, and quickly made up the rest in dainty bouquets for



<P>the breasts, hair, or skirts of her friends, offering them so



<P>prettily that Clara, the elder sister, told her she was `the



<P>sweetest little thing she ever saw', and they looked quite



<P>charmed with her small attention.&nbsp; Somehow the kind act finished



<P>her despondency, and when all the rest went to show themselves



<P>to Mrs. Moffat, she saw a happy, bright-eyed face in the mirror,



<P>as she laid her ferns against her rippling hair and fastened



<P>the roses in the dress that didn't strike her as so very shabby



<P>now.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She enjoyed herself very much that evening, for she danced



<P>to her heart's content.&nbsp; Everyone was very kind, and she had



<P>three compliments.&nbsp; Annie made her sing, and some one said she



<P>had a remarkably fine voice.&nbsp; Major Lincoln asked who `the fresh



<P>little girl with the beautiful eyes' was, and Mr. Moffat insisted



<P>on dancing with her because she `didn't dawdle, but had some spring



<P>in her', as he gracefully expressed it.&nbsp; So altogether she had

a



<P>very nice time, till she overheard a bit of conversation, which



<P>disturbed her extremely.&nbsp; She was sitting just inside the



<P>conservatory, waiting for her partner to bring her an ice, when she



<P>heard a voice ask on the other side of the flowery wall...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How old is he?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sixteen or seventeen, I should say," replied another voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It would be a grand thing for one of those girls, wouldn't



<P>it?&nbsp; Sallie says they are very intimate now, and the old man quite



<P>dotes on them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mrs. M.&nbsp; has made her plans, I dare say, and will play her



<P>cards well, early as it is.&nbsp; The girl evidently doesn't think of

it



<P>yet," said Mrs. Moffat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She told that fib about her momma, as if she did know, and



<P>colored up when the flowers came quite prettily.&nbsp; Poor thing!



<P>She'd be so nice if she was only got up in style.&nbsp; Do you think



<P>she'd be offended if we offered to lend her a dress for Thursday?"



<P>asked another voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She's proud, but I don't believe she'd mind, for that dowdy



<P>tarlatan is all she has got.&nbsp; She may tear it tonight, and that



<P>will be a good excuse for offering a decent one."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here Meg's partner appeared, to find her looking much flushed



<P>and rather agitated.&nbsp; She was proud, and her pride was useful



<P>just then, for it helped her hide her mortification, anger, and



<P>disgust at what she had just heard.&nbsp; For, innocent and unsuspicious



<P>as she was, she could not help understanding the gossip of her



<P>friends.&nbsp; She tried to forget it, but could not, and kept repeating



<P>to herself, "Mrs. M.&nbsp; has made her plans," "that fib about her



<P>mamma," and 'dowdy tarlatan," till she was ready to cry and rush



<P>home to tell her troubles and ask for advice.&nbsp; As that was impossible,



<P>she did her best to seem gay, and being rather excited, she



<P>succeeded so well that no one dreamed what an effort she was making.



<P>She was very glad when it was all over and she was quiet in her bed,



<P>where she could think and wonder and fume till her head ached and



<P>her hot cheeks were cooled by a few natural tears.&nbsp; Those foolish,



<P>yet well meant words, had opened a new world to Meg, and much



<P>disturbed the peace of the old one in which till now she had lived



<P>as happily as a child.&nbsp; Her innocent friendship with Laurie was



<P>spoiled by the silly speeches she had overheard.&nbsp; Her faith in

her



<P>mother was a little shaken by the worldly plans attributed to her



<P>by Mrs. Moffat, who judged others by herself, and the sensible



<P>resolution to be contented with the simple wardrobe which suited



<P>a poor man's daughter was weakened by the unnecessary pity of



<P>girls who thought a shabby dress one of the greatest calamities



<P>under heaven.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Meg had a restless night, and got up heavy-eyed, unhappy,



<P>half resentful toward her friends, and half ashamed of herself for



<P>not speaking out frankly and setting everything right.&nbsp; Everybody



<P>dawdled that morning, and it was noon before the girls found



<P>energy enough even to take up their worsted work.&nbsp; Something in



<P>the manner of her friends struck Meg at once.&nbsp; They treated her



<P>with more respect, she thought, took quite a tender interest in



<P>what she said, and looked at her with eyes that plainly betrayed



<P>curiosity.&nbsp; All this surprised and flattered her, though she did



<P>not understand it till Miss Belle looked up from her writing, and



<P>said, with a sentimental air...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Daisy, dear, I've sent an invitation to your friend, Mr.



<P>Laurence, for Thursday.&nbsp; We should like to know him, and it's only



<P>a proper compliment to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg colored, but a mischievous fancy to tease the girls made



<P>her reply demurely, "You are very kind, but I'm afraid he won't



<P>come."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why not, Cherie?" asked Miss Belle.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He's too old."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My child, what do you mean?&nbsp; What is his age, I beg to



<P>know!" cried Miss Clara.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nearly seventy, I believe," answered Meg, counting stitches



<P>to hide the merriment in her eyes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You sly creature!&nbsp; Of course we meant the young man,"



<P>exclaimed Miss Belle, laughing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There isn't any, Laurie is only a little boy."&nbsp; And Meg



<P>laughed also at the queer look which the sisters exchanged as she



<P>thus described her supposed lover.



<P>"About you age," Nan said.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nearer my sister Jo's, I am seventeen in August," returned



<P>Meg, tossing her head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's very nice of him to send you flowers, isn't it?" said



<P>Annie, looking wise about nothing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, he often does, to all of us, for their house is full, and



<P>we are so fond of them.&nbsp; My mother and old Mr. Laurence are friends,



<P>you know, so it is quite natural that we children should play together."



<P>And Meg hoped they would say no more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's evident Daisy isn't out yet," said Miss Clara to Belle with a

nod.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Quite a pastoral state of innocence all round," returned



<P>Miss Belle with a shrug.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm going out to get some little matters for my girls.&nbsp; Can



<P>I do anything for you, young ladies?" asked Mrs. Moffat, lumbering



<P>in like an elephant in silk and lace.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, thank you, ma'am," replied Sallie.&nbsp; "I've got my new



<P>pink silk for Thursday and don't want a thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nor I..." began Meg, but stopped because it occurred to



<P>her that she did want several things and could not have them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What shall you wear?" asked Sallie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My old white one again, if I can mend it fit to be seen, it



<P>got sadly torn last night," said Meg, trying to speak quite easily,



<P>but feeling very uncomfortable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why don't you send home for another?" said Sallie, who was



<P>not an observing young lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I haven't got any other."&nbsp; It cost Meg an effort to say that,



<P>but Sallie did not see it and exclaimed in amiable surprise, "Only



<P>that?" How funny..."&nbsp; She did not finish her speech, for Belle



<P>shook her head at her and broke in, saying kindly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not at all.&nbsp; Where is the use of having a lot of dresses



<P>when she isn't out yet?&nbsp; There's no need of sending home, Daisy,



<P>even if you had a dozen, for I've got a sweet blue silk laid away,



<P>which I've outgrown, and you shall wear it to please me, won't



<P>you, dear?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are very kind, but I don't mind my old dress if you



<P>don't, it does well enough for a little girl like me," said Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now do let me please myself by dressing you up in style.



<P>I admire to do it, and you'd be a regular little beauty with a



<P>touch here and there.&nbsp; I shan't let anyone see you till you are



<P>done, and then we'll burst upon them like Cinderella and her



<P>godmother going to the ball," said Belle in her persuasive tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg couldn't refuse the offer so kindly made, for a desire to



<P>see if she would be `a little beauty' after touching up caused



<P>her to accept and forget all her former uncomfortable feelings



<P>toward the Moffats.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On the Thursday evening, Belle shut herself up with her maid,



<P>and between them they turned Meg into a fine lady.&nbsp; They crimped



<P>and curled her hair, they polished her neck and arms with some



<P>fragrant powder, touched her lips with coralline salve to make



<P>them redder, and Hortense would have added `a soupcon of rouge',



<P>if Meg had not rebelled.&nbsp; They laced her into a sky-blue dress,



<P>which was so tight she could hardly breathe and so low in the



<P>neck that modest Meg blushed at herself in the mirror.&nbsp; A set



<P>of silver filagree was added, bracelets, necklace, brooch, and



<P>even earrings, for Hortense tied them on with a bit of pink



<P>silk which did not show.&nbsp; A cluster of tea-rose buds at the



<P>bosom and a ruche, reconciled Meg to the display of her pretty,



<P>white shoulders, and a pair of high-heeled silk boots satisfied



<P>the last wish of her heart.&nbsp; A lace handkerchief, a plumy fan,



<P>and a bouquet in a shoulder holder finished her off, and Miss



<P>Belle surveyed her with the satisfaction of a little girl with



<P>a newly dressed doll.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mademoiselle is chatmante, tres jolie, is she not?" cried



<P>Hortense, clasping her hands in an affected rapture.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come and show yourself," said Miss Belle, leading the way



<P>to the room where the others were waiting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As Meg went rustling after, with her long skirts trailing,



<P>her earrings tinkling, her curls waving, and her heart beating,



<P>she felt as if her fun had really begun at last, for the mirror



<P>had plainly told her that she was `a little beauty'.&nbsp; Her friends



<P>repeated the pleasing phrase enthusiastically, and for several



<P>minutes she stood, like a jackdaw in the fable, enjoying her



<P>borrowed plumes, while the rest chattered like a party of magpies.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"While I dress, do you drill her, Nan, in the management of her



<P>skirt and those French heels, or she will trip herself up.&nbsp; Take



<P>your silver butterfly, and catch up that long curl on the left side



<P>of her head, Clara, and don't any of you disturb the charming work



<P>of my hands," said Belle, as she hurried away, looking well pleased



<P>with her success.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You don't look a bit like yourself, but you are very nice.



<P>I'm nowhere beside you, for Belle has heaps of taste, and you're



<P>quite French, I assure you.&nbsp; Let your flowers hang, don't be so



<P>careful of them, and be sure you don't trip," returned Sallie, trying



<P>not to care that Meg was prettier than herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Keeping that warning carefully in mind, Margaret got safely



<P>downstairs and sailed into the drawing rooms where the Moffats and



<P>a few early guests were assembled.&nbsp; She very soon discovered that



<P>there is a charm about fine clothes which attracts a certain class



<P>of people and secures their respect.&nbsp; Several young ladies, who



<P>had taken no notice of her before, were very affectionate all of



<P>a sudden.&nbsp; Several young gentlemen, who had only stared at her

at



<P>the other party, now not only stared, but asked to be introduced,



<P>and said all manner of foolish but agreeable things to her, and



<P>several old ladies, who sat on the sofas, and criticized the rest



<P>of the party, inquired who she was with an air of interest.&nbsp; She



<P>heard Mrs. Moffat reply to one of them...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Daisy March--father a colonel in the army--one of our first



<P>families, but reverses of fortune, you know; intimate friends of



<P>the Laurences; sweet creature, I assure you; my Ned is quite wild



<P>about her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear me!" said the old lady, putting up her glass for



<P>another observation of Meg, who tried to look as if she had not



<P>heard and been rather shocked at Mrs. Moffat's fibs.



<P>The `queer feeling' did not pass away, but she imagined



<P>herself acting the new part of fine lady and so got on pretty



<P>well, though the tight dress gave her a side-ache, the train kept



<P>getting under her feet, and she was in constant fear lest her



<P>earrings should fly off and get lost or broken.&nbsp; She was flirting



<P>her fan and laughing at the feeble jokes of a young gentleman



<P>who tried to be witty, when she suddenly stopped laughing and



<P>looked confused, for just opposite, she saw Laurie.&nbsp; He was



<P>staring at her with undisguised surprise, and disapproval also,



<P>she thought, for though he bowed and smiled, yet something in



<P>his honest eyes made her blush and wish she had her old dress on.



<P>To complete her confusion, she saw Belle nudge Annie, and both



<P>glance from her to Laurie, who, she was happy to see, looked



<P>unusually boyish and shy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Silly creatures, to put such thoughts into my head.&nbsp; I won't



<P>care for it, or let it change me a bit," thought Meg, and rustled



<P>across the room to shake hands with her friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad you came, I was afraid you wouldn't." she said,



<P>with her most grown-up air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo wanted me to come, and tell her how you looked, so I



<P>did," answered Laurie, without turning his eyes upon her, though



<P>he half smiled at her maternal tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What shall you tell her?" asked Meg, full of curiosity to



<P>know his opinion of her, yet feeling ill at ease with him for the



<P>first time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall say I didn't know you, for you look so grown-up and



<P>unlike yourself, I'm quite afraid of you," he said, fumbling at



<P>his glove button.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How absurd of you!&nbsp; The girls dressed me up for fun, and I



<P>rather like it.&nbsp; Wouldn't Jo stare if she saw me?" said Meg, bent



<P>on making him say whether he thought her improved or not.



<P>"Yes, I think she would," returned Laurie gravely.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't you like me so?' asked Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I don't," was the blunt reply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why not?" in an anxious tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He glanced at her frizzled head, bare shoulders, and fantastically



<P>trimmed dress with an expression that abashed her more than



<P>his answer, which had not particle of his usual politeness in it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't like fuss and feathers."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That was altogether too much from a lad younger than herself,



<P>and Meg walked away, saying petulantly, "You are the rudest boy I



<P>ever saw."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Feeling very much ruffled, she went and stood at a quiet window



<P>to cool her cheeks, for the tight dress gave her an uncomfortably



<P>brilliant color.&nbsp; As she stood there, Major Lincoln passed by,

and



<P>a minute after she heard him saying to his mother...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They are making a fool of that little girl.&nbsp; I wanted you



<P>to see her, but they have spoiled her entirely.&nbsp; She's nothing



<P>but a doll tonight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, dear!" sighed Meg.&nbsp; "I wish I'd been sensible and worn



<P>my own things, then I should not have disgusted other people, or



<P>felt so uncomfortable and ashamed of myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She leaned her forehead on the cool pane, and stood half



<P>hidden by the curtains, never minding that her favorite waltz



<P>had begun, till some one touched her, and turning, she saw



<P>Laurie, looking penitent, as he said, with his very best bow



<P>and his hand out...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Please forgive my rudeness, and come and dance with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm afraid it will be to disagreeable to you," said Meg,



<P>trying to look offended and failing entirely.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a bit of it, I'm dying to do it.&nbsp; Come, I'll be good.



<P>I don't like your gown, but I do think you are just splendid."



<P>And he waved his hands, as if words failed to express his



<P>admiration.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg smiled and relented, and whispered as they stood waiting



<P>to catch the time, "Take care my skirt doesn't trip you up.&nbsp; It's



<P>the plague of my life and I was a goose to wear it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pin it round your neck, and then it will be useful," said



<P>Laurie, looking down at the little blue boots, which he evidently



<P>approved of.



<P>Away they went fleetly and gracefully, for having practiced



<P>at home, they were well matched, and the blithe young couple were



<P>a pleasant sight to see, as they twirled merrily round and round,



<P>feeling more friendly than ever after their small tiff.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Laurie, I want you to do me a favor, will you?' said Meg,



<P>as he stood fanning her when her breath gave out, which it did



<P>very soon though she would not own why.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Won't I!" said Laurie, with alacrity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Please don't tell them at home about my dress tonight.



<P>They won't understand the joke, and it will worry Mother.'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then why did you do it?" said Laurie's eyes, so plainly



<P>that Meg hastily added...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall tell them myself all about it, and `fess' to Mother



<P>how silly I've been.&nbsp; But I'd rather do it myself.&nbsp; So you'll

not



<P>tell, will you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I give you my word I won't, only what shall I say when



<P>they ask me?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Just say I looked pretty well and was having a good time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll say the first with all my heart, but how about the



<P>other?&nbsp; You don't look as if you were having a good time.&nbsp;

Are



<P>you?' And Laurie looked at her with an expression which made her



<P>answer in a whisper...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, not just now.&nbsp; Don't think I'm horrid.&nbsp; I only wanted



<P>a little fun, but this sort doesn't pay, I find, and I'm getting



<P>tired of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here comes Ned Moffat.&nbsp; What does he want?" said Laurie,



<P>knitting his black brows as if he did not regard his young host



<P>in the light of a pleasant addition to the party.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He put his name down for three dances, and I suppose he's



<P>coming for them.&nbsp; What a bore!" said Meg, assuming a languid air



<P>which amused Laurie immensely.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He did not speak to her again till suppertime, when he saw



<P>her drinking champagne with Ned and his friend Fisher, who were



<P>behaving `like a pair of fools', as Laurie said to himself, for



<P>he felt a brotherly sort of right to watch over the Marches and



<P>fight their battles whenever a defender was needed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'll have a splitting headache tomorrow, if you drink



<P>much of that.&nbsp; I wouldn't, Meg, your mother doesn't like it, you



<P>know," he whispered, leaning over her chair, as Ned turned to



<P>refill her glass and Fisher stooped to pick up her fan.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm not Meg tonight, I'm `a doll' who does all sorts of



<P>crazy things.&nbsp; Tomorrow I shall put away my `fuss and feathers'



<P>and be desperately good again," se answered with an affected



<P>little laugh.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Wish tomorrow was here, then," muttered Laurie, walking off,



<P>ill-pleased at the change he saw in her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg danced and flirted, chattered and giggled, as the other



<P>girls did.&nbsp; After supper she undertook the German, and blundered



<P>through it, nearly upsetting her partner with her long skirt, and



<P>romping in a way that scandalized Laurie, who looked on and meditated



<P>a lecture.&nbsp; But he got no chance to deliver it, for Meg kept away



<P>from him till he came to say good night.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Remember!" she said, trying to smile, for the splitting



<P>headache had already begun.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Silence a` la mort," replied Laurie, with a melodramatic



<P>flourish, as he went away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This little bit of byplay excited Annie's curiosity, but Meg



<P>was too tired for gossip and went to bed, feeling as if she had



<P>been to a masquerade and hadn't enjoyed herself as much as she



<P>expected.&nbsp; She was sick all the next day, and on Saturday went

home,



<P>quite used up with her fortnight's fun and feeling that she had



<P>`sat in the lap of luxury' long enough.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It does seem pleasant to be quiet, and not have company



<P>manners on all the time.&nbsp; Home is a nice place, though it isn't



<P>splendid," said Meg, looking about her with a restful expression,



<P>as she sat with her mother and Jo on the Sunday evening.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad to hear you say so, dear, for I was afraid home



<P>would seem dull and poor to you after your fine quarters," replied



<P>her mother, who had given her many anxious looks that day.&nbsp; For



<P>motherly eyes are quick to see any change in children's faces.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg had told her adventures gayly and said over and over what



<P>a charming time she had had, but something still seemed to weigh



<P>upon her spirits, and when the younger girls were gone to bed, she



<P>sat thoughtfully staring at the fire, saying little and looking



<P>worried.&nbsp; As the clock struck nine and Jo proposed bed, Meg



<P>suddenly left her chair and, taking Beth's stool, leaned her elbows



<P>on her mother's knee, saying bravely...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Marmee, I want to `fess'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought so.&nbsp; What is it, dear?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shall I go away?" asked Jo discreetly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course not.&nbsp; Don't I always tell you everything?&nbsp; I was



<P>ashamed to speak of it before the younger children, but I want you



<P>to know all the dreadful things I did at the Moffats'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We are prepared," said Mrs. March, smiling but looking a



<P>little anxious.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I told you they dressed me up, but I didn't tell you that



<P>they powdered and squeezed and frizzled, and made me look like a



<P>fashion plate.&nbsp; Laurie thought I wasn't proper.&nbsp; I know he

did,



<P>though he didn't say so, and one man called me `a doll'.&nbsp; I knew



<P>it was silly, but they flattered me and said I was a beauty, and



<P>quantities of nonsense, so I let them make a fool of me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is that all?" asked Jo, as Mrs. March looked silently at



<P>the downcast face of her pretty daughter, and could not find it



<P>in her heart to blame her little follies.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I drank champagne and romped and tried to flirt, and



<P>was altogether abominable," said Meg self-reproachfully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is something more, I think."&nbsp; And Mrs. March smoothed



<P>the soft cheek, which suddenly grew rosy as Meg answered slowly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes.&nbsp; It's very silly, but I want to tell it, because I hate



<P>to have people say and think such things about us and Laurie."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Then she told the various bits of gossip she had heard at the



<P>Moffats', and as she spoke, Jo saw her mother fold her lips tightly,



<P>as if ill pleased that such ideas should be put into Meg's innocent



<P>mind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, if that isn't the greatest rubbish I ever heard," cried



<P>Jo indignantly.&nbsp; "Why didn't you pop out and tell them so on the



<P>spot?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I couldn't, it was so embarrassing for me.&nbsp; I couldn't help



<P>hearing at first, and then I was so angry and ashamed, I didn't



<P>remember that I ought to go away."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Just wait till I see Annie Moffat, and I'll show you how to



<P>settle such ridiculous stuff.&nbsp; The idea of having `plans' and being



<P>kind to Laurie because he's rich and may marry us by-and-by!&nbsp; Won't



<P>he shout when I tell him what those silly things say about us poor



<P>children?" And Jo laughed, as if on second thoughts the thing



<P>struck her as a good joke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you tell Laurie, I'll never forgive you!&nbsp; She mustn't,



<P>must she, Mother?" said Meg, looking distressed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, never repeat that foolish gossip, and forget it as soon



<P>as you can," said Mrs. March gravely.&nbsp; "I was very unwise to let



<P>you go among people of whom I know so little, kind, I dare say,



<P>but worldly, ill-bred, and full of these vulgar ideas about young



<P>people.&nbsp; I am more sorry than I can express for the mischief this



<P>visit may have done you, Meg."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't be sorry, I won't let it hurt me.&nbsp; I'll forget all the



<P>bad and remember only the good, for I did enjoy a great deal, and



<P>thank you very much for letting me go.&nbsp; I'll not be sentimental

or



<P>dissatisfied, Mother.&nbsp; I know I'm a silly little girl, and I'll



<P>stay with you till I'm fit to take care of myself.&nbsp; But it is nice



<P>to be praised and admired, and I can't help saying I like it," said



<P>Meg, looking half ashamed of the confession.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is perfectly natural, and quite harmless, if the liking



<P>does not become a passion and lead one to do foolish or unmaidenly



<P>things.&nbsp; Learn to know and value the praise which is worth having,



<P>and to excite the admiration of excellent people by being modest



<P>as well as pretty, Meg."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Margaret sat thinking a moment, while Jo stood with her hands



<P>behind her, looking both interested and a little perplexed, for it



<P>was a new thing to see Meg blushing and talking about admiration,



<P>lovers, and things of that sort.&nbsp; And Jo felt as if during that



<P>fortnight her sister had grown up amazingly, and was drifting away



<P>from her into a world where she could not follow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mother, do you have `plans', as Mrs. Moffat said?" asked Meg



<P>bashfully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, my dear, I have a great many, all mothers do, but mine



<P>differ somewhat from Mrs. Moffat's, I suspect.&nbsp; I will tell you



<P>some of them, for the time has come when a word may set this



<P>romantic little head and heart of yours right, on a very serious



<P>subject.&nbsp; You are young, Meg, but not too young to understand me,



<P>and mothers' lips are the fittest to speak of such things to girls



<P>like you.&nbsp; Jo, your turn will come in time, perhaps, so listen

to



<P>my `plans' and help me carry them out, if they are good."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo went and sat on one arm of the chair, looking as if she



<P>thought they were about to join in some very solemn affair.



<P>Holding a hand of each, and watching the two young faces wistfully,



<P>Mrs. March said, in her serious yet cheery way...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I want my daughters to be beautiful, accomplished, and good.



<P>To be admired, loved, and respected.&nbsp; To have a happy youth, to



<P>be well and wisely married, and to lead useful, pleasant lives,



<P>with as little care and sorrow to try them as God sees fit to send.



<P>To be loved and chosen by a good man is the best and sweetest thing



<P>which can happen to a woman, and I sincerely hope my girls may



<P>know this beautiful experience.&nbsp; It is natural to think of it,

Meg,



<P>right to hope and wait for it, and wise to prepare for it, so that



<P>when the happy time comes, you may feel ready for the duties and



<P>worthy of the joy.&nbsp; My dear girls, I am ambitious for you, but

not



<P>to have you make a dash in the world, marry rich men merely because



<P>they are rich, or have splendid houses, which are not homes because



<P>love is wanting.&nbsp; Money is a needful and precious thing, and when



<P>well used, a noble thing, but I never want you to think it is the



<P>first or only prize to strive for.&nbsp; I'd rather see you poor men's



<P>wives, if you were happy, beloved, contented, than queens on thrones,



<P>without self-respect and peace."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor girls don't stand any chance, Belle says, unless they



<P>put themselves forward," sighed Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then we'll be old maids," said Jo stoutly.



<P>"right, Jo.&nbsp; Better be happy old maids than unhappy wives, or



<P>unmaidenly girls, running about to find husbands," said Mrs. March



<P>decidedly.&nbsp; "Don't be troubled, Meg, poverty seldom daunts a sincere



<P>lover.&nbsp; Some of the best and most honored women I know were poor



<P>girls, but so love-worthy that they were not allowed to be old maids.



<P>Leave these things to time.&nbsp; Make this home happy, so that you

may



<P>be fit for homes of your own, if they are offered you, and contented



<P>here if they are not.&nbsp; One thing remember, my girls.&nbsp; Mother

is



<P>always ready to be your confidante, Father to be your friend, and



<P>both of hope and trust that our daughters, whether married or single,



<P>will be the pride and comfort of out lives."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We will, Marmee, we will!" cried both, with all their hearts,



<P>as she bade them good night.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 35</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER THIRTY-FIVE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Whatever his motive might have been, Laurie studied to



<P>some purpose that year, for he graduated with honor, and



<P>gave the Latin oration with the grace of a Phillips and the



<P>eloquence of a Demosthenes, so his friends said.&nbsp; They were



<P>all there, his grandfather--oh, so proud--Mr. and Mrs. March,



<P>John and Meg, Jo and Beth, and all exulted over him with the



<P>sincere admiration which boys make light of at the time, but



<P>fail to win from the world by any after-triumphs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've got to stay for this confounded supper, but I shall



<P>be home early tomorrow.&nbsp; You'll come and meet me as usual,



<P>girls?" Laurie said, as he put the sisters into the carriage



<P>after the joys of the day were over.&nbsp; He said `girls', but he



<P>meant Jo, for she was the only one who kept up the old custom.



<P>She had not the heart to refuse her splendid, successful boy



<P>anything, and answered warmly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll come, Teddy, rain or shine, and march before you,



<P>playing `Hail the conquering hero comes' on a jew's-harp."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie thanked her with a look that made her think in a



<P>sudden panic, "Oh, deary me!&nbsp; I know he'll say something, and



<P>then what shall I do?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Evening meditation and morning work somewhat allayed her



<P>fears, and having decided that she wouldn't be vain enough



<P>to think people were going to propose when she had given them



<P>every reason to know what her answer would be, she set forth



<P>at the appointed time, hoping Teddy wouldn't do anything to



<P>make her hurt his poor feelings.&nbsp; A call at Meg's, and a



<P>refreshing sniff and sip at the Daisy and Demijohn, still



<P>further fortified her for the tete-a-tete, but when she saw



<P>a stalwart figure looming in the distance, she had a strong



<P>desire to turn about and run away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where's the jew's-harp, Jo?" cried Laurie, as soon as



<P>he was within speaking distance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I forgot it." And Jo took heart again, for that salutation



<P>could not be called loverlike.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She always used to take his arm on these occasions, now



<P>she did not, and he made no complaint, which was a bad sign,



<P>but talked on rapidly about all sorts of faraway subjects,



<P>till they turned from the road into the little path that led



<P>homeward through the grove.&nbsp; Then he walked more slowly, suddenly



<P>lost his fine flow of language, and now and then a dreadful



<P>pause occurred.&nbsp; To rescue the conversation from one of



<P>the wells of silence into which it kept falling, Jo said



<P>hastily, "Now you must have a good long holiday!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I intend to."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Something in his resolute tone made Jo look up quickly to



<P>find him looking down at her with an expression that assured



<P>her the dreaded moment had come, and made her put out her hand



<P>with an imploring, "No, Teddy.&nbsp; Please don't!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will, and you must hear me.&nbsp; It's no use, Jo, we've got



<P>to have it out, and the sooner the better for both of us," he



<P>answered, getting flushed and excited all at once.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Say what you like then.&nbsp; I'll listen," said Jo, with a



<P>desperate sort of patience.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie was a young lover, but he was in earnest, and meant



<P>to `have it out', if he died in the attempt, so he plunged into



<P>the subject with characteristic impetuousity, saying in a voice



<P>that would get choky now and then, in spite of manful efforts to



<P>keep it steady .&nbsp; ..



<P>"I've loved you ever since I've known you, Jo, couldn't help



<P>it, you've been so good to me.&nbsp; I've tried to show it, but you



<P>wouldn't let me.&nbsp; Now I'm going to make you hear, and give me an



<P>answer, for I can't go on so any longer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wanted to save you this.&nbsp; I thought you'd understand...



<P>began Jo, finding it a great deal harder than she expected.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know you did, but the girls are so queer you never know



<P>what they mean.&nbsp; They say no when they mean yes, and drive a



<P>man out of his wits just for the fun of it," returned Laurie,



<P>entrenching himself behind an undeniable fact.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't.&nbsp; I never wanted to make you care for me so, and



<P>I went away to keep you from it if I could."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought so.&nbsp; It was like you, but it was no use.&nbsp; I



<P>only loved you all the more, and I worked hard to please you,



<P>and I gave up billiards and everything you didn't like, and



<P>waited and never complained, for I hoped you'd love me, though



<P>I'm not half good enough..." Here there was a choke that



<P>couldn't be controlled, so he decapitated buttercups while he



<P>cleared his `confounded throat'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You, you are, you're a great deal too good for me, and



<P>I'm so grateful to you, and so proud and fond of you, I don't



<P>know why I can't love you as you want me to.&nbsp; I've tried, but



<P>I can't change the feeling, and it would be a lie to say I do



<P>when I don't."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Really, truly, Jo?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He stopped short, and caught both her hands as he put



<P>his question with a look that she did not soon forget.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Really, truly, dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were in the grove now, close by the stile, and when



<P>the last words fell reluctantly from Jo's lips, Laurie dropped



<P>her hands and turned as if to go on, but for once in his life



<P>the fence was too much for him.&nbsp; So he just laid his head down



<P>on the mossy post, and stood so still that Jo was frightened.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, Teddy, I'm sorry, so desperately sorry, I could kill



<P>myself if it would do any good!&nbsp; I wish you wouldn't take it



<P>so hard, I can't help it.&nbsp; You know it's impossible for people



<P>to make themselves love other people if they don't," cried Jo



<P>inelegantly but remorsefully, as she softly patted his shoulder,



<P>remembering the time when he had comforted her so long ago.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They do sometimes," said a muffled voice from the post.



<P>"I don't believe it's the right sort of love, and I'd



<P>rather not try it," was the decided answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a long pause, while a blackbird sung blithely on



<P>the willow by the river, and the tall grass rustled in the wind.



<P>Presently Jo said very soberly, as she sat down on the step of



<P>the stile, "Laurie, I want to tell you something."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He started as if he had been shot, threw up his head, and



<P>cried out in a fierce tone, "Don't tell me that, Jo, I can't bear



<P>it now!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tell what?" she asked, wondering at his violence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That you love that old man."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What old man?" demanded Jo, thinking he must mean his



<P>grandfather.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That devilish Professor you were always writing about.



<P>If you say you love him, I know I shall do something desperate."



<P>And he looked as if he would keep his word, as he clenched



<P>his hands with a wrathful spark in his eyes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo wanted to laugh, but restrained herself and said warmly,



<P>for she too, was getting excited with all this, "Don't swear,



<P>Teddy!&nbsp; He isn't old, nor anything bad, but good and kind, and



<P>the best friend I've got, next to you.&nbsp; Pray, don't fly into



<P>a passion.&nbsp; I want to be kind, but I know I shall get angry if



<P>you abuse my Professor.&nbsp; I haven't the least idea of loving



<P>him or anybody else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you will after a while, and then what will become of me?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'll love someone else too, like a sensible boy, and



<P>forget all this trouble."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't love anyone else, and I'll never forget you, Jo,



<P>Never! Never!" with a stamp to emphasize his passionate words.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What shall I do with him?" sighed Jo, finding that emotions



<P>were more unmanagable than she expected.&nbsp; "You haven't heard



<P>what I wanted to tell you.&nbsp; Sit down and listen, for indeed I



<P>want to do right and make you happy," she said, hoping to soothe



<P>him with a little reason, which proved that she knew nothing



<P>about love.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Seeing a ray of hope in that last speech, Laurie threw himself



<P>down on the grass at her feet, leaned his arm on the lower



<P>step of the stile, and looked up at her with an expectant face.



<P>Now that arrangement was not conducive to calm speech or clear



<P>thought on Jo's part, for how could she say hard things to her



<P>boy while he watched her with eyes full of love and longing,



<P>and lashes still wet with the bitter drop or two her hardness



<P>of heart had wrung from him?&nbsp; She gently turned his head away,



<P>saying, as she stroked the wavy hair which had been allowed to



<P>grow for her sake--how touching that was, to be sure!



<P>"I agree with Mother that you and I are not suited to each



<P>other, because our quick tempers and strong wills would probably



<P>make us very miserable, if we were so foolish as to..."



<P>Jo paused a little over the last word, but Laurie uttered it



<P>with a rapturous expression.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Marry--no we shouldn't!&nbsp; If you loved me, Jo, I should



<P>be a perfect saint, for you could make me anything you like."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I can't.&nbsp; I've tried and failed, and I won't risk



<P>our happiness by such a serious experiment.&nbsp; We don't agree and



<P>we never shall, so we'll be good friends all our lives, but we



<P>won't go and do anything rash."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, we will if we get the chance," muttered Laurie rebelliously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now do be reasonable, and take a sensible view of the case,"



<P>implored Jo, almost at her wit's end.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I won't be reasonable.&nbsp; I don't want to take what you



<P>call `a sensible view'.&nbsp; It won't help me, and it only makes



<P>it harder.&nbsp; I don't believe you've got any heart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish I hadn't."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a little quiver in Jo's voice, and thinking it a



<P>good omen, Laurie turned round, bringing all his persuasive



<P>powers to bear as he said, in the wheedlesome tone that had



<P>never been so dangerously wheedlesome before, "Don't disappoint



<P>us, dear!&nbsp; Everyone expects it.&nbsp; Grandpa has set his heart

upon



<P>it, your people like it, and I can't get on without you.&nbsp; Say



<P>you will, and let's be happy.&nbsp; Do, do!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Not until months afterward did Jo understand how she had



<P>the strength of mind to hold fast to the resolution she had



<P>made when she decided that she did not love her boy, and



<P>never could.&nbsp; It was very hard to do, but she did it, knowing



<P>that delay was both useless and cruel.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't say `yes' truly, so I won't say it at all.&nbsp; You'll



<P>see that I'm right, by-and-by, and thank me for it..." she



<P>began solemnly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll be hanged if I do!"&nbsp; And Laurie bounced up off the



<P>grass, burning with indignation at the very idea.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, you will!" persisted Jo.&nbsp; "You'll get over this after



<P>a while, and find some lovely accomplished girl, who will adore



<P>you, and make a fine mistress for your fine house.&nbsp; I shouldn't.



<P>I'm homely and awkward and odd and old, and you'd be ashamed



<P>of me, and we should quarrel--we can't help it even now, you see-and



<P>I shouldn't like elegant society and you would, and you'd



<P>hate my scribbling, and I couldn't get on without it, and we



<P>should be unhappy, and wish we hadn't done it, and everything



<P>would be horrid!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Anything more?" asked asked Laurie, finding it hard to



<P>listen patiently to this prophetic burst.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing more, except that I don't believe I shall ever



<P>marry.&nbsp; I'm happy as I am, and love my liberty too well to



<P>be in a hurry to give it up for any mortal man."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know better!" broke in Laurie.&nbsp; "You think so now,



<P>but there'll come a time when you will care for somebody, and



<P>you'll love him tremendously, and live and die for him.&nbsp; I



<P>know you will, it's your way, and I shall have to stand by



<P>and see it."&nbsp; And the despairing lover cast his hat upon the



<P>ground with a gesture that would have seemed comical, if his



<P>face had not been so tragic.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I will live and die for him, if her ever comes and



<P>makes me love him in spite of myself, and you must do the best



<P>you can!" cried Jo, losing patience with poor Teddy.&nbsp; "I've



<P>done my best, but you won't be reasonable, and it's selfish



<P>of you to keep teasing for what I can't give.&nbsp; I shall always



<P>be fond of you, very fond indeed, as a friend, but I'll never



<P>marry you, and the sooner you believe it the better for both



<P>of us--so now!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That speech was like gunpowder.&nbsp; Laurie looked at her a



<P>minute as if he did not quite know what to do with himself,



<P>then turned sharply away, saying in a desperate sort of tone,



<P>"You'll be sorry some day, Jo."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, where are you going?" she cried, for his face frightened her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To the devil!" was the consoling answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For a minute Jo's heart stood still, as he swung himself



<P>down the bank toward the river, but it takes much folly, sin



<P>or misery to send a young man to a violent death, and Laurie



<P>was not one of the weak sort who are conquered by a single



<P>failure.&nbsp; He had no thought of a melodramatic plunge, but



<P>some blind instinct led him to fling hat and coat into his boat,



<P>and row away with all his might, making better time up the



<P>river than he had done in any race.&nbsp; Jo drew a long breath and



<P>unclasped her hands as she watched the poor fellow trying to



<P>outstrip the trouble which he carried in his heart.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That will do him good, and he'll come home in such a



<P>tender, penitent state of mind, that I shan't dare to see him."



<P>she said, adding, as she went slowly home, feeling as if she



<P>had murdered some innocent thing, and buried it under the



<P>leaves.&nbsp; "Now I must go and prepare Mr. Laurence to be very



<P>kind to my poor boy.&nbsp; I wish he'd love Beth, perhaps he may



<P>in time, but I begin to think I was mistaken about her.&nbsp; Oh



<P>dear!&nbsp; How can girls like to have lovers and refuse them?&nbsp;

I



<P>think it's dreadful."



<P>Being sure that no one could do it so well as herself, she



<P>went straight to Mr. Laurence, told the hard story bravely



<P>through, and then broke down, crying so dismally over her own



<P>insensibility that the kind old gentleman, though sorely disappointed,



<P>did not utter a reproach.&nbsp; He found it difficult to understand



<P>how any girl could help loving Laurie, and hoped she would



<P>change her mind, but he knew even better than Jo that love



<P>cannot be forced, so he shook his head sadly and resolved



<P>to carry his boy out of harm's way, for Young Impetuosity's



<P>parting words to Jo disturbed him more than he would confess.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When Laurie came home, dead tired but quite composed, his



<P>grandfather met him as if he knew nothing, and kept up the



<P>delusion very successfully for an hour or two.&nbsp; But when they



<P>sat together in the twilight, the time they used to enjoy so



<P>much, it was hard work for the old man to ramble on as usual,



<P>and harder still for the young one to listen to praises of



<P>the last year's success, which to him now seemed like love's



<P>labor lost.&nbsp; He bore it as long as he could, then went to



<P>his piano and began to play.&nbsp; The window's were open, and Jo,



<P>walking in the garden with Beth, for once understood music



<P>better than her sister, for he played the `SONATA PATHETIQUE',



<P>and played it as he never did before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's very fine, I dare say, but it's sad enough to make



<P>one cry.&nbsp; Give us something gayer, lad," said Mr. Laurence,



<P>whose kind old heart was full of sympathy, which he longed to



<P>show but knew not how.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie dashed into a livelier strain, played stormily for



<P>several minutes, and would have got through bravely, if in a



<P>momentary lull Mrs. March's voice had not been heard calling,



<P>"Jo, dear, come in.&nbsp; I want you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Just what Laurie longed to say, with a different meaning!



<P>As he listened, he lost his place, the music ended with a broken



<P>chord, and the musician sat silent in the dark.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't stand this," muttered the old gentleman.&nbsp; Up he



<P>got, groped his way to the piano, laid a kind hand on either



<P>of the broad shoulders, and said, as gently as a woman, "I



<P>know, my boy, I know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No answer for an instant, then Laurie asked sharply, "Who



<P>told you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo herself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then there's an end of it!"&nbsp; And he shook off his grandfather's



<P>hands with an impatient motion, for though grateful



<P>for the sympathy, his man's pride could not bear a man's pity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not quite.&nbsp; I want to say one thing, and then there shall



<P>be an end of it," returned Mr. Laurence with unusual mildness.



<P>"You won't care to stay at home now, perhaps?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't intend to run away from a girl.&nbsp; Jo can't prevent



<P>my seeing her, and I shall stay and do it as long as I like,"



<P>interrupted Laurie in a defiant tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not if you are the gentleman I think you.&nbsp; I'm disappointed,



<P>but the girl can't help it, and the only thing left



<P>for you to do is to go away for a time.&nbsp; Where will you go?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Anywhere.&nbsp; I don't care what becomes of me."&nbsp; And Laurie



<P>got up with a reckless laugh that grated on his grandfather's



<P>ear.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Take it like a man, and don't do anything rash, for God's



<P>sake.&nbsp; Why not go abroad, as you planned, and forget it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you've been wild to go, and I promised you should



<P>when you got through college."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah, but I didn't mean to go alone!"&nbsp; And Laurie walked



<P>fast through the room with an expression which it was well



<P>his grandfather did not see.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't ask you to go alone.&nbsp; There's someone ready and



<P>glad to go with you, anywhere in the world."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Who, Sir?' stopping to listen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie came back as quickly as he went, and put out his



<P>hand, saying huskily, "I'm a selfish brute, but--you know-Grandfather--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Lord help me, yes, I do know, for I've been through it all



<P>before, once in my own young days, and then with your father.



<P>Now, my dear boy, just sit quietly down and hear my plan.&nbsp; It's



<P>all settled, and can be carried out at once," said Mr. Laurence,



<P>keeping hold of the young man, as if fearful that he would break



<P>away as his father had done before him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, sir, what is it?" And Laurie sat down, without a



<P>sign of interest in face or voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is business in London that needs looking after.&nbsp; I



<P>meant you should attend to it, but I can do it better myself,



<P>and things here will get on very well with Brooke to manage



<P>them.&nbsp; My partners do almost everything, I'm merely holding



<P>on until you take my place, and can be off at any time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you hate traveling, Sir.&nbsp; I can't ask it of you at



<P>your age," began Laurie, who was grateful for the sacrifice,



<P>but much preferred to go alone, if he went at all.



<P>The old gentleman knew that perfectly well, and particularly



<P>desired to prevent it, for the mood in which he found his



<P>grandson assured him that it would not be wise to leave him to



<P>his own devices.&nbsp; So, stifling a natural regret at the thought



<P>of the home comforts he would leave behind him, he said stoutly,



<P>Bless your soul, I'm not superannuated yet.&nbsp; I quite enjoy the



<P>idea.&nbsp; It will do me good, and my old bones won't suffer, for



<P>traveling nowadays is almost as easy as sitting in a chair."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A restless movement from Laurie suggested that his chair



<P>was not easy, or that he did not like the plan, and made the



<P>old man add hastily, "I don't mean to be a marplot or a burden.



<P>I go because I think you'd feel happier than if I was



<P>left behind.&nbsp; I don't intend to gad about with you, but leave



<P>you free to go where you like, while I amuse myself in my own



<P>way.&nbsp; I've friends in London and Paris, and should like to



<P>visit them.&nbsp; Meantime you can go to Italy, Germany, Switzerland,



<P>where you will, and enjoy pictures, music, scenery,



<P>and adventures to your heart's content."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now, Laurie felt just then that his heart was entirely



<P>broken and the world a howling wilderness, but at the sound



<P>of certain words which the old gentleman artfully introduced



<P>into his closing sentence, the broken heart gave an unexpected



<P>leap, and a green oasis or two suddenly appeared in the howling



<P>wilderness.&nbsp; He sighed, and then said, in a spiritless tone,



<P>"Just as you like, Sir.&nbsp; It doesn't matter where I go or what I

do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It does to me, remember that, my lad.&nbsp; I give you entire



<P>liberty, but I trust you to make an honest use of it.&nbsp; Promise



<P>me that, Laurie."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Anything you like, Sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good," thought the old gentleman.&nbsp; "You don't care now,



<P>but there'll come a time when that promise will keep you out



<P>of mischief, or I'm much mistaken."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Being an energetic individual, Mr. Laurence struck while



<P>the iron was hot, and before the blighted being recovered spirit



<P>enough to rebel, they were off.&nbsp; During the time necessary for



<P>preparation, Laurie bore himself as young gentleman usually do



<P>in such cases.&nbsp; He was moody, irritable, and pensive by turns,



<P>lost his appetite, neglected his dress and devoted much time



<P>to playing tempestuously on his piano, avoided Jo, but consoled



<P>himself by staring at her from his window, with a tragic



<P>face that haunted her dreams by night and oppressed her with a



<P>heavy sense of guilt by day.&nbsp; Unlike some sufferers, he never



<P>spoke of his unrequited passion, and would allow no one, not



<P>even Mrs. March, to attempt consolation or offer sympathy.&nbsp; On



<P>some accounts, this was a relief to his friends, but the weeks



<P>before his departure were very uncomfortable, and everyone rejoiced



<P>that the `poor, dear fellow was going away to forget his



<P>trouble, and come home happy'.&nbsp; Of course, he smiled darkly at



<P>their delusion, but passed it by with the sad superiority of



<P>one who knew that his fidelity like his love was unalterable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the parting came he affected high spirits, to conceal



<P>certain inconvenient emotions which seemed inclined to assert



<P>themselves.&nbsp; This gaiety did not impose upon anybody, but they



<P>tried to look as if it did for his sake, and he got on very well



<P>till Mrs. March kissed him, whit a whisper full of motherly



<P>solicitude.&nbsp; Then feeling that he was going very fast, he hastily



<P>embraced them all round, not forgetting the afflicted Hannah, and



<P>ran downstairs as if for his life.&nbsp; Jo followed a minute after

to



<P>wave her hand to him if he looked round.&nbsp; He did look round, came



<P>back, put his arms about her as she stood on the step above him,



<P>and looked up at her with a face that made his short appeal eloquent



<P>and pathetic.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, Jo, can't you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Teddy, dear, I wish I could!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That was all, except a little pause.&nbsp; Then Laurie straightened



<P>himself up, said, "It's all right, never mind," and went away without



<P>another word.&nbsp; Ah, but it wasn't all right, and Jo did mind, for



<P>while the curly head lay on her arm a minute after her hard answer,



<P>she felt as if she had stabbed her dearest friend, and when he left



<P>her without a look behind him, she knew that the boy Laurie never



<P>would come again.



<P>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
