   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 21</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER TWENTY-ONE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo's face was a study next day, for the secret rather weighed



<P>upon her, and she found it hard not to look mysterious and



<P>important.&nbsp; Meg observed it, but did not trouble herself to make



<P>inquiries, for she had learned that the best way to manage Jo was



<P>by the law of contraries, so she felt sure of being told everything



<P>if she did not ask.&nbsp; She was rather surprised, therefore,



<P>when the silence remained unbroken, and Jo assumed a patronizing



<P>air, which decidedly aggravated Meg, who in turn assumed an air



<P>of dignified reserve and devoted herself to her mother.&nbsp; This left



<P>Jo to her own devices, for Mrs. March had taken her place as nurse,



<P>and bade her rest, exercise, and amuse herself after her long



<P>confinement.&nbsp; Amy being gone, Laurie was her only refuge, and much



<P>as she enjoyed his society, she rather dreaded him just then, for



<P>he was an incorrigible tease, and she feared he would coax the



<P>secret from her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was quite right, for the mischief-loving lad no sooner



<P>suspected a mystery than he set himself to find it out, and led



<P>Jo a trying life of it.&nbsp; He wheedled, bribed, ridiculed,



<P>threatened, and scolded; affected indifference, that he might surprise



<P>the truth from her; declared her knew, then that he didn't care;



<P>and at last, by dint of perseverance, he satisfied himself that



<P>it concerned Meg and Mr. Brooke.&nbsp; Feeling indignant that he was



<P>not taken into his tutor's confidence, he set his wits to work



<P>to devise some proper retaliation for the slight.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg meanwhile had apparently forgotten the matter and was



<P>absorbed in preparations for her father's return, but all of a



<P>sudden a change seemed to come over her, and, for a day or two,



<P>she was quite unlike herself.&nbsp; She started when spoken to,



<P>blushed when looked at, was very quiet, and sat over her sewing,



<P>with a timid, troubled look on her face.&nbsp; To her mother's inquiries



<P>she answered that she was quite well, and Jo's she silenced by



<P>begging to be let alone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She feels it in the air--love, I mean--and she's going very



<P>fast.&nbsp; She's got most of the symptoms--is twittery and cross,



<P>doesn't eat, lies awake, and mopes in corners.&nbsp; I caught her



<P>singing that song he gave her, and once she said `John', as you



<P>do, and then turned as red as a poppy.&nbsp; whatever shall we do?"



<P>said Jo, looking ready for any measures, however violent.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing but wait.&nbsp; Let her alone, be kind and patient, and



<P>Father's coming will settle everything," replied her mother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here's a note to you, Meg, all sealed up.&nbsp; How odd! Teddy



<P>never seals mine," said Jo next day, as she distributed the



<P>contents of the little post office.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March and Jo were deep in their own affairs, when a



<P>sound from Meg made them look up to see her staring at her



<P>note with a frightened face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My child, what is it?" cried her mother, running to her,



<P>while Jo tried to take the paper which had done the mischief.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's all a mistake, he didn't send it.&nbsp; Oh, Jo, how could



<P>you do it?" and Meg hid her face in her hands, crying as if her



<P>heart were quite broken.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me!&nbsp; I've done nothing!&nbsp; What's she talking about?" cried



<P>Jo, bewildered.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg's mild eyes kindled with anger as she pulled a crumpled



<P>note from her pocket and threw it at Jo, saying reproachfully,



<P>"You wrote it, and that bad boy helped you.&nbsp; How could you be



<P>so rude, so mean, and cruel to us both?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo hardly heard her, for she and her mother were reading the



<P>note, which was written in a peculiar hand.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My Dearest Margaret,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can no longer restrain my passion, and must know my fate



<P>before I return.&nbsp; I dare not tell your parents yet, but I think



<P>they would consent if they knew that we adored one another.&nbsp; Mr.



<P>Laurence will help me to some good place, and then, my sweet



<P>girl, you will make me happy.&nbsp; I implore you to say nothing to



<P>your family yet, but to send one word of hope through Laurie to,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your devoted John."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, the little villain!&nbsp; That's the way he meant to pay me



<P>for keeping my word to Mother.&nbsp; I'll give him a hearty scolding



<P>and bring him over to beg pardon," cried Jo, burning to execute



<P>immediate justice.&nbsp; But her mother held her back, saying, with



<P>a look she seldom wore...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Stop, Jo, you must clear yourself first.&nbsp; You have played



<P>so many pranks that I am afraid you have had a hand in this."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"On my word, Mother, I haven't!&nbsp; I never saw that note



<P>before, and don't know anything about it, as true as I live!"



<P>said Jo, so earnestly that they believed her.&nbsp; "If I had taken



<P>part in it I'd have done it better than this, and have written



<P>a sensible note.&nbsp; I should think you'd have known Mr. Brooke



<P>wouldn't write such stuff as that," she added, scornfully



<P>tossing down the paper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's like his writing," faltered Meg, comparing it with the



<P>note in her hand.



<P>"Oh, Meg, you didn't answer it?" cried Mrs. March quickly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I did!" and Meg hid her face again, overcome with shame.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here's a scrape!&nbsp; Do let me bring that wicked boy over to



<P>explain and be lectured.&nbsp; I can't rest till I get hold of him."



<P>And Jo made for the door again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hush!&nbsp; Let me handle this, for it is worse than I thought.



<P>Margaret, tell me the whole story," commanded Mrs. March, sitting



<P>down by Meg, yet keeping hold of Jo, lest she should fly off.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I received the first letter from Laurie, who didn't look



<P>as if he knew anything about it," began Meg, without looking up.



<P>"I was worried at first and meant to tell you, then I remembered



<P>how you liked Mr. Brooke, so I thought you wouldn't mind if I



<P>kept my little secret for a few days.&nbsp; I'm so silly that I liked



<P>to think no one knew, and while I was deciding what to say, I



<P>felt like the girls in books, who have such things to do.&nbsp; Forgive



<P>me, Mother, I'm paid for my silliness now.&nbsp; I never can look him



<P>in the face again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What did you say to him?' asked Mrs. March.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I only said I was too young to do anything about it yet,



<P>that I didn't wish to have secrets from you, and he must speak



<P>to father.&nbsp; I was very grateful for his kindness, and would be



<P>his friend, but nothing more, for a long while."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March smiled, as if well pleased, and Jo clapped her



<P>hands, exclaiming, with a laugh, "You are almost equal to



<P>Caroline Percy, who was a pattern of prudence!&nbsp; Tell on, Meg.



<P>What did he say to that?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He writes in a different way entirely, telling me that he



<P>never sent any love letter at all, and is very sorry that my



<P>roguish sister, Jo, should take liberties with our names.&nbsp; It's



<P>very kind and respectful, but think how dreadful for me!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg leaned against her mother, looking the image of despair,



<P>and Jo tramped about the room, calling Laurie names.&nbsp; All of a



<P>sudden she stopped, caught up the two notes, and after looking



<P>at them closely, said decidedly, "I don't believe Brooke ever



<P>saw either of these letters.&nbsp; Teddy wrote both, and keeps yours



<P>to crow over me with because I wouldn't tell him my secret."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't have any secrets, Jo.&nbsp; Tell it to Mother and keep



<P>out of trouble, as I should have done," said Meg warningly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bless you, child!&nbsp; Mother told me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That will do, Jo.&nbsp; I'll comfort Meg while you go and get



<P>Laurie.&nbsp; I shall sift the matter to the bottom, and put a stop



<P>to such pranks at once."



<P>Away ran Jo, and Mrs. March gently told Meg Mr. Brooke's



<P>real feelings.&nbsp; "Now, dear, what are your own?&nbsp; Do you love

him



<P>enough to wait till her can make a home for you, or will you



<P>keep yourself quite free for the present?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've been so scared and worried, I don't want to have



<P>anything to do with lovers for a long while, perhaps never,"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>answered Meg petulantly.&nbsp; "If John doesn't know anything about



<P>this nonsense, don't tell him, and make Jo and Laurie hold their



<P>tongues.&nbsp; I won't be deceived and plagued and made a fool of.



<P>It's a shame!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Seeing Meg's usually gentle temper was roused and her



<P>pride hurt by this mischievous joke, Mrs. March soothed her



<P>by promises of entire silence and great discretion for the



<P>future.&nbsp; The instant Laurie's step was heard in the hall, Meg



<P>fled into the study, and Mrs. March received the culprit alone.



<P>Jo had not told him why he was wanted, fearing he wouldn't come,



<P>but he knew the minute he saw Mrs. March's face, and stood



<P>twirling his hat with a guilty air which convicted him at once.



<P>Jo was dismissed, but chose to march up and down the hall like



<P>a sentinel, having some fear that the prisoner might bolt.&nbsp; The



<P>sound of voices in the parlor rose and fell for half an hour,



<P>but what happened during that interview the girls never knew.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When they were called in, Laurie was standing by their



<P>mother with such a penitent face that Jo forgave him on the



<P>spot, but did not think it wise to betray the fact.&nbsp; Meg received



<P>his humble apology, and was much comforted by the assurance that



<P>Brooke knew nothing of the joke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll never tell him to my dying day, wild horses shan't



<P>drag it out of me, so you'll forgive me, Meg, and I'll do



<P>anything to show how out-and-out sorry I am," he added,



<P>looking very much ashamed of himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll try, but it was a very ungentlemanly thing to do, I



<P>didn't think you could be so sly and malicious, Laurie," replied



<P>Meg, trying to hid her maidenly confusion under a gravely



<P>reproachful air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was altogether abominable, and I don't deserve to be



<P>spoken to for a month, but you will, though, won't you?" And



<P>Laurie folded his hands together with such and imploring gesture,



<P>as he spoke in his irresistibly persuasive tone, that it was



<P>impossible to frown upon him in spite of his scandalous behavior.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg pardoned him, and Mrs. March's grave face relaxed, in



<P>spite of her efforts to keep sober, when she heard him declare



<P>that he would atone for his sins by all sorts of penances, and



<P>abase himself like a worm before the injured damsel.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo stood aloof, meanwhile, trying to harden her heart



<P>against him, and succeeding only in primming up her face into



<P>an expression of entire disapprobation.&nbsp; Laurie looked at her



<P>once or twice, but as she showed no sign of relenting, he felt



<P>injured, and turned his back on her till the others were done



<P>with him, when he made her a low bow and walked off without a



<P>word.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As soon as he had gone, she wished she had been more forgiving,



<P>and when Meg and her mother went upstairs, she felt



<P>lonely and longed for Teddy.&nbsp; After resisting for some time,



<P>she yielded to the impulse, and armed with a book to return,



<P>went over to the big house.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is Mr. Laurence in?" asked Jo, of a housemaid, who was



<P>coming downstairs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Miss, but I don't believe he's seeable just yet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why not?&nbsp; Is he ill?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"La, no Miss, but he's had a scene with Mr. Laurie, who is



<P>in one of his tantrums about something, which vexes the old



<P>gentleman, so I dursn't go nigh him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where is Laurie?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shut up in his room, and he won't answer, though I've been



<P>a-tapping.&nbsp; I don't know what's to become of the dinner, for it's



<P>ready, and there's no one to eat it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll go and see what the matter is.&nbsp; I'm not afraid of either



<P>of them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Up went Jo, and knocked smartly on the door of Laurie's



<P>little study.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Stop that, or I'll open the door and make you!" called out



<P>the young gentleman in a threatening tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo immediately knocked again.&nbsp; The door flew open, and in



<P>she bounced before Laurie could recover from his surprise.&nbsp; Seeing



<P>that he really was out of temper, Jo, who knew how to manage him,



<P>assumed a contrite expression, and going artistically down upon



<P>her knees, said meekly, "Please forgive me for being so cross.&nbsp;

I



<P>came to make it up, and can't go away till I have."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's all right.&nbsp; Get up, and don't be a goose, Jo," was the



<P>cavalier reply to her petition.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, I will.&nbsp; Could I ask what's the matter?&nbsp; You don't



<P>look exactly easy in your mind."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I've been shaken, and I won't bear it!" growled Laurie indignantly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Who did it?" demanded Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Grandfather.&nbsp; If it had been anyone else I'd have..."



<P>And the injured youth finished his sentence by an energetic



<P>gesture of the right arm.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's nothing.&nbsp; I often shake you, and you don't mind,"



<P>said Jo soothingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pooh!&nbsp; You're a girl, and it's fun, but I'll allow no man



<P>to shake me!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't think anyone would care to try it, if you looked



<P>as much like a thundercloud as you do now.&nbsp; Why were you treated



<P>so?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Just because I wouldn't say what your mother wanted me for.



<P>I'd promised not to tell, and of course I wasn't going to break



<P>my word."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Couldn't you satisfy your grandpa in any other way?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, he would have the truth, the whole truth, and nothing



<P>but the truth.&nbsp; I'd have told my part of the scrape, if I could



<P>without bringing Meg in.&nbsp; As I couldn't, I held my tongue, and



<P>bore the scolding till the old gentleman collared me.&nbsp; Then I



<P>bolted, for fear I should forget myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It wasn't nice, but he's sorry, I know, so go down and



<P>make up.&nbsp; I'll help you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hanged if I do!&nbsp; I'm not going to be lectured and pummelled



<P>by everyone, just for a bit of a frolic.&nbsp; I was sorry about Meg,



<P>and begged pardon like a man, but I won't do it again,



<P>when I wasn't in the wrong."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He didn't know that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He ought to trust me, and not act as if I was a baby.&nbsp; It's



<P>no use, Jo, he's got to learn that I'm able to take care of



<P>myself, and don't need anyone's apron string to hold on by."



<P>"What pepper pots you are! " sighed Jo.&nbsp; "How do you mean



<P>to settle this affair?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, he ought to beg pardon, and believe me when I say I



<P>can't tell him what the fuss's about."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bless you!&nbsp; He won't do that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I won't go down till he does."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Teddy, be sensible.&nbsp; Let it pass, and I'll explain



<P>what I can.&nbsp; You can't stay here, so what's the use of being



<P>melodramatic?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't intend to stay here long, anyway.&nbsp; I'll slip off and



<P>take a journey somewhere, and when Grandpa misses me he'll come



<P>round fast enough."



<P>"I dare say, but you ought not to go and worry him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't preach.&nbsp; I'll go to Washington and see Brooke.&nbsp; It's



<P>gay there, and I'll enjoy myself after the troubles."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What fun you'd have!&nbsp; I wish I could run off too," said



<P>Jo, forgetting her part of mentor in lively visions of martial



<P>life at the capital.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come on, then!&nbsp; Why not?&nbsp; You go and surprise your father,



<P>and I'll stir up old Brooke.&nbsp; It would be a glorious joke.&nbsp;

Let's



<P>do it, Jo.&nbsp; We'll leave a letter saying we are all right, and trot



<P>off at once.&nbsp; I've got money enough.&nbsp; It will do you good,

and no



<P>harm, as you go to your father."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For a moment Jo looked as if she would agree, for wild as



<P>the plan was, it just suited her.&nbsp; She was tired of care and



<P>confinement, longed for change, and thoughts of her father



<P>blended temptingly with the novel charms of camps and hospitals,



<P>liberty and fun.&nbsp; Her eyes kindled as they turned wistfully



<P>toward the window, but they fell on the old house opposite,



<P>and she shook her head with sorrowful decision.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I was a boy, we'd run away together, and have a capital time,



<P>but as I'm a miserable girl, I must be proper and stop at home.



<P>Don't tempt me, Teddy, it's a crazy plan."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's the fun of it," began Laurie, who had got a willful



<P>fit on him and was possessed to break out of bounds in some way.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hold your tongue!" cried Jo, covering her ears.&nbsp; "`Prunes



<P>and prisms' are my doom, and I may as well make up my mind to



<P>it.&nbsp; I came here to moralize, not to hear things that make me



<P>skip to think of."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know Meg would wet-blanket such a proposal, but I



<P>thought you had more spirit," began Laurie insinuatingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bad boy, be quiet!&nbsp; Sit down and think of your own sins,



<P>don't go making me add to mine.&nbsp; If I get your grandpa to



<P>apologize for the shaking, will you give up running away?"



<P>asked Jo seriously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, but you won't do it," answered Laurie, who wished



<P>to make up, but felt that his outraged dignity must be



<P>appeased first.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I can manage the young one, I can the old one," muttered Jo,



<P>as she walked away, leaving Laurie bent over a railroad map



<P>with his head propped up on both hands.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come in!"&nbsp; And Mr. Laurence's gruff voice sounded gruffer



<P>than ever, as Jo tapped at his door.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's only me, Sir, come to return a book," she said blandly,



<P>as she entered.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Want any more?" asked the old gentleman, looking grim and



<P>vexed, but trying not to show it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, please.&nbsp; I like old Sam so well, I think I'll try the



<P>second volume," returned Jo, hoping to propitiate him by



<P>accepting a second dose of Boswell's Johnson, as he had recommended



<P>that lively work.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The shaggy eyebrows unbent a little as he rolled the steps



<P>toward the shelf where the Johnsonian literature was placed.&nbsp; Jo



<P>skipped up, and sitting on the top step, affected to be searching



<P>for her book, but was really wondering how best to introduce the



<P>dangerous object of her visit.&nbsp; Mr. Laurence seemed to suspect



<P>that something was brewing in her mind, for after taking several



<P>brisk turns about the room, he faced round on her, speaking so



<P>abruptly that Rasselas tumbled face downward on the floor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What has that boy been about?&nbsp; Don't try to shield him.&nbsp;

I



<P>know he has been in mischief by the way he acted when he came



<P>home.&nbsp; I can't get a word from him, and when I threatened to



<P>shake the truth out of him he bolted upstairs and locked himself



<P>into his room."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He did wrong, but we forgave him, and all promised not to



<P>say a word to anyone," began Jo reluctantly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That won't do.&nbsp; He shall not shelter himself behind a promise



<P>from you softhearted girls.&nbsp; If he's done anything amiss, he



<P>shall confess, beg pardon, and be punished.&nbsp; Out with it, Jo.



<P>I won't be kept in the dark."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Laurence looked so alarming and spoke so sharply that Jo



<P>would have gladly run away, if she could, but she was perched aloft



<P>on the steps, and he stood at the foot, a lion in the path, so she



<P>had to stay and brave it out.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed, Sir, I cannot tell.&nbsp; Mother forbade it.&nbsp; Laurie has



<P>confessed, asked pardon, and been punished quite enough.&nbsp; We don't



<P>keep silence to shield him, but someone else, and it will make



<P>more trouble if you interfere.&nbsp; Please don't.&nbsp; It was partly

my



<P>fault, but it's all right now.&nbsp; So let's forget it, and talk about



<P>the RAMBLER or something pleasant."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hang the RAMBLER!&nbsp; Come down and give me your word that



<P>this harum-scarum boy of mine hasn't done anything ungrateful or



<P>impertinent.&nbsp; If he has, after all your kindness to him, I'll



<P>thrash him with my own hands."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The threat sounded awful, but did not alarm Jo, for she knew



<P>the irascible old gentleman would never lift a finger against his



<P>grandson, whatever he might say to the contrary.&nbsp; She obediently



<P>descended, and made as light of the prank as she could without



<P>betraying Meg or forgetting the truth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hum...&nbsp; ha...&nbsp; well, if the boy held his tongue



<P>because he promised, and not from obstinacy, I'll forgive him.



<P>He's a stubborn fellow and hard to manage," said Mr. Laurence,



<P>rubbing up his hair till it looked as if he had been out in a gale,



<P>and smoothing the frown from his brow with an air of relief.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So am I, but a kind word will govern me when all the king's



<P>horses and all the king's men couldn't," said Jo, trying to say



<P>a kind word for her friend, who seemed to get out of one scrape



<P>only to fall into another.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You think I'm not kind to him, hey?" was the sharp answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, dear no, Sir.&nbsp; You are rather too kind sometimes, and



<P>then just a trifle hasty when he tries your patience.&nbsp; Don't you



<P>think you are?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo was determined to have it out now, and tried to look



<P>quite placid, though she quaked a little after her bold speech.



<P>To her great relief and surprise, the old gentleman only threw



<P>his spectacles onto the table with a rattle and exclaimed frankly,



<P>"You're right, girl, I am!&nbsp; I love the boy, but he tries my



<P>patience past bearing, and I know how it will end, if we go on so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll tell you, he'll run away." Jo was sorry for that speech the minute



<P>it was made.&nbsp; She meant to warn him that Laurie would not bear

much restraint,



<P>and hoped he would be more forebearing with the lad.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Laurence's ruddy face changed suddenly, and he sat down,



<P>with a troubled glance at the picture of a handsome man, which



<P>hung over his table.&nbsp; It was Laurie's father, who had run away



<P>in his youth, and married against the imperious old man's will.



<P>Jo fancied her remembered and regretted the past, and she wished



<P>she had held her tongue.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He won't do it unless he is very much worried, and only



<P>threatens it sometimes, when he gets tired of studying.&nbsp; I often



<P>think I should like to, especially since my hair was cut, so if



<P>you ever miss us, you may advertise for two boys and look among



<P>the ships bound for India."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She laughed as she spoke, and Mr. Laurence looked relieved,



<P>evidently taking the whole as a joke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You hussy, how dare you talk in that way?&nbsp; Where's your



<P>respect for me, and your proper bringing up?&nbsp; Bless the boys



<P>and girls!&nbsp; What torments they are, yet we can't do without



<P>them," he said, pinching her cheeks good-humoredly.&nbsp; "Go and



<P>bring that boy down to his dinner, tell him it's all right, and



<P>advise him not to put on tragedy airs with his grandfather.&nbsp; I



<P>won't bear it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He won't come, Sir.&nbsp; He feels badly because you didn't believe

him



<P>when he said he couldn't tell.&nbsp; I think the shaking hurt his feelings



<P>very much."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo tried to look pathetic but must have failed, for Mr.



<P>Laurence began to laugh, and she knew the day was won.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm sorry for that, and ought to thank him for not shaking



<P>me, I suppose.&nbsp; What the dickens does the fellow expect?" And



<P>the old gentleman looked a trifle ashamed of his own testiness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I were you, I'd write him an apology, Sir.&nbsp; He says he



<P>won't come down till he has one, and talks about Washington, and



<P>goes on in an absurd way.&nbsp; A formal apology will make him see



<P>how foolish he is, and bring him down quite amiable.&nbsp; Try it.&nbsp;

He



<P>likes fun, and this was is better than talking.&nbsp; I'll carry it



<P>up, and teach him his duty."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Laurence gave her a sharp look, and put on his spectacles,



<P>saying slowly, "You're a sly puss, but I don't mind being



<P>managed by you and Beth.&nbsp; Here, give me a bit of paper,



<P>and let us have done with this nonsense."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The note was written in the terms which one gentleman would



<P>use to another after offering some deep insult.&nbsp; Jo dropped a kiss



<P>on the top of Mr. Laurence's bald head, and ran up to slip the



<P>apology under Laurie's door, advising him through the keyhole to



<P>be submissive, decorous, and a few other agreeable impossibilities.



<P>Finding the door locked again, she left the note to do its work,



<P>and was going quietly away, when the young gentleman slid down



<P>the banisters, and waited for her at the bottom, saying, with his



<P>most virtuous expression of countenance, "What a good fellow you



<P>are, Jo! Did you get blown up?" he added, laughing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, he was pretty mild, on the whole."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"AH!&nbsp; I got it all round.&nbsp; Even you cast me off over there,



<P>and I felt just ready to go to the deuce," he began apologetically.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't talk that way, turn over a new leaf and begin again,



<P>Teddy, my son."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I keep turning over new leaves, and spoiling them, as I



<P>used to spoil my copybooks, and I make so many beginnings there



<P>never will be an end," he said dolefully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Go and eat your dinner, you'll feel better after it.&nbsp; Men



<P>always croak when they are hungry," and Jo whisked out at the



<P>front door after that.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's a `label' on my `sect'," answered Laurie, quoting



<P>Amy, as he went to partake of humble pie dutifully with his



<P>grandfather, who was quite saintly in temper and overwhelmingly



<P>respectful in manner all the rest of the day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Everyone thought the matter ended and the little cloud



<P>blown over, but the mischief was done, for though others forgot



<P>it, Meg remembered.&nbsp; She never alluded to a certain person, but



<P>she thought of him a good deal, dreamed dreams more than ever,



<P>and once Jo, rummaging her sister's desk for stamps, found a



<P>bit of paper scribbled over with the words, `Mrs. John Brooke',



<P>whereat she groaned tragically and cast it into the fire, feeling



<P>that Laurie's prank had hastened the evil day for her.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 19</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER NINETEEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While these things were happening at home, Amy was having



<P>hard times at Aunt March's.&nbsp; She felt her exile deeply, and



<P>for the first time in her life, realized how much she was



<P>beloved and petted at home.&nbsp; Aunt March never petted any one.



<P>She did not approve of it, but she meant to be kind, for the well-



<P>behaved little girl pleased her very much, and Aunt March had



<P>a soft place in her old heart for her nephew's children, though



<P>she didn't think it proper to confess it.&nbsp; She really did her



<P>best to make Amy happy, but, dear me, what mistakes she made.



<P>Some old people keep young at heart in spite of wrinkles and



<P>gray hairs, can sympathize with children's little cares and



<P>joys, make them feel at home, and can hide wise lessons under



<P>pleasant plays, giving and receiving friendship in the sweetest



<P>way.&nbsp; But Aunt March had not this gift, and she worried Amy very



<P>much with her rules and orders, her prim ways, and long, prosy



<P>talks.&nbsp; Finding the child more docile and amiable than her sister,



<P>the old lady felt it her duty to try and counteract, as far as



<P>possible, the bad effects of home freedom and indulgence.&nbsp; So she



<P>took Amy by the hand, and taught her as she herself had been



<P>taught sixty years ago, a process which carried dismay to Amy's



<P>soul, and made her feel like a fly in the web of a very strict



<P>spider.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had to wash the cups every morning, and polish up the



<P>old-fashioned spoons, the fat silver teapot, and the glasses till



<P>they shone.&nbsp; Then she must dust the room, and what a trying job



<P>that was.&nbsp; Not a speck escaped Aunt March's eye, and all the



<P>furniture had claw legs and much carving, which was never dusted



<P>to suit.&nbsp; Then Polly had to be fed, the lap dog combed, and a



<P>dozen trips upstairs and down to get things or deliver orders,



<P>for the old lady was very lame and seldom left her big chair.&nbsp;

After



<P>these tiresome labors, she must do her lessons, which was a daily



<P>trial of every virtue she possessed.&nbsp; Then she was allowed one



<P>hour for exercise or play, and didn't she enjoy it?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie came every day, and wheedled Aunt March till Amy was



<P>allowed to go out with him, when they walked and rode and had



<P>capital times.&nbsp; After dinner, she had to read aloud, and sit still



<P>while the old lady slept, which she usually did for an hour, as



<P>she dropped off over the first page.&nbsp; Then patchwork or towels



<P>appeared, and Amy sewed with outward meekness and inward rebellion



<P>till dusk, when she was allowed to amuse herself as she liked



<P>till teatime.&nbsp; The evenings were the worst of all, for Aunt March



<P>fell to telling long stories about her youth, which were so



<P>unutterably dull that Amy was always ready to go to be, intending



<P>to cry over her hard fate, but usually going to sleep before



<P>she had squeezed out more than a tear or two.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If it had not been for Laurie, and old Esther, the maid,



<P>she felt that she never could have got through that dreadful



<P>time.&nbsp; The parrot alone was enough to drive her distracted, for



<P>he soon felt that she did not admire him, and revenged himself



<P>by being as mischievous as possible.&nbsp; He pulled her hair



<P>whenever she came near him, upset his bread and milk to plague her



<P>when she had newly cleaned his cage, made Mop bark by pecking



<P>at him while Madam dozed, called her names before company, and



<P>behaved in all respects like an reprehensible old bird.&nbsp; Then she



<P>could not endure the dog, a fat, cross beast who snarled and



<P>yelped at her when she made his toilet, and who lay on his back



<P>with all his legs in the air and a most idiotic expression of



<P>countenance when he wanted something to eat, which was about a



<P>dozen times a day.&nbsp; The cook was bad-tempered, the old coachman



<P>was deaf, and Esther the only one who ever took any notice of



<P>the young lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Esther was a Frenchwoman, who had lived with`Madame', as



<P>she called her mistress, for many years, and who rather



<P>tyrannized over the old lady, who could not get along without her.



<P>Her real name was Estelle, but Aunt March ordered her to change it,



<P>and she obeyed, on condition that she was never asked to change



<P>her religion.&nbsp; She took a fancy to Mademoiselle, and amused her



<P>very much with odd stories of her life in France, when Amy sat



<P>with her while she got up Madam's laces.&nbsp; She also allowed her



<P>to roam about the great house, and examine the curious and pretty



<P>things stored away in the big wardrobes and the ancient chests,



<P>for Aunt March hoarded like a magpie.&nbsp; Amy's chief delight was



<P>an Indian cabinet, full of queer drawers, little pigeonholes,



<P>and secret places, in which were kept all sorts of ornaments,



<P>some precious, some merely curious, all more or less antique.



<P>To examine and arrange these things gave Amy great satisfaction,



<P>especially the jewel cases, in which on velvet cushions reposed



<P>the ornaments which had adorned a belle forty years ago.&nbsp; There



<P>was the garnet set which Aunt March wore when she came out, the



<P>pearls her father gave her on her wedding day, her lover's diamonds,



<P>the jet mourning rings and pins, the queer lockets, with portraits



<P>of dead friends and weeping willows made of hair inside, the baby



<P>bracelets her one little daughter had worn, Uncle March's big



<P>watch, with the red seal so many childish hands had played with,



<P>and in a box all by itself lay Aunt March's wedding ring, too small



<P>now for her fat finger, but put carefully away like the most



<P>precious jewel of them all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Which would Mademoiselle choose if she had her will?" asked



<P>Esther, wo always sat near to watch over and lock up the valuables.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I like the diamonds best, but there is no necklace among them,



<P>and I'm fond of necklaces, they are so becoming.&nbsp; I should choose



<P>this if I might," replied Amy, looking with great admiration at a



<P>string of gold and ebony beads from which hung a heavy cross of



<P>the same.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I, too, covet that, but not as a necklace.&nbsp; Ah, no!&nbsp; To me

it



<P>is a rosary, and as such I should use it like a good catholic," said



<P>Esther, eyeing the handsome thing wistfully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is it meant to use as you use the string of good-smelling



<P>wooden beads hanging over your glass?" asked Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Truly, yes, to pray with.&nbsp; It would be pleasing to the saints



<P>if one used so fine a rosary as this, instead of wearing it as a



<P>vain bijou."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You seem to take a great deal of comfort in your prayers,



<P>Esther, and always come down looking quiet and satisfied.&nbsp; I wish



<P>I could."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If Mademoiselle was a Catholic, she would find true comfort,



<P>but as that is not to be, it would be well if you went apart each



<P>day to meditate and pray, as did the good mistress whom I served



<P>before Madame.&nbsp; She had a little chapel, and in it found solacement



<P>for much trouble."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Would it be right for me to do so too?" asked Amy, who in



<P>her loneliness felt the need of help of some sort, and found that



<P>she was apt to forget her little book, now that Beth was not there



<P>to remind her of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It would be excellent and charming, and I shall gladly



<P>arrange the little dressing room for you if you like it.&nbsp; Say



<P>nothing to Madame, but when she sleeps go you and sit alone a



<P>while to think good thoughts, and pray the dear God preserve



<P>your sister."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Esther was truly pious, and quite sincere in her advice, for



<P>she had an affectionate heart, and felt much for the sisters in



<P>their anxiety.&nbsp; Amy liked the idea, and gave her leave to arrange



<P>the light closet next her room, hoping it would do her good.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish I knew where all these pretty things would go when



<P>Aunt March dies," she said, as she slowly replaced the shining



<P>rosary and shut the jewel cases one by one.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To you and your sisters.&nbsp; I know it, Madame confides in me.



<P>I witnessed her will, and it is to be so," whispered Esther smiling.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How nice!&nbsp; But I wish she'd let us have them now.



<P>Procrastination is not agreeable," observed Amy, taking a last



<P>look at the diamonds.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is too soon yet for the young ladies to wear these things.



<P>The first one who is affianced will have the pearls, Madame has said



<P>it, and I have a fancy that the little turquoise ring will be given



<P>to you when you go, for Madame approves your good behavior and



<P>charming manners."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you think so?&nbsp; Oh, I'll be a lamb, if I can only have that



<P>lovely ring!&nbsp; It's ever so much prettier than Kitty Bryant's.&nbsp;

I do



<P>like Aunt March after all." And Amy tried on the blue ring with a



<P>delighted face and a firm resolve to earn it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>From that day she was a model of obedience, and the old lady



<P>complacently admired the success of her training.&nbsp; Esther fitted



<P>up the closet with a little table, placed a footstool before it,



<P>and over it a picture taken from one of the shut-up rooms.&nbsp; She



<P>thought it was of no great value, but, being appropriate, she



<P>borrowed it, well knowing that Madame would never know it, nor



<P>care if she did.&nbsp; It was, however, a very valuable copy of one

of



<P>the famous pictures of the world, and Amy's beauty-loving eyes were



<P>never tired of looking up at the sweet face of the Divine Mother,



<P>while her tender thoughts of her own were busy at her heart.&nbsp; On



<P>the table she laid her little testament and hymnbook, kept a vase



<P>always full of the best flowers Laurie brought her, and came every



<P>day to `sit alone' thinking good thoughts, and praying the dear



<P>God to preserve her sister.&nbsp; Esther had given her a rosary of black



<P>beads with a silver cross, but Amy hung it up and did not use it,



<P>feeling doubtful as to its fitness for Protestant prayers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The little girl was very sincere in all this, for being left



<P>alone outside the safe home nest, she felt the need of some kind



<P>hand to hold by so sorely that she instinctively turned to the



<P>strong and tender Friend, whose fatherly love most closely



<P>surrounds His little children.&nbsp; She missed her mother's help to



<P>understand and rule herself, but having been taught where to look,



<P>she did her best to find the way and walk in it confidingly.&nbsp; But



<P>Amy was a young pilgrim, and just now her burden seemed very heavy.



<P>She tried to forget herself, to keep cheerful, and be satisfied with



<P>doing right, though no one saw or praised her for it.&nbsp; In her first



<P>effort at being very, very good, she decided to make her will, as



<P>Aunt March had done, so that if she did fall ill and die, her



<P>possessions might be justly and generously divided.&nbsp; It cost her

a pang



<P>even to think of giving up the little treasures which in her eyes



<P>were as precious as the old lady's jewels.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>During one of her play hours she wrote out the important



<P>document as well as she could, with some help from Esther as



<P>to certain legal terms, and when the good-natured Frenchwoman



<P>had signed her name, Amy felt relieved and laid it by to show



<P>Laurie, whom she wanted as a second witness.&nbsp; As it was a rainy



<P>day, she went upstairs to amuse herself in one of the large



<P>chambers, and took Polly with her for company.&nbsp; In this room



<P>there was a wardrobe full of old-fashioned costumes with which



<P>Esther allowed her to play, and it was her favorite amusement to



<P>array herself in the faded brocades, and parade up and down before



<P>the long mirror, making stately curtsies, and sweeping her train



<P>about with a rustle which delighted her ears.&nbsp; So busy was she

on



<P>this day that she did not hear Laurie's ring nor see his face



<P>peeping in at her as she gravely promenaded to and fro, flirting



<P>her fan and tossing her head, on which she wore a great pink turban,



<P>contrasting oddly with her blue brocade dress and yellow quilted



<P>petticoat.&nbsp; She was obliged to walk carefully, for she had on



<P>highheeled shoes, and, as Laurie told Jo afterward, it was a comical



<P>sight to see her mince along in her gay suit, with Polly sidilng



<P>and bridling just behind her, imitating her as well as he could,



<P>and occasionally stopping to laugh or exclaim, "Ain't we fine?



<P>Get along, you fright!&nbsp; Hold your tongue!&nbsp; Kiss me, dear!&nbsp;

Ha! Ha!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Having with difficulty restrained an explosion of merriment,



<P>lest it should offend her majesty, Laurie tapped and was graciously



<P>received.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sit down and rest while I put these things away, then I want



<P>to consult you about a very serious matter," said Amy, when she



<P>had shown her splendor and driven Polly into a corner.&nbsp; "That bird



<P>is the trial of my life," she continued, removing the pink mountain



<P>from her head, while Laurie seated himself astride a chair.



<P>"Yesterday, when Aunt was asleep and I was trying to be as still as

a



<P>mouse, Polly began to squall and flap about in his cage, so I went



<P>to let him out, and found a big spider there.&nbsp; I poked it out,

and



<P>it ran under the bookcase.&nbsp; Polly marched straight after it, stooped



<P>down and peeped under the bookcase, saying, in his funny way, with a



<P>cock of his eye, `Come out and take a walk, my dear.' I couldn't help



<P>laughing, which made Poll swear, and Aunt woke up and scolded us both."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did the spider accept the old fellow's invitation?" asked Laurie, yawning.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, out it came, and away ran Polly, frightened to death, and



<P>scrambled up on Aunt's chair, calling out, `Catch her! Catch her!



<P>Catch her!' as I chased the spider."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's a lie!&nbsp; Oh, lor!" cried the parrot, pecking at Laurie's

toes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'd wring your neck if you were mine, you old torment," cried



<P>Laurie, shaking his fist at the bird, who put his head on one side



<P>and gravely croaked, "Allyluyer!&nbsp; Bless your buttons, dear!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now I'm ready," said Amy, shutting the wardrobe and taking a



<P>piece of paper out of her pocket.&nbsp; "I want you to read that, please,



<P>and tell me if it is legal and right.&nbsp; I felt I ought to do it,

for



<P>life is uncertain and I don't want any ill feeling over my tomb."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie bit his lips, and turning a little from the pensive



<P>speaker, read the following document, with praiseworthy gravity,



<P>considering the spelling:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>MY LAST WILL AND TESTIMENT

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I, Amy Curtis March, being in my sane mind, go give and



<P>bequeethe all my earthly property--viz.to wit:--namely

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To my father, my best pictures, sketches, maps, and works



<P>of art, including frames.&nbsp; Also my $100, to do what he likes with.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To my mother, all my clothes, except the blue apron with



<P>pockets--also my likeness, and my medal, with much love.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To my dear sister Margaret, I give my turkquoise ring (if I



<P>get it), also my green box with the doves on it, also my; piece



<P>of real lace for her neck, and my sketch of her as a memorial of



<P>her 'little girl'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To Jo I leave my breastpin, the one mended with sealing wax,



<P>also my bronze inkstand--she lost the cover--and my most precious



<P>plaster rabbit, because I am sorry I burned up her story.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To Beth (if she lives after me) I give my dolls and the



<P>little bureau, my fan, my linen collars and my new slippers if



<P>she can wear them being thin when she gets well.&nbsp; And I herewith



<P>also leave her my regret that I ever made fun of old Joanna.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To my friend and neighbor Theodore Laurence I bequeethe my



<P>paper mashay portfolio, my clay model of a horse though he did



<P>say it hadn't any neck.&nbsp; Also in return for his great kindness



<P>in the hour of affliction any one of my artistic works he likes,



<P>Noter Dame is the best.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To our venerable benefactor Mr. Laurence I leave my purple



<P>box with a looking glass in the cover which will be nice for



<P>his pens and remind him of the departed girl who thanks him



<P>for his favors to her family, especially Beth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I wish my favorite playmate Kitty Bryant to have the blue



<P>silk apron and my gold-bead ring with a kiss.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To Hannah I give the bandbox she wanted and all the patchwork



<P>I leave hoping she `will remember me, when it you see'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And now having disposed of my most valuable property I hope



<P>all will be satisfied and not blame the dead.&nbsp; I forgive everyone,



<P>and trust we may all meet when the trump shall sound.&nbsp; Amen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To this will and testiment I set my hand and seal on this



<P>20th day of Nov.&nbsp; Anni Domino 1861.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy Curtis March

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Witnesses:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Estelle Valnor,



<P>Theodore Laurence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The last name was written in pencil, and Amy explained



<P>that he was to rewrite it in ink and seal it up for her properly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What put it into your head?&nbsp; Did anyone tell you about Beth's



<P>giving away her things?" asked Laurie soberly, as Amy laid a bit



<P>of red tape, with sealing wax, a taper, and a standish before him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She explained and then asked anxiously, "What about Beth?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm sorry I spoke, but as I did, I'll tell you.&nbsp; She felt so



<P>ill one day that she told Jo she wanted to give her piano to Meg,



<P>her cats to you, and the poor old doll to Jo, who would love it for



<P>her sake.&nbsp; She was sorry she had so little to give, and left locks



<P>of hair to the rest of us, and her best love to Grandpa.&nbsp; She never



<P>thought of a will."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie was signing and sealing as he spoke, and did not look



<P>up till a great tear dropped on the paper.&nbsp; Amy's face was full



<P>of trouble, but she only said, "Don't people put sort of



<P>postscripts to their wills, sometimes?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, `codicils', they call them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Put one in mine then, that I wish all my curls cut off, and



<P>given round to my friends.&nbsp; I forgot it, but I want it done though



<P>it will spoil my looks."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie added it, smiling at Amy's last and greatest sacrifice.



<P>Then he amused her for an hour, and was much interested in all her



<P>trials.&nbsp; But when he came to go, Amy held him back to whisper with



<P>trembling lips, "Is there really any danger about Beth?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm afraid there is, but we must hope for the best, so don't



<P>cry, dear."&nbsp; And Laurie put his arm about her with a brotherly



<P>gesture which was very comforting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When he had gone, she went to her little chapel, and sitting



<P>in the twilight, prayed for Beth, with streaming tears and an



<P>aching heart, feeling that a million turquoise rings would not



<P>console her for the loss of her gentle little sister.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 25</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER TWENTY-FIVE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The June roses over the porch were awake bright and early on



<P>that morning, rejoicing with all their hearts in the cloudless



<P>sunshine, like friendly little neighbors, as they were.&nbsp; Quite

flushed



<P>with excitement were their ruddy faces, as they swung in the wind,



<P>whispering to one another what they had seen, for some peeped in at



<P>the dining room windows where the feast was spread, some climbed up



<P>to nod and smile at the sisters as they dressed the bride, others



<P>waved a welcome to those who came and went on various errands in



<P>garden, porch, and hall, and all, from the rosiest full-blown



<P>flower to the palest baby bud, offered their tribute of beauty and



<P>fragrance to the gentle mistress who had loved and tended them so



<P>long.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg looked very like a rose herself, for all that was best and



<P>sweetest in heart and soul seemed to bloom into her face that day,



<P>making it fair and tender, with a charm more beautiful than beauty.



<P>Neither silk, lace, nor orange flowers would she have.&nbsp; "I don't



<P>want a fashionable wedding, but only those about me whom I love,



<P>and to them I wish to look and be my familiar self."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So she made her wedding gown herself, sewing into it the tender



<P>hopes and innocent romances of a girlish heart.&nbsp; her sisters braided



<P>up her pretty hair, and the only ornaments she wore were the lilies



<P>of the valley, which `her John' liked best of all the flowers that



<P>grew.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You do look just like our own dear Meg, only so very sweet



<P>and lovely that I should hug you if it wouldn't crumple your dress,"



<P>cried Amy, surveying her with delight when all was done.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then I am satisfied.&nbsp; But please hug and kiss me, everyone,



<P>and don't mind my dress.&nbsp; I want a great many crumples of this



<P>sort put into it today."&nbsp; And Meg opened her arms to her sisters,



<P>who clung about her with April faces for a minute, feeling that



<P>the new love had not changed the old.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now I'm going to tie John's cravat for him, and then to stay



<P>a few minutes with Father quietly in the study."&nbsp; And Meg ran



<P>down to perform these little ceremonies, and then to follow her



<P>mother wherever she went, conscious that in spite of the smiles



<P>on the motherly face, there was a secret sorrow hid in the motherly



<P>heart at the flight of the first bird from the nest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As the younger girls stand together, giving the last touches



<P>to their simple toilet, it may be a good time to tell of a few



<P>changes which three years have wrought in their appearance, for



<P>all are looking their best just now.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo's angles are much softened, she has learned to carry herself



<P>with ease, if not grace.&nbsp; The curly crop has lengthened into



<P>a thick coil, more becoming to the small head atop of the tall



<P>figure.&nbsp; There is a fresh color in her brown cheeks, a soft shine



<P>in her eyes, and only gentle words fall from her sharp tongue today.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth has grown slender, pale, and more quiet than ever.&nbsp; The



<P>beautiful, kind eyes are larger, and in them lies an expression



<P>that saddens one, although it is not sad itself.&nbsp; It is the shadow



<P>of pain which touches the young face with such pathetic patience,



<P>but Beth seldom complains and always speaks hopefully of `being



<P>better soon'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy is with truth considered `the flower of the family', for



<P>at sixteen she has the air and bearing of a full-grown woman, not



<P>beautiful, but possessed of that indescribable charm called grace.



<P>One saw it in the lines of her figure, the make and motion of her



<P>hands, the flow of her dress, the droop of her hair, unconscious



<P>yet harmonious, and as attractive to many as beauty itself.&nbsp; Amy's



<P>nose still afflicted her, for it never would grow Grecian, so did



<P>her mouth, being too wide, and having a decided chin.&nbsp; These offending



<P>features gave character to her whole face, but she never could see it,



<P>and consoled herself with her wonderfully fair complexion,



<P>keen blue eyes, and curls more golden and abundant than ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All three wore suits of thin silver gray (their best gowns for



<P>the summer), with blush roses in hair and bosom, and all three



<P>looked just what they were, fresh-faced, happy-hearted girls, pausing



<P>a moment in their busy lives to read with wistful eyes the sweetest



<P>chapter in the romance of womanhood.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There were to be no ceremonious performances, everything was



<P>to be as natural and homelike as possible, so when Aunt March arrived,



<P>she was scandalized to see the bride come running to welcome and lead

her in,



<P>to find the bridegroom fastening up a garland that had fallen down,



<P>and to catch a glimpse of the paternal minister marching upstairs



<P>with a grave countenance and a wine bottle under each arm.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word, here's a state of things!" cried the old lady,



<P>taking the seat of honor prepared for her, and settling the folds



<P>of her lavender moire with a great rustle.&nbsp; "You oughtn't to be



<P>seen till the last minute, child."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm not a show, Aunty, and no one is coming to stare at me,



<P>to criticize my dress, or count the cost of my luncheon.&nbsp; I'm too



<P>happy to care what anyone says or thinks, and I'm going to have



<P>my little wedding just as I like it.&nbsp; John, dear, here's your



<P>hammer."&nbsp; And away went Meg to help `that man' in his highly



<P>improper employment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Brooke didn't even say, "Thank you," but as he stooped



<P>for the unromantic tool, he kissed his little bride behind the



<P>folding door, with a look that made Aunt March whisk out her



<P>pocket handkerchief with a sudden dew in her sharp old eyes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A crash, a cry, and a laugh from Laurie, accompanied by the



<P>indecorous exclamation, "Jupiter Ammon!&nbsp; Jo's upset the cake again!"



<P>caused a momentary flurry, which was hardly over when a flock of



<P>cousins arrived, and `the party came in', as Beth used to say when



<P>a child.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't let that young giant come near me, he worries me worse



<P>than mosquitoes," whispered the old lady to Amy, as the rooms filled



<P>and Laurie's black head towered above the rest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He has promised to be very good today, and he can be perfectly



<P>elegant if he likes," returned Amy, and gliding away to warn



<P>Hercules to beware of the dragon, which warning caused him to haunt



<P>the old lady with a devotion that nearly distracted her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was no bridal procession, but a sudden silence fell upon



<P>the room as Mr. March and the young couple took their places under



<P>the green arch.&nbsp; Mother and sisters gathered close, as if loath

to



<P>give Meg up.&nbsp; The fatherly voice broke more than once, which only



<P>seemed to make the service more beautiful and solemn.&nbsp; The bridegroom's



<P>hand trembled visibly, and no one heard his replies.&nbsp; But Meg



<P>looked straight up in her husband's eyes, and said, "I will!"



<P>with such tender trust in her own face and voice that her mother's



<P>heart rejoiced and Aunt March sniffed audibly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo did not cry, though she was very near it once, and was only



<P>saved from a demonstration by the consciousness that Laurie was



<P>staring fixedly at her, with a comical mixture of merriment and



<P>emotion in his wicked black eyes.&nbsp; Beth kept her face hidden on

her



<P>mother's shoulder, but Amy stood like a graceful statue, with a



<P>most becoming ray of sunshine touching her white forehead and the



<P>flower in her hair.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It wasn't at all the thing, I'm afraid, but the minute she was



<P>fairly married, Meg cried, "The first kiss for Marmee!" and turning,



<P>gave it with her heart on her lips.&nbsp; During the next fifteen minutes



<P>she looked more like a rose than ever, for everyone availed themselves



<P>of their privileges to the fullest extent, from Mr. Laurence



<P>to old Hannah, who, adorned with a headdress fearfully and



<P>wonderfully made, fell upon her in the hall, crying with a sob



<P>and a chuckle, "Bless you, deary, a hundred times!&nbsp; The cake ain't



<P>hurt a mite, and everything looks lovely."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Everybody cleared up after that, and said something brilliant,



<P>or tried to, which did just as well, for laughter is ready when



<P>hearts are light.&nbsp; There was no display of gifts, for they were



<P>already in the little house, nor was there an elaborate breakfast,



<P>but a plentiful lunch of cake and fruit, dressed with flowers.



<P>Mr. Laurence and Aunt March shrugged and smiled at one another when



<P>water, lemonade, and coffee were found to be to only sorts of



<P>nectar which the three Hebes carried around.&nbsp; No one said anything,



<P>till Laurie, who insisted on serving the bride, appeared before her,



<P>with a loaded salver in his hand and a puzzled expression on his face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Has Jo smashed all the bottles by accident?" he whispered,



<P>"or am I merely laboring under a delusion that I saw some lying



<P>about loose this morning?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, your grandfather kindly offered us his best, and Aunt



<P>March actually sent some, but Father put away a little for Beth,



<P>and dispatched the rest to the Soldier's Home.&nbsp; You know he thinks



<P>that wine should be used only in illness, and Mother says that



<P>neither she nor her daughters will ever offer it to any young man



<P>under her roof."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg spoke seriously and expected to see Laurie frown or laugh,



<P>but he did neither, for after a quick look at her, he said, in



<P>his impetuous way, "I like that!&nbsp; For I've seen enough harm done



<P>to wish other women would think as you do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are not made wise by experience, I hope?" And there was



<P>an anxious accent in Meg's voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No.&nbsp; I give you my word for it.&nbsp; Don't think too well of

me,



<P>either, this is not one of my temptations.&nbsp; Being brought up where



<P>wine is as common as water and almost as harmless, I don't care for



<P>it, but when a pretty girl offers it, one doesn't like to refuse,



<P>you see."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you will, for the sake of others, if not for your own.



<P>Come, Laurie, promise, and give me one more reason to call this the



<P>happiest day of my life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A demand so sudden and so serious made the young man hesitate



<P>a moment, for ridicule is often harder to bear than self-denial.



<P>Meg knew that if he gave the promise he would keep it at all costs,



<P>and feeling her power, used it as a woman may for her friend's good.



<P>She did not speak, but she looked up at him with a face made very



<P>eloquent by happiness, and a smile which said, "No one can refuse



<P>me anything today."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie certainly could not, and with an answering smile, he



<P>gave her his hand, saying heartily, "I promise, Mrs. Brooke!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thank you, very, very much."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I drink `long life to your resolution', Teddy," cried Jo,



<P>baptizing him with a splash of lemonade, as she waved her glass and



<P>beamed approvingly upon him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So the toast was drunk, the pledge made and loyally kept in



<P>spite of many temptations, for with instinctive wisdom, the girls



<P>seized a happy moment to do their friend a service, for which he



<P>thanked them all his life.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After lunch, people strolled about, by twos and threes, through



<P>the house and garden, enjoying the sunshine without and within.&nbsp;

Meg



<P>and John happened to be standing together in the middle of the grass



<P>plot, when Laurie was seized with an inspiration which put the



<P>finishing touch to this unfashionable wedding.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"All the married people take hands and dance round the new-made



<P>husband and wife, as the Germans do, while we bachelors and spinsters



<P>prance in couples outside!" cried Laurie, promenading down the path



<P>with Amy, with such infectious spirit and skill that everyone else



<P>followed their example without a murmur.&nbsp; Mr. and Mrs. March, Aunt



<P>and Uncle Carrol began it, others rapidly joined in, even Sallie



<P>Moffat, after a moment's hesitation, threw her train over her arm



<P>and whisked Ned into the ring.&nbsp; But the crowning joke was Mr.



<P>Laurence and Aunt March, for when the stately old gentleman chass'ed



<P>solemnly up to the old lady, she just tucked her cane under arm, and



<P>hopped briskly away to join hands with the rest and dance about the



<P>bridal pair, while the young folks pervaded the garden like butterflies



<P>on a midsummer day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Want of breath brought the impromptu ball to a close, and then



<P>people began to go.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish you well, my dear, I heartily wish you well, but I think



<P>you'll be sorry for it," said Aunt March to Meg, adding to the



<P>bridegroom, as he led her to the carriage, "You've got a treasure,



<P>young man, see that you deserve it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is the prettiest wedding I've been to for an age, Ned, and



<P>I don't see why, for there wasn't a bit of style about it," observed



<P>Mrs. Moffat to her husband, as they drove away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Laurie, my lad, if you ever want to indulge in this sort of



<P>thing, get one of those little girls to help you, and I shall be



<P>perfectly satisfied," said Mr. Laurence, settling himself in his



<P>easy chair to rest after the excitement of the morning.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll do my best to gratify you, Sir," was Laurie's unusually



<P>dutiful reply, as he carefully unpinned the posy Jo had put in his



<P>buttonhole.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The little house was not far away, and the only bridal journey



<P>Meg had was the quiet walk with John from the old home to the new.



<P>When she came down, looking like a pretty Quakeress in her



<P>dovecolored suit and straw bonnet tied with white, they all gathered



<P>about her to say goodby, as tenderly as if she had been going to



<P>make the grand tour.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't feel that I am separated from you, Marmee dear, or that



<P>I love you any the less for loving John so much," she said, clinging



<P>to her mother, with full eyes for a moment.&nbsp; "I shall come every

day,



<P>Father, and expect to keep my old place in all your hearts, though I



<P>am married.&nbsp; Beth is going to be with me a great deal, and the

other



<P>girls will drop in now and then to laugh at my housekeeping struggles.



<P>Thank you all for my happy wedding day.&nbsp; Goodby, goodby!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They stood watching her, with faces full of love and hope and



<P>tender pride as she walked away, leaning on her husband's arm, with



<P>her hands full of flowers and the June sunshine brightening her happy



<P>face--and so Meg's married life began.



<P>
