   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 31</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER THIRTY-ONE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>London

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dearest People,



<P>Here I really sit at a front window of the Bath Hotel,



<P>Piccadilly.&nbsp; It's not a fashionable place, but Uncle stopped



<P>here years ago, and won't go anywhere else.&nbsp; However, we don't



<P>mean to stay long, so it's no great matter.&nbsp; Oh, I can't begin



<P>to tell you how I enjoy it all!&nbsp; I never can, so I'll only give



<P>you bits out of my notebook, for I've done nothing but sketch



<P>and scribble since I started.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I sent a line from Halifax, when I felt pretty miserable,



<P>but after that I got on delightfully, seldom ill, on deck all



<P>day, with plenty of pleasant people to amuse me.&nbsp; Everyone was



<P>very kind to me, especially the officers.&nbsp; Don't laugh, Jo,



<P>gentlemen really are very necessary aboard ship, to hold on to,



<P>or to wait upon one, and as they have nothing to do, it's a mercy



<P>to make them useful, otherwise they would smoke themselves to death,



<P>I'm afraid.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Aunt and Flo were poorly all the way, and liked to be let



<P>alone, so when I had done what I could for them, I went and



<P>enjoyed myself.&nbsp; Such walks on deck, such sunsets, such splendid



<P>air and waves!&nbsp; It was almost as exciting as riding a fast horse,



<P>when we went rushing on so grandly.&nbsp; I wish Beth could have come,



<P>it would have done her so much good.&nbsp; As for Jo, she would have



<P>gone up and sat on the maintop jib, or whatever the high thing



<P>is called, made friends with the engineers, and tooted on the



<P>captain's speaking trumpet, she'd have been in such a state of



<P>rapture.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was all heavenly, but I was glad to see the Irish coast,



<P>and found it very lovely, so green and sunny, with brown cabins



<P>here and there, ruins on some of the hills, and gentlemen's



<P>countryseats in the valleys, with deer feeding in the parks.



<P>It was early in the morning, but I didn't regret getting up to



<P>see it, for the bay was full of little boats, the shore so picturesque,



<P>and a rosy sky overhead.&nbsp; I never shall forget it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At Queenstown on of my new acquaintances left us, Mr.



<P>Lennox, and when I said something about the Lakes of Killarney,



<P>he sighed and and, with a look at me...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, have you e'er heard of Kate Kearney?



<P>She lives on the banks of Killarney;



<P>From the glance of her eye,



<P>Shun danger and fly,



<P>For fatal's the glance of Kate Kearney."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Wasn't that nonsensical?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>We only stopped at Liverpool a few hours.&nbsp; It's a dirty,



<P>noisy place, and I was glad to leave it.&nbsp; Uncle rushed out and



<P>bought a pair of dogskin gloves, some ugly, thick shoes, and an



<P>umbrella, and got shaved `a la mutton chop, the first thing.



<P>Then he flattered himself that he looked like a true Briton,



<P>but the first time he had the mud cleaned off his shoes, the



<P>little bootblack knew that an American stood in them, and said,



<P>with a grin, "There yer har, sir.&nbsp; I've given `em the latest



<P>Yankee shine."&nbsp; It amused Uncle immensely.&nbsp; Oh, I must tell

you



<P>what that absurd Lennox did!&nbsp; He got his friend Ward, who came



<P>on with us, to order a bouquet for me, and the first thing I



<P>saw in my room was a lovely one, with "Robert Lennox's compliments,"



<P>on the card.&nbsp; Wasn't that fun, girls? I like traveling.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I never shall get to London if I don't hurry.&nbsp; The trip was



<P>like riding through a long picture gallery, full of lovely landscapes.



<P>The farmhouses were my delight, with thatched roofs,



<P>ivy up to the eaves, latticed windows, and stout women with rosy



<P>children at the doors.&nbsp; The very cattle looked more tranquil



<P>than ours, as they stood knee-deep in clover, and the hens had



<P>a contented cluck, as if they never got nervous like Yankee



<P>biddies.&nbsp; Such perfect color I never saw, the grass so green, sky



<P>so blue, grain so yellow, woods so dark, I was in a rapture all



<P>the way.&nbsp; So was Flo, and we kept bouncing from one side to the



<P>other, trying to see everything while we were whisking along at



<P>the rate of sixty miles an hour.&nbsp; Aunt was tired and went to sleep,



<P>but Uncle read his guidebook, and wouldn't be astonished at anything.



<P>This is the way we went on.&nbsp; Amy, flying up--"Oh, that



<P>must be Kenilworth, that gray place among the trees!"&nbsp; Flo, darting



<P>to my window--"How sweet!&nbsp; We must go there sometime, won't we



<P>Papa?" Uncle, calmly admiring his boots--"No, my dear, not unless



<P>you want beer, that's a brewery."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A pause--then Flo cried out, "Bless me, there's a gallows and



<P>a man going up."&nbsp; "Where, where?" shrieks Amy, staring out at two



<P>tall posts with a crossbeam and some dangling chains.&nbsp; "A colliery,"



<P>remarks Uncle, with a twinkle of the eye.&nbsp; "Here's a lovely flock



<P>of lambs all lying down," says Amy.&nbsp; "See, Papa, aren't they



<P>pretty?" added Flo sentimentally.&nbsp; "Geese, young ladies," returns



<P>Uncle, in a tone that keeps us quiet till Flo settles down to



<P>enjoy the FLIRTATIONS OF CAPTAIN CAVENDISH, and I have the scenery



<P>all to myself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Of course it rained when we got to London, and there was



<P>nothing to be seen but fog and umbrellas.&nbsp; We rested, unpacked,



<P>and shopped a little between the showers.&nbsp; Aunt Mary got me some



<P>new things, for I came off in such a hurry I wasn't half ready.



<P>A white hat and blue feather, a muslin dress to match, and the



<P>loveliest mantle you ever saw.&nbsp; Shopping in Regent Street is



<P>perfectly splendid.&nbsp; Things seem so cheap, nice ribbons only



<P>sixpence a yard.&nbsp; I laid in a stock, but shall get my gloves



<P>in Paris.&nbsp; Doesn't that sound sort of elegant and rich?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Flo and I, for the fun of it, ordered a hansom cab, while



<P>Aunt and Uncle were out, and went for a drive, though we learned



<P>afterward that it wasn't the thing for young ladies to ride in



<P>them alone.&nbsp; It was so droll!&nbsp; For when we were shut in by

the



<P>wooden apron, the man drove so fast that Flo was frightened, and



<P>told me to stop him.&nbsp; but he was up outside behind somewhere,



<P>and I couldn't get at him.&nbsp; He didn't hear me call, nor see me



<P>flap my parasol in front, and there we were, quite helpless,



<P>rattling away, and whirling around corners at a breakneck pace.



<P>At last, in my despair, I saw a little door in the roof, and on



<P>poking it open, a red eye appeared, and a beery voice said...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, then, mum?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I gave my order as soberly as I could, and slamming down



<P>the door, with an "Aye, aye, mum," the man made his horse walk,



<P>as if going to a funeral.&nbsp; I poked again and said, "A little



<P>faster," then off he went, helter-skelter as before, and we



<P>resigned ourselves to our fate.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Today was fair, and we went to Hyde Park, close by, for we



<P>are more aristocratic than we look.&nbsp; The Duke of Devonshire lives



<P>near.&nbsp; I often see his footmen lounging at the back gate, and



<P>the Duke of Wellington's house is not far off.&nbsp; Such sights as

I



<P>saw, my dear!&nbsp; It was as good as Punch, for there were fat dowagers



<P>rolling about in their red and yellow coaches, with gorgeous



<P>Jeameses in silk stockings and velvet coats, up behind, and powdered



<P>coachmen in front.&nbsp; Smart maids, with the rosiest children



<P>I ever saw, handsome girls, looking half asleep, dandies in queer



<P>English hats and lavender kids lounging about, and tall soldiers,



<P>in short red jackets and muffin caps stuck on one side, looking



<P>so funny I longed to sketch them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Rotten Row means `Route de Roi', or the king's way, but



<P>now it's more like a riding school than anything else.&nbsp; The



<P>horses are splendid, and the men, especially the grooms, ride



<P>well, but the women are stiff, and bounce, which isn't according



<P>to our rules.&nbsp; I longed to show them a tearing American



<P>gallop, for they trotted solemnly up and down, in their scant



<P>habits and high hats, looking like the women in a toy Noah's



<P>Ark.&nbsp; Everyone rides--old men, stout ladies, little children--



<P>and the young folks do a deal of flirting here, I say a pair



<P>exchange rose buds, for it's the thing to wear one in the



<P>button-hole, and I thought it rather a nice little idea.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the P.M.&nbsp; to Westminster Abbey, but don't expect me to



<P>describe it, that's impossible, so I'll only say it was sublime!



<P>This evening we are going to see Fechter, which will be an appropriate



<P>end to the happiest day of my life.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It's very late, but I can't let my letter go in the morning



<P>without telling you what happened last evening.&nbsp; Who do



<P>you think came in, as we were at tea?&nbsp; Laurie's English friends,



<P>Fred and Frank Vaughn!&nbsp; I was so surprised, for I shouldn't have



<P>known them but for the cards.&nbsp; both are tall fellows with whiskers,



<P>Fred handsome in the English style, and Frank much better,



<P>for he only limps slightly, and uses no crutches.&nbsp; They had heard



<P>from Laurie where we were to be, and came to ask us to their



<P>house, but Uncle won't go, so we shall return the call, and see



<P>them as we can.&nbsp; They went to the theater with us, and we did



<P>have such a good time, for Frank devoted himself to Flo, and



<P>Fred and I talked over past, present, and future fun as if we



<P>had know each other all our days.&nbsp; Tell Beth Frank asked for her,



<P>and was sorry to hear of her ill health.&nbsp; Fred laughed when I



<P>spoke of Jo, and sent his `respectful compliments to the big hat'.



<P>Neither of them had forgotten Camp Laurence, or the fun we had



<P>there.&nbsp; What ages ago it seems, doesn't it?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Aunt is tapping on the wall for the third time, so I must



<P>stop.&nbsp; I really feel like a dissipated London fine lady, writing



<P>here so late, with my room full of pretty things, and my head



<P>a jumble of parks, theaters, new gowns, and gallant creatures



<P>who say "Ah!" and twirl their blond mustaches with the true



<P>English lordliness.&nbsp; I long to see you all, and in spite of my



<P>nonsense am, as ever, your loving...



<P>AMY

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>PARIS

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dear girls,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In my last I told you about our London visit, how kind the



<P>Vaughns were, and what pleasant parties they made for us.&nbsp; I enjoyed



<P>the trips to Hampton Court and the Kensington Museum more than



<P>anything else, for at Hampton I saw Raphael's cartoons, and



<P>at the Museum, rooms full of pictures by Turner, Lawrence, Reynolds,



<P>Hogarth, and the other great creatures.&nbsp; The day in Richmond



<P>Park was charming, for we had a regular English picnic, and



<P>I had more splendid oaks and groups of deer than I could copy,



<P>also heard a nightingale, and saw larks go up.&nbsp; We `did' London



<P>to our heart's content, thanks to Fred and Frank, and were sorry



<P>to go away, for though English people are slow to take you in,



<P>when they once make up their minds to do it they cannot be outdone



<P>in hospitality, I think.&nbsp; The Vaughns hope to meet us in



<P>Rome next winter, and I shall be dreadfully disappointed if they



<P>don't, for Grace and I are great friends, and the boys very



<P>nice fellows, especially Fred.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Well, we were hardly settled here, when he turned up again,



<P>saying he had come for a holiday, and was going to Switzerland.



<P>Aunt looked sober at first, but he was so cool about it she



<P>couldn't say a word.&nbsp; And now we get on nicely, and are very



<P>glad he came, for he speaks French like a native, and I don't



<P>know what we should do without him.&nbsp; Uncle doesn't know ten



<P>words, and insists on talking English very loud, as if it



<P>would make people understand him.&nbsp; Aunt's pronunciation is



<P>old-fashioned, and Flo and I, though we flattered ourselves



<P>that we knew a good deal, find we don't, and are very grateful



<P>to have Fred do the `parley vooing', as Uncle calls it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such delightful times as we are having!&nbsp; Sight-seeing from



<P>morning till night, stopping for nice lunches in the gay cafes,



<P>and meeting with all sorts of droll adventures.&nbsp; Rainy days I



<P>spend in the Louvre, revelling in pictures.&nbsp; Jo would turn up



<P>her naughty nose at some of the finest, because she has no



<P>soul for art, but I have, and I'm cultivation eye and taste



<P>as fast as I can.&nbsp; She would like the relics of great people



<P>better, for I've seen her Napoleon's cocked hat and gray



<P>coat, his baby's cradle and his old toothbrush, also Marie



<P>Antoinette's little shoe, the ring of Saint Denis, Charlemagne's



<P>sword, and many other interesting things.&nbsp; I'll talk for hours



<P>about them when I come, but haven't time to write.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Palais Royale is a heavenly place, so full of bijouterie



<P>and lovely things that I'm nearly distracted because I can't



<P>buy them.&nbsp; Fred wanted to get me some, but of course I didn't



<P>allow it.&nbsp; Then the Bois and Champs Elysees are tres magnifique.



<P>I've seen the imperial family several times, the emperor an ugly,



<P>hard-looking man, the empress pale and pretty, but dressed in



<P>bad taste, I thought--purple dress, green hat, and yellow gloves.



<P>Little Nap is a handsome boy, who sits chatting to his tutor,



<P>and kissed his hand to the people as he passes in his four-horse



<P>barouche, with postilions in red satin jackets and a mounted



<P>guard before and behind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>We often walk in the Tuileries Gardens, for they are



<P>lovely, though the antique Luxembourg Gardens suit me better.



<P>Pere la Chaise is very curious, for many of the tombs are



<P>like small rooms, and looking in, one sees a table, with



<P>images or pictures of the dead, and chairs for the mourners



<P>to sit in when they come to lament.&nbsp; That is so Frenchy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Our rooms are on the Rue de Rivoli, and sitting on the



<P>balcony, we look up and down the long, brilliant street.&nbsp; It



<P>is so pleasant that we spend our evenings talking there when



<P>too tired with our day's work to go out.&nbsp; Fred is very entertaining,



<P>and is altogether the most agreeable young man I ever knew--



<P>except Laurie, whose manners are more charming.&nbsp; I wish Fred



<P>was dark, for I don't fancy light men, however, the Vaughns



<P>are very rich and come of an excellent family, so I won't



<P>find fault with their yellow hair, as my own is yellower.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Next week we are off to Germany and Switzerland, and as



<P>we shall travel fast, I shall only be able to give you hasty



<P>letters.&nbsp; I keep my diary, and try to `remember correctly and



<P>describe clearly all that I see and admire', as Father advised.



<P>It is good practice for me, and with my sketchbook will give



<P>you a better idea of my tour than these scribbles.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Adieu, I embrace you tenderly.



<P>VOTRE AMIE

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>HEIDELBERG

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>My dear Mamma,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Having a quiet hour before we leave for Berne, I'll try to



<P>tell you what has happened, for some of it is very important,



<P>as you will see.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The sail up the Rhine was perfect, and I just sat and enjoyed



<P>it with all my might.&nbsp; Get Father's old guidebooks and



<P>read about it.&nbsp; I haven't words beautiful enough to describe it.



<P>At Coblenz we had a lovely time, for some students from Bonn,



<P>with whom Fred got acquainted on the boat, gave us a serenade.



<P>It was a moonlight night, and about one o'clock Flo and I were



<P>waked by the most delicious music under our windows.&nbsp; We flew up,



<P>and hid behind the curtains, but sly peeps showed us Fred and



<P>the students singing away down below.&nbsp; It was the most romantic



<P>thing I ever saw--the river, the bridge of boats, the great fortress



<P>opposite, moonlight everywhere, and music fit to melt a heart of stone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When they were done we threw down some flowers, and saw



<P>them scramble for them, kiss their hands to the invisible ladies,



<P>and go laughing away, to smoke and drink beer, I suppose.&nbsp; Next



<P>morning Fred showed me one of the crumpled flowers in his vest



<P>pocket, and looked very sentimental.&nbsp; I laughed at him, and said



<P>I didn't throw it, but Flo, which seemed to disgust him, for he



<P>tossed it out of the window, and turned sensible again.&nbsp; I'm



<P>afraid I'm going to have trouble with that boy, it begins to



<P>look like it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The baths at Nassau were very gay, so was Baden-Baden,



<P>where Fred lost some money, and I scolded him.&nbsp; He needs someone



<P>to look after him when Frank is not with him.&nbsp; Kate said



<P>once she hoped he'd marry soon, and I quite agree with her



<P>that it would be well for him.&nbsp; Frankfurt was delightful.&nbsp;

I



<P>saw Goeth's house, Schiller's statue, and Dannecker's famous



<P>Ariadne.&nbsp; It was very lovely, but I should have enjoyed it



<P>more if I had known the story better.&nbsp; I didn't like to ask, as



<P>everyone knew it or pretended they did.&nbsp; I wish Jo would tell



<P>me all about it.&nbsp; I ought to have read more, for I find I don't



<P>know anything, and it mortifies me.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now comes the serious part, for it happened here, and Fred



<P>has just gone.&nbsp; He has been so kind and jolly that we all got



<P>quite fond of him.&nbsp; I never thought of anything but a traveling



<P>friendship till the serenade night.&nbsp; Since then I've begun to



<P>feel that the moonlight walks, balcony talks, and daily adventures



<P>were something more to him than fun.&nbsp; I haven't flirted,



<P>Mother, truly, but remembered what you said to me, and have done



<P>my very best.&nbsp; I can't help it if people like me.&nbsp; I don't

try to



<P>make them, and it worries me if I don't care for them, though Jo



<P>says I haven't got any heart.&nbsp; Now I know Mother will shake her



<P>head, and the girls say, "Oh, the mercenary little wretch!", but



<P>I've made up my mind, and if Fred asks me, I shall accept him,



<P>though I'm not madly in love.&nbsp; I like him, and we get on comfortably



<P>together.&nbsp; He is handsome, young, clever enough, and very



<P>rich--ever so much richer than the Laurences.&nbsp; I don't think his



<P>family would object, and I should be very happy, for they are all



<P>kind, well-bred, generous people, and they like me.&nbsp; Fred, as the



<P>eldest twin, will have the estate, I suppose, and such a splendid



<P>one it is!&nbsp; A city house in a fashionable street, not so showy



<P>as our big houses, but twice as comfortable and full of solid



<P>luxury, such as English people believe in.&nbsp; I like it, for it's



<P>genuine.&nbsp; I've seen the plate, the family jewels, the old servants,



<P>and pictures of the country place, with its park, great house,



<P>lovely grounds, and fine horses.&nbsp; Oh, it would be all I should



<P>ask!&nbsp; And I'd rather have it than any title such as girls snap



<P>up so readily, and find nothing behind.&nbsp; I may be mercenary,



<P>but I hate poverty, and don't mean to bear it a minute longer



<P>than I can help.&nbsp; One of us must marry well.&nbsp; Meg didn't,

Jo



<P>won't, Beth can't yet, so I shall, and make everything okay all



<P>round.&nbsp; I wouldn't marry a man I hated or despised.&nbsp; You may

be



<P>sure of that, and though Fred is not my model hero, he does very



<P>well, and in time I should get fond enough of him if he was very



<P>fond of me, and let me do just as I liked.&nbsp; So I've been turning



<P>the matter over in my mind the last week, for it was impossible to



<P>help seeing that Fred liked me.&nbsp; He said nothing, but little things



<P>showed it.&nbsp; He never goes with Flo, always gets on my side of the



<P>carriage, table, or promenade, looks sentimental when we are alone,



<P>and frowns at anyone else who ventures to speak tome.&nbsp; Yesterday



<P>at dinner, when an Austrian officer stared at us and then said



<P>something to his friend, a rakish-looking baron, about `ein wonderschones



<P>Blondchen', Fred looked as fierce as a lion, and cut his meat



<P>so savagely it nearly flew off his plate.&nbsp; He isn't one of the



<P>cool, stiff Englishmen, but is rather peppery, for he has Scotch



<P>blood in him, as one might guess from his bonnie blue eyes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Well, last evening we went up to the castle about sunset, at



<P>least all of us but Fred, who was to meet us there after going to



<P>the Post Restante for letters.&nbsp; We had a charming time poking



<P>about the ruins, the vaults where the monster tun is, and the



<P>beautiful gardens made by the elector long ago for his English



<P>wife.&nbsp; I liked the great terrace best, for the view was divine,



<P>so while the rest went to see the rooms inside, I sat there trying



<P>to sketch the gray stone lion's head on the wall, with scarlet



<P>woodbine sprays hanging round it.&nbsp; I felt as if I'd got into a



<P>romance, sitting there, watching the Meckar rolling through the



<P>valley, listening to the music of the Austrian band below, and



<P>waiting for my lover, like a real storybook girl.&nbsp; I had a feeling



<P>that something was going to happen and I was ready for it.&nbsp; I



<P>didn't feel blushy or quakey, but quite cool and only a little



<P>excited.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By-and-by I heard Fred's voice, and then he came hurrying



<P>through the great arch to find me.&nbsp; He looked so troubled that

I



<P>forgot all about myself, and asked what the matter was.&nbsp; He said



<P>he'd just got a letter begging him to come home, for Frank was



<P>very ill.&nbsp; So he was going at once on the night train and only



<P>had time to say good-by.&nbsp; I was very sorry for him, and disappointed



<P>for myself, but only for a minute because he said, as he shook hands,



<P>and said it in a way that I could not mistake,&nbsp; "I shall soon come

back,



<P>you won't forget me, Amy?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I didn't promise, but I looked at him, and he seemed satisfied,



<P>and there was no time for anything but messages and good-byes,



<P>for he was off in an hour, and we all miss him very much.



<P>I know he wanted to speak, but I think, from something he once



<P>hinted, that he had promised his father not to do anything of



<P>the sort yet a while, for is is a rash boy, and the old gentleman



<P>dreads a foreign daughter-in-law.&nbsp; We shall soon meet in



<P>Rome, and then, if I don't change my mind, I'll say "Yes, thank



<P>you," when he says "Will you, please?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Of course this is all very private, but I wished you to



<P>know what was going on.&nbsp; Don't be anxious about me, remember I



<P>am your `prudent Amy', and be sure I will do nothing rashly.



<P>Send me as much advice as you like.&nbsp; I'll use it if I can.&nbsp;

I



<P>wish I could see you for a good talk, Marmee.&nbsp; Love and trust me.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Ever your AMY



<P>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER THIRTY</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Chester's fair was so very elegant and select that it



<P>was considered a great honor by the young ladies of the neighborhood



<P>to be invited to take a table, and everyone was much interest



<P>in the matter.&nbsp; Amy was asked, but Jo was not, which was



<P>fortunate for all parties, as her elbows were decidedly



<P>akimbo at this period of her life, and it took a good many hard



<P>knocks to teach her how to get on easily.&nbsp; The `haughty, uninteresting



<P>creature' was let severely alone, but Amy's talent and taste were duly



<P>complimented by the offer of the art table, and she exerted herself



<P>to prepare and secure appropriate and valuable contributions to it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Everything went on smoothly till the day before the fair



<P>opened, then there occurred one of the little skirmishes which



<P>it is almost impossible to avoid, when some five-and-twenty



<P>women, old and young, with all their private piques and prejudices,



<P>try to work together.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>May Chester was rather jealous of Amy because the latter



<P>was a greater favorite than herself, and just at this time



<P>several trifling circumstances occurred to increase the feeling.



<P>Amy's dainty pen-and-ink work entirely eclipsed May's painted



<P>vases--that was one thorn.&nbsp; Then the all conquering Tudor had



<P>danced four times with Amy at a late party and only once with



<P>May--that was thorn number two.&nbsp; But the chief grievance that



<P>rankled in her soul, and gave an excuse for her unfriendly conduct,



<P>was a rumor which some obliging gossip had whispered to



<P>her, that the March girls had made fun of her at the Lambs'.



<P>All the blame of this should have fallen upon Jo, for her



<P>naughty imitation had been too lifelike to escape detection,



<P>and the frolicsome Lambs had permitted the joke to escape.&nbsp; No



<P>hint of this had reached the culprits, however, and Amy's dismay



<P>can be imagined, when, the very evening before the fair, as she



<P>was putting the last touches to her pretty table, Mrs. Chester,



<P>who, of course, resented the supposed ridicule of her daughter,



<P>said, in a bland tone, but with a cold look...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I find, dear, that there is some feeling among the young



<P>ladies about my giving this table to anyone but my girls.&nbsp; As



<P>this is the most prominent, and some say the most attractive



<P>table of all, and they are the chief getters-up of the fair, it



<P>is thought best for them to take this place.&nbsp; I'm sorry, but I



<P>know you are too sincerely interested in the cause to mind a



<P>little personal disappointment, and you shall have another table



<P>if you like."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Chester fancied beforehand that it would be easy to



<P>deliver this little speech, but when the time came, she found



<P>it rather difficult to utter it naturally, with Amy's unsuspicious



<P>eyes looking straight at her full of surprise and trouble.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Amy felt that there was something behind this, but would



<P>not guess what, and said quietly, feeling hurt, and showing that



<P>she did, "Perhaps you had rather I took no table at all?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, my dear, don't have any ill feeling, I beg.&nbsp; It's



<P>merely a matter of expediency, you see, my girls will naturally



<P>take the lead, and this table is considered their proper place.



<P>I think it very appropriate to you, and feel very grateful for



<P>your efforts to make it so pretty, but we must give up our private



<P>wishes, of course, and I will see that you have a good place



<P>elsewhere.&nbsp; Wouldn't you like the flower table?&nbsp; The little

girls



<P>undertook it, but they are discouraged.&nbsp; You could make a charming



<P>thing of it, and the flower table is always attractive you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Especially to gentlemen," added May, with a look which enlightened



<P>Amy as to one cause of her sudden fall from favor.&nbsp; She colored



<P>angrily, but took no other notice of that girlish sarcasm,



<P>and answered with unexpected amiability...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It shall be as you please, Mrs. Chester.&nbsp; I'll give up my



<P>place here at once, and attend to the flowers, if you like."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You can put your own things on your own table, if you



<P>prefer," began May, feeling a little conscience-stricken, as she



<P>looked at the pretty racks, the painted shells, and quaint



<P>illuminations Amy had so carefully made and so gracefully arranged.



<P>She meant it kindly, but Amy mistook her meaning, and said quickly .&nbsp;

..

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, certainly, if they are in your way," and sweeping her



<P>contributions into her apron, pell-mell, she walked off, feeling



<P>that herself and her works of art had been insulted past forgiveness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now she's mad.&nbsp; Oh, dear, I wish I hadn't asked you to speak,&nbsp;

Mama,"



<P>said May, looking disconsolately at the empty spaces on her table.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Girls' quarrels are soon over," returned her mother, feeling



<P>a trifle ashamed of her own part in this one, as well she might.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The little girls hailed Amy and her treasures with delight,



<P>which cordial reception somewhat soothed her perturbed spirit, and



<P>she fell to work, determined to succeed florally, if she could not



<P>artistically.&nbsp; But everything seemed against her.&nbsp; It was

late, and



<P>she was tired.&nbsp; Everyone was too busy with their own affairs to

help



<P>her, and the little girls were only hindrances, for the dears fussed



<P>and chattered like so many magpies, making a great deal of confusion



<P>in their artless efforts to preserve the most perfect order.&nbsp; The



<P>evergreen arch wouldn't stay firm after she got it up, but wiggled



<P>and threatened to tumble down on her head when the hanging baskets



<P>were filled.&nbsp; Her best tile got a splash of water, which left a

sephia



<P>tear on the Cupid's cheek.&nbsp; She bruised her hands with hammering,

and



<P>got cold working in a draft, which last affliction filled her with



<P>apprehensions for the morrow.&nbsp; Any girl reader who has suffered

like



<P>afflictions will sympathize with poor Amy and wish her well through



<P>her task.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was great indignation at home when she told her story



<P>that evening.&nbsp; Her mother said it was a shame, but told her she



<P>had done right.&nbsp; Beth declared she wouldn't go to the fair at all,



<P>and Jo demanded why she didn't take all her pretty things and leave



<P>those mean people to get on without her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Because they are mean is no reason why i should be.&nbsp; I hate



<P>such things, and though I think I've a right to be hurt, I don't



<P>intend to show it.&nbsp; They will feel that more than angry speeches



<P>or huffy actions, won't they, Marmee?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's the right spirit, my dear.&nbsp; A kiss for a blow is always



<P>best, though it's not very easy to give it sometimes," said her



<P>mother, with the air of one who had learned the difference between



<P>preaching and practicing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In spite of various very natural temptations to resent and



<P>retaliate, Amy adhered to her resolution all the next day, bent



<P>on conquering her enemy by kindness.&nbsp; She began well, thanks to

a



<P>silent reminder that came to her unexpectedly, but most opportunely.



<P>As she arranged her table that morning, while the little girls were



<P>in the anteroom filling the baskets, she took up her pet production,



<P>a little book, the antique cover of which her father had found among



<P>his treasures, and in which on leaves of vellum she had beautifully



<P>illuminated different texts.&nbsp; As she turned the pages rich in dainty



<P>devices with very pardonable pride, her eye fell upon one verse that



<P>made her stop and think.&nbsp; Framed in a brilliant scrollwork of scarlet,



<P>blue and gold, with little spirits of good will helping one another



<P>up and down among the thorns and flowers, were the words, "Thou shalt



<P>love thy neighbor as thyself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I ought, but I don't," thought Amy, as her eye went from the



<P>bright page to May's discontented face behind the big vases, that



<P>could not hide the vacancies her pretty work had once filled.&nbsp;

Amy



<P>stood a minute, turning the leaves in her hand, reading on each some



<P>sweet rebuke for all heartburnings and uncharitableness of spirit.



<P>Many wise and true sermons are preached us every day by unconscious



<P>ministers in street, school, office, or home.&nbsp; Even a fair table



<P>may become a pulpit, if it can offer the good and helpful words



<P>which are never out of season.&nbsp; Amy's conscience preached her a



<P>little sermon from that text, then and there, and she did what many



<P>of us do not always do, took the sermon to heart, and straightway



<P>put it in practice.



<P>A group of girls were standing about May's table, admiring



<P>the pretty things, and talking over the change of saleswomen.&nbsp;

They



<P>dropped their voices, but Amy knew they were speaking of her, hearing



<P>one side of the story and judging accordingly.&nbsp; It was not pleasant,



<P>but a better spirit had come over her, and presently a chance



<P>offered for proving it.&nbsp; She heard May say sorrowfully...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's too bad, for there is no time to make other things, and



<P>I don't want to fill up with odds and ends.&nbsp; The table was just



<P>complete then.&nbsp; Now it's spoiled."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say she'd put them back if you asked her," suggested



<P>someone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How could I after all the fuss?" began May, but she did not



<P>finish, for Amy's voice came across the hall, saying pleasantly...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You may have them, and welcome, without asking, if you want



<P>them.&nbsp; I was just thinking I'd offer to put them back, for they



<P>belong to your table rather than mine.&nbsp; Here they are, please take



<P>them, and forgive me if I was hasty in carrying them away last night."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she spoke, Amy returned her contribution, with a nod and a



<P>smile, and hurried away again, feeling that it was easier to do a



<P>friendly thing than it was to stay and be thanked for it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, I call that lovely of her, don't you?" cried one girl.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>May's answer was inaudible, but another young lady, whose



<P>temper was evidently a little soured by making lemonade, added,



<P>with a disagreeable laugh, "Very lovely, for she knew she wouldn't



<P>sell them at her own table."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now, that was hard.&nbsp; When we make little sacrifices we like



<P>to have them appreciated, at least, and for a minute Amy was sorry



<P>she had done it, feeling that virtue was not always its won reward.



<P>But it is, as she presently discovered, for her spirits began to



<P>rise, and her table to blossom under her skillful hands, the girls



<P>were very kind, and that one little act seemed to have cleared the



<P>atmosphere amazingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a very long day and a hard one for Amy, as she sat behind



<P>her table, often quite alone, for the little girls deserted



<P>very soon.&nbsp; Few cared to buy flowers in summer, and her bouquets



<P>began to droop long before night.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The art table was the most attractive in the room.&nbsp; There was



<P>a crowd about it all day long, and the tenders were constantly flying



<P>to and fro with important faces and rattling money boxes.&nbsp; Amy



<P>often looked wistfully across, longing to be there, where she felt



<P>at home and happy, instead of in a corner with nothing to do.&nbsp;

It



<P>might seem no hardship to some of us, but to a pretty, blithe young



<P>girl, it was not only tedious, but very trying, and the thought of



<P>Laurie and his friends made it a real martyrdom.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She did not go home till night, and then she looked so pale



<P>and quiet that they knew the day had been a hard one, though she



<P>made no complaint, and did not even tell what she had done.&nbsp; Her



<P>mother gave her an extra cordial cup of tea.&nbsp; Beth helped her dress,



<P>and made a charming little wreath for her hair, while Jo astonished



<P>her family by getting herself up with unusual care, and hinting



<P>darkly that the tables were about to be turned.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't do anything rude, pray Jo.&nbsp; I won't have any fuss made,



<P>so let it all pass and behave yourself," begged Amy, as she departed



<P>early, hoping to find a reinforcement of flowers to refresh her poor



<P>little table.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I merely intend to make myself entrancingly agreeable to ever



<P>one I know, and to keep them in your corner as long as possible.



<P>Teddy and his boys will lend a hand, and we'll have a good time yet."



<P>returned Jo, leaning over the gate to watch for Laurie.&nbsp; Presently



<P>the familiar tramp was heard in the dusk, and she ran out to meet him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is that my boy?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As sure as this is my girl!"&nbsp; And Laurie tucked her hand under



<P>his arm with the air of a man whose every wish was gratified.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, teddy, such doings!" And Jo told Amy's wrongs with sisterly zeal.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A flock of our fellows are going to drive over by-and-by, and



<P>I'll be hanged if I don't make them buy every flower she's got, and



<P>camp down before her table afterward," said Laurie, espousing her



<P>cause with warmth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The flowers are not at all nice, Amy says, and the fresh ones



<P>may not arrive in time.&nbsp; I don't wish to be unjust or suspicious,

but



<P>I shouldn't wonder if they never came at all.&nbsp; When people do one



<P>mean thing they are very likely to do another," observed Jo in a



<P>disgusted tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Didn't Hayes give you the best out of our gardens? I told him to."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I didn't know that, he forgot, I suppose, and, as your grandpa was



<P>poorly, I didn't like to worry him by asking, though I did want some."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Jo, how could you think there was any need of asking?



<P>They are just as much yours as mine.&nbsp; Don't we always go halves



<P>in everything?" began Laurie, in the tone that always made Jo



<P>turn thorny.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Gracious, I hope not!&nbsp; Half of some of your things wouldn't



<P>suit me at all.&nbsp; But we mustn't stand philandering here.&nbsp;

I've got



<P>to help Amy, so you go and make yourself splendid, and if you'll



<P>be so very kind as to let Hayes take a few nice flowers up to the



<P>Hall, I'll bless you forever."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Couldn't you do it now?" asked Laurie, so suggestively that



<P>Jo shut the gate in his face with inhospitable haste, and called



<P>through the bars, "Go away, Teddy, I'm busy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Thanks to the conspirators, the tables were turned that night,



<P>for Hayes sent up a wilderness of flowers, with a loverly basket



<P>arranged in his best manner for a centerpiece.&nbsp; Then the March

family



<P>turned out en masse, and Jo exerted herself to some purpose, for



<P>people not only came, but stayed, laughing at her nonsense, admiring



<P>Amy's taste, and apparently enjoying themselves very much.&nbsp; Laurie



<P>and his friends gallantly threw themselves into the breach, bought



<P>up the bouquets, encamped before the table, and made that corner



<P>the liveliest spot in the room.&nbsp; Amy was in her element now, and

out



<P>of gratitude, if nothing more, was as spritely and gracious as possible,



<P>coming to the conclusion, about that time, that virtue was



<P>it's own reward, after all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo behaved herself with exemplary propriety, and when Amy was



<P>happily surrounded by her guard of honor, Jo circulated about the



<P>hall, picking up various bits of gossip, which enlightened her upon



<P>the subject of the Chester change of base.&nbsp; She reproached herself



<P>for her share of the ill feeling and resolved to exonerate Amy as



<P>soon as possible.&nbsp; She also discovered what Amy had done about

the



<P>things in the morning, and considered her a model of magnanimity.&nbsp;

As



<P>she passed the art table, she glanced over it for her sister's



<P>things, but saw no sign of them.&nbsp; "Tucked away out of sight, I

dare



<P>say," thought Jo, who could forgiver her own wrongs, but hotly resented



<P>any insult offered her family.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good evening, Miss Jo.&nbsp; How does Amy get on?" asked May with



<P>a conciliatory air, for she wanted to show that she also could be



<P>generous.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She has sold everything she had that was worth selling, and



<P>now she is enjoying herself.&nbsp; The flower table is always attractive,



<P>you know, `especially to gentlemen'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo couldn't resist giving that little slap, but May took it



<P>so meekly she regretted it a minute after, and fell to praising



<P>the great vases, which still remained unsold.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is Amy's illumination anywhere about" I took a fancy to



<P>buy that for Father," said Jo, very anxious to learn the fate of



<P>her sister's work.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Everything of Amy's sold long ago.&nbsp; I took care that the



<P>right people saw them, and they made a nice little sum of money



<P>for us," returned May, who had overcome sundry small temptations,



<P>as well as Amy had, that day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Much gratified, Jo rushed back to tell the good news, and



<P>Amy looked both touched and surprised by the report of May's



<P>word and manner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, gentlemen, I want you to go and do your duty by the



<P>other tables as generously as you have by mine, especially the



<P>art table," she said, ordering out `Teddy's own', as the girls



<P>called the college friends.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"`Charge, Chester, charge!' is the motto for that table, but



<P>do your duty like men, and you'll get your money's worth of art



<P>in every sense of the word," said the irrepressible Jo, as the



<P>devoted phalanx prepared to take the field.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To hear is to obey, but March is fairer far than May," said



<P>little Parker, making a frantic effort to be both witty and tender,



<P>and getting promptly quenched by Laurie, who said...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well, my son, for a small boy!" and walked him off, with



<P>a paternal pat on the head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Buy the vases," whispered Amy to Laurie, as a final heaping



<P>of coals of fire on her enemy's head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To May's great delight, Mr. Laurence not only bought the vases,



<P>but pervaded the hall with one under each arm.&nbsp; The other gentlemen



<P>speculated with equal rashness in all sorts of frail trifles, and



<P>wandered helplessly about afterward, burdened with wax flowers,



<P>painted fans, filigree portfolios, and other useful and appropriate



<P>purchases.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Aunt Carrol was there, heard the story, looked pleased, and



<P>said something to Mrs. March in a corner, which made the latter



<P>lady beam with satisfaction, and watch Amy with a face full of



<P>mingled pride and anxiety, though she did not betray the cause



<P>of her pleasure till several days later.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The fair was pronounced a success, and when May bade Amy



<P>goodnight, she did not gush as usual, but gave her an affectionate



<P>kiss, and a look which said `forgive and forget'.&nbsp; That satisfied



<P>Amy, and when she got home she found the vases paraded on



<P>the parlor chimney piece with a great bouquet in each.&nbsp; "The



<P>reward of merit for a magnanimous March," as Laurie announced



<P>with a flourish.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You've a deal more principle and generosity and nobleness



<P>of character than I ever gave you credit for, Amy.&nbsp; You've behaved



<P>sweetly, and I respect you with all my heart," said Jo



<P>warmly, as they brushed their hair together late that night.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, we all do, and love her for being so ready to forgive.



<P>It must have been dreadfully hard, after working so long and setting



<P>your heart on selling your own pretty things.&nbsp; I don't believe

I could



<P>have done it as kindly as you did," added Beth from her pillow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, girls, you needn't praise me so.&nbsp; I only did as I'd



<P>be done by.&nbsp; You laugh at me when I say I want to be a lady, but



<P>I mean a true gentlewoman in mind and manners, and I try to do



<P>it as far as I know how.&nbsp; I can't explain exactly, but I want to



<P>be above the little meannesses and follies and faults that spoil



<P>so many women.&nbsp; I'm far from it now, but I do my best, and hope

in



<P>time to be what Mother is."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy spoke earnestly, and Jo said, with a cordial hug, "I



<P>understand now what you mean, and I'll never laugh at you again.



<P>You are getting on faster than you think, and I'll take lessons



<P>of you in true politeness, for you've learned the secret, I believe.



<P>Try away, deary, you'll get your reward some day, and



<P>no one will be more delighted than I shall."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A week later Amy did get her reward, and poor Jo found it



<P>hard to be delighted.&nbsp; A letter came from Aunt Carrol, and Mrs.



<P>March's face was illuminated to such a degree when she read it



<P>that Jo and Beth, who were with her, demanded what the glad



<P>tiding were.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aunt Carrol is going abroad next month, and wants..."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me to go with her!" burst in Jo, flying out of her chair



<P>in an uncontrollable rapture.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, dear, not you.&nbsp; It's Amy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, Mother!&nbsp; She's too young, it's my turn first.&nbsp; I've



<P>wanted it so long.&nbsp; It would do me so much good, and be so altogether



<P>splendid.&nbsp; I must go!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm afraid it's impossible, Jo.&nbsp; Aunt says Amy, decidedly,



<P>and it is not for us to dictate when she offers such a favor."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's always so.&nbsp; Amy has all the fun and I have all the work.



<P>It isn't fair, oh, it isn't fair!" cried Jo passionately.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm afraid it's partly your own fault, dear.&nbsp; When Aunt spoke



<P>to me the other day, she regretted your blunt manners and too



<P>independent spirit, and here she writes, as if quoting something you



<P>had said--`I planned at first to ask Jo, but as `favors burden her',



<P>and she `hates French', I think I won't venture to invite her.&nbsp;

Amy



<P>is more docile, will make a good companion for Flo, and receive



<P>gratefully any help the trip may give her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, my tongue, my abominable tongue!&nbsp; Why can't I learn to



<P>keep it quiet?' groaned Jo, remembering words which had been



<P>her undoing.&nbsp; When she had heard the explanation of the quoted



<P>phrases, Mrs. March said sorrowfully...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish you could have gone, but there is no hope of it this



<P>time, so try to bear it cheerfully, and don't sadden Amy's pleasure



<P>by reproaches or regrets."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll try," said Jo, winking hard as she knelt down to pick



<P>up the basket she had joyfully upset.&nbsp; "I'll take a leaf out of



<P>her book, and try not only to seem glad, but to be so, and not



<P>grudge her one minute of happiness.&nbsp; But it won't be easy, for



<P>it is a dreadful disappointment."&nbsp; And poor Jo bedewed the little



<P>fat pincushion she held with several very bitter tears.



<P>"Jo, dear, I'm very selfish, but I couldn't spare you, and



<P>I'm glad you are not going quite yet," whispered Beth, embracing



<P>her, basket and all, with such a clinging touch and loving face



<P>that Jo felt comforted in spite of the sharp regret that made her



<P>want to box her own ears, and humbly beg Aunt Carrol to burden



<P>her with this favor, and see how gratefully she would bear it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By the time Amy came in, Jo was able to take her part in



<P>the family jubilation, not quite as heartily as usual, perhaps,



<P>but without repinings at Amy's good fortune.&nbsp; The young lady



<P>herself received the news as tidings of great joy, went about



<P>in a solemn sort of rapture, and began to sort her colors and



<P>pack her pencils that evening, leaving such trifles as clothes,



<P>money, and passports to those less absorbed in visions of art



<P>than herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It isn't a mere pleasure trip to me, girls," she said impressively,



<P>as she scraped her best palette.&nbsp; "It will decide my career,



<P>for if I have any genius, I shall find it out in Rome,



<P>and will do something to prove it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Suppose you haven't?" said Jo, sewing away, with red eyes,



<P>at the new collars which were to be handed over to Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then I shall come home and teach drawing for my living,"



<P>replied the aspirant for fame, with philosophic composure.



<P>But she made a wry face at the prospect, and scratched away



<P>at her palette as if bent on vigorous measures before she



<P>gave up her hopes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, you won't.&nbsp; You hate hard work, and you'll marry some



<P>rich man, and come home to sit in the lap of luxury all your



<P>days," said Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your predictions sometimes come to pass, but I don't believe



<P>that one will.&nbsp; I'm sure I wish it would, for if I can't be



<P>an artist myself, I should like to be able to help those who are,"



<P>said Amy, smiling, as if the part of Lady Bountiful would suit



<P>her better than that of a poor drawing teacher.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hum!" said Jo, with a sigh.&nbsp; "If you wish it you'll have it,



<P>for your wishes are always granted--mine never."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Would you like to go?" asked Amy, thoughtfully patting her



<P>nose with her knife.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Rather!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, in a year or two I'll send for you, and we'll dig in



<P>the Forum for relics, and carry out all the plans we've made so



<P>many times."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you.&nbsp; I'll remind you of your promise when that joyful



<P>day comes, if it ever does," returned Jo, accepting the vague but



<P>magnificent offer as gratefully as she could.



<P>"There was not much time for preparation, and the house was



<P>in a ferment till Amy was off.&nbsp; Jo bore up very well till the



<P>last flutter of blue ribbon vanished, when she retired to her



<P>refuge, the garret, and cried till she couldn't cry any more.



<P>Amy likewise bore up stoutly till the steamer sailed.&nbsp; Then



<P>just as the gangway was about to be withdrawn, it suddenly came



<P>over her that a whole ocean was soon to roll between her and



<P>those who loved her best, and she clung to Laurie, the last



<P>lingerer, saying with a sob...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, take care of them for me, and if anything should



<P>happen...&nbsp; "

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will, dear, I will, and if anything happens, I'll come



<P>and comfort you," whispered Laurie, little dreaming that he would



<P>be called upon to keep his word.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So Amy sailed away to find the Old World, which is always



<P>new and beautiful to young eyes, while her father and friend



<P>watched her from the shore, fervently hoping that none but gentle



<P>fortunes would befall the happy-hearted girl, who waved her hand



<P>to them till they could see nothing but the summer sunshine dazzling



<P>on the sea.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 24</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B><FONT SIZE=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

LITTLE WOMEN PART 2</FONT></B>



<P><B>CHAPTER TWENTY-FOUR</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In order that we may start afresh and go to Meg's wedding



<P>with free minds, it will be well to begin with a little gossip



<P>about the Marches.&nbsp; And here let me premise that if any of the



<P>elders think there is too much `lovering' in the story, as I fear



<P>they may (I'm not afraid the young folks will make that objection),



<P>I can only say with Mrs. March, "What can you expect when I have



<P>four gay girls in the house, and a dashing young neighbor over the



<P>way?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The three years that have passed have brought but few changes



<P>to the quiet family.&nbsp; The war is over, and Mr. March safely at



<P>home, busy with his books and the small parish which found in him



<P>a minister by nature as by grace, a quiet, studious man, rich in



<P>the wisdom that is better than learning, the charity which calls



<P>all mankind `brother', the piety that blossoms into character,



<P>making it august and lovely.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These attributes, in spite of poverty and the strict integrity



<P>which shut him out from the more worldly successes, attracted to



<P>him many admirable persons, as naturally as sweet herbs draw bees,



<P>and as naturally he gave them the honey into which fifty years of



<P>hard experience had distilled no bitter drop.&nbsp; Earnest young men



<P>found the gray-headed scholar as young at heart as they, thoughtful



<P>or troubled women instinctively brought their doubts to him, sure



<P>of finding the gentlest sympathy, the wisest counsel.&nbsp; Sinners

told



<P>their sins to the pure-hearted old man and were both rebuked and



<P>saved.&nbsp; Gifted men found a companion in him.&nbsp; Ambitious men

caught



<P>glimpses of nobler ambitions than their own, and even worldlings



<P>confessed that his beliefs were beautiful and true, although `they



<P>wouldn't pay'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To outsiders the five energetic women seemed to rule the house,



<P>and so they did in many things, but the quiet scholar, sitting among



<P>his books, was still the head of the family, the household conscience,



<P>anchor, and comforter, for to him the busy, anxious women always



<P>turned in troublous times, finding him, in the truest sense of those



<P>sacred words, husband and father.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The girls gave their hearts into their mother's keeping, their



<P>souls into their father's, and to both parents, who lived and labored



<P>so faithfully for them, they gave a love that grew with their growth



<P>and bound them tenderly together by the sweetest tie which blesses



<P>life and outlives death.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March is as brisk and cheery, though rather grayer, than



<P>when we saw her last, and just now so absorbed in Meg's affairs that



<P>the hospitals and homes still full of wounded `boys' and soldiers'



<P>widows, decidedly miss the motherly missionary's visits.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>John Brooke did his duty manfully for a year, got wounded, was



<P>sent home, and not allowed to return.&nbsp; He received no stars or

bars,



<P>but he deserved them, for he cheerfully risked all he had, and life



<P>and love are very precious when both are in full bloom.&nbsp; Perfectly



<P>resigned to his discharge, he devoted himself to getting well,



<P>preparing for business, and earning a home for Meg.&nbsp; With the good



<P>sense and sturdy independence that characterized him, he refused



<P>Mr. Laurence's more generous offers, and accepted the place of



<P>bookkeeper, feeling better satisfied to begin with an honestly earned



<P>salary than by running any risks with borrowed money.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Meg had spent the time in working as well as waiting, growing



<P>womanly in character, wise in housewifely arts, and prettier than



<P>ever, for love is a great beautifier.&nbsp; She had her girlish ambitions



<P>and hopes, and felt some disappointment at the humble way in which



<P>the new life must begin.&nbsp; Ned Moffat had just married Sallie Gardiner,



<P>and Meg couldn't help contrasting their fine house and carriage,



<P>many gifts, and splendid outfit with her own, and secretly wishing



<P>she could have the same.&nbsp; But somehow envy and discontent soon



<P>vanished when she thought of all the patient love and labor John had



<P>put into the little home awaiting her, and when they sat together in



<P>the twilight, talking over their small plans, the future always grew



<P>so beautiful and bright that she forgot Sallie's splendor and felt



<P>herself the richest, happiest girl in Christendom.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo never went back to Aunt March, for the old lady took such



<P>a fancy to AMy that she bribed her with the offer of drawing lessons



<P>from one of the best teachers going, and for the sake of this



<P>advantage, Amy would have served a far harder mistress.&nbsp; So she

gave her



<P>mornings to duty, her afternoons to pleasure, and prospered finely.



<P>Jo meantime devoted herself to literature and Beth, who remained



<P>delicate long after the fever was a thing of the past.&nbsp; Not an



<P>invalid exactly, but never again the rosy, healthy creature she had



<P>been, yet always hopeful, happy, and serene, and busy with the quiet



<P>duties she loved, everyone's friend, and an angel in the house, long



<P>before those who loved her most had learned to know it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As long as THE SPREAD EAGLE paid her a dollar a column for her



<P>`rubbish', as she called it, Jo felt herself a woman of means, and



<P>spun her little romances diligently.&nbsp; But great plans fermented

in



<P>her busy brain and ambitious mind, and the old tin kitchen in the



<P>garret held a slowly increasing pile of blotted manuscript, which



<P>was one day to place the name of March upon the roll of fame.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie, having dutifully gone to college to please his grandfather,



<P>was now getting through it in the easiest possible manner



<P>to please himself.&nbsp; A universal favorite, thanks to money, manners,



<P>much talent, and the kindest heart that ever got its owner into



<P>scrapes by trying to get other people out of them, he stood in



<P>great danger of being spoiled, and probably would have been, like



<P>many another promising boy, if he had not possessed a talisman



<P>against evil in the memory of the kind old man who was bound up in



<P>his success, the motherly friend who watched over him as if he were



<P>her son, and last, but not least by any means, the knowledge that



<P>four innocent girls loved, admired, and believed in him with all



<P>their hearts.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Being only `a glorious human boy', of course he frolicked and



<P>flirted, grew dandified, aquatic, sentimental, or gymnastic, as



<P>college fashions ordained, hazed and was hazed, talked slang, and



<P>more than once came perilously near suspension and expulsion.&nbsp;

But



<P>as high spirits and the love of fun were the causes of these pranks,



<P>he always managed to save himself by frank confession, honorable



<P>atonement, or the irresistible power of persuasion which he possessed



<P>in perfection.&nbsp; In fact, he rather prided himself on his narrow



<P>escapes, and liked to thrill the girls with graphic accounts of his



<P>triumphs over wrathful tutors, dignified professors, and vanquished



<P>enemies.&nbsp; The `men of my class', were heroes in the eyes of the

girls,



<P>who never wearied of the exploits of `our fellows', and were frequently



<P>allowed to bask in the smiles of these great creatures, when Laurie



<P>brought them home with him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy especially enjoyed this high honor, and became quite a belle



<P>among them, for her ladyship early felt and learned to use the gift



<P>of fascination with which she was endowed.&nbsp; Meg was too much absorbed



<P>in her private and particular John to care for any other lords of



<P>creation, and Beth too shy to do more than peep at them and wonder



<P>how Amy dared to order them about so, but Jo felt quite in her own



<P>element, and found it very difficult to refrain from imitating the



<P>gentlemanly attitudes, phrases, and feats, which seemed more natural



<P>to her than the decorums prescribed for young ladies.&nbsp; They all

liked



<P>Jo immensely, but never fell in love with her, though very few escaped



<P>without paying the tribute of a sentimental sigh or two at Amy's shrine.



<P>And speaking of sentiment brings us very naturally to the `Dovecote'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That was the name of the little brown house Mr. Brooke had prepared



<P>for Meg's first home.&nbsp; Laurie had christened it, saying it was



<P>highly appropriate to the gentle lovers who `went on together like a



<P>pair of turtledoves, with first a bill and then a coo'.&nbsp; It was

a



<P>tiny house, with a little garden behind and a lawn about as big as a



<P>pocket handkerchief in the front.&nbsp; Here Meg meant to have a fountain,



<P>shrubbery, and a profusion of lovely flowers, though just at present



<P>the fountain was represented by a weather-beaten urn, very like a



<P>dilapidated slopbowl, the shrubbery consisted of several young larches,



<P>undecided whether to live or die, and the profusion of flowers was



<P>merely hinted by regiments of sticks to show where seeds were planted.



<P>But inside, it was altogether charming, and the happy bride saw no



<P>fault from garret to cellar.&nbsp; To be sure, the hall was so narrow

it



<P>was fortunate that they had no piano, for one never could have been



<P>got in whole, the dining room was so small that six people were a



<P>tight fit, and the kitchen stairs seemed built for the express



<P>purpose of precipitating both servants and china pell-mell into the



<P>coalbin.&nbsp; But once get used to these slight blemishes and nothing



<P>could be more complete, for good sense and good taste had presided



<P>over the furnishing, and the result was highly satisfactory.&nbsp; There



<P>were no marble-topped tables, long mirrors, or lace curtains in the



<P>little parlor, but simple furniture, plenty of books, a fine picture



<P>or two, a stand of flowers in the bay window, and, scattered all



<P>about, the pretty gifts which came from friendly hands and were the



<P>fairer for the loving messages they brought.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I don't think the Parian Psyche Laurie gave lost any of its



<P>beauty because John put up the bracket it stood upon, that any



<P>upholsterer could have draped the plain muslin curtains more



<P>gracefully than Amy's artistic hand, or that any store-room was ever



<P>better provided with good wishes, merry words, and happy hopes



<P>than that in which Jo and her mother put away Meg's few boxes,



<P>barrels, and bundles, and I am morally certain that the spandy new



<P>kitchen never could have looked so cozy and neat if Hannah had not



<P>arranged every pot and pan a dozen times over, and laid the fire



<P>all ready for lighting the minute `Mis.&nbsp; Brooke came home'.&nbsp;

I also



<P>doubt if any young matron ever began life with so rich a supply of



<P>dusters, holders, and piece bags, for Beth made enough to last till



<P>the silver wedding came round, and invented three different kinds



<P>of dishcloths for the express service of the bridal china.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>People who hire all these things done for them never know



<P>what they lose, for the homeliest tasks get beautified if loving



<P>hands do them, and Meg found so many proofs of this that everything



<P>in her small nest, from the kitchen roller to the silver vase on



<P>her parlor table, was eloquent of home love and tender forethought.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>What happy times they had planning together, what solemn



<P>shopping excursions, what funny mistakes they made, and what



<P>shouts of laughter arose over Laurie's ridiculous bargains.&nbsp; In



<P>his love of jokes, this young gentleman, though nearly through



<P>college, was a much of a boy as ever.&nbsp; His last whim had been to



<P>bring with him on his weekly visits some new, useful, and ingenious



<P>article for the young housekeeper.&nbsp; Now a bag of remarkable



<P>clothespins, next, a wonderful nutmeg grater which fell to pieces at

the



<P>first trial, a knife cleaner that spoiled all the knives, or a



<P>sweeper that picked the nap neatly off the carpet and left the dirt,



<P>labor-saving soap that took the skin off one's hands, infallible



<P>cements which stuck firmly to nothing but the fingers of the



<P>deluded buyer, and every kind of tinware, from a toy savings bank for



<P>odd pennies, to a wonderful boiler which would wash articles in its



<P>own steam with every prospect of exploding in the process.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In vain Meg begged him to stop.&nbsp; John laughed at him, and Jo called



<P>him `Mr. Toodles'.&nbsp; He was possessed with a mania for patronizing



<P>Yankee ingenuity, and seeing his friends fitly furnished forth.



<P>So each week beheld some fresh absurdity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Everything was done at last, even to Amy's arranging different



<P>colored soaps to match the different colored rooms, and Beth's



<P>setting the table for the first meal.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Are you satisfied?&nbsp; Does it seem like home, and do you feel



<P>as if you should be happy here?" asked Mrs. March, as she and her



<P>daughter went through the new kingdom arm in arm, for just then



<P>they seemed to cling together more tenderly than ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Mother, perfectly satisfied, thanks to you all, and so



<P>happy that I can't talk about it," with a look that was far better



<P>than words.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If she only had a servant or two it would be all right," said Amy,



<P>coming out of the parlor, where she had been trying to decide whether



<P>the bronze Mercury looked best on the whatnot or the mantlepiece.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mother and I have talked that over, and I have made up my



<P>mind to try her way first.&nbsp; There will be so little to do that

with



<P>Lotty to run my errands and help me here and there, I shall only



<P>have enough work to keep me from getting lazy or homesick," answered



<P>Meg tranquilly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sallie Moffat has four," began Amy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If Meg had four, the house wouldn't hold them, and master and



<P>missis would have to camp in the garden," broke in Jo, who, enveloped



<P>in a big blue pinafore, was giving the last polish to the door handles.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sallie isn't a poor man's wife, and many maids are in keeping



<P>with her fine establishment.&nbsp; Meg and John begin humbly, but I

have



<P>a feeling that there will be quite as much happiness in the little



<P>house as in the big one.&nbsp; It's a great mistake for young girls

like



<P>Meg to leave themselves nothing to do but dress, give orders, and



<P>gossip.&nbsp; When I was first married, I used to long for my new clothes



<P>to wear out or get torn, so that i might have the pleasure of mending



<P>them, for I got heartily sick of doing fancywork and tending my



<P>pocket handkerchief."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why didn't you go into the kitchen and make messes, as Sallie



<P>says she does to amuse herself, though they never turn out well and



<P>the servants laugh at her," said Meg.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I did after a while, not to `mess' but to learn of Hannah how



<P>things should be done, that my servants need not laugh at me.&nbsp;

It



<P>was play then, but there came a time when I was truly grateful that



<P>I not only possessed the will but the power to cook wholesome food



<P>for my little girls, and help myself when I could no longer afford



<P>to hire help.&nbsp; You begin at the other end, Meg, dear, but the lessons



<P>you learn now will be of use to you by-and-by when John is a richer



<P>man, for the mistress of a house, however splendid, should know how



<P>work ought to be done, if she wishes to be well and honestly served."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Mother, I'm sure of that," said Meg, listening respectfully



<P>to the little lecture, for the best of women will hold forth



<P>upon the all absorbing subject of house keeping.&nbsp; "Do you know

I



<P>like this room most of all in my baby house," added Meg, a minute



<P>after, as they went upstairs and she looked into her well-stored



<P>linen closet.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth was there, laying the snowy piles smoothly on the shelves



<P>and exulting over the goodly array.&nbsp; All three laughed as Meg spoke,



<P>for that linen closet was a joke.&nbsp; You see, having said that if

Meg



<P>married `that Brooke' she shouldn't have a cent of her money, Aunt



<P>March was rather in a quandary when time had appeased her wrath and



<P>made her repent her vow.&nbsp; She never broke her word, and was much



<P>exercised in her mind how to get round it, and at last devised a



<P>plan whereby she could satisfy herself.&nbsp; Mrs. Carrol, Florence's



<P>mamma, was ordered to buy, have made, and marked a generous supply



<P>of house and table linen, and send it as her present, all of which



<P>was faithfully done, but the secret leaked out, and was greatly



<P>enjoyed by the family, for Aunt March tried to look utterly



<P>unconscious, and insisted that she could give nothing but the



<P>old-fashioned pearls long promised to the first bride.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's a housewifely taste which I am glad to see.&nbsp; I had a



<P>young friend who set up housekeeping with six sheets, but she had



<P>finger bowls for company and that satisfied her," said Mrs. March,



<P>patting the damask tablecloths, with a truly feminine appreciation



<P>of their fineness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I haven't a single finger bowl, but this is a setout that will



<P>last me all my days, Hannah says."&nbsp; And Meg looked quite contented,



<P>as well she might.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A tall, broad-shouldered young fellow, with a cropped head, a



<P>felt basin of a hat, and a flyaway coat, came tramping down the



<P>road at a great pace, walked over the low fence without stopping to



<P>open the gate, straight up to Mrs. March, with both hands out and



<P>a hearty .&nbsp; ..

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here I am, Mother!&nbsp; Yes, it's all right."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The last words were in answer to the look the elder lady gave



<P>him, a kindly questioning look which the handsome eyes met so



<P>frankly that the little ceremony closed, as usual, with a motherly



<P>kiss.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"For Mrs. John Brooke, with the maker's congratulations and



<P>compliments.&nbsp; Bless you, Beth!&nbsp; What a refreshing spectacle

you



<P>are, Jo.&nbsp; Amy, you are getting altogether too handsome for a



<P>single lady."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As Laurie spoke, he delivered a brown paper parcel to Meg,



<P>pilled Beth's hair ribbon, stared at Jo's bib pinafore, and fell



<P>into an attitude of mock rapture before Amy, then shook hands all



<P>round, and everyone began to talk.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where is John?" asked Meg anxiously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Stopped to get the license for tomorrow, ma'am."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Which side won the last match, Teddy?" inquired Jo, who persisted



<P>in feeling an interest in manly sports despite her nineteen years.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ours, of course.&nbsp; Wish you'd been there to see."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How is the lovely Miss Randal?" asked Amy with a significant smile.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"More cruel than ever.&nbsp; Don't you see how I'm pining away?"



<P>And Laurie gave his broad chest a sounding slap and heaved a



<P>melodramatic sigh.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What's the last joke?&nbsp; Undo the bundle and see, Meg," said



<P>Beth, eying the knobby parcel with curiosity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's a useful thing to have in the house in case of fire



<P>or thieves," observed Laurie, as a watchman's rattle appeared,



<P>amid the laughter of the girls.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Any time when John is away and you get frightened, Mrs.



<P>Meg, just swing that out of the front window, and it will rouse



<P>the neighborhood in a jiffy.&nbsp; Nice thing, isn't it?" And Laurie



<P>gave them a sample of its powers that made them cover up their ears.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There's gratitude for you!&nbsp; And speaking of gratitude reminds



<P>me to mention that you may thank Hannah for saving your wedding cake



<P>from destruction.&nbsp; I saw it going into your house as I came by,

and



<P>if she hadn't defended it manfully I'd have had a pick at it, for it



<P>looked like a remarkably plummy one."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wonder if you will ever grow up, Laurie," said Meg in a



<P>matronly tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm doing my best, ma'am, but can't get much higher, I'm afraid,



<P>as six feet is about all men can do in these degenerate days,"



<P>responded the young gentleman, whose head was about level with the



<P>little chandelier.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I suppose it would be profanation to eat anything in this



<P>spick-and-span bower, so as I'm tremendously hungry,



<P>I propose an adjournment," he added presently.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mother and I are going to wait for John.&nbsp; There are some last



<P>things to settle," said Meg, bustling away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Beth and I are going over to Kitty Bryant's to get more flowers



<P>for tomorrow," added Amy, tying a picturesque hat over her picturesque



<P>curls, and enjoying the effect as much as anybody.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come, Jo, don't desert a fellow.&nbsp; I'm in such a state of exhaustion



<P>I can't get home without help.&nbsp; Don't take off your apron,



<P>whatever you do, it's peculiarly becoming," said Laurie, as Jo



<P>bestowed his especial aversion in her capacious pocket and offered



<P>her arm to support his feeble steps.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Teddy, I want to talk seriously to you about tomorrow,"



<P>began Jo, as they strolled away together.&nbsp; "You must promise to



<P>behave well, and not cut up any pranks, and spoil our plans."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a prank."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And don't say funny things when we ought to be sober."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never do.&nbsp; You are the one for that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I implore you not to look at me during the ceremony.&nbsp; I



<P>shall certainly laugh if you do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You won't see me, you'll be crying so hard that the thick fog



<P>round you will obscure the prospect."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never cry unless for some great affliction."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such as fellows going to college, hey?" cut in Laurie, with



<P>suggestive laugh.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't be a peacock.&nbsp; I only moaned a trifle to keep the girls



<P>company."



<P>"Exactly.&nbsp; I say, Jo, how is Grandpa this week?&nbsp; Pretty amiable?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very.&nbsp; Why, have you got into a scrape and want to know how



<P>he'll take it?" asked Jo rather sharply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Jo, do you think I'd look your mother in the face and say



<P>`All right', if it wasn't?" And Laurie stopped short, with an injured



<P>air.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I don't."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then don't go and be suspicious.&nbsp; I only want some money," said



<P>Laurie, walking on again, appeased by her hearty tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You spend a great deal, Teddy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bless you, I don't spend it, it spends itself somehow, and is



<P>gone before I know it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are so generous and kind-hearted that you let people borrow,



<P>and can't say `No' to anyone.&nbsp; We heard about Henshaw and all you

did



<P>for him.&nbsp; If you always spent money in that way, no one would blame



<P>you," said Jo warmly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, he made a mountain out of a molehill.&nbsp; You wouldn't have me



<P>let that fine fellow work himself to death just for want of a little



<P>help, when he is worth a dozen of us lazy chaps, would you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course not, but I don't see the use of your having seventeen



<P>waistcoats, endless neckties, and a new hat every time you come home.
