   <TITLE>Chapter 32</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER THIRTY-TWO</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jo, I'm anxious about Beth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, Mother, she has seemed unusually well since the



<P>babies came."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's not her health that troubles me now, it's her spirits.



<P>I'm sure there is something on her mind, and I want you to discover



<P>what it is."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What makes you think so, Mother?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She sits alone a good deal, and doesn't talk to her father



<P>as much as she used.&nbsp; I found her crying over the babies the



<P>other day.&nbsp; When she sings, the songs are always sad ones, and



<P>now and then I see a look in her face that I don't understand.



<P>This isn't like Beth, and it worries me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have you asked her about it?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have tried once or twice, but she either evaded my



<P>questions or looked so distressed that I stopped.&nbsp; I never



<P>force my children's confidence, and I seldom have to wait



<P>for long."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March glanced at Jo as she spoke, but the face



<P>opposite seemed quite unconscious of any secret disquietude



<P>but Beth's, and after sewing thoughtfully for a minute, Jo



<P>said, "I think she is growing up, and so begins to dream dreams,



<P>and have hopes and fears and fidgets, without knowing why or



<P>being able to explain them.&nbsp; Why, Mother, Beth's eighteen, but



<P>we don't realize it, and treat her like a child, forgetting



<P>she's a woman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So she is.&nbsp; Dear heart, how fast you do grow up," returned



<P>her mother with a sigh and a smile.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Can't be helped, Marmee, so you must resign yourself to



<P>all sorts of worries, and let your birds hop out of the nest,



<P>one by one.&nbsp; I promise never to hop very far, if that is any



<P>comfort to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's a great comfort, Jo.&nbsp; I always feel strong when you



<P>are at home, now Meg is gone.&nbsp; Beth is too feeble and Amy too



<P>young to depend upon, but when the tug comes, you are always



<P>ready."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, you know I don't mind hard jobs much, and there



<P>must always be one scrub in a family.&nbsp; Amy is splendid in fine



<P>works and I'm not, but I feel in my element when all the carpets



<P>are to be taken up, or half the family fall sick at once.



<P>Amy is distinguishing herself abroad, but if anything is amiss



<P>at home, I'm your man."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I leave Beth to your hands, then, for she will open her



<P>tender little heart to her Jo sooner than to anyone else.&nbsp; Be



<P>very kind, and don't let her think anyone watches or talks



<P>about; her.&nbsp; If she only would get quite strong and cheerful



<P>again, I shouldn't have a wish in the world."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Happy woman!&nbsp; I've got heaps."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear, what are they?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll settle Bethy's troubles, and then I'll tell you mine.



<P>They are not very wearing, so they'll keep."&nbsp; And Jo stitched away,



<P>with a wise nod which set her mother's heart at rest about her for



<P>the present at least.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While apparently absorbed in her own affairs, Jo watched



<P>Beth, and after many conflicting conjectures, finally settled



<P>upon one which seemed to explain the change in her.&nbsp; A slight



<P>incident gave Jo the clue to the mystery, she thought, and



<P>lively fancy, loving heart did the rest.&nbsp; She was affecting



<P>to write busily one Saturday afternoon, when she and Beth were



<P>alone together.&nbsp; Yet as she scribbled, she kept her eye on her



<P>sister, who seemed unusually quiet.&nbsp; Sitting at the window, Beth's



<P>work often dropped into her lap, and she leaned her head upon her



<P>hand, in a dejected attitude, while her eyes rested on the dull,



<P>autumnal landscape.&nbsp; Suddenly some one passed below, whistling



<P>like an operatic blackbird, and a voice called out, "All serene!



<P>Coming in tonight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Beth started, leaned forward, smiled and nodded, watched the



<P>passer-by till his quick tramp died away, then said softly as if



<P>to herself, "How strong and well and happy that dear boy looks."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hum!" said Jo, still intent upon her sister's face, for the



<P>bright color faded as quickly as it came, the smile vanished, and



<P>presently a tear lay shining on the window ledge.&nbsp; Beth whisked



<P>it off, and in her half-averted face read a tender sorrow that



<P>made her own eyes fill.&nbsp; Fearing to betray herself, she slipped



<P>away, murmuring something about needing more paper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mercy on me, Beth loves Laurie!" she said, sitting down in



<P>her own room, pale with the shock of the discovery which she



<P>believed she had just made.&nbsp; "I never dreamed of such a thing.



<P>What will Mother say?&nbsp; I wonder if her..."&nbsp; there Jo stopped



<P>and turned scarlet with a sudden thought.&nbsp; "If he shouldn't love



<P>back again, how dreadful it would be.&nbsp; He must.&nbsp; I'll make

him!"



<P>And she shook her head threateningly at the picture of the mischievous-



<P>looking boy laughing at her from the wall.&nbsp; "Oh dear, we are



<P>growing up with a vengeance.&nbsp; Here's Meg married and a mamma,



<P>Amy flourishing away at Paris, and Beth in love.&nbsp; I'm the only



<P>one that has sense enough to keep out of mischief."&nbsp; Jo thought



<P>intently for a minute with her eyes fixed on the picture, then



<P>she smoothed out her wrinkled forehead and said, with a decided



<P>nod at the face opposite, "No thank you, sir, you're very



<P>charming, but you've no more stability than a weathercock.&nbsp; So



<P>you needn't write touching notes and smile in that insinuating



<P>way, for it won't do a bit of good, and I won't have it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Then she sighed, and fell into a reverie from which she



<P>did not wake till the early twilight sent her down to take new



<P>observations, which only confirmed her suspicion.&nbsp; Though



<P>Laurie flirted with Amy and joked with Jo, his manner to Beth



<P>had always been peculiarly kind and gentle, but so was everybody's.



<P>Therefore, no one thought of imagining that he cared more



<P>for her than for the others.&nbsp; Indeed, a general impression



<P>had prevailed in the family of late that `our boy' was getting



<P>fonder than ever of Jo, who, however, wouldn't hear a word upon



<P>the subject and scolded violently if anyone dared to suggest it.



<P>If they had known the various tender passages which had been



<P>nipped in the bud, they would have had the immense satisfaction



<P>of saying, "I told you so."&nbsp; But Jo hated `philandering', and



<P>wouldn't allow it, always having a joke or a smile ready at the



<P>least sign of impending danger.



<P>When Laurie first went to college, he fell in love about



<P>once a month, but these small flames were as brief as ardent,



<P>did no damage, and much amused Jo, who took great interest in



<P>the alternations of hop, despair, and resignation, which were



<P>confided to her in their weekly conferences.&nbsp; But there came a



<P>time when Laurie ceased to worship at many shrines, hinted



<P>darkly at one all-absorbing passion, and indulged occasionally



<P>in Byronic fits of gloom.&nbsp; Then he avoided the tender subject



<P>altogether, wrote philosophical notes to Jo, turned studious,



<P>and gave out that he was going to `dig', intending to graduate



<P>in a blaze of glory.&nbsp; This suited the young lady better than



<P>twilight confidences, tender pressures of the hand, and



<P>eloquent glances of the eye, for with Jo, brain developed



<P>earlier than heart, and she preferred imaginary heroes to



<P>real ones, because when tired of them, the former could be



<P>shut up in the tin kitchen till called for, and the latter



<P>were less manageable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Things were in this state when the grand discovery was



<P>made, and Jo watched Laurie that night as she had never done



<P>before.&nbsp; If she had not got the new idea into her head, she



<P>would have seen nothing unusual in the fact that Beth was



<P>very quiet, and Laurie very kind to her.&nbsp; But having given the



<P>rein to her lively fancy, it galloped away with her at a great



<P>pace, and common sense, being rather weakened by a long course



<P>or romance writing, did not come to the rescue.&nbsp; As usual Beth



<P>lay on the sofa and Laurie sat in a low chair close by, amusing



<P>her with all sorts of gossip, for she depended on her weekly



<P>`spin', and he never disappointed her.&nbsp; But that evening Jo



<P>fancied that Beth's eyes rested on the lively, dark face



<P>beside her with peculiar pleasure, and that she listened with



<P>intense interest to an account of some exciting cricket match,



<P>though the phrases, `caught off a tice', `stumped off his ground'',



<P>and `the leg hit for three', were as intelligible to her as



<P>Sanskrit.&nbsp; She also fancied, having set her heart upon seeing it,



<P>that she saw a certain increase of gentleness in Laurie's manner,



<P>that he dropped his voice now and then, laughed less than usual,



<P>was a little absent--minded, and settled the afghan over Beth's



<P>feet with an assiduity that was really almost tender.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Who knows?&nbsp; Stranger things have happened," thought Jo,



<P>as she fussed about the room.&nbsp; "She will make quite an angel



<P>of him, and he will make life delightfully easy and pleasant



<P>for the dear, if they only love each other.&nbsp; I don't see how he



<P>can help it, and I do believe he would if the rest of us were out of



<P>the way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As everyone was out of the way but herself, Jo began to



<P>feel that she ought to dispose of herself with all speed.&nbsp; But



<P>where should she go? And burning to lay herself upon the shrine



<P>of sisterly devotion, she sat down to settle that point.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now, the old sofa was a regular patriarch of a sofa--long,



<P>broad, well-cushioned, and low, a trifle shabby, as well it might



<P>be, for the girls had slept and sprawled on it as babies,



<P>fished over the back, rode on the arms, and had menageries



<P>under it as children, and rested tired heads, dreamed dreams,



<P>and listened to tender talk on it as young women.&nbsp; They all loved



<P>it, for it was a family refuge, and one corner had always been



<P>Jo's favorite lounging place.&nbsp; Among the many pillows that adorned



<P>the venerable couch was one, hard, round, covered with prickly



<P>horsehair, and furnished with a knobby button at each end.&nbsp; This



<P>repulsive pillow was her especial property, being used as a weapon



<P>of defense, a barricade, or a stern preventive of too much slumber.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Laurie knew this pillow well, and had cause to regard it with



<P>deep aversion, having been unmercifully pummeled with it in former



<P>days when romping was allowed, and now frequently debarred by it



<P>from the seat he most coveted next ot Jo in the sofa corner.&nbsp; If



<P>`the sausage' as the called it, stood on end, it was a sign that



<P>he might approach and repose, but if it lay flat across the sofa,



<P>woe to man, woman, or child who dared disturb it!&nbsp; That evening



<P>Jo forgot to barricade her corner, and had not been in her seat



<P>five minutes, before a massive form appeared beside her, and with



<P>both arms spread over the sofa back, both long legs stretched out



<P>before him, Laurie exclaimed, with a sigh of satisfaction...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, this is filling at the price."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No slang," snapped Jo, slamming down the pillow.&nbsp; But it was



<P>too late, there was no room for it, and coasting onto the floor,



<P>it disappeared in a most mysterious manner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come, Jo, don't be thorny.&nbsp; After studying himself to a



<P>skeleton all the week, a fellow deserves petting and ought to get



<P>it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Beth will pet you.&nbsp; I'm busy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, she's not to be bothered with me, but you like that sort



<P>of thing, unless you've suddenly lost your taste for it.&nbsp; Have

you?



<P>Do you hate your boy, and want to fire pillows at him?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Anything more wheedlesome than that touching appeal was seldom



<P>heard, but Jo quenched `her boy' by turning on him with a stern



<P>query, "How many bouquets have you sent Miss Randal this week?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not one, upon my word.&nbsp; She's engaged.&nbsp; Now then."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad of it, that's one of your foolish extravagances,



<P>sending flowers and things to girls for whom you don't care two



<P>pins," continued Jo reprovingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sensible girls for whom I do care whole papers of pins won't



<P>let me send them `flowers and things', so what can I do?&nbsp; My feelings



<P>need a` vent'."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mother doesn't approve of flirting even in fun, and you do



<P>flirt desperately, Teddy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'd give anything if I could answer, `So do you'.&nbsp; As I can't,



<P>I'll merely say that I don't see any harm in that pleasant little



<P>game, if all parties understand that it's only play."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, it does look pleasant, but I can't learn how it's done.



<P>I've tried, because one feels awkward in company not to do as



<P>everybody else id doing, but I don't seem to get on", said Jo,



<P>forgetting to play mentor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Take lessons of Amy, she has a regular talent for it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, she does it very prettily, and never seems to go too



<P>far.&nbsp; I suppose it's natural to some people to please without



<P>trying, and others to always say and do the wrong thing in the



<P>wrong place."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad you can't flirt.&nbsp; It's really refreshing to see a



<P>sensible, straightforward girl, who can be jolly and kind without



<P>making a fool of herself.&nbsp; Between ourselves, Jo, some of the



<P>girls I know really do go on at such a rate I'm ashamed of them.



<P>They don't mean any harm, I'm sure, but if they knew how we



<P>fellows talked about them afterward, they'd mend their ways, I



<P>fancy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They do the same, and as their tongues are the sharpest,



<P>you fellows get the worst of it, for you are as silly as they,



<P>every bit.&nbsp; If you behaved properly, they would, but knowing



<P>you like their nonsense, they keep it up, and then you blame



<P>them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Much you know about it, ma'am," said Laurie in a superior tone.



<P>"We don't like romps and flirts, though we may act as if



<P>we did sometimes.&nbsp; The pretty, modest girls are never



<P>talked about, except respectfully, among gentleman.



<P>Bless your innocent soul!&nbsp; If you could be in my place



<P>for a month you'd see things that would astonish you a trifle.



<P>Upon my word, when I see one of those harum-scarum girls,



<P>I always want to say with our friend Cock Robin...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Out upon you, fie upon you,



<P>Bold-faced jig!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was impossible to help laughing at the funny conflict



<P>between Laurie's chivalrous reluctance to speak ill of womankind,



<P>and his very natural dislike of the unfeminine folly of



<P>which fashionable society showed him many samples.&nbsp; Jo knew



<P>that `young Laurence' was regarded as a most eligible parti



<P>by worldly mamas, was much smiled upon by their daughters,



<P>and flattered enough by ladies of all ages to make a coxcomb



<P>of him, so she watched him rather jealously, fearing



<P>he would be spoiled, and rejoiced more than she confessed



<P>to find that he still believed in modest girls.&nbsp; Returning



<P>suddenly to her admonitory tone, she said, dropping her



<P>voice, "If you must have a `went', Teddy, go and devote



<P>yourself to one of the `pretty, modest girls' whom you do



<P>respect, and not waste your time with the silly ones."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You really advise it?" And Laurie looked at her with



<P>an odd mixture of anxiety and merriment in his face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I do, but you'd better wait till you are through



<P>college, on the whole, and be fitting yourself for the place



<P>meantime.&nbsp; You're not half good enough for--well, whoever



<P>the modest girl may be."&nbsp; And Jo looked a little queer likewise,



<P>for a name had almost escaped her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That I'm not!" acquiesced Laurie, with an expression of



<P>humility quite new to him, as he dropped his eyes and absently



<P>wound Jo's apron tassel round his finger.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mercy on us, this will never do," thought Jo, adding



<P>aloud, "Go and sing to me.&nbsp; I'm dying for some music, and



<P>always like yours."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'd rather stay here, thank you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, you can't, there isn't room.&nbsp; Go and make yourself



<P>useful, since you are too big to be ornamental.&nbsp; I thought you



<P>hated to be tied to a woman's apron string?" retorted Jo,



<P>quoting certain rebellious words of his own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah, that depends on who wears the apron!" and Laurie



<P>gave an audacious tweak at the tassel.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Are you going?" demanded Jo, diving for the pillow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He fled at once, and the minute it was well, "Up with the



<P>bonnets of bonnie Dundee," she slipped away to return no more



<P>till the young gentleman departed in high dudgeon.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo lay long awake that night, and was just dropping off



<P>when the sound of a stifled sob made her fly to Beth's bedside,



<P>with the anxious inquiry, "What is it, dear?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought you were asleep," sobbed Beth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is it the old pain, my precious?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, it's a new one, but I can bear it."&nbsp; And Beth tried



<P>to check her tears.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Tell me all about it, and let me cure it as I often did



<P>the other."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You can't, there is no cure."&nbsp; There Beth's voice gave



<P>way, and clinging to her sister, she cried so despairingly



<P>that Jo was frightened.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where is it?&nbsp; Shall I call Mother?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no, don't call her, don't tell her.&nbsp; I shall be



<P>better soon.&nbsp; Lie down here and `poor' my head.&nbsp; I'll be



<P>quiet and go to sleep, indeed I will."



<P>Jo obeyed, but as her hand went softly to and fro across



<P>Beth's hot forehead and wet eyelids, her heart was very full



<P>and she longed to speak.&nbsp; But young as she was, Jo had learned



<P>that hearts, like flowers, cannot be rudely handled, but must



<P>open naturally, so though she believed she knew the cause of



<P>Beth's new pain, she only said, in her tenderest tone, "Does



<P>anything trouble you, deary?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Jo," after a long pause.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Wouldn't it comfort you to tell me what it is?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"not now, not yet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then I won't ask, but remember, Bethy, that Mother and



<P>Jo are always glad to hear and help you, if they can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know it.&nbsp; I'll tell you by-and-by."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is the pain better now?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, yes, much better, you are so comfortable, Jo."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Go to sleep, dear.&nbsp; I'll stay with you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So cheek to cheek they fell asleep, and on the morrow



<P>Beth seemed quite herself again, for at eighteen neither heads



<P>nor hearts ache long, and a loving word can medicine most ills.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Jo had made up her mind, and after pondering over a



<P>project for some days, she confided it to her mother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You asked me the other day what my wishes were.&nbsp; I'll



<P>tell you one of them, Marmee," she began, as they sat along



<P>together.&nbsp; "I want to go away somewhere this winter for a



<P>change."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, Jo?" And her mother looked up quickly, as if the



<P>words suggested a double meaning.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With her eyes on her work Jo answered soberly, "I want



<P>something new.&nbsp; I feel restless and anxious to be seeing,



<P>doing, and learning more than I am.&nbsp; I brood too much over



<P>my own small affairs, and need stirring up, so as I can be



<P>spared this winter, I'd like to hop a little way and try my



<P>wings."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where will you hop?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To New York.&nbsp; I had a bright idea yesterday, and this is



<P>it.&nbsp; You know Mrs. Kirke wrote to you for some respectable



<P>young person to teach her children and sew.&nbsp; It's rather hard



<P>to find just the thing, but I think I should suit if I tried."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear, go out to service in that great boarding house!"



<P>And Mrs. March looked surprised, but not displeased.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's not exactly going out to service, for Mrs. Kirke is



<P>your friend--the kindest soul that ever lived--and would make



<P>things pleasant for me, I know.&nbsp; Her family is separate from



<P>the rest, and no one knows me there.&nbsp; Don't care if they do.



<P>It's honest work, and I'm not ashamed of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nor I.&nbsp; But your writing?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"All the better for the change.&nbsp; I shall see and hear new



<P>things, get new ideas, and even if I haven't much time there,



<P>I shall bring home quantities of material for my rubbish."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have no doubt of it, but are these your only reasons for



<P>this sudden fancy?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, Mother."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"May I know the others?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo looked up and Jo looked down, then said slowly, with



<P>sudden color in her cheeks.&nbsp; "It may be vain and wrong to



<P>say it, but--I'm afraid--Laurie is getting too fond of me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then you don't care for him in the way it is evident he



<P>begins to care for you?' And Mrs. March looked anxious as she



<P>put the question.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mercy, no!&nbsp; I love the dear boy, as I always have, and



<P>am immensely proud of him, but as for anything more, it's out



<P>of the question."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm glad of that, Jo."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, please?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Because, dear, I don't think you suited to one another.&nbsp; As



<P>friends you are very happy, and your frequent quarrels soon blow



<P>over, but I fear you would both rebel if you were mated for life.



<P>You are too much alike and too fond of freedom, not to mention



<P>hot tempers and strong wills, to get on happily together, in a



<P>relation which needs infinite patience and forbearance, as well



<P>as love."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's just the feeling I had, though I couldn't express it.



<P>I'm glad you think he is only beginning to care for me.&nbsp; It would



<P>trouble me sadly to make him unhappy, for I couldn't fall in love



<P>with the dear old fellow merely out of gratitude, could I?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are sure of his feeling for you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The color deepened in Jo's cheeks as she answered, with



<P>the look of mingled pleasure, pride, and pain which young



<P>girls wear when speaking of first lovers, "I'm afraid it is



<P>so, Mother.&nbsp; He hasn't said anything, but he looks a great deal.



<P>I think I had better go away before it comes to anything."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I agree with you, and if it can be managed you shall go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo looked relieved, and after a pause, said, smiling, "How



<P>Mrs. Moffat would wonder at your want of management, if she



<P>knew, and how she will rejoice that Annie may still hope."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"AH, Jo, mothers may differ in their management, but the



<P>hope is the same in all--the desire to see their children happy.



<P>Meg is so, and I am content with her success.&nbsp; You I leave to



<P>enjoy your liberty till you tire of it, for only then will you



<P>find that there is something sweeter.&nbsp; Amy is my chief care



<P>now, but her good sense will help ;her.&nbsp; For Beth, I indulge



<P>no hopes except that she may be well.&nbsp; By the way, she seems



<P>brighter this last day or two.&nbsp; Have you spoken to her?'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, she owned she had a trouble, and promised to tell



<P>me by-and-by.&nbsp; I said no more, for I think I know it," And



<P>Jo told her little story.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March shook her head, and did not take so romantic



<P>a view of the case, but looked grave, and repeated her opinion



<P>that for Laurie's sake Jo should go away for a time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let us say nothing about it to him till the plan is settled,



<P>then I'll run away before he can collect his wits and be tragic.



<P>Beth must think I'm going to please myself, as I am, for I can't



<P>talk about Laurie to her.&nbsp; But she can pet and comfort him after



<P>I'm gone, and so cure him of this romantic notion.&nbsp; He's been



<P>through so many little trials of the sort, he's used to it, and



<P>will soon get over his lovelornity."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo spoke hopefully, but could not rid herself of the foreboding



<P>fear that this `little trial' would be harder than the others,



<P>and that Laurie would not get over his `lovelornity' as easily



<P>as heretofore.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The plan was talked over in a family council and agreed



<P>upon, for Mrs. Kirke gladly accepted Jo, and promised to



<P>make a pleasant home for her.&nbsp; The teaching would render



<P>her independent, and such leisure as she got might be made



<P>profitable by writing, while the new scenes and society would



<P>be both useful and agreeable.&nbsp; Jo liked the prospect and was



<P>eager to be gone, for the home nest was growing too narrow



<P>for her restless nature and adventurous spirit.&nbsp; When all was



<P>settled, with fear and trembling she told Laurie, but to her



<P>surprise he took it very quietly.&nbsp; He had been graver than



<P>usual of late, but very pleasant, and when jokingly accused



<P>of turning over a new leaf, he answered soberly, "So I am,



<P>and I mean this one shall stay turned."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo was very much relieved that one of his virtuous fits



<P>should come on just then, and made her preparations with a



<P>lightened heart, for Beth seemed more cheerful, and hoped



<P>she was doing the best for all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"One thing I leave in your especial care," she said, the



<P>night before she left.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You mean your papers?" asked Beth.



<P>"No, my boy.&nbsp; Be very good to him, won't you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of course I will, but I can't fill your place, and he'll



<P>miss you sadly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It won't hurt him, so remember, I leave him in your



<P>charge, to plague, pet, and keep in order."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'll do my best, for your sake," promised Beth, wondering



<P>why Jo looked at her so queerly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When Laurie said good-by, he whispered significantly, "It



<P>won't do a bit of good, Jo.&nbsp; My eye is on you, so mind what you



<P>do, or I'll come and bring you home."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 26</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER TWENTY-SIX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It takes people a long time to learn the difference between



<P>talent and genius, especially ambitious young men and women.



<P>Amy was learning this distinction through much tribulation, for



<P>mistaking enthusiasm for inspiration, she attempted every branch of



<P>art with youthful audacity.&nbsp; For a long time there was a lull in



<P>the `mud-pie' business, and she devoted herself to the finest



<P>pen-and-ink drawing, in which she showed such taste and skill that



<P>her graceful handiwork proved both pleasant and profitable.&nbsp; But



<P>over-strained eyes caused pen and ink to be laid aside for a bold



<P>attempt at poker sketching.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While this attack lasted, the family lived in constant fear



<P>of a conflagration, for the odor of burning wood pervaded the



<P>house at all hours, smoke issued from attic and shed with



<P>alarming frequency, red-hot pokers lay about promiscuously, and Hannah



<P>never went to bed without a pail of water and the dinner bell at



<P>her door in case of fire.&nbsp; Raphael's face was found boldly executed



<P>on the underside of the moulding board, and Bacchus on the head of a



<P>beer barrel.&nbsp; A chanting cherub adorned the cover of the sugar

bucket,



<P>and attempts to portray Romeo and Juliet supplied kindling for some

time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>From fire to oil was a natural transition for burned fingers,



<P>and Amy fell to painting with undiminished ardor.&nbsp; An artist friend



<P>fitted her out with his castoff palettes, brushes, and colors, and



<P>she daubed away, producing pastoral and marine views such as were



<P>never seen on land or sea.&nbsp; Her monstrosities in the way of cattle



<P>would have taken prizes at an agricultural fair, and the perilous



<P>pitching of her vessels would have produced seasickness in the most



<P>nautical observer, if the utter disregard to all known rules of



<P>shipbuilding and rigging had not convulsed him with laughter at the



<P>first glance.&nbsp; Swarthy boys and dark-eyed Madonnas, staring at

you



<P>from one corner of the studio, suggested Murillo.&nbsp; Oily brown shadows



<P>of faces with a lurid streak in the wrong place, meant Rembrandt.



<P>Buxom ladies and dropiscal infants, Rubens, and Turner appeared in



<P>tempests of blue thunder, orange lightning, brown rain, and purple



<P>clouds, with a tomato-colored splash in the middle, which might be



<P>the sun or a bouy, a sailor's shirt or a king's robe, as the



<P>spectator pleased.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Charcoal portraits came next, and the entire family hung in a



<P>row, looking as wild and crocky as if just evoked from a coalbin.



<P>Softened into crayon sketches, they did better, for the likenesses



<P>were good, and Amy's hair, Jo's nose, Meg's mouth, and Laurie's



<P>eyes were pronounced `wonderfully fine'.&nbsp; A return to clay and



<P>plaster followed, and ghostly casts of her acquaintances haunted



<P>corners of the house, or tumbled off closet shelves onto people's



<P>heads.&nbsp; Children were enticed in as models, till their incoherent



<P>accounts of her mysterious doings caused Miss Amy to be regarded in



<P>the light of a young ogress.&nbsp; Her efforts in this line, however,



<P>were brought to an abrupt close by an untoward accident, which



<P>quenched her ardor.&nbsp; Other models failing her for a time, she



<P>undertook to cast her own pretty foot, and the family were one day



<P>alarmed by an unearthly bumping and screaming and running to the rescue,



<P>found the young enthusiast hopping wildly about the shed with her



<P>foot held fast in a pan full of plaster, which had hardened with



<P>unexpected rapidity.&nbsp; With much difficulty and some danger she

was



<P>dug out, for Jo was so overcome with laughter while she excavated



<P>that her knife went too far, cut the poor foot, and left a lasting



<P>memorial of one artistic attempt, at least.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After this Amy subsided, till a mania for sketching from nature



<P>set her to haunting river, field, and wood, for picturesque studies,



<P>and sighing for ruins to copy.&nbsp; She caught endless colds sitting

on



<P>damp grass to book `delicious bit', composed of a stone, a stump, one



<P>mushroom, and a broken mullein stalk, or `a heavenly mass of clouds',



<P>that looked like a choice display of featherbeds when done.&nbsp; She



<P>sacrificed her complexion floating on the river in the midsummer sun

to



<P>study light and shade, and got a wrinkle over her nose trying after



<P>`points of sight', or whatever the squint-and-string performance is

called.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If `genius is eternal patience', as Michelangelo affirms, Amy



<P>had some claim to the divine attribute, for she persevered in spite



<P>of all obstacles, failures, and discouragements, firmly believing



<P>that in time she should do something worthy to be called `high art'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was learning, doing, and enjoying other things, meanwhile,



<P>for she had resolved to be an attractive and accomplished woman,



<P>even if she never became a great artist.&nbsp; Here she succeeded better,



<P>for she was one of those happily created beings who please without



<P>effort, make friends everywhere, and take life so gracefully and



<P>easily that less fortunate souls are tempted to believe that such



<P>are born under a lucky star.&nbsp; Everybody liked her, for among her



<P>good gifts was tact.&nbsp; She had an instinctive sense of what was



<P>pleasing and proper, always said the right thing to the right person,



<P>did just what suited the time and place, and was so self-possessed



<P>that her sisters used to say, "If Amy went to court without any



<P>rehearsal beforehand, she'd know exactly what to do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>One of her weaknesses was a desire to move in `our best society',



<P>without being quite sure what the best really was.&nbsp; Money, position,



<P>fashionable accomplishments, and elegant manners were most desirable



<P>things in her eyes, and she liked to associate with those who



<P>possessed them, often mistaking the false for the true, and admiring

what



<P>was not admirable.&nbsp; Never forgetting that by birth she was a gentlewoman,



<P>she cultivated her aristocratic tastes and feelings, so that when



<P>the opportunity came she might be ready to take the place from



<P>which poverty now excluded her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My lady," as her friends called her, sincerely desired to be



<P>a genuine lady, and was so at heart, but had yet to learn that money



<P>cannot buy refinement of nature, that rank does not always confer



<P>nobility, and that true breeding makes itself felt in spite of



<P>external drawbacks.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I want to ask a favor of you, Mamma," Amy said, coming in



<P>with an important air one day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, little girl, what is it?" replied her mother, in whose



<P>eyes the stately young lady still remained `the baby'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Our drawing class breaks up next week, and before the girls



<P>separate for the summer, I want to ask them out here for a day.&nbsp;

They



<P>are wild to see the river, sketch the broken bridge, and copy some



<P>of the things they admire in my book.&nbsp; They have been very kind

to



<P>me in many ways, and I am grateful, for they are all rich and I know



<P>I am poor, yet they never made any difference."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why should they?" And Mrs. March put the question with what



<P>the girls called her `Maria Theresa air'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You know as well as I that it does make a difference with



<P>nearly everyone, so don't ruffle up like a dear, motherly hen, when



<P>your chickens get pecked by smarter birds.&nbsp; The ugly duckling turned



<P>out a swan, you know."&nbsp; And Amy smiled without bitterness, for

she



<P>possessed a happy temper and hopeful spirit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March laughed, and smoothed down her maternal pride as



<P>she asked, "Well, my swan, what is your plan?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should like to ask the girls out to lunch next week, to take



<P>them for a drive to the places they want to see, a row on the river,



<P>perhaps, and make a little artistic fete for them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That looks feasible.&nbsp; What do you want for lunch?&nbsp; Cake,



<P>sandwiches, fruit, and coffee will be all that is necessary, I suppose?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, dear, no!&nbsp; We must have cold tongue and chicken, French



<P>chocolate and ice cream, besides.&nbsp; The girls are used to such things,



<P>and I want my lunch to be proper and elegant, though I do work for



<P>my living."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How many young ladies are there?" asked her mother, beginning



<P>to look sober.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Twelve or fourteen in the class, but I dare say they won't all come."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bless me, child, you will have to charter an omnibus to carry



<P>them about."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, Mother, how can you think of such a thing?&nbsp; Not more than



<P>six or eight will probably come, so I shall hire a beach wagon and



<P>borrow Mr. Laurence's cherry-bounce." (Hannah's pronunciation of



<P>charabanc.)

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"All of this will be expensive, Amy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not very.&nbsp; I've calculated the cost, and I'll pay for it myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't you think, dear, that as these girls are used to such



<P>things, and the best we can do will be nothing new, that some simpler



<P>plan would be pleasanter to them, as a change if nothing more, and



<P>much better for us than buying or borrowing what we don't need, and



<P>attempting a style not in keeping with our circumstances?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I can't have it as I like, I don't care to have it at all.



<P>I know that I can carry it out perfectly well, if you and the girls



<P>will help a little, and I don't see why I can't if I'm willing to pay



<P>for it," said Amy, with the decision which opposition was apt to



<P>change into obstinacy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. March knew that experience was an excellent teacher, and



<P>when it was possible she left her children to learn alone the lessons



<P>which she would gladly have made easier, if they had not objected to



<P>taking advice as much as they did salts and senna.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well, Amy, if your heart is set upon it, and you see your



<P>way through without too great an outlay of money, time, and temper,



<P>I'll say no more.&nbsp; Talk it over with the girls, and whichever way



<P>you decide, I'll do my best to help you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thanks, Mother, you are always so kind."&nbsp; And away went Amy to



<P>lay her plan before her sisters.



<P>Meg agreed at once, and promised to her aid, gladly offering



<P>anything she possessed, from her little house itself to her very



<P>best saltspoons.&nbsp; But Jo frowned upon the whole project and would



<P>have nothing to do with it at first.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why in the world should you spend your money, worry your family,



<P>and turn the house upside down for a parcel of girls who don't care

a



<P>sixpence for you?&nbsp; I thought you had too much pride and sense to



<P>truckle to any mortal woman just because she wears French boots and



<P>rides in a coupe," said Jo, who, being called from the tragic climax



<P>of her novel, was not in the best mood for social enterprises.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I don't truckle, and I hate being patronized as much as you do!"



<P>returned Amy indignantly, for the two still jangled when such



<P>questions arose.&nbsp; "The girls do care for me, and I for them, and

there's a



<P>great deal of kindness and sense and talent among them, in spite of



<P>what you call fashionable nonsense.&nbsp; You don't care to make people



<P>like you, to go into good society, and cultivate your manners and



<P>tastes.&nbsp; I do, and I mean to make the most of every chance that

comes.



<P>You can go through the world with your elbows out and your nose in the



<P>air, and call it independence, if you like.&nbsp; That's not my way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When Amy had whetted her tongue and freed her mind she usually



<P>got the best of it, for she seldom failed to have common sense on her



<P>side, while Jo carried her love of liberty and hate of conventionalities



<P>to such an unlimited extent that she naturally found herself



<P>worsted in an argument.&nbsp; Amy's definition of Jo's idea of independence



<P>was such a good hit that both burst out laughing, and the discussion



<P>took a more amiable turn.&nbsp; Much against her will, Jo at length



<P>consented to sacrifice a day to Mrs. Grundy, and help her sister



<P>through what she regarded as `a nonsensical business'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The invitations were sent, nearly all accepted, and the following



<P>Monday was set apart for the grand event.&nbsp; Hannah was out of humor



<P>because her week's work was deranged, and prophesied that "ef the



<P>washin' and ironin' warn't done reg'lar, nothin' would go well



<P>anywheres".&nbsp; This hitch in the mainspring of the domestic machinery



<P>had a bad effect upon the whole concern, but Amy's motto was `Nil



<P>desperandum', and having made up her mind what to do, she proceeded



<P>to do it in spite of all obstacles.&nbsp; To begin with, Hannah's cooking



<P>didn't turn out well.&nbsp; The chicken was tough, the tongue too salt,



<P>and the chocolate wouldn't froth properly.&nbsp; Then the cake and ice

cost



<P>more than Amy expected, so did the wagon, and various other expenses,



<P>which seemed trifling at the outset, counted up rather alarmingly



<P>afterward.&nbsp; Beth got a cold and took to her bed.&nbsp; Meg had

an unusual



<P>number of callers to keep her at home, and Jo was in such a divided



<P>state of mind that her breakages, accidents, and mistakes were



<P>uncommonly numerous, serious, and trying.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It it was not fair on Monday, the young ladies were to come on



<P>Tuesday, and arrangement which aggravated Jo and Hannah to the last



<P>degree.&nbsp; On Monday morning the weather was in that undecided state



<P>which is more exasperating than a steady pour.&nbsp; It drizzled a little,



<P>shone a little, blew a little, and didn't make up its mind till it



<P>was too late for anyone else to make up theirs.&nbsp; Amy was up at

dawn,



<P>hustling people out of their beds and through their breakfasts, that



<P>the house might be got in order.&nbsp; The parlor struck her as looking



<P>uncommonly shabby, but without stopping to sigh for what she had not,



<P>she skillfully made the best of what she had, arranging chairs over



<P>the worn places in the carpet, covering stains on the walls with



<P>homemade statuary, which gave an artistic air to the room, as did the



<P>lovely vases of flowers Jo scattered about.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The lunch looked charming, and as she surveyed it, she sincerely



<P>hoped it would taste well, and that the borrowed glass, china, and



<P>silver would get safely home again.&nbsp; The carriages were promised,

Meg



<P>and Mother were all ready to do the honors, Beth was able to help



<P>Hannah behind the scenes, Jo had engaged to be as lively and amiable



<P>as an absent mind, and aching head, and a very decided disapproval of



<P>everybody and everything would allow, and as she wearily dressed, Amy



<P>cheered herself with anticipations of the happy moment when, lunch



<P>safely over, she should drive away with her friends for an afternoon



<P>of artistic delights, for the `cherry bounce' and the broken bridge



<P>were her strong points.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Then came the hours of suspense, during which she vibrated from



<P>parlor to porch, while public opinion varied like the weathercock.&nbsp;

A



<P>smart shower at eleven had evidently quenched the enthusiasm of the



<P>young ladies who were to arrive at twelve, for nobody came, and at two



<P>the exhausted family sat down in a blaze of sunshine to consume the



<P>perishable portions of the feast, that nothing might be lost.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No doubt about the weather today, they will certainly come, so



<P>we must fly round and be ready for them," said Amy, as the sun woke



<P>her next morning.&nbsp; She spoke briskly, but in her secret soul she

wished



<P>she had said nothing about Tuesday, for her interest like her cake was



<P>getting a little stale.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can't get any lobsters, so you will have to do without salad



<P>today," said Mr. March, coming in half an hour later, with an



<P>expression of placid despair.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Use the chicken then, the toughness won't matter in a salad,"



<P>advised his wife.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Hannah left it on the kitchen table a minute, and the kittens got at

it.



<P>I'm very sorry, amy," added Beth, who was still a patroness of cats.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then I must have a lobster, for tongue alone won't do," said Amy decidedly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shall I rush into town and demand one?" asked Jo, with the



<P>magnanimity of a martyr.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You'd come bringing it home under your arm without any paper,



<P>just to try me.&nbsp; I'll go myself," answered Amy, whose temper was



<P>beginning to fail.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Shrouded in a thick veil and armed with a genteel traveling basket,



<P>she departed, feeling that a cool drive would soothe her ruffled spirit



<P>and fit her for the labors of the day.&nbsp; After some delay, the object

of



<P>her desire was procured, likewise a bottle of dressing to prevent



<P>further loss of time at home, and off she drove again, well pleased

with



<P>her own forethought.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As the omnibus contained only one other passenger, a sleepy old



<P>lady, Amy pocketed her veil and beguiled the tedium of the way by



<P>trying to find out where all her money had gone to.&nbsp; So busy was

she



<P>with her card full of refractory figures that she did not observe a



<P>newcomer, who entered without stopping the vehicle, till a masculine



<P>voice said, "Good morning, Miss March," and, looking up, she beheld



<P>one of Laurie's most elegant college friends.&nbsp; Fervently hoping

that



<P>he would get out before she did, Amy utterly ignored the basket at her



<P>feet, and congratulating herself that she had on her new traveling



<P>dress, returned the young man's greeting with her usual suavity and



<P>spirit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They got on excellently, for Amy's chief care was soon set at



<P>rest by learning that the gentleman would leave first, and she was



<P>chatting away in a peculiarly lofty strain, when the old lady got out.



<P>In stumbling to the door, she upset the basket, and--oh horror!--the



<P>lobster, in all its vulgar size and brilliancy, was revealed to the



<P>highborn eyes of a Tudor.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"By Jove, she's forgotten her dinner!" cried the unconscious



<P>youth, poking the scarlet monster into its place with his cane, and



<P>preparing to hand out the basket after the old lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Please don't--it's--it's mine," murmured Amy, with a face nearly



<P>as red as her fish.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, really, I beg pardon.&nbsp; It's an uncommonly fine one, isn't

it?"



<P>said Tudor, with great presence of mind, and an air of sober interest



<P>that did credit to his breeding.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amy recovered herself in a breath, set her basket boldly on the



<P>seat, and said, laughing, "Don't you wish you were to have some of the



<P>salad he's going to make, and to see the charming young ladies who are



<P>to eat it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now that was tact, for two of the ruling foibles of the masculine



<P>mind were touched.&nbsp; The lobster was instantly surrounded by a halo

of



<P>pleasing reminiscences, and curiosity about `the charming young ladies'



<P>diverted his mind from the comical mishap.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I suppose he'll laugh and joke over it with Laurie, but I shan't



<P>see them, that's a comfort," thought Amy, as Tudor bowed and departed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She did not mention this meeting at home (though she discovered



<P>that, thanks to the upset, her new dress was much damaged by the



<P>rivulets of dressing that meandered down the skirt), but went through



<P>with the preparations which now seemed more irksome than before, and



<P>at twelve o'clock all was ready again.&nbsp; feeling that the neighbors



<P>were interested in her movements, she wished to efface the memory of



<P>yesterday's failure by a grand success today, so she ordered the



<P>`cherry bounce', and drove away in state to meet and escort her guests



<P>to the banquet.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There's the rumble, they're coming!&nbsp; I'll go onto the porch and



<P>meet them.&nbsp; It looks hospitable, and I want the poor child to have

a



<P>good time after all her trouble," said Mrs. March, suiting the action



<P>to the word.&nbsp; But after one glance, she retired, with an indescribable



<P>expression, for looking quite lost in the big carriage, sat Amy and



<P>one young lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Run, Beth, and help Hannah clear half the things off the table.



<P>It will be too absurd to put a luncheon for twelve before a single



<P>girl," cried Jo, hurrying away to the lower regions, too excited to



<P>stop even for a laugh.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In came Amy, quite calm and delightfully cordial to the one



<P>guest who had kept her promise.&nbsp; The rest of the family, being

of



<P>a dramatic turn, played their parts equally well, and Miss Eliott



<P>found them a most hilarious set, for it was impossible to control



<P>entirely the merriment which possessed them.&nbsp; The remodeled lunch



<P>being gaily partaken of, the studio and garden visited, and art



<P>discussed with enthusiasm, Amy ordered a buggy (alas for the elegant



<P>cherry-bounce), and drove her friend quietly about the neighborhood



<P>till sunset, when `the party went out'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she came walking in, looking very tired but as composed as



<P>ever, she observed that every vestige of the unfortunate fete had



<P>disappeared, except a suspicious pucker about the corners of Jo's



<P>mouth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You've had a loverly afternoon for your drive, dear," said



<P>her mother, as respectfully as if the whole twelve had come.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Eliott is a very sweet girl, and seemed to enjoy herself,



<P>I thought," observed Beth, with unusual warmth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Could you spare me some of your cake?&nbsp; I really need some, I



<P>have so much company, and I can't make such delicious stuff as yours,"



<P>asked Meg soberly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Take it all.&nbsp; I'm the only one here who likes sweet things, and



<P>it will mold before I can dispose of it," answered Amy, thinking with



<P>a sigh of the generous store she had laid in for such an end as this.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It's a pity Laurie isn't here to help us," began Jo, as they sat



<P>down to ice cream and salad for the second time in two days.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A warning look from her mother checked any further remarks, and



<P>the whole family ate in heroic silence, till Mr. March mildly observed,



<P>"salad was one of the favorite dishes of the ancients, and Evelyn..."



<P>Here a general explosion of laughter cut short the `history of salads',



<P>to the great surprise of the learned gentleman.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bundle everything into a basket and send it to the Hummels.&nbsp; Germans



<P>like messes.&nbsp; I'm sick of the sight of this, and there's no reason

you



<P>should all die of a surfeit because I've been a fool," cried Amy, wiping



<P>her eyes.



<P>"I thought I should have died when I saw you two girls rattling



<P>about in the what-you-call-it, like two little kernels in a very big



<P>nutshell, and Mother waiting in state to receive the throng," sighed



<P>Jo, quite spent with laughter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I'm very sorry you were disappointed, dear, but we all did our



<P>best to satisfy you," said Mrs. March, in a tone full of motherly



<P>regret.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am satisfied.&nbsp; I've done what I undertook, and it's not my



<P>fault that it failed.&nbsp; I comfort myself with that," said Amy with

a



<P>little quiver in her voice.&nbsp; "I thank you all very much for helping



<P>me, and I'll thank you still more if you won't allude to it for a



<P>month, at least."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No one did for several months, but the word `fete' always produced



<P>a general smile, and Laurie's birthday gift to Amy was a tiny



<P>coral lobster in the shape of a charm for her watch guard.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 27</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER TWENTY-SEVEN</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fortune suddenly smiled upon Jo, and dropped a good luck



<P>penny in her path.&nbsp; Not a golden penny, exactly, but I doubt



<P>if half a million would have given more real happiness then did



<P>the little sum that came to her in this wise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Every few weeks she would shut herself up in her room, put



<P>on her scribbling suit, and `fall into a vortex', as she expressed



<P>it, writing away at her novel with all her heart and soul, for till



<P>that was finished she could find no peace.&nbsp; Her `scribbling suit'



<P>consisted of a black woolen pinafore on which she could wipe her



<P>pen at will, and a cap of the same material, adorned with a



<P>cheerful red bow, into which she bundled her hair when the decks were



<P>cleared for action.&nbsp; This cap was a beacon to the inquiring eyes

of



<P>her family, who during these periods kept their distance, merely



<P>popping in their heads semi-occasionally to ask, with interest,



<P>"Does genius burn, Jo?" They did not always venture even to ask



<P>this question, but took an observation of the cap, and judged



<P>accordingly.&nbsp; If this expressive article of dress was drawn low



<P>upon the forehead, it was a sign that hard work was going on, in



<P>exciting moments it was pushed rakishly askew, and when despair



<P>seized the author it was plucked wholly off, and cast upon the



<P>floor, and cast upon the floor.&nbsp; At such times the intruder silently



<P>withdrew, and not until the red bow was seen gaily erect upon the



<P>gifted brow, did anyone dare address Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She did not think herself a genius by any means, but when the



<P>writing fit came on, she gave herself up to it with entire abandon,



<P>and led a blissful life, unconscious of want, care, or bad weather,



<P>while she sat safe and happy in an imaginary world, full of friends



<P>almost as real and dear to her as any in the flesh.&nbsp; Sleep forsook



<P>her eyes, meals stood untasted, day and night were all too short to



<P>enjoy the happiness which blessed her only at such times, and made



<P>these hours worth living, even if they bore no other fruit.&nbsp; The



<P>devine afflatus usually lasted a week or two, and then she emerged



<P>from her `vortex', hungry, sleepy, cross, or despondent.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was just recovering from one of these attacks when she was



<P>prevailed upon to escort Miss Crocker to a lecture, and in return



<P>for her virtue was rewarded with a new idea.&nbsp; It was a People's



<P>Course, the lecture on the Pyramids, and Jo rather wondered at the



<P>choice of such a subject for such an audience, but took it for



<P>granted that some great social evil would be remedied or some great

want



<P>supplied by unfolding the glories of the Pharaohs to an audience



<P>whose thoughts were busy with the price of coal and flour, and whose



<P>lives were spent in trying to solve harder riddles than that of the

Sphinx.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were early, and while Miss Crocker set the heel of her



<P>stocking, Jo amused herself by examining the faces of the people who



<P>occupied the seat with them.&nbsp; On her left were two matrons, with



<P>massive foreheads and bonnets to match, discussing Women's Rights and



<P>making tatting.&nbsp; Beyond sat a pair of humble lovers, artlessly



<P>holding each other by the hand, a somber spinster eating peppermints

out



<P>of a paper bag, and an old gentleman taking his preparatory nap



<P>behind a yellow bandanna.&nbsp; On her right, her only neighbor was

a



<P>studious looking lad absorbed in a newspaper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a pictorial sheet, and Jo examined the work of art nearest



<P>her, idly wondering what fortuitous concatenation of circumstances



<P>needed the melodramatic illustration of an Indian in full war costume,



<P>tumbling over a precipice with a wolf at his throat, while two



<P>infuriated young gentlemen, with unnaturally small feet and big eyes,



<P>were stabbing each other close by, and a disheveled female was flying

away



<P>in the background with her mouth wide open.&nbsp; Pausing to turn a

page,



<P>the lad saw her looking and, with boyish good nature offered half his



<P>paper, saying bluntly, "want to read it? That's a first-rate story."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jo accepted it with a smile, for she had never outgrown her



<P>liking for lads, and soon found herself involved in the usual labyrinth



<P>of love, mystery, and murder, for the story belonged to that class of



<P>light literature in which the passions have a holiday, and when the



<P>author's invention fails, a grand catastrophe clears the stage of one



<P>half the dramatis personae, leaving the other half to exult over



<P>their downfall.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Prime, isn't it?" asked the boy, as her eye went down the last



<P>paragraph of her portion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think you and I could do as well as that if we tried,"



<P>returned Jo, amused at his admiration of the trash.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should think I was a pretty lucky chap if I could.&nbsp; She makes



<P>a good living out of such stories, they say."&nbsp; And he pointed to

the



<P>name of Mrs. S.L.A.N.G.&nbsp; Northbury, under the title of the tale.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you know her?" asked Jo, with sudden interest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, but I read all her pieces, and I know a fellow who works in



<P>the office where this paper is printed."



<P>"Do you say she makes a good living out of stories like this?"



<P>And Jo looked more respectfully at the agitated group and thickly



<P>sprinkled exclamation points that adorned the page.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Guess she does!&nbsp; She knows just what folks like, and gets paid



<P>well for writing it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here the lecture began, but Jo heard very little of it, for while



<P>Professor Sands was prosing away about Belzoni, Cheops, scarabei, and



<P>hieroglyphics, she was covertly taking down the address of the paper,



<P>and boldly resolving to try for the hundred-dollar prize offered in



<P>its columns for a sensational story.&nbsp; By the time the lecture ended



<P>and the audience awoke, she had built up a splendid fortune for herself



<P>(not the first founded on paper), and was already deep in the



<P>concoction of her story, being unable to decide whether the duel



<P>should come before the elopement or after the murder.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>she said nothing of her plan at home, but fell to work next day,



<P>much to the disquiet of her mother, who always looked a little anxious



<P>when `genius took to burning'.&nbsp; Jo had never tried this style before,



<P>contenting herself with very mild romances for THE SPREAD EAGLE.&nbsp;

Her



<P>experience and miscellaneous reading were of service now, for they



<P>gave her some idea of dramatic effect, and supplied plot, language,



<P>and costumes.&nbsp; Her story was as full of desperation and despair

as her



<P>limited acquaintance with those uncomfortable emotions enabled her to



<P>make it, and having located it in Lisbon, she wound up with an earthquake,



<P>as a striking and appropriate denouement.&nbsp; The manuscript was



<P>privately dispatched, accompanied by a note, modestly saying that if



<P>the tale didn't get the prize, which the writer hardly dared expect,



<P>she would be very glad to receive any sum it might be considered worth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Six weeks is a long time to wait, and a still longer time for



<P>a girl to keep a secret, but Jo did both, and was just beginning



<P>to give up all hope of ever seeing her manuscript again,



<P>when a letter arrived which almost took her breath away, for on



<P>opening it, a check for a hundred dollars fell into her lap.&nbsp; For



<P>a minute she stared at it as if it had been a snake, then she read



<P>her letter and began to cry.&nbsp; If the amiable gentleman who wrote



<P>that kindly note could have known what intense happiness he was



<P>giving a fellow creature, I think he would devote his leisure hours,



<P>if he has any, to that amusement, for Jo valued the letter more than



<P>the money, because it was encouraging, and after years of effort it



<P>was so pleasant to find that she had learned to do something, though



<P>it was only to write a sensation story.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A prouder young woman was seldom seen than she, when, having



<P>composed herself, she electrified the family by appearing before them



<P>with the letter in one hand, the check in the other, announcing that



<P>she had won the prize.&nbsp; Of course there was a great jubilee, and

when



<P>the story came everyone read and praised it, though after her father



<P>had told her that the language was good, the romance fresh and hearty,



<P>and the tragedy quite thrilling, he shook his head, and said in his



<P>unworldly way...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You can do better than this, Jo.&nbsp; Aim at the highest, and never



<P>mind the money."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think the money is the best part of it.&nbsp; What will you do with



<P>such a fortune?" asked Amy, regarding the magic slip of paper with a



<P>reverential eye.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Send Beth and Mother to the seaside for a month or two," answered



<P>Jo promptly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To the seaside they went, after much discussion, and though Beth



<P>didn't come home as plump and rosy as could be desired, she was much



<P>better, while Mrs. March declared she felt ten years younger.&nbsp;

So Jo



<P>was satisfied with the investment of her prize money, and fell to work



<P>with a cheery spirit, bent on earning more of those delightful checks.



<P>She did earn several that year, and began to feel herself a power



<P>in the house, for by the magic of a pen, her `rubbish' turned into



<P>comforts for them all.&nbsp; The Duke's Daughter paid the butcher's

bill,



<P>A Phantom Hand put down a new carpet, and the Curse of the Coventrys



<P>proved the blessing of the Marches in the way of groceries and gowns.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Wealth is certainly a most desirable thing, but poverty has its



<P>sunny side, and one of the sweet uses of adversity is the genuine



<P>satisfaction which comes from hearty work of head or hand, and to the



<P>inspiration of necessity, we owe half the wise, beautiful, and useful



<P>blessings of the world.&nbsp; Jo enjoyed a taste of this satisfaction,



<P>and ceased to envy richer girls, taking great comfort in the knowledge



<P>that she could supply her own wants, and need ask no one for a penny.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Little notice was taken of her stories, but they found a market,



<P>and encouraged by this fact, she resolved to make a bold stroke for



<P>fame and fortune.&nbsp; Having copied her novel for the fourth time,

read



<P>it to all her confidential friends, and submitted it with fear and



<P>trembling to three publishers, she at last disposed of it, on condition



<P>that she would cut it down one third, and omit all the parts



<P>which she particularly admired.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now I must either bundle it back in to my tin kitchen to mold,



<P>pay for printing it myself, or chop it up to suit purchasers and get



<P>what I can for it.&nbsp; Fame is a very good thing to have in the house,



<P>but cash is more convenient, so I wish to take the sense of the meeting



<P>on this important subject," said Jo, calling a family council.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't spoil your book, my girl, for there is more in it than



<P>you know, and the idea is well worked out.&nbsp; Let it wait and ripen,"



<P>was her father's advice, and he practiced what he preached, having



<P>waited patiently thirty years for fruit of his own to ripen, and



<P>being in no haste to gather it even now when it was sweet and mellow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It seems to me that Jo will profit more by taking the trial



<P>than by waiting," said Mrs. March.&nbsp; "Criticism is the best test

of



<P>such work, for it will show her both unsuspected merits and faults,



<P>and help her to do better next time.&nbsp; We are too partial, but the



<P>praise and blame of outsiders will prove useful, even if she gets



<P>but little money."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said Jo, knitting her brows, "that's just it.&nbsp; I've been



<P>fussing over the thing so long, I really don't know whether it's good,



<P>bad, or indifferent.&nbsp; It will be a great help to have cool, impartial



<P>persons take a look at it, and tell me what they think of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wouldn't leave a word out of it.&nbsp; You'll spoil it if you do,



<P>for the interest of the story is more in the minds than in the actions



<P>of the people, and it will be all a muddle if you don't explain as you



<P>go on," said Meg, who firmly believed that this book was the most



<P>remarkable novel ever written.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But Mr. Allen says, `Leave out the explanations, make it brief



<P>and dramatic, and let the characters tell the story'," interrupted



<P>Jo, turning to the publisher's note.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do as he tells you.&nbsp; He knows what will sale, and we don't.



<P>Make a good, popular book, and get as much money as you can.



<P>By-and-by, when you've got a name, you can afford to digress,



<P>and have philosophical and metaphysical people in your novels,"



<P>said Amy, who took a strictly practical view of the subject.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said Jo, laughing, "if my people are `philosophical and



<P>metaphysical', it isn't my fault, for I know nothing about such



<P>things, except what I hear father say;, sometimes.&nbsp; If I've got

some



<P>of his wise ideas jumbled up with my romance, so much the better for



<P>me.&nbsp; Now, Beth, what do you say?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should so like to see it printed soon," was all Beth said,



<P>and smiled in saying it.&nbsp; But there was an unconscious emphasis

on



<P>the last word, and a wistful look in the eyes that never lost their



<P>childlike candor, which chilled Jo's heart for a minute with a



<P>forboding fear, and decided her to make her little venture `soon'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So, with Spartan firmness, the young authoress laid her first-born



<P>on her table, and chopped it up as ruthlessly as any ogre.&nbsp; In

the hope



<P>of pleasing everyone, she took everyone's advice, and like the old man



<P>and his donkey in the fable suited nobody.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her father liked the metaphysical streak which had unconsciously



<P>got into it, so that was allowed to remain though she had her



<P>doubts about it.&nbsp; Her mother thought that there was a trifle too

much



<P>description.&nbsp; Out, therefore it came, and with it many necessary



<P>links in the story.&nbsp; Meg admired the tragedy, so Jo piled up the



<P>agony to suit her, while Amy objected to the fun, and, with the



<P>best intentions in life, Jo quenched the spritly scenes which



<P>relieved the somber character of the story.&nbsp; Then, to complicate



<P>the ruin, she cut it down one third, and confidingly sent the



<P>poor little romance, like a picked robin, out into the big, busy



<P>world to try its fate.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Well, it was printed, and she got three hundred dollars for



<P>it, likewise plenty of praise and blame, both so much greater than



<P>she expected that she was thrown into a state of bewilderment from



<P>which it took her some time to recover.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You said, Mother, that criticism would help me.&nbsp; But how can



<P>it, when it's so contradictory that I don't know whether I've written



<P>a promising book or broken all the ten commandments?" cried poor



<P>Jo, turning over a heap of notices, the perusal of which filled her



<P>with pride and joy one minute, wrath and dismay the next.&nbsp; "This



<P>man says, `An exquisite book, full of truth, beauty, and earnestness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All is sweet, pure, and healthy.'" continued the perplexed



<P>authoress.&nbsp; "The next, `The theory of the book is bad, full of



<P>morbid fancies, spiritualistic ideas, and unnatural characters.'



<P>Now, as I had no theory of any kind, don't believe in Spiritualism,



<P>and copied my characters from life, I don't see how this critic can



<P>be right.&nbsp; Another says, `It's one of the best American novels

which



<P>has appeared for years.' (I know better than that), and the next



<P>asserts that `Though it is original, and written with great force



<P>and feeling, it is a dangerous book.' 'Tisn't!&nbsp; Some make fun of

it,



<P>some overpraise, and nearly all insist that I had a deep theory to



<P>expound, when I only wrote it for the pleasure and the money.&nbsp;

I



<P>wish I'd printed the whole or not at all, for I do hate to be so



<P>misjudged."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her family and friends administered comfort and commendation



<P>liberally.&nbsp; Yet it was a hard time for sensitive, high-spirited

Jo,



<P>who meant so well and had apparently done so ill.&nbsp; But it did her



<P>good, for those whose opinion had real value gave her the critism



<P>which is an author's best education, and when the first soreness



<P>was over, she could laugh at her poor little book, yet believe in



<P>it still, and feel herself the wiser and stronger for the buffeting



<P>she had received.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not being a genius, like Keats, it won't kill me," she said



<P>stoutly, "and I've got the joke on my side, after all, for the parts



<P>that were taken straight out of real life are denounced as impossible



<P>and absurd, and the scenes that I made up out of my own silly head



<P>are pronounced `charmingly natural, tender, and true'.&nbsp; So I'll



<P>comfort myself with that, and when I'm ready, I'll up again and take



<P>another."



<P>
