   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 33</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER THIRTY-THREE</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>New York, November

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dear Marmee and Beth,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I'm going to write you a regular volume, for I've got heaps



<P>to tell, though I'm not a fine young lady traveling on the continent.



<P>When I lost sight of Father's dear old face, I felt a



<P>trifle blue, and might have shed a briny drop or two, if an



<P>Irish lady with four small children, all crying more or less,



<P>hadn't diverted my mind, for I amused myself by dropping gingerbread



<P>nuts over the seat every time they opened their mouths to roar.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Soon the sun came out, and taking it as a good omen, I



<P>cleared up likewise and enjoyed my journey with all my heart.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Kirke welcomed me so kindly I felt at home at once,



<P>even in that big house full of strangers.&nbsp; She gave me a funny



<P>little sky parlor--all she had, but there is a stove in it, and a



<P>nice table in a sunny window, so I can sit here and write whenever



<P>I like.&nbsp; A fine view and a church tower opposite atone for



<P>the many stairs, and I took a fancy to my den on the spot.



<P>The nursery, where I am to teach and sew, is a pleasant room next



<P>Mrs. Kirke's private parlor, and the two little girls are pretty



<P>children, rather spoiled, I fancy, but they took to me after



<P>telling them The Seven Bad Pigs, and I've no doubt I shall make



<P>a model governess.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I am to have my meals with the children, if I prefer it to



<P>the great table, and for the present I do, for I am bashful,



<P>though no one will believe it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, my dear, make yourself at home," said Mrs. K.&nbsp; in her



<P>motherly way, "I'm on the drive from morning to night, as you



<P>may suppose with such a family, but a great anxiety will be off



<P>my mind if I know the children are safe with you.&nbsp; My rooms are



<P>always open to you, and your own shall be as comfortable as I



<P>can make it.&nbsp; There are some pleasant people in the house if you



<P>feel sociable, and your evenings are always free.&nbsp; Come to me



<P>if anything goes wrong, and be as happy as you can.&nbsp; There's the



<P>tea bell, I must run and change my cap."&nbsp; And off she bustled,



<P>leaving me to settle myself in my new nest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As I went downstairs soon after, I saw something I liked.



<P>The flights are very long in this tall house, and as I stood



<P>waiting at the head of the third one for a little servant girl



<P>to lumber up, I saw a gentleman come along behind her, take the



<P>heavy hod of coal out of her hand, carry it all the way up, put



<P>it down at a door near by, and walk away, saying, with a kind



<P>nod and a foreign accent, "It goes better so.&nbsp; The little back



<P>is too young to haf such heaviness."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Wasn't it good of him?&nbsp; I like such things, for as Father



<P>says, trifles show character.&nbsp; When I mentioned it to Mrs. K.,



<P>that evening, she laughed, and said, "That must have been



<P>Professor Bhaer, he's always doing things of that sort."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. K.&nbsp; told me he was from Berlin, very learned and good,



<P>but poor as a church mouse, and gives lessons to support himself



<P>and two little orphan nephews whom he is educating here, according



<P>to the wishes of his sister, who married an American.&nbsp; Not



<P>a very romantic story, but it interested me, and I was glad to



<P>hear that Mrs. K.&nbsp; lends him her parlor for some of his scholars.



<P>There is a glass door between it and the nursery, and I mean to



<P>peep at him, and then I'll tell you how he looks.&nbsp; He's almost



<P>forty, so it's no harm, Marmee.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After tea and a go-to-bed romp with the little girls, I



<P>attacked the big workbasket, and had a quiet evening chatting



<P>with my new friend.&nbsp; I shall keep a journal-letter, and send it



<P>once a week, so goodnight, and more tomorrow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tuesday Eve

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Had a lively time in my seminary this morning, for the



<P>children acted like Sancho, and at one time I really thought I



<P>should shake them all round.&nbsp; Some good angel inspired me to



<P>try gymnastics, and I kept it up till they were glad to sit down



<P>and keep still.&nbsp; After luncheon, the girl took them out for a



<P>walk, and I went to my needlework like little Mabel `with a



<P>willing mind'.&nbsp; I was thanking my stars that I'd learned to



<P>make nice buttonholes, when the parlor door opened and shut,



<P>and someone began to hum, Kennst Du Das Land, like a big bumblebee.



<P>It was dreadfully improper, I know, but I couldn't



<P>resist the temptation, and lifting one end of the curtain



<P>before the glass door, I peeped in.&nbsp; Professor Bhaer was there,



<P>and while he arranged his books, I took a good look at him.&nbsp; A



<P>regular German--rather stout, with brown hair tumbled all over



<P>his head, a bushy beard, good nose, the kindest eyes I ever



<P>saw, and a splendid big voice that does one's ears good, after



<P>our sharp or slipshod American gabble.&nbsp; His clothes were rusty,



<P>his hands were large, and he hadn't a really handsome feature



<P>in his face, except his beautiful teeth, yet I liked him, for



<P>he had a fine head, his linen was very nice, and he looked



<P>like a gentleman, though two buttons were off his coat and



<P>there was a patch on one shoe.&nbsp; He looked sober in spite of



<P>his humming, till he went to the window to turn the hyacinth



<P>bulbs toward the sun, and stroke the cat, who received him



<P>like an old friend.&nbsp; Then he smiled, and when a tap came at



<P>the door, called out in a loud, brisk tone, "Herein!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I was just going to run, when I caught sight of a morsel of



<P>a child carrying a big book, and stopped, to see what was going



<P>on.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me wants me Bhaer," said the mite, slamming down her book



<P>and running to meet him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thou shalt haf thy Bhaer.&nbsp; Come, then, and take a goot



<P>hug from him, my Tina," said the Professor, catching her up



<P>with a laugh, and holding her so high over his head that she



<P>had to stoop her little face to kiss him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now me mus tuddy my lessin," went on the funny little



<P>thing.&nbsp; So he put her up at the table, opened the great dictionary



<P>she had brought, and gave her a paper and pencil, and



<P>she scribbled away, turning a leaf now and then, and passing



<P>her little fat finger down the page, as if finding a word,



<P>so soberly that I nearly betrayed myself by a laugh, while



<P>Mr. Bhaer stood stroking her pretty hair with a fatherly look



<P>that made me think she must be his own, though she looked more



<P>French than German.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Another knock and the appearance of two young ladies sent



<P>me back to my work, and there I virtuously remained through all



<P>the noise and gabbling that went on next door.&nbsp; One of the girls



<P>kept laughing affectedly, and saying, "Now Professor," in a



<P>coquettish tone, and the other pronounced her German with an



<P>accent that must have made it hard for him to keep sober.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Both seemed to try his patience sorely, for more than once



<P>I heard him say emphatically, "No, no, it is not so, you haf



<P>not attend to what I say," and once there was a loud rap, as



<P>if he struck the table with his book, followed by the despairing



<P>exclamation, "Prut!&nbsp; It all goes bad this day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor man, I pitied him, and when the girls were gone, took



<P>just one more peep to see if he survived it.&nbsp; He seemed to have



<P>thrown himself back in his chair, tired out, and sat there with



<P>his eyes shut till the clock struck two, when he jumped up, put



<P>his books in his pocket, as if ready for another lesson, and



<P>taking little Tina who had fallen asleep on the sofa in his



<P>arms, he carried her quietly away.&nbsp; I fancy he has a hard life



<P>of it.&nbsp; Mrs. Kirke asked me if I wouldn't go down to the five



<P>o'clock dinner, and feeling a little bit homesick, I thought



<P>I would, just to see what sort of people are under the same



<P>roof with me.&nbsp; So I made myself respectable and tried to slip



<P>in behind Mrs. Kirke, but as she is short and I'm tall, my



<P>efforts at concealment were rather a failure.&nbsp; She gave me a



<P>seat by her, and after my face cooled off, I plucked up courage



<P>and looked about me.&nbsp; The long table was full, and every--



<P>one intent on getting their dinner, the gentlemen especially,



<P>who seemed to be eating on time, for they bolted in every



<P>sense of the word, vanishing as soon as they were done.&nbsp; There



<P>was the usual assortment of young men absorbed in themselves,



<P>young couples absorbed in each other, married ladies in their



<P>babies, and old gentlemen in politics.&nbsp; I don't think I shall



<P>care to have much to do with any of them, except one sweetfaced



<P>maiden lady, who looks as if she had something in her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Cast away at the very bottom of the table was the Professor,



<P>shouting answers to the questions of a very inquisitive,



<P>deaf old gentleman on one side, and talking philosophy with



<P>a Frenchman on the other.&nbsp; If Amy had been here, she'd have



<P>turned her back on him forever because, sad to relate, he had



<P>a great appetite, and shoveled in his dinner in a manner which



<P>would have horrified `her ladyship'.&nbsp; I didn't mind, for I like



<P>`to see folks eat with a relish', as Hannah says, and the poor



<P>man must have needed a deal of food after teaching idiots all day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As I went upstairs after dinner, two of the young men



<P>were settling their hats before the hall mirror, and I heard



<P>one say low to the other, "Who's the new party?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Governess, or something of that sort."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What the deuce is she at our table for?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Friend of the old lady's."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Handsome head, but no style."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a bit of it.&nbsp; Give us a light and come on."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I felt angry at first, and then I didn't care, for a governess



<P>is as good as a clerk, and I've got sense, if I haven't



<P>style, which is more than some people have, judging from the



<P>remarks of the elegant beings who clattered away, smoking like



<P>bad chimneys.&nbsp; I hate ordinary people!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Thursday

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Yesterday was a quiet day spent in teaching, sewing, and



<P>writing in my little room, which is very cozy, with a light and



<P>fire.&nbsp; I picked up a few bits of news and was introduced to the



<P>Professor.&nbsp; It seems that Tina is the child of the Frenchwoman



<P>who does the fine ironing in the laundry here.&nbsp; The little thing



<P>has lost her heart to Mr. Bhaer, and follows him about the house



<P>like a dog whenever he is at home, which delights him, as he is



<P>very fond of children, though a `bacheldore'.&nbsp; Kitty and Minnie



<P>Kirk likewise regard him with affection, and tell all sorts of



<P>stories about the plays he invents, the presents he brings, and



<P>the splendid tales he tells.&nbsp; The younger men quiz him, it seems,



<P>call him Old Fritz, Lager Beer, Ursa Major, and make all manner



<P>of jokes on his name.&nbsp; But he enjoys it like a boy, Mrs. Kirke



<P>says, and takes it so good-naturedly that they all like him in



<P>spite of his foreign ways.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The maiden lady is a Miss Norton, rich, cultivated, and



<P>kind.&nbsp; She spoke to me at dinner today (for I went to table



<P>again, it's such fun to watch people), and asked me to come



<P>and see her at her room.&nbsp; She has fine books and pictures,



<P>knows interesting persons, and seems friendly, so I shall make



<P>myself agreeable, for I do want to get into good society, only



<P>it isn't the same sort that Amy likes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I was in our parlor last evening when Mr. Bhaer came in



<P>with some newspapers for Mrs. Kirke.&nbsp; She wasn't there, but



<P>Minnie, who is a little old woman, introduced me very prettily.



<P>"This is Mamma's friend, Miss March."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, and she's jolly and we like her lots," added Kitty,



<P>who is and `enfant terrible'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>We both bowed, and then we laughed, for the prim introduction



<P>and the blunt addition were rather a comical contrast.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah, yes, I hear these naughty ones go to vex you, Mees



<P>Marsch.&nbsp; If so again, call at me and I come," he said, with a



<P>threatening frown that delighted the little wretches.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I promised I would, and he departed, but it seems as if I



<P>was doomed to see a good deal of him, for today as I passed



<P>his door on my way out, by accident I knocked against it with



<P>my umbrella.&nbsp; It flew open, and there he stood in his dressing



<P>gown, with a big blue sock on one hand and a darning needle



<P>in the other.&nbsp; He didn't seem at all ashamed of it, for when



<P>I explained and hurried on, he waved his hand, sock and all,



<P>saying in his loud, cheerful way...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You haf a fine day to make your walk.&nbsp; Bon voyage, Mademoiselle."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I laughed all the way downstairs, but it was a little pathetic,



<P>also to think of the poor man having to mend his own clothes.



<P>The German gentlemen embroider, I know, but darning hose is



<P>another thing and not so pretty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nothing has happened to write about, except a call on Miss



<P>Norton, who has a room full of pretty things, and who was very



<P>charming, for she showed me all her treasures, and asked me if



<P>I would sometimes go with her to lectures and concerts, as her



<P>escort, if I enjoyed them.&nbsp; She put it as a favor, but I'm sure



<P>Mrs. Kirke has told her about us, and she does it out of kindness



<P>to me.&nbsp; I'm as proud as Lucifer, but such favors from such



<P>people don't burden me, and I accepted gratefully.



<P>When I got back to the nursery there was such an uproar



<P>in the parlor that I looked in, and there was Mr. Bhaer down



<P>on his hands and knees, with Tina on his back, Kitty leading



<P>him with a jump rope, and Minnie feeding two small boys with



<P>seedcakes, as they roared and ramped in cages built of chairs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We are playing nargerie," explained Kitty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dis is mine effalunt!" added Tina, holding on by the



<P>Professor's hair.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mamma always allows us to do what we like Saturday afternoon,



<P>when Franz and Emil come, doesn't she, Mr. Bhaer?"



<P>said Minnie.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The `effalunt' sat up, looking as much in earnest as any



<P>of them, and said soberly to me, "I gif you my wort it is so,



<P>if we make too large a noise you shall say Hush! to us, and we



<P>go more softly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I promised to do so, but left the door open and enjoyed the



<P>fun as much as they did, for a more glorious frolic I never



<P>witnessed.&nbsp; They played tag and soldiers, danced and sang,



<P>and when it began to grow dark they all piled onto the sofa about



<P>the Professor, while he told charming fairy stories of the storks



<P>on the chimney tops, and the little `koblods', who ride the



<P>snowflakes as they fall.&nbsp; I wish Americans were as simple and



<P>natural as Germans, don't you?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I'm so fond of writing, I should go spinning on forever if



<P>motives of economy didn't stop me, for though I've used thin



<P>paper and written fine, I tremble to think of the stamps this



<P>long letter will need.&nbsp; Pray forward Amy's as soon as you can



<P>spare them.&nbsp; My small news will sound very flat after her



<P>splendors, but you will like them, I know.&nbsp; Is Teddy studying



<P>so hard that he can't find time to write to his friends?&nbsp; Take



<P>good care of him for me, Beth, and tell me all about the babies,



<P>and give heaps of love to everyone.&nbsp; From your faithful Jo.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>P.S.&nbsp; On reading over my letter, it strikes me as rather



<P>Bhaery, but I am always interested in odd people, and I really



<P>had nothing else to write about.&nbsp; Bless you!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>DECEMBER

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>My Precious Betsey,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As this is to be a scribble-scrabble letter, I direct it to



<P>you, for it may amuse you, and give you some idea of my goings



<P>on, for though quiet, they are rather amusing, for which, oh,



<P>be joyful!&nbsp; After what Amy would call Herculaneum efforts, in



<P>the way of mental and moral agriculture, my young ideas begin



<P>to shoot and my little twigs to bend as I could wish.&nbsp; They are



<P>not so interesting tome as Tina and the boys, but I do my duty



<P>by them, and they are fond of me.&nbsp; Franz and Emil are jolly



<P>little lads, quite after my own heart, for the mixture of



<P>German and American spirit in the produces a constant state of



<P>effervescence.&nbsp; Saturday afternoons are riotous times, whether



<P>spent in the house or out, for on pleasant days they all go to



<P>walk, like a seminary, with the Professor and myself to keep



<P>order, and then such fun!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>We are very good friends now, and I've begun to take



<P>lessons.&nbsp; I really couldn't help it, and it all came about in



<P>such a droll way that I must tell you.&nbsp; To begin at the beginning,



<P>Mrs. Kirke called to me one day as I passed Mr. Bhaer's room



<P>where she was rummaging.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did you ever see such a den, my dear?&nbsp; Just come and



<P>help me put these books to rights, for I've turned everything



<P>upside down, trying to discover what he has done with the six



<P>new handkerchiefs I gave him not long ago."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I went in, and while we worked I looked about me, for it



<P>was `a den' to be sure.&nbsp; Books and papers everywhere, a broken



<P>meerschaum, and an old flute over the mantlepiece as if done



<P>with, a ragged bird without any tail chirped on one window



<P>seat, and a box of white mice adorned the other.&nbsp; Half-finished



<P>boats and bits of string lay among the manuscripts.&nbsp; Dirty



<P>little boots stood drying before the fire, and traces of the



<P>dearly beloved boys, for whom he makes a slave of himself,



<P>were to be seen all over the room.&nbsp; After a grand rummage



<P>three of the missing articles were found, one over the bird



<P>cage, one covered with ink, and a third burned brown, having



<P>been used as a holder.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such a man!" laughed good-natured Mrs. K., as she put the



<P>relics in the rag bay.&nbsp; "I suppose the others are torn up to



<P>rig ships, bandage cut fingers, or make kite tails.&nbsp; It's dreadful,



<P>but I can't scold him.&nbsp; He's so absent-minded and goodnatured,



<P>he lets those boys ride over him roughshod.&nbsp; I agreed to do



<P>his washing and mending, but he forgets to give out his things



<P>and I forget to look them over, so he comes to a sad pass sometimes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let me mend them," said I.&nbsp; "I don't mind it, and he needn't



<P>know.&nbsp; I'd like to, he's so kind to me about bringing my letters



<P>and lending books."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So I have got his things in order, and knit heels into two



<P>pairs of the socks, for they were boggled out of shape with his



<P>queer darns.&nbsp; Nothing was said, and I hoped he wouldn't find it



<P>out, but one day last week he caught me at it.&nbsp; Hearing the



<P>lessons he gives to others has interested and amused me so much



<P>that I took a fancy to lear, for Tina runs in and out, leaving



<P>the door open, and I can hear.&nbsp; I had been sitting near this



<P>door, finishing off the last sock, and trying to understand what



<P>he said to a new scholar, who is as stupid as I am.&nbsp; The girl



<P>had gone, and I thought he had also, it was so still, and I was



<P>busily gabbling over a verb, and rocking to and fro in a most



<P>absurd way, when a little crow made me look up, and there was



<P>Mr. Bhaer looking and laughing quietly, while he made signs to



<P>Tina not to betray him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So!" he said, as I stopped and stared like a goose, "you



<P>peep at me, I peep at you, and this is not bad, but see, I am



<P>not pleasanting when I say, haf you a wish for German?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, but you are too busy.&nbsp; I am too stupid to learn," I



<P>blundered out, as red as a peony.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Prut!&nbsp; We will make the time, and we fail not to find the



<P>sense.&nbsp; At efening I shall gif a little lesson with much gladness,



<P>for look you, Mees Marsch, I haf this debt to pay."&nbsp; And



<P>he pointed to my work `Yes, ' they say to one another, these so



<P>kind ladies, `he is a stupid old fellow, he will see not what we



<P>do, he will never observe that his sock heels go not in holes



<P>any more, he will think his buttons grow out new when they fall,



<P>and believe that strings make theirselves.' "Ah!&nbsp; But I haf an



<P>eye, and I see much.&nbsp; I haf a heart, and I feel thanks for this.



<P>Come, a little lesson then and now, or no more good fairy works



<P>for me and mine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Of course I couldn't say anything after that, and as it



<P>really is a splendid opportunity, I made the bargain, and we



<P>began.&nbsp; I took four lessons, and then I stuck fast in a grammatical



<P>bog.&nbsp; The Professor was very patient with me, but it must



<P>have been torment to him, and now and then he'd look at me



<P>with such an expression of mild despair that it was a toss-up



<P>with me whether to laugh or cry.&nbsp; I tried both ways, and when



<P>it came to a sniff or utter mortification and woe, he just



<P>threw the grammar on to the floor and marched out of the room.



<P>I felt myself disgraced and deserted forever, but didn't blame



<P>him a particle, and was scrambling my papers together, meaning



<P>to rush upstairs and shake myself hard, when in he came, as



<P>brisk and beaming as if I'd covered myself in glory.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now we shall try a new way.&nbsp; You and I will read these



<P>pleasant little MARCHEN together, and dig no more in that dry



<P>book, that goes in the corner for making us trouble."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He spoke so kindly, and opened Hans Andersons's fairy



<P>tales so invitingly before me, that I was more ashamed than



<P>ever, and went at my lesson in a neck-or-nothing style that



<P>seemed to amuse him immensely.&nbsp; I forgot my bashfulness, and



<P>pegged away (no other word will express it) with all my might,



<P>tumbling over long words, pronouncing according to inspiration



<P>of the minute, and doing my very best.&nbsp; When I finished reading



<P>my first page, and stopped for breath, he clapped his hands and



<P>cried out in his hearty way, "Das ist gut!' Now we go well!&nbsp; My



<P>turn.&nbsp; I do him in German, gif me your ear."&nbsp; And away he

went,



<P>rumbling out the words with his strong voice and a relish which



<P>was good to see as well as hear.&nbsp; Fortunately the story was the



<P>CONSTANT TIN SOLDIER, which is droll, you know, so I could laugh,



<P>and I did, though I didn't understand half he read, for I couldn't



<P>help it, he was so earnest, I so excited, and the whole thing so



<P>comical.



<P>After that we got on better, and now I read my lessons



<P>pretty well, for this way of studying suits me, and I can see



<P>that the grammar gets tucked into the tales and poetry as one



<P>gives pills in jelly.&nbsp; I like it very much, and he doesn't seem



<P>tired of it yet, which is very good of him, isn't it?&nbsp; I mean



<P>to give him something on Christmas, for I dare not offer money.



<P>Tell me something nice, Marmee.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I'm glad Laurie seems so happy and busy, that he has given



<P>up smoking and lets his hair grow.&nbsp; You see Beth manages him



<P>better than I did.&nbsp; I'm not jealous, dear, do your best, only



<P>don't make a saint of him.&nbsp; I'm afraid I couldn't like him



<P>without a spice of human naughtiness.&nbsp; Read him bits of my



<P>letters.&nbsp; I haven't time to write much, and that will do just



<P>as well.&nbsp; Thank Heaven Beth continues so comfortable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>JANUARY

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A Happy New Year to you all, my dearest family, which of



<P>course includes Mr. L.&nbsp; and a young man by the name of Teddy.



<P>I can't tell you how much I enjoyed your Christmas bundle,



<P>for i didn't get it till night and had given up hoping.&nbsp; Your



<P>letter came in the morning, but you said nothing about a



<P>parcel, meaning it for a surprise, so I was disappointed,



<P>for I'd had a `kind of feeling' that you wouldn't forget me.



<P>I felt a little low in my mind as I sat up in my room after



<P>tea, and when the big, muddy, battered-looking bundle was



<P>brought to me, I just hugged it and pranced.&nbsp; It was so



<P>homey and refreshing that I sat down on the floor and read



<P>and looked and ate and laughed and cried, in my usual absurd



<P>way.&nbsp; The things were just what I wanted, and all the better



<P>for being made instead of bought.&nbsp; Beth's new `ink bib' was



<P>capital, and Hannah's box of hard gingerbread will be a



<P>treasure.&nbsp; I'll be sure and wear the nice flannels you sent,



<P>Marmee, and read carefully the books Father has marked.&nbsp; Thank



<P>you all, heaps and heaps!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Speaking of books reminds me that I'm getting rich in that



<P>line, for on New Year's Day Mr. Bhaer gave me a fine Shakespeare.



<P>It is one he values much, and I've often admired it,



<P>set up in the place of honor with his German Bible, Plato,



<P>Homer, and Milton, so you may imagine how I felt when he brought



<P>it down, without its cover, and showed me my own name in it,



<P>"from my friend Friedrich Bhaer".

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You say often you wish a library.&nbsp; Here I gif you one, for



<P>between these lids (he meant covers) is many books in one.&nbsp; Read



<P>him well, and he will help you much, for the study of character



<P>in this book will help you to read it in the world and paint it



<P>with your pen."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I thanked him as well as I could, and talk now about `my



<P>library', as if I had a hundred books.&nbsp; I never knew how much



<P>there was in Shakespeare before, but then I never had a Bhaer



<P>to explain it to me.&nbsp; Now don't laugh at his horrid name.&nbsp;

It



<P>isn't pronounced either Bear or Beer, as people will say it,



<P>but something between the two, as only Germans can give it.



<P>I'm glad you both like what I tell you about him, and hope you



<P>will know him some day.&nbsp; Mother would admire his warm heart,



<P>Father his wise head.&nbsp; I admire both, and feel rich in my new



<P>`friend Friedrich Bhaer'.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Not having much money, or knowing what he'd like, I got



<P>several little things, and put them about the room, where he



<P>would find them unexpectedly.&nbsp; They were useful, pretty, or



<P>funny, a new standish on his table, a little vase for his



<P>flower, he always has one, or a bit of green in a glass, to



<P>keep him fresh, he says, and a holder for his blower, so



<P>that he needn't burn up what Amy calls `mouchoirs'.&nbsp; I made



<P>it like those Beth invented, a big butterfly with a fat body,



<P>and black and yellow wings, worsted feelers, and bead eyes.



<P>It took his fancy immensely, and he put it on his mantlepiece



<P>as an article of virtue, so it was rather a failure after all.



<P>Poor as he is, he didn't forget a servant or a child in the



<P>house, and not a soul here, from the French laundrywoman to



<P>Miss Norton forgot him.&nbsp; I was so glad of that.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They got up a masquerade, and had a gay time New Year's



<P>Eve.&nbsp; I didn't mean to go down, having no dress.&nbsp; But at the



<P>last minute, Mrs. Kirke remembered some old brocades, and Miss



<P>Norton lent me lace and feathers.&nbsp; So I dressed up as Mrs.



<P>Malaprop, and sailed in with a mask on.&nbsp; No one knew me, for I



<P>disguised my voice, and no one dreamed of the silent, haughty



<P>Miss March (for they think I am very stiff and cool, most of



<P>them, and so I am to whippersnappers) could dance and dress,



<P>and burst out into a `nice derangement of epitaphs, like an



<P>allegory on the banks of the Nile'.&nbsp; I enjoyed it very much,



<P>and when we unmasked it was fun to see them stare at me.&nbsp; I



<P>heard one of the young men tell another that he knew I'd been



<P>an actress, in fact, he thought he remembered seeing me at



<P>one of the minor theaters.&nbsp; Meg will relish that joke.&nbsp; Mr.



<P>Bhaer was Nick Bottom, and Tina was Titania, a perfect little



<P>fairy in his arms.&nbsp; To see them dance was `quite a landscape',



<P>to use a Teddyism.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I had a very happy New Year, after all, and when I thought



<P>it over in my room, I felt as if I was getting on a little in



<P>spite of my many failures, for I'm cheerful all the time now,



<P>work with a will, and take more interest in other people than



<P>I used to, which is satisfactory.&nbsp; Bless you all!&nbsp; Ever your



<P>loving...&nbsp; Jo



<P>
